*Therefore, you should probably have about 60 meg to load them.*

and Caveat emptor!!

suggestions, corrections, emendations, and new words.  help.out

Midnight, Central Time, of the last day of the stated month.  A
preliminary version may often be posted for suggestion, comment
and editing by those who wish to do so.  To be sure you have an

in the first week of the next month.  Since our ftp program has
a bug in it that scrambles the date [tried to fix and failed] a
look at the file size will have to do, but we will try to see a
new copy has at least one byte more or less.


Information about Project Gutenberg (one page)

We produce about two million dollars for each hour we work.  The
fifty hours is one conservative estimate for how long it we take
to get any etext selected, entered, proofread, edited, copyright
searched and analyzed, the copyright letters written, etc.  This
projected audience is one hundred million readers.  If our value
per text is nominally estimated at one dollar, then we produce 2
million dollars per hour this year we, will have to do four text
files per month:  thus upping our productivity from one million.
The Goal of Project Gutenberg is to Give Away One Trillion Etext
Files by the December 31, 2001.  [10,000 x 100,000,000=Trillion]
This is ten thousand titles each to one hundred million readers,
which is 10% of the expected number of computer users by the end
of the year 2001.

We need your donations more than ever!

All donations should be made to "Project Gutenberg/IBC", and are
tax deductible to the extent allowable by law ("IBC" is Illinois
Benedictine College).  (Subscriptions to our paper newsletter go
to IBC, too)

<centered><point26>P.</point26></centered>

<hw>P</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <def>the sixteenth letter of the English
alphabet, is a nonvocal consonant whose form and value come from
the Latin, into which language the letter was brought, through
the ancient Greek, from the Ph\'d2nician, its probable origin
being Egyptain. Etymologically P is most closely related to
<it>b</it>, <it>f</it>, and <it>v</it>; as ho<xex>bb</xex>le,
ho<xex>pp</xex>le; <xex>f</xex>ather, <xex>p</xex>aternal;
reci<xex>p</xex>ient, recei<xex>v</xex>e. See <er>B</er>,
<er>F</er>, and <er>M</er>.</def>

See <xex>Guide to Pronunciation</xex>, <sect/<sect/ 247, 248, and
184-195.

<hw>Pa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A shortened form of
<er>Papa</er>.</def>

<hw>Pa"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>paage</ets>, <ets>paiage</ets>, F. <ets>p\'82age</ets>, fr.
(assumed) LL. <ets>pedaticum</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pes</ets>,
<ets>pedis</ets>, foot. See <er>Pedage</er>,
<er>Pedal</er>.]</ety> <fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld> <def>A toll for
passage over another person's grounds.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>peage</asp> and <asp>pedage</asp>.]</altsp>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>\'d8Paard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D., a
horse.]</ety> <def>The zebra.</def> <mark>[S. Africa]</mark>

<hw>Paas</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Pace</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer</au>

<hw>Paas</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D.
<ets>paash</ets>. See <er>Pasch</er>.]</ety> <def>The Easter
festival.</def> <mark>[Local, U. S.]</mark>

<au>Bartlett.</au>

<cs><col>Paas egg</col>. <cd>See <cref>Easter egg</cref>, under
<er>Easter</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pab"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pabularis</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of, pertaining to, or fit for,
pabulum or food; affording food.</def>

<hw>Pab`u*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pabulatio</ets>, fr. <ets>pabulari</ets> to feed, fr.
<ets>pabulum</ets> food. See <er>Pabulum</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of feeding, or providing food.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Cockeram.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Food; fodder; pabulum.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pab"u*lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pabulosus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Affording pabulum, or food;
alimental.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pab"u*lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., akin to
<ets>pascere</ets> to pasture. See <er>Pastor</er>.]</ety>
<def>The means of nutriment to animals or plants; food;
nourishment; hence, that which feeds or sustains, as fuel for a
fire; that upon which the mind or soul is nourished; <as>as,
intellectual <ex>pabulum</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pac</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of moccasin,
having the edges of the sole turned up and sewed to the
upper.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<hw>Pa"ca</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pg., from the
native name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small South
American rodent (<spn>C\'d2logenys paca</spn>), having blackish
brown fur, with four parallel rows of white spots along its
sides; the spotted cavy. It is nearly allied to the agouti and
the Guinea pig.</def>

<hw>Pa"ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pacare</ets> to pacify.]</ety> <def>Placable.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pa*cane"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A species of hickory. See <er>Pecan</er>.</def>

<hw>Pa"cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pacatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>pacare</ets> to pacify, fr.

requite, <er>Peace</er>.]</ety> <def>Appeased; pacified;
tranquil.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pa"ca*ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pacified;
pacate.</def>

<hw>Pa*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pacatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of pacifying; a
peacemaking.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pas</ets>, F. <ets>pas</ets>, from L. <ets>passus</ets> a
step, pace, orig., a stretching out of the feet in walking; cf.
<ets>pandere</ets>, <ets>passum</ets>, to spread, stretch; perh.
akin to E. <ets>patent</ets>. Cf. <er>Pas</er>,
<er>Pass</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A single movement from one
foot to the other in walking; a step.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The length of a step in walking or marching,
reckoned from the heel of one foot to the heel of the other; --
used as a unit in measuring distances; <as>as, he advanced fifty
<ex>paces</ex></as>.</def> \'bdThe heigh of sixty <xex>pace</xex>
.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<note><hand/ Ordinarily the <xex>pace</xex> is estimated at two
and one half linear feet; but in measuring distances be stepping,
the <xex>pace</xex> is extended to three feet (one yard) or to
three and three tenths feet (one fifth of a rod). The regulation
marching <xex>pace</xex> in the English and United States armies
is thirty inches for quick time, and thirty-six inches for double
time. The Roman <xex>pace</xex> (<xex>passus</xex>) was from the
heel of one foot to the heel of the same foot when it next
touched the ground, five Roman feet.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Manner of stepping or moving; gait; walk;
<as>as, the walk, trot, canter, gallop, and amble are
<ex>paces</ex> of the horse; a swaggering <ex>pace</ex>; a quick
<ex>pace</ex>.</as></def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow,
Creeps in this petty <qex>pace</qex> from day to day.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>In the military schools of riding a variety of <ex>paces</ex>
are taught.</q>
<qau>Walsh.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A slow gait; a footpace.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chucer.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Specifically, a kind of fast amble; a
rack.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Any single movement, step, or procedure.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The first <qex>pace</qex> necessary for his majesty to make is
to fall into confidence with Spain.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A broad step or platform; any
part of a floor slightly raised above the rest, as around an
altar, or at the upper end of a hall.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Weaving)</fld> <def>A device in a loom, to
maintain tension on the warp in pacing the web.</def>

<cs><col>Geometrical pace</col>, <cd>the space from heel to heel
between the spot where one foot is set down and that where the
same foot is again set down, loosely estimated at five feet, or
by some at four feet and two fifths. See <cref>Roman pace</cref>
in the Note under def. 2.</cd> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> --
<mcol><col>To keep</col>, <or/ <col>hold</col>, <col>pace
with</col></mcol>, <cd>to keep up with; to go as fast as.</cd>
\'bdIn intellect and attainments he <xex>kept pace with<xex> his
age.\'b8
<au>Southey.</au>
</cs>

<hw>Pace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Paced</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pacing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To go; to walk;
specifically, to move with regular or measured steps.</def> \'bdI
<xex>paced</xex> on slowly.\'b8 <au>Pope</au>. \'bdWith speed so
<xex>pace</xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To proceed; to pass on.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Or [ere] that I further in this tale <qex>pace</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To move quickly by lifting the legs on the same
side together, as a horse; to amble with rapidity; to rack.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To pass away; to die.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pace</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To walk over
with measured tread; to move slowly over or upon; <as>as, the
guard <ex>paces</ex> his round</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Pacing</xex>
light the velvet plain.\'b8

<au>T. Warton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To measure by steps or paces; <as>as, to
<ex>pace</ex> a piece of ground</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To develop, guide, or control the pace or paces
of; to teach the pace; to break in.</def>

<q>If you can, <qex>pace</qex> your wisdom
In that good path that I would wish it go.</q>
<qau>Shak</qau>

<cs><col>To pace the web</col> <fld>(Weaving)</fld>, <cd>to wind
up the cloth on the beam, periodically, as it is woven, in a
loom.</cd></cs>

<hw>Paced</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having, or
trained in, [such] a pace or gait; trained; -- used in
composition; <as>as, slow-<ex>paced</ex>; a
thorough-<ex>paced</ex> villain.</as></def>

<hw>Pa"cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or that
which, paces; especially, a horse that paces.</def>

<hw>Pa*cha"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<def>See <er>Pasha</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pa`cha*ca*mac"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
divinity worshiped by the ancient Peruvians as the creator of the
universe.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pa*chak"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The fragrant roots of the <spn>Saussurea
Costus</spn>, exported from India to China, and used for burning
as incense. It is supposed to be the <xex>costus</xex> of the
ancients.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>putchuck</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pa*cha"lic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a. & n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pashalic</er>.</def>

<mhw><hw>\'d8Pa*chi"si</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Par*che"si</hw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr></mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind., fr.
<ets>pachis</ets> twenty-five, the highest throw in the
game.]</ety> <def>A game, somewhat resembling backgammon,
originating in India.</def>

<hw>Pa*chom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
thickness + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics)</fld>
<def>An instrument for measuring thickness, as of the glass of a
mirror, or of paper; a pachymeter.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pa*chon"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A substance resembling gutta-percha, and
used to adulterate it, obtained from the East Indian tree
<spn>Isonandra acuminata</spn>.</def>

<hw>Pach"y-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Gr. <?/ thick.]</ety> <def>A
combining form meaning <xex>thick</xex>; <as>as,
<ex>pachy</ex>derm, <ex>pachy</ex>dactyl</as>.</def>

<hw>Pach`y*car"pous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pachy-</ets> + Gr. <?/ fruit.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Having the pericarp thick.</def>

<hw>Pach`y*dac"tyl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pachy-</ets> + <ets>dactyl</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A bird or other animal having thick
toes.</def>

<hw>Pach`y*dac"tyl*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having thick toes.</def>

<hw>Pach"y*derm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pachyderme</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of

<hw>Pach`y*der"mal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>\'d8Pach`y*der"ma*ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ thick-skinned; <?/ thick + <?/
skin.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A group of hoofed mammals
distinguished for the thickness of their skins, including the
elephant, hippopotamus, rhinoceros, tapir, horse, and hog. It is
now considered an artificial group.</def>

<hw>Pach`y*der"ma*tous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Thick-skinned; not sensitive to ridicule.</def>

<hw>Pach`y*men`in*gi"tis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pach"y*ote</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pac"i*fi`a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being pacified or appeased; placable.</def>

<hw>Pa*cif"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pacificus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pacifique</ets>. See
<er>Pacify</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to peace; suited to
make or restore peace; of a peaceful character; not warlike; not
quarrelsome; conciliatory; <as>as, <ex>pacific</ex> words or
acts; a <ex>pacific</ex> nature or condition.</as></def>

<cs><col>Pacific Ocean</col>, <cd>the ocean between America and
Asia, so called by Magellan, its first European navigator, on
account of the exemption from violent tempests which he enjoyed
while sailing over it; -- called also, simply, the
<altname>Pacific</altname>, and, formerly, the <altname>South
sea</altname>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Peacemaking; appeasing; conciliatory; tranquil;
calm; quiet; peaceful; reconciling; mild; gentle.</syn>

<hw>Pa*cif"ic*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Placable.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Pa*cif"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to peace; pacific.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> <au>Sir H.
Wotton</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>Pa*cif"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos> <mark>[R.]</mark></wordforms>

<hw>Pa*cif`i*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pacificatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pacification</ets>. See
<er>Pacify</er>.]</ety> <def>The act or process of pacifying, or
of making peace between parties at variance;
reconciliation.</def> \'bdAn embassy of
<xex>pacification</xex>.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pa*cif"i*ca`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>One who, or that which, pacifies; a
peacemaker.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pa*cif"i*ca*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pacificatorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to make peace;

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>Pac"fi`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pacifies.</def>

<hw>Pac"i*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pacified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pacifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>pacifier</ets>, L.
<ets>pacificare</ets>; <ets>pax</ets>, <ets>pacis</ets>, peace +
<ets>-ficare</ets> (in comp.) to make. See <er>Peace</er>, and
<er>-fy</er>.]</ety> <def>To make to be at peace; to appease; to
calm; to still; to quiet; to allay the agitation, excitement, or
resentment of; to tranquillize; <as>as, to <ex>pacify</ex> a man
when angry; to <ex>pacify</ex> pride, appetite, or
importunity.</as></def> \'bdPray ye, <xex>pacify</xex>
yourself.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To <qex>pacify</qex> and settle those countries.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Pa*cin"i*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of, pertaining to, or discovered by,
Filippo <xex>Pacini</xex>, an Italian physician of the 19th
century.</def>

<cs><col>Pacinian corpuscles</col>, <cd>small oval bodies
terminating some of the minute branches of the sensory nerves in
the integument and other parts of the body. They are supposed to
be tactile organs.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pack</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Pact</er>.]</ety> <def>A pact.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Daniel.</au>

<hw>Pack</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to D. <ets>pak</ets>, G.
<ets>pack</ets>, Dan. <ets>pakke</ets>, Sw. <ets>packa</ets>,
Icel. <ets>pakki</ets>, Gael. & Ir. <ets>pac</ets>, Arm.
<ets>pak</ets>. Cf. <er>Packet</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A bundle made up and prepared to be carried;
especially, a bundle to be carried on the back; a load for an
animal; a bale, as of goods.</def>

<au>Piers Plowman.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Cf. <er>Peck</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>A
number or quantity equal to the contents of a pack; hence, a
multitude; a burden.</def> \'bdA <xex>pack</xex> of sorrows.\'b8
\'bdA <xex>pack</xex> of blessings.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<note><hand/ \'bdIn England, by a <xex>pack</xex> of meal is
meant 280 lbs.; of wool, 240 lbs.\'b8</note>

<au>McElrath.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A number or quantity of connected or similar
things</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A full set of playing cards;
also, the assortment used in a particular game; <as>as, a euchre
<ex>pack</ex></as></def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A number of hounds or
dogs, hunting or kept together</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A number
of persons associated or leagued in a bad design or practice; a
gang; <as>as, a <ex>pack</ex> of thieves or knaves</as></def>.
<sd>(d)</sd> <def>A shook of cask staves</def>. <sd>(e)</sd>
<def>A bundle of sheet-iron plates for rolling
simultaneously.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A large area of floating pieces of ice driven
together more or less closely.</def>

<au>Kane.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>An envelope, or wrapping, of sheets used in
hydropathic practice, called <xex>dry pack</xex>, <xex>wet
pack</xex>, <xex>cold pack</xex>, etc., according to the method
of treatment.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <ety>[Prob. the same word; but cf. AS.
<ets>p<?/can</ets> to deceive.]</ety> <def>A loose, lewd, or
worthless person. See <er>Baggage</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Skelton.</au>

<cs><col>Pack animal</col>, <cd>an animal, as a horse, mule,
etc., employed in carrying packs.</cd> -- <col>Pack cloth</col>,
<cd>a coarse cloth, often duck, used in covering packs or
bales.</cd> -- <col>Pack horse</col>. <cd>See <cref>Pack
animal</cref> (above).</cd> -- <col>Pack ice</col>. <cd>See def.
4, above.</cd> -- <col>Pack moth</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a small moth (<spn>Anacampsis sarcitella</spn>) which, in the
larval state, is very destructive to wool and woolen
fabrics.</cd> -- <col>Pack needle</col>, <cd>a needle for sewing
with pack thread. <au>Piers Plowman</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pack
saddle</col>, <cd>a saddle made for supporting the load on a pack
animal. <au>Shak</au>. -- <col>Pack staff</col>, <cd>a staff for
supporting a pack; a peddler's staff.</cd> -- <col>Pack
thread</col>, <cd>strong thread or small twine used for tying
packs or parcels.</cd> -- <col>Pack train</col>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a troop of pack animals.</cd>
</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1029 -->

<hw>Pack</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Packed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Packing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Akin to D. <ets>pakken</ets>, G. <ets>packen</ets>, Dan.
<ets>pakke</ets>, Sw. <ets>packa</ets>, Icel. <ets>pakka</ets>.
See <er>Pack</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
a pack of; to arrange closely and securely in a pack; hence, to
place and arrange compactly as in a pack; to press into close
order or narrow compass; as to <xex>pack</xex> goods in a box; to
<xex>pack</xex> fish.</def>

<q>Strange materials <qex>packed</qex> up with wonderful art.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Where . . . the bones
Of all my buried ancestors are <qex>packed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To fill in the manner of a pack, that is,
compactly and securely, as for transportation; hence, to fill
closely or to repletion; to stow away within; to cause to be
full; to crowd into; <as>as, to <ex>pack</ex> a trunk; the play,
or the audience, <ex>packs</ex> the theater.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To sort and arrange (the cards) in a pack so as
to secure the game unfairly.</def>

<q>And mighty dukes <qex>pack</qex> cards for half a crown.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Hence: To bring together or make up unfairly and
fraudulently, in order to secure a certain result; <as>as, to
<ex>pack</ex> a jury or a causes</as>.</def>

<q>The expected council was dwindling into . . . a
<qex>packed</qex> assembly of Italian bishops.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To contrive unfairly or fraudulently; to
plot.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q> He lost life . . . upon a nice point subtilely devised and
<qex>packed</qex> by his enemies.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To load with a pack; hence, to load; to
encumber; <as>as, to <ex>pack</ex> a horse</as>.</def>

<q>Our thighs <qex>packed</qex> with wax, our mouths with
honey.</q>
<qau>Shack.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To cause to go; to send away with baggage or
belongings; esp., to send away peremptorily or suddenly; --
sometimes with <xex>off</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>pack</ex> a boy off
to school</as>.</def>

<q>He . . . must not die</q>

<q>Till George be <qex>packed</qex> with post horse up to
heaven.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To transport in a pack, or in the manner of a
pack (<it>i. e.</it>, on the backs of men or beasts).</def>
<mark>[Western U.S.]</mark>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Hydropathy)</fld> <def>To envelop in a wet or
dry sheet, within numerous coverings. See <er>Pack</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 5.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>To render impervious, as by
filling or surrounding with suitable material, or to fit or
adjust so as to move without giving passage to air, water, or
steam; <as>as, to <ex>pack</ex> a joint; to <ex>pack</ex> the
piston of a steam engine.</as></def>

<hw>Pack</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make up
packs, bales, or bundles; to stow articles securely for
transportation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To admit of stowage, or of making up for
transportation or storage; to become compressed or to settle
together, so as to form a compact mass; <as>as, the goods
<ex>pack</ex> conveniently; wet snow <ex>packs</ex>
well.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To gather in flocks or schools; <as>as, the
grouse or the perch begin to <ex>pack</ex></as>.</def>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To depart in haste; -- generally with
<xex>off</xex> or <xex>away</xex>.</def>

<q>Poor Stella must <qex>pack</qex> off to town</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<q>You shall <qex>pack</qex>,
And never more darken my doors again.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To unite in bad measures; to confederate for ill
purposes; to join in collusion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdGo
<xex>pack</xex> with him.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>To send packing</col>, <cd>to drive away; to send off
roughly or in disgrace; to dismiss unceremoniously. \'bdThe
parliament . . . presently <xex>sent<xex> him
<xex>packing<xex>.</cd></cs>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Pack"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Act or process of packing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A bundle made up for transportation; a packet; a
bale; a parcel; <as>as, a <ex>package</ex> of goods</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A charge made for packing goods.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A duty formerly charged in the port of London on
goods imported or exported by aliens, or by denizens who were the
sons of aliens.</def>

<hw>Pack"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person whose
business is to pack things; especially, one who packs food for
preservation; <as>as, a pork <ex>packer</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pack"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>paquet</ets>, dim. fr. LL. <ets>paccus</ets>, from the same
source as E. <ets>pack</ets>. See <er>Pack</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A small pack or package; a little bundle or
parcel; <as>as, a <ex>packet</ex> of letters</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Originally, a vessel employed by government to
convey dispatches or mails; hence, a vessel employed in conveying
dispatches, mails, passengers, and goods, and having fixed days
of sailing; a mail boat.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Packet boat</col>, <col>ship</col>, <or/
<col>vessel</col></mcol>. <cd>See <er>Packet</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
2.</cd> -- <col>Packet day</col>, <cd>the day for mailing letters
to go by packet; or the sailing day.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Packet
note</col> <or/ <col>post</col></mcol>. <cd>See under
<er>Paper</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pack"et</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Packeted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Packeting</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make up into
a packet or bundle.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To send in a packet or dispatch vessel.</def>

<q>Her husband
Was <qex>packeted</qex> to France.</q>
<qau>Ford.</qau>

<hw>Pack"et</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To ply with a packet or
dispatch boat.</def>

<hw>Pack"fong`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Chin.
<ets>peh tung</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Metal.)</fld> <def>A Chinese
alloy of nickel, zinc, and copper, resembling German
silver.</def>

<hw>Pack herse</hw>. <def>See under 2d <er>Pack</er>.</def>

<hw>Pack"house`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Warehouse
for storing goods.</def>

<hw>Pack"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or
process of one who packs.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any material used to pack, fill up, or make
close.</def> Specifically <fld>(Mach.)</fld>: <def>A substance or
piece used to make a joint impervious</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>A thin layer, or sheet, of yielding or elastic material
inserted between the surfaces of a flange joint</def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The substance in a stuffing box, through which
a piston rod slides</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A yielding ring, as
of metal, which surrounds a piston and maintains a tight fit, as
inside a cylinder, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Masonry)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Filling</er>.</def> <mark>[Rare in the U. S.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A trick; collusion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bale.</au>

<cs><col>Cherd packing</col> <fld>(Bridge Building)</fld>,
<cd>the arrangement, side by side, of several parts, as bars,
diagonals, a post, etc., on a pin at the bottom of a chord.
<au>Waddell</au>.</cd> -- <col>Packing box</col>, <cd>a stuffing
box. See under <er>Stuffing</er>.</cd> -- <col>Packing
press</col>, <cd>a powerful press for baling cotton, wool, hay,
etc.</cd> -- <col>Packing ring</col>. <cd>See <er>Packing</er>, 2
<sd>(c)</sd>, and <xex>Illust<xex>. of <er>Piston</er>.</cd> --
<col>Packing sheet</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A large cloth for
packing goods</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A sheet prepared for packing
hydropathic patients.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pack"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Packmen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>One who bears a
pack; a peddler.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pack saddle</hw>, <hw>Pack thread</hw>  }</mhw>.
<def>See under 2d <er>Pack</er>.</def>

<hw>Pack"wax`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>Same as <er>Paxwax</er>.</def>

<hw>Pack"way`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A path, as
over mountains, followed by pack animals.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pa"co</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pa"cos</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
}</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp. <ets>paco</ets>, fr. Peruv.
<ets>paco</ets>. Cf. <er>Alpaca</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Alpaca</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Peruv. <ets>paco</ets>, <ets>pacu</ets>, red,
reddish, reddish ore containing silver; perh. a different
word.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>An earthy-looking ore,
consisting of brown oxide of iron with minute particles of native
silver.</def>

<au>Ure.</au>

<hw>Pact</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pactum</ets>, fr. <ets>paciscere</ets> to make a bargain or
contract, fr. <ets>pacere</ets> to settle, or agree upon; cf.
<ets>pangere</ets> to fasten, Gr. <?/, Skr. <ets>p\'beca</ets>
bond, and E. <ets>fang</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pacie</ets>. Cf.
<er>Peace</er>, <er>Fadge</er>, <pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <def>An
agreement; a league; a compact; a covenant.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>The engagement and <qex>pact</qex> of society whish goes by
the name of the constitution.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Pac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pactio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>paction</ets>. See

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Pac"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of the

<au>Bp. Sanderson.</au>

<hw>Pac*ti"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pactitius</ets>, <ets>pacticius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Setted by

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Pac*to"li*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pertaining
to the Pactolus, a river in ancient Lydia famous for its golden
sands.</def>

<hw>Pa"cu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A South American freah-water fish (<spn>Myleies pacu</spn>),
of the family <spn>Characinid\'91</spn>. It is highly esteemed as
food.</def>

<hw>Pad</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D. <ets>pad</ets>.
<root/21. See <er>Path</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A footpath;
a road.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An easy-paced horse; a padnag.</def>

<au>Addison</au>

<q>An abbot on an ambling <qex>pad</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A robber that infests the road on foot; a
highwayman; -- usually called a <altname>footpad</altname>.</def>

<au>Gay. Byron.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The act of robbing on the highway.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pad</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To travel upon foot; to
tread.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Padding</qex> the streets for half a crown.</q>
<qau>Somerville.</qau>

<hw>Pad</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To travel heavily
or slowly.</def>

<au>Bunyan.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To rob on foot.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Cotton Mather.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To wear a path by walking.</def> <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pad</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. akin to
<ets>pod</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A soft, or small,
cushion; a mass of anything soft; stuffing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A kind of cushion for writing upon, or for
blotting; esp., one formed of many flat sheets of writing paper,
or layers of blotting paper; a block of paper.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A cushion used as a saddle without a tree or
frame.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A stuffed guard or protection; esp., one worn on
the legs of horses to prevent bruising.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A cushionlike thickening
of the skin one the under side of the toes of animals.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A floating leaf of a water lily or similar
plant.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A soft bag or cushion to
relieve pressure, support a part, etc.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A piece of timber fixed on a
beam to fit the curve of the deck.</def>

<au>W. C. Russel.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>A measure for fish; <as>as, sixty mackerel go to
a <ex>pad</ex></as>; a basket of soles.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<au>Simmonds.</au>

<cs><col>Pad cloth</col>, <cd>a saddlecloth; a housing.</cd> --
<col>Pad saddle</col>. <cd>See def. 3, above.</cd> -- <col>Pad
tree</col> <fld>(Harness Making)</fld>, <cd>a piece of wood or
metal which gives rigidity and shape to a harness pad.</cd></cs>

<au>Knight.</au>

<hw>Pad"dle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Prob. for
<ets>pattle</ets>, and a dim. of <ets>pat</ets>, v.; cf. also E.
<ets>pad</ets> to tread, Prov. G. <ets>paddeln</ets>,
<ets>padden</ets>, to walk with short steps, to paddle, G.
<ets>patschen</ets> to splash, dash, dabble, F.
<ets>patouiller</ets> to dabble, splash, fr. <ets>patte</ets> a
paw. <?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To use the hands or fingers in
toying; to make caressing strokes.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To dabble in water with hands or feet; to use a
paddle, or something which serves as a paddle, in swimming, in
paddling a boat, etc.</def>

<q>As the men were <qex>paddling</qex> for their lives.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<q>While <qex>paddling</qex> ducks the standing lake desire.</q>
<qau>Gay.</qau>

<hw>Pad"dle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Paddled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Paddling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To pat or stroke amorously, or gently.</def>

<q>To be <qex>paddling</qex> palms and pinching fingers.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To propel with, or as with, a paddle or
paddles.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To pad; to tread upon; to trample.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pad"dle</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Paddle</er>,
<pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An implement with a
broad blade, which is used without a fixed fulcrum in propelling
and steering canoes and boats.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The broad part of a paddle, with which the
stroke is made; hence, any short, broad blade, resembling that of
a paddle.</def>

<q>Thou shalt have a <qex>paddle</qex> upon thy weapon.</q>
<qau>Deut. xxiii. 13.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One of the broad boards, or floats, at the
circumference of a water wheel, or paddle wheel.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A small gate in sluices or lock gates to admit
or let off water; -- also called <altname>clough</altname>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A paddle-shaped foot, as
of the sea turtle.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A paddle-shaped implement for string or
mixing.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <ety>[In this sense prob. for older
<ets>spaddle</ets>, <ets>a dim</ets>. <ets>of spade</ets>.]</ety>
<def>See <cref>Paddle staff</cref> (b), below.</def> <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<cs><col>Paddle beam</col> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld>, <cd>one of
two large timbers supporting the spring beam and paddle box of a
steam vessel.</cd> -- <col>Paddle board</col>. <cd>See
<er>Paddle</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3.</cd> -- <col>Paddle box</col>,
<cd>the structure inclosing the upper part of the paddle wheel of
a steam vessel.</cd> -- <col>Paddle shaft</col>, <cd>the
revolving shaft which carries the paddle wheel of a steam
vessel.</cd> -- <col>Paddle staff</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A staff
tipped with a broad blade, used by mole catchers.</cd>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A long-handled spade
used to clean a plowshare; -- called also <altname>plow
staff</altname>.</cd> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Paddle
steamer</col>, <cd>a steam vessel propelled by paddle wheels, in
distinction from a screw propeller.</cd> -- <col>Paddle
wheel</col>, <cd>the propelling wheel of a steam vessel, having
paddles (or floats) on its circumference, and revolving in a
vertical plane parallel to the vessel's length.</cd></cs>

<fld>(Zo\'94l)</fld> <def>A large ganoid fish (<spn>Polyodon

cat</altname>, and <altname>spoonbill sturgeon</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pad"lock`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. orig.,
a lock for a <ets>pad</ets> gate, or a gate opening to a
<ets>path</ets>, or perh., a lock for a basket or pannier, and
from Prov. E. <ets>pad</ets> a pannier. Cf. <er>Pad</er> a path,
<er>Paddler</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A portable lock with a
bow which is usually jointed or pivoted at one end so that it can
be opened, the other end being fastened by the bolt, -- used for
fastening by passing the bow through a staple over a hasp or
through the links of a chain, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: A curb; a restraint.</def>

<hw>Pa"gan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>paganus</ets> a countryman, peasant, villager, a pagan, fr.
<ets>paganus</ets> of or pertaining to the country, rustic, also,
pagan, fr. <ets>pagus</ets> a district, canton, the country,
perh. orig., a district with fixed boundaries: cf.
<ets>pangere</ets> to fasten. Cf. <er>Painim</er>,
<er>Peasant</er>, and <er>Pact</er>, also
<er>Heathen</er>.]</ety> <def>One who worships false goods; an
idolater; a heathen; one who is neither a Christian, a
Mohammedan, nor a Jew.</def>

<q>Neither having the accent of Christians, nor the gait of
Christian, <qex>pagan</qex>, nor man.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Gentile; heathen; idolater.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Pagan</er>, <er>Gentile</er>, <er>Heathen</er>.
<xex>Gentile</xex> was applied to the other nations of the earth
as distinguished from the Jews. <xex>Pagan</xex> was the name
given to idolaters in the early Christian church, because the
<xex>villagers</xex>, being most remote from the centers of
instruction, remained for a long time unconverted.
<xex>Heathen</xex> has the same origin. <xex>Pagan</xex> is now
more properly applied to rude and uncivilized idolaters, while
<xex>heathen</xex> embraces all who practice idolatry.</usage>

<hw>Pa"gan</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>paganus</ets> of or
pertaining to the country, pagan. See <er>Pagan</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to pagans; relating to
the worship or the worshipers of false goods; heathen;
idolatrous, <as>as, <ex>pagan</ex> tribes or
superstitions</as>.</def>

<q>And all the rites of <qex>pagan</qex> honor paid.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pa"gan*dom</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The pagan
lands; pagans, collectively; paganism.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pa*gan"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pa*gan"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to
pagans or paganism; heathenish; paganish.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
\'bdThe <xex>paganic</xex> fables of the goods.\'b8
<au>Cudworth</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>Pa*gan"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos> <mark>[R.]</mark></wordforms>

<hw>Pa"gan*ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to pagans; heathenish.</def> \'bdThe old
<xex>paganish</xex> idolatry.\'b8

<au>Sharp</au>

<hw>Pa"gan*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>paganismus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>paganisme</ets>. See
<er>Pagan</er>, and cf. <er>Painim</er>.]</ety> <def>The state of
being pagan; pagan characteristics; esp., the worship of idols or
false gods, or the system of religious opinions and worship
maintained by pagans; heathenism.</def>

<hw>Pa*gan"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Paganitas</ets>.]</ety> <def>The state of being a pagan;
paganism.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<hw>Pa"gan*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Paganized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Paganizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To render pagan or heathenish; to
convert to paganism.</def>

<au>Hallywell.</au>

<hw>Pa"gan*ize</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To behave like
pagans.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pa"gan*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pagan manner.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Page</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. It.
<ets>paggio</ets>, LL. <ets>pagius</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/, dim. of
<?/, <?/, a boy, servant; perh. akin to L. <ets>puer</ets>. Cf.
<er>Pedagogue</er>, <er>Puerile</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
serving boy; formerly, a youth attending a person of high degree,
especially at courts, as a position of honor and education; now
commonly, in England, a youth employed for doin errands, waiting
on the door, and similar service in households; in the United
States, a boy emploed to wait upon the members of a legislative
body.</def>

<q>He had two <qex>pages</qex> of honor -- on either hand
one.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A boy child.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A contrivance, as a band, pin, snap, or the
like, to hold the skirt of a woman's dress from the ground.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Brickmaking.)</fld> <def>A track along which
pallets carrying newly molded bricks are conveyed to the
hack.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several species
of beautiful South American moths of the genus
<spn>Urania</spn>.</def>

<hw>Page</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To attend (one) as a
page.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Page</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L. <ets>pagina</ets>;
prob. akin to <ets>pagere</ets>, <ets>pangere</ets>, to fasten,
fix, make, the pages or leaves being fastened together. Cf.
<er>Pact</er>, <er>Pageant</er>, <er>Pagination</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One side of a leaf of a book or
manuscript.</def>

<q>Such was the book from whose <qex>pages</qex> she sang.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: A record; a writing; <as>as, the
<ex>page</ex> of history</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>The type set up for printing
a page.</def>

<hw>Page</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Paged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Paging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To mark or number
the pages of, as a book or manuskript; to furnish with
folios.</def>

<hw>Pag"eant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pagent</ets>, <ets>pagen</ets>, originally, a movable
scaffold or stage, hence, what was exhibited on it, fr. LL.
<ets>pagina</ets>, akin to <ets>pangere</ets> to fasten; cf. L.
<ets>pagina</ets> page, leaf, slab, <ets>compaginare</ets> to
join together, <ets>compages</ets> a joining together, structure.
See <er>Pact</er>, <er>Page</er> of a book.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A theatrical exhibition; a spectacle.</def>
\'bdA <xex>pageant</xex> truly played.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To see sad <qex>pageants</qex> of men's miseries.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An elaborate exhibition devised for the
entertainmeut of a distinguished personage, or of the public; a
show, spectacle, or display.</def>

<q>The gaze of fools, and <qex>pageant</qex> of a day !</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>We love the man, the paltry <qex>pageant</qex> you.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<hw>Pag"eant</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of the nature of a pageant;
spectacular.</def> \'bd<xex>Pageant</xex> pomp.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pag"eant</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To exhibit in show; to
represent; to mimic.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdHe
<xex>pageants</xex> us.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pag"eant*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Scenic
shows or spectacles, taken collectivelly; spectacular guality;
splendor.</def>

<q>Such <qex>pageantry</qex> be to the people shown.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>The <qex>pageantry</qex> of festival.</q>
<qau>J. A. Symonds.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Pomp; parade; show; display; spectacle.</syn>

being a page.</def>

<hw>Pa"god</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pagode</ets>. See <er>Pagoda</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A pagoda. <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdOr some queer
<xex>pagod</xex>.\'bd</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An idol.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Stillingfleet.</au>

<hw>Pa*go"da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pg.
<ets>pagoda</ets>, <ets>pagode</ets>, fr.Hind. & Per.
<ets>but-kadah</ets> a house of idols, or abode of God; Per.
<ets>but</ets> an idol + <ets>kadah</ets> a house, a
temple.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A term by which Europeans
designate religious temples and tower-like buildings of the
Hindoos and Buddhists of India, Farther India, China, and Japan,
-- usually but not always, devoted to idol worship.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An idol.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Prob. so named from the image of a pagoda or a
deity (cf. Skr. <ets>bhagavat</ets> holy, divine) stamped on
it.]</ety> <def>A gold or silver coin, of various kinds and
values, formerly current in India. The Madras gold pagoda was
worth about three and a half rupees.</def>

<hw>Pa*go"dite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>Agalmatolite; -- so called because sometimes carved by the
Chinese into the form of pagodas. See
<er>Agalmatolite</er>.</def>

<hw>Pa*gu"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pain</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>peine</ets>, F. <ets>peine</ets>, fr. L. <ets>poena</ets>,
penalty, punishment, torment, pain; akin to Gr. <ets><?/</ets>
penalty. Cf. <er>Penal</er>, <er>Pine</er> to languish,
<er>Punish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Punishment suffered or
denounced; suffering or evil inflicted as a punishment for crime,
or connected with the commission of a crime; penalty.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>We will, by way of mulct or <qex>pain</qex>, lay it upon
him.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Interpose, on <qex>pain</qex> of my displeasure.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>None shall presume to fly, under <qex>pain</qex> of death.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any uneasy sensation in animal bodies, from
slight uneasiness to extreme distress or torture, proceeding from
a derangement of functions, disease, or injury by violence;
bodily distress; bodily suffering; an ache; a smart.</def>
\'bdThe <xex>pain</xex> of Jesus Christ.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pain</xex> may occur in any part of the body
where sensory nerves are distributed, and it is always due to
some kind of stimulation of them. The sensation is generally
referred to the peripheral end of the nerve.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>Specifically, the throes or
travail of childbirth.</def>

<q>She bowed herself and travailed, for her <qex>pains</qex> came
upon her.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. iv. 19.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Uneasiness of mind; mental distress;
disquietude; anxiety; grief; solicitude; anguish.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>In rapture as in <qex>pain</qex>.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>See <er>Pains</er>, labor, effort.</def>

<cs><col>Bill of pains and penalties</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Bill</er>.</cd> -- <col>To die in the pain</col>, <cd>to be
tortured to death. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<au>Chaucer.</au></cd></cs>

<hw>Pain</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pained</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Paining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>peinen</ets>, OF.
<ets>pener</ets>, F. <ets>peiner</ets> to fatigue. See
<er>Pain</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To inflict
suffering upon as a penalty; to punish.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif (Acts xxii. 5).</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put to bodily uneasiness or anguish; to
afflict with uneasy sensations of any degree of intensity; to
torment; to torture; <as>as, his dinner or his wound
<ex>pained</ex> him; his stomach <ex>pained</ex> him.</as></def>

<q>Excess of cold, as well as heat, <qex>pains</qex> us.</q>
<qau>Lock<?/</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To render uneasy in mind; to disquiet; to
distress; to grieve; as a child's faults <xex>pain</xex> his
parents.</def>

<q>I am <qex>pained</qex> at m<?/ very heart.</q>
<qau>Jer. iv. 19.</qau>

<cs><col>To pain one's self</col>, <cd>to exert or trouble one's
self; to take pains; to be solicitous. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bdShe <xex>pained her<xex> to do all that she
might.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To disquiet; trouble; afflict; grieve; aggrieve;
distress; agonize; torment; torture.</syn>

<hw>Pain"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82nible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Causing pain; painful.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The manacles of Astyages were not . . . the less weighty and
<qex>painable</qex> for being composed of gold or silver.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<hw>Pain"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Full of pain; causing uneasiness or distress, either
physical or mental; afflictive; disquieting; distressing</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Requiring labor or toil; difficult; executed
with laborious effort; as a <xex>painful</xex> service; a
<xex>painful</xex> march.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Painstaking; careful; industrious.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<q>A very <qex>painful</qex> person, and a great clerk.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<q>Nor must the <qex>painful</qex> husbandman be tired.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Disquieting; troublesome; afflictive; distressing;
grievous; laborious; toilsome; difficult; arduous. --
<wordforms><wf>Pain"ful*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pain"ful*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></syn></wordforms>

<hw>Pai"nim</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos><ety>[OE.

<hw>Pains</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos><def>Labor; toilsome
effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural in form, but used with a
singular or plural verb, commonly the former.</def>

<q>And all my <qex>pains</qex> is sorted to no proof.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The <qex>pains</qex> they had taken was very great.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q>The labored earth your <qex>pains</qex> have sowed and
tilled.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Paint</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Painted</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Painting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>peinten</ets>, fr. F. <ets>peint</ets>, <ets>p</ets>.
<ets>p</ets>. o<?/ <ets>peindre</ets> to paint, fr. L.
<ets>pingere</ets>, <ets>pictum</ets>; cf. Gr. <ets><?/</ets>
many-colored, Skr. <ets>pic</ets> to adorn. Cf. <er>Depict</er>,
<er>Picture</er>, <er>Pigment</er>, <er>Pint</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover with coloring matter; to apply paint
to; <as>as, to <ex>paint</ex> a house, a signboard,
etc</as>.</def>

<q>Jezebel <qex>painted</qex> her face and tired her head.</q>
<qau>2 Kings ix. 30.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To color, stain, or tinge; to adorn or
beautify with colors; to diversify with colors.</def>

<q>Not <qex>painted</qex> with the crimson spots of blood.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Cuckoo buds of yellow hue
Do <qex>paint</qex> the meadows with delight.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To form in colors a figure or likeness of on a
flat surface, as upon canvas; to represent by means of colors or
hues; to exhibit in a tinted image; to portray with paints;
<as>as, to <ex>paint</ex> a portrait or a landscape</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Fig.: To represent or exhibit to the mind; to
describe vividly; to delineate; to image; to depict.</def>

<q>Disloyal?
The word is too good to <qex>paint</qex> out her wickedness.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>If folly grow romantic, I must <qex>paint</qex> it.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To color; picture; depict; portray; delineate;
sketch; draw; describe.</syn>

<hw>Paint</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To practice the
art of painting; <as>as, the artist <ex>paints</ex>
well</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To color one's face by way of beautifying
it</def>.

<q>Let her <qex>paint</qex> an inch thick.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Paint</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
pigment or coloring substance.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The same
prepared with a vehicle, as oil, water with gum, or the like, for
application to a surface.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A cosmetic; rouge.</def>

<au>Praed.</au>

<hw>Paint"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Covered or
adorned with paint; portrayed in colors.</def>

<q>As idle as a <qex>painted</qex> ship
Upon a <qex>painted</qex> ocean.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Nat. Hist.)</fld> <def>Marked with bright
colors; <as>as, the <ex>painted</ex> turtle; <ex>painted</ex>
bunting.</as></def>

<cs><col>Painted beauty</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
handsome American butterfly (<spn>Vanessa Huntera</spn>), having
a variety of bright colors,</cd> -- <col>Painted cup</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any plant of an American genus of herbs
(<spn>Castilleia</spn>) in which the bracts are usually
bright-colored and more showy than the flowers. <spn>Castilleia
coccinea</spn> has brilliantly scarlet bracts, and is common in
meadows.</cd> -- <col>Painted finch</col>. <cd>See
<er>Nonpareil</er>.</cd> -- <col>Painted lady</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a bright-colored butterfly. See
<er>Thistle butterfly</er>.</cd> -- <col>Painted turtle</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a common American freshwater tortoise
(<spn>Chrysemys picta</spn>), having bright red and yellow
markings beneath.</cd></cs>

<hw>Paint"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE,
<ets>pantere</ets> a noose, snare, F. <ets>panti\'8are</ets>, LL.
<ets>panthera</ets>, L. <ets>panther</ets> a hunting net, fr. Gr.
<ets><?/</ets>; <?/  all + <?/ beast; cf. Ir. <ets>painteir</ets>
a net, gin, snare, Gael. <ets>painntear</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A rope at the bow of a boat, used to
fasten it to anything.</def>

<au>Totten.</au>

<hw>Paint"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Corrupt. of
<ets>panther</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The
panther, or puma.</def> <mark>[A form representing an illiterate
pronunciation, U. S.]</mark>

<au>J. F. Cooper.</au>

<hw>Paint"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See lst
<er>Paint</er>.]</ety> <def>One whose occupation is to
paint</def>; esp.: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>One who covers buildings,
ships, ironwork, and the like, with paint</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>An artist who represents objects or scenes in color on a
flat surface, as canvas, plaster, or the like.</def>

<cs><col>Painter's colic</col>. <fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Lead colic</cref>, under <er>Colic</er>.</cd> --
<col>Painter stainer</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A painter of coats
of arms.</cd> <au>Crabb.</au> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A member of a
livery company or guild in London, bearing this name.</cd></cs>

<hw>Paint"er*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like a
painter's work.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdA
<xex>painterly</xex> glose of a visage.\'b8

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<hw>Paint"er*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or position
of being a painter.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Br. Gardiner.</au>

<hw>Paint"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or
employment of laying on, or adorning with, paints or
colors.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>The work of the painter;
also, any work of art in which objects are represented in color
on a flat surface; a colored representation of any object or
scene; a picture.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Color laid on; paint.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A depicting by words; vivid representation in
words.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Picture</er>.</syn>

<hw>Paint"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not capable of being
painted or described.</def> \'bdIn <xex>paintless</xex>
patience.\'b8

<au>Savage.</au>

<hw>Pain"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>peinture</ets>. See <er>Paint</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, and
cf. <er>Picture</er>.]</ety> <def>The art of painting.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer. Dryden.</au>

<hw>Paint"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Unskillfully
painted, so that the painter's method of work is too obvious;
also, having too much pigment applied to the surface.</def>
<mark>[Cant]</mark>

<hw>Pair</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>paire</ets>, LL. <ets>paria</ets>, L. <ets>paria</ets>, pl.
of <ets>par</ets> pair, fr. <ets>par</ets>, adj., equal. Cf.
<er>Apparel</er>, <er>Par</er> equality, <er>Peer</er> an
equal.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A number of things resembling one another, or
belonging together; a set; <as>as, a <ex>pair</ex> or flight of
stairs</as>. \'bdA <xex>pair</xex> of beads.\'b8 
<au>Chaucer</au>. <au>Beau. & Fl.</au> \'bdFour <xex>pair</xex>
of stairs.\'b8 <au>Macaulay</au>. <note>[Now mostly or quite
disused, except as to stairs.]</note></def>

<q>Two crowns in my pocket, two <qex>pair</qex> of cards.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Two things of a kind, similar in form, suited to
each other, and intended to be used together; <as>as, a
<ex>pair</ex> of gloves or stockings; a <ex>pair</ex> of
shoes.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Two of a sort; a span; a yoke; a couple; a
brace; <as>as, a <ex>pair</ex> of horses; a <ex>pair</ex> of
oxen.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A married couple; a man and wife.</def> \'bdA
happy <xex>pair</xex>.\'b8 <au>Dryden</au>.  \'bdThe hapless
<xex>pair</xex>.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>.

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A single thing, composed of two pieces fitted to
each other and used together; <as>as, a <ex>pair</ex> of
scissors; a <ex>pair</ex> of tongs; a <ex>pair</ex> of
bellows.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Two members of opposite parties or opinion, as
in a parliamentary body, who mutually agree not to vote on a
given question, or on issues of a party nature during a specified
time; <as>as, there were two <ex>pairs</ex> on the final
vote</as>.</def> <mark>[Parliamentary Cant]</mark>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Kinematics)</fld> <def>In a mechanism, two
elements, or bodies, which are so applied to each other as to
mutually constrain relative motion.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pairs</xex> are named in accordance with the
kind of motion they permit; thus, a journal and its bearing form
a <xex>turning pair</xex>, a cylinder and its piston a
<xex>sliding pair</xex>, a screw and its nut a <xex>twisting
pair</xex>, etc. Any <xex>pair</xex> in which the constraining
contact is along lines or at points only (as a cam and roller
acting together), is designated a <xex>higher pair</xex>; any
<xex>pair</xex> having constraining surfaces which fit each other
(as a cylindrical pin and eye, a screw and its nut, etc.), is
called a <xex>lower pair</xex>.</note>

<cs><col>Pair royal</col> <plu>(pl. <plw>Pairs Royal</plw>)</plu>
<cd>three things of a sort; -- used especially of playing cards
in some games, as cribbage; as three kings, three \'bdeight
spots\'b8 etc. Four of a kind are called a <xex>double pair
royal<xex>. \'bdSomething in his face gave me as much pleasure as
a <xex>pair royal<xex> of naturals in my own hand.\'b8
<au>Goldsmith</au>. \'bdThat great <xex>pair royal<xex> of
adamantine sisters [the Fates].\'b8 <au>Quarles</au>.</cd>
<altsp>[Written corruptly <asp>parial<asp> and
<asp>prial<asp>.]</altsp></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Pair</er>, <er>Flight</er>, <er>Set</er>.</syn>
<usage> Originally, <xex>pair</xex> was not confined to two
things, but was applied to any number of equal things
(<xex>pares</xex>), that go together. Ben Jonson speaks of a
<xex>pair</xex> (set) of chessmen; also, he and Lord Bacon speak
of a <xex>pair</xex> (pack) of cards. A \'bd<xex>pair</xex> of
stairs\'b8 is still in popular use, as well as the later
expression, \'bdflight of stairs.\'b8</usage>

<hw>Pair</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Paired</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pairing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be joined in
paris; to couple; to mate, as for breeding.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To suit; to fit, as a counterpart.</def>

<q>My heart was made to fit and <qex>pair</qex> with thine.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Same as <cref>To pair off</cref>. See phrase
below.</def>

<cs><col>To pair off</col>, <cd>to separate from a company in
pairs or couples; specif. (<mark>Parliamentary Cant</mark>), to
agree with one of the opposite party or opinion to abstain from
voting on specified questions or issues. See <er>Pair</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 6.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pair</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To unite in
couples; to form a pair of; to bring together, as things which
belong together, or which complement, or are adapted to one
another.</def>

<q>Glossy jet is <qex>paired</qex> with shining white.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To engage (one's self) with another of opposite
opinions not to vote on a particular question or class of
questions.</def> <mark>[Parliamentary Cant]</mark>

<cs><col>Paired fins</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Fin</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pair</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Impair</er>.]</ety>
<def>To impair.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Pair"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
impairs.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<hw>Pair"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Pair</er>, <pos>v.
i.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of uniting or
arranging in pairs or couples.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>See <cref>To pair off</cref>, under
<er>Pair</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos></def>

<cs><col>Pairyng time</col>, <cd>the time when birds or other
animals pair.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pair"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Impairment.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<hw>Pal"ace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>palais</ets>, F. <ets>palais</ets>, fr. L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The residence of a sovereign, including the
lodgings of high officers of state, and rooms for business, as
well as halls for ceremony and reception.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The official residence of a bishop or other
distinguished personage.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Loosely, any unusually magnificent or stately
house.</def>

<cs><col>Palace car</col>. <cd>See under <er>Car</er>.</cd> --

personal actions arising within twelve miles of the palace at
Whitehall. The court was abolished in 1849.

<hw>Pal`an*quin"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>palanquin</ets>, Pg. <ets>palanquim</ets>, Javan.
<ets>palangki</ets>, OJavan. <ets>palangkan</ets>, through
Prakrit fr. Skr. <ets>parya<?/ka</ets>, <ets>palya<?/ka</ets>,
bed, couch; <ets>pari</ets> around (akin to E. pref.
<ets>peri-</ets>) + <ets>a<?/ka</ets> a hook, flank, probably

<er>Palkee</er>.]</ety> <def>An inclosed carriage or litter,
commonly about eight feet long, four feet wide, and four feet

poles, -- used in India, China, etc., for the conveyance of a

<hw>Pal"a*tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>palatal</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to
the palate; palatine; <as>as, the <ex>palatal</ex>
bones</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>Uttered by the aid of the
palate; -- said of certain sounds, as the sound of <xex>k</xex>
in <xex>kirk</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pal"a*tal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>A sound
uttered, or a letter pronounced, by the aid of the palate, as the
letters <xex>k</xex> and <xex>y</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pal"a*tal*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Phon.)</fld> <def>To palatize.</def>

<hw>Pal"ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>palatum</ets>: cf. F. <ets>palais</ets>, Of. also
<ets>palat</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The
roof of the mouth.</def>

<note><hand/ The fixed portion, or palate proper, supported by
the maxillary and palatine bones, is called the <xex>hard
palate</xex> to distinguish it from the membranous and muscular
curtain which separates the cavity of the mouth from the pharynx
and is called the <xex>soft palate</xex>, or
<xex>velum</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Relish; taste; liking; -- a sense originating in
the mistaken notion that the palate is the organ of taste.</def>

<q>Hard task! to hit the <qex>palate</qex> of such guests.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: Mental relish; intellectual taste.</def>

<au>T. Baker.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A projection in the throat of
such flowers as the snapdragon.</def>

<hw>Pal"ate</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To perceive by the
taste.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pa*la"ver</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.
<ets>palabra</ets>, or Pg. <ets>palavra</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>parabola</ets> a comparison, a parable, LL., a word. See
<er>Parable</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Talk; conversation; esp., idle or beguiling
talk; talk intended to deceive; flattery.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In Africa, a parley with the natives; a talk;
hence, a public conference and deliberation; a debate.</def>

<q>This epoch of parliaments and eloquent
<qex>palavers</qex>.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<hw>Pa*la"ver</hw>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &
p. p.</pos> <er>Palavered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Palavering</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To make palaver
with, or to; to used palaver;to talk idly or deceitfully; to
employ flattery; to cajole; <as>as, to <ex>palaver</ex>
artfully</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Palavering</qex> the little language for her benefit.</q>
<qau>C. Bront<?/</qau>

<hw>Pa*la"ver*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
palavers; a flatterer.</def>

<hw>Pale</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Paler</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Palest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'83le</ets>, fr. <ets>p\'83lir</ets> to turn pale, L.
<ets>pallere</ets> to be o<?/ look pale. Cf. <er>Appall</er>,
<er>Fallow</er>, <er>pall</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>,
<er>Pallid</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Wanting in color; not ruddy; dusky white;
pallid; wan; <as>as, a <ex>pale</ex> face; a <ex>pale</ex> red; a
<ex>pale</ex> blue.</as></def> \'bd<xex>Pale</xex> as a forpined
ghost.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Speechless he stood and <qex>pale</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>They are not of complexion red or <qex>pale</qex>.</q>
<qau>T. Randolph.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not bright or brilliant; of a faint luster or
hue; dim; <as>as, the <ex>pale</ex> light of the moon</as>.</def>

<q>The night, methinks, is but the daylight sick;
It looks a little <qex>paler</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pale</xex> is often used in the formation of
self-explaining compounds; as, <xex>pale</xex>-colored,
<xex>pale</xex>-eyed, <xex>pale</xex>-faced,
<xex>pale</xex>-looking, etc.</note>

<hw>Pale</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Paleness; pallor.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pale</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Paled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Paling</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To turn pale; to lose color or
luster.</def>

<au>Whittier.</au>

<q>Apt to <qex>pale</qex> at a trodden worm.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<hw>Pale</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To make pale; to diminish
the brightness of.</def>

<q>The glow<?/worm shows the matin to be near,
And gins to <qex>pale</qex> his uneffectual fire.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pale</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>pal</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>palus</ets>: cf. D. <ets>paal</ets>. See <er>Pol<?/</er> a
stake, and lst <er>Pallet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A pointed
stake or slat, either driven into the ground, or fastened to a
rail at the top and bottom, for fencing or inclosing; a
picket.</def>

<q>Deer creep through when a <qex>pale</qex> tumbles down.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which incloses or fences in; a boundary; a
limit; a fence; a palisade.</def> \'bdWithin one <xex>pale</xex>
or hedge.\'b8

<au>Robynson (More's Utopia).</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A space or field having bounds or limits; a
limited region or place; an inclosure; -- often used
figuratively.</def> \'bdTo walk the studious cloister's
<xex>pale</xex>.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>. \'bdOut of the
<xex>pale</xex> of civilization.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A stripe or band, as on a garment.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>One of the greater ordinaries,
being a broad perpendicular stripe in an escutcheon, equally
distant from the two edges, and occupying one third of it.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A cheese scoop.</def>

<au>Simmonds.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld> <def>A shore for bracing a
timber before it is fastened.</def>

<cs><col>English pale</col> <fld>(Hist.)</fld>, <cd>the limits or
territory within which alone the English conquerors of Ireland
held dominion for a long period after their invasion of the
country in 1172.</cd></cs>

<au>Spencer.</au>

<hw>Pale</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To inclose with pales, or as
with pales; to encircle; to encompass; to fence off.</def>

<q>[Your isle, which stands]  ribbed and <qex>paled</qex> in
With rocks unscalable and roaring waters.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Pa"le*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pale\'91</plw> <pr>(-<emac/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.,
chaff.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The interior
chaff or husk of grasses.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>One of the
chaffy scales or bractlets growing on the receptacle of many
compound flowers, as the Coreopsis, the sunflower, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A pendulous process of the
skin on the throat of a bird, as in the turkey; a dewlap.</def>

<hw>Pa`le*a"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>palea</ets> chaff.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Chaffy;
resembling or consisting of pale\'91, or chaff; furnished with
chaff; <as>as, a <ex>paleaceous</ex> receptacle</as>.</def>

<hw>Pa`le*arc"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Paleo-</ets> + <ets>arctic</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Belonging to a region of the earth's surface which includes
all Europe to the Azores, Iceland, and all temperate Asia.</def>

<hw>Paled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See 5th
<er>Pale</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Striped.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd[Buskins] . . . <xex>paled</xex> part per
part.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Inclosed with a paling.</def> \'bdA
<xex>paled</xex> green.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pa`le*\'89ch`i*noi"de*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.
pl.</pos> <ety>[NL. See <er>Paleo-</er>, and
<er>Echinoidea</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An extinct
order of sea urchins found in the Paleozoic rocks. They had more
than twenty vertical rows of plates. Called also
<altname>Pal\'91echini</altname>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>Pal\'91echinoidea</asp>.]</altsp>

<-- p. 1032 -->

<hw>Pale"face`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A white
person; -- an appellation supposed to have been applied to the
whites by the American Indians.</def>

<au>J. F. Cooper.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pa`le*ich"thy*es</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Paleo-</er>, and <er>Ichthyology</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A comprehensive division of fishes
which includes the elasmobranchs and ganoids.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>Pal\'91ichthyes</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pale"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>Pale</ets>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>In a pale manner;
dimly; wanly; not freshly or ruddily.</def>

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<hw>Pal`em*pore"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A superior
kind of dimity made in India, -- used for bed coverings.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>palampore</asp>, <asp>palampoor</asp>,
etc.]</altsp>

<au>De Colange.</au>

<hw>Pale"ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality
or condition of being pale; want of freshness or ruddiness; a
sickly whiteness; lack of color or luster; wanness.</def>

<q>The blood the virgin's cheek forsook;
A livid <qex>paleness</qex> spreads o'er all her look.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

Nicaragua and Honduras.</def>

extinct animals, with relics of human beings.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pa`le*o*the"ri*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ ancient + <?/ beast.]</ety>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An extinct genus of herbivorous

form, but now known to have had a more slender form, with a long
neck like that of a llama.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>Pal\'91otherium</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pal"ette</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Pallet</er> a thin board.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>A thin, oval or square
board, or tablet, with a thumb hole at one end for holding it, on
which a painter lays and mixes his pigments.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>pallet</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anc. Armor)</fld> <def>One of the plates
covering the points of junction at the bend of the shoulders and
elbows.</def>

<au>Fairholt.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A breastplate for a breast
drill.</def>

<cs><col>Palette knife</col>, <cd>a knife with a very flexible
steel blade and no cutting edge, rounded at the end, used by
painters to mix colors on the grinding slab or palette.</cd> --
<col>To set the palette</col> <fld>(Paint.)</fld>, <cd>to lay
upon it the required pigments in a certain order, according to
the intended use of them in a picture.</cd></cs>

<au>Fairholt.</au>

<hw>Pal"frey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>palefrai</ets>, OF. <ets>palefrei</ets>, F.
<ets>palefroi</ets>, LL. <ets>palafredus</ets>,
<ets>parafredus</ets>, from L. <ets>paraveredus</ets> a horse for
extraordinary occasions, an extra post horse; Gr. <?/ along,

<au>Spenser.</au>

Charger and <qex>palfrey</qex>.</q>

<hw>Pal`i*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>palus</ets> a stake + <ets>-ficare</ets> (in comp.) to make:

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>Pa"li*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Resembling a palus; <as>as, the

<hw>Pal*la"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, <?/, Pallas.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld> <def>Any statue of the

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: That which affords effectual protection

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pal*la"di*um</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A rare metallic element of the light
platinum group, found native, and also alloyed with platinum and
gold. It is a silver-white metal resembling platinum, and like it
permanent and untarnished in the air, but is more easily fusible.
It is unique in its power of occluding hydrogen, which it does to
the extent of nearly a thousand volumes, forming the alloy
<chform>Pd2H</chform>. It is used for graduated circles and
verniers, for plating certain silver goods, and somewhat in
dentistry. It was so named in 1804 by Wollaston from the asteroid
<xex>Pallas</xex>, which was discovered in 1802. Symbol Pd.
Atomic weight, 106.2.</def>

<-- p. 1033 -->

<ets>pallium</ets> a mantle. See <er>Pall</er>.]</ety>

<hw>Pal"li*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>palliatus</ets>, fr. <ets>pallium</ets> a cloak. See
<er>Pall</er> the garment.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Covered with a
mant<?/e; cloaked; disguised.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Eased; mitigated; alleviated.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Fell.</au>

<hw>Pal"li*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos>
<er>Palliated</er><pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Palliating</er><pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
cover with a mantle or cloak; to cover up; to hide.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Being <qex>palliated</qex> with a pilgrim's coat.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Herbert.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cover with excuses; to conceal the enormity
of, by excuses and apologies; to extenuate; <as>as, to
<ex>palliate</ex> faults</as></def>.

<q>They never hide or <qex>palliate</qex> their vices.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> To reduce in violence; to lessen or abate; to
mitigate; to ease withhout curing; <as>as, to <ex>palliate</ex> a
disease</as>.</q>

<q>To <qex>palliate</qex> dullness, and give time a shove.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To cover; cloak; hide; extenuate; conceal.</syn>
<usage> -- To <er>Palliate</er>, <er>Extenuate</er>,
<er>Cloak</er>. These words, as here compared, are used in a
figurative sense in reference to our treatment of wrong action.
We <xex>cloak</xex> in order to conceal completely. We
<xex>extenuate</xex> a crime when we endeavor to show that it is
<xex>less</xex> than has been supposed; we <xex>palliate</xex> a
crime when we endeavor to <xex>cover</xex> or <xex>conceal</xex>
its enormity, at least in part.  This naturally leads us to
soften some of its features, and thus <xex>palliate</xex>
approaches <xex>extenuate</xex> till they have become nearly or
quite identical.  \'bdTo <xex>palliate</xex> is not now used,
though it once was, in the sense of wholly cloaking or covering
over, as it might be, our sins, but in that of
<xex>extenuating</xex>; to <xex>palliate</xex> our faults is not
to hide them altogether, but to seek to diminish their guilt in
part.\'b8

<au>Trench.</au>
</usage>

<hw>Pal`li*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>palliation</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
palliating, or state of being palliated; extenuation; excuse;
<as>as, the <ex>palliation</ex> of faults, offenses,
vices</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Mitigation; alleviation, as of a disease.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which cloaks or covers; disguise; also, the
state of being covered or disguised.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pal"li*a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>palliatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Serving to palliate; serving to
extenuate or mitigate.</def>

<hw>Pal"li*a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That
which palliates; a palliative agent.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Pal"li*a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Palliative; extenuating.</def>
