<hw>Par"ri*cide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>parricida</ets>; <ets>pater</ets> father +
<ets>caedere</ets> to kill. See <er>Father</er>,
<er>Homicide</er>, and cf. <er>Patricide</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Properly, one who murders one's own father; in a
wider sense, one who murders one's father or mother or any
ancestor.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[L. <ets>parricidium</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act
or crime of murdering one's own father or any ancestor.</def>

<hw>Par`ri*cid"i*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Parricidal.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Par"rock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>pearruc</ets>, <ets>pearroc</ets>. See <er>Park</er>.]</ety>
<def>A croft, or small field; a paddock.</def> <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Par"rot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. fr. F.
<ets>Pierrot</ets>, dim. of <ets>Pierre</ets> Peter. F.
<ets>pierrot</ets> is also the name of the sparrow. Cf.
<er>Paroquet</er>, <er>Petrel</er>, <er>Petrify</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>In a general sense, any
bird of the order <spn>Psittaci</spn>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of
<spn>Psittacus</spn>, <spn>Chrysotis</spn>, <spn>Pionus</spn>,
and other genera of the family <spn>Psittacid\'91</spn>, as
distinguished from the parrakeets, macaws, and lories. They have
a short rounded or even tail, and often a naked space on the
cheeks. The gray parrot, or jako (<spn>P. erithacus</spn>) of
Africa (see <er>Jako</er>), and the species of Amazon, or green,
parrots (<spn>Chrysotis</spn>) of America, are examples. Many
species, as cage birds, readily learn to imitate sounds, and to
repeat words and phrases.</def>

<cs><col>Carolina parrot</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
Carolina parrakeet. See <er>Parrakeet</er>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Night parrot</col>, <or/ <col>Owl parrot</col></mcol>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Kakapo</er>.</cd> --
<col>Parrot coal</col>, <cd>cannel coal; -- so called from the
crackling and chattering sound it makes in burning.</cd>
<mark>[Eng. & Scot.]</mark> -- <col>Parrot green</col>.
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Scheele's green</cref>, under
<er>Green</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>Parrot weed</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a suffrutescent plant (<spn>Bocconia
frutescens</spn>) of the Poppy family, native of the warmer parts
of America. It has very large, sinuate, pinnatifid leaves, and
small, panicled, apetalous flowers.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Parrot
wrasse</col>, <col>Parrot fish</col></mcol>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any fish of the genus
<spn>Scarus</spn>. One species (<spn>S. Cretensis</spn>), found
in the Mediterranean, is esteemed by epicures, and was highly
prized by the ancient Greeks and Romans.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"rot</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To repeat by rote, as a
parrot.</def>

<hw>Par"rot</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To chatter like a
parrot.</def>

<hw>Par"rot*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
simply repeats what he has heard.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>J. S. Mill.</au>

<hw>Par"rot*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Servile
imitation or repetition.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
<au>Coleridge</au>. \'bdThe supine <xex>parrotry</xex>.\'b8
<au>Fitzed. Hall</au>.

<hw>Par"rot's-bill`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So
called from the resemblance of its curved superior petal to a
parrot's bill.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The glory pea. See
under <er>Glory</er>.</def>

<hw>Par"ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Parried</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Parrying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>par\'82</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>parer</ets>. See <er>Pare</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To ward off; to stop, or to turn aside; <as>as,
to <ex>parry</ex> a thrust, a blow, or anything that means or
threatens harm</as>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<q>Vice <qex>parries</qex> wide
The undreaded volley with a sword of straw.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To avoid; to shift or put off; to evade.</def>

<q>The French government has <qex>parried</qex> the payment of
our claims.</q>
<qau>E. Everett.</qau>

<hw>Par"ry</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To ward off, evade, or
turn aside something, as a blow, argument, etc.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Par"ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Parries</plw>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>A warding off of a thrust or blow, as
in sword and bayonet exercises or in boxing; hence, figuratively,
a defensive movement in debate or other intellectual
encounter.</def>

<hw>Parse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Parsed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Parsing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[L. <ets>pars</ets> a part; <ets>pars orationis</ets> a part
of speech. See <er>Part</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>
<fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>To resolve into its elements, as a
sentence, pointing out the several parts of speech, and their
relation to each other by government or agreement; to analyze and
describe grammatically.</def>

<q>Let him construe the letter into English, and <qex>parse</qex>
it over perfectly.</q>
<qau>Ascham.</qau>

<hw>Par"see</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind. & Per.
<ets>p\'bers\'c6</ets> a Persian, a follower of Zoroaster, a fire
worshiper. Cf. <er>Persian</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the adherents of the Zoroastrian or
ancient Persian religion, descended from Persian refugees settled
in India; a fire worshiper; a Gheber.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The Iranian dialect of much of the religious
literature of the Parsees.</def>

<hw>Par"see*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
religion and customs of the Parsees.</def>

<hw>Pars"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
parses.</def>

<hw>Par`si*mo"ni*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>parcimonieux</ets>. See <er>Parsimony</er>.]</ety>
<def>Exhibiting parsimony; sparing in expenditure of money;
frugal to excess; penurious; niggardly; stingy.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Par`si*mo"ni*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Par`si*mo"ni*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<q>A prodigal king is nearer a tyrant than a
<qex>parsimonious</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Extraordinary funds for one campaign may spare us the expense
of many years; whereas a long, <qex>parsimonious</qex> war will
drain us of more men and money.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Covetous; niggardly; miserly; penurious; close;
saving; mean; stingy; frugal. See <er>Avaricious</er>.</syn>

<hw>Par"si*mo*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>parsimonia</ets>, <ets>parcimonia</ets>; cf.
<ets>parcere</ets> to spare, <ets>parsus</ets> sparing: cf. F.
<ets>parcimonie</ets>.]</ety> <def>Closeness or sparingness in
the expenditure of money; -- generally in a bad sense; excessive
frugality; niggardliness.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Awful <qex>parsimony</qex> presided generally at the
table.</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Economy; frugality; illiberality; covetousness;
closeness; stinginess. See <er>Economy</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pars"ley</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>persely</ets>, <ets>persil</ets>, F. <ets>persil</ets>, L.
<ets>petroselinum</ets> rock parsley, Gr. <?/; <?/ stone + <?/
parsley. Cf. <er>Celery</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An
aromatic umbelliferous herb (<spn>Carum Petroselinum</spn>),
having finely divided leaves which are used in cookery and as a
garnish.</def>

<q>As she went to the garden for <qex>parsley</qex>, to stuff a
rabbit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Fool's parsley</col>. <cd>See under <er>Fool</er>.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Hedge parsley</col>, <col>Milk parsley</col>,
<col>Stone parsley</col></mcol>, <cd>names given to various weeds
of similar appearance to the parsley.</cd> -- <col>Parsley
fern</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a small fern with leaves
resembling parsley (<spn>Cryptogramme crispa</spn>).</cd> --
<col>Parsley piert</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a small herb
(<spn>Alchemilla arvensis</spn>) formerly used as a remedy for
calculus.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pars"nip</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>parsnepe</ets>, from a French form, fr. L.
<ets>pastinaca</ets>; cf. <ets>pastinare</ets> to dig up,
<ets>pastinum</ets> a kind of dibble; cf. OF.
<ets>pastenade</ets>, <ets>pastenaque</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The aromatic and edible spindle-shaped
root of the cultivated form of the <xex>Pastinaca sativa</xex>, a
biennial umbelliferous plant which is very poisonous in its wild
state; also, the plant itself.</def>

<cs><col>Cow parsnip</col>. <cd>See <er>Cow parsnip</er>.</cd> --
<col>Meadow parsnip</col>, <cd>the European cow parsnip.</cd> --
<col>Poison parsnip</col>, <cd>the wild stock of the
parsnip.</cd> -- <col>Water parsnip</col>, <cd>any plant of the
umbelliferous genus <spn>Sium</spn>, the species of which are
poisonous.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"son</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>persone</ets> person, parson, OF. <ets>persone</ets>, F.
<ets>personne</ets> person, LL. <ets>persona</ets> (sc.
<ets>ecclesiae</ets>), fr. L. <ets>persona</ets> a person. See
<er>Person</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Eccl. Law)</fld> <def>A person who
represents a parish in its ecclesiastical and corporate
capacities; hence, the rector or incumbent of a parochial church,
who has full possession of all the rights thereof, with the cure
of souls.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any clergyman having ecclesiastical preferment;
one who is in orders, or is licensed to preach; a preacher.</def>

<q>He hears the <qex>parson</qex> pray and preach.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<cs><col>Parson bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a New
Zealand bird (<spn>Prosthemadera Nov\'91seelandi\'91</spn>)
remarkable for its powers of mimicry and its ability to
articulate words. Its color is glossy black, with a curious tuft
of long, curly, white feathers on each side of the throat. It is
often kept as a cage bird.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"son*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Eng. Eccl. Law)</fld> <def>A certain portion of lands,
tithes, and offerings, for the maintenance of the parson of a
parish.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The glebe and house, or the house only, owned by
a parish or ecclesiastical society, and appropriated to the
maintenance or use of the incumbent or settled pastor.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Money paid for the support of a parson.</def>
<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<q>What have I been paying stipend and teind,
<qex>parsonage</qex> and vicarage, for?</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<hw>Par"soned</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Furnished
with a parson.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Par*son"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Par*son"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to a
parson; clerical.</def>

<q>Vainglory glowed in his <qex>parsonic</qex> heart.</q>
<qau>Colman.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Par*son"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Par"son*ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Appropriate
to, or like, a parson; -- used in disparagement.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Part</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>part</ets>, L. <ets>pars</ets>, gen. <ets>partis</ets>; cf.
<ets>parere</ets> to bring forth, produce. Cf. <er>Parent</er>,
<er>Depart</er>, <er>Parcel</er>, <er>Partner</er>,
<er>Party</er>, <er>Portion</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of
the portions, equal or unequal, into which anything is divided,
or regarded as divided; something less than a whole; a number,
quantity, mass, or the like, regarded as going to make up, with
others, a larger number, quantity, mass, etc., whether actually
separate or not; a piece; a fragment; a fraction; a division; a
member; a constituent.</def>

<q>And kept back <qex>part</qex> of the price, . . . and brought
a certain <qex>part</qex> and laid it at the apostles'feet.</q>
<qau>Acts v. 2.</qau>

<q>Our ideas of extension and number -- do they not contain a
secret relation of the <qex>parts</qex> ?</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>I am a <qex>part</qex> of all that I have met.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> Hence, specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An equal
constituent portion; one of several or many like quantities,
numbers, etc., into which anything is divided, or of which it is
composed; proportional division or ingredient.</def>

<q>An homer is the tenth <qex>part</qex> of an ephah.</q>
<qau>Ex. xvi. 36.</qau>

<q>A thought which, quartered, hath but one <qex>part</qex>
wisdom,
And ever three <qex>parts</qex> coward.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A constituent portion of a living or spiritual
whole; a member; an organ; an essential element</def>.

<q>All the <qex>parts</qex> were formed . . . into one harmonious
body.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>The pulse, the glow of every <qex>part</qex>.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A constituent of character or capacity;
quality; faculty; talent; -- usually in the plural with a
collective sense</def>. \'bdMen of considerable
<xex>parts</xex>.\'b8 <au>Burke</au>. \'bdGreat quickness of
<xex>parts</xex>.\'b8 <au>Macaulay</au>.

<q>Which maintained so politic a state of evil, that they will
not admit any good <qex>part</qex> to intermingle with them.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(d)</sd> <def>Quarter; region; district; -- usually in the
plural</def>. \'bdThe uttermost <xex>part</xex> of the
heaven.\'b8  <au>Neh. i. 9</au>.

<q>All <qex>parts</qex> resound with tumults, plaints, and
fears.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sd>(e)</sd> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Such portion of any
quantity, as when taken a certain number of times, will exactly
make that quantity; as, 3 is a <xex>part</xex> of 12; -- the
opposite of <xex>multiple</xex>. Also, a line or other element of
a geometrical figure.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which belongs to one, or which is assumed
by one, or which falls to one, in a division or apportionment;
share; portion; lot; interest; concern; duty; office.</def>

<q>We have no <qex>part</qex> in David.</q>
<qau>2 Sam. xx. 1.</qau>

<q>Accuse not Nature! she hath done her <qex>part</qex>;
Do thou but thine.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Let me bear
My <qex>part</qex> of danger with an equal share.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> Hence, specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>One of the
opposing parties or sides in a conflict or a controversy; a
faction.</def>

<q>For he that is not against us is on our <qex>part</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mark ix. 40.</qau>

<q>Make whole kingdoms take her brother's <qex>part</qex>.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A particular character in a drama or a play; an
assumed personification; also, the language, actions, and
influence of a character or an actor in a play; or, figuratively,
in real life. See <cref>To act a part</cref>, under
<er>Act</er>.</def>

<q>That <qex>part</qex>
Was aptly fitted and naturally performed.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>It was a brute <qex>part</qex> of him to kill so capital a
calf.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Honor and shame from no condition rise;
Act well your <qex>part</qex>, there all the honor lies.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>One of the different melodies
of a concerted composition, which heard in union compose its
harmony; also, the music for each voice or instrument; <as>as,
the treble, tenor, or bass <ex>part</ex>; the violin
<ex>part</ex>, etc</as>.</def>

<cs><col>For my part</col>, <cd>so far as concerns me; for my
share.</cd> -- <col>For the most part</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Most</er>, <pos>a.</pos></cd> -- <col>In good part</col>,
<cd>as well done; favorably; acceptably; in a friendly
manner.</cd> <au>Hooker</au>. <col>In ill part</col>,
<cd>unfavorably; with displeasure.</cd> -- <col>In part</col>,
<cd>in some degree; partly.</cd> -- <col>Part and parcel</col>,
<cd>an essential or constituent portion; -- a reduplicative
phrase. Cf. <cref>might and main</cref>, <cref>kith and
kin</cref>, etc. \'bdShe was . . . <xex>part and parcel<xex> of
the race and place.\'b8 <au>Howitt</au>.</cd> -- <col>Part of
speech</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>a sort or class of words of
a particular character; thus, the noun is a <xex>part of
speech<xex> denoting the name of a thing; the verb is a <xex>part
of speech<xex> which asserts something of the subject of a
sentence.</cd> -- <col>Part owner</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>one
of several owners or tenants in common. See <cref>Joint
tenant</cref>, under <er>Joint</er>.</cd> -- <col>Part
singing</col>, <cd>singing in which two or more of the harmonic
parts are taken.</cd> -- <col>Part song</col>, <cd>a song in two
or more (commonly four) distinct vocal parts. \'bdA <xex>part
song<xex> differs from a madrigal in its exclusion of
contrapuntual devices; from a glee, in its being sung by many
voices, instead of by one only, to each part.\'b8 <au>Stainer &
Barrett</au>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Portion; section; division; fraction; fragment;
piece; share; constituent. See <er>Portion</er>, and
<er>Section</er>.</syn>

<hw>Part</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Parted</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Parting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>partir</ets>, L. <ets>partire</ets>, <ets>partiri</ets>, p.
p. <ets>partitus</ets>, fr. <ets>pars</ets>, gen.
<ets>partis</ets>, a part. See <er>Part</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To divide; to separate into distinct parts; to
break into two or more parts or pieces; to sever.</def> \'bdThou
shalt <xex>part</xex> it in pieces.\'b8

<au>Lev. ii. 6.</au>

<q>There, [celestial love] <qex>parted</qex> into rainbow
hues.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To divide into shares; to divide and distribute;
to allot; to apportion; to share.</def>

<q>To <qex>part</qex> his throne, and share his heaven with
thee.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>They <qex>parted</qex> my raiment among them.</q>
<qau>John xix. 24.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To separate or disunite; to cause to go apart;
to remove from contact or contiguity; to sunder.</def>

<q>The Lord do so to me, and more also, if aught but death
<qex>part</qex> thee and me.</q>
<qau>Ruth i. 17.</qau>

<q>While he blessed them, he was <qex>parted</qex> from them, and
carried up into heaven.</q>
<qau>Luke xxiv. 51.</qau>

<q>The narrow seas that <qex>part</qex>
The French and English.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Hence: To hold apart; to stand between; to
intervene betwixt, as combatants.</def>

<q>The stumbling night did <qex>part</qex> our weary powers.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To separate by a process of extraction,
elimination, or secretion; <as>as, to <ex>part</ex> gold from
silver</as>.</def>

<q>The liver minds his own affair, . . .
And <qex>parts</qex> and strains the vital juices.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To leave; to quit.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Since presently your souls must <qex>part</qex> your
bodies.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To part a cable</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to break
it.</cd> -- <col>To part company</col>, <cd>to separate, as
travelers or companions.</cd></cs>

<hw>Part</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be broken or
divided into parts or pieces; to break; to become separated; to
go asunder; <as>as, rope <ex>parts</ex>; his hair <ex>parts</ex>
in the middle.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To go away; to depart; to take leave; to quit
each other; hence, to die; -- often with <xex>from</xex>.</def>

<q>He wrung Bassanio's hand, and so they <qex>parted</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>He owned that he had <qex>parted</qex> from the duke only a
few hours before.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<q>His precious bag, which he would by no means <qex>part</qex>
from.</q>
<qau>G. Eliot.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To perform an act of parting; to relinquish a
connection of any kind; -- followed by <xex>with</xex> or
<xex>from</xex>.</def>

<q>Celia, for thy sake, I <qex>part</qex>
With all that grew so near my heart.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<q>Powerful hands . . . will not <qex>part</qex>
Easily from possession won with arms.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>It was strange to him that a father should feel no tenderness
at <qex>parting</qex> with an only son.</q>
<qau>A. Trollope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To have a part or share; to partake.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThey shall <xex>part</xex> alike.\'b8

<au>1 Sam. xxx. 24.</au>

<hw>Part</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Partly; in a measure.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Part"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Partible</er>.</def>

<au>Camden.</au>

<hw>Part"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. See
<er>Part</er>, <pos>v.</pos> & <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Division; the act of dividing or sharing.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Part; portion; share.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Ford.</au>

<hw>Par*take"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp.</pos> <er>Partook</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. p.</pos> <er>Partaken</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. &
vb. n.</pos> <er>Partaking</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[<ets>Part</ets> + <ets>take</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To take a part, portion, lot, or share, in
common with others; to have a share or part; to participate; to
share; <as>as, to <ex>partake</ex> of a feast with
others</as>.</def> \'bdBrutes <xex>partake</xex> in this
faculty.\'b8

<au>Locke.</au>

<q>When I against myself with thee <qex>partake</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have something of the properties, character,
or office; -- usually followed by <xex>of</xex>.</def>

<q>The attorney of the Duchy of Lancaster <qex>partakes</qex>
partly of a judge, and partly of an attorney-general.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<-- p. 1046 -->

<hw>Par*take"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To partake of; to have a part or share in; to share.</def>

<q>Let every one <qex>partake</qex> the general joy.</q>
<qau>Driden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To admit to a share; to cause to participate; to
give a part to.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spencer.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To distribute; to communicate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Par*tak"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who partakes; a sharer; a participator.</def>

<q><qex>Partakers</qex> of their spiritual things.</q>
<qau>Rom. xv. 27.</qau>

<q>Wish me <qex>partaker</qex> in my happiness.</q>
<qau>Shark.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An accomplice; an associate; a partner.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Partakers</qex> wish them in the blood of the
prophets.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxiii. 30.</qau>

<hw>Par"tan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Ir. &
Gael. <ets>partan</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An
edible British crab.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Part"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Separated; devided.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Endowed with parts or abilities.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Cleft so that the divisions
reach nearly, but not quite, to the midrib, or the base of the
blade; -- said of a leaf, and used chiefly in composition;
<as>as, three-<ex>parted</ex>, five-<ex>parted</ex>,
etc</as>.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Part"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
which, parts or separates.</def>

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<hw>Par*terre"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
<ets>par</ets> on, by (L. <ets>per</ets>)+<ets>terre</ets> earth,
ground, L. <ets>terra</ets>. See <er>Terrace</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Hort.)</fld> <def>An ornamental and diversified
arrangement of beds or plots, in which flowers are cultivated,
with intervening spaces of gravel or turf for walking on.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The pit of a theater; the parquet.</def>
<mark>[France]</mark>

<hw>Par*the"ni*ad</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Parthenic</er>.]</ety> <def>A poem in honor of a
virgin.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Par*then"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/ a maid, virgin.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Spartan Partheni\'91, or sons of unmarried women.</def>

<hw>Par`the*no*gen"e*sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <grk>parqe`nos</grk> a virgin + E.
<ets>genesis</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld>
<def>The production of new individuals from virgin females by
means of ova which have the power of developing without the
intervention of the male element; the production, without
fertilization, of cells capable of germination. It is one of the
phenomena of alternate generation. Cf. <er>Heterogamy</er>, and
<er>Metagenesis</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The production of seed without
fertilization, believed to occur through the nonsexual formation
of an embryo extraneous to the embrionic vesicle.</def>

<hw>Par`the*no*ge*net"ic</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Biol.)</fld>
<def>Of, pertaining to, or produced by, parthenogenesis; <as>as,
<ex>parthenogenetic</ex> forms</as>.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Par`the*no*ge*net"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Par`the*no*gen"i*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Parthenogenetic.</def>

<hw>Par`the*nog"e*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Parthenogenesis</er>.</def>

<hw>Par"the*non</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
Gr. <grk>Parqenw`n</grk>, fr.<grk>parqe`nos</grk> a virgin, i.
e., Athene, the Greek goddess called also Pallas.]</ety> <def>A
celebrated marble temple of Athene, on the Acropolis at Athens.
It was of the pure Doric order, and has had an important
influence on art.</def>

<hw>\'d8Par*ten"o*pe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
the name of a Siren, fr. Gr. <?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gr.
Myth.)</fld> <def>One of the Sirens, who threw herself into the
sea, in despair at not being able to beguile Ulysses by her
songs.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of the asteroids between Mars and Jupiter,
descovered by M. de Gasparis in 1850.</def>

<hw>Par"thi*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to ancient Parthia, in Asia.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A native Parthia.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Parthian arrow</col>, <cd>an arrow discharged at an
enemy when retreating from him, as was the custom of the ancient
Parthians; hence, a parting shot.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. LL.
<ets>partials</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pars</ets>, gen.
<ets>partis</ets>, a part; cf. (for sense 1) F.
<ets>partiel</ets>. See <er>Part</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of, pertaining to, or affecting, a part only;
not general or universal; not total or entire; <as>as, a
<ex>partial</ex> eclipse of the moon</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Partial</xex> dissolutions of the earth.\'b8

<au>T. Burnet.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Inclined to favor one party in a cause, or one
side of a question, more then the other; baised; not indifferent;
<as>as, a judge should not be <ex>partial</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Ye have been <qex>partial</qex> in the law.</q>
<qau>Mal. ii. 9.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Having a predelection for; inclined to favor
unreasonably; foolishly fond.</def> \'bdA <xex>partial</xex>
parent.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<q>Not <qex>partial</qex> to an ostentatious display.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to a subordinate
portion; <as>as, a compound umbel is made up of a several
<ex>partial</ex> umbels; a leaflet is often supported by a
<ex>partial</ex> petiole.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Partial differentials</col>, <col>Partial
differential coefficients</col>, <col>Partial
differentiation</col></mcol>, <cd>etc. (of a function of two or
more variables), the differentials, differential coefficients,
differentiation etc., of the function, upon the hypothesis that
some of the variables are for the time constant.</cd> --
<col>Partial fractions</col> <fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>fractions
whose sum equals a given fraction.</cd> -- <col>Partial
tones</col> <fld>(Music)</fld>, <cd>the simple tones which in
combination form an ordinary tone; the overtones, or harmonics,
which, blending with a fundamental tone, cause its special
quality of sound, or <xex>timbre<xex>, or tone color. See, also,
<er>Tone</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"tial*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Partiality; specifically <fld>(Theol.)</fld>, the doctrine
of the Partialists.</def>

<hw>Par"tial*ist</hw> <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who is
partial.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>One who holds that the
atonement was made only for a part of mankind, that is, for the
elect.</def>

<hw>Par`ti*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>partialit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being partial; inclination to favor
one party, or one side of a question, more than the other; undue
bias of mind.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A predilection or inclination to one thing
rather than to others; special taste or liking; <as>as, a
<ex>partiality</ex> for poetry or painting</as>.</def>

<au>Roget.</au>

<hw>Par"tial*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos> <def>To
make or be partial.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Par"tial*ly</hw> <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In part;
not totally; <as>as, <ex>partially</ex> true; the sun
<ex>partially</ex> eclipsed.</as></def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In a partial manner; with undue bias of mind;
with unjust favor or dislike; <as>as, to judge
<ex>partially</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Part"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Par*tic"i*pate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Par*tic"i*pate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Participated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Participating</er>.]</wordforms> <def>Tj have a share in

<au>Shak.</au>

<qau>Hayward.</qau>

<q>Mine may come when men
With angels may <qex>participate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>Par*tic`i*pa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of participating, or sharing in

sorrows</as>.</def>

<q>These deities are so by <qex>participation</qex>.</q>

<q>What an honor, that God should admit us into such a blessed

<hw>Par`ti*cip"i*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>participialis</ets>: cf. E. <ets>participal</ets>. See
<er>Participle</er>.]</ety> <def>Having, or partaking of, the
nature and use of a participle; formed from a participle; <as>as,
a <ex>participial</ex> noun</as>.</def>

<au>Lowth.</au>

<hw>Par`ti*cip"i*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A participial
word.</def>

<hw>Par`ti*cip"i*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.p</pos> <er>Participialized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Participializing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To form into, or put
in the form of, a participle.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Par`ti*cip"i*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In the sense or
manner of a participle.</def>

<hw>Par"ti*ci*ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>participe</ets>, L. <ets>participium</ets>, fr.
<ets>particeps</ets> sharing, participant; <ets>pars</ets>, gen.
partis, a part + <ets>capere</ets> to take. See
<er>Participate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>
<def>A part of speech partaking of the nature both verb and
adjective; a form of a verb, or verbal adjective, modifying a
noun, but taking the adjuncts of the verb from which it is
derived. In the sentences: a letter is <xex>written</xex>;
<xex>being</xex> asleep he did not hear; <xex>exhausted</xex> by
toil he will sleep soundly, -- <xex>written</xex>,
<xex>being</xex>, and <xex>exhausted</xex>are
<xex>participles</xex>.</def>

<q>By a <qex>participle</qex>, [I understand] a verb in an
adjectival aspect.</q>
<qau>Earle.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Present participles</xex>, called also
<xex>imperfect</xex>, or <xex>incomplete</xex>,
<xex>participles</xex>, end in <xex>-ing</xex>. <xex>Past
participles</xex>, called also <xex>perfect</xex>, or
<xex>complete</xex>, <xex>participles</xex>, for the most part
end in <xex>-ed</xex>, <xex>-d</xex>, <xex>-t</xex>,
<xex>-en</xex>, or <xex>-n</xex>. A participle when used merely
as an attribute of a noun, without reference to time, is called
an <xex>adjective</xex>, or a <xex>participial adjective</xex>;
as, a <xex>written</xex> constitution; a <xex>rolling</xex>
stone; the <xex>exhausted</xex> army. The verbal noun in
<xex>-ing</xex> has the form of the present participle. See
<cref>Verbal noun</cref>, under <er>Verbal</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything that partakes of the nature of
different things.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>participles</qex> or confines between plants and
living creatures.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Par"ti*cle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>particula</ets>, dim of <ets>pars</ets>, gen
<ets>partis</ets>, a part: cf. F. <ets>particule</ets>. See
<er>Part</er>, and cf. <er>Parcel</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
minute part or portion of matter; a morsel; a little bit; an
atom; a jot; <as>as, a <ex>particle</ex> of sand, of wood, of
dust</as>.</def>

<q>The small size of atoms which unite
To make the smallest <qex>particle</qex> of light.</q>
<qau>Blackmore.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any very small portion or part; the smallest
portion; <as>as, he has not a <ex>particle</ex> of patriotism or
virtue</as>.</def>

<q>The houses had not given their commissioners authority in the
least <qex>particle</qex> to recede.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A crumb or
little piece of concecrated host.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
smaller hosts distributed in the communion of the laity.</def>

<au>Bp. Fitzpatrick.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>A subordinate word that is
never inflected (a preposition, conjunction, interjection); or a
word that can not be used except in compositions; <as>as,
<ex>ward</ex> in back<ex>ward</ex>, <ex>ly</ex> in
love<ex>ly</ex></as>.</def>

<-- elementary particle (Physics) -->

<hw>Par"ti*col`ored</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Party-colored</er>.</def>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>particuler</ets>, F. <ets>particulier</ets>, L.
<ets>particularis</ets>. See <er>Particle</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Relating to a part or portion of anything;
concerning a part separated from the whole or from others of the
class; separate; sole; single; individual; specific; <as>as, the
<ex>particular</ex> stars of a constellation</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>[/Make] each <qex>particular</qex> hair to stand an end,
Like quills upon the fretful porpentine.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Seken in every halk and every herne
<qex>Particular</qex> sciences for to lerne.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to a single person, class, or
thing; belonging to one only; not general; not common; hence,
personal; peculiar; singular.</def> \'bdThine own
<xex>particular</xex> wrongs.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Wheresoever one plant draweth such a <qex>particular</qex>
juice out of the earth.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Separate or distinct by reason of superiority;
distinguished; important; noteworthy; unusual; special; <as>as,
he brought no <ex>particular</ex> news; she was the
<ex>particular</ex> belle of the party.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Concerned with, or attentive to, details;
minute; circumstantial; precise; <as>as, a full and
<ex>particular</ex> account of an accident</as>; hence, nice;
fastidious; <as>as, a man <ex>particular</ex> in his
dress</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Containing a part
only; limited; <as>as, a <ex>particular</ex> estate, or one
precedent to an estate in remainder</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Holding a particular estate; <as>as, a <ex>particular</ex>
tenant</as>.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>Forming a part of a genus;
relatively limited in extension; affirmed or denied of a part of
a subject; <as>as, a <ex>particular</ex> proposition; -- opposed
to <contr>universal</contr>: e. g. (<ex>particular</ex>
affirmative) Some men are wise; (<ex>particular</ex> negative)
Some men are not wise.</as></def>

<cs><col>Particular average</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Average</er>.</cd> -- <col>Particular Baptist</col>, <cd>one
of a branch of the Baptist denomination the members of which hold
the doctrine of a particular or individual election and
reprobation.</cd> -- <col>Particular lien</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>,
<cd>a lien, or a right to retain a thing, for some charge or
claim growing out of, or connected with, that particular
thing.</cd> -- <col>Particular redemption</col>, <cd>the doctrine
that the purpose, act, and provisions of redemption are
restricted to a limited number of the human race. See
<er>Calvinism</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Minute; individual; respective; appropriate;
peculiar; especial; exact; specific; precise; critical;
circumstantial. See <er>Minute</er>.</syn>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A separate or distinct member of a class, or part of a
whole; an individual fact, point, circumstance, detail, or item,
which may be considered separately; <as>as, the
<ex>particulars</ex> of a story</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Particulars</qex> which it is not lawful for me to
reveal.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>It is the greatest interest of <qex>particulars</qex> to
advance the good of the community.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Special or personal peculiarity, trait, or
character; individuality; interest, etc.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>For his <qex>particular</qex> I'll receive him gladly.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>If the <qex>particulars</qex> of each person be
considered.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Temporal blessings, whether such as concern the public . . .
or such as concern our <qex>particular</qex>.</q>
<qau>Whole Duty of Man.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One of the details or items of
grounds of claim; -- usually in the <xex>pl</xex>.; also, a bill
of particulars; a minute account; <as>as, a <ex>particular</ex>
of premises</as>.</def>

<q>The reader has a <qex>particular</qex> of the books wherein
this law was written.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<cs><col>Bill of particulars</col>. <cd>See under <er>Bill</er>.
-- <col>In particular</col>, specially; peculiarly.</cd>
\'bdThis, <xex>in particular<xex>, happens to the lungs.\'b8
<au>Blackmore</au>. -- <col>To go into particulars</col>, <cd>to
relate or describe in detail or minutely.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>particularisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A minute
description; a detailed statement.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>The doctrine of particular
election.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(German Politics)</fld> <def>Devotion to the
interests of one's own kingdom or province rather than to those
of the empire.</def>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>particulariste</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who holds to
particularism.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Par*tic`u*lar*is"tic</wf>,
<pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Par*tic`u*lar"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Particularities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>particularit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or
quality of being particular; distinctiveness; circumstantiality;
minuteness in detail.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is particular</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Peculiar quality; individual characteristic;
peculiarity</def>. \'bdAn old heathen altar with this
<xex>particularity</xex>.\'b8 <au>Addison</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Special circumstance; minute detail; particular</def>.
\'bdEven descending to <xex>particularities</xex>.\'b8 <au>Sir P.
Sidney</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Something of special or private
concern or interest.</def>

<q>Let the general trumpet blow his blast,
<qex>Particularities</qex> and petty sounds
To cease!</q>
<qau>Shak</qau>.

<hw>Par*tic`u*lar*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>The act of particularizing.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Particularized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Particularizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>particulariser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To give as a particular,
or as the particulars; to mention particularly; to give the
particulars of; to enumerate or specify in detail.</def>

<q>He not only boasts of his parentage as an Israelite, but
<qex>particularizes</qex> his descent from Benjamin.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar*ize</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To mention or
attend to particulars; to give minute details; to be
circumstantial; <as>as, to <ex>particularize</ex> in a
narrative</as>.</def>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a
particular manner; expressly; with a specific reference or
interest; in particular; distinctly.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In an especial manner; in a high degree; <as>as,
a <ex>particularly</ex> fortunate man; a <ex>particularly</ex>
bad failure.</as></def>

<q>The exact propriety of Virgil I <qex>particularly</qex>
regarded as a great part of his character.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Par*tic"u*lar*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
particular; a detail.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Par*tic"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Particle</er>.]</ety> <def>To particularize.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Par*tic"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having the form of a particle.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Referring to, or produced by, particles, such as
dust, minute germs, etc.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The smallpox is a <qex>particulate</qex> disease.</q>
<qau>Tyndall.</qau>

<hw>Par"ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Part</er>, <pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Serving to
part; dividing; separating.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Given when departing; <as>as, a <ex>parting</ex>
shot; a <ex>parting</ex> salute.</as></def> \'bdGive him that
<xex>parting</xex> kiss.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Departing.</def> \'bdSpeed the
<xex>parting</xex> guest.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Admitting of being parted; partible.</def>

<cs><col>Parting fellow</col>, <cd>a partner. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<au>Chaucer</au>.</cd> -- <col>Parting pulley</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Pulley</er>.</cd> -- <col>Parting sand</col>
<fld>(Founding)</fld>, <cd>dry, nonadhesive sand, sprinkled upon
the partings of a mold to facilitate the separation.</cd> --
<col>Parting strip</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>in a sash
window, one of the thin strips of wood let into the pulley stile
to keep the sashes apart; also, the thin piece inserted in the
window box to separate the weights.</cd> -- <col>Parting
tool</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a thin tool, used in turning
or planing, for cutting a piece in two.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1047 -->

<hw>Par"ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of parting or dividing; the state of being parted;
division; separation.</def> \'bdThe <xex>parting</xex> of the
way.\'b8

<au>Ezek. xxi. 21.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A separation; a leave-taking.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>And there were sudden <qex>partings</qex>, such as press
The life from out young hearts.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A surface or line of separation where a division
occurs.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Founding)</fld> <def>The surface of the sand of
one section of a mold where it meets that of another
section.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The separation and
determination of alloys; esp., the separation, as by acids, of
gold from silver in the assay button.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A joint or fissure, as in a
coal seam.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>The breaking, as of a cable,
by violence.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Lamellar separation in a
crystallized mineral, due to some other cause than cleavage, as
to the presence of twinning lamell\'91.</def>

<hw>Par"ti*san</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. It.
<ets>partigiano</ets>. See <er>Party</er>, and cf.
<er>Partisan</er> a truncheon.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>partizan</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An adherent to a
party or faction; esp., one who is strongly and passionately
devoted to a party or an interest.</def> \'bdThe violence of a
<xex>partisan</xex>.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<q>Both sides had their <qex>partisans</qex> in the colony.</q>
<qau>Jefferson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The commander of
a body of detached light troops engaged in making forays and
harassing an enemy.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Any member of such a
corps.</def>

<hw>Par"ti*san</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Written also
<ets>partizan</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Adherent to a party
or faction; especially, having the character of blind,
passionate, or unreasonable adherence to a party; <as>as, blinded
by <ex>partisan</ex> zeal</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>Serving as a partisan in a
detached command; <as>as, a <ex>partisan</ex> officer or
corps</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Partisan ranger</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a member of
a partisan corps.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"ti*san</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pertuisane</ets>, prob. fr. It. <ets>partigiana</ets>,
influenced in French by OF. <ets>pertuisier</ets> to pierce. It
was prob. so named as the weapon of some <ets>partisans</ets>, or
party men. Cf. <er>Partisan</er> one of a corps of light
troops.]</ety> <def>A kind of halberd or pike; also, a truncheon;
a staff.</def>

<q>And make him with our pikes and <qex>partisans</qex> a
grave.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Par"ti*san*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of being a
partisan, or adherent to a party; feelings or conduct appropriate
to a partisan.</def>

<hw>\'d8Par*ti"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[It.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A suite; a set of
variations.</def>

<hw>Par"tite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>partitus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>partire</ets> to part, divide,
from <ets>pars</ets>. See <er>Part</er>, and cf. <er>Party</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Divided nearly to the
base; <as>as, a <ex>partite</ex> leaf is a simple separated down
nearly to the base</as>.</def>

<hw>Par*ti"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>partition</ets>, L. <ets>partitio</ets>. See <er>Part</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of parting or
dividing; the state of being parted; separation; division;
distribution; <as>as, the <ex>partition</ex> of a
kingdom</as>.</def>

<q>And good from bad find no <qex>partition</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which divides or separates; that by which
different things, or distinct parts of the same thing, are
separated; separating boundary; dividing line or space;
specifically, an interior wall dividing one part or apartment of
a house, an inclosure, or the like, from another; <as>as, a brick
<ex>partition</ex>; lath and plaster
<ex>partitions</ex>.</as></def>

<q>No sight could pass
Betwixt the nice <qex>partitions</qex> of the grass.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A part divided off by walls; an apartment; a
compartment.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdLodged in a small
<xex>partition</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law.)</fld> <def>The servance of common or
undivided interests, particularly in real estate. It may be
effected by consent of parties, or by compulsion of law.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A score.</def>

<cs><col>Partition of numbers</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>the
resolution of integers into parts subject to given
conditions.</cd></cs>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<hw>Par*ti"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Partitioned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Partitioning</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To divide
into parts or shares; to divide and distribute; <as>as, to
<ex>partition</ex> an estate among various heirs</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To divide into distinct parts by lines, walls,
etc.; <as>as, to <ex>partition</ex> a house</as>.</def>

<q>Uniform without, though severally <qex>partitioned</qex>
within.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

act of partitioning.</def>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<au>1 Cor. xi. 18.</au>

<hw>Part"ner</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>parcener</ets>, influenced by <ets>part</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who has a part in anything with an other; a
partaker; an associate; a sharer. \'bd<xex>Partner</xex> of his
fortune.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au> Hence: <sd>(a)</sd> A husband or a
wife. <sd>(b)</sd> Either one of a couple who dance together.
<sd>(c)</sd> One who shares as a member of a partnership in the
management, or in the gains and losses, of a business.</def>

<q>My other self, the <qex>partner</qex> of my life.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An associate in any business or
occupation; a member of a partnership. See
<er>Partnership</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A framework
of heavy timber surrounding an opening in a deck, to strengthen
it for the support of a mast, pump, capstan, or the like.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Dormant</col>, <or/ <col>Silent</col>,
<col>partner</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Dormant</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Associate; colleague; coadjutor; confederate;
partaker; participator; companion; comrade; mate.</syn>

<hw>Part"ner</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To associate, to
join.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Part"ner*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state
or condition of being a partner; <as>as, to be in
<ex>partnership</ex> with another; to have <ex>partnership</ex>
in the fortunes of a family or a state.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A division or sharing among partners; joint
possession or interest.</def>

<q>Rome, that ne'er knew three lordly heads before,
First fell by fatal <qex>partnership</qex> of power.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<q>He does possession keep,
And is too wise to hazard <qex>partnership</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An alliance or association of persons for the
prosecution of an undertaking or a business on joint account; a
company; a firm; a house; <as>as, to form a
<ex>partnership</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A contract between two or more
competent persons for joining together their money, goods, labor,
and skill, or any or all of them, under an understanding that
there shall be a communion of profit between them, and for the
purpose of carrying on a legal trade, business, or
adventure.</def>

<au>Kent. Story.</au>

<note><hand/ Community of profit is absolutely essential to,
though not necessary the test of, a partnership.</note>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Arith.)</fld> <def>See <er>Fellowship</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 6.</def>

<cs><col>Limited partnership</col>, <cd>a form of partnership in
which the firm consists of one or more general partners, jointly
and severally responsible as ordinary partners, and one or more
special partners, who are not liable for the debts of the
partnership beyond the amount of cash they contribute as
capital.</cd> -- <col>Partnership in commendam</col>, <cd>the
title given to the limited partnership (F. <xex>soci\'82t\'82 en
commandit\'82<xex>) of the French law, introduced into the code
of Louisiana. <au>Burrill</au>.</cd> -- <col>Silent
partnership</col>, <cd>the relation of partnership sustained by a
person who furnishes capital only.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par*took"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <def><pos>imp.</pos> of
<er>Partake</er>.</def>

<hw>Par"tridge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>partriche</ets>, <ets>pertriche</ets>, OF.
<ets>pertris</ets>, <ets>perdriz</ets>, F. <ets>perdrix</ets>, L.
<ets>perdix</ets>, <ets>-icis</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any one of numerous
species of small gallinaceous birds of the genus
<spn>Perdix</spn> and several related genera of the family
<spn>Perdicid\'91</spn>, of the Old World. The partridge is noted
as a game bird.</def>

<q>Full many a fat <qex>partrich</qex> had he in mew.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<note><hand/ The common European, or gray, partridge (<spn>Perdix
cinerea</spn>) and the red-legged partridge (<spn>Caccabis
rubra</spn>) of Southern Europe and Asia are well-known
species.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any one of several species of quail-like birds
belonging to <spn>Colinus</spn>, and allied genera.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<note><hand/ Among them are the bobwhite (<spn>Colinus
Virginianus</spn>) of the Eastern States; the plumed, or
mountain, partridge (<spn>Oreortyx pictus</spn>) of California;
the Massena partridge (<spn>Cyrtonyx Montezum\'91</spn>); and the
California partridge (<spn>Callipepla Californica</spn>).</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The ruffed grouse (<spn>Bonasa
umbellus</spn>).</def> <mark>[New Eng.]</mark>

<cs><col>Bamboo partridge</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
spurred partridge of the genus <spn>Bambusicola</spn>. Several
species are found in China and the East Indies.</cd> --
<col>Night partridge</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
woodcock.</cd> <mark>[Local, U.S.]</mark> -- <col>Painted
partridge</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a francolin of
South Africa (<spn>Francolinus pictus</spn>).</cd> --
<col>Partridge berry</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The scarlet berry of a trailing american plant
(<spn>Mitchella repens</spn>) of the order
<spn>Rubiace\'91</spn>, having roundish evergreen leaves, and
white fragrant flowers sometimes tinged with purple, growing in
pairs with the ovaries united, and producing the berries which
remain over winter; also, the plant itself</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The fruit of the creeping wintergreen (<spn>Gaultheria
procumbens</spn>); also, the plant itself.</cd> -- <col>Partridge
dove</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>Same as <cref>Mountain
witch</cref>, under <er>Mountain</er>.</cd> -- <col>Partridge
pea</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a yellow-flowered leguminous
herb (<spn>Cassia Cham\'91crista</spn>), common in sandy fields
in the Eastern United States.</cd> -- <col>Partridge shell</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large marine univalve shell
(<spn>Dolium perdix</spn>), having colors variegated like those
of the partridge.</cd> -- <col>Partridge wood</col> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A variegated wood, much esteemed for cabinetwork. It is
obtained from tropical America, and one source of it is said to
be the leguminous tree <spn>Andira inermis</spn>.</cd> Called
also <altname>pheasant wood</altname>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A name
sometimes given to the dark-colored and striated wood of some
kind of palm, which is used for walking sticks and umbrella
handles.</cd> -- <col>Sea partridge</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>an Asiatic sand partridge (<spn>Ammoperdix Bonhami</spn>); --
so called from its note.</cd> -- <col>Snow partridge</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large spurred partridge (<spn>Lerwa
nivicola</spn>) which inhabits the high mountains of Asia.</cd>
-- <col>Spruce partridge</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Spruce</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Wood partridge</col>, <or/
<col>Hill partridge</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
small Asiatic partridge of the genus
<spn>Arboricola</spn>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Departure.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Par*tu"ri*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Parturient</er>.]</ety> <def>To bring forth young.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Par*tu"ri*en*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Parturition.</def>

<hw>Par*tu"ri*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>parturiens</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>parturire</ets> to desire to
bring forth, fr. <ets>parere</ets>, <ets>partum</ets>, to bring
forth. See <er>Parent</er>.]</ety> <def>Bringing forth, or about
to bring forth, young; fruitful.</def>

<au>Jer. Tailor.</au>

<hw>Par*tu`ri*fa"cient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>parturire</ets> to desire to bring forth + <ets>facere</ets>
to make.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A medicine tending to
cause parturition, or to give relief in childbearing.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>Par*tu"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Parturient.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>Par`tu*ri"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>parturitio</ets>, fr. <ets>parturire</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>parturition</ets>. See <er>Parturient</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of bringing forth, or being delivered
of, young; the act of giving birth; delivery; childbirth.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is brought forth; a birth.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Par*tu"ri*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to parturition; obstetric.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Par"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Parties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F. <ets>parti</ets>
and <ets>partie</ets>, fr. F. <ets>partir</ets> to part, divide,
L. <ets>partire</ets>, <ets>partiri</ets>. See <er>Part</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A part or portion.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe most <xex>party</xex> of the
time.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A number of persons united in opinion or action,
as distinguished from, or opposed to, the rest of a community or
association; esp., one of the parts into which a people is
divided on questions of public policy.</def>

<q>Win the noble Brutus to our <qex>party</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The peace both <qex>parties</qex> want is like to last.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A part of a larger body of company; a
detachment; especially <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, a small body of troops
dispatched on special service.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A number of persons invited to a social
entertainment; a select company; <as>as, a dinner
<ex>party</ex></as>; also, the entertainment itself; <as>as, to
give a <ex>party</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>One concerned or interested in an affair; one
who takes part with others; a participator; <as>as, he was a
<ex>party</ex> to the plot; a <ex>party</ex> to the
contract.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The plaintiff or the defendant in a lawsuit,
whether an individual, a firm, or corporation; a litigant.</def>

<q>The cause of both <qex>parties</qex> shall come before the
judges.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxii. 9.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Hence, any certain person who is regarded as
being opposed or antagonistic to another.</def>

<q>It the jury found that the <qex>party</qex> slain was of
English race, it had been adjudged felony.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Davies.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Cause; side; interest.</def>

<q>Have you nothing said
Upon this <qex>Party</qex> 'gainst the Duke of Albany?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>A person; <as>as, he is a queer
<ex>party</ex></as>.</def> <mark>[Now accounted a
vulgarism.]</mark>

<note>
\'bdFor several generations, our ancestors largely employed
<xex>party</xex> for <xex>person</xex>; but this use of the word,
when it appeared to be reviving, happened to strike, more
particularly, the fancy of the vulgar; and the consequence has
been, that the polite have chosen to leave it in their undisputed
possession.\'b8
<au>Fitzed. Hall.</au></note>

<cs><col>Party jury</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a jury composed
of different parties, as one which is half natives and half
foreigners.</cd> -- <col>Party man</col>, <cd>a partisan.
<au>Swift</au>.</cd> -- <col>Party spirit</col>, <cd>a factious
and unreasonable temper, not uncommonly shown by party men.
<au>Whately</au>.</cd> -- <col>Party verdict</col>, <cd>a joint
verdict. <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>Party wall</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <cd>A wall built upon the
dividing line between two adjoining properties, usually having
half its thickness on each property</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>A wall that separates adjoining houses, as
in a block or row.</cd></cs>

<hw>Par"ty</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>parti</ets> divided,
fr. <ets>partir</ets> to divide. See <er>Part</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>, and cf. <er>Partite</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Parted or divided, as in the direction or
form of one of the ordinaries; <as>as, an escutcheon
<ex>party</ex> per pale</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Partial; favoring one party.</def><-- partisan
-->

<hw>\'d8Pa*ru"si*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,

<hw>Pa*sha"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Turk.
<ets>p\'besh\'be</ets>, <ets>b\'besh\'be</ets>; cf. Per.
<ets>b\'besh\'be</ets>, <ets>b\'bedsh\'beh</ets>; perh. a
corruption of Per. <ets>p\'bedish\'beh</ets>. Cf.
<er>Bashaw</er>, <er>Padishah</er>, <er>Shah</er>.]</ety> <def>An
honorary title given to officers of high rank in Turkey, as to
governers of provinces, military commanders, etc. The earlier
form was <altname>bashaw</altname>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pacha</asp>.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ There are three classes of pashas, whose rank is
distinguished by the number of the horsetails borne on their
standards, being one, two, or three, a <xex>pasha</xex> of three
tails being the highest.</note>

several plants of the genus <spn>Anemone</spn>, section
<spn>Pulsatilla</spn>. They are perennial herbs with rather large
purplish blossoms, which appear in early spring, or about Easter,
whence the common name. Called also
<altname>campana</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pas"quin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.
<ets>pasquino</ets> a mutilated statue at Rome, set up against
the wall of the place of the Orsini; -- so called from a witty
cobbler or tailor, near whose shop the statue was dug up. On this
statue it was customary to paste satiric papers.]</ety> <def>A
lampooner; also, a lampoon. See <er>Pasquinade</er>.</def>

<q>The Grecian wits, who satire first began,
Were pleasant <qex>pasquins</qex> on the life of man.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>
