<hw>Pass</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Passed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Passing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[F. <ets>passer</ets>, LL. <ets>passare</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>passus</ets> step, or from <ets>pandere</ets>,
<ets>passum</ets>, to spread out, lay open. See
<er>Pace</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To go; to move; to
proceed; to be moved or transferred from one point to another; to
make a transit; -- usually with a following adverb or adverbal
phrase defining the kind or manner of motion; <as>as, to
<ex>pass</ex> on, by, out, in, etc.; to <ex>pass</ex> swiftly,
directly, smoothly, etc.; to <ex>pass</ex> to the rear, under the
yoke, over the bridge, across the field, beyond the border,
etc.</as></def>  \'bdBut now <xex>pass</xex> over [i.e.,
<xex>pass</xex> on].\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>On high behests his angels to and fro
<qex>Passed</qex> frequent.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Sweet sounds rose slowly through their mouths,
And from their bodies <qex>passed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To move or be transferred from one state or
condition to another; to change possession, condition, or
circumstances; to undergo transition; <as>as, the business has
<ex>passed</ex> into other hands</as>.</def>

<q>Others, dissatisfied with what they have, . . .
<qex>pass</qex> from just to unjust.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To move beyond the range of the senses or of
knowledge; to pass away; hence, to disappear; to vanish; to
depart; specifically, to depart from life; to die.</def>

<q>Disturb him not, let him <qex>pass</qex> paceably.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Beauty is a charm, but soon the charm will
<qex>pass</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>The <qex>passing</qex> of the sweetest soul
That ever looked with human eyes.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To move or to come into being or under notice;
to come and go in consciousness; hence, to take place; to occur;
to happen; to come; to occur progressively or in succession; to
be present transitorly.</def>

<q>So death <qex>passed</qex> upon all men.</q>
<qau>Rom. v. 12.</qau>

<q>Our own consciousness of what <qex>passes</qex> within our own
mind.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To go by or glide by, as time; to elapse; to be
spent; <as>as, their vacation <ex>passed</ex>
pleasantly</as>.</def>

<q>Now the time is far <qex>passed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mark vi. 35</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To go from one person to another; hence, to be
given and taken freely; <as>as, clipped coin will not
<ex>pass</ex></as>; to obtain general acceptance; to be held or
regarded; to circulate; to be current; -- followed by
<xex>for</xex> before a word denoting value or estimation.</def>
\'bdLet him <xex>pass</xex> for a man.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>False eloquence <qex>passeth</qex> only where true is not
understood.</q>
<qau>Felton.</qau>

<q>This will not <qex>pass</qex> for a fault in him.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To advance through all the steps or stages
necessary to validity or effectiveness; to be carried through a
body that has power to sanction or reject; to receive legislative
sanction; to be enacted; <as>as, the resolution <ex>passed</ex>;
the bill <ex>passed</ex> both houses of Congress.</as></def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To go through any inspection or test
successfully; to be approved or accepted; <as>as, he attempted
the examination, but did not expect to <ex>pass</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To be suffered to go on; to be tolerated; hence,
to continue; to live alogn.</def> \'bdThe play may
<xex>pass</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>To go unheeded or neglected; to proceed without
hindrance or opposition; <as>as, we let this act
<ex>pass</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>To go beyond bounds; to surpass; to be in
excess.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThis <xex>passes</xex>,
Master Ford.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>To take heed; to care.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>As for these silken-coated slaves, I <qex>pass</qex> not.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>To go through the intestines.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<sn>14.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To be conveyed or transferred
by will, deed, or other instrument of conveyance; <as>as, an
estate <ex>passes</ex> by a certain clause in a deed</as>.</def>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<sn>15.</sn> <fld>(Fencing)</fld> <def>To make a lunge or pass;
to thrust.</def>

<sn>16.</sn> <fld>(Card Playing)</fld> <def>To decline to play in
one's turn; in euchre, to decline to make the trump.</def>

<q>She would not play, yet must not <qex>pass</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>To bring to pass</col>, <col>To come to
pass</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Bring</er>, and
<er>Come</er>.</cd> -- <col>To pass away</col>, <cd>to disappear;
to die; to vanish. \'bdThe heavens shall <xex>pass away<xex>.\'b8
<au>2 Pet. iii. 10</au>. \'bdI thought to <xex>pass away<xex>
before, but yet alive I am.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>.</cd> --
<col>To pass by</col>, <cd>to go near and beyond a certain person
or place; as, he <xex>passed by<xex> as we stood there.</cd> --
<col>To pass into</col>, <cd>to change by a gradual transmission;
to blend or unite with.</cd> -- <col>To pass on</col>, <cd>to
proceed.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To pass on</col> <or/
<col>upon</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To happen to; to come
upon; to affect</cd>. \'bdSo death <xex>passed upon<xex> all
men.\'b8 <au>Rom. v. 12</au>. \'bdProvided no indirect act
<xex>pass upon<xex> our prayers to define them.\'b8 <au>Jer.
Taylor</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To determine concerning; to give
judgment or sentence upon.</cd> \'bdWe may not <xex>pass
upon<xex> his life.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>To pass
off</col>, <cd>to go away; to cease; to disappear; <as>as, an
agitation <ex>passes off<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>To pass
over</col>, <cd>to go from one side or end to the other; to
cross, as a river, road, or bridge.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pass</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> In
simple, transitive senses; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To go by,
beyond, over, through, or the like; to proceed from one side to
the other of; <as>as, to <ex>pass</ex> a house, a stream, a
boundary, etc</as></def>. <sd>(b)</sd> Hence: <def>To go from one
limit to the other of; to spend; to live through; to have
experience of; to undergo; to suffer</def>.</def> \'bdTo
<xex>pass</xex> commodiously this life.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>She loved me for the dangers I had <qex>passed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>To go by without noticing; to omit attention
to; to take no note of; to disregard</def>.

<q>Please you that I may <qex>pass</qex> This doing.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I <qex>pass</qex> their warlike pomp, their proud array.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sd>(d)</sd> <def>To transcend; to surpass; to excel; to
exceed</def>.

<q>And strive to <qex>pass</qex> . . . 
Their native music by her skillful art.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Whose tender power
<qex>Passes</qex> the strength of storms in their most desolate
hour.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sd>(e)</sd> <def>To go successfully through, as an examination,
trail, test, etc.; to obtain the formal sanction of, as a
legislative body; <as>as, he <ex>passed</ex> his examination; the
bill <ex>passed</ex> the senate</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> In causative senses: as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To cause
to move or go; to send; to transfer from one person, place, or
condition to another; to transmit; to deliver; to hand; to make
over; <as>as, the waiter <ex>passed</ex> bisquit and cheese; the
torch was <ex>passed</ex> from hand to hand</as></def>.

<q>I had only time to <qex>pass</qex> my eye over the medals.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>Waller <qex>passed</qex> over five thousand horse and foot by
Newbridge.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>To cause to pass the lips; to utter; to
pronounce; hence, to promise; to pledge; <as>as, to <ex>pass</ex>
sentence</as></def>.

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Father, thy word is <qex>passed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>To cause to advance by stages of progress; to
carry on with success through an ordeal, examination, or action;
specifically, to give legal or official sanction to; to ratify;
to enact; to approve as valid and just; <as>as, he
<ex>passed</ex> the bill through the committee; the senate
<ex>passed</ex> the law</as></def>. <sd>(e)</sd> <def>To put in
circulation; to give currency to; <as>as, to <ex>pass</ex>
counterfeit money</as></def>. \'bd<xex>Pass</xex> the happy
news.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>. <sd>(f)</sd> <def>To cause to obtain
entrance, admission, or conveyance; <as>as, to <ex>pass</ex> a
person into a theater, or over a railroad</as></def>.

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To emit from the bowels; to evacuate.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To take a turn with (a line,
gasket, etc.), as around a sail in furling, and make
secure.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Fencing)</fld> <def>To make, as a thrust,
punto, etc.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Passed midshipman</col>. <cd>See under Midshipman.</cd>
-- <col>To pass a dividend</col>, <cd>to omit the declaration and
payment of a dividend at the time when due.</cd> -- <col>To pass
away</col>, <cd>to spend; to waste. \'bdLest she <xex>pass
away<xex> the flower of her age.\'b8 <au>Ecclus. xlii.
9</au>.</cd><-- (b) to die --> -- <col>To pass by</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To disregard; to neglect</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>To excuse; to spare; to overlook.</cd> -- <col>To pass
off</col>, <cd>to impose fraudulently; to palm off.
\'bd<xex>Passed<xex> himself <xex>off<xex> as a bishop.\'b8
<au>Macaulay</au>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To pass (something)
on</col> <or/ <col>upon (some one)</col></mcol>, <cd>to put upon
as a trick or cheat; to palm off. \'bdShe <xex>passed<xex> the
child <xex>on<xex> her husband for a boy.\'b8
<au>Dryden</au>.</cd> -- <col>To pass over</col>, <cd>to
overlook; not to note or resent; as, to <xex>pass over<xex> an
affront.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pass</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pas</ets> (for
sense 1), and <ets>passe</ets>, fr. <ets>passer</ets> to pass.
See <er>Pass</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An
opening, road, or track, available for passing; especially, one
through or over some dangerous or otherwise impracticable
barrier; a passageway; a defile; a ford; <as>as, a mountain
<ex>pass</ex></as>.</def>

<q>\'bdTry not the <qex>pass</qex>!\'b8 the old man said.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fencing)</fld> <def>A thrust or push; an
attempt to stab or strike an adversary.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A movement of the hand over or along anything;
the manipulation of a mesmerist.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Rolling Metals)</fld> <def>A single passage of
a bar, rail, sheet, etc., between the rolls.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>State of things; condition; predicament.</def>

<q>Have his daughters brought him to this <qex>pass</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Matters have been brought to this <qex>pass</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Permission or license to pass, or to go and
come; a psssport; a ticket permitting free transit or admission;
<as>as, a railroad or theater <ex>pass</ex>; a military
<ex>pass</ex>.</as></def>

<q>A ship sailing under the flag and <qex>pass</qex> of an
enemy.</q>
<qau>Kent.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Fig.: a thrust; a sally of wit.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Estimation; character.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Common speech gives him a worthy <qex>pass</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <ety>[Cf. <er>Passus</er>.]</ety> <def>A part; a
division.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<cs><col>Pass boat</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a punt, or
similar boat.</cd> -- <col>Pass book</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A
book in which a trader enters articles bought on credit, and then
passes or sends it to the purchaser</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>See
<er>Bank book</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pass box</col>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a wooden or metallic box, used to carry
cartridges from the service magazine to the piece.</cd> --
<col>Pass check</col>, <cd>a ticket of admission to a place of
entertainment, or of readmission for one who goes away in
expectation of returning.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pass"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>passable</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being
passed, traveled, navigated, traversed, penetrated, or the like;
<as>as, the roads are not <ex>passable</ex>; the stream is
<ex>passable</ex>in boats.</as></def>

<q>His body's a <qex>passable</qex> carcass if it be not hurt; it
is a throughfare for steel.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being freely circulated or
disseminated; acceptable; generally receivable; current.</def>

<q>With men as with false money -- one piece is more or less
<qex>passable</qex> than another.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<q>Could they have made this slander <qex>passable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Collier.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Such as may be allowed to pass without serious
objection; tolerable; admissable; moderate; mediocre.</def>

<q>My version will appear a <qex>passable</qex> beauty when the
original muse is absent.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pass"a*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being
passable.</def>

<hw>Pass"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Tolerably;
moderately.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>\'d8Pas`sa*ca*glia</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>\'d8Pas`sa*ca*glio</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Sp. <ets>pasacalle</ets> a certain tune on the guitar,
prop., a tune played in passing through the streets.]</ety>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>An old Italian or Spanish dance tune, in
slow three-four measure, with divisions on a ground bass,
resembling a chaconne.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pas*sade"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pas*sa"do</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>passade</ets>;
cf. Sp. <ets>pasada</ets>. See <er>Pass</er>, <pos>v.
i.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Fencing)</fld> <def>A pass or
thrust.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Man.)</fld> <def>A turn or course of a horse
backward or forward on the same spot of ground.</def>

<hw>Pas"sage</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>passage</ets>. See <er>Pass</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of passing; transit from one place to
another; movement from point to point; a going by, over, across,
or through; <as>as, the <ex>passage</ex> of a man or a carriage;
the <ex>passage</ex> of a ship or a bird; the <ex>passage</ex> of
light; the <ex>passage</ex> of fluids through the pores or
channels of the body.</as></def>

<q>What! are my doors opposed against my <qex>passage</qex>!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Transit by means of conveyance; journey, as by
water, carriage, car, or the like; travel; right, liberty, or
means, of passing; conveyance.</def>

<q>The ship in which he had taken <qex>passage</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Price paid for the liberty to pass; fare;
<as>as, to pay one's <ex>passage</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Removal from life; decease; departure;
death.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdEndure thy mortal
<xex>passage</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>When he is fit and season'd for his <qex>passage</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Way; road; path; channel or course through or by
which one passes; way of exit or entrance; way of access or
transit. Hence, a common avenue to various apartments in a
building; a hall; a corridor.</def>

<q>And with his pointed dart
Explores the nearest <qex>passage</qex> to his heart.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>The Persian army had advanced into the . . .
<qex>passages</qex> of Cilicia.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A continuous course, process, or progress; a
connected or continuous series; <as>as, the <ex>passage</ex> of
time</as>.</def>

<q>The conduct and <qex>passage</qex> of affairs.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Davies.</qau>

<q>The <qex>passage</qex> and whole carriage of this action.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A separate part of a course, process, or series;
an occurrence; an incident; an act or deed.</def> \'bdIn thy
<xex>passages</xex> of life.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The . . . almost incredible <qex>passage</qex> of their
unbelief.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A particular portion constituting a part of
something continuous; esp., a portion of a book, speech, or
musical composition; a paragraph; a clause.</def>

<q>How commentators each dark <qex>passage</qex> shun.</q>
<qau>Young.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Reception; currency.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir K. Digby.</au>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>A pass or en encounter; <as>as, a
<ex>passage</ex> at arms</as>.</def>

<q>No <qex>passages</qex> of love
Betwixt us twain henceforward evermore.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>11.</sn> <def>A movement or an evacuation of the
bowels.</def>

<sn>12.</sn> <def>In parliamentary proceedings: <sd>(a)</sd> The
course of a proposition (bill, resolution, etc.) through the
several stages of consideration and action; <as>as, during its
<ex>passage</ex> through Congress the bill was amended in both
Houses</as>. <sd>(b)</sd> The advancement of a bill or other
proposition from one stage to another by an affirmative vote;
esp., the final affirmative action of the body upon a
proposition; hence, adoption; enactment; <as>as, the
<ex>passage</ex> of the bill to its third reading was
delayed</as>.</def> \'bdThe <xex>passage</xex> of the Stamp
Act.\'b8

<au>D. Hosack.</au>

<q>The final question was then put upon its
<qex>passage</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cushing.</qau>

<cs><col>In passage</col>, <cd>in passing; cursorily. \'bdThese .
. . have been studied but <xex>in passage<xex>.\'b8
<au>Bacon</au>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Middle passage</col>,
<col>Northeast passage</col>, <col>Northwest
passage</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Middle</er>,
<er>Northeast</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Of passage</col>,
<cd>passing from one place, region, or climate, to another;
migratory; -- said especially of birds \'bdBirds <xex>of
passage<xex>.\'b8 <au>Longfellow</au>.</cd>  -- <col>Passage
hawk</col>, <cd>a hawk taken on its passage or migration.</cd> --
<col>Passage money</col>, <cd>money paid for conveyance of a
passenger, -- usually for carrying passengers by water.</cd>
</cs>

<hw>\'d8Pas"se*res</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

all singing birds (Oscines), together with many other small
perching birds.</def>

<hw>Pas"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>passibilis</ets>, fr. <ets>pati</ets>, to suffer: cf. F.

<def>Susceptible of feeling or suffering, or of impressions from
external agents.</def>

<qex>passible</qex>.</q>

<au>Brerewood.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pas"si*flo"ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
from L. <ets>passio</ets> passion (fr. <ets>pati</ets>,
<ets>passus</ets>, to suffer) + <ets>flos</ets>,
<ets>floris</ets>, flower.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus
of plants, including the passion flower. It is the type of the
order <spn>Passiflore\'91</spn>, which includes about nineteen
genera and two hundred and fifty species.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pas"sim</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>Here and there; everywhere; <as>as, this
word occurs <ex>passim</ex> in the poem</as>.</def>

<hw>Pass"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of one
who, or that which, passes; the act of going by or away.</def>

<cs><col>Passing bell</col>, <cd>a tolling of a bell to announce
that a soul is passing, or has passed, from its body (formerly
done to invoke prayers for the dying); also, a tolling during the
passing of a funeral procession to the grave, or during funeral
ceremonies.</cd></cs>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>  <au>Longfellow.</au>

<hw>Pass"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Relating to the
act of passing or going; going by, beyond, through, or away;
departing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Exceeding; surpassing, eminent.</def>
<au>Chaucer</au>. \'bdHer <xex>passing</xex> deformity.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Passing note</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>a character
including a passing tone.</cd> -- <col>Passing tone</col>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>a tone introduced between two other tones,
on an unaccented portion of a measure, for the sake of smoother
melody, but forming no essential part of the harmony.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pass"ing</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Exceedingly; excessively;
surpassingly; <as>as, <ex>passing</ex> fair; <ex>passing</ex>
strange.</as></def> \'bdYou apprehend <xex>passing</xex>
shrewdly.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pass"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Exceedingly.</def>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>passio</ets>, fr. <ets>pati</ets>, <ets>passus</ets>, to
suffer. See <er>Patient</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A suffering
or enduring of imposed or inflicted pain; any suffering or
distress (as, a cardiac <xex>passion</xex>); specifically, the
suffering of Christ between the time of the last supper and his
death, esp. in the garden upon the cross.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>passions</xex> of this time.\'b8

<au>Wyclif (Rom. viii. 18).</au>

<q>To whom also he showed himself alive after his
<qex>passion</qex>, by many infallible proofs.</q>
<qau>Acts i. 3.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being acted upon; subjection to an
external agent or influence; a passive condition; -- opposed to
<xex>action</xex>.</def>

<q>A body at rest affords us no idea of any active power to move,
and, when set is motion, it is rather a <qex>passion</qex> than
an action in it.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Capacity of being affected by external agents;
susceptibility of impressions from external agents.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Moldable and not moldable, scissible and not scissible, and
many other <qex>passions</qex> of matter.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The state of the mind when it is powerfully
acted upon and influenced by something external to itself; the
state of any particular faculty which, under such conditions,
becomes extremely sensitive or uncontrollably excited; any
emotion or sentiment (specifically, love or anger) in a state of
abnormal or controlling activity; an extreme or inordinate
desire; also, the capacity or susceptibility of being so
affected; <as>as, to be in a <ex>passion</ex>; the
<ex>passions</ex> of love, hate, jealously, wrath, ambition,
avarice, fear, etc.; a <ex>passion</ex> for war, or for drink; an
orator should have <ex>passion</ex> as well as rhetorical
skill.</as></def>  \'bdA <xex>passion</xex> fond even to
idolatry.\'b8 <au>Macaulay</au>. \'bdHer <xex>passion</xex> is to
seek roses.\'b8

<au>Lady M. W. Montagu.</au>

<q>We also are men of like <qex>passions</qex> with you.</q>
<qau>Acts xiv. 15.</qau>

<q>The nature of the human mind can not be sufficiently
understood, without considering the affections and
<qex>passions</qex>, or those modifications or actions of the
mind consequent upon the apprehension of certain objects or
events in which the mind generally conceives good or evil.</q>
<qau>Hutcheson.</qau>

<q>The term <qex>passion</qex>, and its adverb
<qex>passionately</qex>, often express a very strong predilection
for any pursuit, or object of taste -- a kind of enthusiastic
fondness for anything.</q>
<qau>Cogan.</qau>

<q>The bravery of his grief did put me
Into a towering <qex>passion</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The ruling <qex>passion</qex>, be it what it will,
The ruling <qex>passion</qex> conquers reason still.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Who walked in every path of human life,
Felt every <qex>passion</qex>.</q>
<qau>Akenside.</qau>

<q>When statesmen are ruled by faction and interest, they can
have no <qex>passion</qex> for the glory of their country.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Disorder of the mind; madness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Passion week. See <cref>Passion week</cref>,
below.</def>

<au>R. of Gl.</au>

<cs><col>Passion flower</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any flower
or plant of the genus <spn>Passiflora</spn>; -- so named from a
fancied resemblance of parts of the flower to the instruments of
our Savior's crucifixion.</cd></cs>

<note><hand/ The flowers are showy, and the fruit is sometimes
highly esteemed (see <er>Granadilla</er>, and <er>Maypop</er>).
The roots and leaves are generally more or less noxious, and are
used in medicine. The plants are mostly tendril climbers, and are
commonest in the warmer parts of America, though a few species
are Asiatic or Australian.</note>

<cs><col>Passion music</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>originally,
music set to the gospel narrative of the passion of our Lord;
after the Reformation, a kind of oratorio, with narrative,
chorals, airs, and choruses, having for its theme the passion and
crucifixion of Christ.</cd> -- <col>Passion play</col>, <cd>a
mystery play, in which the scenes connected with the passion of
our Savior are represented dramatically.</cd> -- <col>Passion
Sunday</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, <cd>the fifth Sunday in Lent, or
the second before Easter.</cd> -- <col>Passion Week</col>,
<cd>the last week but one in Lent, or the second week preceding
Easter. \'bdThe name of <xex>Passion week<xex> is frequently, but
improperly, applied to Holy Week.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Shipley.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Passion</er>, <er>Feeling</er>,
<er>Emotion</er>.</syn> <usage> When any <xex>feeling</xex> or
<xex>emotion</xex> completely masters the mind, we call it a
<xex>passion</xex>; as, a <xex>passion</xex> for music, dress,
etc.; especially is anger (when thus extreme) called
<xex>passion</xex>. The mind, in such cases, is considered as
having lost its self-control, and become the passive instrument
of the feeling in question.</usage>

<hw>Pas"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Passioned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p.pr & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Passioning</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To give a passionate
character to.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Keats.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To suffer pain or
sorrow; to experience a passion; to be extremely agitated.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdDumbly she <xex>passions</xex>,
frantically she doteth.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to passion or the passions; exciting, influenced by,
or ministering to, the passions.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos>
<def>A passionary.</def></def2>

<hw>Pas"sion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>passionarius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>passionaire</ets>.]</ety>
<def>A book in which are described the sufferings of saints and
martyrs.</def>

<au>T. Warton.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>passionatus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>passionn\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable or susceptible of passion, or of
different passions; easily moved, excited or agitated;
specifically, easily moved to anger; irascible; quick-tempered;
<as>as, a <ex>passionate</ex> nature</as>.</def>

<q>Homer's Achilles is haughty and <qex>passionate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Characterized by passion; expressing passion;
ardent in feeling or desire; vehement; warm; <as>as, a
<ex>passionate</ex> friendship</as>.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>passionate</xex> Pilgrim.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Suffering; sorrowful.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To affect with passion; to impassion.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Great pleasure, mixed with pitiful regard,
The godly kind and queen did <qex>passionate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To express feelingly or sorrowfully.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion*ate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>In a passionate manner; with strong feeling;
ardently.</def>

<q>Sorrow expresses itself . . . loudly and
<qex>passionately</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Angrily; irascibly.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion*ate*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or
quality of being passionate.</def>

<hw>Pas"sion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld>
<def>A member of a religious order founded in Italy in 1737, and
introduced into the United States in 1852. The members of the
order unite the austerities of the Trappists with the activity
and zeal of the Jesuits and Lazarists. Called also
<xex>Barefooted Clerks of the Most Holy Cross</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pas"sion*less</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Void of
passion; without anger or emotion; not easily excited;
calm.</def> \'bdSelf-contained and <xex>passionless</xex>.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Pas"sion*tide`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Passion</ets> + <ets>tide</ets> time.]</ety> <def>The
last fortnight of Lent.</def>

<hw>Pas"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>passivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>passif</ets>. See
<er>Passion</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Not active, but acted
upon; suffering or receiving impressions or influences; <as>as,
they were <ex>passive</ex> spectators, not actors in the
scene</as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>passive</qex> air
Upbore their nimble tread.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The mind is wholly <qex>passive</qex> in the reception of all
its simple ideas.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Receiving or enduring without either active
sympathy or active resistance; without emotion or excitement;
patient; not opposing; unresisting; <as>as, <ex>passive</ex>
obedience; <ex>passive</ex> submission.</as></def>

<q>The best virtue, <qex>passive</qex> fortitude.</q>
<qau>Massinger.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Inactive; inert; not showing
strong affinity; <as>as, red phosphorus is comparatively
<ex>passive</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Designating certain morbid
conditions, as hemorrhage or dropsy, characterized by relaxation
of the vessels and tissues, with deficient vitality and lack of
reaction in the affected tissues.</def>

<cs><col>Passive congestion</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>,
<cd>congestion due to obstruction to the return of the blood from
the affected part.</cd> -- <col>Passive iron</col>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>iron which has been subjected to the
action of heat, of strong nitric acid, chlorine, etc. It is then
not easily acted upon by acids.</cd> -- <col>Passive
movement</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a movement of a part, in
order to exercise it, made without the assistance of the muscles
which ordinarily move the part.</cd> -- <col>Passive
obedience</col><cd> (as used by writers on government), obedience
or submission of the subject or citizen as a duty in all cases to
the existing government.</cd> -- <col>Passive prayer</col>,
<cd>among mystic divines, a suspension of the activity of the
soul or intellectual faculties, the soul remaining quiet, and
yielding only to the impulses of grace.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Passive verb</col>, <or/ <col>Passive
voice</col></mcol> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>a verb, or form of a
verb, which expresses the effect of the action of some agent; as,
in Latin, <xex>doceor<xex>, I am taught; in English, she <xex>is
loved<xex>; the picture <xex>is admired<xex> by all; he <xex>is
assailed<xex> by slander.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Inactive; inert; quiescent; unresisting; unopposing;
suffering; enduring; submissive; patient.</syn>

<hw>Pas"sive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a
passive manner; inertly; unresistingly.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>As a passive verb; in the passive voice.</def>

<hw>Pas"sive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state
of being passive; unresisting submission.</def>

<q>To be an effect implies <qex>passiveness</qex>, or the being
subject to the power and action of its cause.</q>
<qau>J. Edwards.</qau>

<hw>Pas*siv"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>passivit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Passiveness; --
opposed to <xex>activity</xex>.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>The tendency of a body to
remain in a given state, either of motion or rest, till disturbed
by another body; inertia.</def>

<au>Cheyne.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The quality or condition of
any substance which has no inclination to chemical activity;
inactivity.</def>

opening more locks than one; a master key.</def>

<hw>Pass"o`ver</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pass</ets> + <ets>over</ets>. See Pasch.]</ety>
<fld>(Jewish Antiq.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A feast of the Jews,
instituted to commemorate the sparing of the Hebrews in Egypt,
when God, smiting the firstborn of the Egyptians, <xex>passed
over</xex> the houses of the Israelites which were marked with
the blood of a lamb.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The sacrifice
offered at the feast of the passover; the paschal lamb.</def>

<au>Ex. xii.</au>

<hw>Pass`-pa*role"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>passe-parole</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>An order
passed from front to rear by word of mouth.</def>

<hw>Pass"port</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>passeport</ets>, orig., a permission to leave a port or to
sail into it; <ets>passer</ets> to pass + <ets>port</ets> a port,
harbor. See <er>Pass</er>, and <er>Port</er> a harbor.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Permission to pass; a document given by the
competent officer of a state, permitting the person therein named
to pass or travel from place to place, without molestation, by
land or by water.</def>

<q>Caution in granting <qex>passports</qex> to Ireland.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A document carried by neutral merchant vessels
in time of war, to certify their nationality and protect them
from belligerents; a sea letter.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A license granted in time of war for the removal
of persons and effects from a hostile country; a
safe-conduct.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Figuratively: Anything which secures advancement
and general acceptance.</def>

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<q>His <qex>passport</qex> is his innocence and grace.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Past</hw>, <pos>prep.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Beyond, in
position, or degree; further than; beyond the reach or influence

<au>Macaulay</au>.

<q>Love, when once <qex>past</qex> government, is consequently
<qex>past shame</qex>.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<-- p. 1050 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Beyond, in time; after; <as>as, <ex>past</ex>
the hour</as>.</def>

<qau>Shak.</qau>

<mark>[R.]</mark>

<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Bows not <qex>past</qex> three quarters of a yard long.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<as>as, he ran <ex>past</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The alarum of drums swept <qex>past</qex>.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<hw>Paste</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>paste</ets>, F. <ets>p\'83te</ets>, L. <ets>pasta</ets>, fr.
Gr. <?/ barley broth; cf. <?/ barley porridge, <?/ sprinkled with
salt, <?/ to sprinkle. Cf. <er>Pasty</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<er>Patty</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A soft composition, as of
flour moistened with water or milk, or of earth moistened to the
consistence of dough, as in making potter's ware.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, in cookery, a dough prepared for
the crust of pies and the like; pastry dough.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A kind of cement made of flour and water, starch
and water, or the like, -- used for uniting paper or other
substances, as in bookbinding, etc., -- also used in calico
printing as a vehicle for mordant or color.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A highly refractive vitreous composition,
variously colored, used in making imitations of precious stones
or gems. See <er>Strass</er>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A soft confection made of the inspissated juice
of fruit, licorice, or the like, with sugar, etc.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>The mineral substance in which
other minerals are imbedded.</def>

<cs><col>Paste eel</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the vinegar
eel. See under <er>Vinegar</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Paste</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pasted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pasting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To unite with paste; to
fasten or join by means of paste.</def>

<hw>Paste"board`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A stiff thick kind of paper board, formed of several single
sheets pasted one upon another, or of paper macerated and pressed
into molds, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Cookery)</fld> <def>A board on which pastry
dough is rolled; a molding board.</def>

<hw>Pas"tel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.; cf. It.

<--3. a drawing using pastel, or of a pastel shade.

<hw>Pas"tern</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Of.
<ets>pasturon</ets>, F. <ets>p\'83turon</ets>, fr. OF.
<ets>pasture</ets> a tether, for beasts while pasturing; prop., a
pasturing. See <er>Pasture</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The part
of the foot of the horse, and allied animals, between the fetlock
and the coffin joint. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Horse</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The upper bone, or phalanx, of the foot is called
the <stype>great pastern bone</stype>; the second, the
<stype>small pastern bone</stype>; and the third, in the hoof,
the <stype>coffin bone</stype>.</note>

<cs><col>Pastern joint</col>, <cd>the joint in the hoof of the
horse, and allied animals, between the great and small pastern
bones.</cd></cs>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A shackle for horses while pasturing.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A patten.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pas*teur"ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Fr.
<ets>Pasteur</ets>, a French scientist.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
method of treatment, devised by Pasteur, for preventing certain
diseases, as hydrophobia, by successive inoculations with an
attenuated virus of gradually increasing strength.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pasteurization.</def>

<hw>Pas*teur`i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
process devised by Pasteur for preventing or checking
fermentation in fluids, such as wines, milk, etc., by exposure to
a temperature of 140<deg/ F., thus destroying the vitality of the
contained germs or ferments.</def>

<hw>Pas*teur"ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To subject to pasteurization.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To treat by pasteurizm.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A work of

art, as a vase or statue made up of parts of original works, with

<hw>Pas"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
<ets>pascere</ets>, <ets>pastum</ets>, to pasture, to feed. Cf.
<er>Pabulum</er>, <er>Pasture</er>, <er>Food</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A shepherd; one who has the care of flocks and
herds.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A guardian; a keeper; specifically
<fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, a minister having the charge of a church and
parish.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A species of starling
(<spn>Pastor roseus</spn>), native of the plains of Western Asia
and Eastern Europe.  Its head is crested and glossy greenish
black, and its back is rosy. It feeds largely upon locusts.</def>

<hw>Pas"tor*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The office,
jurisdiction, or duty, of a pastor; pastorate.</def>

<hw>Pas"tor*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pastoralis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pastoral</ets>. See
<er>Pastor</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to
shepherds; hence, relating to rural life and scenes; <as>as, a
<ex>pastoral</ex> life</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Relating to the care of souls, or to the pastor
of a church; <as>as, <ex>pastoral</ex> duties; a
<ex>pastoral</ex> letter.</as></def>

<cs><col>Pastoral staff</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, <cd>a staff,
usually of the form of a shepherd's crook, borne as an official
emblem by a bishop, abbot, abbess, or other prelate privileged to
carry it. See <er>Crook</er>, and <er>Crosier</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pastoral Theology</col>, <cd>that part of theology which
treats of the duties of pastors.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pas"tor*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A poem describing the life and manners of shepherds; a poem
in which the speakers assume the character of shepherds; an idyl;
a bucolic.</def>

<q>A <qex>pastoral</qex> is a poem in which any action or passion
is represented by its effects on a country life.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A cantata relating to rural
life; a composition for instruments characterized by simplicity
and sweetness; a lyrical composition the subject of which is
taken from rural life.</def>

<au>Moore (Encyc. of Music).</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>A letter of a pastor to his
charge; specifically, a letter addressed by a bishop to his
diocese; also <fld>(Prot. Epis. Ch.)</fld>, a letter of the House
of Bishops, to be read in each parish.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pas`to*ra"le</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[It.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A composition
in a soft, rural style, generally in 6-8 or 12-8 time.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A kind of dance; a kind of figure used in a
dance.</def>

<hw>Pas"tor*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>In a pastoral or rural manner.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In the manner of a pastor.</def>

<hw>Pas"tor*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pastorat</ets>. See <er>Pastor</er>.]</ety> <def>The office,
state, or jurisdiction of a pastor.</def>

<hw>Pas"tor*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no pastor.</def>

pastor.</def>

<hw>Pas"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pasture</ets>, F. <ets>p\'83ture</ets>, L.

feed on growing grass; to supply grass as food for; <as>as, the
farmer <ex>pastures</ex> fifty oxen; the land will
<ex>pasture</ex> forty cows.</as></def>

<hw>Pas"ture</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To feed on growing

<hw>Pat</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Patted</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Patting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>patschen</ets>, Prov. G. <ets>patzen</ets>, to strike,
tap.]</ety> <def>To strike gently with the fingers or hand; to
stroke lightly; to tap; <as>as, to <ex>pat</ex> a dog</as>.</def>

<q>Gay <qex>pats</qex> my shoulder, and you vanish quite.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Pat</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A light, quik blow
or stroke with the fingers or hand; a tap.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small mass, as of butter, shaped by
pats.</def>

<q>It looked like a tessellated work of <qex>pats</qex> of
butter.</q>
<qau>Dickens.</qau>

<hw>Pat</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. <ets>pat</ets> a light
blow, D. <ets>te pas</ets> convenient, pat, where <ets>pas</ets>
is fr. F. <ets>passer</ets> to pass.]</ety> <def>Exactly
suitable; fit; convenient; timely.</def> \'bd<xex>Pat</xex>
allusion.\'b8

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>Pat</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pat manner.</def>

<q>I foresaw then 't would come in <qex>pat</qex> hereafter.</q>
<qau>Sterne.</qau>

expansion of the integument uniting the fore limb with the body
and extending between the elongated fingers to form the wing; in

<er>Butterfly</er>.</def>

<hw>Pat`a*vin"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>patavinitas</ets>, fr. <ets>Patavium</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>patavinit\'82</ets>]</ety> <def>The use of local or
provincial words, as in the peculiar style or diction of Livy,
the Roman historian; -- so called from Patavium, now Padua, the
place of Livy's nativity.</def>

<hw>Patch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pacche</ets>; of uncertain origin, perh. for
<ets>placche</ets>; cf. Prov. E. <ets>platch</ets> patch, LG.
<ets>plakk</ets>, <ets>plakke</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
piece of cloth, or other suitable material, sewed or otherwise
fixed upon a garment to repair or strengthen it, esp. upon an old
garment to cover a hole.</def>

<q><qex>Patches</qex> set upon a little breach.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: A small piece of anything used to repair
a breach; <as>as, a <ex>patch</ex> on a kettle, a roof,
etc</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A small piece of black silk stuck on the face,
or neck, to hide a defect, or to heighten beauty.</def>

<q>Your black <qex>patches</qex> you wear variously.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Gun.)</fld> <def>A piece of greased cloth or
leather used as wrapping for a rifle ball, to make it fit the
bore.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Fig.: Anything regarded as a patch; a small
piece of ground; a tract; a plot; <as>as, scattered
<ex>patches</ex> of trees or growing corn</as>.</def>

<q>Employed about this <qex>patch</qex> of ground.</q>
<qau>Bunyan.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A block on the muzzle of a
gun, to do away with the effect of dispart, in sighting.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A paltry fellow; a rogue; a ninny; a fool.</def>
<mark>[Obs. or Colloq.]</mark> \'bdThou scurvy
<xex>patch</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Patch ice</col>, <cd>ice in overlapping pieces in the
sea.</cd> -- <col>Soft patch</col>, <cd>a patch for covering a
crack in a metallic vessel, as a steam boiler, consisting of soft
material, as putty, covered and held in place by a plate bolted
or riveted fast.</cd></cs>

<hw>Patch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Patched</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Patching</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To mend by
sewing on a piece or pieces of cloth, leather, or the like;
<as>as, to <ex>patch</ex> a coat</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To mend with pieces; to repair with pieces
festened on; to repair clumsily; <as>as, to <ex>patch</ex> the
roof of a house</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To adorn, as the face, with a patch or
patches.</def>

<q>Ladies who <qex>patched</qex> both sides of their faces.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To make of pieces or patches; to repair as with
patches; to arrange in a hasty or clumsy manner; -- generally
with <xex>up</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>patch</ex> up a
truce</as>.</def> \'bdIf you'll <xex>patch</xex> a quarrel.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pa"ten*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Patent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The condition of being
open, enlarged, or spread.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being patent or evident.</def>

<-- p. 1051 -->

<hw>Pat"ent</hw> <pr>(p<acr/t"<it>e</it>nt <or/
p<amac/t"<it>e</it>nt)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>patens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>patere</ets>
to be open: cf. F. <ets>patent</ets>. Cf. <er>Fathom</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <note>(<xex>Oftener pronounced</xex>
<pr>p<amac/t"<it>e</it>nt</pr> <xex>in this sense</xex>)</note>
<def>Open; expanded; evident; apparent; unconcealed; manifest;
public; conspicuous.</def>

<q>He had received instructions, both <qex>patent</qex> and
secret.</q>
<qau>Motley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Open to public perusal; -- said of a document
conferring some right or privilege; <as>as, letters
<ex>patent</ex></as>. See <cref>Letters patent</cref>, under 3d
<er>Letter</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Appropriated or protected by letters patent;
secured by official authority to the exclusive possession,
control, and disposal of some person or party; patented; <as>as,
a <ex>patent</ex> right; <ex>patent</ex> medicines.</as></def>

<q>Madder . . . in King Charles the First's time, was made a
<qex>patent</qex> commodity.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Spreading; forming a nearly
right angle with the steam or branch; <as>as, a <ex>patent</ex>
leaf</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Patent leather</col>, <cd>a varnished or lacquered
leather, used for boots and shoes, and in carriage and harness
work.</cd> -- <col>Patent office</col>, <cd>a government bureau
for the examination of inventions and the granting of
patents.</cd> -- <col>Patent right</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The
exclusive right to an invention, and the control of its
manufacture</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>The right,
granted by the sovereign, of exclusive control of some business
of manufacture, or of the sale of certain articles, or of certain
offices or prerogatives.</cd> -- <col>Patent rolls</col>, <cd>the
registers, or records, of patents.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pat"ent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>patente</ets>.
See <er>Patent</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
letter patent, or letters patent; an official document, issued by
a sovereign power, conferring a right or privilege on some person
or party.</def> Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A writing
securing to an invention</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A document
making a grant and conveyance of public lands.</def>

<q>Four other gentlemen of quality remained mentioned in that
<qex>patent</qex>.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<note><hand/ In the United States, by the act of 1870, patents
for inventions are issued for seventeen years, without the
privilege of renewal except by act of Congress.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The right or privilege conferred by such a
document; hence, figuratively, a right, privilege, or license of
the nature of a patent.</def>

<q>If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her
<qex>patent</qex> to offend.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pat"ent</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Patented</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Patenting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To grant by patent; to make
the subject of a patent; to secure or protect by patent; <as>as,
to <ex>patent</ex> an invention; to <ex>patent</ex> public
lands.</as></def>

<hw>Pat"ent*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Suitable
to be patented; capable of being patented.</def>

<hw>Pat`ent*ee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One to whom
a grant is made, or a privilege secured, by patent.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pat"ent-ham"mered</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Stone Cutting)</fld> <def>Having a surface dressed by

<pos>a.</pos>)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Openly;

<hw>\'d8Pat"e*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>\'d8Pa`ter*fa*mil`i*as</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Pateresfamilias</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.,
fr. <ets>pater</ets> father + <ets>familias</ets>, gen. of
<ets>familia</ets> family.]</ety> <fld>(Rom. Law)</fld> <def>The
head of a family; in a large sense, the proprietor of an estate;
one who is his own master.</def>

<hw>Pa*ter"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>paternus</ets>, fr. <ets>pater</ets> a father: cf. F.
<ets>paternel</ets>. See <er>Father</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to a father; fatherly; showing the
disposition of a father; guiding or instructing as a father;
<as>as, <ex>paternal</ex> care</as>.</def> \'bdUnder
<xex>paternal</xex> rule.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Received or derived from a father; hereditary;
<as>as, a <ex>paternal</ex> estate</as>.</def>

<q>Their small <qex>paternal</qex> field of corn.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Paternal government</col> <fld>(Polit. Science)</fld>,
<cd>the assumption by the governing power of a quasi-fatherly
relation to the people, involving strict and intimate supervision
of their business and social concerns, upon the theory that they
are incapable of managing their own afffairs.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pa*ter"nal*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Polit.
Science)</fld> <def>The theory or practice of paternal
government. See <cref>Paternal government</cref>, under
<er>Paternal</er>.</def>

<au>London Times.</au>

<-- paternalistic, = relating to paternalism -->

<hw>Pa*ter"nal*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a paternal
manner.</def>

<hw>Pa*ter"ni*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>paternitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>paternit\'82</ets>. See
<er>Paternal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The relation of a
father to his child; fathership; fatherhood; family headship;
<as>as, the divine <ex>paternity</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The world, while it had scarcity of people, underwent no other
dominion than <qex>paternity</qex> and eldership.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Derivation or descent from a father; male
parentage; <as>as, the <ex>paternity</ex> of a child</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Origin; authorship.</def>

<q>The <qex>paternity</qex> of these novels was . . .
disputed.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<hw>Path</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Paths</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[As. <?/, <?/; <?/akin
to D. <ets>pad</ets>, G. <ets>pfad</ets>, of uncertain origin;
cf. Gr. <?/, Skr. <ets>patha</ets>, <ets>path</ets>.
<root/21.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A trodden way; a footway.</def>

<q>The dewy <qex>paths</qex> of meadows we will tread.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A way, course, or track, in which anything moves
or has moved; route; passage; an established way; <as>as, the
<ex>path</ex> of a meteor, of a caravan, of a storm, of a
pestilence</as>. Also used figuratively, of a course of life or
action.</def>

<q>All the <qex>paths</qex> of the Lord are mercy and truth.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxv. 10.</qau>

<q>The <qex>paths</qex> of glory lead but to the grave.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<hw>Pa*thet"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>patheticus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, <?/, to suffer: cf. F.
<ets>path\'82tique</ets>. See <er>Pathos</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Expressing or showing anger; passionate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Affecting or moving the tender emotions, esp.
pity or grief; full of pathos; <as>as, a <ex>pathetic</ex> song
or story</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Pathetic</xex> action.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<q>No theory of the passions can teach a man to be
<qex>pathetic</qex>.</q>
<qau>E. Porter.</qau>

<cs><col>Pathetic muscle</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the
superior oblique muscle of the eye.</cd> -- <col>Pathetic
nerve</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the fourth cranial, or
trochlear, nerve, which supplies the superior oblique, or
pathetic, muscle of the eye.</cd> -- <col>The pathetic</col>,
<cd>a style or manner adapted to arouse the tender
emotions.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pa*thol"o*gist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pathologiste</ets>.]</ety> <def>One skilled in pathology; an

<hw>Pa*thol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pathologies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Gr. <?/ a
suffering, disease + <ets>-logy: cf. F.
<ets>pathologie</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The science
which treats of diseases, their nature, causes, progress,
symptoms, etc.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pathology</xex> is <xex>general</xex> or
<xex>special</xex>, according as it treats of disease or morbid
processes in general, or of particular diseases; it is also
subdivided into <xex>internal</xex> and <xex>external</xex>, or
<xex>medical</xex> and <xex>surgical</xex> pathology. Its
departments are <stype>nosology</stype>,
<stype>\'91tiology</stype>, <stype>morbid anatomy</stype>,
<stype>symptomatology</stype>, and <stype>therapeutics</stype>,
which treat respectively of the classification, causation,
organic changes, symptoms, and cure of diseases.</note>

<cs><col>Celluar pathology</col>, <cd>a theory that gives
prominence to the vital action of cells in the healthy and
diseased function of the body.</cd></cs>

<au>Virchow.</au>

<hw>\'d8Path`o*p\'d2"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;

<hw>Pa"thos</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., from Gr.
<?/ a suffering, passion, fr. <?/, <?/, to suffer; cf. <?/ toil,
L. <ets>pati</ets> to suffer, E. <ets>patient</ets>.]</ety>
<def>That quality or property of anything which touches the
feelings or excites emotions and passions, esp., that which
awakens tender emotions, such as pity, sorrow, and the like;
contagious warmth of feeling, action, or expression; pathetic
quality; <as>as, the <ex>pathos</ex> of a picture, of a poem, or
of a cry</as>.</def>

<q>The combination of incident, and the <qex>pathos</qex> of
catastrophe.</q>
<qau>T. Warton.</qau>

<hw>Pa"tience</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>patience</ets>, fr. L. <ets>patientia</ets>. See
<er>Patient</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state or quality of
being patient; the power of suffering with fortitude;
uncomplaining endurance of evils or wrongs, as toil, pain,
poverty, insult, oppression, calamity, etc.</def>

<q>Strenthened with all might, . . . unto all <qex>patience</qex>
and long-suffering.</q>
<qau>Col. i. 11.</qau>

<q>I must have <qex>patience</qex> to endure the load.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Who hath learned lowliness
From his Lord's cradle, <qex>patience</qex> from his cross.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act or power of calmly or contentedly
waiting for something due or hoped for; forbearance.</def>

<q>Have <qex>patience</qex> with me, and I will pay thee all.</q>
<qau>Matt. xviii. 29.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Constancy in labor or application;
perseverance.</def>

<q>He learned with <qex>patience</qex>, and with meekness
taught.</q>
<qau>Harte.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Sufferance; permission.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<q>They stay upon your <qex>patience</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A kind of dock (<spn>Rumex
Patientia</spn>), less common in America than in Europe; monk's
rhubarb.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Card Playing)</fld> <def>Solitaire.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Patience</er>, <er>Resignation</er>.</syn>
<usage> <xex>Patience</xex> implies the quietness or
self-possession of one's own spirit under sufferings,
provocations, etc.; <xex>resignation</xex> implies submission to
the will of another. The Stoic may have <xex>patience</xex>; the
Christian should have both <xex>patience</xex> and
<xex>resignation</xex>.</usage>

<hw>Pa"tient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>patiens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>pati</ets>
to suffer. Cf. <er>Pathos</er>, <er>Passion</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the quality of enduring; physically able
to suffer or bear.</def>

<q><qex>Patient</qex> of severest toil and hardship.</q>
<qau>Bp. Fell.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Undergoing pains, trails, or the like, without
murmuring or fretfulness; bearing up with equanimity against
trouble; long-suffering.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Constant in pursuit or exertion; persevering;
calmly diligent; <as>as, <ex>patient</ex> endeavor</as>.</def>

<q>Whatever I have done is due to <qex>patient</qex> thought.</q>
<qau>Sir I. Newton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Expectant with calmness, or without discontent;
not hasty; not overeager; composed.</def>

<q>Not <qex>patient</qex> to expect the turns of fate.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Forbearing; long-suffering.</def>

<q>Be <qex>patient</qex> toward all men.</q>
<qau>1 Thess. v. 14.</qau>

<hw>Pa"tient</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>ONe who, or
that which, is passively affected; a passive recipient.</def>

<q>Malice is a passion so impetuous and precipitate that often
involves the agent and the <qex>patient</qex>.</q>
<qau>Gov. of Tongue.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A person under medical or surgical treatment; --
correlative to <xex>physician</xex> or <xex>nurse</xex>.</def>

<q>Like a physician, . . . seeing his <qex>patient</qex> in a
pestilent fever.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<cs><col>In patient</col>, <cd>a patient who receives lodging and
food, as treatment, in a hospital or an infirmary.</cd> --
<col>Out patient</col>, <cd>one who receives advice and medicine,
or treatment, from an infirmary.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pa"tri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>patria</ets> fatherland, country, fr. <ets>pater</ets>

patrial noun. Thus <xex>Romanus</xex>, a Roman, and
<xex>Troas</xex>, a woman of Troy, are <xex>patrial</xex> nouns,
or <xex>patrials</xex>.</def></def2>

<au>Andrews.</au>

<hw>Pa"tri*arch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>patriarche</ets>, L. <ets>patriarcha</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/
lineage, especially on the father's side, race; <?/ father + <?/
a leader, chief, fr. <?/ to lead, rule. See <er>Father</er>,
<er>Archaic</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The father and ruler of
a family; one who governs his family or descendants by paternal
right; -- usually applied to heads of families in ancient
history, especially in Biblical and Jewish history to those who
lived before the time of Moses.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch. & Gr. Ch.)</fld> <def>A dignitary
superior to the order of archbishops; <as>as, the
<ex>patriarch</ex> of Constantinople, of Alexandria, or of
Antioch</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A venerable old man; an elder. Also used
figuratively.</def>

<q>The <qex>patriarch</qex> hoary, the sage of his kith and the
hamlet.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<q>The monarch oak, the <qex>partiarch</qex> of trees.</q>
<qau>Dryde.</qau>

<hw>Pa`tri*ar"chal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>patriarcal</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining
to a patriarch or to patriarchs; possessed by, or subject to,
patriarchs; <as>as, <ex>patriarchal</ex> authority or
jurisdiction; a <ex>patriarchal</ex> see; a <ex>patriarchal</ex>
church.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Characteristic of a patriarch; venerable.</def>

<q>About whose <qex>patriarchal</qex> knee
Late the little children clung.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Ethnol.)</fld> <def>Having an organization of
society and government in which the head of the family exercises
authority over all its generations.</def>

<cs><col>Patriarchal cross</col> <fld>(Her.)</fld>, <cd>a cross,
the shaft of which is intersected by two transverse beams, the
upper one being the smaller. See <xex>Illust<xex>. (2) of
<er>Cross</er>.</cd> -- <col>Patriarchal dispensation</col>,
<cd>the divine dispensation under which the patriarchs lived
before the law given by Moses.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pa*tri"cian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>patricius</ets>, fr. <ets>patres</ets> fathers or senators,
pl. of <ets>pater</ets>: cf. F. <ets>patricien</ets>. See
<er>Paternal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld>
<def>Of or pertaining to the Roman <xex>patres</xex> (fathers) or
senators, or patricians.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of, pertaining to, or appropriate to, a person
of high birth; noble; not plebeian.</def>

<q>Born in the <qex>patrician</qex> file of society.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<q>His horse's hoofs wet with <qex>patrician</qex> blood.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Pa*tri"cian</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>patricius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>patricien</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>Originally, a member of
any of the families constituting the <xex>populus Romanus</xex>,
or body of Roman citizens, before the development of the plebeian
order; later, one who, by right of birth or by special privilege
conferred, belonged to the nobility.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A person of high birth; a nobleman.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One familiar with the works of the Christian
Fathers; one versed in patristic lore.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Colridge.</au>

<hw>Pa*trol"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Patrolled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Patrolling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>patrouiller</ets>, O. & Prov. F. <ets>patrouiller</ets> to
paddle, paw about, patrol, fr. <ets>patte</ets> a paw; cf. D.
<ets>poot</ets> paw, G. <ets>pfote</ets>, and E. <ets>pat</ets>,
v.]</ety> <def>To go the rounds along a chain of sentinels; to
traverse a police district or beat.</def>

<hw>Pa*trol"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v.</pos><def>t To go the
rounds of, as a sentry, guard, or policeman; <as>as, to
<ex>patrol</ex> a frontier; to <ex>patrol</ex> a beat.</as></def>

<hw>Pa*trol"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>patrouille</ets>,
OF. <ets>patouille</ets>. See <er>Patrol</er>, <pos>v.
i.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
going of the rounds along the chain of sentinels and between the
posts, by a guard, usually consisting of three or four men, to
insure greater security from attacks on the outposts.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A movement, by a small body of troops beyond
the line of outposts, to explore the country and gain
intelligence of the enemy's whereabouts.</def> <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>The guard or men who go the rounds for observation; a
detachment whose duty it is to patrol.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any perambulation of a particular line or
district to guard it; also, the men thus guarding; <as>as, a
customs <ex>patrol</ex>; a fire <ex>patrol</ex>.</as></def>

<q>In France there is an army of <qex>patrols</qex> to secure her
fiscal regulations.</q>
<qau>A. Hamilton.</qau>

<hw>Pa*trole"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. & v.</pos> <def>See
<er>Patrol</er>, <pos>n. & v.</pos></def>

<plw>Patrolmen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>One who patrols;
a watchman; especially, a policeman who patrols a particular
precinct of a town or city.</def>

<hw>Pa"tron</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>patronus</ets>, fr. <ets>pater</ets> a father. See

<er>Pattern</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who protects,

\'bd<xex>Patron</xex> of my life and liberty.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au>
\'bdThe <xex>patron</xex> of true holiness.\'b8 <au>Spenser</au>.

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A master
who had freed his slave, but still retained some paternal rights
over him.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A man of distinction under
whose protection another person placed himself.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>An advocate or pleader.</def>

<q>Let him who works the client wrong
Beware the <qex>patron</qex>'s ire.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who encourages or helps a person, a cause,
or a work; a furtherer; a promoter; <as>as, a <ex>patron</ex> of
art</as>.</def>

disposition of a benefice.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A guardian saint. -- called also <altname>patron
saint</altname>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>See <er>Padrone</er>,
2.</def>

<cs><col>Patrons of Husbandry</col>, <cd>the grangers. See
<er>Granger</er>, 2.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pat"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pattered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pattering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Freq. of <ets>pat</ets> to

succession of slight, sharp sounds; <as>as, <ex>pattering</ex>
rain or hail; <ex>pattering</ex> feet.</as></def>

<q>The stealing shower is scarce to <qex>patter</qex> heard.</q>
<qau>Thomson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To mutter; to mumble; <as>as, to <ex>patter</ex>
with the lips</as>.</def> <au>Tyndale</au>. <ety>[In this sense,
and in the following, perh. from <ets>pater</ets>noster.]</ety>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To talk glibly; to chatter; to harangue.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<q>I've gone out and <qex>pattered</qex> to get money.</q>
<qau>Mayhew.</qau>

<au>J. R. Drake.</au>

<hw>Pat"ter</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A quick
succession of slight sounds; <as>as, the <ex>patter</ex> of rain;
the <ex>patter</ex> of little feet.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Glib and rapid speech; a voluble harangue.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The cant of a class; patois; <as>as, thieves's
<ex>patter</ex>; gypsies' <ex>patter</ex>.</as></def>

patters, or talks glibly; specifically, a street peddler.</def>
<mark>[Cant, Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pat"tern</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>patron</ets>, F. <ets>patron</ets>, a patron, also, a
pattern. See <er>Patron</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything
proposed for imitation; an archetype; an exemplar; that which is
to be, or is worthy to be, copied or imitated; <as>as, a
<ex>pattern</ex> of a machine</as>.</def>

<q>I will be the <qex>pattern</qex> of all patience.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A part showing the figure or quality of the
whole; a specimen; a sample; an example; an instance.</def>

<q>He compares the <qex>pattern</qex> with the whole piece.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Stuff sufficient for a garment; <as>as, a dress
<ex>pattern</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Figure or style of decoration; design; <as>as,
wall paper of a beautiful <ex>pattern</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Something made after a model; a copy.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The <qex>patterns</qex> of things in the heavens.</q>
<qau>Heb. ix. 23.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Anything cut or formed to serve as a guide to
cutting or forming objects; <as>as, a dressmaker's
<ex>pattern</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Founding)</fld> <def>A full-sized model around
which a mold of sand is made, to receive the melted metal. It is
usually made of wood and in several parts, so as to be removed
from the mold without injuring it.</def>

<-- a definable characteristic relationship between the members
of any set of objects or actions; also, the set having a
definable relationship between its members.

  Thus: the distribution of bomb or shell impacts on a target
area, or of bullet holes in a target; a set of traits or actions
that appear to be consistent throughout the members of a group or
over time within a group, as behavioral pattern, traffic pattern,
dress pattern -->

<cs><mcol><col>Pattern box</col>, <col>chain</col>, <or/
<col>cylinder</col></mcol> <fld>(Figure Weaving)</fld>,
<cd>devices, in a loom, for presenting several shuttles to the
picker in the proper succession for forming the figure.</cd> --
<col>Pattern card</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A set of samples on a
card</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Weaving)</fld> <cd>One of the
perforated cards in a Jacquard apparatus.</cd> -- <col>Pattern
reader</col>, <cd>one who arranges textile patterns.</cd> --
<col>Pattern wheel</col> <fld>(Horology)</fld>, <cd>a
count-wheel.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pat"tern</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Patterned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Patterning</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
make or design (anything) by, from, or after, something that
serves as a pattern; to copy; to model; to imitate.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>[A temple] <qex>patterned</qex> from that which Adam reared in
Paradise.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Herbert.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To serve as an example for; also, to
parallel.</def>

<cs><col>To pattern after</col>, <cd>to imitate; to
follow.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pau*low"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
So named from the Russian princess Anna
<ets>Pavlovna</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of
trees of the order <spn>Scrophulariace\'91</spn>, consisting of
one species, <spn>Paulownia imperialis</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ The tree is native to Japan, and has immense
heart-shaped leaves, and large purplish flowers in panicles. The
capsules contain many little winged seeds, which are beautiful
microscopic objects. The tree is hardy in America as far north as
Connecticut.</note>

<hw>Pause</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>pausa</ets>. See <er>Pose</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
temporary stop or rest; an intermission of action; interruption;
suspension; cessation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Temporary inaction or waiting; hesitation;
suspence; doubt.</def>

<q>I stand in <qex>pause</qex> where I shall first begin.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In speaking or reading aloud, a brief arrest or
suspension of voice, to indicate the limits and relations of
sentences and their parts.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>In writing and printing, a mark indicating the
place and nature of an arrest of voice in reading; a punctuation
point; <as>as, teach the pupil to mind the
<ex>pauses</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A break or paragraph in writing.</def>

<q>He writes with warmth, which usually neglects method, and
those partitions and <qex>pauses</qex> which men educated in
schools observe.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A hold. See 4th <er>Hold</er>,
7.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Stop; cessation; suspension.</syn>

<hw>Pause</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Paused</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pausing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pauser</ets>, L.
<ets>pausare</ets>. See <er>Pause</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<er>Pose</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make a short stop; to
cease for a time; to intermit speaking or acting; to stop; to
wait; to rest.</def> \'bdTarry, <xex>pause</xex> a day or
two.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Pausing</qex> while, thus to herself she mused.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be intermitted; to cease; <as>as, the music
<ex>pauses</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To hesitate; to hold back; to delay.</def>
<rj><mark>[R.]</mark></rj>

<q>Why doth the Jew <qex>pause</qex>? Take thy forfeiture.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>
<-- is this anti-semitic or what? -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To stop in order to consider; hence, to
consider; to reflect.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdTake time to
<xex>pause</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>To pause upon</col>, <cd>to deliberate concerning.</cd>

<au>Shak.</au></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To intermit; stop; stay; wait; delay; tarry;
hesitate; demur.</syn>

<hw>Pause</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To cause to stop or rest;
-- used reflexively.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pav"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pavane</ets>; cf. It. & Sp. <ets>pavana</ets>, and Sp.
<ets>pavon</ets>, <ets>pavo</ets>, a peacock, L.

<hw>\'d8Pa`v\'82"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., from

<hw>Pave</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Paved</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Paving</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>paver</ets> to pave, LL. <ets>pavare</ets>, from L.
<ets>pavire</ets> to beat, ram, or tread down; cf. Gr. <?/ to
beat, strike.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay or cover with stone,
brick, or other material, so as to make a firm, level, or
convenient surface for horses, carriages, or persons on foot, to
travel on; to floor with brick, stone, or other solid material;
<as>as, to <ex>pave</ex> a street; to <ex>pave</ex> a
court.</as></def><-- for vehicles -->

<q>With silver <qex>paved</qex>, and all divine with gold.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>To <qex>pave</qex> thy realm, and smooth the broken ways.</q>
<qau>Gay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To make smooth, easy, and safe; to
prepare, as a path or way; <as>as, to <ex>pave</ex> the way to
promotion; to <ex>pave</ex> the way for an enterprise.</as></def>

<q>It might open and <qex>pave</qex> a prepared way to his own
title.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Pave"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. LL.
<ets>pavamentum</ets>, L. <ets>pavimentum</ets>. See
<er>Pave</er>.]</ety> <def>That with which anythingis paved; a
floor or covering of solid material, laid so as to make a hard
and convenient surface for travel; a paved road or sidewalk; a
decorative interior floor of tiles or colored bricks.</def>

<q>The riches of heaven's <qex>pavement</qex>, trodden gold.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><col>Pavement teeth</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>flattened teeth which in certain fishes, as the skates and
cestracionts, are arranged side by side, like tiles in a
pavement.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pa*vil"ion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pavillon</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pavilio</ets> a butterfly, also,
a tent, because spread out like a butterfly's wings.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A temporary movable habitation; a large tent; a
marquee; esp., a tent raised on posts.</def> \'bd[The] Greeks do
pitch their brave <xex>pavilions</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A single body or mass of
building, contained within simple walls and a single roof,
whether insulated, as in the park or garden of a larger edifice,
or united with other parts, and forming an angle or central
feature of a large pile.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A flag, colors, ensign, or
banner.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Tent</er>
<fld>(Her.)</fld></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That part of a brilliant which lies between the
girdle and collet. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Brilliant</er>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The auricle of the ear; also,
the fimbriated extremity of the Fallopian tube.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A covering; a canopy; figuratively, the
sky.</def>

<q>The <qex>pavilion</qex> of heaven is bare.</q>
<qau>Shelley.</qau>

n.</pos> <er>Pavilioning</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To furnish or

<q>The field <qex>pavilioned</qex> with his guardians bright.</q>

<hw>Pa*vise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pavaix</ets>, F. <ets>pavois</ets>; cf. It.

Antiq.)</fld> <def>A soldier who carried a pavise.</def>

<hw>Paw</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<hw>Pawl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[W.
<ets>pawl</ets> a pole, a stake. Cf. <er>Pole</er> a
stake.]</ety> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A pivoted tongue, or
sliding bolt, on one part of a machine, adapted to fall into
notches, or interdental spaces, on another part, as a ratchet
wheel, in such a manner as to permit motion in one direction and
prevent it in the reverse, as in a windlass; a catch, click, or
detent. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Ratchet Wheel</er>.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>paul</asp>, or
<asp>pall</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Pawl bitt</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a heavy timber,
set abaft the windlass, to receive the strain of the pawls.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Pawl rim</col> <or/ <col>ring</col></mcol>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a stationary metallic ring surrounding

the pawls off.</def>

<hw>Pawn</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>paune</ets>,
<ets>poun</ets>, OF. <ets>peon</ets>, <ets>poon</ets>, F.
<ets>pion</ets>, LL. <ets>pedo</ets> a foot soldier, fr. L.
