cf. <er>Pioneer</er>, <er>Peon</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chess)</fld>
<def>A man or piece of the lowest rank.</def>

<hw>Pawn</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>pan</ets> pledge,
assurance, skirt, piece, F. <ets>pan</ets> skirt, lappet, piece,
from L. <ets>pannus</ets>. See <er>Pane</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Anything delivered or deposited as security, as for the
payment of money borrowed, or of a debt; a pledge. See
<er>Pledge</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 1.</def>

<q>As for mortgaging or pawning, . . . men will not take
<qex>pawns</qex> without use [<it>i.e.</it>, interest].</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>State of being pledged; a pledge for the
fulfillment of a promise.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Redeem from broking <qex>pawn</qex> the blemish'd crown.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>As the morning dew is a <qex>pawn</qex> of the evening
fatness.</q>
<qau>Donne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A stake hazarded in a wager.</def>
<mark>[Poetic]</mark>

<q>My life I never held but as a <qex>pawn</qex>
To wage against thy enemies.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>In pawn</col>, <col>At pawn</col></mcol>, <cd>in
the state of being pledged. \'bdSweet wife, my honor is <xex>at
pawn<xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pawn ticket</col>,
<cd>a receipt given by the pawnbroker for an article
pledged.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pawn</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<er>Pawning</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To give or

one's watch</as>.</def><-- = to hock (colloq.) -->

<q>And <qex>pawned</qex> the last remaining piece of plate.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pledge for the fulfillment of a promise; to
stake; to risk; to wager; to hazard.</def>

<q><qex>Pawning</qex> his honor to obtain his lust.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Paw`nees"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>; <sing>sing.
<singw>Pawnee</singw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></sing>. <fld>(Ethnol.)</fld>
<def>A tribe of Indians (called also <altname>Loups</altname>)
who formerly occupied the region of the Platte river, but now
live mostly in the Indian Territory. The term is often used in a
wider sense to include also the related tribes of Rickarees and
Wichitas. Called also <altname>Pani</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pax</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>pax</ets>
peace. See <er>Peace</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>
<def>The kiss of peace; also, the embrace in the sanctuary now
substituted for it at High Mass in Roman Catholic churches.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A tablet or board, on
which is a representation of Christ, of the Virgin Mary, or of
some saint and which, in the Mass, was kissed by the priest and
then by the people, in medi\'91val times; an osculatory. It is
still used in communities, confraternities, etc.</def>

<q>Kiss the <qex>pax</qex>, and be quiet like your neighbors.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Pax*il"lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Paxilli</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a peg.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of a peculiar kind of spines
covering the surface of certain starfishes. They are pillarlike,
with a flattened summit which is covered with minute spinules or
granules. See <xex>Illustration</xex> in Appendix.</def>

<hw>Pax"wax`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>faxvax</ets>, fr. AS. <ets>fea<?/</ets> hair (akin to OHG.
<ets>fahs</ets>) + <ets>weaxan</ets> to grow. See <er>Wax</er> to
grow, and cf. <er>Faxed</er>, <er>Pectinate</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The strong ligament of the back of the
neck in quadrupeds. It connects the back of the skull with dorsal
spines of the cervical vertebr\'91, and helps to support the
head. Called also <altname>paxywaxy</altname> and
<altname>packwax</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pay</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>peier</ets>, fr. L. <ets>picare</ets> to pitch,
<ets>i<?/</ets> pitch: cf. OF. <ets>peiz</ets> pitch, F.
<ets>poix</ets>. See <er>Pitch</er> a black substance.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To cover, as bottom of a vessel, a seam,
a spar, etc., with tar or pitch, or waterproof composition of
tallow, resin, etc.; to smear.</def>

<hw>Pay</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Paid</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Paying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>paien</ets>, F.
<ets>payer</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pacare</ets> to pacify, appease,
fr. <ets>pax</ets>, <ets>pacis</ets>, peace. See
<er>Peace</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To satisfy, or content;
specifically, to satisfy (another person) for service rendered,
property delivered, etc.; to discharge one's obligation to; to
make due return to; to compensate; to remunerate; to recompense;
to requite; <as>as, to <ex>pay</ex> workmen or
servants</as>.</def>

<q>May no penny ale them <qex>pay</qex> [<it>i. e.</it>,
satisfy].</q>
<qau>P. Plowman.</qau>

<q>[She] <qex>pays</qex> me with disdain.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, figuratively: To compensate justly; to
requite according to merit; to reward; to punish; to retort or
retaliate upon.</def>

<q>For which, or pay me quickly, or I'll <qex>pay</qex> you.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To discharge, as a debt, demand, or obligation,
by giving or doing what is due or required; to deliver the amount
or value of to the person to whom it is owing; to discharge a
debt by delivering (money owed).</def> \'bd<xex>Pay</xex> me that
thou owest.\'b8

<au>Matt. xviii. 28.</au>

<q>Have patience with me, and I will <qex>pay</qex> thee all.</q>
<qau>Matt. xviii. 26.</qau>

<q>If they <qex>pay</qex> this tax, they starve.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To discharge or fulfill, as a duy; to perform or
render duty, as that which has been promised.</def>

<q>This day have I <qex>paid</qex> my vows.</q>
<qau>Prov. vii. 14.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To give or offer, without an implied obligation;
<as>as, to <ex>pay</ex> attention; to <ex>pay</ex> a
visit.</as></def>

<q>Not <qex>paying</qex> me a welcome.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To pay off</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To make compensation
to and discharge; <as>as, <ex>to pay off<ex> the crew of a
ship</as></cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To allow (a thread, cord, etc.)
to run off; to unwind.</cd> -- <col>To pay one's duty</col>,
<cd>to render homage, as to a sovereign or other superior.</cd>
-- <col>To pay out</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to pass out;
hence, to slacken; to allow to run out; <as>as, <ex>to pay
out<ex> more cable.</as>  See under <er>Cable</er>.</cd> --
<col>To pay the piper</col>, <cd>to bear the cost, expense, or
trouble.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cs>

<hw>Pay</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To give a
recompense; to make payment, requital, or satisfaction; to
discharge a debt.</def>

<q>The wicked borroweth, and <qex>payeth</qex> not again.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxvii. 21.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, to make or secure suitable return for
expense or trouble; to be remunerative or profitable; to be worth
the effort or pains required; <as>as, it will <ex>pay</ex> to
ride; it will <ex>pay</ex> to wait; politeness always
<ex>pays</ex>.</as></def>

<cs><col>To pay for</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To make amends for;
to atone for; <as>as, men often <ex>pay for<ex> their mistakes
with loss of property or reputation, sometimes with
life</as></cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To give an equivalent for; to
bear the expense of; to be mulcted on account of.</cd>

<q>'T was I <qex>paid for</qex> your sleeps; I watched your
wakings.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

-- <col>To pay off</col>. <ety>[Etymol. uncertain.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <cd>To fall to leeward, as the head of a
vessel under sail.</cd> -- <col>To pay on</col>. <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain.]</ety> <cd>To beat with vigor; to redouble blows.</cd>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>To pay round</col> <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <cd>To turn the ship's
head.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pay</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Satisfaction;
content.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An equivalent or return for money due, goods
purchased, or services performed; salary or wages for work or
service; compensation; recompense; payment; hire; <as>as, the
<ex>pay</ex> of a clerk; the <ex>pay</ex> of a
soldier.</as></def>

<q>Where only merit constant <qex>pay</qex> receives.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>There is neither <qex>pay</qex> nor plunder to be got.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<cs><col>Full pay</col>, <cd>the whole amount of wages or salary;
maximum pay; especially, the highest pay or allowance to civil or
military officers of a certain rank, without deductions.</cd> --
<col>Half pay</col>. <cd>See under <er>Half</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pay day</col>, <cd>the day of settlement of accounts.</cd>
-- <col>Pay dirt</col> <fld>(Mining)</fld>, <cd>earth which
yields a profit to the miner.</cd> <mark>[Western U.S.]</mark> --
<col>Pay office</col></mcol>, <cd>a place where payment is
made.</cd> -- <col>Pay roll</col>, <cd>a roll or list of persons
entitled to payment, with the amounts due.</cd></cs><-- (b) the
total sum of money which is paid to all employees on payday -->

<hw>Pay"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>payable</ets>. Cf. <er>Pacable</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>That may, can, or should be paid; suitable to be paid;
justly due.</def>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<q>Thanks are a tribute <qex>payable</qex> by the poorest.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>That may be
discharged or settled by delivery of value.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Matured; now due.</def>

<hw>Pay*ee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The person to
whom money is to be, or has been, paid; the person named in a
bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, the amount is promised
or directed to be paid. See <cref>Bill of exchange</cref>, under
<er>Bill</er>.</def>

<hw>Pay"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. & a.</pos> <def>Pagan.
<ety>[F.]</ety> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pay"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who pays;
specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or
should be, paid.</def>

<hw>Pay"mas`ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pays; one who compensates, rewards, or requites; specifically, an
officer or agent of a government, a corporation, or an employer,
whose duty it is to pay salaries, wages, etc., and keep account
of the same.</def>

<hw>Pay"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>payment</ets>, <ets>paiement</ets>. See <er>Pay</er> to
requite.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of paying, or giving
compensation; the discharge of a debt or an obligation.</def>

<q>No man envieth the <qex>payment</qex> of a debt.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is paid; the thing given in discharge
of a debt, or an obligation, or in fulfillment of a promise;
reward; recompense; requital; return.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Punishment; chastisement.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Payn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. & F.
<ets>pain</ets>, fr. L. <ets>panis</ets> bread.]</ety>

<hw>Payn`de*main"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pain</ets> bread + <ets>demaine</ets> manorial, lordly, own,
private. See <er>Payn</er>, and <er>Demesne</er>. Said to be so

<hw>Pay"tine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>An alkaloid obtained from a white bark resembling that of

<hw>Pea</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>peis</ets>. See <er>Poise</er>.]</ety> <def>The sliding
weight on a steelyard.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pee</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pea</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Peak</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 3.</def>

<hw>Pea</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Peas</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr> or <plw>Pease</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>pese</ets>, fr. AS. <ets>pisa</ets>, or OF. <ets>peis</ets>,
F. <ets>pois</ets>; both fr. L. <ets>pisum</ets>; cf. Gr. <?/,
<?/. The final <ets>s</ets> was misunderstood in English as a
plural ending. Cf. <er>Pease</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A plant, and its fruit, of the genus
<spn>Pisum</spn>, of many varieties, much cultivated for food. It
has a papilionaceous flower, and the pericarp is a legume,
popularly called a <xex>pod</xex>.</def>

<note><hand/ When a definite number, more than one, is spoken of,
the plural form <xex>peas</xex> is used; as, the pod contained
nine <xex>peas</xex>; but, in a collective sense, the form
<xex>pease</xex> is preferred; as, a bushel of <xex>pease</xex>;
they had <xex>pease</xex> at dinner. This distinction is not
always preserved, the form <xex>peas</xex> being used in both
senses.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A name given, especially in the Southern States,
to the seed of several leguminous plants (species of
<spn>Dolichos</spn>, <spn>Cicer</spn>, <spn>Abrus</spn>, etc.)
esp. those having a scar (<xex>hilum</xex>) of a different color
from the rest of the seed.</def>

<note><hand/ The name <xex>pea</xex> is given to many leguminous
plants more or less closely related to the common pea. See the
Phrases, below.</note>

<cs><col>Beach pea</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a seashore plant,
<spn>Lathyrus maritimus</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Black-eyed pea</col>,
<cd>a West Indian name for <spn>Dolichos sph\'91rospermus</spn>
and its seed.</cd> -- <col>Butterfly pea</col>, <cd>the American
plant <spn>Clitoria Mariana</spn>, having showy blossoms.</cd> --
<col>Chick pea</col>. <cd>See <er>Chick-pea</er>.</cd> --
<col>Egyptian pea</col>. <cd>Same as <er>Chick-pea</er>.</cd> --
<col>Everlasting pea</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Everlasting</er>.</cd> -- <col>Glory pea</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Glory</er>, <pos>n.</pos></cd> -- <col>Hoary pea</col>,
<cd>any plant of the genus <spn>Tephrosia</spn>; goat's rue.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Issue pea</col>, <col>Orris pea</col></mcol>.
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>See under <er>Issue</er>, and
<er>Orris</er>.</cd> -- <col>Milk pea</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<cd>See under <er>Milk</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pea berry</col>, <cd>a
kind of a coffee bean or grain which grows single, and is round
or pea-shaped; often used adjectively; as, <xex>pea-berry<xex>
coffee.</cd> -- <col>Pea bug</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<cd>Same as <er>Pea weevil</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pea coal</col>,
<cd>a size of coal smaller than nut coal.</cd> -- <col>Pea
crab</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any small crab of the genus
<spn>Pinnotheres</spn>, living as a commensal in bivalves; esp.,
the European species (<spn>P. pisum</spn>) which lives in the
common mussel and the cockle.</cd> -- <col>Pea dove</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the American ground dove.</cd> --
<col>Pea-flower tribe</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a suborder
(<spn>Papilionace\'91</spn>) of leguminous plants having blossoms
essentially like that of the pea. <au>G. Bentham</au>.</cd> --
<col>Pea maggot</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the larva of a
European moth (<spn>Tortrix pisi</spn>), which is very
destructive to peas.</cd> -- <col>Pea ore</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>argillaceous oxide of iron, occurring in
round grains of a size of a pea; pisolitic ore.</cd> -- <col>Pea
starch</col>, <cd>the starch or flour of the common pea, which is
sometimes used in adulterating wheat flour, pepper, etc.</cd> --
<col>Pea tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the name of several
leguminous shrubs of the genus <spn>Caragana</spn>, natives of
Siberia and China.</cd> -- <col>Pea vine</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Any plant which bears peas</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>A kind of vetch or tare, common in the United States
(<spn>Lathyrus Americana</spn>, and other similar species).</cd>
-- <col>Pea weevil</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small
weevil (<spn>Bruchus pisi</spn>) which destroys peas by eating
out the interior.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon pea</col>.
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Pigeon pea</er>.</cd> -- <col>Sweet
pea</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the annual plant <spn>Lathyrus
odoratus</spn>; also, its many-colored, sweet-scented
blossoms.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pea"bird`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The wryneck; -- so called from its
note.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pea"bod*y bird`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>An American sparrow (<spn>Zonotrichia albicollis</spn>)
having a conspicuous white throat. The name is imitative of its
note. Called also <altname>White-throated
sparrow</altname>.</def>

<hw>Peace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pees</ets>, <ets>pais</ets>, OF. pais, paiz, pes, F.
<ets>paix</ets>, L. <ets>pax</ets>, <ets>pacis</ets>, akin to
<ets>pacere</ets>, <ets>paciscere</ets>, <ets>pacisci</ets>, to
make an agreement, and prob. also <ets>pangere</ets> to fasten.
Cf. <er>Appease</er>, <er>Fair</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, <er>Fay</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>, <er>Fang</er>, <er>Pacify</er>, <er>Pact</er>,
<er>Pay</er> to requite.]</ety> <def>A state of quiet or
tranquillity; freedom from disturbance or agitation; calm;
repose</def>; specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Exemption from, or
cessation of, war with public enemies</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Public quiet, order, and contentment in obedience to
law</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Exemption from, or subjection of,
agitating passions; tranquillity of mind or conscience</def>.
<sd>(d)</sd> <def>Reconciliation; agreement after variance;
harmony; concord.</def> \'bdThe eternal love and
<xex>pees</xex>.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<note><hand/ <xex>Peace</xex> is sometimes used as an exclamation
in commanding silence, quiet, or order. \'bd<xex>Peace</xex>!
foolish woman.\'b8</note>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>At peace</col>, <cd>in a state of peace.</cd> --
<col>Breach of the peace</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Breach</er>.</cd> -- <col>Justice of the peace</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Justice</er>.</cd> -- <col>Peace of God</col>.
<fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A term used in wills,
indictments, etc., as denoting a state of peace and good
conduct.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <cd>The peace of
heart which is the gift of God.</cd> -- <col>Peace
offering</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Jewish Antiq.)</fld> <cd>A
voluntary offering to God in token of devout homage and of a
sense of friendly communion with Him</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A
gift or service offered as satisfaction to an offended
person.</cd> -- <col>Peace officer</col>, <cd>a civil officer
whose duty it is to preserve the public peace, to prevent riots,
etc., as a sheriff or constable.</cd> -- <col>To hold one's
peace</col>, <cd>to be silent; to refrain from speaking.</cd> --
<col>To make one's peace with</col>, <cd>to reconcile one with,
to plead one's cause with, or to become reconciled with, another.
\'bdI will <xex>make your peace<xex> with him.\'b8
<au>Shak</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peace</hw>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos> <def>To make or become
quiet; to be silent; to stop.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Peace</xex> your tattlings.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>When the thunder would not <qex>peace</qex> at my bidding.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Peace"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>peisible</ets>, F. <ets>paisible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Begin in
or at peace; tranquil; quiet; free from, or not disposed to, war,
disorder, or excitement; not quarrelsome.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Peace"a*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>Peace"a*bly</wf>, adv.</wordforms>

<syn>Syn. -- Peaceful; pacific; tranquil; quiet; mild;
undisturbed; serene; still.</syn>  -- <usage><er>Peaceable</er>,
<er>Peaceful</er>. <xex>Peaceable</xex> describes the state of an
individual, nation, etc., in reference to external hostility,
attack, etc.; <xex>peaceful</xex>, in respect to internal
disturbance. The former denotes \'bdin the spirit of peace;\'b8
latter; \'bdin the possession or enjoyment of peace.\'b8  A
<xex>peaceable</xex> adjustment of difficulties; a
<xex>peaceful</xex> life, scene.</usage>

<hw>Peace"break`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
disturbs the public peace.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Peace"break`ing</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Peace"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Possessing or enjoying peace; not disturbed by war, tumult,
agitation, anxiety, or commotion; quiet; tranquil; <as>as, a
<ex>peaceful</ex> time; a <ex>peaceful</ex> country; a
<ex>peaceful</ex> end.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not disposed or tending to war, tumult or
agitation; pacific; mild; calm; peaceable; <as>as,
<ex>peaceful</ex> words</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Peaceable</er>.</syn>

<hw>Peach</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>peche</ets>, <ets>peshe</ets>, OF. <ets>pesche</ets>, F.
<ets>p\'88che</ets>, fr. LL. <ets>persia</ets>, L.
<ets>Persicum</ets> (sc. <ets>malum</ets>) a Persian apple, a
peach. Cf. <er>Persian</er>, and <er>Parsee</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A well-known high-flavored juicy fruit,
containing one or two seeds in a hard almond-like endocarp or
stone; also, the tree which bears it (<spn>Prunus, <or/ Amygdalus
Persica</spn>). In the wild stock the fruit is hard and
inedible.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Guinea</col>, <or/ <col>Sierra Leone</col>,
<col>peach</col></mcol>, <cd>the large edible berry of the
<spn>Sarcocephalus esculentus</spn>, a rubiaceous climbing shrub
of west tropical Africa.</cd> -- <col>Palm peach</col>, <cd>the
fruit of a Venezuelan palm tree (<spn>Bactris
speciosa</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Peach color</col>, <cd>the pale red
color of the peach blossom.</cd> -- <col>Peach-tree borer</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the larva of a clearwing moth
(<spn>\'92geria, <or/ Sannina, exitiosa</spn>) of the family
<spn>\'92geriid\'91</spn>, which is very destructive to peach
trees by boring in the wood, usually near the ground; also, the
moth itself.  See <xex>Illust.</xex> under
<er>Borer</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pea"cock`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pecok</ets>. <ets>Pea-</ets> in this word is from AS.
<ets>pe\'a0</ets>, <ets>p\'bewa</ets>, peacock, fr. L.
<ets>pavo</ets>, prob. of Oriental origin; cf. Gr. <?/, <?/, Per.
<ets>t\'beus</ets>, <ets>t\'bewus</ets>, Ar.
<ets>t\'bewu<?/s</ets>. See <er>Cock</er> the bird.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The male of any pheasant
of the genus <spn>Pavo</spn>, of which at least two species are
known, native of Southern Asia and the East Indies.</def>

<note><hand/ The upper tail coverts, which are long and capable
of erection, are each marked with a black spot bordered by
concentric bands of brilliant blue, green, and golden colors. The
common domesticated species is <spn>Pavo cristatus</spn>. The
Javan peacock (<spn>P. muticus</spn>) is more brilliantly colored
than the common species.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In common usage, the species in general or
collectively; a peafowl.</def>

<cs><col>Peacock butterfly</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
handsome European butterfly (<spn>Hamadryas Io</spn>) having
ocelli like those of peacock.</cd> -- <col>Peacock fish</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the European blue-striped wrasse
(<spn>Labrus variegatus</spn>); -- so called on account of its
brilliant colors. Called also <altname>cook wrasse</altname> and
<altname>cook</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Peacock pheasant</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of handsome
Asiatic pheasants of the genus <spn>Polyplectron</spn>. They
resemble the peacock in color.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peak</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pek</ets>, AS. <ets>peac</ets>, perh of Celtic origin; cf.
Ir. <ets>peac</ets> a sharp-pointed thing. Cf.
<er>Pike</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A point; the sharp end or
top of anything that terminates in a point; <as>as, the
<ex>peak</ex>, or front, of a cap</as>.</def> \'bdRun your beard
into a <xex>peak</xex>.\'b8

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The top, or one of the tops, of a hill,
mountain, or range, ending in a point; often, the whole hill or
mountain, esp. when isolated; <as>as, the <ex>Peak</ex> of
Teneriffe</as>.</def>

<q>Silent upon a <qex>peak</qex> in Darien.</q>
<qau>Keats.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The upper
aftermost corner of a fore-and-aft sail; -- used in many
combinations; <as>as, <ex>peak</ex>-halyards,
<ex>peak</ex>-brails, etc</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
narrow part of a vessel's bow, or the hold within it.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>The extremity of an anchor fluke; the
bill.</def> <altsp>[In the last sense written also <asp>pea</asp>
and <asp>pee</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Fore peak</col>. <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Fore</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peak</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Peaked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Peaking</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To rise or extend
into a peak or point; to form, or appear as, a peak.</def>

<q>There <qex>peaketh</qex> up a mighty high mount.</q>
<qau>Holand.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To acquire sharpness of figure or features;
hence, to look thin or sicky.</def> \'bdDwindle, <xex>peak</xex>,
and pine.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Cf. <er>Peek</er>.]</ety> <def>To pry; to peep
slyly.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Peak arch</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a pointed or
Gothic arch.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peak</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To raise
to a position perpendicular, or more nearly so; <as>as, to
<ex>peak</ex> oars, to hold them upright; to <ex>peak</ex> a gaff
or yard, to set it nearer the perpendicular.</as></def>

<hw>Peal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Etymol.

<hw>Peal</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To appeal.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spencer.</au>

<hw>Peal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[An abbrev. of F.
<ets>appel</ets> a call, appeal, ruffle of a drum, fr.
<ets>appeller</ets> to call, L. <ets>appellare</ets>. See
<er>Appeal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A loud sound, or a
succession of loud sounds, as of bells, thunder, cannon, shouts,
of a multitude, etc.</def> \'bdA fair <xex>peal</xex> of
artillery.\'b8

<au>Hayward.</au>

<q>Whether those <qex>peals</qex> of praise be his or no.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>And a deep thunder, <qex>peal</qex> on <qex>peal</qex>,
afar.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A set of bells tuned to each other according to
the diatonic scale; also, the changes rung on a set of
bells.</def>

<cs><col>To ring a peal</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Ring</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peal</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pealed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pealing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To utter or give
out loud sounds.</def>

<q>There let the <qex>pealing</qex> organ blow.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To resound; to echo.</def>

<q>And the whole air <qex>pealed</qex>
<qex>With the cheers of our men</qex>.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<hw>Peal</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To utter or give
forth loudly; to cause to give out loud sounds; to noise
abroad.</def>

<q>The warrior's name,
Though <qex>pealed</qex> and chimed on all the tongues of
fame.</q>
<qau>J. Barlow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To assail with noise or loud sounds.</def>

<q>Nor was his ear less <qex>pealed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To pour out.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<hw>Pea"nut</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The fruit of a trailing leguminous plant (<spn>Arachis
hypog\'91a</spn>); also, the plant itself, which is widely
cultivated for its fruit.</def>

<note><hand/ The fruit is a hard pod, usually containing two or
three seeds, sometimes but one, which ripen beneath the soil.
Called also <altname>earthnut</altname>,
<altname>groundnut</altname>, and <xex>goober</xex>.</note>

<hw>Pear</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pere</ets>, AS. <ets>peru</ets>, L. <ets>pirum</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>poire</ets>. Cf. <er>Perry</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The fleshy pome, or fruit, of a rosaceous tree (<spn>Pyrus
communis</spn>), cultivated in many varieties in temperate
climates; also, the tree which bears this fruit. See <cref>Pear
family</cref>, below.</def>

<cs><col>Pear blight</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>A
name of two distinct diseases of pear trees, both causing a
destruction of the branches, viz., that caused by a minute insect
(<spn>Xyleborus pyri</spn>), and that caused by the freezing of
the sap in winter. <au>A. J. Downing</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>A very small beetle (<spn>Xyleborus
pyri</spn>) whose larv\'91 bore in the twigs of pear trees and
cause them to wither.</cd> -- <col>Pear family</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a suborder of rosaceous plants
(<spn>Pome\'91</spn>), characterized by the calyx tube becoming
fleshy in fruit, and, combined with the ovaries, forming a pome.
It includes the apple, pear, quince, service berry, and
hewthorn.</cd> -- <col>Pear gauge</col> <fld>(Physics)</fld>,
<cd>a kind of gauge for measuring the exhaustion of an air-pump
receiver; -- so called because consisting in part of a
pear-shaped glass vessel.</cd> <col>Pear shell</col></mcol>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any marine gastropod shell of the
genus <spn>Pyrula</spn>, native of tropical seas; -- so called
from the shape.</cd> -- <col>Pear slug</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the larva of a sawfly which is very
injurious to the foliage of the pear tree.</cd></cs>

<-- Illustr. of pear slug (Celandria cerasi) -->

<hw>Pearch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<def>See <er>Perch</er>.</def>

<hw>Pearl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A fringe or
border.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> -- <def2><pos>v. t. </pos>
<def>To fringe; to border. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> See
<er>Purl</er>.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Pearl stitch</col>. <cd>See <cref>Purl stitch</cref>,
under <er>Purl</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pearl</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>perle</ets>, F.
<ets>perle</ets>, LL. <ets>perla</ets>, <ets>perula</ets>,
probably fr. (assumed) L. <ets>pirulo</ets>, dim. of L.
<ets>pirum</ets> a pear. See <er>Pear</er>, and cf. <er>Purl</er>
to mantle.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A shelly
concretion, usually rounded, and having a brilliant luster, with
varying tints, found in the mantle, or between the mantle and
shell, of certain bivalve mollusks, especially in the pearl
oysters and river mussels, and sometimes in certain univalves. It
is usually due to a secretion of shelly substance around some
irritating foreign particle. Its substance is the same as nacre,
or mother-of-pearl. Pearls which are round, or nearly round, and
of fine luster, are highly esteemed as jewels, and compare in
value with the precious stones.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, figuratively, something resembling a
pearl; something very precious.</def>

<q>I see thee compassed with thy kingdom's <qex>pearl</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>And those <qex>pearls</qex> of dew she wears.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Nacre, or mother-of-pearl.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A fish allied to the
turbot; the brill.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A light-colored
tern.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the circle of
tubercles which form the bur on a deer's antler.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A whitish speck or film on the eye.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A capsule of gelatin or similar substance
containing some liquid for medicinal application, as ether.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>A size of type, between
agate and diamond.</def>

\'b5 <pearltype>This line is printed in the type called
<ex>pearl</ex>.</pearltype>

<cs><col>Ground pearl</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Ground</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pearl barley</col>, <cd>kernels of
barley, ground so as to form small, round grains.</cd> --
<col>Pearl diver</col>, <cd>one who dives for pearl oysters.</cd>
-- <col>Pearl edge</col>, <cd>an edge of small loops on the side
of some kinds of ribbon; also, a narrow kind of thread edging to
be sewed on lace.</cd> -- <col>Pearl eye</col>,
<cd>cataract.</cd> <mark>[R.]</mark> -- <col>Pearl
gray</col></mcol>, <cd>a very pale and delicate blue-gray
color.</cd> -- <col>Pearl millet</col>, <cd>Egyptian millet
(<spn>Penicillaria spicata</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Pearl moss</col>.
<cd>See <er>Carrageen</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pearl moth</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any moth of the genus
<spn>Margaritia</spn>; -- so called on account of its pearly
color.</cd> -- <col>Pearl oyster</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>any one of several species of large tropical marine bivalve
mollusks of the genus <spn>Meleagrina</spn>, or
<spn>Margaritifera</spn>, found in the East Indies (especially at
Ceylon), in the Persian Gulf, on the coast of Australia, and on
the Pacific coast of America. Called also <altname>pearl
shell</altname>, and <altname>pearl mussel</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Pearl powder</col>. <cd>See <cref>Pearl white</cref>,
below.</cd> -- <col>Pearl sago</col>, <cd>sago in the form of
small pearly grains.</cd> -- <col>Pearl sinter</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>fiorite.</cd> -- <col>Pearl spar</col>
<fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a crystallized variety of dolomite, having
a pearly luster.</cd> -- <col>Pearl white</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>Basic bismuth nitrate, or bismuth subchloride; -- used
chiefly as a cosmetic</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A variety of white
lead blued with indigo or Berlin blue.</cd></cs><-- cultured
pearl, a pearl grown by a pearl oyster into which a round pellet
has been placed, to serve as the seed for more predictable growth
of the pearl.  The pellet is usually made from mother-of-pearl,
and additional layers of nacre are deposited onto the seed by the
oyster.  Such pearls, being more easily obtained than natural
pearls, are less expensive. -->

<hw>Pearl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining
to pearl or pearls; made of pearls, or of mother-of-pearl.</def>

<hw>Pearl</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To set or adorn
with pearls, or with mother-of-pearl. Used also
figuratively.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cause to resemble pearls; to make into small
round grains; <as>as, to <ex>pearl</ex> barley</as>.</def>

<hw>Pearl</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To resemble
pearl or pearls.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To give or hunt for pearls; <as>as, to go
<ex>pearling</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pearl*a"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Resembling pearl or mother-of-pearl; pearly in quality or
appearance.</def>

<hw>Pearl"ash`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A white amorphous or granular substance
which consists principally of potassium carbonate, and has a
strong alkaline reaction. It is obtained by lixiviating wood
ashes, and evaporating the lye, and has been an important source
of potassium compounds. It is used in making soap, glass,
etc.</def>

<hw>Pearl"-eyed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a
pearly speck in the eye; afflicted with the cataract.</def>

<hw>Pearl"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any fish whose scales yield a
pearl-like pigment used in manufacturing artificial pearls, as
the bleak, and whitebait.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

glassy volcanic rock of a grayish color and pearly luster, often
having a spherulitic concretionary structure due to the curved
cracks produced by contraction in cooling. See <xex>Illust</xex>.
under <er>Perlitic</er>.</def>

<hw>Peat</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. for <ets>beat</ets>,
prop., material used to make the fire burn <ets>better</ets>, fr.
AS. <ets>b<?/tan</ets> to better, mend (a fire), <ets>b<?/t</ets>
advantage. See <er>Better</er>, <er>Boot</er> advantage.]</ety>
<def>A substance of vegetable origin, consisting of roots and
fibers, moss, etc., in various stages of decomposition, and
found, as a kind of turf or bog, usually in low situations, where
it is always more or less saturated with water. It is often dried
and used for fuel.</def>

<cs><col>Peat bog</col>, <cd>a bog containing peat; also, peat as
it occurs in such places; peat moss.</cd> -- <col>Peat
moss</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The plants which, when decomposed,
become peat</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A fen producing peat</cd>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>Moss of the genus
<spn>Sphagnum</spn>, which often grows abundantly in boggy or
peaty places.</cd> -- <col>Peat reek</col>, <cd>the reek or smoke
of peat; hence, also, the peculiar flavor given to whisky by
being distilled with peat as fuel. <mark>[Scot.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Pec"ca*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Peccaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[From the native
South American name: cf. F. <ets>p\'82cari</ets>, Sp.
<ets>pecar</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A pachyderm
of the genus <spn>Dicotyles</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ The collared peccary, or tajacu (<spn>Dicotyles
torquatus</spn>), is about the size and shape of a small hog, and
has a white ring aroung the neck. It ranges from Arkansas to
Brazil. A larger species (<spn>D. labiatus</spn>), with white
cheeks, is found in South America.</note>

<hw>Peck</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. akin to <ets>pack</ets>;
or, orig., an indefinite quantity, and fr. <ets>peck</ets>, v.
(below): cf. also F. <ets>picotin</ets> a peak.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The fourth part of a bushel; a dry measure of
eight quarts; <as>as, a <ex>peck</ex> of wheat</as>.</def> \'bdA
<xex>peck</xex> of provender.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A great deal; a large or excessive
quantity.</def> \'bdA <xex>peck</xex> of uncertainties and
doubts.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>.

<hw>Peck</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pecked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pecking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See <er>Pick</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To strike with the beak; to
thrust the beak into; <as>as, a bird <ex>pecks</ex> a
tree</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: To strike, pick, thrust against, or dig
into, with a pointed instrument; especially, to strike, pick,
etc., with repeated quick movements.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To seize and pick up with the beak, or as with
the beak; to bite; to eat; -- often with <xex>up</xex>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>This fellow <qex>pecks</qex> up wit as pigeons peas.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To make, by striking with the beak or a pointed
instrument; <as>as, to <ex>peck</ex> a hole in a tree</as>.</def>

<hw>Peck</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make strokes
with the beak, or with a pointed instrument.</def>

<au>Carew.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pick up food with the beak; hence, to
eat.</def>

<q>[The hen] went <qex>pecking</qex> by his side.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>To peck at</col>, <cd>to attack with petty and repeated
blows; to carp at; to nag; to tease.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1056 -->

<hw>Peck</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A quick, sharp
stroke, as with the beak of a bird or a pointed instrument.</def>

<au>Garth.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pe*cop"te*ris</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ to comb + <?/ a kind of fern.]</ety>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An extensive genus of fossil ferns; --
so named from the regular comblike arrangement of the
leaflets.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pec"o*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. L. <ets>pecus</ets>. See <er>Pecuniary</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An extensive division of ruminants,
including the antelopes, deer, and cattle.</def>

<hw>Pec"tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A salt of pectic acid.</def>

<hw>Pec"ten</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pecten</ets>, <ets>-inis</ets>, a comb, a kind of shellfish.
See <er>Pectinate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>A vascular pigmented membrane projecting into
the vitreous humor within the globe of the eye in birds, and in
many reptiles and fishes; -- also called
<altname>marsupium</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The pubic
bone.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of bivalve
mollusks of the genus <spn>Pecten</spn>, and numerous allied
genera (family <spn>Pectinid\'91</spn>); a scallop. See
<er>Scallop</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The comb of a scorpion.
See <er>Comb</er>, 4 <sd>(b)</sd>.</def>

<hw>Pec"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
curdled.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to
pectin; specifically, designating an acid obtained from ordinary
vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphous substance, tough and
horny when dry, but gelatinous when moist.</def>

<hw>Pec"tin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
curdled, congealed, from <?/ to make fast or stiff: cf. F.
<ets>pectine</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a
series of carbohydrates, commonly called <altname>vegetable
jelly</altname>, found very widely distributed in the vegetable
kingdom, especially in ripe fleshy fruits, as apples,
cranberries, etc. It is extracted as variously colored,
translucent substances, which are soluble in hot water but become
viscous on cooling.</def>

<hw>Pec"ti*nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pecten</ets> comb. See <er>Pectinate</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to a comb; resembling a comb.</def>

<hw>Pec"ti*nal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A fish whose bone<?/
resemble comb teeth.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pec"ti*na`te</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pec"ti*na`ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pectinatus</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>pectinare</ets> to comb,
from <ets>pecten</ets>, <ets>-inis</ets>, a comb; cf. Gr. <?/ to

<ets>paxwax</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Resembling the teeth
of a comb.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Nat. Hist.)</fld> <def>Having very narrow,
close divisions, in arrangement and regularity resembling those
of a comb; comblike; <as>as, a <ex>pectinate</ex> leaf;
<ex>pectinated</ex> muscles</as>.  See <xex>Illust</xex>.
<sd>(e)</sd> of <er>Antenn\'91</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Interlaced, like two combs.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdOur fingers <xex>pectinated</xex>, or shut
together.\'b8

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<cs><col>Pectinate claw</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a claw
having a serrate edge, found in some birds, and supposed to be
used in cleaning the feathers.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pec"to*ral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<cs><mcol><col>Pectoral arch</col>, <or/ <col>Pectoral
girdle</col></mcol> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the two or more bony
or cartilaginous pieces of the vertebrate skeleton to which the
fore limbs are articulated; the shoulder girdle. In man it
consists of two bones, the scapula and clavicle, on each
side.</cd> -- <col>Pectorial cross</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>,
<cd>a cross worn on the breast by bishops and abbots, and
sometimes also by canons.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Pectorial</col>
fins, <or/ <col>Pectorials</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>fins situated on the sides, behind the gills. See
<xex>Illust<xex>. under <er>Fin</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pectorial
rail</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Land rail</cref>
<sd>(b)</sd> under <er>Land</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pectorial
sandpiper</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the jacksnipe
<sd>(b)</sd>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pec`to*ril"o*quy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>loqui</ets> to speak: cf. F.
<ets>pectoriloquie</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The
distinct articulation of the sounds of a patient's voice, heard
on applying the ear to the chest in auscultation. It usually
indicates some morbid change in the lungs or pleural
cavity.</def>

<hw>Pec"tose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pect</ets>ic + cellul<ets>ose</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An amorphous carbohydrate found in the
vegetable kingdom, esp. in unripe fruits. It is associated with
cellulose, and is converted into substances of the pectin
group.</def>

<hw>Pec"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Peculated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Peculating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>peculatus</ets>,
p.p. of <ets>peculari</ets> to peculate, akin to
<ets>peculium</ets> private property. See
<er>Peculiar</er>.]</ety> <def>To appropriate to one's own use
the property of the public; to steal public moneys intrusted to
one's care; to embezzle.</def>

<q>An oppressive, . . . rapacious, and <qex>peculating</qex>
despotism.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Pec`u*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
or practice of peculating, or of defrauding the public by
appropriating to one's own use the money or goods intrusted to
one's care for management or disbursement; embezzlement.</def>

<q>Every British subject . . . active in the discovery of
<qex>peculations</qex> has been ruined.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Pec"u*la`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<def>One who peculates.</def> \'bd<xex>Peculators</xex> of the
public gold.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>Pe*cul"iar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>peculiaris</ets>, fr. <ets>peculium</ets> private property,
akin to <ets>pecunia</ets> money: cf. OF. <ets>peculier</ets>.
See <er>Pecuniary</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One's own;
belonging solely or especially to an individual; not possessed by
others; of private, personal, or characteristic possession and
use; not owned in common or in participation.</def>

<q>And purify unto himself a <qex>peculiar</qex> people.</q>
<qau>Titus ii. 14.</qau>

<q>Hymns . . . that Christianity hath <qex>peculiar</qex> unto
itself.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Particular; individual; special;
appropriate.</def>

<q>While each <qex>peculiar</qex> power forgoes his wonted
seat.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>My fate is Juno's most <qex>peculiar</qex> care.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Unusual; singular; rare; strange; <as>as, the
sky had a <ex>peculiar</ex>appearance</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Peculiar</er>, <er>Special</er>,
<er>Especial</er>.</syn> <usage> <xex>Peculiar</xex> is from the
Roman <xex>peculium</xex>, which was a thing emphatically and
distinctively one's own, and hence was dear. The former sense
always belongs to <xex>peculiar</xex> (as, a <xex>peculiar</xex>
style, <xex>peculiar</xex> manners, etc.), and usually so much of
the latter as to involve feelings of interest; as,
<xex>peculiar</xex> care, watchfulness, satisfaction, etc.
Nothing of this kind belongs to <xex>special</xex> and
<xex>especial</xex>. They mark simply the relation of
<xex>species</xex> to <xex>genus</xex>, and denote that there is
something in this case more than ordinary; as, a
<xex>special</xex> act of Congress; <xex>especial</xex> pains,
etc.</usage>

<q>Beauty, which, either walking or asleep,
Shot forth <qex>peculiar</qex> graces.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>For naught so vile that on the earth doth live,
But to the earth some <qex>special</qex> good doth give.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pe*cul"iar</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
peculiar; a sole or exclusive property; a prerogative; a
characteristic.</def>

<q>Revenge is . . . the <qex>peculiar</qex> of Heaven.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Canon Law)</fld> <def>A particular parish
or church which is exempt from the jurisdiction of the
ordinary.</def>

<cs><col>Court of Peculiars</col> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld>, <cd>a
branch of the Court of Arches having cognizance of the affairs of
peculiars. <au>Blackstone</au>.</cd> -- <col>Dean of
peculiars</col>. <cd>See under <er>Dean</er>, 1.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pe*cul`iar"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Peculiarities</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being peculiar; individuality;
singularity.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is peculiar; a special and
distinctive characteristic or habit; particularity.</def>

<q>The smallest <qex>peculiarity</qex> of temper on manner.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Exclusive possession or right.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pe*cu"li*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. See

<hw>Ped"a*gogue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld> <def>A slave who led his master's

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A teacher of children; one whose occupation is

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who by teaching has become formal, positive,
or pedantic in his ways; one who has the manner of a
schoolmaster; a pedant.</def>

<hw>Pe"dal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pedalis</ets>, fr. <ets>pes</ets>, <ets>pedis</ets>, foot.
See <er>Foot</er>, and cf. <er>Pew</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to the foot, or to feet, literally or
figuratively; specifically <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, pertaining to
the foot of a mollusk; <as>as, the <ex>pedal</ex>
ganglion</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <pr>(<?/)</pr> <def>Of or pertaining to a pedal;
having pedals.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Pedal curve</col> <or/ <col>surface</col></mcol>
<fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>the curve or surface which is the locus
of the feet of perpendiculars let fall from a fixed point upon
the straight lines tangent to a given curve, or upon the planes
tangent to a given surface.</cd> -- <col>Pedal note</col>
<fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>the note which is held or sustained
through an organ point. See <cref>Organ point</cref>, under
<er>Organ</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pedal organ</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>,
<cd>an organ which has pedals or a range of keys moved by the
feet; that portion of a full organ which is played with the
feet.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pe"dal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82dale</ets>, It. <ets>pedale</ets>. See <er>Pedal</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A lever
or key acted on by the foot, as in the pianoforte to raise the
dampers, or in the organ to open and close certain pipes; a
treadle, as in a lathe or a bicycle.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A pedal curve or
surface.</def>

<hw>Pe*da"li*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Relating to
the foot, or to a metrical foot; pedal.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Maunder.</au>

<hw>Pe*dal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of

<hw>Ped"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<au>Addison.</au>

<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<hw>Pe*da"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pedarius</ets>, fr. <ets>pedarius</ets> belonging to the
foot, fr. <ets>pes</ets>, <ets>pedis</ets>, foot.]</ety>
<fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>One of a class eligible to the
office of senator, but not yet chosen, who could sit and speak in
the senate, but could not vote; -- so called because he might
indicate his opinion by walking over to the side of the party he
favored when a vote was taken.</def>

<hw>Ped"dle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Peddler</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To travel about with
wares for sale; to go from place to place, or from house to
house, for the purpose of retailing goods; <as>as, to
<ex>peddle</ex> without a license</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To do a small business; to be busy about
trifles; to piddle.</def>

<hw>Ped"dle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Peddled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Peddling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
sell from place to place; to retail by carrying around from
customer to customer; to hawk; hence, to retail in very small
quantities; <as>as, to <ex>peddle</ex> vegetables or
tinware</as>.</def>

<hw>Ped"dler</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<ets>peoddare</ets>, fr. OE. <ets>ped</ets> a basket, of unknown
origin.]</ety> <def>One who peddles; a traveling trader; one who
travels about, retailing small wares; a hawker.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>pedlar</asp> and
<asp>pedler</asp>.]</altsp> \'bdSome vagabond huckster or
<xex>peddler</xex>.\'b8

<au>Hakluyt.</au>

<hw>Ped"es*tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.
<ets>pedestal</ets>; cf. F. <ets>pi\'82destal</ets>, It.
<ets>piedestallo</ets>; fr. L. <ets>es</ets>, <ets>pedis</ets>,
foot + OHG. <ets>stal</ets> standing place, station, place, akin
to E. <ets>stall</ets>. See <er>Foot</er>, and <er>Stall</er>,
and <er>Footstall</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<def>The base or foot of a column, statue, vase, lamp, or the
like; the part on which an upright work stands. It consists of
three parts, the base, the die or dado, and the cornice or
surbase molding. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Column</er>.</def>

<q>Build him a <qex>pedestal</qex>, and say, \'bdStand
there!\'b8</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Railroad Cars)</fld> <def>A
casting secured to the frame of a truck and forming a jaw for
holding a journal box.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>
<def>A pillow block; a low housing</def>. <sd>(c)</sd>
<fld>(Bridge Building)</fld> <def>An iron socket, or support, for
the foot of a brace at the end of a truss where it rests on a
pier.</def>

<cs><col>Pedestal coil</col> <fld>(steam Heating)</fld>, <cd>a
group of connected straight pipes arranged side by side and one
above another, -- used in a radiator.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ped"i*cel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82dicelle</ets>. See <er>Pedicle</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A stalk which supports one
flower or fruit, whether solitary or one of many ultimate
divisions of a common peduncle. See <er>Peduncle</er>, and
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Flower</er>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A
slender support of any special organ, as that of a capsule in
mosses, an air vesicle in alg\'91, or a sporangium in
ferns.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A slender stem by which
certain of the lower animals or their eggs are attached. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Aphis lion</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The ventral part
of each side of the neural arch connecting with the centrum of a
vertebra.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>An outgrowth of the frontal
bones, which supports the antlers or horns in deer and allied
animals.</def>

<hw>Ped"i*celed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pedicellate.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ped`i*cel*la"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Pedicellari\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.
See <er>Pedicel</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A
peculiar forcepslike organ which occurs in large numbers upon
starfishes and echini. Those of starfishes have two movable jaws,
or blades, and are usually nearly, or quite, sessile; those of
echini usually have three jaws and a pedicel. See
<xex>Illustration</xex> in Appendix.</def>

<hw>Ped"i*cel`late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a
pedicel; supported by a pedicel.</def>

<hw>Ped"i*gree</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Of unknown
origin; possibly fr. F. <ets>par degr\'82s</ets> by degrees, --
for a pedigree is properly a genealogical table which records the

<hw>Ped"i*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>\'d8Ped`i*pal"pi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n pl.</pos>

<hw>Ped`i*pal"pus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pedipalpi</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL. See
<er>Pes</er>, and <er>Palpus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>One of the second pair of mouth organs of arachnids. In some
they are leglike, but in others, as the scorpion, they terminate
in a claw.</def>

<asp>p\'91dobaptist</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Ped"o*man`cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pedi-</ets> + <ets>-mancy</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Divination by examining the soles of the feet.</def>

<hw>Pe*dom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pedi-</ets>, <ets>pedo-</ets> + <ets>-meter</ets>: cf.
F. <ets>p\'82dom\'8atre</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>An
instrument for including the number of steps in walking, and so
ascertaining the distance passed over. It is usually in the form
of a watch; an oscillating weight by the motion of the body
causes the index to advance a certain distance at each
step.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Ped`o*met"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Ped`o*met"ric*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or measured by, a pedometer.</def>

<hw>Ped`o*mo"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pedi-</ets>, <ets>pedo-</ets> +
<ets>-motive</ets>.]</ety> <def>Moved or worked by the action of
the foot or feet on a pedal or treadle.</def>

<hw>Pe*dot"ro*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/, <?/, a child + <?/ to nourish: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82dotrophie</ets>.]</ety> <def>The art of nourishing
children properly.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pe`dre*gal"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp., a
stony place, fr. <ets>piedra</ets> stone.]</ety> <def>A lava
field.</def> <mark>[Mexico & Western U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Pe*dun"cle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formed fr.
(assumed) L. <ets>pedunculus</ets>, dim. of <ets>pes</ets>,
<ets>pedis</ets>, a foot: cf. F. <ets>p\'82doncule</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The stem or stalk that
supports the flower or fruit of a plant, or a cluster of flowers
or fruits.</def>

<note><hand/ The ultimate divisions or branches of a peduncle are
called <xex>pedicels</xex>. In the case of a solitary flower, the
stalk would be called a <xex>peduncle</xex> if the flower is
large, and a <xex>pedicel</xex> if it is small or
delicate.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A sort of stem by which
certain shells and barnacles are attached to other objects. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Barnacle</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A band of nervous or fibrous
matter connecting different parts of the brain; <as>as, the
<ex>peduncles</ex> of the cerebellum; the <ex>peduncles</ex> of
the pineal gland.</as></def>

<hw>Pe*dun"cled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a
peduncle; supported on a peduncle; pedunculate.</def>

<hw>Pe*dun"cu*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82donculaire</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to a
peduncle; growing from a peduncle; <as>as, a <ex>peduncular</ex>
tendril</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pe*dun`cu*la"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Peduncle</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A division of Cirripedia, including the stalked or goose
barnacles.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pe*dun"cu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pe*dun"cu*la`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Having a peduncle; growing on a peduncle;
<as>as, a <ex>pedunculate</ex> flower; a <ex>pedunculate</ex>
eye, as in a lobster.</as></def>

<hw>Peek</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<hw>Peel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pel</ets>. Cf. <er>Pile</er> a heap.]</ety> <def>A small
tower, fort, or castle; a keep.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Peel</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>pelle</ets>, L.
<ets>pala</ets>.]</ety> <def>A spadelike implement, variously
used, as for removing loaves of bread from a baker's oven; also,
a T-shaped implement used by printers and bookbinders for hanging
wet sheets of paper on lines or poles to dry. Also, the blade of
an oar.</def>

<hw>Peel</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Confused with
<ets>peel</ets> to strip, but fr. F. <ets>piller</ets> to
pillage. See <er>Pill</er> to rob, <er>Pillage</er>.]</ety>
<def>To plunder; to pillage; to rob.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>But govern ill the nations under yoke,
<qex>Peeling</qex> their provinces.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Peel</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Peeled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Peeling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>peler</ets> to pull
out the hair, to strip, to peel, fr. L. <ets>pilare</ets> to
deprive of hair, fr. <ets>pilus</ets> a hair; or perh. partly fr.
F. <ets>peler</ets> to peel off the skin, perh. fr. L.
<ets>pellis</ets> skin (cf. <er>Fell</er> skin). Cf.
<er>Peruke</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To strip off the skin,
bark, or rind of; to strip by drawing or tearing off the skin,
bark, husks, etc.; to flay; to decorticate; <as>as, to
<ex>peel</ex> an orange</as>.</def>

<q>The skillful shepherd <qex>peeled</qex> me certain wands.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To strip or tear off; to remove by stripping, as
the skin of an animal, the bark of a tree, etc.</def>

<hw>Peel</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To lose the skin, bark, or
rind; to come off, as the skin, bark, or rind does; -- often used
with an adverb; <as>as, the bark <ex>peels</ex> easily or
readily</as>.</def>

<hw>Peel</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The skin or rind; <as>as, the
<ex>peel</ex> of an orange</as>.</def>

<hw>Pee"le</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A graceful and swift South African antelope (<spn>Pelea
capreola</spn>). The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and
sides. The horns are black, long, slender, straight, nearly
smooth, and very sharp. Called also <altname>rheeboc</altname>,
and <altname>rehboc</altname>.</def>

<hw>Peel"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who peels
or strips.</def>

<hw>Peel"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Peel</er> to
plunder.]</ety> <def>A pillager.</def>

<hw>Peel"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A nickname for a policeman;
-- so called from Sir Robert <xex>Peel</xex>. <mark>[British
Slang]</mark> See <er>Bobby</er>.</def>

<hw>Peel"house`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See 1st
<er>Peel</er>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Peen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>pinne</ets> pane of a hammer.]</ety> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
round-edged, or hemispherical, end to the head of a hammer or
sledge, used to stretch or bend metal by indentation.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The sharp-edged end of the head of a mason's
hammer.</def> <altsp>[Spelt also <asp>pane</asp>,
<asp>pein</asp>, and <asp>piend</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Peen</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To draw, bend, or
straighten, as metal, by blows with the peen of a hammer or
sledge.</def>

<hw>Peep</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Peeped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Peeping</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Of imitative origin; cf. OE. <ets>pipen</ets>, F.
<ets>piper</ets>, <ets>p\'82pier</ets>, L. <ets>pipire</ets>,
<ets>pipare</ets>, <ets>pipiare</ets>, D. & G. <ets>piepen</ets>.
Senses 2 and 3 perhaps come from a transfer of sense from the
sound which chickens make upon the first breaking of the shell to
the act accompanying it; or perhaps from the influence of
<ets>peek</ets>, or <ets>peak</ets>. Cf. <er>Pipe</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cry, as a chicken hatching or newly hatched;
to chirp; to cheep.</def>

<q>There was none that moved the wing, or opened the mouth, or
<qex>peeped</qex>.</q>
<qau>Is. x. 14.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To begin to appear; to look forth from
concealment; to make the first appearance.</def>

<q>When flowers first <qex>peeped</qex>, and trees did blossoms
bear.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<-- p. 1058 -->

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To look cautiously or slyly; to peer, as through
a crevice; to pry.</def>

<q><qex>eep</qex> through the blanket of the dark.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>From her cabined loophole <qex>peep</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><col>Peep sight</col>, <cd>an adjustable piece, pierced with
a small hole to peep through in aiming, attached to a rifle or
other firearm near the breech.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peep</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
cry of a young chicken; a chirp.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>First outlook or appearance.</def>

<q>Oft have we seen him at the <qex>peep</qex> of dawn.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sly look; a look as through a crevice, or from
a place of concealment.</def>

<q>To take t' other <qex>peep</qex> at the stars.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Any small
sandpiper, as the least sandpiper (<spn>Trigna
minutilla</spn>).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The European meadow
pipit (<spn>Anthus pratensis</spn>).</def>

<cs><col>Peep show</col>, <cd>a small show, or object exhibited,
which is viewed through an orifice or a magnifying glass.</cd> --
<col>Peep-o'-day boys</col>, <cd>the Irish insurgents of 1784; --
so called from their visiting the house of the loyal Irish at day
break in search of arms. <mark>[Cant]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Peep"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
chicken just breaking the shell; a young bird.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who peeps; a prying person; a spy.</def>

<q>Who's there? <qex>peepers</qex>, . . . eavesdroppers?</q>
<qau>J. Webster.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The eye; <as>as, to close the
<ex>peepers</ex></as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Peep"hole`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A hole, or
crevice, through which one may peep without being
discovered.</def>

<hw>Peep"ing hole`</hw>. <def>See <er>Peephole</er>.</def>

<hw>Pee"pul tree`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Hind.
<ets>p\'c6pal</ets>, Skr. <ets>pippala</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A sacred tree (<spn>Ficus religiosa</spn>)
of the Buddhists, a kind of fig tree which attains great size and
venerable age. See <er>Bo tree</er>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pippul tree</asp>, and <asp>pipal tree</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Peer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.p</pos> <er>Peered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Peering</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OF. <ets>parir</ets>, <ets>pareir</ets> equiv. to F.
<ets>para\'8ctre</ets> to appear, L. <ets>parere</ets>. Cf.
<er>Appear</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To come in sight; to
appear.</def> <mark>[Poetic]</mark>

<q>So honor <qex>peereth</qex> in the meanest habit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>See how his gorget <qex>peers</qex> above his gown!</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Perh. a different word; cf. OE.
<ets>piren</ets>, LG. <ets>piren</ets>. Cf. <er>Pry</er> to
peep.]</ety> <def>To look narrowly or curiously or intently; to
peep; <as>as, the <ex>peering</ex> day</as>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q><qex>Peering</qex> in maps for ports, and piers, and
roads.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>As if through a dungeon grate he <qex>peered</qex>.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>Peer</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>per</ets>, OF.
<ets>per</ets>, F. <ets>pair</ets>, fr. L. <ets>par</ets> equal.
Cf. <er>Apparel</er>, <er>Pair</er>, <er>Par</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<er>Umpire</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the same rank,
quality, endowments, character, etc.; an equal; a match; a
mate.</def>

<q>In song he never had his <qex>peer</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Shall they consort only with their <qex>peers</qex>?</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A comrade; a companion; a fellow; an
associate.</def>

<q>He all his <qex>peers</qex> in beauty did surpass.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A nobleman; a member of one of the five degrees
of the British nobility, namely, duke, marquis, earl, viscount,
baron; <as>as, a <ex>peer</ex> of the realm</as>.</def>

<q>A noble <qex>peer</qex> of mickle trust and power.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>House of Peers</col>, <col>The Peers</col></mcol>,
<cd>the British House of Lords. See <er>Parliament</er>.</cd> --
<col>Spiritual peers</col>, <cd>the bishops and archibishops, or
lords spiritual, who sit in the House of Lords.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peer</hw> <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To make equal in rank.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Heylin.</au>

<hw>Peer</hw> <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To be, or to assume to be,
equal.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Peer"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Peer</er> an equal, and cf. <er>Parage</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The rank or dignity of a peer.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The body of peers; the nobility,
collectively.</def>

<q>When Charlemain with all his <qex>peerage</qex> fell.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Peer"dom</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Peerage; also,
a lordship.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Peer"ess</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The wife of a peer; a woman
ennobled in her own right, or by right of marriage.</def>

<hw>Pee"vish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pevische</ets>; of uncertain origin, perh. from a word
imitative of the noise made by fretful children +
<ets>-ish</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Habitually fretful;
easily vexed or fretted; hard to please; apt to complain;
querulous; petulant.</def> \'bdHer <xex>peevish</xex> babe.\'b8

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<q>She is <qex>peevish</qex>, sullen, froward.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Expressing fretfulness and discontent, or
unjustifiable dissatisfaction; <as>as, a <ex>peevish</ex>
answer</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Silly; childish; trifling.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To send such <qex>peevish</qex> tokens to a king.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Querulous; petulant; cross; ill-tempered; testy;
captious; discontented. See <er>Fretful</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pee"vish*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a peevish
manner.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pee"vish*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being
peevish; disposition to murmur; sourness of temper.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Petulance</er>.</syn>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pee"vit</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pee"wit</hw>

<hw>Peg</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pegge</ets>; cf. Sw. <ets>pigg</ets>, Dan. <ets>pig</ets> a
point, prickle, and E. <ets>peak</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
small, pointed piece of wood, used in fastening boards together,
in attaching the soles of boots or shoes, etc.; <as>as, a shoe
<ex>peg</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A wooden pin, or nail, on which to hang things,
as coats, etc. Hence, colloquially and figuratively: A support; a
reason; a pretext; <as>as, a <ex>peg</ex> to hang a claim
upon</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One of the pins of a musical instrument, on
which the strings are strained.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One of the pins used for marking points on a
cribbage board.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A step; a degree; esp. in the slang phrase
\'bdTo take one down <xex>peg</xex>.\'b8</def>

<q>To screw papal authority to the highest <qex>peg</qex>.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<q>And took your grandess down a <qex>peg</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hudibras.</qau>

<cs><col>Peg ladder</col>, <cd>a ladder with but one standard,
into which cross pieces are inserted.</cd> -- <col>Peg
tankard</col>, <cd>an ancient tankard marked with pegs, so as
divide the liquor into equal portions.</cd> \'bdDrink down to
your <xex>peg<xex>.\'b8 <au>Longfellow</au>. -- <col>Peg
tooth</col>. <cd>See <cref>Fleam tooth</cref> under
<er>Fleam</er>.</cd> -- <col>Peg top</col>, <cd>a boy's top which
is spun by throwing it.</cd> -- <col>Screw peg</col>, <cd>a small
screw without a head, for fastening soles.</cd></cs>

<hw>Peg</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Pegged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pegging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To put pegs into; to fasten the parts of with pegs; <as>as,
to <ex>peg</ex> shoes</as>; to confine with pegs; to restrict or
limit closely.</def>

<q>I will rend an oak
And <qex>peg</qex> thee in his knotty entrails.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Cribbage)</fld> <def>To score with a peg, as
points in the game; <as>as, she <ex>pegged</ex> twelwe
points</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Peg</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To work diligently, as one
who pegs shoes; -- usually with <xex>on</xex>, <xex>at</xex>, or
<xex>away</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>peg</ex> away at a
task</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pe`ga*dor"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp., a
sticker.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A species of remora
(<spn>Echeneis naucrates</spn>). See <er>Remora</er>.</def>

<hw>Pe*ga"se*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Pegasus, or, figuratively, to poetry.</def>

<hw>Peg"a*soid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pegasus</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Like or pertaining to Pegasus.</def>

<hw>Peg"a*sus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gr. Myth.)</fld> <def>A winged
horse fabled to have sprung from the body of Medusa when she was
slain. He is noted for causing, with a blow of his hoof,
Hippocrene, the inspiring fountain of the Muses, to spring from
Mount Helicon. On this account he is, in modern times, associated
with the Muses, and with ideas of poetic inspiration.</def>

<q>Each spurs his jaded <qex>Pegasus</qex> apace.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A northen constellation
near the vernal equinoctial point. Its three brightest stars,
with the brightest star of Andromeda, form the <xex>square of
Pegasus</xex>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of small fishes,
having large pectoral fins, and the body covered with hard, bony
plates. Several species are known from the East Indies and
China.</def>

<hw>Peg"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who fastens
with pegs.</def>

<hw>Peg"ging</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act or
process of fastening with pegs.</def>

<ets>pegma</ets> a movable stage, Gr. <?/, orig., a
framework.]</ety> <def>A sort of moving machine employed in the
old pageants.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Peg"ma*tite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From Gr.
<?/ something fastened together, in allusion to the quartz and
feldspar in graphic granite: cf. F. <ets>pegmatite</ets>. See
<er>Pegm</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Graphic
granite. See under <er>Granite</er>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>More
generally, a coarse granite occurring as vein material in other
rocks.</def>

<hw>Peh"le*vi`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Parsee
<ets>Pahlavi</ets>.]</ety> <def>An ancient Persian dialect in
which words were partly represented by their Semitic equivalents.
It was in use from the 3d century (and perhaps earlier) to the
middle of the 7th century, and later in religious writings.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>Pahlavi</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pe*la"gi*an</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld> <def>A follower of <ets>Pelagius</ets>,

<hw>Pel`ar*gon"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>\'d8Pel`ar*go"ni*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a stork.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A
large genus of plants of the order <spn>Geraniace\'91</spn>,
differing from Geranium in having a spurred calyx and an
irregular corolla.</def>

<note><hand/ About one hundred and seventy species are known,
nearly all of them natives of South Africa, and many having very
beautiful blossoms. See the Note under <er>Geranium</er>.</note>

<hw>Pelf</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

<hw>Pel"i*can</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82lican</ets>, L. <ets>pelicanus</ets>,
<ets>pelecanus</ets>, Gr. <?/, <?/, <?/, the woodpecker, and also
a water bird of the pelican kind, fr. <?/ to hew with an ax, akin
to Skr. <ets>para<cced/u</ets>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pelecan</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any large webfooted bird of the genus of
<spn>Pelecanus</spn>, of which about a dozen species are known.
They have an enormous bill, to the lower edge of which is
attached a pouch in which captured fishes are temporarily
stored.</def>

<note><hand/ The American white pelican (<spn>Pelecanus
erythrorhynchos</spn>) and the brown species (<spn>P.
fuscus</spn>) are abundant on the Florida coast in winter, but
breed about the lakes in the Rocky Mountains and British
America.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <def>A retort or still having
a curved tube or tubes leading back from the head to the body for
continuous condensation and redistillation.</def>

<note><hand/ The principle is still employed in certain modern
forms of distilling apparatus.</note>

<cs><col>Frigate pelican</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
frigate bird. See under <er>Frigate</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pelican
fish</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>deep-sea fish
(<spn>Eurypharynx pelecanoides</spn>) of the order
<spn>Lyomeri</spn>, remarkable for the enormous development of
the jaws, which support a large gular pouch.</cd> -- <col>Pelican
flower</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the very large and curiously
shaped blossom of a climbing plant (<spn>Aristolochia
grandiflora</spn>) of the West Indies; also, the plant
itself.</cd> -- <col>Pelican ibis</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a large Asiatic wood ibis (<spn>Tantalus
leucocephalus</spn>). The head and throat are destitute of
feathers; the plumage is white, with the quills and the tail
greenish black.</cd> -- <col>Pelican in her piety</col> (in
heraldry and symbolical art), <cd>a representation of a pelican
in the act of wounding her breast in order to nourish her young
with her blood; -- a practice fabulously attributed to the bird,
on account of which it was adopted as a symbol of the Redeemer,
and of charity.</cd> -- <col>Pelican's foot</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a marine gastropod shell of the genus
<spn>Aporrhais</spn>, esp. <spn>Aporrhais pes-pelicani</spn> of
Europe.</cd></cs>
