<hw>Pel"li*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>paritorie</ets>, OF. <ets>paritoire</ets>, F.
<ets>pari\'82taire</ets>; (cf. It. & Sp. <ets>parietaria</ets>),
L. <ets>parietaria</ets> the parietary, or pellitory, the wall
plant, fr. <ets>parietarus</ets> belonging to the walls, fr.
<ets>paries</ets>, <ets>parietis</ets> a wall. Cf.
<er>Parietary</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The common name
of the several species of the genus <spn>Parietaria</spn>, low,
harmless weeds of the Nettle family; -- also called <altname>wall
pellitory</altname>, and <altname>lichwort</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Parietaria officinalis</xex> is common on old
walls in Europe; <xex>P</xex>.<xex>Pennsylvanica</xex> is found
in the United States; and six or seven more species are found
near the Mediterranean, or in the Orient.</note>

<hw>Pel"li*to*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.
<ets>pelitre</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pyrethrum</ets>. See
<er>Bertram</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
composite plant (<spn>Anacyclus Pyrethrum</spn>) of the
Mediterranean region, having finely divided leaves and whitish
flowers. The root is the officinal pellitory, and is used as an
irritant and sialogogue. Called also <altname>bertram</altname>,
and <altname>pellitory of Spain</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The feverfew (<spn>Chrysanthemum Parthenium</spn>); -- so
called because it resembles the above.</def>

<hw>Pel`o*pon*ne"sian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Peloponnesius</ets>, fr. <ets>Peloponnesus</ets>, Gr. <?/,
lit., the Island of Pelops; <?/, <?/, Pelops + <?/ an
island.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to the Peloponnesus, or
southern peninsula of Greece.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A
native or an inhabitant of the Peloponnesus.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8Pe*lo"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,

<hw>Pelt</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>pelz</ets> a pelt, fur, fr. OF. <ets>pelice</ets>, F.
<ets>pelisse</ets> (see <er>Pelisse</er>); or perh. shortened fr.
<ets>peltry</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The skin of a beast
with the hair on; a raw or undressed hide; a skin preserved with
the hairy or woolly covering on it. See 4th <er>Fell</er>.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<q>Raw <qex>pelts</qex> clapped about them for their clothes.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The human skin.</def> <mark>[Jocose]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Falconry)</fld> <def>The body of any quarry
killed by the hawk.</def>

<cs><col>Pelt rot</col>, <cd>a disease affecting the hair or wool
of a beast.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pelt</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pelted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pelting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>pelten</ets>,
<ets>pulten</ets>, <ets>pilten</ets>, to thrust, throw, strike;
cf. L. <ets>pultare</ets>, equiv. to <ets>pulsare</ets> (v. freq.
fr. <ets>pellere</ets> to drive), and E. <ets>pulse</ets> a
beating.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To strike with something thrown
or driven; to assail with pellets or missiles, <as>as, to
<ex>pelt</ex> with stones; <ex>pelted</ex> with hail.</as></def>

<q>The children billows seem to <qex>pelt</qex> the clouds.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To throw; to use as a missile.</def>

<q>My Phillis me with <qex>pelted</qex> apples plies.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pelt</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw
missiles.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To throw out words.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Another smothered seems to <qex>pelt</qex>and swear.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pelt</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A blow or stroke from something

<cs><mcol><col>Pelvic arch</col>, <or/ <col>Pelvic
girdle</col></mcol> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the two or more bony
or cartilaginous pieces of the vertebrate skeleton to which the
hind limbs are articulated.  When fully ossified, the arch
usually consists of three principal bones on each side, the
ilium, ischium, and pubis, which are often closely united in the
adult, forming the innominate bone. See <cref>Innominate
bone</cref>, under <er>Innominate</er>.</cd></cs>

<ets>pelvim\'8atre</ets>.]</ety> <def>An instrument for measuring

<au>Coxe.</au>

<hw>Pel"vis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a basin,

together with the sacrum. See <cref>Pelvic arch</cref>, under
<er>Pelvic</er>, and <er>Sacrum</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The calyx of a
crinoid.</def>

<cs><col>Pelvis of the kidney</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the
basinlike cavity into which the ureter expands as it joins the

<hw>Pem"mi*can</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written
also <ets>pemican</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Among the North
American Indians, meat cut in thin slices, divested of fat, and
dried in the sun.</def>

<q>Then on <qex>pemican</qex> they feasted.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Meat, without the fat, cut in thin slices, dried
in the sun, pounded, then mixed with melted fat and sometimes
dried fruit, and compressed into cakes or in bags. It contains
much nutriment in small compass, and is of great use in long
voyages of exploration.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pem*phi"gus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Nl.,
fr. Gr. <?/, <?/, a bubble.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
somewhat rare skin disease, characterized by the development of
blebs upon different part of the body.</def>

<au>Quain.</au>

<hw>Pen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>penne</ets>, OF. <ets>penne</ets>, <ets>pene</ets>, F.
<ets>penne</ets>, fr. L. <ets>penna</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A feather.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A wing.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An instrument used for writing with ink,
formerly made of a reed, or of the quill of a goose or other
bird, but now also of other materials, as of steel, gold, etc.
Also, originally, a stylus or other instrument for scratching or
graving.</def>

<q>Graven with an iron <qex>pen</qex> and lead in the rock.</q>
<qau>Job xix. 24.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Fig.: A writer, or his style; <as>as, he has a
sharp <ex>pen</ex></as>.</def> \'bdThose learned
<xex>pens</xex>.\'b8

<au>Fuller.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The internal shell of a
squid.</def>

<def>A female swan.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark><-- contrast
cob, the male swan -->

-- <mcol><col>Drawing</col>, <or/ <col>Ruling</col>,

<hw>Pen</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>Pen</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Penned</er> <pr>(?)</pr> or <er>Pent</er> (<?/);
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Penning</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>pennen</ets>, AS. <ets>pennan</ets> in
<ets>on-pennan</ets> to unfasten, prob. from the same source as
<ets>pin</ets>, and orig. meaning, to fasten with a peg.See
<er>Pin</er>, <pos>n. & v.</pos>]</ety> <def>To shut up, as in a
pen or cage; to confine in a small inclosure or narrow space; to
coop up, or shut in; to inclose.</def> \'bdAway with her, and
<xex>pen</xex> her up.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Watching where shepherds <qex>pen</qex> their flocks at
eve.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pen</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From <er>Pen</er> to shut
in.]</ety> <def>A small inclosure; <as>as, a <ex>pen</ex> for
sheep or for pigs</as>.</def>

<q>My father stole two geese out of a <qex>pen</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pe"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>poenalis</ets>, fr. <ets>poena</ets> punishment: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82nal</ets>. See <er>Pain</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or
pertaining to punishment, to penalties, or to crimes and
offenses; pertaining to criminal jurisprudence</def>: as:
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>Enacting or threatening punishment; <as>as, a
<ex>penal</ex> statue; the <ex>penal</ex> code</as></def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Incurring punishment; subject to a penalty;
<as>as, a <ex>penal</ex>act of offense</as></def>. <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>Inflicted as punishment; used as a means of punishment;
<as>as, a <ex>penal</ex> colony or settlement</as>.</def>
\'bdAdamantine chains and <xex>penal</xex> fire.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<cs><col>Penal code</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a code of laws
concerning crimes and offenses and their punishment.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Penal laws</col>, <col>Penal statutes</col></mcol>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>laws prohibited certain acts, and imposing
penalties for committing them.</cd> -- <col>Penal
servitude</col>, <cd>imprisonment with hard labor, in a prison,
in lieu of transportation.</cd> <mark>[Great Brit.]</mark> --
<col>Penal suit</col>, <col>Penal action</col></mcol>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a suit for penalties.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pe*nal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. LL.
<ets>poenalitas</ets>. See <er>Penalty</er>.]</ety> <def>The
quality or state of being penal; lability to punishment.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pe"nal*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Sport.)</fld> <def>To put a penalty on. See

<hw>Pe"nal*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a penal

<hw>Pe"nal*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Penalties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82nalit\'82</ets>. See <er>Penal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Penal retribution; punishment for crime or offense; the
suffering in person or property which is annexed by law or
judicial decision to the commission of a crime, offense, or
trespass.</def>

<q>Death is the <qex>penalty</qex> imposed.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The suffering, or the sum to be forfeited, to
which a person subjects himself by covenant or agreement, in case
of nonfulfillment of stipulations; forfeiture; fine.</def>

<q>The <qex>penalty</qex> and forfeit of my bond.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A handicap.</def> <mark>[Sporting Cant]</mark>

<note><hand/ The term <xex>penalty</xex> is in law mostly applied
to a pecuniary punishment.</note>

transgression.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>penance</ets>, <ets>peneance</ets>, L.
<ets>paenitentia</ets> repentance. See <er>Penitence</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Repentance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif (Luke xv. 7).</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pain; sorrow; suffering.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdJoy or <xex>penance</xex> he feeleth
none.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>A means of repairing a sin
committed, and obtaining pardon for it, consisting partly in the
performance of expiatory rites, partly in voluntary submission to
a punishment corresponding to the transgression. Penance is the
fourth of seven sacraments in the Roman Catholic Church.</def>

<au>Schaff-Herzog Encyc.</au>

<q>And bitter <qex>penance</qex>, with an iron whip.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Quoth he, \'bdThe man hath <qex>penance</qex> done,
And <qex>penance</qex> more will do.\'b8</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Pen`chant"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.

<hw>Pen"cil</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pincel</ets>, F. <ets>pinceau</ets>, L.
<ets>penicillum</ets>, <ets>penicillus</ets>, equiv. to
<ets>peniculus</ets>, dim. of <ets>penis</ets> a tail. Cf.
<er>Penicil</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A small, fine brush of
hair or bristles used by painters for laying on colors.</def>

<q>With subtile <qex>pencil</qex> depainted was this storie.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A slender cylinder or strip of black lead,
colored chalk, slate etc., or such a cylinder or strip inserted
in a small wooden rod intended to be pointed, or in a case, which
forms a handle, -- used for drawing or writing. See
<er>Graphite</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence, figuratively, an artist's ability or
peculiar manner; also, in general, the act or occupation of the
artist, descriptive writer, etc.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Opt.)</fld> <def>An aggregate or collection of
rays of light, especially when diverging from, or converging to,
a point.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A number of lines that
intersect in one point, the point of intersection being called
the <xex>pencil point</xex>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A small medicated
bougie.</def>

<cs><col>Pencil case</col>, <cd>a holder for pencil lead.</cd> --
<col>Pencil flower</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an American
perennial leguminous herb (<spn>Stylosanthes elatior</spn>).</cd>
-- <col>Pencil lead</col>, <cd>a slender rod of black lead, or
the like, adapted for insertion in a holder.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"cil</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>Pen"ciled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Written also
<ets>pencilled</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Painted, drawn,
sketched, or marked with a pencil.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Radiated; having pencils of rays.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Nat. Hist.)</fld> <def>Marked with parallel or

<hw>Pen"cil*ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written
also <ets>pencilling</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The work of

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Brickwork)</fld> <def>Lines of white or black

<hw>Pen"craft</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Penmanship; skill in writing; chirography.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The art of composing or writing;
authorship.</def>

<q>I would not give a groat for that person's knowledge in
<qex>pencraft</qex>.</q>
<qau>S<?/e<?/ne.</qau>

<hw>Pend</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Oil cake;
penock.</def> <mark>[India]</mark>

<hw>Pend</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pended</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pending</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>pendere</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To hang; to
depend.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q><qex>Pending</qex> upon certain powerful motions.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be undecided, or in process of
adjustment.</def>

<hw>Pend</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. <ets>pen</ets> to shut
in, or AS. <ets>pyndan</ets>, E. <ets>pound</ets> an
inclosure.]</ety> <def>To pen; to confine.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q><qex>ended</qex> within the limits . . . of Greece.</q>
<qau>Udall.</qau>

<hw>Pend"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., orig.
p.pr. of <ets>pendre</ets> to hang, L. <ets>pendere</ets>. Cf.
<er>Pendent</er>, <er>Pansy</er>, <er>Pensive</er>,
<er>Poise</er>, <er>Ponder</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Something which hangs or depends; something suspended; a
hanging appendage, especially one of an ornamental character; as
to a chandelier or an eardrop; also, an appendix or addition, as
to a book.</def>

<q>Some hang upon the <qex>pendants</qex> of her ear.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Many . . . have been pleased with this work and its
<qex>pendant</qex>, the Tales and Popular Fictions.</q>
<qau>Keightley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A hanging ornament on roofs,
ceilings, etc., much used in the later styles of Gothic
architecture, where it is of stone, and an important part of the
construction. There are imitations in plaster and wood, which are
mere decorative features.</def> \'bd[A bridge] with . . .
<xex>pendants</xex> graven fair.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>One of a pair; a
counterpart; <as>as, one vase is the <ex>pendant</ex> to the
other vase</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A pendulum.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir K. Digby.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The stem and ring of a watch, by which it is
suspended.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<au>Knight.</au>

<cs><col>Pendant post</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>a part of the
framing of an open timber roof; a post set close against the
wall, and resting upon a corbel or other solid support, and
supporting the ends of a collar beam or any part of the
roof.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen*den"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>\'d8Pen"du`line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. See

<hw>Pen"du*lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pendulus</ets>, fr. <ets>pendere</ets> to hang. Cf.
<er>Pendant</er>, and cf. <er>Pendulum</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Depending; pendent loosely; hanging; swinging.</def>
<au>Shak.</au> \'bdThe <xex>pendulous</xex> round earth.
<au>Milton</au>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wavering; unstable; doubtful.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdA <xex>pendulous</xex> state of mind.\'b8

<au>Atterbury.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Inclined or hanging downwards,
as a flower on a recurved stalk, or an ovule which hangs from the
upper part of the ovary.</def>

<hw>Pen"du*lous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pendulous
manner.</def>

<hw>Pen"du*lous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being pendulous; the state of hanging loosely;
pendulosity.</def>

<hw>Pen"du*lum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pendulums</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. L.
<ets>pendulus</ets> hanging, swinging. See
<er>Pendulous</er>.]</ety> <def>A body so suspended from a fixed
point as to swing freely to and fro by the alternate action of
gravity and momentum. It is used to regulate the movements of
clockwork and other machinery.</def>

<note><hand/ The time of oscillation of a pendulum is independent
of the arc of vibration, provided this arc be small.</note>

<cs><col>Ballistic pendulum</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Ballistic</er>.</cd> -- <col>Compensation pendulum</col>,
<cd>a clock pendulum in which the effect of changes of
temperature of the length of the rod is so counteracted, usually
by the opposite expansion of differene metals, that the distance
of the center of oscillation from the center of suspension
remains invariable; as, the <xex>mercurial compensation
pendulum<xex>, in which the expansion of the rod is compensated
by the opposite expansion of mercury in a jar constituting the
bob; the <xex>gridiron pendulum<xex>, in which compensation is
effected by the opposite expansion of sets of rodsof different
metals.</cd> -- <col>Compound pendulum</col>, <cd>an ordinary
pendulum; -- so called, as being made up of different parts, and
contrasted with <xex>simple pendulum<xex>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Conical</col> <or/ <col>Revolving</col>,
<col>pendulum</col></mcol>, <cd>a weight connected by a rod with
a fixed point; and revolving in a horizontal cyrcle about the
vertical from that point.</cd> -- <col>Pendulum bob</col>,
<cd>the weight at the lower end of a pendulum.</cd> --
<col>Pendulum level</col>, <cd>a plumb level. See under
<er>Level</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pendulum wheel</col>, <cd>the
balance of a watch.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Simple</col> <or/
<col>Theoretical</col>, <col>pendulum</col></mcol>, <cd>an
imaginary pendulum having no dimensions except length, and no
weight except at the center of oscillation; in other words, a
material point suspended by an ideal line.</cd></cs>

Odyssey, Gr. <?/.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of
curassows, including the guans.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pen`e*tra"li*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[L., fr. <ets>penetralis</ets> penetrating, internal. See
<er>Penetrate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The recesses, or
innermost parts, of any thing or place, especially of a temple or
palace.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hidden things or secrets; privacy; sanctuary;
<as>as, the sacred <ex>penetralia</ex> of the home</as>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pen"e*trance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pen"e*tran*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being penetrant; power of entering or piercing; penetrating power
of quality; <as>as, the <ex>penetrancy</ex> of subtile
effluvia</as>.</def>

<hw>Pen"e*trant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>penetrans</ets>, p.pr. of <ets>penetrare</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82n\'82trant</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having power to enter or
pierce; penetrating; sharp; subtile; <as>as, <ex>penetrant</ex>
cold</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Penetrant</xex> and powerful
arguments.\'b8

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Pen"e*trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Penetrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Penetrating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>penetratus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>penetrare</ets> to penetrate;
akin to <ets>penitus</ets> inward, inwardly, and perh. to
<ets>pens</ets> with, in the power of, <ets>penus</ets> store of
food, innermost part of a temple.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
enter into; to make way into the interior of; to effect an
entrance into; to pierce; <as>as, light <ex>penetrates</ex>
darkness</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To affect profoundly through the senses or
feelings; to touch with feeling; to make sensible; to move
deeply; <as>as, to <ex>penetrate</ex> one's heart with
pity</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The translator of Homer should <qex>penetrate</qex> himself
with a sense of the plainness and directness of Homer's
style.</q>
<qau>M. Arnold.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To pierce into by the mind; to arrive at the
inner contents or meaning of, as of a mysterious or difficult
subject; to comprehend; to understand.</def>

<q>Things which here were too subtile for us to
<qex>penetrate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ray.</qau>

<hw>Pen"e*trate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To pass; to make way;
to pierce. Also used figuratively.</def>

<q>Preparing to <qex>penetrate</qex> to the north and west.</q>
<qau>J. R. Green.</qau>

<q>Born where Heaven's influence scarce can
<qex>penetrate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>The sweet of life that <qex>penetrates</qex> so near.</q>
<qau>Daniel.</qau>

<hw>Pen"e*tra`ting</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having the power of entering, piercing, or pervading; sharp;
subtile; penetrative; <as>as, a <ex>penetrating</ex>
odor</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Acute; discerning; sagacious; quick to discover;
<as>as, a <ex>penetrating</ex> mind</as>.</def>

<hw>Pen"e*tra`ting*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a penetrating
manner.</def>

<hw>Pen"e*tra`tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>penetratio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82n\'82tration</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or
process of penetrating, piercing, or entering; also, the act of
mentally penetrating into, or comprehending, anything
difficult.</def>

<q>And to each in ward part,
With gentle <qex>penetration</qex>, though unseen,
Shoots invisible virtue even to the deep.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>A <qex>penetration</qex> into the difficulties of algebra.</q>
<qau>Watts.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Acuteness; insight; sharp discoverment;
sagacity; <as>as, a person of singular
<ex>penetration</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Walpole.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Discernment; sagacity; acuteness; sharpness;
discrimination. See <er>Discernment</er>, and
<er>Sagacity</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pen"e*tra*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82n\'82tratif</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Tending to
penetrate; of a penetrating quality; piercing; <as>as, the

<q>His look became keen and <qex>penetrative</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Acute; discerning; sagacious; <as>as,

<xex>penetrative</xex> eye.\'b8

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<hw>Pen"guin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. orig.
the name of another bird, and fr. W. <ets>pen</ets> head +
<ets>gwyn</ets> white; or perh. from a native South American
name.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any bird of
the order Impennes, or Ptilopteri. They are covered with short,
thick feathers, almost scalelike on the wings, which are without
true quills. They are unable to fly, but use their wings to aid
in diving, in which they are very expert. See <cref>King
penguin</cref>, under <er>Jackass</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ Penguins are found in the south temperate and
antarctic regions. The king penguins (<spn>Aptenodytes
Patachonica</spn>, and <spn>A. longirostris</spn>) are the
largest; the jackass penguins (<spn>Spheniscus</spn>) and the
rock hoppers (<spn>Catarractes</spn>) congregate in large numbers
at their breeding grounds.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The egg-shaped fleshy fruit of
a West Indian plant (<spn>Bromelia Pinguin</spn>) of the
Pineapple family; also, the plant itself, which has rigid,
pointed, and spiny-toothed leaves, and is used for hedges.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>pinguin</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Arctic penguin</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
great auk. See <er>Auk</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"guin*er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A breeding place, or rookery, of
penguins.</def>

<hw>Pen"i*tence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82nitence</ets>, L. <ets>paenitentia</ets>. See
<er>Penitent</er>, and cf. <er>Penance</er>.]</ety> <def>The
quality or condition of being penitent; the disposition of a

<au>Chaucer.</au>

To mitigate, if not reverse, the doom.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pen"i*tent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82nitent</ets>, L. <ets>paenitens</ets>,
<ets>-entis</ets>, <ets>poenitens</ets>, p.pr. of
<ets>paenitere</ets>, <ets>poenitere</ets>, to cause to repent,
to repent; prob. akin to <ets>poena</ets> punishment. See
<er>Pain</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Feeling pain or sorrow on
account of sins or offenses; repentant; contrite; sincerely
affected by a sense of guilt, and resolved on amendment of
life.</def>

<q>Be <qex>penitent</qex>, and for thy fault contrite.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The pound he tamed, the <qex>penitent</qex> he cheered.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Doing penance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pen"i*tent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who
repents of sin; one sorrowful on account of his
transgressions.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One under church censure, but admitted to
penance; one undergoing penance.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One under the direction of a confessor.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Penitents</xex> is an appellation given to
certain fraternities in Roman Catholic countries, distinguished
by their habit, and employed in charitable acts.</note>

<hw>Pen`i*ten"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82nitentiel</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to
penitence, or to penance; expressing penitence; of the nature of
penance; <as>as, the <ex>penitential</ex> book;
<ex>penitential</ex> tears.</as></def> \'bd<xex>Penitential</xex>
stripes.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>Guilt that all the <qex>penitential</qex> fires of hereafter
can not cleanse.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<hw>Pen`i*ten"tial</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld>
<def>A book formerly used by priests hearing confessions,
containing rules for the imposition of penances; -- called also
<altname>penitential book</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pen`i*ten"tial*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a penitential
manner.</def>

<hw>Pen`i*ten"tia*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>p\'82nitentiaire</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Relating
to penance, or to the rules and measures of penance.</def> \'bdA
<xex>penitentiary</xex> tax.\'b8

<au>Abp. Bramhall.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Expressive of penitence; <as>as, a
<ex>penitentiary</ex> letter</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Used for punishment, discipline, and
reformation.</def> \'bd<xex>Penitentiary</xex> houses.\'b8

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pen`i*ten"tia*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Penitentiaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82nitencier</ets>. See <er>Penitent</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who prescribes the rules and measures of

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who does penance.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A small building in a monastery where penitents
confessed.</def>

<au>Shpiley.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That part of a church to which penitents were
admitted.</def>

<au>Shipley.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An office of
the papal court which examines cases of conscience, confession,
absolution from vows, etc., and delivers decisions,
dispensations, etc.  Its chief is a cardinal, called the
<xex>Grand Penitentiary</xex>, appointed by the pope.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>An officer in some dioceses since <sc>A.
D.</sc> 1215, vested with power from the bishop to absolve in
cases reserved to him.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A house of correction, in which offenders are
confined for punishment, discipline, and reformation, and in
which they are generally compelled to labor.</def>

<hw>Pen`i*ten"tia*ry*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The office or
condition of a penitentiary of the papal court.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Wood.</au>

<hw>Pen"nant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

pennant</stype> (called also <xex>whip</xex> or <xex>coach
whip</xex>) is a long, narrow piece of bunting, carried at the
masthead of a government vessel in commission. The <stype>board
pennant</stype> is an oblong, nearly square flag, carried at the
masthead of a commodore's vessel</def>. \'bdWith flags and
<xex>pennants</xex> trimmed.\'b8 <au>Drayton</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>A rope or strap to which a purchase is hooked.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pen*nat"u*la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

species of <spn>Pennatula</spn>, <spn>Pteroides</spn>, and allied
genera of Alcyonaria, having a featherlike form; a sea-pen. The
zooids are situated along one edge of the side branches.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pen*nat`u*la"ce*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Pennatula</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A division of alcyonoid corals, including the seapens and
related kinds. They are able to move about by means of the hollow
muscular peduncle, which also serves to support them upright in
the mud. See <er>Pennatula</er>, and <xex>Illust</xex>. under
<er>Alcyonaria</er>.</def>

<hw>Pen"ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Perh. a
corruption of <ets>pun</ets>, for <ets>pound</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Denoting pound weight for one thousand; -- used in

nails, nails of which one thousand weight ten pounds</as>.</def>

<hw>Pen*ny</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Pennies</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr> or <plw>Pence</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.
<xex>Pennies</xex> denotes the number of coins; <xex>pence</xex>
the amount of pennies in value</plu>. <ety>[OE. <ets>peni</ets>,
AS. <ets>penig</ets>, <ets>pening</ets>, <ets>pending</ets>; akin
to D. <ets>penning</ets>, OHG. <ets>pfenning</ets>,
<ets>pfenting</ets>, G. <ets>pfennig</ets>, Icel.
<ets>penningr</ets>; of uncertain origin.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>An English coin, formerly of copper, now of bronze, the
twelfth part of an English shilling in account value, and equal
to four farthings, or about two cents; -- usually indicated by
the abbreviation <xex>d</xex>. (the initial of
<xex>denarius</xex>).</def>

<note><hand/ \'bdThe chief Anglo-Saxon coin, and for a long
period the only one, corresponded to the <xex>denarius</xex> of
the Continent . . . [and was] called <xex>penny</xex>, denarius,
or denier.\'b8 <au>R. S. Poole</au>.  The ancient silver
<xex>penny</xex> was worth about three pence sterling (see
<er>Pennyweight</er>). The old Scotch <xex>penny</xex> was only
one twelfth the value of the English coin. In the United States
the word <xex>penny</xex> is popularly used for
<xex>cent</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any small sum or coin; a groat; a stiver.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Money, in general; <as>as, to turn an honest
<ex>penny</ex></as>.</def>

<q>What <qex>penny</qex> hath Rome borne,
What men provided, what munition sent?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Script.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Denarius</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Penny cress</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an annual herb
of the Mustard family, having round, flat pods like silver
pennies (<spn>Thlaspi arvense</spn>). <au>Dr. Prior</au>.</cd> --
<col>Penny dog</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of shark
found on the South coast of Britain: the tope.</cd> -- <col>Penny
father</col>, <cd>a penurious person; a niggard.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Robinson (More's Utopia)</au>.</cd> --
<col>Penny grass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>pennyroyal.</cd>
<mark>[R.]</mark> -- <col>Penny post</col></mcol>, <cd>a post
carrying a letter for a penny; also, a mail carrier.</cd> --
<col>Penny wise</col>, <cd>wise or prudent only in small matters;
saving small sums while losing larger; -- used chiefly in the
phrase, <xex>penny wise<xex> and pound foolish.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Worth or costing
one penny.</def>

<hw>Pen`ny*roy"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[A
corruption of OE. <ets>puliall royal</ets>. OE.
<ets>puliall</ets> is ultimately derived fr. L.
<ets>puleium</ets>, or <ets>pulegium</ets> regium (so called as
being good against fleas), fr. <ets>pulex</ets> a flea; and
<ets>royal</ets> is a translation of L. <ets>regium</ets>, in
<ets>puleium regium</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An
aromatic herb (<spn>Mentha Pulegium</spn>) of Europe; also, a
North American plant (<spn>Hedeoma pulegioides</spn>) resembling
it in flavor.</def>

<cs><col>Bastard pennyroyal</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Blue curls</cref>, under <er>Blue</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"ny*weight`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A troy
weight containing twenty-four grains, or the twentieth part of an
ounce; <as>as, a <ex>pennyweight</ex> of gold or of arsenic</as>.
It was anciently the weight of a silver penny, whence the
name.</def>

<hw>Pen"ny*wort`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A European trailing herb (<spn>Linaria
Cymbalaria</spn>) with roundish, reniform leaves. It is often
cultivated in hanging baskets.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>March</col>, <or/ <col>Water</col>,
<col>pennywort</col></mcol>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>March</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>pensio</ets> a paying, payment, fr. <ets>pendere</ets>,
<ets>pensum</ets>, to weight, to pay; akin to
<ets>pend<?/re</ets> to hang. See <er>Pendant</er>, and cf.
<er>Spend</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A payment; a tribute;
something paid or given.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The stomach's <qex>pension</qex>, and the time's expense.</q>
<qau>Sylvester.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A stated allowance to a person in consideration
of past services; payment made to one retired from service, on
account of age, disability, or other cause; especially, a regular
stipend paid by a government to retired public officers, disabled
soldiers, the families of soldiers killed in service, or to
meritorious authors, or the like.</def>

<q>To all that kept the city <qex>pensions</qex> and wages.</q>
<qau>1 Esd. iv. 56.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A certain sum of money paid to a clergyman in
lieu of tithes.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <ety>[F., pronounced <pr><?/</pr>.]</ety> <def>A
boarding house or boarding school in France, Belgium,
Switzerland, etc.</def>

<hw>Pen"sion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pensioned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pensioning</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To grant a
pension to; to pay a regular stipend to; in consideration of
service already performed; -- sometimes followed by
<xex>off</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>pension</ex> off a
servant</as>.</def>

<q>One knighted Blackmore, and one <qex>pensioned</qex>
Quarles.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Pen"sion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<hw>Pen"sion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pensionaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pensionnaire</ets>. Cf. <er>Pensioner</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who receives a pension; a pensioner.</def>

<au>E. Hall.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of the chief magistrates of towns in

<cs><col>Grand pensionary</col>, <cd>the title of the prime
minister, or or president of the Council, of Holland when a
republic.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pen"sion*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One in receipt of a pension; hence, figuratively, a
dependent.</def>

<q>The fickle <qex>pensioners</qex> of Morpheus' train.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Old <qex>pensioners</qex> . . . of Chelsea Hospital.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of an honorable band of gentlemen who attend
the sovereign of England on state occasions, and receive an
annual pension, or allowance, of \'9c150 and two horses.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pensionnaire</ets> one who pays for
his board. Cf. <er>Pensionary</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>In
the university of Cambridge, England, one who pays for his living
in commons; -- corresponding to <xex>commoner</xex> at
Oxford.</def>

<au>Ld. Lytton.</au>

<hw>Pen"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pensif</ets>, fr. <ets>penser</ets> to think, fr. L.
<ets>pensare</ets> to weigh, ponder, consider, v. intens. fr.
<ets>pendere</ets> to weigh. See <er>Pension</er>,
<er>Poise</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Thoughtful, sober, or
sad; employed in serious reflection; given to, or favorable to,
earnest or melancholy musing.</def>

<q>The <qex>pensive</qex> secrecy of desert cell.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Anxious cares the <qex>pensive</qex> nymph oppressed.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Expressing or suggesting thoughtfulness with
sadness; <as>as, <ex>pensive</ex> numbers</as>.</def>

<au>Prior.</au>

<hw>Pen"sived</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Made
pensive.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pen"sive*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
pensive manner.</def>

<hw>Pen"sive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of being
pensive; serious thoughtfulness; seriousness.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>Pen"stock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Etymol.
uncertain; perh. fr. <ets>pen</ets> an inclosure +
<ets>stock</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A close conduit or pipe
for conducting water, as, to a water wheel, or for emptying a
pond, or for domestic uses.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The barrel of a wooden pump.</def>

<hw>Pent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p. <or/ a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Pen</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <def>Penned or shut up;
confined; -- often with <xex>up</xex>.</def>

<q>Here in the body <qex>pent</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. Montgomery.</qau>

<q>No <qex>pent-up</qex> Utica contracts your powers.</q>
<qau>J. M. Sewall.</qau>

<hw>Pen"ta-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Gr. <?/, a later combining

combining form denoting <xex>five</xex>; <as>as,
<ex>penta</ex>capsular; <ex>penta</ex>gon.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Denoting the degree of
<xex>five</xex>, either as regards quality, property, or
composition; <as>as, <ex>penta</ex>sulphide; <ex>pent</ex>oxide,
etc.</as>  Also used adjectively.</def>

<hw>Pen"ta*cle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<hw>\'d8Pen*tam"e*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<hw>Pen*tam"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
Gr. <?/; <?/ (see <er>Penta-</er>) + <?/ measure.]</ety>
<fld>(Gr. & L.Pros.)</fld> <def>A verse of five feet.</def>

<note><hand/ The dactylic pentameter consists of two parts
separated by a di\'91resis. Each part consists of two dactyls and
a long syllable. The spondee may take the place of the dactyl in
the first part, but not in the second. The <xex>elegiac
distich</xex> consists of the hexameter followed by the
pentameter.</note>

<au>Harkness.</au>

<hw>Pen*tam"e*ter</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having five metrical
feet.</def>

regarded as composed of five methylene residues. Cf.
<er>Trimethylene</er>, and <er>Tetramethylene</er>.</def>

<hw>Pen"te*cost</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pentecoste</ets>, Gr. <?/ (sc. <?/) the fiftieth day,
Pentecost, fr. <?/ fiftieth, fr. <?/ fifty, fr. <?/ five. See
<er>Five</er>, and cf. <er>Pingster</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A solemn festival of the Jews; -- so called because
celebrated on the fiftieth day (seven weeks) after the second day
of the Passover (which fell on the sixteenth of the Jewish month
Nisan); -- hence called, also, the <altname>Feast of
Weeks</altname>. At this festival an offering of the first fruits
of the harvest was made. By the Jews it was generally regarded as
commemorative of the gift of the law on the fiftieth day after
the departure from Egypt.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A festival of the Roman Catholic and other
churches in commemoration of the descent of the Holy Spirit on
the apostles; which occurred on the day of Pentecost; -- called
also <altname>Whitsunday</altname>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pen`te*cos"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to Pentecost or to Whitsuntide.</def>

<hw>Pen`te*cos"tals</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<def>Offerings formerly made to the parish priest, or to the
mother church, at Pentecost.</def>

<au>Shipley.</au>

<hw>Pen`te*cos"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ fifty.]</ety> <fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld>
<def>An officer in the Spartan army commanding fifty men.</def>

<au>Mitford.</au>

<hw>Pen`te*cos"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pentecosties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Gr. <?/, fr.
<?/ the fiftieth, <?/ fifty.]</ety> <fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld>
<def>A troop of fifty soldiers in the Spartan army; -- called
also <altname>pentecostys</altname>.</def>

<au>Jowett (Thucyd. ).</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pen*tel"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pen*tel"i*can</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to
Mount Pentelicus, near Athens, famous for its fine white marble
quarries; obtained from Mount Pentelicus; <as>as, the
<ex>Pentelic</ex> marble of which the Parthenon is
built</as>.</def>

a lean-to. Also figuratively.</def> \'bdThe <xex>penthouse</xex>
of his eyes.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<-- 2. An apartment at the top of a building.  It is often the
most luxuriously appointed apartment, and is thus used as a
metaphor for luxurious living. -->

<hw>Pe*num"bra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr. L.
<ets>paene</ets> almost + <ets>umbra</ets> shade.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An incomplete or partial shadow.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>The shadow cast, in an
eclipse, where the light is partly, but not wholly, cut off by
the intervening body; the space of partial illumination between
the umbra, or perfect shadow, on all sides, and the full
light.</def>

<au>Sir I. Newton.</au>

<note><hand/ The faint shade surrounding the dark central portion
of a solar spot is also called the <altname>penumbra</altname>,
and sometimes <altname>umbra</altname>.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Paint.)</fld> <def>The part of a picture where
the shade imperceptibly blends with the light.</def>

<hw>Pe*num"brala</hw>. <def>Of or pertaining to a penumbra;
resembling a penumbra; partially illuminated.</def>

<hw>Pe*nu"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Penury</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Excessively sparing in
the use of money; sordid; stingy; miserly.</def> \'bdA
<xex>penurious</xex> niggard of his wealth.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Not bountiful or liberal; scanty.</def>

<q>Here creeps along a poor, <qex>penurious</qex> stream.</q>
<qau>C. Pitt.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Destitute of money; suffering extreme
want.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdMy <xex>penurious</xex>
band.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Avaricious; covetous; parsimonious; miserly;
niggardly; stingy. See <er>Avaricious</er>.</syn>

--<wordforms><wf>Pe*nu"ri*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pe*nu"ri*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pen"u*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>penuria</ets>; cf. Gr. <?/ hunger, <?/ poverty, need, <?/
one who works for his daily bread, a poor man, <?/ to work for
one's daily bread, to be poor: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82nurie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Absence of
resources; want; privation; indigence; extreme poverty;
destitution.</def> \'bdA <xex>penury</xex> of military
forces.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>They were exposed to hardship and <qex>penury</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sprat.</qau>

<q>It arises in neither from <qex>penury</qex> of thought.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Penuriousness; miserliness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Pe"o*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Peonies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>pione</ets>, <ets>pioine</ets>, <ets>pioni</ets>, OF.
<ets>pione</ets>, F. <ets>pivoine</ets>, L. <ets>paeonia</ets>,

flower, of the ranunculaceous genus <spn>P\'91onia</spn>. Of the

herbs with showy flowers, often double in cultivation.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>p\'91ony</asp>, and
<asp>piony</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Peo"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>peple</ets>, <ets>people</ets>, OF. <ets>pueple</ets>, F.
<ets>peuple</ets>, fr. L. <ets>populus</ets>. Cf.
<er>Populage</er>, <er>Public</er>, <er>Pueblo</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The body of persons who compose a community,
tribe, nation, or race; an aggregate of individuals forming a
whole; a community; a nation.</def>

<q>Unto him shall the gathering of the <qex>people</qex> be.</q>
<qau>Gen. xlix. 10.</qau>

<q>The ants are a <qex>people</qex> not strong.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxx. 25.</qau>

<q>Before many <qex>peoples</qex>, and nations, and tongues.</q>
<qau>Rev. x. 11.</qau>

<q>Earth's monarchs are her <qex>peoples</qex>.</q>
<qau>Whitter</qau>.

<q>A government of all the <qex>people</qex>, by all the
<qex>people</qex>, for all the <qex>people</qex>.</q>
<qau>T. Parker.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>People</xex>is a collective noun, generally
construed with a plural verb, and only occasionally used in the
plural form (<xex>peoples</xex>), in the sense of nations or
races.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Persons, generally; an indefinite number of men
and women; folks; population, or part of population; <as>as,
country <ex>people</ex></as>; -- sometimes used as an indefinite
subject or verb, like <xex>on</xex> in French, and <xex>man</xex>
in German; <as>as, <ex>people</ex> in adversity</as>.</def>

<q><qex>People</qex> were tempted to lend by great premiums.</q>
<qau>Swift</qau>.

<q><qex>People</qex> have lived twenty-four days upon nothing but
water.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot</qau>.

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The mass of comunity as distinguished from a
special class; the commonalty; the populace; the vulgar; the
common crowd; <as>as, nobles and <ex>people</ex></as>.</def>

<q>And strive to gain his pardon from the <qex>people</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison</qau>.

<sn>4.</sn> With a possessive pronoun: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>One's
ancestors or family; kindred; relations; <as>as, my
<ex>people</ex> were English</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>One's
subjects; fellow citizens; companions; followers</def>. \'bdYou
slew great number of his <xex>people</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak</au>.

<syn>Syn. -- <er>People</er>, <er>Nation</er>.</syn> <usage> When
speaking of a state, we use <xex>people</xex> for the mass of the
community, as distinguished from their rulers, and
<xex>nation</xex> for the entire political body, including the
rulers. In another sense of the term, <xex>nation</xex> describes
those who are descended from the same stock; and in this sense
the Germans regard themselves as one <xex>nation</xex>, though
politically subject to different forms of government.</usage>

<hw>Peo"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. &  p. p.</pos> <er>Peopled</er> <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Peopling</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Cf. OF. <ets>popler</ets>, <ets>puepler</ets>, F.
<ets>puepler</ets>. Cf. <er>Populate</er>.]</ety> <def>To stock
with people or inhabitants; to fill as with people; to
populate.</def> \'bd<xex>Peopled</xex> heaven with angels.\'b8

<au>Dryden</au>.

<q>As the gay motes that <qex>people</qex> the sunbeams.</q>
<qau>Milton</qau>.

<hw>Peo"pled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Stocked with,
or as with, people; inhabited.</def> \'bdThe <xex>peopled</xex>
air.\'b8

<au>Gray</au>.

<hw>Peo"ple*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of
people.</def>

<au>Poe</au>.

inhabitant.</def> \'bd<xex>Peoplers</xex> of the peaceful
glen.\'b8

<au>J. S. Blackie.</au>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer</au>.

<hw>\'d8Pep"lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
Gr. <?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An upper garment worn by Grecian
and Roman women.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A kind of kerchief formerly worn by

<hw>\'d8Pe"po</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a kind
of melon, from Gr. <?/.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any fleshy
fruit with a firm rind, as a pumpkin, melon, or gourd. See
<er>Gourd</er>.</def>

<hw>Pep"per</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>peper</ets>, AS. <ets>pipor</ets>, L. <ets>piper</ets>, fr.
Gr. <?/, <?/, akin to Skr. <ets>pippala</ets>,
<ets>pippali</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A well-known,
pungently aromatic condiment, the dried berry, either whole or
powdered, of the <spn>Piper nigrum</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Common</xex>, or <xex>black</xex>,
<xex>pepper</xex> is made from the whole berry, dried just before
maturity; <xex>white pepper</xex> is made from the ripe berry
after the outer skin has been removed by maceration and friction.
It has less of the peculiar properties of the plant than the
black pepper.  Pepper is used in medicine as a carminative
stimulant.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The plant which yields pepper,
an East Indian woody climber (<spn>Piper nigrum</spn>), with
ovate leaves and apetalous flowers in spikes opposite the leaves.
The berries are red when ripe. Also, by extension, any one of the
several hundred species of the genus <spn>Piper</spn>, widely
dispersed throughout the tropical and subtropical regions of the
earth.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any plant of the genus Capsicum, and its fruit;
red pepper; <as>as, the bell <ex>pepper</ex></as>.</def>

<note><hand/ The term <xex>pepper</xex> has been extended to
various other fruits and plants, more or less closely resembling
the true pepper, esp. to the common varieties of
<spn>Capsicum</spn>. See <er>Capsicum</er>, and the Phrases,
below.</note>

<cs><col>African pepper</col>, <cd>the Guinea pepper. See under
<er>Guinea</er>.</cd> -- <col>Cayenne pepper</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Cayenne</er>.</cd> -- <col>Chinese pepper</col>, <cd>the
spicy berries of the <spn>Xanthoxylum piperitum</spn>, a species
of prickly ash found in China and Japan.</cd> -- <col>Guinea
pepper</col>. <cd>See under <er>Guinea</er>, and
<er>Capsicum</er>.</cd> -- <col>Jamaica pepper</col>. <cd>See
<er>Allspice</er>.</cd> -- <col>Long pepper</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The spike of berries of <spn>Piper longum</spn>, an East
Indian shrub</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The root of <spn>Piper, <or/
Macropiper, methysticum</spn>. See <er>Kava</er>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Malaguetta</col>, <or/ <col>Meleguetta</col>,
<col>pepper</col></mcol>, <cd>the aromatic seeds of the
<spn>Amomum Melegueta</spn>, an African plant of the Ginger
family. They are sometimes used to flavor beer, etc., under the
name of <altname>grains of Paradise</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Red
pepper</col>. <cd>See <er>Capsicum</er>.</cd> -- <col>Sweet
pepper bush</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an American shrub
(<spn>Clethra alnifolia</spn>), with racemes of fragrant white
flowers; -- called also <altname>white alder</altname>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Pepper box</col> <or/ <col>caster</col></mcol>, <cd>a
small box or bottle, with a perforated lid, used for sprinkling
ground pepper on food, etc.</cd> -- <col>Pepper corn</col>.
<cd>See in the Vocabulary.</cd> -- <col>Pepper elder</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a West Indian name of several plants of
the Pepper family, species of <spn>Piper</spn> and
<spn>Peperomia</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Pepper moth</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a European moth (<spn>Biston
betularia</spn>) having white wings covered with small black
specks.</cd> -- <col>Pepper pot</col>, <cd>a mucilaginous soup or
stew of vegetables and cassareep, much esteemed in the West
Indies.</cd> -- <col>Pepper root</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>.
<cd>See <er>Coralwort</er>.</cd> -- <col>pepper sauce</col>,
<cd>a condiment for the table, made of small red peppers steeped
in vinegar.</cd> -- <col>Pepper tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>an aromatic tree (<spn>Drimys axillaris</spn>) of the
Magnolia family, common in New Zealand. See <cref>Peruvian mastic
tree</cref>, under <er>Mastic</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pep"per</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Peppered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Peppering</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
sprinkle or season with pepper.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Figuratively: To shower shot or other missiles,
or blows, upon; to pelt; to fill with shot, or cover with bruises
or wounds.</def> \'bdI have <xex>peppered</xex> two of them.\'b8
\'bdI am <xex>peppered</xex>, I warrant, for this world.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pep"per</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To fire numerous shots
(at).</def>

<hw>Pep"per*brand`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>See 1st <er>Bunt</er>.</def>

<hw>Pep"per*grass`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Any herb of the cruciferous
genus <spn>Lepidium</spn>, especially the garden peppergrass, or
garden cress, <spn>Lepidium sativum</spn>; -- called also
<altname>pepperwort</altname>. All the species have a pungent
flavor.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The common pillwort of Europe
(<spn>Pilularia globulifera</spn>). See <er>Pillwort</er>.</def>

<hw>Pep"per*idge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. NL.
<ets>berberis</ets>, E. <ets>barberry</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A North American tree (<spn>Nyssa
multiflora</spn>) with very tough wood, handsome oval polished
leaves, and very acid berries, -- the sour gum, or common tupelo.
See <er>Tupelo</er>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>piperidge</asp> and <asp>pipperidge</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Pepperidge bush</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the
barberry.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pep"per*mint</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pepper</ets> + <ets>mint</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An aromatic and pungent plant of the genus

and confectionery.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A volatile oil (oil of peppermint) distilled
from the fresh herb; also, a well-known essence or spirit
(essence of peppermint) obtained from it.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A lozenge of sugar flavored with
peppermint.</def>

<cs><col>Peppermint</col><cd> camphor. <fld>(Chem.)</fld> Same as
<er>Menthol</er>.</cd> -- <col>Peppermint tree</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name given to several Australian species
of gum tree (<spn>Eucalyptus amygdalina</spn>, <spn>E.
piperita</spn>, <spn>E. odorata</spn>, etc.) which have hard and
durable wood, and yield an essential oil.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pep"per*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to pepper; having the qualities of pepper;
hot; pungent.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: Hot-tempered; passionate; choleric.</def>

<hw>Pep"sin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ a
cooking, digesting, digestion, fr. <?/, <?/, to cook, digest: cf.
F. <ets>pepsine</ets>. Cf. <er>Dyspepsia</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>An unorganized proteolytic
ferment or enzyme contained in the secretory glands of the
stomach. In the gastric juice it is united with dilute
hydrochloric acid (0.2 per cent, approximately) and the two
together constitute the active portion of the digestive fluid. It
is the active agent in the gastric juice of all animals.</def>

<note><hand/ As prepared from the glandular layer of pigs' or
calves' stomachs it constitutes an important article of
pharmacy.</note>

<hw>Pep`sin*hy`dro*chlo"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Peptohydrochloric</er>.</def>

<hw>Pep*sin"o*gen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pepsin</ets> + <ets>-gen</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.
Chem.)</fld> <def>The antecedent of the ferment pepsin. A
substance contained in the form of granules in the peptic cells
of the gastric glands. It is readily convertible into pepsin.
Also called <altname>propepsin</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pep"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pepticus</ets>, Gr. <?/. See <er>Pepsin</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Relating to digestion; promoting digestion;
digestive; <as>as, <ex>peptic</ex> sauces</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Able to digest.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Tolerably nutritive for a mind as yet so
<qex>peptic</qex>.</q>
<qau>Carlyle.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to
pepsin; resembling pepsin in its power of digesting or dissolving
albuminous matter; containing or yielding pepsin, or a body of
like properties; <as>as, the <ex>peptic</ex> glands</as>.</def>

<hw>Pep"tic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An agent that
promotes digestion.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The digestive organs.</def>

<q>Is there some magic in the place,
Or do my <qex>peptics</qex> differ?</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Pep"tics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The science of
digestion.</def>

<hw>Pep"to*gen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pepto</ets>ne + <ets>-gen</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A substance convertible into
peptone.</def>

<hw>Pep`to*gen"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Peptogenous</er>.</def>

<hw>Pep*tog"e*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>Capable of yielding, or being
converted into, peptone.</def>

<hw>Pep`to*hy`dro*chlo"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[See <er>Peptone</er>, and <er>Hydrochloric</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>Designating a hypothetical acid
(called <xex>peptohydrochloric acid</xex>,
<xex>pepsinhydrochloric acid</xex>, and <xex>chloropeptic</xex>
acid) which is supposed to be formed when pepsin and dilute
(0.1-0.4 per cent) hydrochloric acid are mixed together.</def>

<hw>Pep"tone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
cooked.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The
soluble and diffusible substance or substances into which
albuminous portions of the food are transformed by the action of
the gastric and pancreatic juices. Peptones are also formed from
albuminous matter by the action of boiling water and boiling
dilute acids.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Collectively, in a broader
sense, all the products resulting from the solution of albuminous
matter in either gastric or pancreatic juice. In this case,
however, intermediate products (albumose bodies), such as
<xex>antialbumose</xex>, <xex>hemialbumose</xex>, etc., are mixed
with the true peptones. Also termed <xex>albuminose</xex>.</def>
<-- soluble polypeptides produced by hydrolysis of protein -->

<note><hand/ Pure peptones are of three kinds,
<xex>amphopeptone</xex>, <xex>antipeptone</xex>, and
<xex>hemipeptone</xex>, and, unlike the albumose bodies, are not
precipitated by saturating their solutions with ammonium
sulphate.</note>

<hw>Pep"to*nize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>To convert into peptone; to digest or
dissolve by means of a proteolytic ferment; <as>as,
<ex>peptonized</ex> food</as>.</def>

<hw>Pep"to*noid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Peptone</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.
Chem.)</fld> <def>A substance related to peptone.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pep`to*nu"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Peptone</er>, and <er>Urine</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The presence of peptone, or a peptonelike
body, in the urine.</def><-- not in Stedman's.  Superseded by
proteinuria? -->

<hw>Pep`to*tox"ine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pepto</ets>ne + <ets>tox</ets>ic +
<ets>-ine</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A toxic
alkaloid found occasionally associated with the peptones formed
from fibrin by pepsinhydrochloric acid.</def>

<hw>Pe"quots</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>; <sing>sing.
<singw>Pequot</singw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></sing>. <fld>(Ethnol.)</fld>

<hw>Per-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[See <er>Per</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A prefix used to signify <xex>through</xex>,
<xex>throughout</xex>, <xex>by</xex>, <xex>for</xex>, or as an
<xex>intensive</xex> as <xex>per</xex>haps, by hap or chance;
<xex>per</xex>ennial, that lasts throughout the year;
<xex>per</xex>force, through or by force; <xex>per</xex>foliate,
<xex>per</xex>forate; <xex>per</xex>spicuous, evident throughout
or very evident; <xex>per</xex>plex, literally, to entangle very
much.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Originally, denoting that the
element to the name of which it is prefixed in the respective
compounds exercised its <xex>highest valence</xex>; now, only
that the element has a <xex>higher valence</xex> than in other
similar compounds; thus, barium <xex>per</xex>oxide is the
highest oxide of barium; while nitrogen and manganese
<xex>per</xex>oxides, so-called, are not the highest oxides of
those elements.</def>

<hw>Per</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>prep.</pos> <ety>[L. Cf.
<er>Far</er>, <er>For-</er>, <er>Pardon</er>, and cf.
<er>Par</er>, <ets>prep</ets>.]</ety> <def>Through; by means of;
through the agency of; by; for; for each; <as>as, <ex>per</ex>
annum; <ex>per</ex> capita, by heads, or according to
individuals; <ex>per</ex> curiam, by the court; <ex>per</ex> se,
by itself, of itself</as>.  <ex>Per</ex> is also sometimes used
with English words.</def>

<cs><col>Per annum</col>, <cd>by the year; in each successive
year; annually.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Per cent</col>, <col>Per
centum</col></mcol>, <cd>by the hundred; in the hundred; -- used
esp. of proportions of ingredients, rate or amount of interest,
and the like; commonly used in the shortened form <xex>per
cent<xex>.</cd><-- commonly symbolized with the per cent sign, %
--> -- <col>Per diem</col>, <cd>by the day.</cd> [For other
phrases from the Latin, see Quotations, Phrases, etc., from
Foreign Languages, in the Supplement.]</cs>

<hw>Per*am"bu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Perambulated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Perambulating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>perambulatus</ets>, p.p. of <ets>perambulare</ets> to

walk. See <er>Per-</er>, and <er>Amble</er>.]</ety> <def>To walk
through or over; especially, to travel over for the purpose of
surveying or examining; to inspect by traversing; specifically,
to inspect officially the boundaries of, as of a town or parish,
by walking over the whole line.</def>

<hw>Per*am"bu*late</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To walk about; to
ramble; to stroll; <as>as, he <ex>perambulated</ex> in the
park</as>.</def>

<hw>Per*am"bu*la`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

distance traveled is shown by an index. See
<er>Odometer</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A low carriage for a child, propelled by

<hw>Per*ceiv"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Power of
perceiving.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe senses and common
<xex>perceivance</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Per*ceive"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Perceived</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Perceiving</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF. <ets>percevoir</ets>,
<ets>perceveir</ets>, L. <ets>percipere</ets>,
<ets>perceptum</ets>; <ets>per</ets> (see <er>Per-</er>) +
<ets>capere</ets> to take, receive. See <er>Capacious</er>, and
cf. <er>Perception</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To obtain
knowledge of through the senses; to receive impressions from by
means of the bodily organs; to take cognizance of the existence,
character, or identity of, by means of the senses; to see, hear,
or feel; <as>as, to <ex>perceive</ex> a distant ship; to
<ex>perceive</ex> a discord.</as></def>

<au>Reid.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take intellectual cognizance of; to apprehend
by the mind; to be convinced of by direct intuition; to note; to
remark; to discern; to see; to understand.</def>

<q>Jesus <qex>perceived</qex> their wickedness.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxii. 18.</qau>

<q>You may, fair lady,
<qex>Perceive</qex> I speak sincerely.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Till we ourselves see it with our own eyes, and
<qex>perceive</qex> it by our own understandings, we are still in
the dark.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To be affected of influented by.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The upper regions of the air <qex>perceive</qex> the
collection of the matter of tempests before the air here
below.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To discern; distinguish; observe; see; feel; know;
understand.</syn> <usage> -- To <er>Perceive</er>,
<er>Discern</er>. To <xex>perceive</xex> a thing is to apprehend
it as presented to the senses or the intellect; to
<xex>discern</xex> is to mark differences, or to see a thing as
distinguished from others around it. We may <xex>perceive</xex>
two persons afar off without being able to <xex>discern</xex>
whether they are men or women. Hence, <xex>discern</xex> is often
used of an act of the senses or the mind involving close,
discriminating, analytical attention. We <xex>perceive</xex> that
which is clear or obvious; we <xex>discern</xex> that which
requires much attention to get an idea of it. \'bdWe
<xex>perceive</xex> light, darkness, colors, or the truth or
falsehood of anything. We <xex>discern</xex> characters, motives,
the tendency and consequences of actions, etc.\'b8</usage>

<au>Crabb.</au>

<-- p. 1064 -->

<hw>Per*cep`ti*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>perceptibilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being perceptible; <as>as, the
<ex>perceptibility</ex> of light or color</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Perception.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Per*cep"ti*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>perceptibilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>perceptible</ets>. See
<er>Perceive</er>.]</ety> <def>Capable of being perceived;
cognizable; discernible; perceivable.</def>

<q>With a <qex>perceptible</qex> blast of the air.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Per*cep"ti*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>Per*cep"ti*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Per*cep"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>perceptio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>perception</ets>. See
<er>Perceive</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of perceiving;
cognizance by the senses or intellect; apperhension by the bodily
organs, or by the mind, of what is presented to them;
discernment; apperhension; cognition.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>The faculty of perceiving;
the faculty, or peculiar part, of man's constitution by which he
has knowledge through the medium or instrumentality of the bodily
organs; the act of apperhending material objects or qualities
through the senses; -- distinguished from
<xex>conception</xex>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<q>Matter hath no life nor <qex>perception</qex>, and is not
conscious of its own existence.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The quality, state, or capability, of being
affected by something external; sensation; sensibility.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>This experiment discovereth <qex>perception</qex> in
plants.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An idea; a notion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<note><hand/ \'bdThe word <xex>perception</xex> is, in the
language of philosophers previous to Reid, used in a very
extensive signification. By Descartes, Malebranche, Locke,
Leibnitz, and others, it is employed in a sense almost as
unexclusive as <xex>consciousness</xex>, in its widest
signification. By Reid this word was limited to our faculty
acquisitive of knowledge, and to that branch of this faculty
whereby, through the senses, we obtain a knowledge of the
external world. But his limitation did not stop here. In the act
of external perception he distinguished two elements, to which he
gave the names of <xex>perception</xex> and <xex>sensation</xex>.
He ought perhaps to have called these <xex>perception
proper</xex> and <xex>sensation proper</xex>, when employed in
his special meaning.\'b8</note>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<hw>Per*cep"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>perceptif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to the act or
power of perceiving; having the faculty or power of perceiving;
used in perception.</def> \'bdHis <xex>perceptive</xex> and
reflective faculties.\'b8

<au>Motley.</au>

<hw>Per`cep*tiv"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being perceptive; power of perception.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>\'d8Per*ces"o*ces</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>perca</ets> a perch + <ets>esox</ets>,
<ets>-ocis</ets>, a pike.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An
order of fishes including the gray mullets (<spn>Mugil</spn>),
the barracudas, the silversides, and other related fishes. So
called from their relation both to perches and to pikes.</def>

<hw>Perch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pearch</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[OE. <ets>perche</ets>, F.
<ets>perche</ets>, L. <ets>perca</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/; cf. <?/
dark-colored, Skr. <ets>p<?/<?/ni</ets> spotted, speckled, and E.
<ets>freckle</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Any fresh-water fish of the genus Perca and of several other
allied genera of the family <spn>Percid\'91</spn>, as the common
American or yellow perch (<spn>Perca flavescens, <or/
Americana</spn>), and the European perch (<spn>P.
fluviatilis</spn>).</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any one of numerous species of spiny-finned
fishes belonging to the <spn>Percid\'91</spn>,
<spn>Serranid\'91</spn>, and related families, and resembling,
more or less, the true perches.</def>

<cs><col>Black perch</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The black bass</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The flasher</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>The sea
bass.</cd> -- <col>Blue perch</col>, <cd>the cunner.</cd> --
<col>Gray perch</col>, <cd>the fresh-water drum.</cd> -- <col>Red
perch</col>, <cd>the rosefish.</cd> -- <col>Red-bellied
perch</col>, <cd>the long-eared pondfish.</cd> -- <col>Perch
pest</col>, <cd>a small crustacean, parasitic in the mouth of the
perch.</cd> -- <col>Silver perch</col>, <cd>the yellowtail.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Stone</col>, <or/ <col>Striped</col>,
<col>perch</col></mcol>, <cd>the pope.</cd> -- <col>White
perch</col>, <cd>the <spn>Roccus, <or/ Morone, Americanus</spn>,
a small silvery serranoid market fish of the Atlantic
coast.</cd></cs>

<hw>Perch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>perche</ets>, L. <ets>pertica</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A pole; a long staff; a rod; esp., a pole or other support
for fowls to roost on or to rest on; a roost; figuratively, any
elevated resting place or seat.</def>

<q>As chauntecleer among his wives all
Sat on his <qex>perche</qex>, that was in his hall.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Not making his high place the lawless <qex>perch</qex>
Of winged ambitions.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A measure of length containing five
and a half yards; a rod, or pole.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>In land
or square measure: A square rod; the 160th part of an acre.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>In solid measure: A mass 16<frac12/ feet long,
1 foot in height, and 1<frac12/ feet in breadth, or 24<frac34/
cubic feet (in local use, from 22 to 25 cubic feet); -- used in
measuring stonework.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A pole connecting the fore gear and hind gear of
a spring carriage; a reach.</def>

<hw>Perch</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Perched</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Perching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>percher</ets>. See <er>Perch</er> a pole.]</ety> <def>To
alight or settle, as a bird; to sit or roost.</def>

<q>Wrens make prey where eagles dare not <qex>perch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Perch</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To place or to
set on, or as on, a perch.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To occupy as a perch.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<def>Pertaining to, or designating, a certain one of the highly
oxidized compounds of chromium, which has a deep blue color, and

<hw>Per*cuss"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Percussed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Percussing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>percussus</ets>,
p.p. of <ets>percutere</ets>; <ets>per + quatere</ets> to shake,
strike. See <er>Quash</er>.]</ety> <def>To strike smartly; to
strike upon or against; <as>as, to <ex>percuss</ex> the chest in
medical examination</as>.</def>

<q>Flame <qex>percussed</qex> by air giveth a noise.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Per*cuss"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To
strike or tap in an examination by percussion. See
<er>Percussion</er>, 3.</def>

<au>Quain.</au>

<hw>Per*cus"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>percussio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>percussion</ets>. See
<er>Percuss</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of percussing,
or striking one body against another; forcible collision, esp.
such as gives a sound or report.</def>

<au>Sir I. Newton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: The effect of violent collision;
vibratory shock; impression of sound on the ear.</def>

<q>The thunderlike <qex>percussion</qex> of thy sounds.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The act of tapping or striking
the surface of the body in order to learn the condition of the
parts beneath by the sound emitted or the sensation imparted to
the fingers. Percussion is said to be <xex>immediate</xex> if the
blow is directly upon the body; if some interventing substance,
as a pleximeter, is, used, it is called <xex>mediate</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Center of percussion</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Center</er>.</cd> -- <col>Percussion bullet</col>, <cd>a
bullet containing a substance which is exploded by percussion; an
explosive bullet.</cd> -- <col>Percussion cap</col>, <cd>a small
copper cap or cup, containing fulminating powder, and used with a
percussion lock to explode gunpowder.</cd> -- <col>Percussion
fuze</col>. <cd>See under <er>Fuze</er>.</cd> -- <col>Percussion
lock</col>, <cd>the lock of a gun that is fired by percussion
upon fulminating powder.</cd> -- <col>Percussion match</col>,
<cd>a match which ignites by percussion.</cd> -- <col>Percussion
powder</col>, <cd>powder so composed as to ignite by slight
percussion; fulminating powder.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Percussion
sieve</col>, <col>Percussion table</col></mcol>, <cd>a machine
for sorting ores by agitation in running water.</cd></cs>

<hw>Per*cuss"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Striking
against; percutient; <as>as, <ex>percussive</ex>
force</as>.</def>

<hw>Per*di"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>perditio</ets>, fr. <ets>perdere</ets>, <ets>perditum</ets>,
to ruin, to lose; <ets>per</ets> (cf. Skr. <ets>par\'be</ets>

or of final happiness in a future state; future misery or eternal
death.</def>

<q>The mere <qex>perdition</qex> of the Turkish fleet.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<qex>perdition</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. M. Mason.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Loss of diminution.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Per"e*grine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>peregrinus</ets>. See <er>Pilgrim</er>.]</ety> <def>Foreign;

<altsp>[Spelt also <asp>pelegrine</asp>.]</altsp>
\'bd<xex>Peregrine</xex> and preternatural heat.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<cs><col>Peregrine falcon</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
courageous and swift falcon (<spn>Falco peregrinus</spn>),
remarkable for its wide distribution over all the continents. The
adult plumage is dark bluish ash on the back, nearly black on the
head and cheeks, white beneath, barred with black below the
throat. Called also <altname>peregrine hawk</altname>,
<altname>duck hawk</altname>, <altname>game hawk</altname>, and
<altname>great-footed hawk</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Per"e*grine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
peregrine falcon.</def>

<hw>Per"emp*to*ri*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Per"emp*to*ri*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of
