that which, persuades or influences.</def> \'bdPowerful
<xex>persuaders</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Per*sua`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Capability of being persuaded.</def>

<au>Hawthorne.</au>

<hw>Per*sua"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. L.
<ets>persuasibilis</ets> persuasive, F. <ets>persuasible</ets>
persuasible.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being persuaded;
persuadable.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Persuasive.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bale.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>Per*sua"si*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>Per*sua"si*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Per*sua"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>persuasio</ets>; Cf. F. <ets>persuasion</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of persuading; the act of influencing
the mind by arguments or reasons offered, or by anything that
moves the mind or passions, or inclines the will to a
determination.</def>

<q>For thou hast all the arts of fine <qex>persuasion</qex>.</q>
<qau>Otway.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being persuaded or convinced;
settled opinion or conviction, which has been induced.</def>

<q>If the general <qex>persuasion</qex> of all men does so
account it.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<q>My firm <qex>persuasion</qex> is, at least sometimes,
That Heaven will weigh man's virtues and his crimes
With nice attention.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A creed or belief; a sect or party adhering to a
certain creed or system of opinions; <as>as, of the same
<ex>persuasion</ex>; all <ex>persuasions</ex> are
agreed.</as></def>

<q>Of whatever state or <qex>persuasion</qex>, religious or
political.</q>
<qau>Jefferson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The power or quality of persuading;
persuasiveness.</def>

<q>Is 't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack <qex>persuasion</qex>?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That which persuades; a persuasive.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Conviction</er>.</syn>

<hw>Per*sua"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>persuasif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to persuade; having the
power of persuading; <as>as, <ex>persuasive</ex>
eloquence</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Persuasive</xex> words.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Per*sul"phide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A sulphide containing more sulphur than
some other compound of the same elements; <as>as, iron pyrites is
a <ex>persulphide</ex></as>; -- formerly called
<altname>persulphuret</altname>.</def>

<hw>Per*sul`pho*cy"a*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Per*sul`pho*cy*an"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, a yellow
crystalline substance (called also <xex>perthiocyanic
acid</xex>), analogous to sulphocyanic acid, but containing more
sulphur.</def>

<hw>Per*sul`pho*cy*an"o*gen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An orange-yellow substance, produced by
the action of chlorine or boiling dilute nitric acid and
sulphocyanate of potassium; -- called also
<altname>pseudosulphocyanogen</altname>,
<altname>perthiocyanogen</altname>, and formerly
<altname>sulphocyanogen</altname>.</def>

<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A persulphide.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pert</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[An aphetic form

<hw>Per*tain"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pertained</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pertaining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>partenen</ets>,
OF. <ets>partenir</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pertinere</ets> to stretch
out, reach, pertain; <ets>per + tenere</ets> to hold, keep. See
<er>Per-</er>, and <er>Tenable</er>, and cf. <er>Appertain</er>,
<er>Pertinent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To belong; to have
connection with, or dependence on, something, as an appurtenance,
attribute, etc.; to appertain; <as>as, saltness <ex>pertains</ex>
to the ocean; flowers <ex>pertain</ex> to plant life.</as></def>

<q>Men hate those who affect that honor by ambition which
<qex>pertaineth</qex> not to them.</q>
<qau>Hayward.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have relation or reference to
something.</def>

<q>These words <qex>pertain</qex> unto us at this time as they
<qex>pertained</qex> to them at their time.</q>
<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<hw>Per`ti*na"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos><ety>[L.

<hw>Per`tur*ba"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of perturbing, or the state of being

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A disturbance in the
regular elliptic or other motion of a heavenly body, produced by
some force additional to that which causes its regular motion;
<as>as, the <ex>perturbations</ex> of the planets are caused by
their attraction on each other</as>.</def>

<au>Newcomb.</au>

<hw>Pe*ru"vi*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A native or an inhabitant of
Peru.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Peruvian balsam</col>. <cd>See <cref>Balsam of
Peru</cref>, under <er>Balsam</er>.</cd> -- <col>Peruvian
bark</col>, <cd>the bitter bark of trees of various species of
Cinchona. It acts as a powerful tonic, and is a remedy for
malarial diseases. This property is due to several alkaloids, as
quinine, cinchonine, etc., and their compounds; -- called also
<altname>Jesuit's bark</altname>, and
<altname>cinchona</altname>. See <er>Cinchona</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Per*vade"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pervaded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pervading</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.

<er>Wade</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To pass or flow through,

<q>That labyrinth is easily <qex>pervaded</qex>.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pass or spread through the whole extent of;
to be diffused throughout.</def>

<q>A spirit of cabal, intrigue, and proselytism
<qex>pervaded</qex> all their thoughts, words, and actions.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Per*verse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>perversus</ets> turned the wrong way, not right, p.p. of
<ets>pervertere</ets>to turn around, to overturn: cf. F.
<ets>pervers</ets>. See <er>Pervert</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Turned aside; hence, specifically, turned away from the
right; willfully erring; wicked; perverted.</def>

<q>The only righteous in a word <qex>perverse</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Obstinate in the wrong; stubborn; intractable;
hence, wayward; vexing; contrary.</def>

<q>To so <qex>perverse</qex> a sex all grace is vain.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Froward; untoward; wayward; stubborn; ungovernable;
intractable; cross; petulant; vexatious.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Perverse</er>, <er>Froward</er>. One who is
<xex>froward</xex> is capricious, and reluctant to obey. One who
is <xex>perverse</xex> has a settled obstinacy of will, and likes
or dislikes by the rule of contradiction to the will of
others.</usage>

<hw>Per*versed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Turned
aside.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Per*vers"ed*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Perversely.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Per*verse"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a perverse
manner.</def>

<hw>Per*verse"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state
of being perverse.</def> \'bdVirtue hath some
<xex>perverseness</xex>.\'b8

<au>Donne.</au>

<hw>Per*ver"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>perversio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>perversion</ets>. See
<er>Pervert</er>.]</ety> <def>The act of perverting, or the state
of being perverted; a turning from truth or right; a diverting
from the true intent or object; a change to something worse; a
turning or applying to a wrong end or use.</def> \'bdViolations
and <xex>perversions</xex> of the laws.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Per*ver"si*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>perversitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>perversit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The quality or state of being perverse; perverseness.</def>

<hw>Per*ver"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos><def>Tending to
pervert.</def>

<hw>Per*vert"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Perverted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Perverting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>pervertir</ets>, L. <ets>pervertere</ets>,
<ets>perversum</ets>; <ets>per + vertere</ets> to turn. See
<er>Per-</er>, and <er>Verse</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
turnanother way; to divert.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Let's follow him, and <qex>pervert</qex> the present
wrath.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To turn from truth, rectitude, or propriety; to
divert from a right use, end, or way; to lead astray; to corrupt;
also, to misapply; to misinterpret designedly; <as>as, to
<ex>pervert</ex> one's words</as>.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>He, in the serpent, had <qex>perverted</qex> Eve.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Per*vert"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become perverted; to
take the wrong course.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Testament of Love.</au>

<hw>Per"vert</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who has
been perverted; one who has turned to error, especially in
religion; -- opposed to <xex>convert</xex>. See the Synonym of
<er>Convert</er>.</def>

<q>That notorious <qex>pervert</qex>, Henry of Navarre.</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<xex>perverter</xex> of his law.\'b8 <au>Bp. Stillingfleet</au>.

<hw>Per*vert"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being perverted.</def>

<hw>Per*ves"ti*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Per*ves`ti*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pes"si*mism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>The opinion or doctrine that everything

is wholly evil; -- opposed to <ant>optimism</ant>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A disposition to take the least hopeful view of

<hw>Pes"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pestered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pestering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Abbrev. fr.
<ets>impester</ets>, fr. OF. <ets>empaistrier</ets>,
<ets>empestrer</ets>, to entangle the feet or legs, to embarrass,
F. <ets>emp</ets>\'88<ets>trer</ets>; pref. <ets>em-</ets>,
<ets>en-</ets> (L. <ets>in</ets> in) + LL. <ets>pastorium</ets>,
<ets>pastoria</ets>, a fetter by which horses are prevented from
wandering in the pastures, fr. L. <ets>pastorius</ets> belonging
to a herdsman or shepherd, <ets>pastor</ets> a herdsman. See
<er>In</er>, and <er>Pasture</er>, <er>Pastor</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To trouble; to disturb; to annoy; to harass with
petty vexations.</def>

<q>We are <qex>pestered</qex> with mice and rats.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<q>A multitude of scribblers daily <qex>pester</qex> the
world.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To crowd together in an annoying way; to
overcrowd; to infest.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>All rivers and pools . . . <qex>pestered</qex> full with
fishes.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

pesters or harasses.</def>

pestering, or the state of being pestered; vexation; worry.</def>
\'bdThe trouble and <xex>pesterment</xex> of children.\'b8

<au>B. Franklin.</au>

<hw>Pes"ter*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos><def>Inclined to

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pes*tif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pes"ti*lence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pestilence</ets>, L. <ets>pestilentia</ets>. See
<er>Pestilent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Specifically, the
disease known as the plague; hence, any contagious or infectious
epidemic disease that is virulent and devastating.</def>

<q>The <qex>pestilence</qex> That walketh in darkness.</q>
<qau>Ps. xci. 6.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: That which is pestilent, noxious, or
pernicious to the moral character of great numbers.</def>

<q>I'll pour this <qex>pestilence</qex> into his ear.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Pestilence weed</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the
butterbur coltsfoot (<spn>Petasites vulgaris</spn>), so called
because formerly considered a remedy for the plague.</cd></cs>

<au>Dr. Prior.</au>

<hw>Pes"ti*lent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pet</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formerly
<ets>peat</ets>, perhaps from Ir. <ets>peat</ets>, akin to Gael.
<ets>peata</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A cade lamb; a lamb
brought up by hand.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any person or animal especially cherished and
indulged; a fondling; a darling; often, a favorite child.</def>

<q>The love of cronies, <qex>pets</qex>, and favorites.</q>
<qau>Tatler.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Prob. fr. <er>Pet</er> a fondling, hence, the
behavior or humor of a spoiled child.]</ety> <def>A slight fit of
peevishness or fretfulness.</def> \'bdIn a <xex>pet</xex> she
started up.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<hw>Pet</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Petted; indulged; admired;

<ex>pet</ex> theory.</as></def>

<q>Some young lady's <qex>pet</qex> curate.</q>

<hw>Pet"al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/ a leaf: cf. F. <ets>p\'82talisme</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Gr.
Antiq.)</fld> <def>A form of sentence among the ancient
Syracusans by which they banished for five years a citizen
suspected of having dangerous influence or ambition. It was
similar to the <xex>ostracism</xex> in Athens; but olive leaves
were used instead of shells for ballots.</def>

<hw>Pet"al*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82talite</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A rare
mineral, occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses, usually
white, or nearly so, in color. It is a silicate of aluminia and
lithia.</def>

<hw>Pe*tal"o*dy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Petal</ets> + Gr. <?/ form.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The metamorphosis of various floral organs, usually stamens,
into petals.</def>

<hw>Pet"al*oid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<def>Petaline.</def>

<hw>Pet`al*oid"e*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Having the whole or part of the perianth

<cs><col>Petaloideous division</col>, <cd>that division of

<spn>Orchidace\'91</spn>, <spn>Amaryllide\'91</spn>,

<hw>Pe*tar"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See

<xex>petar</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pe*tard"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82tard</ets>, fr. <ets>p\'82ter</ets> to break wind, to
crack, to explode, L. <ets>pedere</ets>,
<ets>peditum</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A case
containing powder to be exploded, esp. a conical or cylindrical
case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank, to be
exploded against and break down gates, barricades, drawbridges,
etc.  It has been superseded.</def>

managed a petard.</def>

cap of Mercury; also, a broad-brimmed, low-crowned hat worn by

<hw>Pe*tau"rist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>petaurista</ets> a ropedancer, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to dance on
a rope, fr. <?/ a pole, a stage for ropedancers: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82tauriste</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any
flying marsupial of the genera <spn>Petaurus</spn>,
<spn>Phalangista</spn>, <spn>Acrobata</spn>, and allied genera.
See <cref>Flying mouse</cref>, under <er>Flying</er>, and
<er>Phalangister</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pe*tech"i*\'91</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>;
<sing>sing. <singw>Petechia</singw> <pr>(<?/)</pr></sing>.
<ety>[NL., fr. LL. <ets>peteccia</ets>; cf. F.
<ets>p\'82t\'82chie</ets>, It. <ets>petecchia</ets>, Sp.
<ets>petequia</ets>, Gr. <?/ a label, plaster.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Small crimson, purple, or livid spots,
like flea-bites, due to extravasation of blood, which appear on
the skin in malignant fevers, etc.</def>

<hw>Pe*tech"i*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>p\'82t\'82chial</ets>, LL. <ets>petecchialis</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Characterized by, or pertaining to,
petechi\'91; spotted.</def>

<cs><col>Petechial fever</col>, <cd>a malignant fever,
accompanied with livid spots on the skin.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pe"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A common
baptismal name for a man. The name of one of the apostles,</def>

<cs><col>Peter boat</col>, <cd>a fishing boat, sharp at both
ends, originally of the Baltic Sea, but now common in certain
English rivers.</cd> -- <col>Peter Funk</col>, <cd>the auctioneer
in a mock auction.</cd> <mark>[Cant, U.S.]</mark> --
<mcol><col>Peter pence</col>, <or/ <col>Peter's
pence</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An annual tax or tribute,
formerly paid by the English people to the pope, being a penny
for every house, payable on Lammas or St.Peter's day; -- called
also <altname>Rome scot</altname>, and <altname>hearth
money</altname>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>In modern times, a
voluntary contribution made by Roman Catholics to the private
purse of the pope.</cd> -- <col>Peter's fish</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a haddock; -- so called because the
black spots, one on each side, behind the gills, are
traditionally said to have been caused by the fingers of St.
Peter, when he caught the fish to pay the tribute. The name is
applied, also, to other fishes having similar spots.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pet"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F. See
<er>Petty</er>.]</ety> <def>Small; little; insignificant; mean;
-- Same as <er>Petty</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs., except in legal
language.]</mark>

<q>By what small, <qex>petit</qex> hints does the mind catch hold
of and recover a vanishing notion.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<cs><col>Petit constable</col>, <cd>an inferior civil officer,
subordinate to the high constable.</cd> -- <col>Petit jury</col>,
<cd>a jury of twelve men, impaneled to try causes at the bar of a
court; -- so called in distinction from the <xex>grand
jury<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Petit larceny</col>, <cd>the stealing of
goods of, or under, a certain specified small value; -- opposed
to <xex>grand larceny<xex>. The distinction is abolished in
England.</cd> -- <col>Petit ma\'8ctre</col> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.
<ety>[F., lit., little master.]</ety> <cd>A fop; a coxcomb; a
ladies' man. <au>Goldsmith</au>.</cd> -- <col>Petit
serjeanty</col> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld>, <cd>the tenure of lands of
the crown, by the service of rendering annually some implement of
war, as a bow, an arrow, a sword, a flag, etc.</cd> -- <col>Petit
treason</col>, <cd>formerly, in England, the crime of killing a
person to whom the offender owed duty or subjection, as one's
husband, master, mistress, etc. The crime is now not
distinguished from murder.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pe*ti"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82tition</ets>, L. <ets>petitio</ets>, fr.
<ets>petere</ets>, <ets>petitum</ets>, to beg, ask, seek; perh.
akin to E. <ets>feather</ets>, or <ets>find</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A prayer; a supplication; an imploration; an
entreaty; especially, a request of a solemn or formal kind; a
prayer to the Supreme Being, or to a person of superior power,
rank, or authority; also, a single clause in such a prayer.</def>

<q>A house of prayer and <qex>petition</qex> for thy people.</q>
<qau>1 Macc. vii. 37.</qau>

<q>This last <qex>petition</qex> heard of all her prayer.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A formal written request addressed to an
official person, or to an organized body, having power to grant
it; specifically <fld>(Law)</fld>, a supplication to government,
in either of its branches, for the granting of a particular grace
or right; -- in distinction from a <xex>memorial</xex>, which
calls certain facts to mind; also, the written document.</def>

<cs><col>Petition of right</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a petition
to obtain possession or restitution of property, either real or
personal, from the Crown, which suggests such a title as
controverts the title of the Crown, grounded on facts disclosed
in the petition itself. <au>Mozley & W.</au></cd> -- <col>The
Petition of Right</col> <fld>(Eng. Hist.)</fld>, <cd>the
parliamentary declaration of the rights of the people, assented
to by Charles I.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pe*ti"tion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Petitioned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Petitioning</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To make a prayer
or request to; to ask from; to solicit; to entreat; especially,
to make a formal written supplication, or application to, as to
any branch of the government; <as>as, to <ex>petition</ex> the
court; to <ex>petition</ex> the governor.</as></def>

<q>You have . . . <qex>petitioned</qex> all the gods for my
prosperity.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pe*ti"tion</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make a petition or
solicitation.</def>

<hw>Pe*ti"tion*a*ri*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
way of begging the question; by an assumption.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Petitory suit</col> <or/ <col>action</col></mcol>
<fld>(Admiralty Law)</fld>, <cd>a suit in which the mere title to
property is litigated and sought to be enforced, as distinguished
from a <xex>possessory<xex> suit; also <fld>(Scots Law)</fld>, a
suit wherein the plaintiff claims something as due him by the
defendant.</cd></cs>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<hw>Pe"trel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>p\'82trel</ets>; a dim. of the name <ets>Peter</ets>, L.
<ets>Petrus</ets>, Gr. <?/ a stone (<ets>John
i</ets>.<ets>42</ets>); -- probably so called in allusion to
St.<ets>Peter's</ets> walking on the sea. See
<er>Petrify</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of
numerous species of longwinged sea birds belonging to the family
<spn>Procellarid\'91</spn>. The small petrels, or Mother Carey's
chickens, belong to <stype><spn>Oceanites</spn></stype>,
<stype><spn>Oceanodroma</spn></stype>,
<stype><spn>Procellaria</spn></stype>, and several allied
genera.</def>

<cs><col>Diving petrel</col>, <cd>any bird of the genus
<spn>Pelecanoides</spn>. They chiefly inhabit the southern
hemisphere.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Fulmar petrel</col>, <col>Giant
petrel</col></mcol>. <cd>See <er>Fulmar</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pintado petrel</col>, <cd>the Cape pigeon. See under
<er>Cape</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pintado petrel</col>, <cd>any one of
several small petrels, especially <spn>Procellaria
pelagica</spn>, or Mother Carey's chicken, common on both sides
of the Atlantic.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pet`ri*fac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Petrify</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The process of
petrifying, or changing into stone; conversion of any organic
matter (animal or vegetable) into stone, or a substance of stony
hardness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state or condition of being petrified.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is petrified; popularly, a body
incrusted with stony matter; an incrustation.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Fig.: Hardness; callousness; obduracy.</def>
\'bd<xex>Petrifaction</xex> of the soul.\'b8

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<hw>Pet`ri*fac"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having the quality of converting organic matter into stone;
petrifying.</def>

petrifaction.</def>

<q>The . . . <qex>petrifactive</qex> mutations of hard
bodies.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>Pet`ri*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<hw>Pet"ri*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Petrified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Petrifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>petra</ets> rock, Gr.
<?/ (akin to <?/ a stone) + <ets>-fy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82trifier</ets>. Cf. <er>Parrot</er>, <er>Petrel</er>,
<er>Pier</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To convert, as any animal
or vegetable matter, into stone or stony substance.</def>

<q>A river that <qex>petrifies</qex> any sort of wood or
leaves.</q>
<qau>Kirwan.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make callous or obdurate; to stupefy; to
paralyze; to transform; as by petrifaction; <as>as, to
<ex>petrify</ex> the heart</as>. <xex>Young</xex>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Petrifying</xex> accuracy.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<q>And <qex>petrify</qex> a genius to a dunce.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>The poor, <qex>petrified</qex> journeyman, quite unconscious
of what he was doing.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<q>A hideous fatalism, which ought, logically, to
<qex>petrify</qex> your volition.</q>
<qau>G. Eliot.</qau>

<hw>Pet"ri*fy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To become
stone, or of a stony hardness, as organic matter by calcareous
deposits.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To become stony, callous, or
obdurate.</def>

<q>Like Niobe we marble grow,
And <qex>petrify</qex> with grief.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pe*trog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Petro</ets> + <ets>-graphy</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The art of writing on stone.</def>

department of science which investigates the constitution of
rocks; petrology.</def>

<hw>Pet`ro*hy"oid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Petro</ets> + <ets>hyoid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to petrous, oe periotic,

<ex>petrohyoid</ex> muscles of the frog</as>.</def>

<hw>Pe*trol"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Petroleum.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pet`ro*la"tum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem. &
Pharm.)</fld> <def>A semisolid unctuous substance, neutral, and
without taste or odor, derived from petroleum by distilling off
the lighter portions and purifying the residue. It is a
yellowish, fatlike mass, transparent in thin layers, and somewhat
fluorescent. It is used as a bland protective dressing, and as a
substitute for fatty materials in ointments.</def>

<au>U. S. Pharm.</au>

<note><hand/ <xex>Petrolatum</xex> is the official name for the
purified product. <xex>Cosmoline</xex> and <xex>vaseline</xex>
are commercial names for substances essentially the same, but
differing slightly in appearance and consistency or
fusibility.</note>

<hw>Pe*tro"le*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
L. <ets>petra</ets> a rock + <ets>oleum</ets> oil: cf. F.
<ets>p\'82trole</ets>. Cf. <er>Petrify</er>, and
<er>Oil</er>.]</ety> <def>Rock oil, mineral oil, or natural oil,
a dark brown or greenish inflammable liquid, which, at certain
points, exists in the upper strata of the earth, from whence it
is pumped, or forced by pressure of the gas attending it. It
consists of a complex mixture of various hydrocarbons, largely of
the methane series, but may vary much in appearance, composition,
and properties. It is refined by distillation, and the products
include kerosene, benzine, gasoline, paraffin, etc.</def>

<cs><col>Petroleum spirit</col>, <cd>a volatile liquid obtained
in the distillation of crude petroleum at a temperature of
170\'f8 Fahr., or below. The term is rather loosely applied to a
considerable range of products, including benzine and ligroin.
The terms <xex>petroleum ether<xex>, and <xex>naphtha<xex>, are
sometimes applied to the still more volatile products, including
rhigolene, gasoline, cymogene, etc.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>\'d8P\'82`tro`leur"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.

f.</pos> }</mhw><ety>[F.]</ety> <def>One who makes use of

<hw>Pe*tro"sal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the
petrous, or petrosal, bone, or the corresponding part of the
temporal bone.</def>

<cs><col>Petrosal bone</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>a bone
corresponding to the petrous portion of the temporal bone of man;
or one forming more or less of the periotic capsule.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pet"ti*fog</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pettifogged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pettifogging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[<ets>Petty</ets> +
<ets>fog</ets> to pettifog.]</ety> <def>To do a petty business as
a lawyer; also, to do law business in a petty or tricky
way.</def> \'bdHe takes no money, but <xex>pettifogs</xex>
gratis.\'b8

<au>S. Butler.</au>

<hw>Pet"ti*fog</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To advocate like a
pettifogger; to argue trickily; <as>as, to <ex>pettifog</ex> a
claim</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Pet"ti*fog`ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A lawyer
who deals in petty cases; an attorney whose methods are mean and
tricky; an inferior lawyer.</def>

<q>A <qex>pettifogger</qex> was lord chancellor.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pet"ti*fog`ger*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Pet"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Pettier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Pettiest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>petit</ets>, F. <ets>petit</ets>; probably of Celtic origin,
and akin to E. <ets>piece</ets>. Cf. <er>Petit</er>.]</ety>
<def>Little; trifling; inconsiderable; also, inferior;
subordinate; <as>as, a <ex>petty</ex> fault; a <ex>petty</ex>
prince.</as></def>

<au>Denham.</au>

<q>Like a <qex>petty</qex> god
I walked about, admired of all.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><col>Petty averages</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Average</er>.</cd> -- <col>Petty cash</col>, <cd>money
expended or received in small items or amounts.</cd> --
<col>Petty officer</col>, <cd>a subofficer in the navy, as a
gunner, etc., corresponding to a noncommissionned officer in the
army.</cd></cs>

<note><hand/ For <xex>petty constable</xex>, <xex>petty
jury</xex>, <xex>petty larceny</xex>, <xex>petty treason</xex>,
See <er>Petit</er>.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Little; diminutive; inconsiderable; inferior;
trifling; trivial; unimportant; frivolous.</syn>

<-- p. 1074 -->

<mhw>{ <hw>Pet"u*lance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pet"u*lan*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>petulania</ets>: cf. F. <ets>p\'82tulance</ets>. See
<er>Petulant</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of being
petulant; temporary peevishness; pettishness; capricious ill
humor.</def> \'bdThe <xex>petulancy</xex> of our words.\'b8

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<q>Like pride in some, and like <qex>petulance</qex> in
others.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q>The lowering eye, the <qex>petulance</qex>, the frown.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Petulance</er>, <er>Peevishness</er>. --
<xex>Peevishness</xex> implies the permanence of a sour, fretful
temper; <xex>petulance</xex> implies temporary or capricious
irritation.</syn>

<hw>Pet"u*lant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>petulans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, prop., making slight
attacks upon, from a lost dim. of <ets>petere</ets> to fall upon,
to attack: cf. F. <ets>p\'82tulant</ets>. See
<er>Petition</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Forward; pert;
insolent; wanton.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Burton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capriciously fretful; characterized by
ill-natured freakishness; irritable.</def>
\'bd<xex>Petulant</xex> moods.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Irritable; ill-humored; peevish; cross; fretful;
querulous.</syn>

<hw>Pe*tu"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.

genus of solanaceous herbs with funnelform or salver-shaped
corollas. Two species are common in cultivation, <xex>Petunia
violacera</xex>, with reddish purple flowers, and <xex>P</xex>.
<xex>nyctaginiflora</xex>, with white flowers. There are also
many hybrid forms with variegated corollas.</def>

<hw>Peu"cil</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ pine
tree.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A liquid resembling

<hw>Pew</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pewe</ets>, OF. <ets>puie</ets> parapet, balustrade,
balcony, fr. L. <ets>podium</ets> an elevated place, a jutty,
balcony, a parapet or balcony in the circus, where the emperor
and other distinguished persons sat, Gr. <?/, dim. of <?/, <?/,
foot; -- hence the Latin sense of a raised place (orig. as a rest
or support for the foot). See <er>Foot</er>, and cf.
<er>Podium</er>, <er>Poy</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the
compartments in a church which are separated by low partitions,
and have long seats upon which several persons may sit; --
sometimes called <altname>slip</altname>. Pews were originally
made square, but are now usually long and narrow.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any structure shaped like a church pew, as a
stall, formerly used by money lenders, etc.; a box in theater; a
pen; a sheepfold.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Pepys. Milton.</au>

<cs><col>Pew opener</col>, <cd>an usher in a church.
<mark>[Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Dickens.</au>

<hw>Pew</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To furnish with pews.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Ash.</au>

<hw>Pe"wee</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called from

American tyrant flycatcher (<spn>Sayornis ph\'d2be</spn>, or
<spn>S. fuscus</spn>). Called also <altname>pewit</altname>, and
<altname>ph\'d2be</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The woodcock.</def> <mark>[Local, U.S.]</mark>

<cs><col>Wood pewee</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a bird
(<spn>Contopus virens</spn>) similar to the pewee (See

<hw>Pew"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pewtyr</ets>, OF. <ets>peutre</ets>, <ets>peautre</ets>,
<ets>piautre</ets>: cf. D. <ets>peauter</ets>,
<ets>piauter</ets>, It. <ets>peltro</ets>, Sp. & Pg.
<ets>peltre</ets>, LL. <ets>peutreum</ets>, <ets>pestrum</ets>.
Cf. <er>Spelter</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A hard, tough, but
easily fusible, alloy, originally consisting of tin with a little
lead, but afterwards modified by the addition of copper,
antimony, or bismuth.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Utensils or vessels made of pewter, as dishes,
porringers, drinking vessels, tankards, pots.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pewter</xex> was formerly much used for
domestic utensils. Inferior sorts contain a large proportion of
lead.</note>

<hw>Pew"ter*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One whose
occupation is to make utensils of pewter; a pewtersmith.</def>

<hw>Pey"er's glands`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[So called from
J.K.<ets>Peyer</ets>, who described them in 1677.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Pathches of lymphoid nodules, in the
walls of the small intestiness; agminated glands; -- called also
<altname>Peyer's patches</altname>. In typhoid fever they become
the seat of ulcers which are regarded as the characteristic
organic lesion of that disease.</def>

<hw>Pey"trel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.

<hw>Ph\'91"o*spore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

brownish zo\'94spore, characteristic of an order
(<spn>Ph\'91ospore\'91</spn>) of dark green or olive-colored
alg\'91.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Ph\'91`o*spor"ic</wf>
<pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pha"\'89*thon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
Pha\'89thon (in sense 1), fr. Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, <?/, to shine.
See <er>Phantom</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Class.
Myth.)</fld> <def>The son of Helios (Ph\'d2bus), that is, the son
of light, or of the sun. He is fabled to have obtained permission
to drive the chariot of the sun, in doing which his want of skill
would have set the world on fire, had he not been struck with a
thunderbolt by Jupiter, and hurled headlong into the river
Po.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of oceanic birds
including the tropic birds.</def>

<hw>Pha"\'89*ton</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pha\'82ton</ets> a kind of carriage, fr.
<ets>Pha\'82thon</ets> Pha\'89thon, the son of Helios. See
<er>Pha\'89thon</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A four-wheeled
carriage (with or without a top), open, or having no side pieces,
in front of the seat. It is drawn by one or two horses.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>See <er>Pha\'89thon</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A handsome American
butterfly (<spn>Euphydryas, <or/ Melit\'91a, Pha\'89ton</spn>).
The upper side of the wings is black, with orange-red spots and
marginal crescents, and several rows of cream-colored spots; --
called also <altname>Baltimore</altname>.</def>

<ets>phagedaena</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to eat.]</ety>

<hw>\'d8Phal`an*goi"de*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from <ets>Phalangium</ets> the daddy longlegs (see
<er>Phalangious</er>) + Gr. <?/ form.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A division of Arachnoidea, including
the daddy longlegs or harvestman (<spn>Phalangium</spn>) and many
similar kinds. They have long, slender, many-jointed legs;
usually a rounded, segmented abdomen; and chelate jaws. They
breathe by trache\'91. Called also
<altname><spn>Phalangides</spn></altname>,
<altname><spn>Phalangidea</spn></altname>,
<altname><spn>Phalangiida</spn></altname>, and
<altname><spn>Opilionea</spn></altname>.</def>

<hw>Phal"an*ster*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>-ies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>phalanst\'8are</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/ a phalanx + <?/ firm,
solid.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An association or community

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The dwelling house of a Fourierite
community.</def>

<hw>Pha"lanx</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Phalanxes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, L. <plw>Phalanges</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., from Gr. <?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld> <def>A body of heavy-armed infantry
formed in ranks and files close and deep. There were several
different arrangements, the phalanx varying in depth from four to
twenty-five or more ranks of men.</def> \'bdIn cubic
<xex>phalanx</xex> firm advanced.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The Grecian <qex>phalanx</qex>, moveless as a tower.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any body of troops or men formed in close array,
or any combination of people distinguished for firmness and
solidity of a union.</def>

<q>At present they formed a united <qex>phalanx</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<q>The sheep recumbent, and the sheep that grazed,
All huddling into <qex>phalanx</qex>, stood and gazed.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A Fourierite community; a phalanstery.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>One of the digital bones of
the hand or foot, beyond the metacarpus or metatarsus; an
internode.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <ety>[<ets>pl</ets>. <er>Phalanges</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A group or bundle of stamens, as in
polyadelphous flowers.</def>

<hw>Phan"tasm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>phantasma</ets>. See <er>Phantom</er>, and cf.
<er>Fantasm</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Spelt also
<asp>fantasm</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An image formed by
the mind, and supposed to be real or material; a shadowy or airy
appearance; sometimes, an optical illusion; a phantom; a
dream.</def>

<q>They be but <qex>phantasms</qex> or apparitions.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A mental image or representation of a real
object; a fancy; a notion.</def>

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<q>Figures or little features, of which the description had
produced in you no <qex>phantasm</qex> or expectation.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Phan"tas"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>A phantasm.</def>

<hw>Phan*tas`ma*go"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/ a phantasm + <?/ an assembly, fr. <?/ to
gather: cf. F. <ets>phantasmagorie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>An optical effect produced by a magic lantern. The figures
are painted in transparent colors, and all the rest of the glass
is opaque black. The screen is between the spectators and the
instrument, and the figures are often made to appear as in
motion, or to merge into one another.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The apparatus by which such an effect is
produced.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: A medley of figures; illusive
images.</def> \'bdThis mental <xex>phantasmagoria</xex>.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Phan*tas`ma*go"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Of, relating to, or resembling phantasmagoria;
phantasmagoric.</def>

<hw>Phan*tas`ma*gor"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to phantasmagoria; phantasmagorial.</def>

<au>Hawthorne.</au>

<er>Phantasmagoria</er>.</def>

<hw>Phan"tom</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

simulating an actual tumor in appearance, but disappearing upon
the administration of an an\'91sthetic.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Phar`i*sa"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Phar`i*sa"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>Pharisaicus</ets>, Gr. <?/: cf. F.
<ets>pharisa\'8bque</ets>. See <er>Pharisee</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the Pharisees; resembling
the Pharisees.</def> \'bdThe <xex>Pharisaic</xex> sect among the
Jews.\'b8

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Addicted to external forms and
ceremonies; making a show of religion without the spirit of it;
ceremonial; formal; hypocritical; self-righteous. \'bdExcess of
outward and <xex>pharisaical</xex> holiness.</def> \'b8
<au>Bacon</au>. \'bd<xex>Pharisaical</xex> ostentation.\'b8
<au>Macaulay</au>.

<wf>Phar`i*sa"ic*al*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Phar`i*sa"ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pharisaisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The notions,
doctrines, and conduct of the Pharisees, as a sect.</def>

<au>Sharp.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Rigid observance of external forms of religion,
without genuine piety; hypocrisy in religion; a censorious,
self-righteous spirit in matters of morals or manners.</def>
\'bdA piece of <xex>pharisaism</xex>.\'b8

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>Phar`i*se"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Pharisaeus</ets>, Gr. <?/.]</ety> <def>Following the
practice of Pharisees; Pharisaic.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Pharisean</xex> disciples.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Phar"i*see</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Pharisaeus</ets>, Gr. <?/, from Heb. <ets>p\'berash</ets> to
separate.]</ety> <def>One of a sect or party among the Jews,
noted for a strict and formal observance of rites and ceremonies
and of the traditions of the elders, and whose pretensions to
superior sanctity led them to separate themselves from the other
Jews.</def>

<hw>Phar"i*see*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pharisaism</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Phar`ma*cue"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,

preparations</as>.</def> --

<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

chemistry which ascertains or regulates the composition of
medicinal substances.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phar"ynx</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

openings in fishes and some amphibias.</def>

<hw>Phase</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Phases</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.
<ets>phasis</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to make to appear: cf. F.
<ets>phase</ets>. See <er>Phenomenon</er>, <er>Phantom</er>, and
<er>Emphasis</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
exhibited to the eye; the appearance which anything manifests,
especially any one among different and varying appearances of the
same object.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any appearance or aspect of an object of mental
apprehension or view; <as>as, the problem has many
<ex>phases</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A particular appearance or
state in a regularly recurring cycle of changes with respect to
quantity of illumination or form of enlightened disk; <as>as, the
<ex>phases</ex> of the moon or planets</as>. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. under <er>Moon</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Any one point or portion in
a recurring series of changes, as in the changes of motion of one
of the particles constituting a wave or vibration; one portion of
a series of such changes, in distinction from a contrasted
portion, as the portion on one side of a position of equilibrium,
in contrast with that on the opposite side.</def>

<hw>Pheas"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>fesant</ets>, <ets>fesaunt</ets>, OF. <ets>faisant</ets>,
<ets>faisan</ets>, F. <ets>faisan</ets>, L. <ets>phasianus</ets>,
Gr. <?/ (sc. <?/) the Phasian bird, pheasant, fr. <?/ a river in
Colchis or Pontus.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any one of numerous species of large gallinaceous birds of
the genus <spn>Phasianus</spn>, and many other genera of the
family <spn>Phasianid\'91</spn>, found chiefly in Asia.</def>

<-- # note collocations in notes have italic font in WEB1913 -->
<note><hand/ The <col>common, <or/ English, pheasant</col>
(<spn>Phasianus Colchicus</spn>) is now found over most of
temperate Europe, but was introduced from Asia. The
<col>ring-necked pheasant</col> (<spn>P. torquatus</spn>) and the
<col>green pheasant</col> (<spn>P. versicolor</spn>) have been
introduced into Oregon. The <col>golden pheasant</col>
(<spn>Thaumalea picta</spn>) is one of the most beautiful
species. The <col>silver pheasant</col> (<spn>Euplocamus
nychthemerus</spn>) of China, and several related species from
Southern Asia, are very beautiful.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The ruffed grouse.</def>
<mark>[Southern U.S.]</mark>

<note><hand/ Various other birds are locally called
<xex>pheasants</xex>, as the lyre bird, the leipoa, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Fireback pheasant</col>. <cd>See <er>Fireback</er>.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Gold</col>, <or/ <col>Golden</col>,
<col>pheasant</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a Chinese
pheasant (<spn>Thaumalea picta</spn>), having rich, varied
colors. The crest is amber-colored, the rump is golden yellow,
and the under parts are scarlet.</cd> -- <col>Mountain
pheasant</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the ruffed grouse.</cd>
<mark>[Local, U.S.]</mark> -- <col>Pheasant coucal</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large Australian cuckoo
(<spn>Centropus phasianus</spn>). The general color is black,
with chestnut wings and brown tail. Called also <altname>pheasant
cuckoo</altname>. The name is also applied to other allied
species.</cd> -- <col>Pheasant duck</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The pintail</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The hooded
merganser.</cd> -- <col>Pheasant parrot</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large and beautiful Australian
parrakeet (<spn>Platycercus Adelaidensis</spn>). The male has the
back black, the feathers margined with yellowish blue and
scarlet, the quills deep blue, the wing coverts and cheeks light
blue, the crown, sides of the neck, breast, and middle of the
belly scarlet.</cd> -- <col>Pheasant's eye</col>.
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A red-flowered herb
(<spn>Adonis autumnalis</spn>) of the Crowfoot family; -- called
also <altname>pheasant's-eye Adonis</altname>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The garden pink (<spn>Dianthus plumarius</spn>); -- called
also <altname>Pheasant's-eye pink</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Pheasant shell</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any marine
univalve shell of the genus <spn>Phasianella</spn>, of which
numerous species are found in tropical seas. The shell is smooth
and usually richly colored, the colors often forming blotches
like those of a pheasant.</cd> -- <col>Pheasant wood</col>.
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>Same as <cref>Partridge wood</cref>
<sd>(a)</sd>, under <er>Partridge</er>.</cd> -- <col>Sea
pheasant</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the pintail.</cd> --
<col>Water pheasant</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The sheldrake</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The hooded
merganser.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phen"a*cite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, impostor, deceiver.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A glassy

used as a gem.  It is a silicate of glucina, and receives its
name from its deceptive similarity to quartz.</def>

<hw>Phen`a*kis"to*scope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <?/ a deceiver + <ets>-scope</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
revolving disk on which figures drawn in different relative
attitudes are seen successively, so as to produce the appearance
of an object in actual motion, as an animal leaping, etc., in
consequence of the persistence of the successive visual
impressions of the retina. It is often arranged so that the
figures may be projected upon a screen.</def>

<hw>Phe*nan"threne</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A complex hydrocarbon,
<chform>C14H10</chform>, found in coal tar, and obtained as a
white crystalline substance with a bluish fluorescence.</def>

<hw>Phe*nan"thri*dine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Phe*nan"thro*line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Phen"i*cine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.

<hw>Phen`i*cop"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Phe"nix</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Phenixes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>phoenix</ets>, Gr. <grk>foi^nix</grk>.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>ph\'d2nix</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Gr. Myth.)</fld> <def>A bird fabled to exist single, to be
consumed by fire by its own act, and to rise again from its
ashes.  Hence, an emblem of immortality.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A southern
constellation.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A marvelous person or thing.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Latimer.</au>

<-- rise like a phoenix, to resume an endeavor after an
apparently final defeat -->

<hw>\'d8Phen`o*ga"mi*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Ph\'91nogamia</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Phen`o*ga"mi*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Phen`o*gam"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Phe*nog"a*mous</hw>

<hw>Phe"nol</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ to
show + <ets>-ol</ets>: cf. F. <ets>ph\'82nol</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A white or pinkish
crystalline substance, <chform>C6H5OH</chform>, produced by the
destructive distillation of many organic bodies, as wood, coal,
etc., and obtained from the heavy oil from coal tar.</def>

<note><hand/ It has a peculiar odor, somewhat resembling
creosote, which is a complex mixture of phenol derivatives. It is
of the type of alcohols, and is called also <altname>phenyl
alcohol</altname>, but has acid properties, and hence is
popularly called <altname>carbolic acid</altname>, and was
formerly called <altname>phenic acid</altname>. It is a powerful
caustic poison, and in dilute solution has been used as an
antiseptic.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any one of the series of hydroxyl derivatives of
which phenol proper is the type.</def>

<cs><col>Glacial phenol</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>pure
crystallized phenol or carbolic acid.</cd> -- <col>Phenol
acid</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>any one of a series of
compounds which are at once derivatives of both phenol and some
member of the fatty acid series; thus, salicylic acid is a
<xex>phenol acid<xex>.</cd><-- s.a. is not a fatty acid, but a
benzoic acid derivative.  IT should say "carboxylic acid" --> --
<col>Phenol alcohol</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>any one of
series of derivatives of phenol and carbinol which have the
properties of both combined; thus, saligenin is a <xex>phenol
alcohol<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Phenol aldehyde</col>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>any one of a series of compounds having
both phenol and aldehyde properties.</cd> -- <col>Phenol
phthalein</col>. <cd>See under <er>Phthalein</er>.</cd></cs>

<ety>[<ets>Phenol</ets> + <ets>-ate</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A compound of phenol analogous to a

<hw>Phe"nyl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ to

<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A hydrocarbon radical

derivatives.</def>

<cs><col>Phenyl hydrate</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>phenol or

<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a nitrogenous base
(<chform>C6H5.N2H3</chform>) produced artificially as a colorless
oil which unites with acids, ketones, etc., to form
well-crystallized compounds.</cd></cs>

<-- (2) active effort to promote human welfare; humanitarian

<-- 2. an organization whose purpose is to engage in
philanthropy(2), and is supported by funds from one or a small
number of wealthy individuals; a type of charity, the source of
whose funds is typically from a wealthy individual or a
corporation, or a trust fund established by a wealthy individual. 
It is distinguished from other charitable organizations in that
the source of funds of other charities may come from a large
number of sources, or from public solicitation. -->

<hw>Phil"o*logue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>philologue</ets>.]</ety> <def>A philologist.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<hw>Phi*lol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>philologia</ets> love of learning, interpretation,
philology, Gr. <?/: cf. F. <ets>philologie</ets>. See
<er>Philologer</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Criticism;
grammatical learning.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The study of language, especially in a
philosophical manner and as a science; the investigation of the
laws of human speech, the relation of different tongues to one
another, and historical development of languages; linguistic
science.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Philology</xex> comprehends a knowledge of the
etymology, or origin and combination of words; grammar, the
construction of sentences, or use of words in language;
criticism, the interpretation of authors, the affinities of
different languages, and whatever relates to the history or
present state of languages. It sometimes includes rhetoric,
poetry, history, and antiquities.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A treatise on the science of language.</def>

<-- p. 1077 -->

<hw>Phil`o*pe"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably
a corruption fr. G. <ets>vielliebchen</ets>, LG.
<ets>vielliebken</ets>, or D. <ets>veelliebken</ets>, a
philopena, literally, much loved; but influenced by Gr. <?/ a
friend, and L. <ets>poena</ets> penalty, from an idea that the
gift was a penalty of friendship or love.]</ety> <def>A present
or gift which is made as a forfeit in a social game that is
played in various ways; also, the game itself.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>fillipeen</asp> and
<asp>phillippine</asp>.]</altsp>

<note><hand/ One of the ways may be stated as follows: A person
finding a nut with two kernels eats one, and gives the other to a
person of the opposite sex, and then whichever says
<xex>philopena</xex> first at the next meeting wins the present.
The name is also applied to the kernels eaten.</note>

Grecian myths, is a <qex>philosopheme</qex>.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>Phi*los"o*pher</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>philosophre</ets>, F. <ets>philosophe</ets>, L.
<ets>philosophus</ets>, Gr. <?/; <?/ loving + <?/ wise. Cf.

philosophizes; one versed in, or devoted to, philosophy.</def>

<q>Then certain <qex>philosophers</qex> of the Epicureans, and of

<qau>Acts xvii. 18.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who reduces the principles of philosophy to
practice in the conduct of life; one who lives according to the
rules of practical wisdom; one who meets or regards all
vicissitudes with calmness.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An alchemist.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<cs><col>Philosopher's stone</col>, <cd>an imaginary stone which
the alchemists formerly sought as instrument of converting the
baser metals into gold.</cd></cs>

<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Phi*los"o*phize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Philosophized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Philosophizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To reason like a philosopher; to
search into the reason and nature of things; to investigate
phenomena, and assign rational causes for their existence.</def>

<q>Man <qex>philosophizes</qex> as he lives. He may
<qex>philosophize</qex> well or ill, but <qex>philosophize</qex>
he must.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<hw>Phi*los"o*phi`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who philosophizes.</def>

<hw>Phi*los"o*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Philosophies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>philosophie</ets>, F. <ets>philosophie</ets>, L.
<ets>philosophia</ets>, from Gr. <?/. See
<er>Philosopher</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Literally, the love
of, including the search after, wisdom; in actual usage, the
knowledge of phenomena as explained by, and resolved into, causes
and reasons, powers and laws.</def>

<note><hand/ When applied to any particular department of
knowledge, <xex>philosophy</xex> denotes the general laws or
principles under which all the subordinate phenomena or facts
relating to that subject are comprehended. Thus
<xex>philosophy</xex>, when applied to God and the divine
government, is called <xex>theology</xex>; when applied to
material objects, it is called <xex>physics</xex>; when it treats
of man, it is called <xex>anthropology</xex> and
<xex>psychology</xex>, with which are connected <xex>logic</xex>
and <xex>ethics</xex>; when it treats of the necessary
conceptions and relations by which <xex>philosophy</xex> is
possible, it is called <xex>metaphysics</xex>.</note>

<note><hand/ \'bd<xex>Philosophy</xex> has been defined:
tionscience of things divine and human, and the causes in which
they are contained; -- the science of effects by their causes; --
the science of sufficient reasons; -- the science of things
possible, inasmuch as they are possible; -- the science of things
evidently deduced from first principles; -- the science of truths
sensible and abstract; -- the application of reason to its
legitimate objects; -- the science of the relations of all
knowledge to the necessary ends of human reason; -- the science
of the original form of the ego, or mental self; -- the science
of science; -- the science of the absolute; -- the scienceof the
absolute indifference of the ideal and real.\'b8</note>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A particular philosophical system or theory; the
hypothesis by which particular phenomena are explained.</def>

<q>[Books] of Aristotle and his <qex>philosophie</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>We shall in vain interpret their words by the notions of our
<qex>philosophy</qex> and the doctrines in our school.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Practical wisdom; calmness of temper and
judgment; equanimity; fortitude; stoicism; <as>as, to meet
misfortune with <ex>philosophy</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Then had he spent all his <qex>philosophy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Reasoning; argumentation.</def>

<q>Of good and evil much they argued then, . . . 
Vain wisdom all, and false <qex>philosophy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The course of sciences read in the
schools.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A treatise on philosophy.</def>

<cs><col>Philosophy of the Academy</col>, <cd>that of Plato, who
taught his disciples in a grove in Athens called the
Academy.</cd> -- <col>Philosophy of the Garden</col>, <cd>that of
Epicurus, who taught in a garden in Athens.</cd> --
<col>Philosophy of the Lyceum</col>, <cd>that of Aristotle, the
founder of the Peripatetic school, who delivered his lectures in
the Lyceum at Athens.</cd> -- <col>Philosophy of the Porch</col>,
<cd>that of Zeno and the Stoics; -- so called because Zeno of
Citium and his successors taught in the porch of the Poicile, a
great hall in Athens.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phlegm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>phlegme</ets>, <ets>flegme</ets>, L. <ets>phlegma</ets>, fr.
Gr. <?/ a flame, inflammation, phlegm, a morbid, clammy humor in
the body, fr. <?/ to burn. Cf. <er>Phlox</er>, <er>Flagrant</er>,
<er>Flame</er>, <er>Bleak</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and
<er>Fluminate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the four
humors of which the ancients supposed the blood to be composed.
See <er>Humor</er>.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Viscid mucus secreted in
abnormal quantity in the respiratory and digestive
passages.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <def>A watery distilled
liquor, in distinction from a spirituous liquor.</def>

<au>Crabb.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Sluggishness of temperament; dullness; want of
interest; indifference; coldness.</def>

<q>They judge with fury, but they write with
<qex>phlegm</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Phlo*gis"tian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
believer in the existence of phlogiston.</def>

<hw>Phlo*gis"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to phlogiston, or to
belief in its existence.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Inflammatory; belonging to
inflammations and fevers.</def>

<hw>Phlo*gis"tic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Old
Chem.)</fld> <def>Phlogistic.</def>

<hw>Phlo*gis"ti*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Phlogisticated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Phlogisticating</er>.]</wordforms> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>
<def>To combine phlogiston with; -- usually in the form and sense
of the <pos>p. p.</pos> or the <pos>adj.</pos>; <as>as, highly
<ex>phlogisticated</ex> substances</as>.</def>

<hw>Phlo*gis`ti*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <def>The act or process of combining with
phlogiston.</def>

<hw>Phlo*gis"ton</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ burnt, set on fire, fr. <?/ to set on fire, to burn, fr.
<?/, <?/, a flame, blaze. See <er>Phlox</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Old
Chem.)</fld> <def>The hypothetical principle of fire, or
inflammability, regarded by Stahl as a chemical element.</def>

<note><hand/ This was supposed to be united with combustible
(<xex>phlogisticated</xex>) bodies and to be separated from
incombustible (<xex>dephlogisticated</xex>) bodies, the phenomena
of flame and burning being the escape of phlogiston. Soot and
sulphur were regarded as nearly pure phlogiston.  The essential
principle of this theory was, that combustion was a decomposition
rather than the union and combination which it has since been
shown to be.</note>
<-- this theory is now discredited and superseded by the theory
of chemical reaction between oxidizable substances and oxidants
as an explanation of combustion -->

<hw>Phlo*gog"e*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/, <?/ fire + <ets>-genous</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>Causing inflammation.</def>

<hw>Phlog"o*pite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
firelike.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A kind of mica having
generally a peculiar bronze-red or copperlike color and a pearly
luster. It is a silicate of aluminia, with magnesia, potash, and
some fluorine. It is characteristic of crystalline limestone or
dolomite and serpentine. See <er>Mica</er>.</def>

<hw>Pho*nau"to*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phono-</ets> + Gr. <?/ self +
<ets>-graph</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>An instrument
by means of which a sound can be made to produce a visible trace
or record of itself. It consists essentially of a resonant
vessel, usually of paraboloidal form, closed at one end by a
flexible membrane. A stylus attached to some point of the
membrane records the movements of the latter, as it vibrates,
upon a moving cylinder or plate.</def>

<hw>Pho*nei"do*scope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phono-</ets> + Gr. <?/ form +
<ets>-scope</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>An instrument
for studying the motions of sounding bodies by optical means. It
consists of a tube across the end of which is stretched a film of
soap solution thin enough to give colored bands, the form and
position of which are affected by sonorous vibrations.</def>

<hw>Pho*net"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/ a sound, tone; akin to Gr. <?/ to speak: cf. F.
<ets>phon\'82tique</ets>. See <er>Ban</er> a proclamation.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the voice, or its use.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Representing sounds; <as>as, <ex>phonetic</ex>
characters</as>; -- opposed to <contr>ideographic</contr>;
<as>as, a <ex>phonetic</ex> notation</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Phonetic spelling</col>, <cd>spelling in phonetic
characters, each representing one sound only; -- contrasted with
<xex>Romanic spelling<xex>, or that by the use of the Roman
alphabet.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pho`no*camp"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phono-</ets> + Gr. <?/ to bend: cf. F.

<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Phonocamptic</xex> objects.\'b8

<au>Derham.</au>

<hw>Pho"no*gram</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phono-</ets> + <ets>-gram</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A letter, character, or mark used to represent a particular
sound.</def>

<q><qex>Phonograms</qex> are of three kinds: (1) Verbal signs,
which stand for entire words; (2) Syllabic signs, which stand for
the articulations of which words are composed; (3) Alphabetic
signs, or letters, which represent the elementary sounds into
which the syllable can be resolved.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor (The Alphabet).</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A record of sounds made by a phonograph.</def>

<hw>Pho"no*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phono-</ets> + <ets>-graph</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A character or symbol used to represent a sound, esp. one
used in phonography.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>An instrument for the
mechanical registration and reproduction of audible sounds, as
articulate speech, etc. It consists of a rotating cylinder or
disk covered with some material easily indented, as tinfoil, wax,
paraffin, etc., above which is a thin plate carrying a stylus. As
the plate vibrates under the influence of a sound, the stylus
makes minute indentations or undulations in the soft material,
and these, when the cylinder or disk is again turned, set the
plate in vibration, and reproduce the sound.</def>

<hw>Pho*nog"ra*pher</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One versed or skilled in phonography.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who uses, or is skilled in the use of, the
phonograph. See <er>Phonograph</er>, 2.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pho`no*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pho`no*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>phonographique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to phonography; based upon
phonography.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to phonograph; done by the
phonograph.</def>

<hw>Pho`no*graph"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
phonographic manner; by means of phonograph.</def>

<hw>Pho*nog"ra*phist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Phonographer.</def>

<hw>Pho*nog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phono-</ets> + <ets>-graphy</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A description of the laws of the human voice, or sounds
uttered by the organs of speech.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A representation of sounds by distinctive
characters; commonly, a system of shorthand writing invented by
Isaac Pitman, or a modification of his system, much used by
reporters.</def>

<note><hand/ The consonants are represented by straight lines and
curves; the vowels by dots and short dashes; but by skilled
phonographers, in rapid work, most vowel marks are omitted, and
brief symbols for common words and combinations of words are
extensively employed. The following line is an example of
phonography, in which all the sounds are indicated: --

<-- illustr. of phonetic transcription of the line below -->

<q>They also serve who only stand and wait.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>
</note>
<sn>3.</sn> <def>The art of constructing, or using, the
phonograph.</def>

<hw>Phos"gene</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<hw>Phos"gen*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A rare mineral occurring in tetragonal

<hw>Phos"pham</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>\'d8Phos`pha*tu"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Phos"phene</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
light + <?/ to show.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A luminous
impression produced through excitation of the retina by some
cause other than the impingement upon it of rays of light, as by
pressure upon the eyeball when the lids are closed. Cf.
<er>After-image</er>.</def>

<hw>Phos"phide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A binary compound of phosphorus.</def>

<hw>Phos"phine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A colorless gas, <chform>PH3</chform>,
analogous to ammonia, and having a disagreeable odor resembling
that of garlic. Called also <altname>hydrogen
phosphide</altname>, and formerly, <altname>phosphureted
hydrogen</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ It is the most important compound of phosphorus and
hydrogen, and is produced by the action of caustic potash on
phosphorus. It is spontaneously inflammable, owing to impurities,
and in burning produces peculiar vortical rings of smoke.</note>

<hw>Phos*phin"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, certain
acids analogous to the phosphonic acids, but containing two
hydrocarbon radicals, and derived from the secondary phosphines
by oxidation.</def>

<hw>Phos"phite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A salt of phosphorous acid.</def>

<hw>Phos*phon"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, certain

nucleus of certain derivatives of phosphine.</def>

<hw>Phos"phor-bronze`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phosphor</ets> + <ets>bronze</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Metal.)</fld> <def>A variety of bronze possessing great
hardness, elasticity, and toughness, obtained by melting copper
with tin phosphide. It contains one or two per cent of phosphorus
and from five to fifteen per cent of tin.</def>

<hw>Phos*phor"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>phosphorique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>(<xex>Chem</xex>.) Of or pertaining to phosphorus;

contrasted with the <xex>phosphorous</xex> compounds.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Phosphorescent.</def> \'bdA
<xex>phosphoric</xex> sea.\'b8

<au>Byron.</au>

<cs><col>Glacial phosphoric acid</col>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Metaphosphoric acid in the form of glassy
semitransparent masses or sticks</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Pure
normal phosphoric acid.</cd> -- <col>Phosphoric acid</col>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a white crystalline substance,
<chform>H3PO4</chform>, which is the most highly oxidized acid of
phosphorus, and forms an important and extensive series of
compounds, viz., the phosphates.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Soluble
phosphoric acid</col>, <col>Insoluble phosphoric
acid</col></mcol> <fld>(Agric. Chem.)</fld>, <cd>phosphoric acid
combined in acid salts, or in neutral or basic salts, which are
respectively soluble and insoluble in water or in plant
juices.</cd> -- <col>Reverted phosphoric acid</col> <fld>(Agric.
Chem.)</fld>, <cd>phosphoric acid changed from acid (soluble)
salts back to neutral or basic (insoluble) salts.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phos"phor*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>phosphoreux</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Of or

<hw>Phos"phor*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Phosphori</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., the morning
star, Gr. <?/, lit., light bringer; <?/ light + <?/ to
bring.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The morning star; Phosphor.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A poisonous nonmetallic
element of the nitrogen group, obtained as a white, or yellowish,
translucent waxy substance, having a characteristic disagreeable
smell. It is very active chemically, must be preserved under
water, and unites with oxygen even at ordinary temperatures,
giving a faint glow, -- whence its name. It always occurs
compined, usually in phosphates, as in the mineral apatite, in
bones, etc. It is used in the composition on the tips of friction
matches, and for many other purposes. The molecule contains four
atoms. Symbol P. Atomic weight 31.0.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Hence, any substance which
shines in the dark like phosphorus, as certain phosphorescent
bodies.</def>

<cs><col>Bologna phosphorus</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>,
<cd>sulphide of barium, which shines in the dark after exposure
to light; -- so called because this property was discovered by a
resident of <xex>Bologna<xex>. The term is sometimes applied to
other compounds having similar properties.</cd> -- <col>Metallic
phosphorus</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>an allotropic
modification of phosphorus, obtained as a gray metallic
crystalline substance, having very inert chemical properties. It
is obtained by heating ordinary phosphorus in a closed vessel at
a high temperature.</cd> -- <col>Phosphorus disease</col>
<fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a disease common among workers in
phosphorus, giving rise to necrosis of the jawbone, and other
symptoms.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Red, <or/ Amorphous</col>,
<col>phosphorus</col></mcol> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>an
allotropic modification of phosphorus, obtained as a dark red
powder by heating ordinary phosphorus in closed vessels. It is
not poisonous, is not phosphorescent, and is only moderately
active chemically. It is valuable as a chemical reagent, and is
used in the composition of the friction surface on which safety
matches are ignited.</cd> -- <col>Solar phosphori</col>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>phosphorescent substances which shine in
the dark after exposure to the sunlight or other intense
light.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1079 -->

<hw>Pho"to*drome</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Photo-</ets> + Gr. <?/ to run.]</ety>
<fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>An apparatus consisting of a large
wheel with spokes, which when turning very rapidly is illuminated
by momentary flashes of light passing through slits in a rotating
disk.  By properly timing the succession of flashes the wheel is
made to appear to be motionless, or to rotate more or less slowly
in either direction.</def>

<hw>Pho"to*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Photo-</ets> + <ets>-graph</ets>.]</ety> <def>A

<hw>Pho"to*graph</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &
p. p.</pos> <er>Photographed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Photographing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>
<def>To take a picture or likeness of by means of photography;
<as>as, to <ex>photograph</ex> a view; to <ex>photograph</ex> a
group.</as></def>

<q>He makes his pen drawing on white paper, and they are
afterwards <qex>photographed</qex> on wood.</q>
<qau>Hamerton.</qau>

<note>Also used figuratively.</note>

<q>He is <qex>photographed</qex> on my mind.</q>
<qau>Lady D. Hardy.</qau>

photography; to take photographs.</def>

<hw>Pho*tog"ra*phist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A

<hw>Pho*tog"ra*phom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Photograph</ets> + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Photog.)</fld> <def>An instrument for determining the
sensibility of the plates employed in photographic processes to
luminous rays.</def>

<hw>Pho*tog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Photo-</ets> + <ets>-graphy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>photographie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The science
which relates to the action of light on sensitive bodies in the
production of pictures, the fixation of images, and the
like.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The art or process of producing pictures by this
action of light.</def>

<note><hand/ The well-focused optical image is thrown on a
surface of metal, glass, paper, or other suitable substance,
coated with collodion or gelatin, and sensitized with the
chlorides, bromides, or iodides of silver, or other salts
sensitive to light. The exposed plate is then treated with
reducing agents, as pyrogallic acid, ferrous sulphate, etc., to
develop the latent image. The image is then fixed by washing off
the excess of unchanged sensitive salt with sodium hyposulphite
(<xex>thiosulphate</xex>) or other suitable reagents.</note>

<-- color photography, the production of colored images by a
photographic process.  A variety of dyes are used to produced the
colored images.  Processes may or may not use silver to produce
the colored image. -->

<hw>Pho`to*grav"ure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>A photoengraving; also, the process by which
such a picture is produced.</def>

<hw>Pho`to*he"li*o*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Photo-</ets> + <ets>heliograph</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>A modified kind of telescope adapted to
taking photographs of the sun.</def>

<hw>Pho`to*lith"o*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Photo-</ets> + <ets>lithograph</ets>.]</ety> <def>A

<hw>Pho`to*lith"o*graph</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To produce (a

photographically to a sensitive surface, and the surface
subsequently etched; used for printing or in the production of
integrated circuits. -->

<hw>Pho`to*mi"cro*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pho`to*pho"bi*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/, <?/, light + <?/ fear.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>A dread or intolerance of light.</def>

<au>Sir T. Watson.</au>
