<hw>Phras"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of the nature
of a phrase; consisting of a phrase; <as>as, a <ex>phrasal</ex>
adverb</as>.</def>

<au>Earlc.</au>

<hw>Phrase</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>phrasis</ets> diction, phraseology, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to
speak.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A brief expression, sometimes a
single word, but usually two or more words forming an expression
by themselves, or being a portion of a sentence; <as>as, an
adverbial <ex>phrase</ex></as>.</def>

<q>\'bdConvey\'b8 the wise it call. \'bdSteal!\'b8 foh! a fico
for the <qex>phrase</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A short, pithy expression; especially, one which
is often employed; a peculiar or idiomatic turn of speech;
<as>as, <ex>to err is human</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A mode or form of speech; the manner or style in
which any one expreses himself; diction; expression.</def>
\'bd<xex>Phrases</xex> of the hearth.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<q>Thou speak'st
In better <qex>phrase</qex> and matter than thou didst.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A short clause or portion of a
period.</def>

<note><hand/ A composition consists first of sentences, or
<xex>periods</xex>; these are subdivided into
<xex>sections</xex>, and these into <xex>phrases</xex>.</note>

<cs><col>Phrase book</col>, <cd>a book of idiomatic
phrases.</cd></cs>

<au>J. S. Blackie.</au>

<hw>Phrase</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Phrased</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Phrasing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>phraser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To express in words, or in
peculiar words; to call; to style.</def> \'bdThese suns -- for so
they <xex>phrase</xex> 'em.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Phrase</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To use proper
or fine phrases.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>To group notes into phrases;
<as>as, he <ex>phrases</ex> well</as>. See <er>Phrase</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 4.</def>

<hw>Phrase"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Indescribable.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Phre*nol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, the mind + <ets>-logy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>phr\'82nologie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The science of
the special functions of the several parts of the brain, or of
the supposed connection between the various faculties of the mind
and particular organs in the brain.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In popular usage, the physiological hypothesis
of Gall, that the mental faculties, and traits of character, are
shown on the surface of the head or skull; craniology.</def>
<-- considered pseudo-science by all reputable medical personnel,
but still believed by  -->

<note><hand/ Gall marked out on his model of the head the places
of twenty-six organs, as round inclosures with vacant
interspaces. Spurzheim and Combe divided the whole scalp into
oblong and conterminous patches.</note>

<au>Encyc. Brit.</au>

<-- Illustr. of a chart of phrenology, showing the areas of the
skull as "mapped" by Gall. -->

<cs><col>Phrygian mode</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>one of the
ancient Greek modes, very bold and vehement in style; -- so
called because fabled to have been invented by the
<xex>Phrygian<xex> Marsyas. <au>Moore (Encyc. of
Music)</au>.</cd> -- <col>Phrygian stone</col>, <cd>a light,
spongy stone, resembling a pumice, -- used by the ancients in
dyeing, and said to be drying and astringent.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phthal"ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A salt of phthalic acid.</def>

<hw>Phthal"e*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Phthalic</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a series
of artificial organic dyes made as condensation products of the
phenols with phthalic acid, and well represented by phenol
phthale\'8bn. Their alkaline solutions are fluorescent.</def>

<cs><col>Phenol phthalein</col>, <cd>a white or yellowish white
crystalline substance made from phthalic acid and phenol. Its
solution in alkalies is brilliant red, but is decolorized by
acids, and as this reaction is exceedingly delicate it is used as
an indicator.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phthal"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Na<ets>phthal</ets>ene + <ets>-ic</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or designating, a dibasic
acid obtained by the oxidation of naphthalene and allied
substances.</def>

<cs><col>Phthalic acid</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a white
crystalline substance, <chform>C6H4.(CO2H)2</chform>, analogous
to benzoic acid, and employed in the brilliant dyestuffs called
the phthaleins.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phthal"ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phthal</ets>yl + anhydr<ets>ide</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A lactone obtained by reduction of
phthalyl chloride, as a white crystalline substance; hence, by
extension, any one of the series of which phthalide proper is the
type.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>phthalid</asp>.]</altsp>
<-- phthalic anhydride? would be classed as an acid anhydride,
rather than a lactone.  Obtained commercially by a different
process. -->

<hw>Phthal"i*mide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phthal</ets>ic + <ets>imide</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An imido derivative of phthalic acid,
obtained as a white crystalline substance,
<chform>C6H4.(CO)2NH</chform>, which has itself (like
succinimide) acid properties, and forms a series of salts. Cf.
<xex>Imido acid</xex>, under <er>Imido</er>.</def>

<hw>Phthal"in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A colorless crystalline substance obtained by reduction from
phthale\'8bn, into which it is easily converted by oxidation;
hence, any one of the series of which phthalin proper is the
type.</def>

<hw>Phthal"yl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Phthal</ets>ic + <ets>-yl</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The hypothetical radical of phthalic
acid.</def><-- now usu. pthaloyl -->

<hw>Phy*lac"ter*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<ets>filateri</ets>, OF. <ets>filatire</ets>,

<def>Any charm or amulet worn as a preservative from danger or

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small square box, made either of parchment or
of black calfskin, containing slips of parchment or vellum on
which are written the scriptural passages Exodus xiii. 2-10, and
11-17, Deut. vi. 4-9, 13-22. They are worn by Jews on the head
and left arm, on week-day mornings, during the time of
prayer.</def>

<au>Schaff-Herzog Encyc.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Among the primitive Christians, a case in which
the relics of the dead were inclosed.</def>

<hw>\'d8Phyl*lop"o*da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a leaf + <ets>-poda</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of Entomostraca including a
large number of species, most of which live in fresh water. They
have flattened or leaflike legs, often very numerous, which they
use in swimming. Called also
<altname><spn>Branchiopoda</spn></altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ In some, the body is covered with a bivalve shell
(<spn>Holostraca</spn>); in others, as Apus, by a shield-shaped
carapace (<spn>Monostraca</spn>); in others, like Artemia, there
is no carapace, and the body is regularly segmented. Sometimes
the group is made to include also the Cladocera.</note>

<hw>Phyl*lop"o*dous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Phyllopoda.</def>

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to
<spn>Phyllorhina</spn> and other related genera of bats that have
a leaflike membrane around the nostrils.</def>

<hw>\'d8Phyl`lo*so"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Phyllo-</er>, and <er>-some</er> body.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The larva of the spiny lobsters
(<spn>Palinurus</spn> and allied genera). Its body is remarkably
thin, flat, and transparent; the legs are very long. Called also
<altname>glass-crab</altname>, and
<altname>glass-shrimp</altname>.</def>

<-- p. 1081 -->

<hw>Phyl`lox*e"ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ leaf + <?/ dry.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A small hemipterous insect (<spn>Phylloxera vastatrix</spn>)
allied to the aphids. It attacks the roots and leaves of the
grapevine, doing great damage, especially in Europe.</def>

<note><hand/ It exists in several forms, some of which are
winged, other wingless. One form produces galls on the leaves and
twigs, another affects the roots, causing galls or swellings, and
often killing the vine.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The diseased condition of a vine caused by the
insect just described.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Phy`lo*gen"e*sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Phy*log"e*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <?/ tribe + E. <ets>genesis</ets>, or root of Gr. <?/
to be born.]</ety> <def>The history of genealogical development;
the race history of an animal or vegetable type; the historic
exolution of the <xex>phylon</xex> or tribe, in distinction from
<xex>ontogeny</xex>, or the development of the individual
organism, and from <xex>biogenesis</xex>, or life development
generally.</def>

<hw>Phy*lo*ge*net"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Relating to phylogenesis, or the race history of a type of
organism.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Phy*lo*ge*net"ic*al*ly</wf>
<pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8Phy"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>\'d8Phy"sa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ a bellows.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of
fresh-water Pulmonifera, having reversed spiral shells. See
<cref>Pond snail</cref>, under <er>Pond</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Phy*sa"li*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ a bladder, fr. <?/ a bellows.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of large oceanic Siphonophora
which includes the Portuguese man-of-war.</def>

<note><hand/ It has a large air sac, or float, with a sail-like
crest on its upper side. Numerous zooids of different kinds are
attached to the under side of the float. Some of the zooids have
very long tentacles; some have a mouth and digest food; others
produce gonophores. The American species (<spn>Physalia
arethusa</spn>) is brilliantly colored, the float being pink or
purple, and bright blue; the zooids blue. It is noted for its
virulent stinging powers, as well as for its beautiful colors,
graceful motions, and its ability to sail to windward.</note>

<hw>\'d8Phy*sa"li*\'91</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of
Siphonophora which includes Physalia.</def>

<hw>\'d8Phys`e*ma"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/ a blowing.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A group of simple marine organisms, usually classed as the
lowest of the sponges. They have inflated hollow bodies.</def>

<hw>Phy*se"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/, fr. <?/ to blow: cf. F. <ets>phys\'82t\'8are</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The genus that includes
the sperm whale.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A filtering machine operated by air
pressure.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*an"thro*py</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ nature + <?/ man.]</ety> <def>The philosophy of human life,
or the doctrine of the constitution and diseases of man, and
their remedies.</def>

<hw>Phys"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>phisike</ets>, <ets>fisike</ets>, OF. <ets>phisique</ets>,
F. <ets>physique</ets> knowledge of nature, physics, L.
<ets>physica</ets>, <ets>physice</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/, fr. <?/
natural, from <?/ nature, fr. <?/ to produce, grow, akin to E.
<ets>be</ets>. See <er>Be</er>, and cf. <er>Physics</er>,
<er>Physique</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The art of healing
diseases; the science of medicine; the theory or practice of
medicine.</def><-- obsolete -- superseded by medicine --> \'bdA
doctor of <xex>physik</xex>.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A specific internal application for the cure or
relief of sickness; a remedy for disease; a medicine.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Specifically, a medicine that purges; a
cathartic.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A physician.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Physic nut</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a small tropical
American euphorbiaceous tree (<spn>Jatropha Curcas</spn>), and
its seeds, which are well flavored, but contain a drastic oil
which renders them dangerous if eaten in large
quantities.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phys"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Physiced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Physicking</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To treat with physic
or medicine; to administer medicine to, esp. a cathartic; to
operate on as a cathartic; to purge.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To work on as a remedy; to heal; to cure.</def>

<q>The labor we delight in <qex>physics</qex> pain.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A mind diseased no remedy can <qex>physic</qex>.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<hw>Phys"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to nature (as including all created
existences); in accordance with the laws of nature; also, of or
relating to natural or material things, or to the bodily
structure, as opposed to things mental, moral, spiritual, or
imaginary; material; natural; <as>as, armies and navies are the
<ex>physical</ex> force of a nation; the body is the
<ex>physical</ex> part of man.</as></def>

<q>Labor, in the <qex>physical</qex> world, is . . . employed in
putting objects in motion.</q>
<qau>J. S. Mill.</qau>

<q>A society sunk in ignorance, and ruled by mere
<qex>physical</qex> force.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to physics, or natural
philosophy; treating of, or relating to, the causes and
connections of natural phenomena; <as>as, <ex>physical</ex>
science; <ex>physical</ex> laws.</as></def>
\'bd<xex>Physical</xex> philosophy.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Perceptible through a bodily or material
organization; cognizable by the senses; external; <as>as, the
<ex>physical</ex>, opposed to <ex>chemical</ex>, characters of a
mineral</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to physic, or the art of
medicine; medicinal; curative; healing; also, cathartic;
purgative.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Physical</xex>
herbs.\'b8

<au>Sir T. North.</au>

<q>Is Brutus sick? and is it <qex>physical</qex>
To walk unbraced, and suck up the humors
Of the dank morning?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Physical astronomy</col>, <cd>that part of astronomy
which treats of the causes of the celestial motions;
specifically, that which treats of the motions resulting from
universal gravitation.</cd> -- <col>Physical education</col>,
<cd>training of the bodily organs and powers with a view to the
promotion of health and vigor.</cd> -- <col>Physical
examination</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>an examination of the
bodily condition of a person.</cd> -- <col>Physical
geography</col>. <cd>See under <er>Geography</er>.</cd> --
<col>Physical point</col>, <cd>an indefinitely small portion of
matter; a point conceived as being without extension, yet having
physical properties, as weight, inertia, momentum, etc.; a
material point.</cd> -- <col>Physical signs</col>
<fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>the objective signs of the bodily state
afforded by a physical examination.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phys"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a physical
manner; according to the laws of nature or physics; by physical
force; not morally.</def>

<q>I am not now treating <qex>physically</qex> of light or
colors.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>According to the rules of medicine</def>.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He that lives <qex>physically</qex> must live miserably.</q>
<qau>Cheyne.</qau>

<hw>Phy*si"cian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>fisician</ets>, <ets>fisicien</ets>, OF.
<ets>physucien</ets>, a physician, in F., a natural philosopher,
an experimentalist in physics. See <er>Physic</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A person skilled in physic, or the art of
healing; one duty authorized to prescribe remedies for, and
treat, diseases; a doctor of medicine.</def><-- one trained and
licensed to treat illness and prescribe medicines.  -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, figuratively, one who ministers to moral
diseases; <as>as, a <ex>physician</ex> of the soul</as>.</def>

<hw>Phy*si"cianed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Licensed
as a physician.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdA
<xex>physicianed</xex> apothecary.\'b8

<au>Walpole.</au>

<hw>Phys"i*cism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
tendency of the mind toward, or its preoccupation with, physical
phenomena; materialism in philosophy and religion.</def>

<q>Anthropomorphism grows into theology, while
<qex>physicism</qex> (if I may so call it) develops into
science.</q>
<qau>Huxley.</qau>

<hw>Phys"i*cist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One versed
in physics.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>A believer in the theory that
the fundamental phenomena of life are to be explained upon purely
chemical and physical principles; -- opposed to
<xex>vitalist</xex>.</def>

<hw>Phys"ick*ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <def><pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> fr. <er>Physic</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos></def>

<hw>Phys"i*co-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Fr. Gr. <?/ natural,
physical.]</ety> <def>A combining form, denoting <xex>relation
to</xex>, or <xex>dependence upon</xex>, <xex>natural
causes</xex>, or <xex>the science of physics</xex>.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*co*chem"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Physico-</ets> + <ets>chemical</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Involving the principles of both physics and chemistry;
dependent on, or produced by, the joint action of physical and
chemical agencies.</def>

<au>Huxley.</au>

<hw>Phys`i*co*log"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Physico-</ets> + <ets>logic</ets>.]</ety> <def>Logic
illustrated by physics.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*co*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to physicologic.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Phys`i*col"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Physico-</ets> + <ets>-logy</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Physics.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> --
<wordforms><wf>Phys`i*col"o*gist</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<mark>[R.]</mark></wordforms>

<hw>Phys`i*co-math`e*mat"ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Physico-</ets> + <ets>mathematics</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Mixed mathematics.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*co-phi*los"o*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Physico-</ets> + <ets>philosophy</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The philosophy of nature.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*co-the*ol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Physico-</ets> + <ets>theology</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Theology or divinity illustrated or enforced by physics or
natural philosophy.</def>

<hw>Phys"ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Physic</er>.]</ety> <def>The science of nature, or of natural
objects; that branch of science which treats of the laws and
properties of matter, and the forces acting upon it; especially,
that department of natural science which treats of the causes (as
gravitation, heat, light, magnetism, electricity, etc.) that
modify the general properties of bodies; natural
philosophy.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Chemistry</xex>, though a branch of
<xex>general physics</xex>, is commonly treated as a science by
itself, and the application of physical principles which it
involves constitute a branch called <xex>chemical physics</xex>,
which treats more especially of those physical properties of
matter which are used by chemists in defining and distinguishing
substances.</note>

<hw>Phys"i*o*crat</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
nature + <?/ to rule.]</ety> <def>One of the followers of Quesnay
of France, who, in the 18th century, founded a system of
political economy based upon the supremacy of natural
order.</def> <au>F. A. Walker</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>Phys`i*o*crat"ic</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Phys`i*og"e*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
nature + root of <?/ to be born.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld>
<def>The germ history of the functions, or the history of the
development of vital activities, in the individual, being one of
the branches of ontogeny. See <er>Morphogeny</er>.</def>

<au>Haeckel.</au>

<hw>Phys`i*og"no*mer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Physiognomist.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Phys`i*og*nom"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Phys`i*og*nom"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Gr. <?/: cf. F. <ets>physiognomonique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of

<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Phys`i*og*nom"ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same
as <er>Physiognomy</er>, 1.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*og"no*mist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<au>Southey.</au>

<hw>Phys`i*og`no*mmon"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Physiognomic.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*og"no*my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Physiognomies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>fisonomie</ets>, <ets>phisonomie</ets>, <ets>fisnamie</ets>,
OF. <ets>phisonomie</ets>, F. <ets>physiognomie</ets>,
<ets>physiognomonie</ets>, from Gr. <?/; <?/ nature + <?/ one who
knows or examines, a judge, fr. <?/, <?/, to know. See
<er>Physic</er>, and <er>Know</er>, and cf. <er>Phiz</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The art and science of discovering the
predominant temper, and other characteristic qualities of the
mind, by the outward appearance, especially by the features of
the face.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The face or countenance, with respect to the
temper of the mind; particular configuration, cast, or expression
of countenance, as denoting character.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The art telling fortunes by inspection of the
features.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bale.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The general appearance or aspect of a thing,
without reference to its scientific characteristics; <as>as, the
<ex>physiognomy</ex> of a plant, or of a meteor</as>.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*og"o*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
nature + <?/ birth.]</ety> <def>The birth of nature.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Phys`i*o*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,

<hw>Phys`i*og"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ nature + <ets>-graphy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>physiographie</ets>.]</ety> <def>The science which treats of
the earth's exterior physical features, climate, life, etc., and
of the physical movements or changes on the earth's surface, as
the currents of the atmosphere and ocean, the secular variations
in heat, moisture, magnetism, etc.; physical geography.</def>

<hw>Phys`i*ol"a*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ nature + <?/ service.]</ety> <def>The worship of the powers
or agencies of nature; materialism in religion; nature
worship.</def> \'bdThe <xex>physiolatry</xex> of the Vedas.\'b8

<au>M. Williams.</au>

<hw>Phys`i*o*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to physiology; relating to the science of the

<hw>Phys`i*ol"o*gist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<hw>Phys`i*ol"o*gize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
speculate in physiology; to make physiological

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<hw>Phys`i*ol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Physiologies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>physiologia</ets>, Gr. <?/; <?/ nature + <?/ discourse: cf.
F. <ets>physiologie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The science
which treats of the phenomena of living organisms; the study of
the processes incidental to, and characteristic of, life.</def>

<note><hand/ It is divided into <xex>animal</xex> and
<xex>vegetable physiology</xex>, dealing with animal and
vegetable life respectively. When applied especially to a study
of the functions of the organs and tissues in man, it is called
<xex>human physiology</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A treatise on physiology.</def>

<cs><col>Mental physiology</col>, <cd>the science of the
functions and phenomena of the mind, as distinguished from a
philosophical explanation of the same.</cd></cs>

<hw>Phys`i*oph"y*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ nature + <?/ a clan.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The
tribal history of the functions, or the history of the
paleontological development of vital activities, -- being a
branch of <xex>phylogeny</xex>. See <er>Morphophyly</er>.</def>

<au>Haeckel.</au>

<hw>Phy`so*stig"mine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean

formerly called <altname>eserine</altname>, with which it was
regarded as identical.</def>

<hw>\'d8Phy*sos"to*mi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a bellows + <?/ mouth.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of fishes in which the air
bladder is provided with a duct, and the ventral fins, when
present, are abdominal. It includes the salmons, herrings, carps,
catfishes, and others.</def>

<hw>Pi"a*cle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

expiate, <ets>pius</ets> pious.]</ety> <def>A heinous offense
which requires expiation.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Howell.</au>

oblong case.</cd> -- <col>Upright piano</col>, <cd>one with an
upright frame and vertical wires.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi*as"sa*va</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pg.

<hw>Pi*as"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>piastre</ets>, It. <ets>piastra</ets> a thin plate of metal,
a dollar, LL. <ets>piastra</ets>, fr. L. <ets>emplastrum</ets>.
See <er>Plaster</er>.]</ety> <def>A silver coin of Spain and
various other countries. See <er>Peso</er>. The Spanish piaster
(commonly called <xex>peso</xex>, or <xex>peso duro</xex>) is of
about the value of the American dollar. The Italian piaster, or
scudo, was worth from 80 to 100 cents. The Turkish and Egyptian
piasters are now worth about four and a half cents.</def>

<hw>Pi*as"tre</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Piaster</er>.</def>

<hw>Pi*az"za</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Pi"broch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gael.

<hw>Pi"ca</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pica</ets> a pie, magpie; in sense 3 prob. named from some

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A vitiated appetite that
craves what is unfit for food, as chalk, ashes, coal, etc.;
chthonophagia.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A service-book. See
<er>Pie</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>A size of type next larger
than small pica, and smaller than English.</def>

<note><hand/ <picatype>This line is printed in
<it>pica</it></picatype></note>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pica</xex> is twice the size of nonpareil, and
is used as a standard of measurement in casting leads, cutting
rules, etc., and also as a standard by which to designate several
larger kinds of type, as <xex>double pica</xex>, <xex>two-line
pica</xex>, <xex>four-line pica</xex>, and the like.</note>

<cs><col>Small pica</col> <fld>(Print.)</fld>, <cd>a size of type
next larger than long primer, and smaller than pica.</cd></cs>

<note><hand/ <smpicatype>This line is printed in <it>small
pica</it></smpicatype></note>

<hw>\'d8Pic"e*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., the

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of coniferous trees of the northen
hemisphere, including the Norway spruce and the American black
and white spruces. These trees have pendent cones, which do not
readily fall to pieces, in this and other respects differing from
the firs.</def>

<hw>Pick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Picked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Picking</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>picken</ets>, <ets>pikken</ets>, to prick, peck;
akin to Icel. <ets>pikka</ets>, Sw. <ets>picka</ets>, Dan.
<ets>pikke</ets>, D. <ets>pikken</ets>, G. <ets>picken</ets>, F.
<ets>piquer</ets>, W. <ets>pigo</ets>. Cf. <er>Peck</er>,
<pos>v.</pos>, <er>Pike</er>, <er>Pitch</er> to throw.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw; to pitch.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>As high as I could <qex>pick</qex> my lance.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To peck at, as a bird with its beak; to strike
at with anything pointed; to act upon with a pointed instrument;
to pierce; to prick, as with a pin.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To separate or open by means of a sharp point or
points; <as>as, to <ex>pick</ex> matted wool, cotton, oakum,
etc</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To open (a lock) as by a wire.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To pull apart or away, especially with the
fingers; to pluck; to gather, as fruit from a tree, flowers from
the stalk, feathers from a fowl, etc.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To remove something from with a pointed
instrument, with the fingers, or with the teeth; <as>as, to
<ex>pick</ex> the teeth; to <ex>pick</ex> a bone; to
<ex>pick</ex> a goose; to <ex>pick</ex> a pocket.</as></def>

<q>Did you <qex>pick</qex> Master Slender's purse?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>He <qex>picks</qex> clean teeth, and, busy as he seems
With an old tavern quill, is hungry yet.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To choose; to select; to separate as choice or
desirable; to cull; <as>as, to <ex>pick</ex> one's company; to
<ex>pick</ex> one's way</as>; -- often with <xex>out</xex>.</def>
\'bdOne man <xex>picked</xex> out of ten thousand.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To take up; esp., to gather from here and there;
to collect; to bring together; <as>as, to <ex>pick</ex>
rags</as>; -- often with <xex>up</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>pick</ex>
up a ball or stones; to <ex>pick</ex> up information.</as></def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To trim.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<cs><col>To pick at</col>, <cd>to tease or vex by pertinacious
annoyance.</cd> -- <col>To pick a bone with</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Bone</er>.</cd> -- <col>To pick a thank</col>, <cd>to curry
favor. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Robynson (More's
Utopia)</au>.</cd> -- <col>To pick off</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To
pluck; to remove by picking</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To shoot or
bring down, one by one; <as>as, sharpshooters <ex>pick off<ex>
the enemy</as>.</cd> -- <col>To pick out</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>To mark out; to variegate; <as>as, <ex>to pick out<ex> any
dark stuff with lines or spots of bright colors</as></cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To select from a number or quantity.</cd> --
<col>To pick to pieces</col>, <cd>to pull apart piece by piece;
hence <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>, to analyze; esp., to criticize in
detail.</cd> -- <col>To pick a quarrel</col>, <cd>to give
occasion of quarrel intentionally.</cd> -- <col>To pick up</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To take up, as with the fingers</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To get by repeated efforts; to gather here and
there; <as>as, <ex>to pick up<ex> a livelihood; <ex>to pick
up<ex> news</as>.</cd><-- <sd>(c)</sd> to acquire (an infectious
disease); as, to <ex>pick up</ex> a cold on the airplane. (d) To
meet (a person) and induce to accompany one; as, to pick up a
date at the mall. [See several other defs in MW10] --></cs>

<-- p. 1083 -->

<hw>Pick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
eat slowly, sparingly, or by morsels; to nibble.</def><-- = to
pick at -->

<q>Why stand'st thou <qex>picking</qex>? Is thy palate sore?</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To do anything nicely or carefully, or by
attending to small things; to select something with care.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To steal; to pilfer.</def> \'bdTo keep my hands
from <xex>picking</xex> and stealing.\'b8

<au>Book of Com. Prayer.</au>

<cs><col>To pick up</col>, <cd>to improve by degrees; as, he is
<xex>picking up<xex> in health or business. <mark>[Colloq.
U.S.]</mark></cd><-- or, to increase gradually, as the car picked
up speed rolling downhill --></cs>

<hw>Pick</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>pic</ets> a pickax, a
pick. See <er>Pick</er>, and cf. <er>Pike</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A sharp-pointed tool for picking; -- often used
in composition; <as>as, a tooth<ex>pick</ex>; a
<ex>pick</ex>lock.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mining & Mech.)</fld> <def>A heavy iron tool,
curved and sometimes pointed at both ends, wielded by means of a
wooden handle inserted in the middle, -- used by quarrymen,
roadmakers, etc.; also, a pointed hammer used for dressing
millstones.</def><-- used for digging -->

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A pike or spike; the sharp point fixed in the
center of a buckler.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdTake down my
buckler . . . and grind the <xex>pick</xex> on 't.\'b8

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Choice; right of selection; <as>as, to have
one's <ex>pick</ex></as>.</def>

<q>France and Russia have the <qex>pick</qex> of our stables.</q>
<qau>Ld. Lytton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That which would be picked or chosen first; the
best; <as>as, the <ex>pick</ex> of the flock</as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>A particle of ink or paper
imbedded in the hollow of a letter, filling up its face, and
occasioning a spot on a printed sheet.</def>

<au>MacKellar.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Painting)</fld> <def>That which is picked in,
as with a pointed pencil, to correct an unevenness in a
picture.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Weawing)</fld> <def>The blow which drives the
shuttle, -- the rate of speed of a loom being reckoned as so many
<xex>picks</xex> per minute; hence, in describing the fineness of
a fabric, a weft thread; <as>as, so many <ex>picks</ex> to an
inch</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Pick dressing</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>in cut
stonework, a facing made by a pointed tool, leaving the surface
in little pits or depressions.</cd> -- <col>Pick hammer</col>,
<cd>a pick with one end sharp and the other blunt, used by
miners.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pick"a*back`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>On the
back or shoulders; <as>as, to ride <ex>pickback</ex></as>.</def>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>pickapack</asp>, <asp>pickback</asp>,
and <asp>pickpack</asp>.]</altsp><-- = piggyback -->

<q>A woman stooping to take a child <qex>pickaback</qex>.</q>
<qau>R,Jefferies.</qau>

<hw>Pick"a*nin`ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pickaninnies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. Sp.
<ets>peque\'a4o</ets> little, young.]</ety> <def>A small child;
especially, a negro or mulatto infant.</def> <mark>[U.S. & West
Indies]</mark>

<def>Pickaback.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pick"ax`</hw>, <hw>Pick"axe`</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[A corruption of OE.
<ets>pikois</ets>, <ets>pikeis</ets>, F. <ets>picois</ets>, fr.
<ets>pic</ets>. See <er>Pick</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>A
pick with a point at one end, a transverse edge or blade at the
other, and a handle inserted at the middle; a hammer with a
flattened end for driving wedges and a pointed end for piercing
as it strikes.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pick"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

polished.\'b8

<au>Chapman.</au>

<q>Let the stake be made <qex>picked</qex> at the top.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having a pike or spine on
the back; -- said of certain fishes.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Carefully selected; chosen; <as>as,
<ex>picked</ex> men</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Fine; spruce; smart; precise; dianty.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Picked dogfish</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See
under <er>Dogfish</er>.</cd> -- <col>Picked out</col>,
<cd>ornamented or relieved with lines, or the like, of a
different, usually a lighter, color; as, a carriage body dark
green, <xex>picked out<xex> with red.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pick"ed*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The state of being sharpened; pointedness.</def>

<q>Too much <qex>pickedness</qex> is not manly.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<hw>Pick*eer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pickeered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pickeering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>picorer</ets> to
go marauding, orig., to go to steal cattle, ultimately fr. L.
<ets>pecus</ets>, <ets>pecoris</ets>, cattle; cf. F.
<ets>picor\'82e</ets>, Sp. <ets>pecorea</ets> robbery committed
by straggling soldiers.]</ety> <def>To make a raid for booty; to
maraud; also, to skirmish in advance of an army. See
<er>Picaroon</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Burnet.</au>

<hw>Pick*eer"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pickeers.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pick"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Pick</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which,
picks, in any sense, -- as, one who uses a pick; one who gathers;
a thief; a pick; a pickax; <as>as, a cotton
<ex>picker</ex></as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Pickers</xex> and
stealers.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A machine for picking fibrous
materials to pieces so as to loosen and separate the fiber.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Weaving)</fld> <def>The piece in a loom which
strikes the end of the shuttle, and impels it through the
warp.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Ordnance)</fld> <def>A priming wire for
cleaning the vent.</def>

<hw>Pick"er*el</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Dim. of
<er>Pike</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pickerell</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A young or small
pike.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Bet [better] is, quoth he, a pike than a
<qex>pickerel</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Any one of
several species of freshwater fishes of the genus
<spn>Esox</spn>, esp. the smaller species.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The glasseye, or wall-eyed pike. See
<er>Wall-eye</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The federation, or chain, pickerel (<spn>Esox
reticulatus</spn>) and the brook pickerel (<spn>E.
Americanus</spn>) are the most common American species. They are
used for food, and are noted for their voracity. About the Great
Lakes the pike is called <xex>pickerel</xex>.</note>

<cs><col>Pickerel weed</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a
blue-flowered aquatic plant (<spn>Pontederia cordata</spn>)
having large arrow-shaped leaves. So called because common in
slow-moving waters where pickerel are often found.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pick"er*ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably a
corruption of <er>Pickerel</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The sauger of the St.Lawrence River.</def>

<hw>Pick"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Pick</er> to steal; or perhaps from <er>Pickeer</er>.]</ety>
<def>Petty theft.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<au>Holinshed.</au>

<hw>Pick"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>piquet</ets>, properly dim. of <ets>pique</ets> spear, pike.
See <er>Pike</er>, and cf. <er>Piquet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A stake sharpened or pointed, especially one used in
fortification and encampments, to mark bounds and angles; or one
used for tethering horses.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A pointed pale, used in marking fences.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Probably so called from the
<ets>picketing</ets> of the horses.]</ety> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>
<def>A detached body of troops serving to guard an army from
surprise, and to oppose reconnoitering parties of the enemy; --
called also <altname>outlying picket</altname>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>By extension, men appointed by a trades union,
or other labor organization, to intercept outsiders, and prevent
them from working for employers with whom the organization is at
variance.</def> <mark>[Cant]</mark><-- any individual standing at
the entrance to a building (typically a business establishement),
usually for the purpose of inhibiting or preventing others from
entering that establishment, but sometimes only for demonstration
or protest, and usually bearing a sign informing others of the
nature of the grievance causing the picketing. -->

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A military punishment, formerly resorted to, in
which the offender was forced to stand with one foot on a pointed
stake.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A game at cards. See <er>Piquet</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Inlying picket</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a detachment
of troops held in camp or quarters, detailed to march if called
upon.</cd> -- <col>Picket fence</col>, <cd>a fence made of
pickets. See def. 2, above.</cd> -- <col>Picket guard</col>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a guard of horse and foot, always in
readiness in case of alarm.</cd> -- <col>Picket line</col>.
<fld>(Mil.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A position held and guarded by
small bodies of men placed at intervals</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A
rope to which horses are secured when groomed.</cd> --
<col>Picketpin</col>, <cd>an iron pin for picketing
horses.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pick"et</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Picketed</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Picketing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To fortify with
pointed stakes.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To inclose or fence with pickets or pales.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To tether to, or as to, a picket; <as>as, to
<ex>picket</ex> a horse</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To guard, as a camp or road, by an outlying
picket.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To torture by compelling to stand with one foot
on a pointed stake.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pic"kle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pic"kle</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D. <ets>pekel</ets>.
Probably a dim. fr. <er>Pick</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, alluding to
the cleaning of the fish.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
solution of salt and water, in which fish, meat, etc., may be
preserved or corned; brine.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Vinegar,
plain or spiced, used for preserving vegetables, fish, eggs,
oysters, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any article of food which has been preserved in
brine or in vinegar.</def><-- esp., a cucumber thus preserved -->

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Founding)</fld> <def>A bath of dilute sulphuric
or nitric acid, etc., to remove burnt sand, scale rust, etc.,
from the surface of castings, or other articles of metal, or to
brighten them or improve their color.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A troublesome child; <as>as, a little
<ex>pickle</ex></as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<cs><col>To be in a pickle</col>, <cd>to be in disagreeable
position; to be in a condition of embarrassment, difficulty, or
disorder. \'bdHow cam'st thou in this <xex>pickle<xex>?\'b8
<au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>To put a rod in pickle</col>, <cd>to
prepare a particular reproof, punishment, or penalty for future
application.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pic"nic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>Pic"o*line</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>-ine</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Any one of three
isometric bases (<chform>C6H7N</chform>) related to pyridine, and
obtained from bone oil, acrolein ammonia, and coal-tar naphtha,
as colorless mobile liquids of strong odor; -- called also

<mhw>{ <hw>Pic`o*tee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pic`o*tine"</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>picot\'82</ets>

<hw>Pi"cra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr. <?/
sharp, bitter.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The powder of aloes
with canella, formerly officinal, employed as a cathartic.</def>

<hw>Pi"crate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A salt of picric acid.</def>

<hw>Pi"cric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
bitter.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or
designating, a strong organic acid (called <xex>picric
acid</xex>), intensely bitter.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Picric acid</xex> is obtained by treating
phenol with strong nitric acid, as a brilliant yellow crystalline
substance, <chform>C6H2(NO2)3.OH</chform>. It is used in dyeing
silk and wool, and also in the manufacture of explosives, as it
is very unstable when heated. Called also
<altname>trinitrophenol</altname>, and formerly
<altname>carbazotic acid</altname>.</note>

<hw>Pic"rite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From Gr. <?/
bitter.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A dark green igneous rock,
consisting largely of chrysolite, with hornblende, augite,
biotite, etc.</def>

<hw>Pic"ro*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
bitter + <ets>-lite</ets>.: cf. F. <ets>picrolithe</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A fibrous variety of serpentine.</def>

<hw>Pic"ro*mel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
bitter + <?/ honey: cf. F. <ets>picromel</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Old
Chem.)</fld> <def>A colorless viscous substance having a
bitter-sweet taste.</def>

<note><hand/ It was formerly supposed to be the essential
principle of the bile, but is now known to be a mixture,
principally of salts of glycocholic and taurocholic acids.</note>

<hw>Pic`ro*tox"in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
bitter + <ets>tox</ets>ic + <ets>-in</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A bitter white crystalline substance
found in the cocculus indicus. It is a peculiar poisonous
neurotic and intoxicant, and consists of a mixture of several
neutral substances.</def>

<hw>Pi"cryl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Picr</ets>ic + <ets>-yl</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The hypothetical radical of picric acid,
analogous to phenyl.</def>

of being pictured, or represented by a picture.</def>

<hw>Pic"tur*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pictorial.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Pic"tur*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A picture.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Pic"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pictura</ets>, fr. <ets>pingere</ets>, <ets>pictum</ets>, to
paint: cf. F. <ets>peinture</ets>. See <er>Paint</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The art of painting; representation by
painting.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Any well-expressed image . . . either in <qex>picture</qex> or
sculpture.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A representation of anything (as a person, a
landscape, a building) upon canvas, paper, or other surface,
produced by means of painting, drawing, engraving, photography,
etc.; a representation in colors. By extension, a figure; a
model.</def>

<q><qex>Pictures</qex> and shapes are but secondary objects.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>The young king's <qex>picture</qex> . . . in virgin wax.</q>
<qau>Howell.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An image or resemblance; a representation,
either to the eye or to the mind; that which, by its likeness,
brings vividly to mind some other thing; <as>as, a child is the
<ex>picture</ex> of his father; the man is the <ex>picture</ex>
of grief.</as></def>

<q>My eyes make <qex>pictures</qex> when they are shut.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Picture</xex> is often used adjectively, or in
forming self-explaining compounds; as, <xex>picture</xex> book or
<xex>picture</xex>-book, <xex>picture</xex> frame or
<xex>picture</xex>-frame, <xex>picture</xex> seller or
<xex>picture</xex>-seller, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Picture gallery</col>, <cd>a gallery, or large
apartment, devoted to the exhibition of pictures.</cd> --
<col>Picture red</col>, <cd>a rod of metal tube fixed to the
walls of a room, from which pictures are hung.</cd> --
<col>Picture writing</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The art of recording
events, or of expressing messages, by means of pictures
representing the actions or circumstances in question</cd>.
<au>Tylor</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The record or message so
represented; <as>as, the <ex>picture writing<ex> of the American
Indians</as>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Picture</er>, <er>Painting</er>.</syn> <usage>
Every kind of representation by drawing or painting is a
<xex>picture</xex>, whether made with oil colors, water colors,
pencil, crayons, or India ink; strictly, a <xex>painting</xex> is
a picture made by means of colored paints, usually applied moist
with a brush.</usage>

<hw>Pic"ture</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pictured</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Picturing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To draw or paint a
resemblance of; to delineate; to represent; to form or present an
ideal likeness of; to bring before the mind.</def> \'bdI . . . do
<xex>picture</xex> it in my mind.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>I have not seen him so <qex>pictured</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pic"tured</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Furnished
with pictures; represented by a picture or pictures; <as>as, a
<ex>pictured</ex> scene</as>.</def>

<-- p. 1084 -->

<hw>Pic"tur*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
makes pictures; a painter.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>Pic`tur*esque"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[It.
<ets>pittoresco</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pittoresque</ets>. See
<er>Pictorial</er>.]</ety> <def>Forming, or fitted to form, a
good or pleasing picture; representing with the clearness or
ideal beauty appropriate to a picture; expressing that peculiar
kind of beauty which is agreeable in a picture, natural or
artificial; graphic; vivid; <as>as, a <ex>picturesque</ex> scene
or attitude; <ex>picturesque</ex> language.</as></def>

<q>What is <qex>picturesque</qex> as placed in relation to the
beautiful and the sublime? It is . . . the characteristic pushed
into a sensible excess.</q>
<au>De Quincey.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pic`tur*esque"ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pic`tur*esque"ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

picturesque.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<def>To picture.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To adorn with pictures.</def>

<hw>Pic"ul</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Jav. & Malay
<ets>pikul</ets>, fr. <ets>pikul</ets> to carry on the back, to
carry a burden; n., a man's burden.]</ety> <def>A commercial
weight varying in different countries and for different
commodities. In Borneo it is 135<frac58/ lbs.; in China and
Sumatra, 133<frac12/ lbs.; in Japan, 133<frac13/ lbs.; but
sometimes 130 lbs., etc. Called also, by the Chinese,
<altname>tan</altname>.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pecul</asp>, and <asp>pecal</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pic"u*let</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Dim. of
<er>Picus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of
very small woodpeckers of the genus <spn>Picumnus</spn> and
allied genera. Their tail feathers are not stiff and sharp at the
tips, as in ordinary woodpeckers.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi"cus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

woodpecker.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of

<hw>Pid"dle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Piddled</er>

<hw>Pie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pie</ets>, <ets>pye</ets>; cf. Ir. & Gael. <ets>pighe</ets>

<er>Piggin</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An article of food

<as>as, chicken <ex>pie</ex>; venison <ex>pie</ex>; mince
<ex>pie</ex>; apple <ex>pie</ex>; pumpkin
<ex>pie</ex>.</as></def>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<hw>Pie</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>pie</ets>, L.
<ets>pica</ets>; cf. <ets>picus</ets> woodpecker,
<ets>pingere</ets> to paint; the bird being perhaps named from
its colors. Cf. <er>Pi</er>, <er>Paint</er>,
<er>Speight</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>A magpie.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Any other
species of the genus <spn>Pica</spn>, and of several allied
genera.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>pye</asp>.]</altsp>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>The service book.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Pritn.)</fld> <def>Type confusedly mixed. See
<er>Pi</er>.</def>

<cs><col>By cock and pie</col>, <cd>an adjuration equivalent to

<col>Tree pie</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any Asiatic bird

<hw>Pie"bald`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pie</ets> the party-colored bird +

<hw>Piece</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pece</ets>, F. <ets>pi\'8ace</ets>, LL. <ets>pecia</ets>,
<ets>petia</ets>, <ets>petium</ets>, probably of Celtic origin;
cf. W. <ets>peth</ets> a thing, a part, portion, a little, Armor.
<ets>pez</ets>, Gael. & Ir. <ets>cuid</ets> part, share. Cf.
<er>Petty</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A fragment or part of
anything separated from the whole, in any manner, as by cutting,
splitting, breaking, or tearing; a part; a portion; <as>as, a
<ex>piece</ex> of sugar; to break in <ex>pieces</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Bring it out <qex>piece</qex> by <qex>piece</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ezek. xxiv. 6.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A definite portion or quantity, as of goods or
work; <as>as, a <ex>piece</ex> of broadcloth; a <ex>piece</ex> of
wall paper.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any one thing conceived of as apart from other
things of the same kind; an individual article; a distinct single
effort of a series; a definite performance</def>; especially:
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>A literary or artistic composition; <as>as, a
<ex>piece</ex> of poetry, music, or statuary</as></def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A musket, gun, or cannon; <as>as, a battery of
six <ex>pieces</ex>; a following <ex>piece</ex></as></def>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A coin; <as>as, a sixpenny <ex>piece</ex></as>;
-- formerly applied specifically to an English gold coin worth 22
shillings</def>. <sd>(d)</sd> <def>A fact; an item; <as>as, a
<ex>piece</ex> of news; a <ex>piece</ex> of
knowledge</as></def>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An individual; -- applied to a person as being
of a certain nature or quality; often, but not always, used
slightingly or in contempt.</def> \'bdIf I had not been a
<xex>piece</xex> of a logician before I came to him.\'b8

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<q>Thy mother was a <qex>piece</qex> of virtue.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>His own spirit is as unsettled a <qex>piece</qex> as there is
in all the world.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<-- <col>a piece of cake</col>, a task easily accomplished.
<col>a piece of work</col>, a disparaging term for a person
considered to have an excess of some undesirable quality; esp. 
difficult or eccentric person. <col>Piece of ass</col> vulgar
term for a woman, considered as a partner in sexual intercourse
-->

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Chess)</fld> <def>One of the superior men,
distinguished from a pawn.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A castle; a fortified building.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<cs><col>Of a piece</col>, <cd>of the same sort, as if taken from
the same whole; like; -- sometimes followed by <xex>with<xex>.
<au>Dryden</au>.</cd> -- <col>Piece of eight</col>, <cd>the
Spanish piaster, formerly divided into eight reals.</cd> --
<col>To give a piece of one's mind to</col>, <cd>to speak
plainly, bluntly, or severely to (another).
<au>Tackeray</au>.</cd> -- <col>Piece broker</col>, <cd>one who
buys shreds and remnants of cloth to sell again.</cd> --
<col>Piece goods</col>, <cd>goods usually sold by pieces or fixed
portions, as shirtings, calicoes, sheetings, and the
like.</cd></cs>

<hw>Piece</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pieced</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Piecing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To

<xex>out</xex>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

a joint opposition against him.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Pier</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pere</ets>, OF. <ets>piere</ets> a stone, F.
<ets>pierre</ets>, fr. L. <ets>petra</ets>, Gr. <?/. Cf.
<er>Petrify</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>Any detached mass of masonry, whether insulated
or supporting one side of an arch or lintel, as of a bridge; the
piece of wall between two openings.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Any

See <er>Buttress</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A projecting wharf or landing place.</def>

<cs><col>Abutment pier</col>, <cd>the pier of a bridge next the
shore; a pier which by its strength and stability resists the
thrust of an arch.</cd> -- <col>Pier glass</col>, <cd>a mirror,

<hw>Pierce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pierced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Piercing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>percen</ets>, F.
<ets>percer</ets>, OF. <ets>percier</ets>, <ets>perchier</ets>,
<ets>parchier</ets>; perh. fr. (assumed) LL.
<ets>pertusiare</ets> for <ets>pertusare</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>pertundere</ets>, <ets>pertusum</ets>, to beat, push, bore
through; <ets>per</ets> through + <ets>tundere</ets> to beat: cf.
OF. <ets>pertuisier</ets> to pierce, F. <ets>pertuis</ets> a
hole. Cf. <er>Contuse</er>, <er>Parch</er>,
<er>Pertuse</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To thrust into,
penetrate, or transfix, with a pointed instrument.</def> \'bdI
<xex>pierce</xex> . . . her tender side.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To penetrate; to enter; to force a way into or
through; to pass into or through; <as>as, to <ex>pierce</ex> the
enemy's line; a shot <ex>pierced</ex> the ship.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: To penetrate; to affect deeply; <as>as, to
<ex>pierce</ex> a mystery</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Pierced</xex> with
grief.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<q>Can no prayers <qex>pierce</qex> thee?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pierce</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To enter; to penetrate; to
make a way into or through something, as a pointed instrument
does; -- used literally and figuratively.</def>

<q>And <qex>pierced</qex> to the skin, but bit no more.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>She would not <qex>pierce</qex> further into his meaning.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<hw>Pierce"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That may
be pierced.</def>

<hw>Pierced</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Penetrated;
entered; perforated.</def>

<hw>Pier"cel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>perce</ets>.]</ety> <def>A kind of gimlet for making vents
in casks; -- called also <altname>piercer</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pier"cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, pierces or perforates</def>;
specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An instrument used in forming
eyelets; a stiletto</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A piercel.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The
ovipositor, or sting, of an insect.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>An
insect provided with an ovipositor.</def>

<hw>Pier"cing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Forcibly
entering, or adapted to enter, at or by a point; perforating;
penetrating; keen; -- used also figuratively; <as>as, a
<ex>piercing</ex> instrument, or thrust</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Piercing</xex> eloquence.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<wf>Pier"cing*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pi*e"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

sacred to the Muses.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to Pierides or
Muses.</def>

<q>Drink deep, or taste not the <qex>Pierian</qex> spring.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<cref>Cabbage butterfly</cref>, under <er>Cabbage</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi*e*t\'85"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[It.]</ety> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>A representation of

<au>Mollett.</au>

<hw>Pi"e*tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>pietismus</ets>, F. <ets>pi\'82tisme</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The principle or practice of the Pietists.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Strict devotion; also, affectation of
devotion.</def>

<q>The <qex>Sch\'94ne Seele</qex>, that ideal of gentle
<qex>pietism</qex>, in \'bdWilhelm Meister.\'b8</q>
<qau>W. Pater.</qau>

<hw>Pi"e*tist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>pietist</ets>, F. <ets>pi\'82tiste</ets>. See
<er>Piety</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld> <def>One of a
class of religious reformers in Germany in the 17th century who
sought to revive declining piety in the Protestant churches; --
often applied as a term of reproach to those who make a display
of religious feeling. Also used adjectively.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pi`e*tis"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pi`e*tis"tic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Of or pertaining to the Pietists; hence, in contempt,
affectedly or demonstratively religious.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pi*e"tra du"ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[It., hard
stone.]</ety> <fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>Hard and fine stones in
general, such as are used for inlay and the like, as
distinguished from the softer stones used in building; thus, a
Florentine mosaic is a familiar instance of work in <xex>pietra
dura</xex>, though the ground may be soft marble.</def>

<hw>Pi"e*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pi\'82t\'82</ets>; cf. It. <ets>piet\'85</ets>; both fr. L.
<ets>pietas</ets> piety, fr. <ets>pius</ets> pious. See
<er>Pious</er>, and cf. <er>Pity</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Veneration or reverence of the Supreme Being, and love of
his character; loving obedience to the will of God, and earnest
devotion to his service.</def>

<q><qex>Piety</qex> is the only proper and adequate relief of
decaying man.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Duty; dutifulness; filial reverence and
devotion; affectionate reverence and service shown toward
parents, relatives, benefactors, country, etc.</def>

<q>Conferred upon me for the <qex>piety</qex>
Which to my country I was judged to have shown.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Religion; sanctity; devotion; godliness; holiness.
See <er>Religion</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pig</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D. <ets>big</ets>,

girl, Sw. <ets>piga</ets>, Icel. <ets>p\'c6ka</ets>.]</ety>

iron.]</ety> <def>An oblong mass of cast iron, lead, or other
metal. See <cref>Mine pig</cref>, under <er>Mine</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One who is hoggish; a greedy person.</def>
<mark>[Low]</mark>

<cs><col>Masked pig</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Masked</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pig bed</col>
<fld>(Founding)</fld>, <cd>the bed of sand in which the iron from
a smelting furnace is cast into pigs.</cd> -- <col>Pig
iron</col>, <cd>cast iron in pigs, or oblong blocks or bars, as
it comes from the smelting furnace. See <er>Pig</er>, 4.</cd> --
<col>Pig yoke</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a nickname for a
quadrant or sextant.</cd> -- <col>A pig in a poke</col> (that is,
<xex>bag<xex>), <cd>a blind bargain; something bought or
bargained for, without the quality or the value being known.</cd>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cs>

<hw>Pi"geon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>pipio</ets> a young pipping or chirping bird, fr.
<ets>pipire</ets> to peep, chirp. Cf. <er>Peep</er> to
chirp.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any bird of
the order Columb\'91, of which numerous species occur in nearly
all parts of the world.</def>

<note><hand/ The common domestic pigeon, or dove, was derived
from the Old World rock pigeon (<spn>Columba livia</spn>). It has
given rise to numerous very remarkable varieties, such as the
carrier, fantail, nun, pouter, tumbler, etc. The common wild
pigeons of the Eastern United States are the passenger pigeon,
and the Carolina dove. See under <er>Passenger</er>, and
<er>Dove</er>. See, also, <cref>Fruit pigeon</cref>, <cref>Ground
pigeon</cref>, <cref>Queen pigeon</cref>, <cref>Stock
pigeon</cref>, under <er>Fruit</er>, <er>Ground</er>, etc.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An unsuspected victim of sharpers; a gull.</def>
<mark>[Slang]</mark>

<cs><col>Blue pigeon</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an
Australian passerine bird (<spn>Graucalus melanops</spn>); --
called also <altname>black-faced crow</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Green pigeon</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of
numerous species of Old World pigeons belonging to the family
<spn>Treronid\'91</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Imperial pigeon</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of the large Asiatic fruit
pigeons of the genus <spn>Carpophada</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon
berry</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the purplish black fruit of
the pokeweed; also, the plant itself. See <er>Pokeweed</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Pigeon English</col> <ety>[perhaps a corruption of
<ets>business English<ets>]</ety>, <cd>an extraordinary and
grotesque dialect, employed in the commercial cities of China, as
the medium of communication between foreign merchants and the
Chinese. Its base is English, with a mixture of Portuguese and
Hindoostanee. <au>Johnson's Cyc</au>.</cd><-- pidgin English???
--> -- <col>Pigeon grass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a kind of
foxtail grass (<spn>Setaria glauca</spn>), of some value as
fodder. The seeds are eagerly eaten by pigeons and other
birds.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon hawk</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A small American falcon (<spn>Falco
columbarius</spn>). The adult male is dark slate-blue above,
streaked with black on the back; beneath, whitish or buff,
streaked with brown. The tail is banded.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The American sharp-shinned hawk (<spn>Accipiter velox, <or/
fuscus</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Pigeon hole</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A
hole for pigeons to enter a pigeon house</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>See <er>Pigeonhole</er>.</cd> <sd>(c)</sd> <pluf>pl.</pluf>
<cd>An old English game, in which balls were rolled through
little arches. <au>Halliwell</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon
house</col>, <cd>a dovecote.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon pea</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the seed of <spn>Cajanus Indicus</spn>; a
kind of pulse used for food in the East and West Indies; also,
the plant itself.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon plum</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the edible drupes of two West African
species of <spn>Chrysobalanus</spn> (<spn>C. ellipticus</spn> and
<spn>C. luteus</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Pigeon tremex</col>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See under <er>Tremex</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pigeon wood</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name in the West
Indies for the wood of several very different kinds of trees,
species of <spn>Dipholis</spn>, <spn>Diospyros</spn>, and
<spn>Coccoloba</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Pigeon woodpecker</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the flicker.</cd> -- <col>Prairie
pigeon</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The upland
plover</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The golden plover</cd>.
<mark>[Local, U.S.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Pig"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pigmentum</ets>, fr. the root of <ets>pingere</ets> to
paint: cf. F. <ets>pigment</ets>. See <er>Paint</er>, and cf.
<er>Pimento</er>, <er>Orpiment</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any
material from which a dye, a paint, or the like, may be prepared;
particularly, the refined and purified coloring matter ready for
mixing with an appropriate vehicle.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Any one of the colored
substances found in animal and vegetable tissues and fluids, as
bilirubin, urobilin, chlorophyll, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Wine flavored with species and honey.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<cs><col>Pigment cell</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>a small
cell containing coloring matter, as the pigmented epithelial
cells of the choroid and iris, or the pigmented connective tissue
cells in the skin of fishes, reptiles, etc.</cd></cs>

slang term for a saddle.</def>

<hw>Pigs"ney</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. a dim.
of Dan. <ets>pige</ets> a girl, or Sw. <ets>piga</ets>; or from
E. <ets>pig's eye</ets>.]</ety> <def>A word of endearment for a
girl or woman.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pigsnie</asp>, <asp>pigsny</asp>, etc.]</altsp>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pig"tail`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Hair Dressing)</fld> <def>A cue, or

<hw>Pig"weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>

<hw>Pig"wid`geon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Written
also <ets>pigwidgin</ets> and <ets>pigwiggen</ets>.]</ety> <def>A
cant word for anything petty or small. It is used by Drayton as
the name of a fairy.</def>

<hw>Pi"ka</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any one of several species of rodents of the genus
<spn>Lagomys</spn>, resembling small tailless rabbits. They
inhabit the high mountains of Asia and America. Called also
<altname>calling hare</altname>, and <altname>crying
hare</altname>. See <er>Chief hare</er>.</def>

<hw>Pike</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pique</ets>; perhaps of Celtic origin; cf. W. <ets>pig</ets>
a prick, a point, beak, Arm. <ets>pik</ets> pick. But cf. also L.
<ets>picus</ets> woodpecker (see <er>Pie</er> magpie), and E.
<ets>spike</ets>. Cf. <er>Pick</er>, <pos>n. & v.</pos>,
<er>Peak</er>, <er>Pique</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A foot soldier's weapon, consisting of a
long wooden shaft or staff, with a pointed steel head. It is now
superseded by the bayonet.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A pointed head or spike; esp., one in the center
of a shield or target.</def>

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A hayfork.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<au>Tusser.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A pick.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Wright. Raymond.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A pointed or peaked hill.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A large haycock.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A turnpike; a toll bar.</def>

<au>Dickens.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <pos>sing. & pl.</pos> <def>A
large fresh-water fish (<spn>Esox lucius</spn>), found in Europe
and America, highly valued as a food fish; -- called also
<altname>pickerel</altname>, <altname>gedd</altname>,
<altname>luce</altname>, and <altname>jack</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Blue pike</xex>, <xex>grass pike</xex>,
<xex>green pike</xex>, <xex>wall-eyed pike</xex>, and <xex>yellow
pike</xex>, are names, not of true pike, but of the wall-eye. See
<er>Wall-eye</er>.</note>

<cs><col>Gar pike</col>. <cd>See under <er>Gar</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pike perch</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any fresh-water
fish of the genus <spn>Stizostedion</spn> (formerly
<spn>Lucioperca</spn>). See <er>Wall-eye</er>, and
<er>Sauger</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pike pole</col>, <cd>a long pole
with a pike in one end, used in directing floating logs.</cd> --
<col>Pike whale</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a finback whale
of the North Atlantic (<spn>Bal\'91noptera rostrata</spn>),
having an elongated snout; -- called also <altname>piked
whale</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Sand pike</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the lizard fish.</cd> -- <col>Sea
pike</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the garfish
<sd>(a)</sd>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi*las"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pilastre</ets>, It. <ets>pilastro</ets>, LL.
<ets>pilastrum</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pila</ets> a pillar. See
<er>Pillar</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>An upright
architectural member right-angled in plan, constructionally a
pier (See <er>Pier</er>, 1 <sd>(b)</sd>), but architecturally
corresponding to a column, having capital, shaft, and base to
agree with those of the columns of the same order. In most cases
the projection from the wall is one third of its width, or
less.</def>

<hw>Pi*las"tered</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Furnished

<hw>Pil"chard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. It.
<ets>pilseir</ets>, W. <ets>pilcod</ets> minnows.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small European food fish
(<spn>Clupea pilchardus</spn>) resembling the herring, but
thicker and rounder. It is sometimes taken in great numbers on
the coast of England.</def>

<q>Fools are as like husbands as <qex>pilchards</qex> are to
herrings.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pilus</ets> hair. Cf. <er>Peruke</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A hair; hence, the fiber of wool, cotton, and the like;
also, the nap when thick or heavy, as of carpeting and
velvet.</def>

<q>Velvet soft, or plush with shaggy <qex>pile</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A covering of hair or
fur.</def>

<hw>Pile</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>pilum</ets> javelin.
See <er>Pile</er> a stake.]</ety> <def>The head of an arrow or
spear.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<hw>Pile</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>p\'c6l</ets> arrow,
stake, L. <ets>pilum</ets> javelin; but cf. also L.
<ets>pila</ets> pillar.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A large stake, or
piece of timber, pointed and driven into the earth, as at the
bottom of a river, or in a harbor where the ground is soft, for
the support of a building, a pier, or other superstructure, or to
form a cofferdam, etc.</def>

<note><hand/ Tubular iron piles are now much used.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pile</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>One of the ordinaries or subordinaries
having the form of a wedge, usually placed palewise, with the
broadest end uppermost.</def>

<cs><col>Pile bridge</col>, <cd>a bridge of which the roadway is
supported on piles.</cd> -- <col>Pile cap</col>, <cd>a beam
resting upon and connecting the heads of piles.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Pile driver</col>, <or/ <col>Pile engine</col></mcol>,
<cd>an apparatus for driving down piles, consisting usually of a
high frame, with suitable appliances for raising to a height (by
animal or steam power, the explosion of gunpowder, etc.) a heavy
mass of iron, which falls upon the pile.</cd> -- <col>Pile
dwelling</col>. <cd>See <cref>Lake dwelling</cref>, under
<er>Lake</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pile plank</col> <fld>(Hydraul.
Eng.)</fld>, <cd>a thick plank used as a pile in sheet piling.
See <cref>Sheet piling</cref>, under <er>Piling</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pneumatic pile</col>. <cd>See under <er>Pneumatic</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Screw pile</col>, <cd>one with a screw at the lower end,
and sunk by rotation aided by pressure.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pile</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To drive piles into; to fill
with piles; to strengthen with piles.</def>

<cs><col>To sheet-pile</col>, <cd>to make sheet piling in or
around. See <cref>Sheet piling</cref>, under 2nd
<er>Piling</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pile</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>pile</ets>, L.
<ets>pila</ets> a pillar, a pier or mole of stone. Cf.
<er>Pillar</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A mass of things heaped
together; a heap; <as>as, a <ex>pile</ex> of stones; a
<ex>pile</ex> of wood.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A mass formed in layers; <as>as, a <ex>pile</ex>
of shot</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A funeral pile; a pyre.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A large building, or mass of buildings.</def>

<q>The <qex>pile</qex> o'erlooked the town and drew the
fight.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Iron Manuf.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Fagot</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>A vertical series of
alternate disks of two dissimilar metals, as copper and zinc,
laid up with disks of cloth or paper moistened with acid water
between them, for producing a current of electricity; -- commonly
called <altname>Volta's pile</altname>, <altname>voltaic
pile</altname>, or <altname>galvanic pile</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The term is sometimes applied to other forms of
apparatus designed to produce a current of electricity, or as
synonymous with <xex>battery</xex>; as, for instance, to an
apparatus for generating a current of electricity by the action
of heat, usually called a <xex>thermopile</xex>.</note>

<sn>7.</sn> <ety>[F. <ets>pile</ets> pile, an engraved die, L.
<ets>pila</ets> a pillar.]</ety> <def>The reverse of a coin. See
<er>Reverse</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Cross and pile</col>. <cd>See under <er>Cross</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Dry pile</col>. <cd>See under <er>Dry</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pile</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Piled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Piling</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay or throw
into a pile or heap; to heap up; to collect into a mass; to
accumulate; to amass; -- often with <xex>up</xex>; <as>as, to
<ex>pile</ex> up wood</as>.</def> \'bdHills <xex>piled</xex> on
hills.\'b8 <au>Dryden</au>. \'bdLife <xex>piled</xex> on
life.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>.

<q>The labor of an age in <qex>piled</qex> stones.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cover with heaps; or in great abundance; to
fill or overfill; to load.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>To pile arms</col> <or/ <col>muskets</col></mcol>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>to place three guns together so that they
may stand upright, supporting each other; to stack
arms.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pi"le*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pi"le*a`ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>pileatus</ets>,
fr. <ets>pileus</ets> a felt cap or hat.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having the form of a cap for the head.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having a crest covering
the pileus, or whole top of the head.</def>

<cs><col>Pileated woodpecker</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
large American woodpecker (<spn>Ceophloeus pileatus</spn>). It is
black, with a bright red pointed crest. Called also
<altname>logcock</altname>, and
<altname>woodcock</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pil"fer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
