<hw>Pil"grim</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pilgrim</ets>, <ets>pelgrim</ets>, <ets>pilegrim</ets>,
<ets>pelegrim</ets>; cf. D. <ets>pelgrim</ets>, OHG.
<ets>piligr\'c6m</ets>, G. <ets>pilger</ets>, F.
<ets>p\'8alerin</ets>, It. <ets>pellegrino</ets>; all fr. L.
<ets>peregrinus</ets> a foreigner, fr. <ets>pereger</ets> abroad;
<ets>per</ets> through + <ets>ager</ets> land, field. See
<er>Per-</er>, and <er>Acre</er>, and cf. <er>Pelerine</er>,
<er>Peregrine</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A wayfarer; a
wanderer; a traveler; a stranger.</def>

<q>Strangers and <qex>pilgrims</qex> on the earth.</q>
<qau>Heb. xi. 13.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who travels far, or in strange lands, to
visit some holy place or shrine as a devotee; <as>as, a
<ex>pilgrim</ex> to Loretto; Canterbury <ex>pilgrims</ex></as>.
See <er>Palmer</er>.</def>

<au>P. Plowman.</au>

<hw>Pil"grim</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to a
pilgrim, or pilgrims; making pilgrimages.</def> \'bdWith
<xex>pilgrim</xex> steps.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<cs><col>Pilgrim fathers</col>, <cd>a name popularly given to the
one hundred and two English colonists who landed from the
Mayflower and made the first settlement in New England at
Plymouth in 1620. They were separatists from the Church of
England, and most of them had sojourned in Holland.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pil"grim</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To journey; to wander;
to ramble.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Grew. Carlyle.</au>

<hw>Pil"grim*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pilgrimage</ets>, <ets>pelgrinage</ets>; cf. F.
<ets>p\'8alerinage</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The journey of
a pilgrim; a long journey; especially, a journey to a shrine or
other sacred place. Fig., the journey of human life.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The days of the years of my <qex>pilgrimage</qex>.</q>
<qau>Gen. xlvii. 9.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A tedious and wearisome time.</def>

<q>In prison hast thou spent a <qex>pilgrimage</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Journey; tour; excursion. See
<er>Journey</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pil"grim*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
wander as a pilgrim; to go on a pilgrimage.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pi*lid"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pildia</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/,
dim. of <?/ a cap.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The
free-swimming, hat-shaped larva of certain nemertean worms. It
has no resemblance to its parent, and the young worm develops in
its interior.</def>

etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. <er>Peel</er>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>Pill</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. L. <ets>pilare</ets> to
deprive of hair, and E. <ets>pill</ets>, n. (above).]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To deprive of hair; to make bald.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To peel; to make by removing the skin.</def>

<q>[Jacob] <qex>pilled</qex> white streaks . . . in the rods.</q>
<qau>Gen. xxx. 37.</qau>

<hw>Pill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pilled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pilling</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[F. <ets>piller</ets>, L. <ets>pilare</ets>; cf. It.
<ets>pigliare</ets> to take. Cf. <er>Peel</er> to plunder.]</ety>
<def>To rob; to plunder; to pillage; to peel. See <er>Peel</er>,
to plunder.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>Pillers and robbers were come in to the field to
<qex>pill</qex> and to rob.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Malroy.</qau>

<hw>Pill</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pilute</ets>, L. <ets>pilula</ets> a pill, little ball, dim.
of L. <ets>pila</ets> a ball. Cf. <er>Piles</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A medicine in the form of a little ball, or
small round mass, to be swallowed whole.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Figuratively, something offensive or nauseous
which must be accepted or endured.</def><-- esp., as bitter pill
-->

<au>Udall.</au>

<cs><col>Pill beetle</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any small
beetle of the genus <spn>Byrrhus</spn>, having a rounded body,
with the head concealed beneath the thorax.</cd> -- <col>Pill
bug</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any terrestrial isopod of
the genus <spn>Armadillo</spn>, having the habit of rolling
itself into a ball when disturbed. Called also <altname>pill wood
louse</altname>.</cd></cs><-- poison pill Fig., anything
accompanying a desirable object or action, which makes it
deleterious to him who accepts it; esp. (Finance) a provision in
the regulations or financial structure (as indebtedness) of a
company which makes the company undesirable as a target for a
hostile takeover -->

<hw>Pil"lage</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
<ets>piller</ets> to plunder. See <er>Pill</er> to
plunder.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of pillaging;
robbery.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is taken from another or others by
open force, particularly and chiefly from enemies in war;
plunder; spoil; booty.</def>

<q>Which <qex>pillage</qex> they with merry march bring home.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Plunder; rapine; spoil; depredation.</syn> <usage>
-- <er>Pillage</er>, <er>Plunder</er>. <xex>Pillage</xex> refers
particularly to the act of stripping the sufferers of their
goods, while <xex>plunder</xex> refers to the removal of the
things thus taken; but the words are freely interchanged.</usage>

<hw>Pil"lage</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pillaged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pillaging</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
strip of money or goods by open violence; to plunder; to spoil;
to lay waste; <as>as, to <ex>pillage</ex> the camp of an
enemy</as>.</def>

<q>Mummius . . . took, <qex>pillaged</qex>, and burnt their
city.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<hw>Pil"lage</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To take spoil; to
plunder; to ravage.</def>

<q>They were suffered to <qex>pillage</qex> wherever they
went.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pil"la*ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pillages.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>Pil"lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>piler</ets>F. <ets>pilier</ets>, LL. <ets>pilare</ets>,
<ets>pilarium</ets>, <ets>pilarius</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pila</ets>
a pillar. See <er>Pile</er> a heap.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
general and popular term for a firm, upright, insulated support
for a superstructure; a pier, column, or post; also, a column or
shaft not supporting a superstructure, as one erected for a
monument or an ornament.</def>

<q>Jacob set a <qex>pillar</qex> upon her grave.</q>
<qau>Gen. xxxv. 20.</qau>

<q>The place . . . vast and proud,
Supported by a hundred <qex>pillars</qex> stood.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Figuratively, that which resembles such a pillar
in appearance, character, or office; a supporter or mainstay;
<as>as, the <ex>Pillars</ex> of Hercules; a <ex>pillar</ex> of
the state.</as></def> \'bdYou are a well-deserving
<xex>pillar</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>By day a cloud, by night a <qex>pillar</qex> of fire.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A portable ornamental
column, formerly carried before a cardinal, as emblematic of his
support to the church.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Skelton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Man.)</fld> <def>The center of the volta, ring,
or manege ground, around which a horse turns.</def>

<cs><col>From pillar to post</col>, <cd>hither and thither; to
and fro; from one place or predicament to another; backward and
forward.</cd> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> -- <col>Pillar saint</col>.
<cd>See <er>Stylite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pillars of the
fauces</col>. <cd>See <er>Fauces</er>, 1.</cd></cs>

supporting a journal, as of a shaft. It is usually bolted to the
frame or foundation of a machine, and is often furnished with
journal boxes, and a movable cover, or cap, for tightening the
bearings by means of bolts; -- called also <altname>pillar
block</altname>, or <altname>plumber block</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Pillow lace</col>, <cd>handmade lace wrought with bobbins
upon a lace pillow.</cd> -- <col>Pillow of a plow</col>, <cd>a
crosspiece of wood which serves to raise or lower the beam.</cd>
-- <col>Pillow sham</col>, <cd>an ornamental covering laid over a
pillow when not in use.</cd> -- <col>Pillow slip</col>, <cd>a
pillowcase.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi"lot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pilote</ets>, prob. from D. <ets>peillood</ets> plummet,
sounding lead; <ets>peilen</ets>, <ets>pegelen</ets>, to sound,
measure (fr. D. & G. <ets>peil</ets>, <ets>pegel</ets>, a sort of
measure, water mark) + <ets>lood</ets> lead, akin to E.
<ets>lead</ets>. The pilot, then, is the <ets>lead</ets> man,
i.e., he who throws the lead. See <er>Pail</er>, and
<er>Lead</er> a metal.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<def>One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a
steersman.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, a person duly qualified, and
licensed by authority, to conduct vessels into and out of a port,
or in certain waters, for a fixed rate of fees.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Figuratively: A guide; a director of another
through a difficult or unknown course.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An instrument for detecting the compass
error.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The cowcatcher of a locomotive.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<cs><col>Pilot balloon</col>, <cd>a small balloon sent up in
advance of a large one, to show the direction and force of the
wind.</cd> -- <col>Pilot bird</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A bird found near the Caribbee Islands; -- so
called because its presence indicates to mariners their approach
to these islands.</cd> <au>Crabb</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The
black-bellied plover.</cd> <mark>[Local, U.S.]</mark> --
<col>Pilot boat</col></mcol>, <cd>a strong, fast-sailing boat
used to carry and receive pilots as they board and leave
vessels.</cd> -- <col>Pilot bread</col>, <cd>ship biscuit.</cd>
-- <col>Pilot cloth</col>, <cd>a coarse, stout kind of cloth for
overcoats.</cd> -- <col>Pilot engine</col>, <cd>a locomotive
going in advance of a train to make sure that the way is
clear.</cd> -- <col>Pilot fish</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A pelagic carangoid fish (<spn>Naucrates
ductor</spn>); -- so named because it is often seen in company
with a shark, swimming near a ship, on account of which sailors
imagine that it acts as a pilot to the shark</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The rudder fish (<spn>Seriola zonata</spn>).</cd> --
<col>Pilot jack</col>, <cd>a flag or signal hoisted by a vessel
for a pilot.</cd> -- <col>Pilot jacket</col>, <cd>a pea
jacket.</cd> -- <col>Pilot nut</col> <fld>(Bridge
Building)</fld>, <cd>a conical nut applied temporarily to the
threaded end of a pin, to protect the thread and guide the pin
when it is driven into a hole. <au>Waddell</au>.</cd> --
<col>Pilot snake</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A
large North American snake (<spn>Coluber obsoleus</spn>). It is
lustrous black, with white edges to some of the scales. Called
also <altname>mountain black snake</altname>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>The pine snake.</cd> -- <col>Pilot whale</col>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>Same as <er>Blackfish</er>,
1.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi"lot</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Piloted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Piloting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>piloter</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To direct the course
of, as of a ship, where navigation is dangerous.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Figuratively: To guide, as through dangers or
difficulties.</def> \'bdThe art of <xex>piloting</xex> a

<au>Berkeley.</au>

<-- to operate (an airlane) -->

<hw>Pi"lot*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pilotage</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The pilot's skill or
knowledge, as of coasts, rocks, bars, and channels.</def>

<au>Sir W. Raleigh.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Guidance, as by a pilot.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<hw>Pim"per*nel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<ets>bipennis</ets>; <ets>bis</ets> twice + <ets>penna</ets>

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A plant of the genus <spn>Anagallis</spn>,
of which one species (<spn>A. arvensis</spn>) has small flowers,

speedily close at the approach of bad weather.</def>

<hw>Pin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Pen</er> to confine, or <er>Pinfold</er>.]</ety> <def>To
inclose; to confine; to pen; to pound.</def>

<hw>Pin</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>pinne</ets>, AS.
<ets>pinn</ets> a pin, peg; cf. D. <ets>pin</ets>, G.
<ets>pinne</ets>, Icel. <ets>pinni</ets>, W. <ets>pin</ets>,
Gael. & Ir. <ets>pinne</ets>; all fr. L. <ets>pinna</ets> a
pinnacle, pin, feather, perhaps orig. a different word from
<ets>pinna</ets> feather. Cf. <er>Fin</er> of a fish,
<er>Pen</er> a feather.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A piece of wood,
metal, etc., generally cylindrical, used for fastening separate
articles together, or as a support by which one article may be
suspended from another; a peg; a bolt.</def>

<q>With <qex>pins</qex> of adamant
And chains they made all fast.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Especially, a small, pointed and headed piece of
brass or other wire (commonly tinned), largely used for fastening
clothes, attaching papers, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence, a thing of small value; a trifle.</def>

<q>He . . . did not care a <qex>pin</qex> for her.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which resembles a pin in its form or
use</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A peg in musical instruments,
for increasing or relaxing the tension of the strings</def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A linchpin</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A
rolling-pin</def>. <sd>(d)</sd> <def>A clothespin</def>.
<sd>(e)</sd> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A short shaft, sometimes
forming a bolt, a part of which serves as a journal</def>. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <cref>Knuckle joint</cref>, under
<er>Knuckle</er>. <sd>(f)</sd> <fld>(Joinery)</fld> <def>The
tenon of a dovetail joint.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>One of a row of pegs in the side of an ancient
drinking cup to mark how much each man should drink.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The bull's eye, or center, of a target; hence,
the center.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe very <xex>pin</xex>
of his heart cleft.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Mood; humor.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdIn
merry <xex>pin</xex>.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Caligo. See
<er>Caligo</er>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>An ornament, as a brooch or badge, fastened to
the clothing by a pin; <as>as, a Masonic <ex>pin</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <def>The leg; <as>as, to knock one off his
<ex>pins</ex></as>.</def> <mark>[Slang]</mark>

<cs><col>Banking pin</col> <fld>(Horol.)</fld>, <cd>a pin against
which a lever strikes, to limit its motion.</cd> -- <col>Pin
drill</col> <fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>a drill with a central pin or
projection to enter a hole, for enlarging the hole, or for
sinking a recess for the head of a bolt, etc.; a
counterbore.</cd> -- <col>Pin grass</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<cd>See <er>Alfilaria</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pin hole</col>, <cd>a
small hole made by a pin; hence, any very small aperture or
perforation.</cd> -- <col>Pin lock</col>, <cd>a lock having a
cylindrical bolt; a lock in which pins, arranged by the key, are
used instead of tumblers.</cd> -- <col>Pin money</col>, <cd>an
allowance of money, as that made by a husband to his wife, for
private and personal expenditure.</cd> -- <col>Pin rail</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a rail, usually within the bulwarks, to
hold belaying pins. Sometimes applied to the <altname>fife
rail</altname>. Called also <altname>pin rack</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Pin wheel</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A contrate wheel in which
the cogs are cylindrical pins</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Fireworks)</fld> <cd>A small coil which revolves on a
common pin and makes a wheel of yellow or colored fire.</cd></cs>
<-- a toy with lightweight, usually brightly colored vanes, as of
plastic, which revolve on a pin at the end of a stick, when acted
on by a wind  -->

<hw>Pin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Pinned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pinning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See <er>Pin</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <def>To fasten with, or as with, a pin; to
join; <as>as, to <ex>pin</ex> a garment; to <ex>pin</ex> boards
together.</as></def> \'bdAa if she would <xex>pin</xex> her to
her heart.</def>\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>To pin one's faith upon</col>, <cd>to depend upon; to
trust to.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi"\'a4a cloth`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A fine material for
ladies' shawls, scarfs, handkerchiefs, etc., made from the fiber
of the pineapple leaf, and perhaps from other fibrous tropical
leaves. It is delicate, soft, and transparent, with a slight
tinge of pale yellow.</def>

<hw>Pin"a*coid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, a tablet + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld>
<def>A plane parallel to two of the crystalline axes.</def>

<hw>Pi*nac"o*lin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pinac</ets>one + L. <ets>ol</ets>eum oil.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A colorless oily liquid related to the
ketones, and obtained by the decomposition of pinacone; hence, by
extension, any one of the series of which pinacolin proper is the
type.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>pinacoline</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pin"a*cone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From Gr.
<?/, <?/, a tablet. So called because it unites with water so as
to form tablet-shaped crystals.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A
white crystalline substance related to the glycols, and made from
acetone; hence, by extension, any one of a series of substances
of which pinacone proper is the type.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pinakone</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pin"cers</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>Pinch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pinched</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pinching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>pincer</ets>,
probably fr. OD. <ets>pitsen</ets> to pinch; akin to G.
<ets>pfetzen</ets> to cut, pinch; perhaps of Celtic origin. Cf.
<er>Piece</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To press hard or squeeze
between the ends of the fingers, between teeth or claws, or
between the jaws of an instrument; to squeeze or compress, as
between any two hard bodies.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>o seize; to grip; to bite; -- said of
animals.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He [the hound] <qex>pinched</qex> and pulled her down.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To plait.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Full seemly her wimple <qex>ipinched</qex> was.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Figuratively: To cramp; to straiten; to oppress;
to starve; to distress; <as>as, to be <ex>pinched</ex> for
money</as>.</def>

<q>Want of room . . . <qex>pinching</qex> a whole nation.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To move, as a railroad car, by prying the wheels
with a pinch. See <er>Pinch</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 4.</def>

<hw>Pinch</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To act with
pressing force; to compress; to squeeze; <as>as, the shoe
<ex>pinches</ex></as>.\'b8

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Hunt.)</fld> <def>To take hold; to grip, as a
dog does.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To spare; to be niggardly; to be covetous.</def>

<au>Gower.</au>

<q>The wretch whom avarice bids to <qex>pinch</qex> and
spare.</q>
<qau>Franklin.</qau>

<cs><col>To pinch at</col>, <cd>to find fault with; to take
exception to. <mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pinch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A close
compression, as with the ends of the fingers, or with an
instrument; a nip.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>As much as may be taken between the finger and
thumb; any very small quantity; <as>as, a <ex>pinch</ex> of
snuff</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Pian; pang.</def> \'bdNecessary's sharp
<xex>pinch</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A lever having a projection at one end, acting
as a fulcrum, -- used chiefly to roll heavy wheels, etc. Called
also <altname>pinch bar</altname>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>At a pinch</col>, <col>On a pinch</col></mcol>,
<cd>in an emergency; <as>as, he could <ex>on a pinch<ex> read a
little Latin</as>.</cd><-- in a pinch --></cs>

<hw>Pinch"beck</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Said to be
from the name of the inventor; cf. It.
<ets>prencisbecco</ets>.]</ety> <def>An alloy of copper and zinc,
resembling gold; a yellow metal, composed of about three ounces
of zinc to a pound of copper. It is much used as an imitation of
gold in the manufacture of cheap jewelry.</def>

<hw>Pinch"beck</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Made of pinchbeck; sham;
cheap; spurious; unreal.</def> \'bdA <xex>pinchbeck</xex>
throne.\'b8

<au>J. A. Symonds.</au>

<hw>Pinch"ers</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[From

to be held fast, drawing nails, etc.</def>

<note><hand/ This spelling is preferable to <xex>pincers</xex>,
both on account of its derivation from the English
<xex>pinch</xex>, and because it represents the common
pronunciation.</note>

<er>Pining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>p\'c6nan</ets> to
torment, fr. <ets>p\'c6n</ets> torment. See 1st <er>Pine</er>,
<er>Pain</er>, <pos>n.</pos> & <pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To inflict pain upon; to torment; to torture; to
afflict.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer. Shak.</au>

<q>That people that <qex>pyned</qex> him to death.</q>
<qau>Piers Plowman.</qau>

<q>One is <qex>pined</qex> in prison, another tortured on the
rack.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To grieve or mourn for.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pine</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To suffer; to be
afflicted.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To languish; to lose flesh or wear away, under
any distress or anexiety of mind; to droop; -- often used with
<xex>away</xex>.</def> \'bdThe roses wither and the lilies
<xex>pine</xex>.\'b8

<au>Tickell.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To languish with desire; to waste away with
longing for something; -- usually followed by
<xex>for</xex>.</def>

<q>For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet <qex>pined</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To languish; droop; flag; wither; decay.</syn>

<hw>Pine</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>p\'c6n</ets>, L.
<ets>pinus</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any
tree of the coniferous genus <spn>Pinus</spn>. See
<er>Pinus</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ There are about twenty-eight species in the United
States, of which the <stype>white pine</stype> (<spn>P.
Strobus</spn>), the <stype>Georgia pine</stype> (<spn>P.
australis</spn>), the <stype>red pine</stype> (<spn>P.
resinosa</spn>), and the great West Coast <stype>sugar
pine</stype> (<spn>P. Lambertiana</spn>) are among the most
valuable. The <stype>Scotch pine</stype> or <stype>fir</stype>,
also called <altname>Norway</altname> or <altname>Riga
pine</altname> (<spn>Pinus sylvestris</spn>), is the only British
species. The <stype>nut pine</stype> is any pine tree, or species
of pine, which bears large edible seeds. See <er>Pinon</er>.

    The spruces, firs, larches, and true cedars, though formerly
considered pines, are now commonly assigned to other
genera.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The wood of the pine tree.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A pineapple.</def>

<cs><col>Ground pine</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Ground</er>.</cd> -- <col>Norfolk Island pine</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a beautiful coniferous tree, the
<spn>Araucaria excelsa</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Pine barren</col>,
<cd>a tract of infertile land which is covered with pines.</cd>
<mark>[Southern U.S.]</mark> -- <col>Pine borer</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any beetle whose larv\'91 bore into
pine trees.</cd> -- <col>Pine finch</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<cd>See <er>Pinefinch</er>, in the Vocabulary.</cd> -- <col>Pine
grosbeak</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large grosbeak
(<spn>Pinicola enucleator</spn>), which inhabits the northern
parts of both hemispheres. The adult male is more or less tinged
with red.</cd> -- <col>Pine lizard</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a small, very active, mottled gray lizard (<spn>Sceloporus
undulatus</spn>), native of the Middle States; -- called also
<altname>swift</altname>, <altname>brown scorpion</altname>, and
<altname>alligator</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Pine marten</col>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A European weasel
(<spn>Mustela martes</spn>), called also <altname>sweet
marten</altname>, and <altname>yellow-breasted
marten</altname>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The American sable. See
<er>Sable</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pine moth</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of small
tortricid moths of the genus <spn>Retinia</spn>, whose larv\'91
burrow in the ends of the branchlets of pine trees, often doing
great damage.</cd> -- <col>Pine mouse</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an American wild mouse (<spn>Arvicola
pinetorum</spn>), native of the Middle States. It lives in pine
forests.</cd> -- <col>Pine needle</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>one of the slender needle-shaped leaves of a pine tree. See
<er>Pinus</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pine-needle wool</col>. <cd>See
<cref>Pine wool</cref> (below).</cd> -- <col>Pine oil</col>,
<cd>an oil resembling turpentine, obtained from fir and pine
trees, and used in making varnishes and colors.</cd> -- <col>Pine
snake</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large harmless North
American snake (<spn>Pituophis melanoleucus</spn>). It is
whitish, covered with brown blotches having black margins. Called
also <altname>bull snake</altname>. The Western pine snake
(<spn>P. Sayi</spn>) is chestnut-brown, mottled with black and
orange.</cd> -- <col>Pine tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a
tree of the genus <spn>Pinus</spn>; pine.</cd> -- <col>Pine-tree
money</col>, <cd>money coined in Massachusetts in the seventeenth
century, and so called from its bearing a figure of a pine
tree.</cd> -- <col>Pine weevil</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>any one of numerous species of weevils whose larv\'91 bore in
the wood of pine trees. Several species are known in both Europe
and America, belonging to the genera <spn>Pissodes</spn>,
<spn>Hylobius</spn>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Pine wool</col>, <cd>a
fiber obtained from pine needles by steaming them. It is prepared
on a large scale in some of the Southern United States, and has
many uses in the economic arts; -- called also
<altname>pine-needle wool</altname>, and <altname>pine-wood
wool</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi"ne*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pinea</ets> the cone of a pine, from <ets>pineus</ets> of
the pine, from <ets>pinus</ets> a pine: cf. F.
<ets>pin\'82ale</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to a pine
cone; resembling a pine cone.</def>

<cs><col>Pineal gland</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>a glandlike
body in the roof of the third ventricle of the vertebrate brain;
-- called also <altname>pineal body</altname>,
<altname>epiphysis</altname>, <altname>conarium</altname>. In
some animals it is connected with a rudimentary eye, the
so-called <xex>pineal eye<xex>, and in other animals it is
supposed to be the remnant of a dorsal median eye.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1088 -->

<hw>Pine"ap`ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A tropical plant (<spn>Ananassa
sativa</spn>); also, its fruit; -- so called from the resemblance
of the latter, in shape and external appearance, to the cone of
the pine tree. Its origin is unknown, though conjectured to be
American.</def>

<hw>Pine`as"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pinaster</er>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pine"-clad`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pine"-crowned`</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Clad or crowned with
pine trees; <as>as, <ex>pine-clad</ex> hills</as>.</def>

<hw>Pine"drops`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A reddish herb (<spn>Pterospora
andromedea</spn>) of the United States, found parasitic on the
roots of pine trees.</def>

<hw>Pine"finch`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A small American bird
(<spn>Spinus, <or/ Chrysomitris, spinus</spn>); -- called also
<altname>pine siskin</altname>, and <altname>American
siskin</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The pine
grosbeak.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi*nen"chy*ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ a tablet + <ets>-enchyma</ets>, as in
<ets>parenchyma</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Tabular
parenchyma, a form of cellular tissue in which the cells are
broad and flat, as in some kinds of epidermis.</def>

<hw>Pin"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pineries</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A pine
forest; a grove of pines.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A hothouse in which pineapples are grown.</def>

<hw>Pine"sap`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A reddish fleshy herb of the genus <spn>Monotropa</spn>
(<spn>M. hypopitys</spn>), formerly thought to be parasitic on
the roots of pine trees, but more probably saprophytic.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi*ne"tum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
pine grove.]</ety> <def>A plantation of pine trees; esp., a
collection of living pine trees made for ornamental or scientific
purposes.</def>

<hw>Pine"weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A low, bushy, nearly leafless herb (<spn>Hypericum
Sarothra</spn>), common in sandy soil in the Eastern United
States.</def>

<hw>Pin"ey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Piny</er>.</def>

<hw>Pin"ey</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Of East Indian
origin.]</ety> <def>A term used in designating an East Indian
tree (the <spn>Vateria Indica</spn> or piney tree, of the order
<spn>Dipterocarpe\'91</spn>, which grows in Malabar, etc.) or its
products.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Piney dammar</col>, <col>Piney resin</col>,
<col>Piney varnish</col></mcol>, <cd>a pellucid, fragrant, acrid,
bitter resin, which exudes from the piney tree (<spn>Vateria
Indica</spn>) when wounded. It is used as a varnish, in making
candles, and as a substitute for incense and for amber. Called
also <altname>liquid copal</altname>, and <altname>white
dammar</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Piney tallow</col>, <cd>a solid
fatty substance, resembling tallow, obtained from the roasted
seeds of the <spn>Vateria Indica</spn>; called also
<altname>dupada oil</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Piney thistle</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a plant (<spn>Atractylis gummifera</spn>),
from the bark of which, when wounded, a gummy substance
exudes.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pin"-eyed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Having the stigma visible at the throad of a gamopetalous
corolla, while the stamens are concealed in the tube; -- said of
dimorphous flowers. The opposite of <ant>thrum-eyed</ant>.</def>

<hw>Pin"feath`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A feather
not fully developed; esp., a rudimentary feather just emerging
through the skin.</def>

<hw>Pin"feath`ered</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
part, or all, of the feathers imperfectly developed.</def>

<hw>Pin"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called
from their sharp dorsal spines.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The sailor's choice (<spn>Diplodus, <or/
Lagodon, rhomboides</spn>).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
salt-water bream (<spn>Diplodus Holbrooki</spn>).</def>

<note><hand/ Both are excellent food fishes, common on the coast
of the United States south of Cape Hatteras. The name is also
applied to other allied species.</note>

<hw>Pin"fold`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>pindfold</ets>. See <er>Pinder</er>, <er>Pound</er> an
inclosure, and <er>Fold</er> an inclosure.]</ety> <def>A place in
which stray cattle or domestic animals are confined; a pound; a
penfold.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>A parish <qex>pinfold</qex> begirt by its high hedge.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

imitative origin.]</ety> <def>The sound made by a bullet in
striking a solid object or in passing through the air.</def>

<hw>Pi"nic</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pinus</ets> pine.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Of or
pertaining to the pine; obtained from the pine; formerly,
designating an acid which is the chief constituent of common
resin, -- now called <xex>abietic</xex>, or <xex>sylvic</xex>,
<xex>acid</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pin"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Languishing; drooping; wasting away, as with longing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wasting; consuming.</def> \'bdThe

droopingly.</def>

<au>Poe.</au>

<hw>Pin"ion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A moth of the genus
<spn>Lithophane</spn>, as <spn>L. antennata</spn>, whose larva
bores large holes in young peaches and apples.</def>

<hw>Pin"ion</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>pignon</ets> a
pen, F., gable, pinion (in sense 5); cf. Sp. <ets>pi\'a4on</ets>
pinion; fr. L. <ets>pinna</ets> pinnacle, feather, wing. See
<er>Pin</er> a peg, and cf. <er>Pen</er> a feather,
<er>Pennat</er>, <er>Pennon</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
feather; a quill.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A wing, literal or figurative.</def>

<q>Swift on his sooty <qex>pinions</qex> flits the gnome.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The joint of bird's wing most remote from the
body.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A fetter for the arm.</def>

<au>Ainsworth.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A cogwheel with a small
number of teeth, or leaves, adapted to engage with a larger
wheel, or rack (see <er>Rack</er>); esp., such a wheel having its
leaves formed of the substance of the arbor or spindle which is
its axis.</def>

<cs><col>Lantern pinion</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Lantern</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pinion wire</col>, <cd>wire fluted
longitudinally, for making the pinions of clocks and watches. It
is formed by being drawn through holes of the shape required for
the leaves or teeth of the pinions.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pin"ion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pinioned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pinioning</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bind or
confine the wings of; to confine by binding the wings.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To disable by cutting off the pinion
joint.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To disable or restrain, as a person, by binding
the arms, esp. by binding the arms to the body.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Her elbows <qex>pinioned</qex> close upon her hips.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Hence, generally, to confine; to bind; to tie
up.</def> \'bd<xex>Pinioned</xex> up by formal rules of
state.\'b8

<au>Norris.</au>

<hw>Pin"ioned</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having wings
or pinions.</def>

<hw>Pin"ion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any winged creature.</def>

<hw>Pin"ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called from
<ets>Pini</ets>, a mine in Saxony.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>A compact granular cryptocrystalline mineral of a dull
grayish or greenish white color. It is a hydrous alkaline
silicate, and is derived from the alteration of other minerals,
as iolite.</def>

<hw>Pi"nite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pinus</ets> the pine tree.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>(Paleon.)
Any fossil wood which exhibits traces of having belonged to the
Pine family.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A sweet white crystalline
substance extracted from the gum of a species of pine (<spn>Pinus
Lambertina</spn>). It is isomeric with, and resembles,
quercite.</def>

<hw>Pink</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[D.
<ets>pink</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A vessel with a
very narrow stern; -- called also <altname>pinky</altname>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<cs><col>Pink stern</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a narrow
stern.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pink</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[D. <ets>pinken</ets>,
<ets>pinkoogen</ets>, to blink, twinkle with the eyes.]</ety>
<def>To wink; to blink.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>L'Estrange.</au>

<hw>Pink</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Half-shut; winking.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pink</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pinked</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pinking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>pinken</ets> to
prick, probably a nasalized form of <ets>pick</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pierce with small holes; to cut the edge of,
as cloth or paper, in small scallops or angles.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To stab; to pierce as with a sword.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To choose; to cull; to pick out.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Herbert.</au>

<hw>Pink</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A stab.</def>

<au>Grose.</au>

<hw>Pink</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. akin to <ets>pick</ets>;
as if the edges of the petals were picked out. Cf. <er>Pink</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A name
given to several plants of the caryophyllaceous genus
<spn>Dianthus</spn>, and to their flowers, which are sometimes
very fragrant and often double in cultivated varieties. The
species are mostly perennial herbs, with opposite linear leaves,
and handsome five-petaled flowers with a tubular calyx.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A color resulting from the combination of a pure
vivid red with more or less white; -- so called from the common
color of the flower.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Anything supremely excellent; the embodiment or
perfection of something.</def> \'bdThe very <xex>pink</xex> of
courtesy.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The European minnow; -- so
called from the color of its abdomen in summer.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<cs><col>Bunch pink</col><cd> is <spn>Dianthus
barbatus</spn>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>China</col>, <or/
<col>Indian</col>, <col>pink</col></mcol>. <cd>See under
<er>China</er>.</cd> -- <col>Clove pink</col><cd> is
<spn>Dianthus Caryophyllus</spn>, the stock from which carnations
are derived.</cd> -- <col>Garden pink</col>. <cd>See
<er>Pheasant's eye</er>.</cd> -- <col>Meadow pink</col><cd> is
applied to <spn>Dianthus deltoides</spn>; also, to the ragged
robin.</cd> -- <col>Maiden pink</col>, <cd><spn>Dianthus
deltoides</spn>.</cd> -- <col>Moss pink</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Moss</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pink needle</col>, <cd>the pin grass;
-- so called from the long, tapering points of the carpels. See
<er>Alfilaria</er>.</cd> -- <col>Sea pink</col>. <cd>See
<er>Thrift</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pink</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Resembling the garden pink in
color; of the color called <xex>pink</xex> (see 6th
<er>Pink</er>, 2); <as>as, a <ex>pink</ex> dress; <ex>pink</ex>
ribbons.</as></def>

<cs><col>Pink eye</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a popular name for
an epidemic variety of ophthalmia, associated with early and
marked redness of the eyeball.</cd> -- <col>Pink salt</col>
<fld>(Chem. & Dyeing)</fld>, <cd>the double chlorides of
(stannic) tin and ammonium, formerly much used as a mordant for
madder and cochineal.</cd> -- <col>Pink saucer</col>, <cd>a small
saucer, the inner surface of which is covered with a pink
pigment.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pinked</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pierced with
small holes; worked in eyelets; scalloped on the edge.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<def>Having small eyes.</def>

<hw>Pink"root`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

Marilandica</spn>, used as a powerful vermifuge; also, that of

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A perennial North

cultivated for its showy red blossoms. Called also
<altname>Carolina pink</altname>, <altname>Maryland
pinkroot</altname>, and <altname>worm grass</altname>.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>An annual South American and West Indian plant

<hw>\'d8Pin"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

divisions of a decompound leaf.</def>

pinnate part or organ.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[L. <ets>pinna</ets>, akin to Gr. <?/.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of <spn>Pinna</spn>, a
genus of large bivalve mollusks found in all warm seas. The
byssus consists of a large number of long, silky fibers, which
have been used in manufacturing woven fabrics, as a
curiosity.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The auricle of the ear. See
<er>Ear</er>.</def>

<hw>Pin"nace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pinasse</ets>; cf. It. <ets>pinassa</ets>,

<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A small vessel propelled by

boat.</def>

<qau>Shak.</qau>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Pin"na*cle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pinacle</ets>, F. <ets>pinacle</ets>, L.
<ets>pinnaculum</ets>, fr. <ets>pinna</ets> pinnacle, feather.
See <er>Pin</er> a peg.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<def>An architectural member, upright, and generally ending in a
small spire, -- used to finish a buttress, to constitute a part
in a proportion, as where pinnacles flank a gable or spire, and
the like. Pinnacles may be considered primarily as added weight,
where it is necessary to resist the thrust of an arch, etc.</def>

<q>Some renowned metropolis
With glistering spires and <qex>pinnacles</qex> around.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything resembling a pinnacle; a lofty peak; a
pointed summit.</def>

<q>Three silent <qex>pinnacles</qex> of aged snow.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<q>The slippery tops of human state,
The gilded <qex>pinnacles</qex> of fate.</q>
<qau>Cowley.</qau>

<hw>Pin"na*cle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pinnacled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pinnacling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To
build or furnish with a pinnacle or pinnacles.</def>

<au>T. Warton.</au>

<hw>Pin"tail`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A northern duck (<spn>Dafila
acuta</spn>), native of both continents. The adult male has a
long, tapering tail. Called also <altname>gray duck</altname>,
<altname>piketail</altname>, <altname>piket-tail</altname>,
<altname>spike-tail</altname>, <altname>split-tail</altname>,
<altname>springtail</altname>, <altname>sea pheasant</altname>,
and <altname>gray widgeon</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The sharp-tailed grouse of
the great plains and Rocky Mountains (<spn>Pedioc\'91tes
phasianellus</spn>); -- called also <altname>pintailed
grouse</altname>, <altname>pintailed chicken</altname>,
<altname>springtail</altname>, and
<altname>sharptail</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pin"tos</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>; <sing>sing.

<hw>\'d8Pi"nus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a pine
tree.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A large genus of evergreen
coniferous trees, mostly found in the northern hemisphere. The
genus formerly included the firs, spruces, larches, and hemlocks,
but is now limited to those trees which have the primary leaves
of the branchlets reduced to mere scales, and the secondary ones
(<xex>pine needles</xex>) acicular, and usually in fascicles of
two to seven. See <er>Pine</er>.</def>

<hw>Pin"weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Any plant of the genus <spn>Lechea</spn>, low North American
herbs with branching stems, and very small and abundant leaves
and flowers.</def>

<hw>Pin"worm`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small nematoid worm (<spn>Oxyurus
vermicularis</spn>), which is parasitic chiefly in the rectum of
man. It is most common in children and aged persons.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pinx"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L., perfect indicative
3d sing. of <ets>pingere</ets> to paint.]</ety> <def>A word
appended to the artist's name or initials on a painting, or

<hw>Pi`o*neer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>Pi"ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pieux</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to piety; exhibiting piety; reverential;
dutiful; religious; devout; godly.</def> \'bd<xex>Pious</xex>
hearts.\'b8 <au>Milton</au>. \'bd<xex>Pious</xex> poetry.\'b8
<au>Johnson</au>.

<q>Where was the martial brother's <qex>pious</qex> care?</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Practiced under the pretext of religion;
prompted by mistaken piety; <as>as, <ex>pious</ex> errors;
<ex>pious</ex> frauds.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Godly; devout; religious; righteous.</syn>

<hw>Pi"ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pious manner.</def>

<hw>Pip</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pippe</ets>, D. <ets>pip</ets>, or F. <ets>p\'82pie</ets>;
from LL. <ets>pipita</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pituita</ets> slime,
phlegm, rheum, in fowls, the pip. Cf. <er>Pituite</er>.]</ety>
<def>A contagious disease of fowls, characterized by hoarseness,
discharge from the nostrils and eyes, and an accumulation of
mucus in the mouth, forming a \'bdscale\'b8 on the tongue. By
some the term <xex>pip</xex> is restricted to this last symptom,
the disease being called <xex>roup</xex> by them.</def>

<hw>Pip</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Formerly <ets>pippin</ets>,
<ets>pepin</ets>. Cf. <er>Pippin</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A seed, as of an apple or orange.</def>

<hw>Pip</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perh. for <ets>pick</ets>, F.
<ets>pique</ets> a spade at cards, a pike. Cf.
<er>Pique</er>.]</ety> <def>One of the conventional figures or
\'bdspots\'b8 on playing cards, dominoes, etc.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Pip</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pipped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pipping</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See <er>Peep</er>.]</ety>
<def>To cry or chirp, as a chicken; to peep.</def>

<q>To hear the chick <qex>pip</qex> and cry in the egg.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<hw>Pi*pa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pipas</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The Surinam toad (<spn>Pipa Americana</spn>), noted for its
peculiar breeding habits.</def>

<note><hand/ The male places the eggs on the back of the female,
where they soon become inclosed in capsules formed by the
thickening of the skin. The incubation of the eggs takes place in
the capsules, and the young, when hatched, come forth with well
developed legs.</note>

<hw>Pip"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Transportation,
as of petroleum oil, by means of a pipe conduit; also, the charge
for such transportation.</def>

<hw>Pi"pal tree`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>Same as <er>Peepul
tree</er>.</def>

<hw>Pipe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>p\'c6pe</ets>, probably fr. L. <ets>pipare</ets>,
<ets>pipire</ets>, to chirp; of imitative origin. Cf.
<er>Peep</er>, <er>Pibroch</er>, <er>Fife</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A wind instrument of music, consisting of a tube
or tubes of straw, reed, wood, or metal; any tube which produces
musical sounds; <as>as, a shepherd's <ex>pipe</ex>; the
<ex>pipe</ex> of an organ.</as></def> \'bdTunable as sylvan
<xex>pipe</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>Now had he rather hear the tabor and the <qex>pipe</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any long tube or hollow body of wood, metal,
earthenware, or the like: especially, one used as a conductor of
water, steam, gas, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A small bowl with a hollow steam, -- used in
smoking tobacco, and, sometimes, other substances.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A passageway for the air in speaking and
breathing; the windpipe, or one of its divisions.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The key or sound of the voice.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The peeping whistle, call, or note of a
bird.</def>

<q>The earliest <qex>pipe</qex> of half-awakened birds.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>The bagpipe; <as>as, the
<ex>pipes</ex> of Lucknow</as>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>An elongated body or vein of
ore.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>A roll formerly used in the English exchequer,
otherwise called the <xex>Great Roll</xex>, on which were taken
down the accounts of debts to the king; -- so called because put
together like a pipe.</def>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A boatswain's whistle, used
to call the crew to their duties; also, the sound of it.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pipe</ets>, fr. <ets>pipe</ets> a
wind instrument, a tube, fr. L. <ets>pipare</ets> to chirp. See
Etymol. above.]</ety> <def>A cask usually containing two
hogsheads, or 126 wine gallons; also, the quantity which it
contains.</def>

<cs><col>Pipe fitter</col>, <cd>one who fits pipes together, or
applies pipes, as to an engine or a building.</cd> -- <col>Pipe
fitting</col>, <cd>a piece, as a coupling, an elbow, a valve,
etc., used for connecting lengths of pipe or as accessory to a
pipe.</cd> -- <col>Pipe office</col>, <cd>an ancient office in
the Court of Exchequer, in which the clerk of the pipe made out
leases of crown lands, accounts of cheriffs, etc.</cd>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Pipe tree</col></mcol>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the lilac and the mock orange; -- so
called because their were formerly used to make pipe stems; --
called also <altname>pipe privet</altname>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Pipe wrench</col>, <or/ <col>Pipetongs</col></mcol>,
<cd>a jawed tool for gripping a pipe, in turning or holding
it.</cd> -- <col>To smoke the pipe of peace</col>, <cd>to smoke
from the same pipe in token of amity or preparatory to making a
treaty of peace, -- a custom of the American Indians.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pipe</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To play on a
pipe, fife, flute, or other tubular wind instrument of
music.</def>

<q>We have <qex>piped</qex> unto you, and ye have not danced.</q>
<qau>Matt. xi. 17.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To call, convey orders, etc.,
by means of signals on a pipe or whistle carried by a
boatswain.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To emit or have a shrill sound like that of a
pipe; to whistle.</def> \'bdOft in the <xex>piping</xex>
shrouds.\'b8

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Metal.)</fld> <def>To become hollow in the
process of solodifying; -- said of an ingot, as of steel.</def>

<hw>Pipe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Piped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Piping</er>.]</wordforms>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To perform, as a tune, by playing on a pipe,
flute, fife, etc.; to utter in the shrill tone of a pipe.</def>

<q>A robin . . . was <qex>piping</qex> a few querulous notes.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To call or direct, as a crew,
by the boatswain's whistle.</def>

<q>As fine a ship's company as was ever <qex>piped</qex>
aloft.</q>
<qau>Marryat.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To furnish or equip with pipes; <as>as, to
<ex>pipe</ex> an engine, or a building</as>.</def>

<hw>Pipe" clay`</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr> <def>A plastic, unctuous clay
of a grayish white color, -- used in making tobacco pipes and
various kinds of earthenware, in scouring cloth, and in cleansing
soldiers' equipments.</def>

<hw>Pipe"clay`</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To whiten
or clean with pipe clay, as a soldier's accouterments.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To clear off; <as>as, to <ex>pipeclay</ex>
accounts</as>.</def> <mark>[Slang, Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Piped</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Formed with a
pipe; having pipe or pipes; tubular.</def>

<hw>Pipe"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any lophobranch fish of the genus
<spn>Siphostoma</spn>, or <spn>Syngnathus</spn>, and allied
genera, having a long and very slender angular body, covered with
bony plates. The mouth is small, at the end of a long, tubular
snout. The male has a pouch on his belly, in which the incubation
of the eggs takes place.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Polit. Cant)</fld> <def>A politician who works
in secret; -- in this sense, usually written as one word.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Polit. Cant)</fld> <def>The act or method of

in this sense, usually written as one word.</def>

<hw>Pip`er*a"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

which the pepper (<spn>Piper nigrum</spn>) is the type. There are
about a dozen genera and a thousand species, mostly tropical

<hw>Pi*per"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>

<hw>Pi*per"i*dine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An oily liquid alkaloid,
<chform>C5H11N</chform>, having a hot, peppery, ammoniacal odor.
It is related to pyridine, and is obtained by the decomposition
of piperine.</def>

<hw>Pip"er*ine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>piper</ets> pepper: cf. F. <ets>piperin</ets>,
<ets>piperine</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A white
crystalline compound of piperidine and piperic acid. It is
obtained from the black pepper (<spn>Piper nigrum</spn>) and
other species.</def>

<hw>Pip`er*o"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A white crystalline substance obtained by
oxidation of piperic acid, and regarded as a complex
aldehyde.</def>

<hw>Pi*per"y*lene</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Piper</ets>idine + acet<ets>ylene</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A hydrocarbon obtained by decomposition
of certain piperidine derivatives.</def>

<hw>Pip"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Pipe</er>, <pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Playing on a
musical pipe.</def> \'bdLowing herds and <xex>piping

music of the pipe rather than of the drum and fife.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Emitting a high, shrill sound.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Simmering; boiling; sizzling; hissing; -- from
the sound of boiling fluids.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Piping crow</col>, <col>Piping crow shrike</col>,
<col>Piping roller</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
Australian bird of the genus <spn>Gymnorhina</spn>, esp. <spn>G.
tibicen</spn>, which is black and white, and the size of a small
crow. Called also <altname>caruck</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Piping
frog</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small American tree frog
(<spn>Hyla Pickeringii</spn>) which utters a high, shrill note in
early spring.</cd> -- <col>Piping hot</col>, <cd>boiling hot;
hissing hot; very hot. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pip"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A small cord
covered with cloth, -- used as trimming for women's
dresses.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pipes, collectively; <as>as, the <ex>piping</ex>
of a house</as>.</def>

of birds, etc.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A piece cut off to be set or planted; a cutting;
also, propagation by cuttings.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pi*pis"trel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pip`i*strelle"</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pipistrelle</ets>, It. <ets>pipistrello</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small European bat (<spn>Vesperugo
pipistrellus</spn>); -- called also
<altname>flittermouse</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pip"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So named from
its call note.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of
numerous species of small singing birds belonging to
<spn>Anthus</spn> and allied genera, of the family
<spn>Motacillid\'91</spn>. They strongly resemble the true larks
in habits, colors, and the great length of the hind claw. They
are, therefore, often called <altname>titlarks</altname>, and
<altname>pipit larks</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The <stype>meadow pipit</stype> (<spn>Anthus
pratensis</spn>); the <stype>tree pipit</stype>, or tree lark
(<spn>A. trivialis</spn>); and the <stype>rock pipit</stype>, or
sea lark (<spn>A. obscurus</spn>) are well-known European
species. The common American <xex>pipit</xex>, or brown lark, is
<spn>Anthus Pensilvanicus</spn>. The Western species (<spn>A.
Spraguei</spn>) is called the <stype>American skylark</stype>, on
account of its musical powers.</note>

<hw>Pip"kin</hw>, <pos>n.</pos><ety>[Dim. of
<er>Pipe</er>.]</ety> <def>A small earthen boiler.</def>

<hw>Pip"pin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably fr.
OE. <ets>pippin</ets> a seed, as being raised from the seed. See
<er>Pip</er> a seed.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>An apple from a tree raised from the seed and not grafted; a
seedling apple.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A name given to apples of
several different kinds, as <xex>Newtown pippin</xex>,
<xex>summer pippin</xex>, <xex>fall pippin</xex>, <xex>golden
pippin</xex>.</def>

<q>We will eat a last year's <qex>pippin</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Normandy pippins</col>, <cd>sun-dried apples for winter
use.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi"pra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pipras</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a
woodpecker.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of numerous
species of small clamatorial birds belonging to <spn>Pipra</spn>
and allied genera, of the family <spn>Piprid\'91</spn>. The male
is usually glossy black, varied with scarlet, yellow, or sky
blue. They chiefly inhabit South America.</def>

<hw>Pip*sis"se*wa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From

blossoms. It has been used in nephritic diseases. Called also

<au>Keats.</au>

<hw>Pi"quan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

<hw>Pi"quant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., p.pr. of
<ets>piquer</ets> to prick or sting. See <er>Pike</er>.]</ety>
<def>Stimulating to the taste; giving zest; tart; sharp; pungent;

<xex>piquant</xex> to the tongue as salt.\'b8 <au>Addison</au>.
\'bd<xex>Piquant</xex> railleries.\'b8 <au>Gov. of Tongue</au>.

<hw>Pi"quant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a piquant
manner.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi`qu\'82"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,
p.p. of <ets>piquer</ets> to prick.]</ety> <def>A cotton fabric,
figured in the loom, -- used as a dress goods for women and
children, and for vestings, etc.</def>

<hw>Pique</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The jigger. See <er>Jigger</er>.</def>

<hw>Pique</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
<ets>piquer</ets>. See <er>Pike</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
feeling of hurt, vexation, or resentment, awakened by a social
slight or injury; irritation of the feelings, as through wounded
pride; stinging vexation.</def>

<q>Men take up <qex>piques</qex> and displeasures.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<q>Wars had arisen . . . upon a personal <qex>pique</qex>.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Keenly felt desire; a longing.</def>

<q>Though it have the <qex>pique</qex>, and long,
'Tis still for something in the wrong.</q>
<qau>Hudibras.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Card Playing)</fld> <def>In piquet, the right
of the elder hand to count thirty in hand, or to play before the
adversary counts one.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Displeasure; irritation; grudge; spite.</syn>
<usage> <er>Pique</er>, <er>Spite</er>, <er>Grudge</er>.
<xex>Pique</xex> denotes a quick and often transient sense of
resentment for some supposed neglect or injury, but it is not
marked by malevolence. <xex>Spite</xex> is a stronger term,
denoting settled ill will or malice, with a desire to injure, as
the result of extreme irritation. <xex>Grudge</xex> goes still
further, denoting cherished and secret enmity, with an
unforgiving spirit. A <xex>pique</xex> is usually of recent date;
a <xex>grudge</xex> is that which has long subsisted;
<xex>spite</xex> implies a disposition to cross or vex
others.</usage>

<hw>Pique</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Piqued</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Piquing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>piquer</ets>. See <er>Pike</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
wound the pride of; to sting; to nettle; to irritate; to fret; to
offend; to excite to anger.</def>

<q><qex>Pique</qex> her, and soothe in turn.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To excite to action by causing resentment or
jealousy; to stimulate; to prick; <as>as, to <ex>pique</ex>
ambition, or curiosity</as>.</def>

<au>Prior.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To pride or value; -- used reflexively.</def>

<q>Men . . . <qex>pique</qex> themselves upon their skill.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To offend; displease; irritate; provoke; fret;
nettle; sting; goad; stimulate.</syn>

<hw>Pique</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To cause annoyance or
irritation.</def> \'bdEvery <?/erse hath something in it that
<xex>piques</xex>.\'b8

<au>Tatler.</au>

<hw>Pi*queer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pickeer</er>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pi*queer"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pickeerer</er>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Piqu"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Picket</er>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pi*quet"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., prob. fr.
<ets>pique</ets>. See <er>Pique</er>, <er>Pike</er>, and
<er>Picket</er>.]</ety> <def>A game at cards played between two
persons, with thirty-two cards, all the deuces, threes, fours,
fives, and sixes, being set aside.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>picket</asp> and <asp>picquet</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pi"ra*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Piracies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. LL.
<ets>piratia</ets>, Gr. <?/. See <er>Pirate</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or crime of a pirate.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Common Law)</fld> <def>Robbery on the high
seas; the taking of property from others on the open sea by open
violence; without lawful authority, and with intent to steal; --
a crime answering to <xex>robbery</xex> on land.</def>

<-- air piracy -- to commandeer or hijack an airplane -->

<note><hand/ By statute law several other offenses committed on
the seas (as trading with known pirates, or engaging in the slave
trade) have been made <xex>piracy</xex>.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def></def>\'bdSometimes used, in a quasi-figurative
sense, of violation of copyright; but for this,
<xex>infringement</xex> is the correct and preferable term.\'b8

<au>Abbott.</au>

<hw>Pi*ra"gua</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pirogue</er>.</def>

<hw>Pi*rai"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Piraya</er>.</def>

<hw>Pi*ram"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
trial + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety> <def>A dynamometer for
ascertaining the power required to draw carriages over
roads.</def>

<hw>Pi`ra*ru"cu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the
native South American name.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Same as <er>Arapaima</er>.</def>

<hw>Pi"rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pirata</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to attempt, undertake, from
making attempts or attacks on ships, <?/ an attempt, trial; akin
to E. <ets>peril</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pirate</ets>. See
<er>Peril</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A robber on the high
seas; one who by open violence takes the property of another on
the high seas; especially, one who makes it his business to
cruise for robbery or plunder; a freebooter on the seas; also,
one who steals in a harbor.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An armed ship or vessel which sails without a
legal commission, for the purpose of plundering other vessels on
the high seas.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who infringes the law of copyright, or
publishes the work of an author without permission.</def>

<cs><col>Pirate perch</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
fresh-water percoid fish of the United States (<spn>Aphredoderus
Sayanus</spn>). It is of a dark olive color, speckled with
blackish spots.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pi"rate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pirated</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pirating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pirater</ets>.]</ety> <def>To play the pirate; to practice
robbery on the high seas.</def>

<hw>Pi"rate</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To publish, as books or
writings, without the permission of the author.</def><-- or other
copyrighted material; see also the similar "knock off", to
manufacture an object with a brand name, without permission of
the brand owner, and usually of inferior quality -->

<q>They advertised they would <qex>pirate</qex> his edition.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Pis*ta"chio</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.
<ets>pistacchio</ets> (cf. Sp. <ets>pistacho</ets>, F.
<ets>pistache</ets>), fr. L. <ets>pistacium</ets>, Gr. <?/, <?/,
fr. Per. <ets>pistah</ets>. Cf. <er>Fistinut</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The nut of the <spn>Pistacia vera</spn>, a
tree of the order <spn>Anacardiace\'91</spn>, containing a kernel
of a pale greenish color, which has a pleasant taste, resembling
that of the almond, and yields an oil of agreeable taste and
odor; -- called also <altname>pistachio nut</altname>. It is
wholesome and nutritive. The tree grows in Arabia, Persia, Syria,
and Sicily.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pistachia</asp>.]</altsp>

and the species (<spn>P. Terebinthus</spn>) which yields Chian or
Cyprus turpentine.</def>

<hw>Pis"til</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pistillum</ets>, <ets>pistillus</ets>, a pestle: cf. F.
<ets>pistil</ets>. See <er>Pestle</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The seed-bearing organ of a flower. It consists of an ovary,
containing the ovules or rudimentary seeds, and a stigma, which
is commonly raised on an elongated portion called a
<xex>style</xex>. When composed of one carpel a pistil is simple;
when composed of several, it is compound. See <xex>Illust</xex>.
of <er>Flower</er>, and <er>Ovary</er>.</def>
