<hw>Pis"tol</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pistole</ets>, <ets>pistolet</ets>, It. <ets>pistola</ets>;
prob. from a form <ets>Pistola</ets>, for <ets>Pistoja</ets>, a
town in Italy where pistols were first made. Cf.
<er>Pistole</er>.]</ety> <def>The smallest firearm used, intended
to be fired from one hand, -- now of many patterns, and bearing a
great variety of names. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Revolver</er>.</def><-- generically, also called handgun -->

<cs><col>Pistol carbine</col>, <cd>a firearm with a removable
but-piece, and thus capable of being used either as a pistol or a
carbine.</cd> -- <col>Pistol pipe</col> <fld>(Metal.)</fld>,
<cd>a pipe in which the blast for a furnace is heated, resembling
a pistol in form.</cd> -- <col>Pistol shot</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The discharge of a pistol</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The distance
to which a pistol can propel a ball.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pis"tol</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pistoled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pistoling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pistoler</ets>.]</ety> <def>To shoot with a pistol.</def>
\'bdTo <xex>pistol</xex> a poacher.\'b8

<au>Sydney Smith.</au>

<hw>Pis"to*lade`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<def>A pistol shot.</def>

<hw>Pis*tole"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., probably
a name given in jest in France to a Spanish coin. Cf.
<er>Pistol</er>.]</ety> <def>The name of certain gold coins of
various values formerly coined in some countries of Europe. In
Spain it was equivalent to a quarter doubloon, or about $3.90,
and in Germany and Italy nearly the same. There was an old
Italian pistole worth about $5.40.</def>

<hw>Pis`to*leer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pistolier</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who uses a pistol.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<hw>Pis"to*let`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., a dim.
of <ets>pistole</ets>.]</ety> <def>A small pistol.</def>

<au>Donne. Beau. & Fl.</au>

<-- pistol-whip, to beat with a pistol -->

<-- p. 1091 -->

<hw>Pis"ton</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>piston</ets>; cf. It. <ets>pistone</ets> piston, also
<ets>pestone</ets> a large pestle; all fr. L. <ets>pinsere</ets>,
<ets>pistum</ets>, to pound, to stamp. See <er>Pestle</er>,
<er>Pistil</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A sliding piece
which either is moved by, or moves against, fluid pressure. It
usually consists of a short cylinder fitting within a cylindrical
vessel along which it moves, back and forth. It is used in steam
engines to receive motion from the steam, and in pumps to
transmit motion to a fluid; also for other purposes.</def>

<cs><col>Piston head</col> <fld>(Steam Eng.)</fld>, <cd>that part
of a piston which is made fast to the piston rod.</cd> --
<col>Piston rod</col>, <cd>a rod by which a piston is moved, or
by which it communicates motion.</cd> -- <col>Piston valve</col>
<fld>(Steam Eng.)</fld>, <cd>a slide valve, consisting of a
piston, or connected pistons, working in a cylindrical case which
is provided with ports that are traversed by the valve.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pit</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pit</ets>, <ets>put</ets>, AS. <ets>pytt</ets> a pit, hole,
L. <ets>puteus</ets> a well, pit.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A large
cavity or hole in the ground, either natural or artificial; a
cavity in the surface of a body; an indentation</def>;
specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The shaft of a coal mine; a coal
pit</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A large hole in the ground from
which material is dug or quarried; <as>as, a stone <ex>pit</ex>;
a gravel <ex>pit</ex></as>; or in which material is made by
burning; <as>as, a lime <ex>pit</ex>; a charcoal
<ex>pit</ex></as></def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A vat sunk in the
ground; <as>as, a tan <ex>pit</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Tumble me into some loathsome <qex>pit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any abyss; especially, the grave, or
hades.</def>

<q>Back to the infernal <qex>pit</qex> I drag thee chained.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He keepth back his soul from the <qex>pit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Job xxxiii. 18.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A covered deep hole for entrapping wild beasts;
a pitfall; hence, a trap; a snare. Also used figuratively.</def>

<q>The anointed of the Lord was taken in their
<qex>pits</qex>.</q>
<qau>Lam. iv. 20.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A depression or hollow in the surface of the
human body</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The hollow place under
the shoulder or arm; the axilla, or armpit</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>See <cref>Pit of the stomach</cref> (below)</def>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>The indentation or mark left by a pustule, as
in smallpox.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Formerly, that part of a theater, on the floor
of the house, below the level of the stage and behind the
orchestra; now, in England, commonly the part behind the stalls;
in the United States, the parquet; also, the occupants of such a
part of a theater.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>An inclosed area into which gamecocks, dogs, and
other animals are brought to fight, or where dogs are trained to
kill rats.</def> \'bdAs fiercely as two gamecocks in the
<xex>pit</xex>.\'b8

<au>Locke.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <ety>[Cf. D. <ets>pit</ets>, akin to E.
<ets>pith</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The
endocarp of a drupe, and its contained seed or seeds; a stone;
<as>as, a peach <ex>pit</ex>; a cherry <ex>pit</ex>,
etc.</as></def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A depression or thin spot in
the wall of a duct.</def>

<cs><col>Cold pit</col> <fld>(Hort.)</fld>, <cd>an excavation in
the earth, lined with masonry or boards, and covered with glass,
but not artificially heated, -- used in winter for the storing
and protection of half-hardly plants, and sometimes in the spring
as a forcing bed.</cd> -- <col>Pit coal</col>, <cd>coal dug from
the earth; mineral coal.</cd> -- <col>Pit frame</col>, <cd>the
framework over the shaft of a coal mine.</cd> -- <col>Pit
head</col>, <cd>the surface of the ground at the mouth of a pit
or mine.</cd> -- <col>Pit kiln</col>, <cd>an oven for coking
coal.</cd> -- <col>Pit martin</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>the bank swallow.</cd> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Pit
of the stomach</col></mcol> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the
depression on the middle line of the epigastric region of the
abdomen at the lower end of the sternum; the infrasternal
depression.</cd> -- <col>Pit saw</col> <fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>a
saw worked by two men, one of whom stands on the log and the
other beneath it. The place of the latter is often in a pit,
whence the name.</cd> -- <col>Pit viper</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any viperine snake having a deep pit
on each side of the snout. The rattlesnake and copperhead are
examples.</cd> -- <col>Working pit</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a
shaft in which the ore is hoisted and the workmen carried; -- in
distinction from a shaft used for the pumps.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pit</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pitted</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pitting</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To place or put
into a pit or hole.</def>

<q>They lived like beasts, and were <qex>pitted</qex> like
beasts, tumbled into the grave.</q>
<qau>T. Grander.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To mark with little hollows, as by various
pustules; <as>as, a face <ex>pitted</ex> by smallpox</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To introduce as an antagonist; to set forward
for or in a contest; <as>as, to <ex>pit</ex> one dog against
another</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A fiber obtained from the
<spn>Agave Americana</spn> and other related species, -- used for
making cordage and paper. Called also <altname>pita
fiber</altname>, and <altname>pita thread</altname>.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The plant which yields the fiber.</def>

<-- pita, pita bread.  a thin flat bread that is formed in two
layers, to make a pocket into which other foods may be placed.
-->

<hw>Pit`a*ha"ya</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp., prob.
from the native name.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A cactaceous
shrub (<spn>Cereus Pitajaya</spn>) of tropical America, which
yields a delicious fruit.</def>

<hw>Pit"a*pat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[An
onomatopoetic reduplication of <ets>pat</ets> a light, quick
blow.]</ety> <def>In a flutter; with palpitation or quick
succession of beats.</def> <au>Lowell</au>. \'bdThe fox's heart
went <xex>pitapat</xex>.\'b8 <au>L'Estrange</au>.

<hw>Pit"a*pat`</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A light, repeated sound;
a pattering, as of the rain.</def> \'bdThe <xex>pitapat</xex> of
a pretty foot.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pitch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pich</ets>, AS. <ets>pic</ets>, L. <ets>pix</ets>; akin to
Gr. <?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A thick, black, lustrous, and
sticky substance obtained by boiling down tar. It is used in
calking the seams of ships; also in coating rope, canvas, wood,
ironwork, etc., to preserve them.</def>

<q>He that toucheth <qex>pitch</qex> shall be defiled
therewith.</q>
<qau>Ecclus. xiii. 1.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Pitchstone</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Amboyna pitch</col>, <cd>the resin of <spn>Dammara
australis</spn>. See <er>Kauri</er>.</cd> -- <col>Burgundy
pitch</col>. <cd>See under <er>Burgundy</er>.</cd> -- <col>Canada
pitch</col>, <cd>the resinous exudation of the hemlock tree
(<spn>Abies Canadensis</spn>); hemlock gum.</cd> -- <col>Jew's
pitch</col>, <cd>bitumen.</cd> -- <col>Mineral pitch</col>.
<cd>See <er>Bitumen</er> and <er>Asphalt</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pitch
coal</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>bituminous coal.</cd> --
<col>Pitch peat</col> <fld>(Min.)</fld>, <cd>a black homogeneous
peat, with a waxy luster.</cd> -- <col>Pitch pine</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of pine,
yielding pitch, esp. the <spn>Pinus rigida</spn> of North
America.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pitch</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pitched</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pitching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See
<er>Pitch</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover
over or smear with pitch.</def>

<au>Gen. vi. 14.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To darken; to blacken; to obscure.</def>

<q>The welkin <qex>pitched</qex> with sullen could.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Pitch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>picchen</ets>; akin to E. <ets>pick</ets>,
<ets>pike</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw, generally with
a definite aim or purpose; to cast; to hurl; to toss; <as>as, to
<ex>pitch</ex> quoits; to <ex>pitch</ex> hay; to <ex>pitch</ex> a
ball.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To thrust or plant in the ground, as stakes or
poles; hence, to fix firmly, as by means of poles; to establish;
to arrange; <as>as, to <ex>pitch</ex> a tent; to <ex>pitch</ex> a
camp.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To set, face, or pave with rubble or undressed
stones, as an embankment or a roadway.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To fix or set the tone of; <as>as, to
<ex>pitch</ex> a tune</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To set or fix, as a price or value.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Pitched battle</col>, <cd>a general battle; a battle in
which the hostile forces have fixed positions; -- in distinction
from a <xex>skirmish<xex>.</cd> -- <col>To pitch into</col>,
<cd>to attack; to assault; to abuse.
<mark>[Slang]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Pitch</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To fix or place
a tent or temporary habitation; to encamp.</def> \'bdLaban with
his brethren <xex>pitched</xex> in the Mount of Gilead.\'b8

<au>Gen. xxxi. 25.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To light; to settle; to come to rest from
flight.</def>

<q>The tree whereon they [the bees] <qex>pitch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To fix one's choise; -- with <xex>on</xex> or
<xex>upon</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>Pitch</qex> upon the best course of life, and custom will
render it the more easy.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To plunge or fall; esp., to fall forward; to
decline or slope; <as>as, to <ex>pitch</ex> from a precipice; the
vessel <ex>pitches</ex> in a heavy sea; the field
<ex>pitches</ex> toward the east.</as></def>

<cs><col>Pitch and pay</col>, <cd>an old aphorism which
inculcates ready-money payment, or payment on delivery of
goods.</cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pitch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A throw; a toss; a
cast, as of something from the hand; <as>as, a good
<ex>pitch</ex> in quoits</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Pitch and toss</col>, <cd>a game played by tossing up a
coin, and calling \'bdHeads or tails;\'b8 hence: <col>To play
pitch and toss with (anything)</col></mcol>, <cd>to be careless
or trust to luck about it.</cd> \'bd<xex>To play pitch and toss
with<xex> the property of the country.\'b8 <au>G.
Eliot</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pitch farthing</col>. <cd>See
<cref>Chuck farthing</cref>, under 5th <er>Chuck</er>.</cd></cs>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Cricket)</fld> <def>That point of the ground on
which the ball pitches or lights when bowled.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A point or peak; the extreme point or degree of
elevation or depression; hence, a limit or bound.</def>

<q>Driven headlong from the <qex>pitch</qex> of heaven, down
Into this deep.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Enterprises of great <qex>pitch</qex> and moment.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>To lowest <qex>pitch</qex> of abject fortune.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He lived when learning was at its highest
<qex>pitch</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>The exact <qex>pitch</qex>, or limits, where temperance
ends.</q>
<qau>Sharp.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Height; stature.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hudibras.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A descent; a fall; a thrusting down.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The point where a declivity begins; hence, the
declivity itself; a descending slope; the degree or rate of
descent or slope; slant; <as>as, a steep <ex>pitch</ex> in the
road; the <ex>pitch</ex> of a roof.</as></def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>The relative acuteness or
gravity of a tone, determined by the number of vibrations which
produce it; the place of any tone upon a scale of high and
low.</def>

<note><hand/ Musical tones with reference to <xex>absolute
pitch</xex>, are named after the first seven letters of the
alphabet; with reference to <xex>relative pitch</xex>, in a
series of tones called the <xex>scale</xex>, they are called
<xex>one</xex>, <xex>two</xex>, <xex>three</xex>,
<xex>four</xex>, <xex>five</xex>, <xex>six</xex>,
<xex>seven</xex>, <xex>eight</xex>. <xex>Eight</xex> is also
<xex>one</xex> of a new scale an octave higher, as <xex>one</xex>
is <xex>eight</xex> of a scale an octave lower.</note>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>The limit of ground set to a
miner who receives a share of the ore taken out.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The distance
from center to center of any two adjacent teeth of gearing,
measured on the <xex>pitch line</xex>; -- called also
<xex>circular pitch</xex>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The length,
measured along the axis, of a complete turn of the thread of a
screw, or of the helical lines of the blades of a screw
propeller.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The distance between the
centers of holes, as of rivet holes in boiler plates.</def>

<cs><col>Concert pitch</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>the standard
of pitch used by orchestras, as in concerts, etc.</cd> --
<col>Diametral pitch</col> <fld>(Gearing)</fld>, <cd>the distance
which bears the same relation to the pitch proper, or circular
pitch, that the diameter of a circle bears to its circumference;
it is sometimes described by the number expressing the quotient
obtained by dividing the number of teeth in a wheel by the
diameter of its pitch circle in inches; as, 4 pitch, 8 pitch,
etc.</cd> -- <col>Pitch chain</col>, <cd>a chain, as one made of
metallic plates, adapted for working with a sprocket wheel.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Pitch line</col>, <or/ <col>Pitch
circle</col></mcol> <fld>(Gearing)</fld>, <cd>an ideal line, in a
toothed gear or rack, bearing such a relation to a corresponding
line in another gear, with which the former works, that the two
lines will have a common velocity as in rolling contact; it
usually cuts the teeth at about the middle of their height, and,
in a circular gear, is a circle concentric with the axis of the
gear; the line, or circle, on which the pitch of teeth is
measured.</cd> -- <col>Pitch of a roof</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>,
<cd>the inclination or slope of the sides expressed by the height
in parts of the span; as, one half <xex>pitch<xex>; whole
<xex>pitch<xex>; or by the height in parts of the half span,
especially among engineers; or by degrees, as a <xex>pitch<xex>
of 30\'f8, of 45\'f8, etc.; or by the <xex>rise<xex> and
<xex>run<xex>, that is, the ratio of the height to the half span;
as, a <xex>pitch<xex> of six rise to ten run. <xex>Equilateral
pitch<xex> is where the two sloping sides with the span form an
equilateral triangle.</cd> -- <col>Pitch of a plane</col>
<fld>(Carp.)</fld>, <cd>the slant of the cutting iron.</cd> --
<col>Pitch pipe</col>, <cd>a wind instrument used by choristers
in regulating the pitch of a tune.</cd> -- <col>Pitch point</col>
<fld>(Gearing)</fld>, <cd>the point of contact of the pitch lines
of two gears, or of a rack and pinion, which work
together.</cd></cs>

pitch or tar.</def>

<hw>Pitch"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who pitches anything, as hay, quoits, a ball, etc.;
specifically <fld>(Baseball)</fld>, the player who delivers the
ball to the batsman.</def>

<hw>Pitch"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>picher</ets>, OF. <ets>pichier</ets>, OHG.
<ets>pehhar</ets>, <ets>pehh\'beri</ets>; prob. of the same
origin as E. <ets>beaker</ets>. Cf. <er>Beaker</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A wide-mouthed, deep vessel for holding liquids,
with a spout or protruding lip and a handle; a water jug or jar
with a large ear or handle.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A tubular or cuplike appendage
or expansion of the leaves of certain plants.</def>

<cs><col>American pitcher plants</col>, <cd>the species of
Sarracenia. See <er>Sarracenia</er>.</cd> -- <col>Australian
pitcher plant</col>, <cd>the <spn>Cephalotus follicularis</spn>,
a low saxifragaceous herb having two kinds of radical leaves,
some oblanceolate and entire, others transformed into little
ovoid pitchers, longitudinally triple-winged and ciliated, the
mouth covered with a lid shaped like a cockleshell.</cd> --
<col>California pitcher plant</col>, <cd>the <spn>Darlingtonia
California</spn>. See <er>Darlingtonia</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pitcher
plant</col>, <cd>any plant with the whole or a part of the leaves
transformed into pitchers or cuplike organs, especially the
species of <spn>Nepenthes</spn>. See
<er>Nepenthes</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pit"e*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pitous</ets>, OF. <ets>pitos</ets>, F. <ets>piteux</ets>.
See <er>Pity</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pious; devout.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

temptation.</q>
<qau>Wyclif.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Evincing pity, compassion, or sympathy;
compassionate; tender.</def> \'bd[She] <xex>piteous</xex> of his
case.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<q>She was so charitable and so <qex>pitous</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fitted to excite pity or sympathy; wretched;
miserable; lamentable; sad; <as>as, a <ex>piteous</ex>
case</as>.</def>

<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>The most <qex>piteous</qex> tale of Lear.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Paltry; mean; pitiful.</def>
\'bd<xex>Piteous</xex> amends.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Sorrowful; mournful; affecting; doleful; woeful;
rueful; sad; wretched; miserable; pitiable; pitiful;
compassionate.</syn>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pith</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>pi<?/a</ets>; akin to D. <ets>pit</ets> pith, kernel, LG.
<ets>peddik</ets>. Cf. <er>Pit</er> a kernel.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The soft spongy substance in the center of
the stems of many plants and trees, especially those of the
dicotyledonous or exogenous classes. It consists of cellular
tissue.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The spongy
interior substance of a feather.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The spinal cord; the marrow.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: The which contains the strength of life;
the vital or essential part; concentrated force; vigor; strength;
importance; <as>as, the speech lacked <ex>pith</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Enterprises of great <qex>pith</qex> and moment.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Pith paper</col>. <cd>Same as <cref>Rice paper</cref>,
under <er>Rice</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pith</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>To
destroy the central nervous system of (an animal, as a frog), as
by passing a stout wire or needle up and down the vertebral
canal.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pi*the"ci</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ an ape.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A division
of mammals including the apes and monkeys. Sometimes used in the
sense of <xex>Primates</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pith"e*coid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ an
ape + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to the genus <spn>Pithecia</spn>, or
subfamily <spn>Pithecin\'91</spn>, which includes the saki,
ouakari, and other allied South American monkeys.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the anthropoid apes in
particular, or to the higher apes of the Old World,
collectively.</def>

<hw>Pith"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of
pith.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>W. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pith"i*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pithy
manner.</def>

<hw>Pith"i*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being pithy.</def>

<hw>Pith"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of pith, or of
strength; feeble.</def> <au>Dryden</au>. \'bd<xex>Pithless</xex>
argumentation.\'b8 <au>Glandstone</au>.

<hw>Pit"-hole`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A pit; a
pockmark.</def>

<hw>Pith"some</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pithy;
robust.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Pithsome</xex> health
and vigor.\'b8

<au>R. D. Blackmore.</au>

<hw>Pith"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Pithier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Pithiest</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Consisting wholly, or in part, of pith; abounding in pith;
<as>as, a <ex>pithy</ex> stem; a <ex>pithy</ex> fruit.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having nervous energy; forceful; cogent.</def>

<q>This <qex>pithy</qex> speech prevailed, and all agreed.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>In all these Goodman Fact was very short, but
<qex>pithy</qex>.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<cs><col>Pithy gall</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large,
rough, furrowed, oblong gall, formed on blackberry canes by a
small gallfly (<spn>Diastrophus nebulosus</spn>).</cd></cs>

<hw>Pit"i*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>pitiable</ets>, F. <ets>pitoyable</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Deserving pity; wworthy of, or exciting, compassion;
miserable; lamentable; piteous; <as>as, <ex>pitiable</ex>
persons; a <ex>pitiable</ex> condition; <ex>pitiable</ex>
wretchedness.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Sorrowful; woeful; sad. See <er>Piteous</er>.</syn>

<wf>Pit"i*a*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pit"i*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pities.</def>

<au>Gauden.</au>

<hw>Pit"i*ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Full of pity; tender-hearted; compassionate; kind; merciful;
sympathetic.</def>

<q>The Lord is very <qex>pitiful</qex>, and of tender mercy.</q>
<qau>James v. 11.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Piteous; lamentable; eliciting compassion.</def>

<q>A thing, indeed, very <qex>pitiful</qex> and horrible.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To be pitied for littleness or meanness;
miserable; paltry; contemptible; despicable.</def>

<q>That's villainous, and shows a most <qex>pitiful</qex>
ambition in the fool that uses it.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Despicable; mean; paltry. See
<er>Contemptible</er>.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pit"i*ful*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pit"i*ful*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<ex>pitiless</ex> elements.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Exciting no pity; <as>as, a <ex>pitiless</ex>

<hw>Pit"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Pi*tot's" tube`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Hydraul.)</fld>
<def>A bent tube used to determine the velocity of running water,
by placing the curved end under water, and observing the height
to which the fluid rises in the tube; a kind of current
meter.</def>

<hw>Pit"pan`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A long,
flat-bottomed canoe, used for the navigation of rivers and
lagoons in Central America.</def>

<au>Squier.</au>

<hw>Pit"pat`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. & adv.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pitapat</er>.</def>

<hw>Pit"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any one of a large group of bright-colored clamatorial birds
belonging to <spn>Pitta</spn>, and allied genera of the family
<spn>Pittid\'91</spn>. Most of the species are varied with three
or more colors, such as blue, green, crimson, yellow, purple, and
black. They are called also <altname>ground thrushes</altname>,
and <altname>Old World ant thrushes</altname>; but they are not
related to the true thrushes.</def>

<note><hand/ The pittas are most abundant in the East Indies, but
some inhabit Southern Asia, Africa, and Australia. They live
mostly upon the ground, and feed upon insects of various
kinds.</note>

<hw>Pit"ta*cal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, pitch + <?/ beautiful: cf. F. <ets>pittacale</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A dark blue substance obtained from wood
tar. It consists of hydrocarbons which when oxidized form the
orange-yellow eupittonic compounds, the salts of which are dark
blue.</def>

<hw>Pit"tance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pitance</ets>, <ets>pitaunce</ets>, F. <ets>pitance</ets>;
cf. It. <ets>pietanza</ets>, LL. <ets>pitancia</ets>,
<ets>pittantia</ets>, <ets>pictantia</ets>; perh. fr. L.
<ets>pietas</ets> pity, piety, or perhaps akin to E.
<ets>petty</ets>. Cf. <er>Petty</er>, and <er>Pity</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An allowance of food bestowed in charity; a mess
of victuals; hence, a small charity gift; a dole.</def> \'bdA
good <xex>pitaunce</xex>.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>One half only of this <qex>pittance</qex> was ever given him
in money.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A meager portion, quality, or allowance; an
inconsiderable salary or compensation.</def> \'bdThe small
<xex>pittance</xex> of learning they received.\'b8

<au>Swift.</au>

<q>The inconsiderable <qex>pittance</qex> of faithful
professors.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Pi*tu"i*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pituita</ets> phlegm, pituite: cf. F.
<ets>pituitarie</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Secreting mucus or phlegm; <as>as, the <ex>pituitary</ex>
membrane, or the mucous membrane which lines the nasal
cavities</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of or pertaining to the
pituitary body; <as>as, the <ex>pituitary</ex> fossa</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Pituitary body</col> <or/ <col>gland</col></mcol>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>a glandlike body of unknown function,
situated in the pituitary fossa, and connected with the
infundibulum of the brain; the hypophysis.</cd> -- <col>Pituitary
fossa</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the ephippium.</cd></cs>
<-- glandula pituitaria, basilaris.  Suspended from the base of
the hypothalamus.  secretes pituitary hormones: oxytocin,
antidiuretic hormone; somatotropins, prolactin, thyroid
stimulating hormone, gonadotropins, adrenal corticotropin and
other peptide hormones.  Called the "master gland"  -->

<hw>Pit"u*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pituita</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pituite</ets>. Cf. <er>Pip</er> a
disease of fowls.]</ety> <def>Mucus, phlegm.</def>

<hw>Pi*tu"i*tous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<cs><col>Pituitous fever</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>typhoid

<hw>Pit"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE. <ets>pite</ets>,
OF. <ets>pit\'82</ets>, <ets>piti\'82</ets>, F.
<ets>piti\'82</ets>, L. <ets>pietas</ets> piety, kindness, pity.
See <er>Pious</er>, and cf. <er>Piety</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Piety.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A feeling for the sufferings or distresses of
another or others; sympathy with the grief or misery of another;
compassion; fellow-feeling; commiseration.</def>

<q>He that hath <qex>pity</qex> upon the poor lendeth unto the
Lord.</q>
<qau>Prov. xix. 17.</qau>

<q>He . . . has no more <qex>pity</qex> in him than a dog.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A reason or cause of pity, grief, or regret; a
thing to be regretted.</def> \'bdThe more the
<xex>pity</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>What <qex>pity</qex> is it
That we can die but once to serve our country!</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<note><hand/ In this sense, sometimes used in the plural,
especially in the colloquialism: \'bdIt is a thousand
<xex>pities</xex>.\'b8</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Compassion; mercy; commiseration; condolence;
sympathy, fellow-suffering; fellow-feeling. -- <er>Pity</er>,
<er>Sympathy</er>, <er>Compassion</er>. <xex>Sympathy</xex> is
literally <xex>fellow-feeling</xex>, and therefore requiers a
certain degree of equality in situation, circumstances, etc., to
its fullest exercise. <xex>Compassion</xex> is deep tenderness
for another under severe or inevitable misfortune.
<xex>Pity</xex> regards its object not only as suffering, but
<xex>weak</xex>, and hence as inferior.</syn>

<hw>Pit"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pitied</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pitying</er>.]</wordforms>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To feel pity or compassion for; to have sympathy
with; to compassionate; to commiserate; to have tender feelings
toward (any one), awakened by a knowledge of suffering.</def>

<q>Like as a father <qex>pitieth</qex> his children, so the Lord
<qex>pitieth</qex> them that fear him.</q>
<qau>Ps. ciii. 13.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To move to pity; -- used impersonally.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It <qex>pitieth</qex> them to see her in the dust.</q>
<qau>Bk. of Com. Prayer.</qau>

<hw>Pit"y</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be compassionate; to
show pity.</def>

<q>I will not <qex>pity</qex>, nor spare, nor have mercy.</q>
<qau>Jer. xiii. 14.</qau>

<hw>Pit"y*ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Expressing pity; <as>as, a
<ex>pitying</ex> eye, glance, or word</as>.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pit"y*ing*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8Pi"\'97</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[It., fr.

<hw>Piv"ot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.; prob. akin
to It. <ets>piva</ets> pipe, F. <ets>pipe</ets>. See
<er>Pipe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A fixed pin or short axis,
on the end of which a wheel or other body turns.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The end of a shaft or arbor which rests and
turns in a support; <as>as, the <ex>pivot</ex> of an arbor in a
watch</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence, figuratively: A turning point or
condition; that on which important results depend; <as>as, the
<ex>pivot</ex> of an enterprise</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>The officer or soldier who
simply turns in his place whike the company or line moves around
him in wheeling; -- called also <altname>pivot
man</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Pivot bridge</col>, <cd>a form of drawbridge in which
one span, called the <xex>pivot span<xex>, turns about a central
vertical axis.</cd> -- <col>Pivot gun</col>, <cd>a gun mounted on
a pivot or revolving carriage, so as to turn in any
direction.</cd> -- <col>Pivot tooth</col> <fld>(Dentistry)</fld>,
<cd>an artificial crown attached to the root of a natural tooth
by a pin or peg.</cd></cs>

p.</pos> <er>Pivoted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pivoting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To place on a pivot.</def>

<au>Clarke.</au>

it flowers in earliest spring.</def>

<hw>Pla"ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>placabilis</ets>, fr. <ets>placare</ets> to quiet, pacify:
cf. F. <ets>placable</ets>. See <er>Placate</er>.]</ety>

<hw>Pla*card"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
<ets>plaquer</ets> to lay or clap on, <ets>plaque</ets> plate,
tablet; probably from Dutch, cf. D. <ets>plakken</ets> to paste,
post up, <ets>plak</ets> a flat piece of wood.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A public proclamation; a manifesto or edict issued by
authority.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>All <qex>placards</qex> or edicts are published in his
name.</q>
<qau>Howell.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Permission given by authority; a license;
<as>as, to give a <ex>placard</ex> to do something</as>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>ller.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A written or printed paper, as an advertisement
or a declaration, posted, or to be posted, in a public place; a
poster.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anc. Armor)</fld> <def>An extra plate on the
lower part of the breastplate or backplate.</def>

<au>Planch\'82.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <ety>[Cf. <er>Placket</er>.]</ety> <def>A kind of
stomacher, often adorned with jewels, worn in the fifteenth
century and later.</def>

<hw>Pla*card"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Placarded</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Placarding</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To post
placards upon or within; <as>as, to <ex>placard</ex> a wall, to
<ex>placard</ex> the city</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To announce by placards; <as>as, to
<ex>placard</ex> a sale</as>.</def>

<hw>Plac"ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Placard</er>, 4 & 5.</def>

<hw>Pla"cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Placated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Placating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>placatus</ets>,
p.p. of <ets>placare</ets> to placate, akin to <ets>placere</ets>
to please. See <er>Please</er>.]</ety> <def>To appease; to
pacify; to concilate.</def> \'bdTherefore is he always
propitiated and <xex>placated</xex>.\'b8

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<hw>Pla*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>placatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of placating.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Puttenham (1589).</au>

<hw>Place</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>platea</ets> a street, an area, a courtyard, from Gr.
<grk>platei^a</grk> a street, properly fem. of
<grk>platy`s</grk>, flat, broad; akin to Skr.
<ets>p<rsdot/thu</ets>, Lith. <ets>platus</ets>. Cf.
<er>Flawn</er>, <er>Piazza</er>, <er>Plate</er>,
<er>Plaza</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any portion of space
regarded as measured off or distinct from all other space, or
appropriated to some definite object or use; position; ground;
site; spot; rarely, unbounded space.</def>

<q>Here is the <qex>place</qex> appointed.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>What <qex>place</qex> can be for us
Within heaven's bound?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>The word <qex>place</qex> has sometimes a more confused sense,
and stands for that space which any body takes up; and so the
universe is a <qex>place</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A broad way in a city; an open space; an area; a
court or short part of a street open only at one end.</def>
\'bdHangman boys in the market <xex>place</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A position which is occupied and held; a
dwelling; a mansion; a village, town, or city; a fortified town
or post; a stronghold; a region or country.</def>

<q>Are you native of this <qex>place</qex>?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Rank; degree; grade; order of priority,
advancement, dignity, or importance; especially, social rank or
position; condition; also, official station; occupation;
calling.</def> \'bdThe enervating magic of <xex>place</xex>.\'b8

<au>Hawthorne.</au>

<q>Men in great <qex>place</qex> are thrice servants.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>I know my <qex>place</qex> as I would they should do
theirs.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Vacated or relinquished space; room; stead (the
departure or removal of another being or thing being
implied).</def> \'bdIn <xex>place</xex> of Lord Bassanio.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A definite position or passage of a
document.</def>

<q>The <qex>place</qex> of the scripture which he read was
this.</q>
<qau>Acts viii. 32.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Ordinal relation; position in the order of
proceeding; <as>as, he said in the first
<ex>place</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Reception; effect; -- implying the making room
for.</def>

<q>My word hath no <qex>place</qex> in you.</q>
<qau>John viii. 37.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>Position in the heavens, as
of a heavenly body; -- usually defined by its right ascension and
declination, or by its latitude and longitude.</def>

<cs><col>Place of arms</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a place
calculated for the rendezvous of men in arms, etc., as a fort
which affords a safe retreat for hospitals, magazines, etc.
<au>Wilhelm</au>.</cd> -- <col>High place</col>
<fld>(Script.)</fld>, <cd>a mount on which sacrifices were
offered. \'bdHim that offereth in the <xex>high place<xex>.\'b8
<au>Jer. xlviii. 35</au>.</cd> -- <col>In place</col>, <cd>in
proper position; timely.</cd> -- <col>Out of place</col>,
<cd>inappropriate; ill-timed; as, his remarks were <xex>out of
place<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Place kick</col> <fld>(Football)</fld>,
<cd>the act of kicking the ball after it has been placed on the
ground.</cd> -- <col>Place name</col>, <cd>the name of a place or
locality. <au>London Academy</au>.</cd> -- <col>To give
place</col>, <cd>to make room; to yield; to give way; to give
advantage. \'bdNeither <xex>give place<xex> to the devil.\'b8
<au>Eph. iv. 27</au>. \'bdLet all the rest <xex>give
place<xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.</cd> -- <col>To have place</col>,
<cd>to have a station, room, or seat; as, such desires can
<xex>have<xex> no <xex>place<xex> in a good heart.</cd> --
<col>To take place</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To come to pass; to
occur; as, the ceremony will not <xex>take place<xex>.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To take precedence or priority.</cd>
<au>Addison</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To take effect; to
prevail.</cd> \'bdIf your doctrine <xex>takes place<xex>.\'b8
<au>Berkeley</au>. \'bdBut none of these excuses would <xex>take
place<xex>.\'b8 <au>Spenser</au>. -- <col>To take the place
of</col>, <cd>to be substituted for.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Situation; seat; abode; position; locality;
location; site; spot; office; employment; charge; function;
trust; ground; room; stead.</syn>

<hw>Place</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Placed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Placing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>placer</ets>. See
<er>Place</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To assign a
place to; to put in a particular spot or place, or in a certain
relative position; to direct to a particular place; to fix; to
settle; to locate; <as>as, to <ex>place</ex> a book on a shelf;
to <ex>place</ex> balls in tennis.</as></def>

<q>Upon my head they <qex>placed</qex> a fruitless crown.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put or set in a particular rank, office, or
position; to surround with particular circumstances or relations
in life; to appoint to certain station or condition of life;
<as>as, in whatever sphere one is <ex>placed</ex></as>.</def>

<q><qex>Place</qex> such over them to be rulers.</q>
<qau>Ex. xviii. 21.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To put out at interest; to invest; to loan;
<as>as, to <ex>place</ex> money in a bank</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To set; to fix; to repose; <as>as, to
<ex>place</ex> confidence in a friend</as>.</def> \'bdMy
resolution 's <xex>placed</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To attribute; to ascribe; to set down.</def>

<q><qex>Place</qex> it for her chief virtue.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To place</col><cd> (a person), to identify him.
<mark>[Colloq. U.S.]</mark></cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Put</er>.</syn>

<hw>\'d8Pla*ce"bo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., I
shall please, fut. of <ets>placere</ets> to please.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>The first antiphon of the
vespers for the dead.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A prescription intended to
humor or satisfy.</def>

<cs><col>To sing placebo</col>, <cd>to agree with one in his
opinion; to be complaisant to.</cd></cs>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<-- placebo effect -->

<hw>Pla*cen"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Placent\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Placentas</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a cake, Gr. <?/ a flat cake, from
<?/ flat, fr. <?/, <?/, anything flat and broad.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The vascular appendage which
connects the fetus with the parent, and is cast off in
parturition with the afterbirth.</def>

<note><hand/ In most mammals the placenta is principally
developed from the allantois and chorion, and tufts of vascular
villi on its surface penetrate the blood vessels of the parental
uterus, and thus establish a nutritive and excretory connection
between the blood of the fetus and that of the parent, though the
blood itself does not flow from one to the other.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The part of a pistil or fruit
to which the ovules or seeds are attached.</def>

<hw>Pla*cen"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to the placenta; having, or characterized
by having, a placenta; <as>as, a <ex>placental</ex>
mammal</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Placentalia.</def>

<hw>Pla*cen"tal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>One of the Placentalia.</def>

<-- p. 1093 -->

<hw>Pla"gi*o*stome</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the Plagiostomi.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pla`gi*os"to*mi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/ slanting + <?/, <?/, mouth.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of fishes including the
sharks and rays; -- called also
<altname><spn>Plagiostomata</spn></altname>.</def>

<hw>Pla`gi*os"to*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Plagiostomi.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pla`gi*o*trem"a*ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>;
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ slanting + <?/, <?/, a hole.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Lepidosauria</er>.</def>

<hw>Pla`gi*o*trop"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ aslant + <?/ to turn.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Having
the longer axis inclined away from the vertical line.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pla"gi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <fld>(Civil Law)</fld> <def>Manstealing;
kidnaping.</def>

<hw>Pla*gose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plagosus</ets>. See <er>Plague</er>.]</ety> <def>Fond of
flogging; <as>as, a <ex>plagose</ex> master</as>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Plague</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plaga</ets> a blow, stroke, plague; akin to Gr. <?/, fr. <?/
to strike; cf. L. <ets>plangere</ets> to strike, beat. Cf.
<er>Plaint</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which smites,
wounds, or troubles; a blow; a calamity; any afflictive evil or
torment; a great trail or vexation.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>And men blasphemed God for the <qex>plague</qex> of hail.</q>
<qau>Wyclif.</qau>

<q>The different <qex>plague</qex> of each calamity.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>An acute malignant contagious
fever, that often prevails in Egypt, Syria, and Turkey, and has
at times visited the large cities of Europe with frightful
mortality; hence, any pestilence; <as>as, the great London
<ex>plague</ex></as>.</def> \'bdA <xex>plague</xex> upon the
people fell.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<cs><col>Cattle plague</col>. <cd>See <er>Rinderpest</er>.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Plague mark</col>, <col>Plague spot</col></mcol>,
<cd>a spot or mark of the plague; hence, a token of something
incurable.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plague</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plagued</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plaguing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
infest or afflict with disease, calamity, or natural evil of any
kind.</def>

<q>Thus were they <qex>plagued</qex>
And worn with famine.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To vex; to tease; to harass.</def>

<q>She will <qex>plague</qex> the man that loves her most.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To vex; torment; distress; afflict; harass; annoy;
tease; tantalize; trouble; molest; embarrass; perplex.</syn>

<hw>Plague"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Abounding,
or infecting, with plagues; pestilential; <as>as,
<ex>plagueful</ex> exhalations</as>.</def>

<hw>Plague"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Free from plagues or the
plague.</def>

<hw>Pla"guer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
plagues or annoys.</def>

<hw>Pla"gui*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
plaguing manner; vexatiously; extremely.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark> \'bdRonsard is so <xex>plaguily</xex>
stiff and stately.\'b8

<au>Landor.</au>

<hw>Pla"guy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Vexatious;
troublesome; tormenting; <as>as, a <ex>plaguy</ex> horse</as>.
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark> Also used adverbially; <as>as, \'bdHe is
so <ex>plaguy</ex> proud</as>.\'b8</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Plaice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plaise</ets>, <ets>plais</ets>, prob. fr. L.
<ets>platessa</ets> flatish, plaice. See <er>Place</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A European food fish
(<spn>Pleuronectes platessa</spn>), allied to the flounder, and
growing to the weight of eight or ten pounds or more.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def> A large American flounder (<spn>Paralichthys
dentatus</spn>; called also <altname>brail</altname>,
<altname>puckermouth</altname>, and <altname>summer
flounder</altname>. The name is sometimes applied to other allied
species.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>plaise</asp>.]</altsp>

<cs><col>Plaice mouth</col>, <cd>a mouth like that of a plaice; a
small or wry mouth.</cd> <mark>[R.]</mark></cs>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Plaid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gael.
<ets>plaide</ets> a blanket or plaid, contr. fr.
<ets>peallaid</ets> a sheepskin, fr. <ets>peall</ets> a skin or
hide. CF. <er>Pillion</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A rectangular
garment or piece of cloth, usually made of the checkered material
called tartan, but sometimes of plain gray, or gray with black
stripes. It is worn by both sexes in Scotland.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Goods of any quality or material of the pattern
of a plaid or tartan; a checkered cloth or pattern.</def>

<hw>Plaid</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a pattern or colors
which resemble a Scotch plaid; checkered or marked with bars or
stripes at right angles to one another; <as>as, <ex>plaid</ex>
muslin</as>.</def>

<hw>Plaid"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of the material
of which plaids are made; tartan.</def> \'bdIn <xex>plaided</xex>
vest.\'b8

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Wearing a plaid.</def>

<au>Campbell.</au>

<hw>Plaid"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Plaid
cloth.</def>

<hw>Plain</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>playne</ets>, <ets>pleyne</ets>, fr. F. <ets>plaindre</ets>.
See <er>Plaint</er>.]</ety> <def>To lament; to bewail; to
complain.</def> <mark>[Archaic & Poetic]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>We with piteous heart unto you <qex>pleyne</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Plain</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To lament; to mourn over;
<as>as, to <ex>plain</ex> a loss</as>.</def> <mark>[Archaic &
Poetic]</mark>

<au>Sir J. Harrington.</au>

<hw>Plain</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Plainer</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Plainest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F., level, flat, fr. L.
<ets>planus</ets>, perhaps akin to E. <ets>floor</ets>. Cf.
<er>Llano</er>, <er>Piano</er>, <er>Plan</er>, <er>Plane</er>
level, a level surface.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Without
elevations or depressions; flat; level; smooth; even. See
<er>Plane</er>.</def>

<q>The crooked shall be made straight, and the rough places
<qex>plain</qex>.</q>
<qau>Isa. xl. 4.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Open; clear; unencumbered; equal; fair.</def>

<q>Our troops beat an army in <qex>plain</qex> fight.</q>
<qau>Felton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not intricate or difficult; evident; manifest;
obvious; clear; unmistakable.</def> \'bd'T is a <xex>plain</xex>
case.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Void of extraneous beauty or
ornament; without conspicious embellishment; not rich;
simple.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Not highly cultivated;
unsophisticated; free from show or pretension; simple; natural;
homely; common.</def> \'bd<xex>Plain</xex> yet pious
Christians.\'b8 <au>Hammond</au>. \'bdThe <xex>plain</xex>
people.\'b8 <au>A. Lincoln</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Free from
affectation or disguise; candid; sincere; artless; honest;
frank.</def> \'bdAn honest mind, and <xex>plain</xex>.\'b8
<au>Shak.</au> <sd>(d)</sd> <def>Not luxurious; not highly
seasoned; simple; <as>as, <ex>plain</ex> food</as>.</def>
<sd>(e)</sd> <def>Without beauty; not handsome; homely; <as>as, a
<ex>plain</ex> woman</as>.</def> <sd>(f)</sd> <def>Not
variegated, dyed, or figured; <as>as, <ex>plain</ex>
muslin</as>.</def> <sd>(g)</sd> <def>Not much varied by
modulations; <as>as, a <ex>plain</ex> tune</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Plain battle</col>, <cd>open battle; pitched battle.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Chaucer</au>.</cd> -- <col>Plain
chant</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <cd>Same as <cref>Plain
song</cref>, below.</cd> -- <col>Plain chart</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a chart laid down on Mercator's
projection.</cd> -- <col>Plain dealer</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>One
who practices plain dealing</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A
simpleton</cd>. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Shak</au>.</cd> --
<col>Plain dealing</col>. <cd>See under <er>Dealing</er>.</cd> --
<col>Plain molding</col> <fld>(Join.)</fld>, <cd>molding of which
the surfaces are plain figures.</cd> -- <col>Plain sewing</col>,
<cd>sewing of seams by simple and common stitches, in distinct
from fancy work, embroidery, etc.; -- distinguished also from
designing and fitting garments.</cd> -- <col>Plain song</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The Gregorian chant, or <altname>canto
fermo</altname>; the prescribed melody of the Roman Catholic
service, sung in unison, in tones of equal length, and rarely
extending beyond the compass of an octave</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>A simple melody.</cd> -- <col>Plain speaking</col>,
<cd>plainness or bluntness of speech.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Level; flat; smooth; open; artless; unaffected;
undisguised; frank; sincere; honest; candid; ingenuous;
unembellished; downright; blunt; clear; simple; distinct;
manifest; obvious; apparent. See <er>Manifest</er>.</syn>

<hw>Plain</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a plain manner;
plainly.</def> \'bdTo speak short and <xex>pleyn</xex>.\'b8
<au>Chaucer</au>. \'bdTo tell you <xex>plain</xex>.\'b8
<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Plain</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF. <ets>plaigne</ets>,
F. <ets>plaine</ets>. See <er>Plain</er>, <pos>a.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Level land; usually, an open field or a broad
stretch of land with an even surface, or a surface little varied
by inequalities; <as>as, the <ex>plain</ex> of Jordan; the
American <ex>plains</ex>, or prairies.</as></def>

<q>Descending fro the mountain into <qex>playn</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Him the Ammonite
Worshiped in Rabba and her watery <qex>plain</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A field of battle.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<q>Lead forth my soldiers to the <qex>plain</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Plain</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plained</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plaining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Plane</er>, <pos>v.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To plane or
level; to make plain or even on the surface</def>.
<mark>[R.]</mark></q>

<q>We would rake Europe rather, <qex>plain</qex> the East.</q>
<qau>Wither.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make plain or manifest; to explain.</def>

<q>What's dumb in show, I'll <qex>plain</qex> in speech.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Plaint</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>plainte</ets>, <ets>pleynte</ets>, F. <ets>plainte</ets>,
fr. L. <ets>plangere</ets>, <ets>planctum</ets>
(<ets>plancta</ets>, fem. p.p.), to beat, beat the breast,
lament. Cf. <er>Complain</er>, <er>Plague</er>,
<er>Plangent</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Audible expression of
sorrow; lamentation; complaint; hence, a mournful song; a
lament.</def> <au>Chaucer</au>.\'bdThe Psalmist's mournful
<xex>plaint</xex>.\'b8 <au>Wordsworth</au>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An accusation or protest on account of an
injury.</def>

<q>There are three just grounds of war with Spain: one of
<qex>plaint</qex>, two upon defense.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A private memorial tendered to
a court, in which a person sets forth his cause of action; the
exhibiting of an action in writing.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<-- p. 1094 -->

<hw>Plaint"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Containing a
plaint; complaining; expressing sorrow with an audible
voice.</def> \'bdMy <xex>plaintful</xex> tongue.\'b8

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<hw>Plain"tiff</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plaintif</ets> making complaint, plaintive; in Old French
equiv. to <ets>plaignant</ets> complainant, prosecutor, fr.
<ets>plaindre</ets>. See <er>Plaint</er>, and cf.
<er>Plaintive</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who
commences a personal action or suit to obtain a remedy for an
injury to his rights; -- opposed to <ant>defendant</ant>.</def>

<hw>Plain"tiff</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Plaintive</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Prior.</au>

<hw>Plait</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>playte</ets>, OF. <ets>pleit</ets>, L. <ets>plicatum</ets>,
<ets>plicitum</ets>, p.p. of <ets>plicare</ets> to fold, akin to
<ets>plectere</ets> to plait. See <er>Ply</er>, and cf.
<er>Plat</er> to weave, <er>Pleat</er>, <er>Plight</er>
fold.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A flat fold; a doubling, as of
cloth; a pleat; <as>as, a box <ex>plait</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>plaits</qex> and foldings of the drapery.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A braid, as of hair or straw; a plat.</def>

<cs><col>Polish plait</col>. <fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>Same as
<er>Plica</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plait</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plaited</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Plaiting</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To fold; to
double in narrow folds; to pleat; <as>as, to <ex>plait</ex> a
ruffle</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To interweave the strands or locks of; to braid;
to plat; <as>as, to <ex>plait</ex> hair; to <ex>plait</ex>
rope.</as></def>

<hw>Plait"ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Folded; doubled over;
braided; figuratively, involved; intricate; artful.</def>

<q>Time shall unfold what <qex>plaited</qex> cunning hides.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Plait"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, plaits.</def>

<hw>Plan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>planus</ets> flat, level. See <er>Plain</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A draught or form;
properly, a representation drawn on a plane, as a map or a chart;
especially, a top view, as of a machine, or the representation or
delineation of a horizontal section of anything, as of a
building; a graphic representation; a diagram.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A scheme devised; a method of action or
procedure expressed or described in language; a project; <as>as,
the <ex>plan</ex> of a constitution; the <ex>plan</ex> of an
expedition.</as></def>

<q>God's <qex>plans</qex> like lines pure and white unfold.</q>
<qau>M. R. Smith.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A method; a way of procedure; a custom.</def>

<q>The simple <qex>plan</qex>,
That they should take who have the power,
And they should keep who can.</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Body plan</col>, <col>Floor plan</col></mcol>,
<cd>etc. See under <er>Body</er>, <er>Floor</er>, etc.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Scheme; draught; delineation; plot; sketch; project;
design; contrivance; device. See <er>Scheme</er>.</syn>

<hw>Plan</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Planned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Planning</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To form
a delineation of; to draught; to represent, as by a
diagram.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To scheme; to devise; to contrive; to form in
design; <as>as, to <ex>plan</ex> the conquest of a
country</as>.</def>

<q>Even in penance, <qex>planning</qex> sins anew.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Pla*na"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Planari\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>-rias</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL. See <er>Planary</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of turbellarian worms
belonging to <spn>Planaria</spn>, and many allied genera. The
body is usually flat, thin, and smooth. Some species, in warm
countries, are terrestrial.</def>

<hw>Pla*na"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the Planarida, or
Dendroc\'d2la; any turbellarian worm.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pla*na"ri*an</wf>, <pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8Pla*nar"i*da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A division of
Turbellaria; the Dendroc\'d2la.</def>

<hw>Pla*na"ri*oid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Planaria</ets> + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Like the planarians.</def>

<hw>Pla"na*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>planarius</ets> level. See <er>Plane</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to a plane.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Planch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>planche</ets>.]</ety> <def>A plank.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Ld. Berners.</au>

<hw>Planch</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Planched</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Planching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>planche</ets> a board, plank. See <er>Plank</er>.]</ety>
<def>To make or cover with planks or boards; to plank.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdTo that vineyard is a <xex>planched</xex>
gate.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Planch"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,
<ets>planche</ets>. See <er>Planch</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A floor of wood; also, a plank.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>The under side of a cornice;
a soffit.</def>

<hw>Planch"er</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To form of
planks.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Golding.</au>

<hw>Planch"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>planchette</ets> a small board, dim. of <ets>planche</ets>.
See <er>Planch</er>.]</ety> <def>A flat piece of metal;
especially, a disk of metal ready to be stamped as a coin.</def>

<hw>Plan`chette"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. See
<er>Planchet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A circumferentor. See
<er>Circumferentor</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small tablet of wood supported on casters and
having a pencil attached. The characters produced by the pencil
on paper, while the hand rests on the instrument and it is
allowed to move, are sometimes translated as of oracular or
supernatural import.</def>

<hw>Planch"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The laying
of floors in a building; also, a floor of boards or planks.</def>

<hw>Plane</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>platanus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ broad; -- so called on
account of its broad leaves and spreading form. See
<er>Place</er>, and cf. <er>Platane</er>, <er>Plantain</er> the
tree.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any tree of the genus
Platanus.</def>

<note><hand/ The Oriental plane (<spn>Platanus orientalis</spn>)
is a native of Asia. It rises with a straight, smooth, branching
stem to a great height, with palmated leaves, and long pendulous
peduncles, sustaining several heads of small close-sitting
flowers. The seeds are downy, and collected into round, rough,
hard balls. The Occidental plane (<spn>Platanus
occidentalis</spn>), which grows to a great height, is a native
of North America, where it is popularly called
<xex>sycamore</xex>, <xex>buttonwood</xex>, and
<xex>buttonball</xex>, names also applied to the California
species (<spn>Platanus racemosa</spn>).</note>

<hw>Plane</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>planus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>plan</ets>. See <er>Plan</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <def>Without elevations or depressions;
even; level; flat; lying in, or constituting, a plane; <as>as, a
<ex>plane</ex> surface</as>.</def>

<note><hand/ In science, this word (instead of <xex>plain</xex>)
is almost exclusively used to designate a flat or level
surface.</note>

<cs><col>Plane angle</col>, <cd>the angle included between two
straight lines in a plane.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Plane chart</col>,
<col>Plane curve</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Chart</er> and
<er>Curve</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plane figure</col>, <cd>a figure all
points of which lie in the same plane. If bounded by straight
lines it is a <xex>rectilinear plane figure<xex>, if by curved
lines it is a <xex>curvilinear plane figure<xex>.</cd> --
<col>Plane geometry</col>, <cd>that part of geometry which treats
of the relations and properties of plane figures.</cd> --
<col>Plane problem</col>, <cd>a problem which can be solved
geometrically by the aid of the right line and circle only.</cd>
-- <col>Plane sailing</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>the method of
computing a ship's place and course on the supposition that the
earth's surface is a plane.</cd> -- <col>Plane scale</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a scale for the use of navigators, on
which are graduated chords, sines, tangents, secants, rhumbs,
geographical miles, etc.</cd> -- <col>Plane surveying</col>,
<cd>surveying in which the curvature of the earth is disregarded;
ordinary field and topographical surveying of tracts of moderate
extent.</cd> -- <col>Plane table</col>, <cd>an instrument used
for plotting the lines of a survey on paper in the field.</cd> --
<col>Plane trigonometry</col>, <cd>the branch of trigonometry in
which its principles are applied to plane triangles.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plane</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>plane</ets>, L.
<ets>plana</ets>. See <er>Plane</er>, <pos>v.</pos> &
<pos>a.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A
surface, real or imaginary, in which, if any two points are
taken, the straight line which joins them lies wholly in that
surface; or a surface, any section of which by a like surface is
a straight line; a surface without curvature.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>An ideal surface, conceived
as coinciding with, or containing, some designated astronomical
line, circle, or other curve; <as>as, the <ex>plane</ex> of an
orbit; the <ex>plane</ex> of the ecliptic, or of the
equator.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A block or plate having a
perfectly flat surface, used as a standard of flatness; a surface
plate.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Joinery)</fld> <def>A tool for smoothing boards
or other surfaces of wood, for forming moldings, etc. It consists
of a smooth-soled stock, usually of wood, from the under side or
face of which projects slightly the steel cutting edge of a
chisel, called the <xex>iron</xex>, which inclines backward, with
an apperture in front for the escape of shavings; <as>as, the
jack <ex>plane</ex>; the smoothing <ex>plane</ex>; the molding
<ex>plane</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<cs><col>Objective plane</col> <fld>(Surv.)</fld>, <cd>the
horizontal plane upon which the object which is to be delineated,
or whose place is to be determined, is supposed to stand.</cd> --
<col>Perspective plane</col>. <cd>See <er>Perspective</er>.</cd>
-- <col>Plane at infinity</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a plane
in which points infinitely distant are conceived as
situated.</cd> -- <col>Plane iron</col>, <cd>the cutting chisel
of a joiner's plane.</cd> -- <col>Plane of polarization</col>.
<fld>(Opt.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Polarization</er>.</cd> --
<col>Plane of projection</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The plane on
which the projection is made, corresponding to the
<xex>perspective plane<xex> in perspective; -- called also
<xex>principal plane<xex>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Descriptive
Geom.)</fld> <cd>One of the planes to which points are referred
for the purpose of determining their relative position in
space.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Plane of refraction</col> <or/
<col>reflection</col></mcol> <fld>(Opt.)</fld>, <cd>the plane in
which lie both the incident ray and the refracted or reflected
ray.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plane</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Planed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Planing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>planer</ets>, L.
<ets>planare</ets>, fr. <ets>planus</ets>. See <er>Plane</er>,
<pos>a.</pos>, <er>Plain</er>, <pos>a.</pos>, and cf.
<er>Planish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make smooth; to
level; to pare off the inequalities of the surface of, as of a
board or other piece of wood, by the use of a plane; <as>as, to
<ex>plane</ex> a plank</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To efface or remove.</def>

<q>He <qex>planed</qex> away the names . . . written on his
tables.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Figuratively, to make plain or smooth.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>What student came but that you <qex>planed</qex> her path.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Plane`-par"al*lel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Optics)</fld> <def>Having opposite surfaces exactly plane
and parallel, as a piece of glass.</def>

<hw>Plan"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who, or that which, planes; a planing machine; esp., a machine
for planing wood or metals.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>A wooden block used for
forcing down the type in a form, and making the surface
even.</def>

<au>Hansard.</au>

<cs><col>Planer centers</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Center</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plan"er tree`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[From
J.S.<ets>Planer</ets>, a German botanist.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A small-leaved North American tree
(<spn>Planera aquatica</spn>) related to the elm, but having a
wingless, nutlike fruit.</def>

<hw>Plan"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>planete</ets>, F. <ets>plan\'8ate</ets>, L.
<ets>planeta</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/, and <?/ a planet; prop.
wandering, fr. <?/ to wander, fr. <?/ a wandering.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A celestial body which
revolves about the sun in an orbit of a moderate degree of
eccentricity. It is distinguished from a <xex>comet</xex> by the
absence of a coma, and by having a less eccentric orbit. See
<er>Solar system</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The term <xex>planet</xex> was first used to
distinguish those stars which have an apparent motion through the
constellations from the <xex>fixed</xex> stars, which retain
their relative places unchanged. The <xex>inferior planets</xex>
are Mercury and Venus, which are nearer to the sun than is the
earth; the <xex>superior planets</xex> are Mars, the asteroids,
Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, which are farther from the
sun than is the earth. <xex>Primary planets</xex> are those which
revolve about the sun; <xex>secondary planets</xex>, or
<xex>moons</xex>, are those which revolve around the primary
planets as satellites, and at the same time revolve with them
about the sun.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A star, as influencing the fate of a men.</def>

<q>There's some ill <qex>planet</qex> reigns.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Planet gear</col>. <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Epicyclic train</cref>, under <er>Epicyclic</er>.</cd> --
<col>Planet wheel</col>, <cd>a gear wheel which revolves around
the wheel with which it meshes, in an epicyclic train.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plane" ta`ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>See under
<er>Plane</er>, <pos>a.</pos></def>

<hw>Plan`e*ta"ri*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.:
cf. F. <ets>plan\'82taire</ets>. See <er>Planetary</er>.]</ety>
<def>An orrery. See <er>Orrery</er>.</def>
<-- since the 1930's, orrery has retained its original meaning,
but planetarium now refers primarily to a room with a dome-shaped
roof, in which images of the night sky are projected from a
central projector.  The projector itself is also called a
planetarium. -->

<hw>Plan"et*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. L.
<ets>planetarius</ets> an astrologer, F. <ets>plan\'82taire</ets>
planetary. See <er>Planet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or
pertaining to the planets; <as>as, <ex>planetary</ex>
inhabitants; <ex>planetary</ex> motions; <ex>planetary</ex>
year.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Consisting of planets; <as>as, a
<ex>planetary</ex> system</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Astrol.)</fld> <def>Under the dominion or
influence of a planet.</def> \'bdSkilled in the
<xex>planetary</xex> hours.\'b8

<au>Drayton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Caused by planets.</def> \'bdA
<xex>planetary</xex> plague.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Having the nature of a planet; erratic;
revolving; wandering.</def> \'bdErratical and
<xex>planetary</xex> life.\'b8

<au>Fuller.</au>

<cs><col>Planetary days</col>, <cd>the days of the week as shared
among the planets known to the ancients, each having its day.
<xex>Hutton<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Planetary nebula</col>, <cd>a
nebula exhibiting a uniform disk, like that of a
planet.</cd></cs>

<au>Young.</au>

<hw>Pla*nim"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Plani-</ets> + <ets>-meter</ets>. Cf.
<er>Planometer</er>.]</ety> <def>An instrument for measuring the
area of any plane figure, however irregular, by passing a tracer
around the bounding line; a platometer.</def>

<hw>Plan"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <def><pos>a. & vb. n.</pos> fr.

<cs><col>Planing machine</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>See
<er>Planer</er>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A complex machine for
planing wood, especially boards, containing usually a rapidly
revolving cutter, which chips off the surface in small shavings
as the piece to be planed is passed under it by feeding
apparatus.</cd></cs>

including those that have broad, flat wings, as the ant-lion,
lacewing, etc. Called also <altname>Planipennes</altname>.</def>

<hw>Plan"ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Planished</er>

<cs><col>Planishing rolls</col> <fld>(Coining)</fld>, <cd>rolls

<hw>Plan"i*sphere</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Plani-</ets> + <ets>sphere</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>planisph\'8are</ets>. See <er>Plain</er>, and
<er>Sphere</er>.]</ety> <def>The representation of the circles of
the sphere upon a plane; especially, a representation of the
celestial sphere upon a plane with adjustable circles, or other
appendages, for showing the position of the heavens, the time of
rising and setting of stars, etc., for any given date or
hour.</def>

<hw>Plan`i*spher"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to a planisphere.</def>

<hw>Plank</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>planke</ets>, OF. <ets>planque</ets>, <ets>planche</ets>, F.
<ets>planche</ets>, fr. L. <ets>planca</ets>; cf. Gr. <?/, <?/,
anything flat and broad. Cf. <er>Planch</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A broad piece of sawed timber, differing from a board only
in being thicker. See <er>Board</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: That which supports or upholds, as a board
does a swimmer.</def>

<q>His charity is a better <qex>plank</qex> than the faith of an
intolerant and bitter-minded bigot.</q>
<qau>Southey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One of the separate articles in a declaration of
the principles of a party or cause; <as>as, a <ex>plank</ex> in
the national platform</as>.</def> <mark>[Cant]</mark>

<cs><mcol><col>Plank road</col>, <or/ <col>Plank
way</col></mcol>, <cd>a road surface formed of planks.</cd>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark> -- <col>To walk the plank</col>, <cd>to walk
along a plank laid across the bulwark of a ship, until one
overbalances it and falls into the sea; -- a method of disposing
of captives practiced by pirates.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1095 -->

<hw>Plank</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Planked</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Planking</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover or lay
with planks; <as>as, to <ex>plank</ex> a floor or a
ship</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Planked</xex> with pine.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To lay down, as on a plank or table; to stake or
pay cash; <as>as, to <ex>plank</ex> money in a wager</as>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq. U.S.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To harden, as hat bodies, by felting.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Wooden Manuf.)</fld> <def>To splice together
the ends of slivers of wool, for subsequent drawing.</def>

<cs><col>Planked shad</col>, <cd>shad split open, fastened to a
plank, and roasted before a wood fire.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plank"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
laying planks; also, planks, collectively; a series of planks in
place, as the wooden covering of the frame of a vessel.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of splicing slivers. See <er>Plank</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>, 4.</def>

<hw>Plank"-sheer`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Shipbuilding)</fld> <def>The course of plank laid
horizontally over the timberheads of a vessel's frame.</def>

<hw>Plan"less</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no
plan.</def>

<hw>Plan"ner</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who plans;
a projector.</def>

<hw>Pla"no-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>See <er>Plani-</er>.</def>

<hw>Plan"o*blast</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
to wander + <ets>-blast</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any free-swimming gonophore of a hydroid; a hydroid
medusa.</def>

<hw>Pla"no-con"cave</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Plano-</ets> + <ets>concave</ets>.]</ety> <def>Plane
or flat on one side, and concave on the other; <as>as, a
<ex>plano-concave</ex> lens</as>. See <er>Lens</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pla*nor"bis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,

<hw>Pla"no-su"bu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
