<hw>Plant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>plante</ets>, L. <ets>planta</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A vegetable; an organized living being, generally without
feeling and voluntary motion, and having, when complete, a root,
stem, and leaves, though consisting sometimes only of a single
leafy expansion, or a series of cellules, or even a single
cellule.</def>

<note><hand/ Plants are divided by their structure and methods of
reproduction into two series, <xex>ph\'91nogamous</xex> or
<xex>flowering plants</xex>, which have true flowers and seeds,
and <xex>cryptogamous</xex> or <xex>flowerless plants</xex>,
which have no flowers, and reproduce by minute one-celled spores.
In both series are minute and simple forms and others of great
size and complexity.

    As to their mode of nutrition, plants may be considered as
<xex>self-supporting</xex> and <xex>dependent</xex>.
<xex>Self-supporting plants</xex> always contain chlorophyll, and
subsist on air and moisture and the matter dissolved in moisture,
and as a general rule they excrete oxygen, and use the carbonic
acid to combine with water and form the material for their
tissues. <xex>Dependent plants</xex> comprise all fungi and many
flowering plants of a parasitic or saprophytic nature. As a rule,
they have no chlorophyll, and subsist mainly or wholly on matter
already organized, thus utilizing carbon compounds already
existing, and not excreting oxygen. But there are plants which
are partly dependent and partly self-supporting.

    The movements of climbing plants, of some insectivorous
plants, of leaves, stamens, or pistils in certain plants, and the
ciliary motion of zo\'94spores, etc., may be considered a kind of
voluntary motion.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A bush, or young tree; a sapling; hence, a stick
or staff.</def> \'bdA <xex>plant</xex> of stubborn oak.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The sole of the foot.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
\'bdKnotty legs and <xex>plants</xex> of clay.\'b8

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Com.)</fld> <def>The whole machinery and
apparatus employed in carrying on a trade or mechanical business;
also, sometimes including real estate, and whatever represents
investment of capital in the means of carrying on a business, but
not including material worked upon or finished products; <as>as,
the <ex>plant</ex> of a foundry, a mill, or a
railroad</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A plan; an artifice; a swindle; a trick.</def>
<mark>[Slang]</mark>

<q>It was n't a bad <qex>plant</qex>, that of mine, on Fikey.</q>
<qau>Dickens.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>An oyster
which has been bedded, in distinction from one of natural
growth.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A young oyster suitable for
transplanting.</def> <mark>[Local, U.S.]</mark>

<-- a person who joins a group, to spy on them on behalf of
another person or group -->

<cs><col>Plant bug</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of
numerous hemipterous insects which injure the foliage of plants,
as <spn>Lygus lineolaris</spn>, which damages wheat and
trees.</cd> -- <col>Plant cutter</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a South American passerine bird of the genus
<spn>Phytotoma</spn>, family <spn>Phytotomid\'91</spn>. It has a
serrated bill with which it cuts off the young shoots and buds of
plants, often doing much injury.</cd> -- <col>Plant louse</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any small hemipterous insect which
infests plants, especially those of the families
<spn>Aphid\'91</spn> and <spn>Psyllid\'91</spn>; an
aphid.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Planted</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Planting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS.
<ets>plantian</ets>, L. <ets>plantare</ets>. See <er>Plant</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To put in the ground and
cover, as seed for growth; <as>as, to <ex>plant</ex>
maize</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To set in the ground for growth, as a young
tree, or a vegetable with roots.</def>

<q>Thou shalt not <qex>plant</qex> thee a grove of any trees.</q>
<qau>Deut. xvi. 21.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To furnish, or fit out, with plants; <as>as, to
<ex>plant</ex> a garden, an orchard, or a forest</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To engender; to generate; to set the germ
of.</def>

<q>It engenders choler, <qex>planteth</qex> anger.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To furnish with a fixed and organized
population; to settle; to establish; <as>as, to <ex>plant</ex> a
colony</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Planting</qex> of countries like planting of woods.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To introduce and establish the principles or
seeds of; <as>as, to <ex>plant</ex> Christianity among the
heathen</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To set firmly; to fix; to set and direct, or
point; <as>as, to <ex>plant</ex> cannon against a fort; to
<ex>plant</ex> a standard in any place; to <ex>plant</ex> one's
feet on solid ground; to <ex>plant</ex> one's fist in another's
face.</as></def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To set up; to install; to instate.</def>

<q>We will <qex>plant</qex> some other in the throne.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Plant</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To perform the act of
planting.</def>

<q>I have <qex>planted</qex>; Apollos watered.</q>
<qau>1 Cor. iii. 6.</qau>

<hw>Plant"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable of
being planted; fit to be planted.</def>

<au>B. Edwards.</au>

<hw>Plant"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A word used
once by Shakespeare to designate plants in general, or anything
that is planted.</def>

<q>As true as steel, as <qex>plantage</qex> to the moon.</q>
<qau>Shak. (Troil. iii. sc. 2).</qau>

<hw>Plan"tain</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>plantain-arbre</ets>, <ets>plantanier</ets>, Sp.
<ets>pl\'a0ntano</ets>, <ets>pl\'a0tano</ets>; prob. same word as
<ets>plane</ets> tree.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A treelike perennial herb (<spn>Musa paradisiaca</spn>) of
tropical regions, bearing immense leaves and large clusters of
the fruits called <xex>plantains</xex>. See <er>Musa</er>.</def>
<-- a type of banana -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The fruit of this plant. It is long and somewhat
cylindrical, slightly curved, and, when ripe, soft, fleshy, and
covered with a thick but tender yellowish skin. The plantain is a
staple article of food in most tropical countries, especially
when cooked.</def><-- resembling the banana of commerce, but
smaller -->

<cs><mcol><col>Plantain cutter</col>, <or/ <col>Plantain
eater</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several
large African birds of the genus <spn>Musophaga</spn>, or family
<spn>Musophagid\'91</spn>, especially <spn>Musophaga
violacea</spn>. See <er>Turaco</er>. They are allied to the
cuckoos.</cd> -- <col>Plantain squirrel</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a Java squirrel (<spn>Sciurus
plantani</spn>) which feeds upon plantains.</cd> -- <col>Plantain
tree</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the treelike herb <spn>Musa
paradisiaca</spn>. See def. 1 (above).</cd></cs>

<hw>Plan"tain</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>plantago</ets>. Cf. <er>Plant</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Any plant of the genus <spn>Plantago</spn>, but especially
the <spn>P. major</spn>, a low herb with broad spreading radical
leaves, and slender spikes of minute flowers. It is a native of
Europe, but now found near the abode of civilized man in nearly
all parts of the world.</def>

<cs><col>Indian plantain</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Indian</er>.</cd> -- <col>Mud plantain</col>, <cd>a homely
North American aquatic plant (<spn>Heteranthera
reniformis</spn>), having broad, reniform leaves.</cd> --
<col>Rattlesnake plantain</col>, <cd>an orchidaceous plant
(<spn>Goodyera pubescens</spn>), with the leaves blotched and
spotted with white.</cd> -- <col>Ribwort plantain</col>. <cd>See
<er>Ribwort</er>.</cd> -- <col>Robin's plantain</col>, <cd>the
<spn>Erigeron bellidifolium</spn>, a common daisylike plant of
North America.</cd> -- <col>Water plantain</col>, <cd>a plant of
the genus <spn>Alisma</spn>, having acrid leaves, and formerly
regarded as a specific against hydrophobia.
<au>Loudon</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plan"ti*grade</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>\'d8Plan"u*la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Planul\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a little

by the divergence of its cells in such a manner as to give rise
to a central space, around which the cells arrange themselves as
an envelope; an embryonic form intermediate between the morula
and gastrula. Sometimes used as synonymous with
<altname>gastrula</altname>.</def><-- now usu. gastrula -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The very young,
free-swimming larva of the c\'d2lenterates. It usually has a
flattened oval or oblong form, and is entirely covered with
cilia.</def>

<hw>Plasm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plasma</ets> anything formed or molded, that which is
molded, Gr. <?/, <?/, from <?/ to form, mold: cf. F.
<ets>plasme</ets>. Cf. <er>Plasma</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
mold or matrix in which anything is cast or formed to a
particular shape.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Woodward.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Plasma</er>.</def>

<hw>Plas"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Plasm</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A
variety of quartz, of a color between grass green and leek green,
which is found associated with common chalcedony. It was much
esteemed by the ancients for making engraved ornaments.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The viscous material of an
animal or vegetable cell, out of which the various tissues are
formed by a process of differentiation; protoplasm.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Unorganized material; elementary matter.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A mixture of starch and
glycerin, used as a substitute for ointments.</def>

<au>U. S. Disp.</au>

<-- = blood plasma -->

<-- 6. (physics) a state of matter in which charged particles
have sufficient energy to move freely, rather than bound in atoms
as in ordinary matter; it has some of the properties of a gas,
but is a conductor of electricity; plasmas are found naturally in
the atmosphere of stars, and can be created in special laboratory
apparatus -->

<cs><col>Blood plasma</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>the
colorless fluid of the blood, in which the red and white blood
corpuscles are suspended.</cd> -- <col>Muscle plasma</col>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>the fundamental part of muscle fibers,
a thick, viscid, albuminous fluid contained within the
sarcolemma, which on the death of the muscle coagulates to a
semisolid mass.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1096 -->

<mhw>{ <hw>Plas*mat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Plas*mat"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Forming; shaping; molding.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to plasma;
having the character of plasma; containing, or conveying,
plasma.</def>

<hw>Plas*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plasmatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of forming or
molding.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Grafton.</au>

<hw>Plas*ma"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<def>A former; a fashioner.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdThe
sovereign <xex>plasmator</xex>, God Almighty.\'b8

<au>Urquhart.</au>

<hw>Plas"ma*ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Form;
mold.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Plas"mic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of, pertaining
to, or connected with, plasma; plasmatic.</def>

<-- Plasmid, n. <def>A piece of DNA, usually circular,
functioning as part of the genetic material of a cell, not
integrated with the chromosome and replicating independently of
the chromosome, but transferred, like the chromosome, to
subsequent generations.  In bacteria, plasmids often carry the
genes for antibiotic resistance; they are exploited in genetic
engineering as the vehicles for introduction of extraneous DNA
into cells, to alter the genetic makeup of the cell.  The cells
thus altered may produce desirable proteins which are extracted
and used; in the case of genetically altered plant cells, the
altered cells may grow into complete plants with changed
properties, as for example, increased resistance to disease.
</def>. -->

<hw>Plas"min</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Physiol.
Chem.)</fld> <def>A proteid body, separated by some physiologists
from blood plasma. It is probably identical with
fibrinogen.</def>

<hw>Plas*mo"di*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to, or like, a
plasmodium; <as>as, the <ex>plasmodial</ex> form of a life
cycle</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Plas*mo"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Plasmodia</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL. See
<er>Plasma</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>A
jellylike mass of free protoplasm, without any union of
am\'d2boid cells, and endowed with life and power of
motion.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A naked mobile mass of
protoplasm, formed by the union of several am\'d2balike young,
and constituting one of the stages in the life cycle of Mycetozoa
and other low organisms.</def>

<-- (a) a genus of microorganisms (b) an individual malarial
parasite cell. -->

<hw>Plas"mo*gen</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Plasma</ets> + <ets>-gen</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The important living portion of
protoplasm, considered a chemical substance of the highest
elaboration.  Germ plasm and idioplasm are forms of
plasmogen.</def>

<hw>\'d8Plas"son</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ to form.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The albuminous
material composing the body of a cytode.</def>

<note><hand/ It is considered simpler than protoplasm of an
ordinary cell in that it has not undergone differentiation into
the inner cell nucleus and the outer cell substance.</note>

<au>Haeckel.</au>

<hw>Plas"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS., a
plaster (in sense 1), fr. L. <ets>emplastrum</ets>, Gr. <?/, <?/,
fr. <?/ to daub on, stuff in; <?/ in + <?/ to mold: cf. OF.
<ets>plastre</ets> a plaster (in sense 2), F.
<ets>pl\'83tre</ets>. Cf. <er>Plastic</er>, <er>Emplaster</er>,
<er>Piaster</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Formerly written also
<asp>plaister</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>An external application of a consistency harder than
ointment, prepared for use by spreading it on linen, leather,
silk, or other material. It is adhesive at the ordinary
temperature of the body, and is used, according to its
composition, to produce a medicinal effect, to bind parts
together, etc.; <as>as, a porous <ex>plaster</ex>; sticking
<ex>plaster</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A composition of lime, water, and sand, with or
without hair as a bond, for coating walls, ceilings, and
partitions of houses. See <er>Mortar</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Calcined gypsum, or plaster of Paris, especially
when ground, as used for making ornaments, figures, moldings,
etc.; or calcined gypsum used as a fertilizer.</def>

<cs><col>Plaster cast</col>, <cd>a copy of an object obtained by
pouring plaster of Paris mixed with water into a mold.</cd> --
<col>Plaster of Paris</col>. <ety>[So called because originally
brought from a suburb of Paris.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<cd>Anhydrous calcium sulphate, or calcined gypsum, which forms
with water a paste which soon sets or hardens, and is used for
casts, moldings, etc. The term is loosely applied to any plaster
stone or species of gypsum.</cd> -- <col>Plaster of Paris
bandage</col> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>, <cd>a bandage saturated with a
paste of plaster of Paris, which on drying forms a perfectly
fitting splint.</cd><-- = plaster cast, cast --> -- <col>Plaster
stone</col>, <cd>any species of gypsum. See
<er>Gypsum</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plas"ter</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plastered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plastering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>plastrer</ets> to plaster (in sense 2), F.
<ets>pl\'83trer</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cover with a
plaster, as a wound or sore.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To overlay or cover with plaster, as the
ceilings and walls of a house.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Fig.: To smooth over; to cover or conceal the
defects of; to hide, as with a covering of plaster.</def>

<au>Bale.</au>

<hw>Plas"ter*work`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Plastering used to finish architectural constructions,
exterior or interior, especially that used for the lining of
rooms. Ordinarly, mortar is used for the greater part of the
work, and pure plaster of Paris for the moldings and
ornaments.</def>

<hw>Plas"ter*y</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of the nature of
plaster.</def>

<q>The stone . . . is a poor <qex>plastery</qex> material.</q>
<qau>Clough.</qau>

<hw>-plas"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Gr. <?/ fit for molding,
plastic, fr. <?/ to mold, to form.]</ety> <def>A combining form
signifying <xex>developing</xex>, <xex>forming</xex>,
<xex>growing</xex>; <as>as, hetero<ex>plastic</ex>,
mono<ex>plastic</ex>, poly<ex>plastic</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Plas"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plasticus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to form, mold: cf. F.
<ets>plastique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the power to
give form or fashion to a mass of matter; <as>as, the
<ex>plastic</ex> hand of the Creator</as>.</def>

<au>Prior.</au>

<q>See <qex>plastic</qex> Nature working to his end.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being molded, formed, or modeled, as
clay or plaster; -- used also figuratively; <as>as, the
<ex>plastic</ex> mind of a child</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Pertaining or appropriate to, or characteristic
of, molding or modeling; produced by, or appearing as if produced
by, molding or modeling; -- said of sculpture and the kindred
arts, in distinction from painting and the graphic arts.</def>

<q>Medallions . . . fraught with the <qex>plastic</qex> beauty
and grace of the palmy days of Italian art.</q>
<qau>J. S. Harford.</qau>

<fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>an exudation thrown out upon a wounded

<col>Plastic operation</col>, <cd>an operation in plastic
surgery.</cd> -- <col>Plastic surgery</col>, <cd>that branch of
surgery which is concerned with the repair or restoration of
lost, injured, or deformed parts of the body.</cd></cs>

<-- plastic, n. <def>a substance composed predominantly of a
synthetic organic high polymer capable of being cast or molded;
many varieties of plastic are used to produce articles of
commerce (after 1900). [MW10 gives origin of word as 1905]</def>

<hw>Plat"band`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

or group of moldings, the width of which much exceeds its

<hw>Plate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>plate</ets> a plate of metal, a cuirsas, F. <ets>plat</ets>
a plate, a shallow vessel of silver, other metal, or earth, fr.
<ets>plat</ets> flat, Gr. <?/. See <er>Place</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A flat, or nearly flat,
piece of metal, the thickness of which is small in comparison
with the other dimensions; a thick sheet of metal; <as>as, a
steel <ex>plate</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Metallic armor composed of broad pieces.</def>

<q>Mangled . . . through <qex>plate</qex> and mail.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Domestic vessels and utensils, as flagons,
dishes, cups, etc., wrought in gold or silver.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Metallic ware which is plated, in distinction
from that which is genuine silver or gold.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A small, shallow, and usually circular, vessel
of metal or wood, or of earth glazed and baked, from which food
is eaten at table.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <ety>[Cf. Sp. <ets>plata</ets> silver.]</ety> <def>A
piece of money, usually silver money.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bdRealms and islands were as <xex>plates</xex> dropp'd from his
pocket.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A piece of metal on which anything is engraved
for the purpose of being printed; hence, an impression from the
engraved metal; <as>as, a book illustrated with <ex>plates</ex>;
a fashion <ex>plate</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A page of stereotype, electrotype, or the like,
for printing from; <as>as, publisher's
<ex>plates</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>That part of an artificial set of teeth which
fits to the mouth, and holds the teeth in place. It may be of
gold, platinum, silver, rubber, celluloid, etc.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A horizontal timber laid
upon a wall, or upon corbels projecting from a wall, and
supporting the ends of other timbers; also used specifically of
the <xex>roof plate</xex> which supports the ends of the roof
trusses or, in simple work, the feet of the rafters.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>A roundel of silver or
tinctured argent.</def>

<sn>12.</sn> <fld>(Photog.)</fld> <def>A sheet of glass,
porcelain, metal, etc., with a coating that is sensitive to
light.</def>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>A prize giving to the winner in a
contest.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Plate</xex> is sometimes used in an adjectival
sense or in combination, the phrase or compound being in most
cases of obvious signification; as, <xex>plate</xex> basket or
<xex>plate</xex>-basket, <xex>plate</xex> rack or
<xex>plate</xex>-rack.</note>

<cs><col>Home plate</col>. <fld>(Baseball)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Home base</cref>, under <er>Home</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plate
armor</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>See <er>Plate</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
2.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Strong metal plates for protecting war
vessels, fortifications, and the like.</cd> -- <col>Plate
bone</col>, <cd>the shoulder blade, or scapula.</cd> --
<col>Plate girder</col>, <cd>a girder, the web of which is formed
of a single vertical plate, or of a series of such plates riveted
together.</cd> -- <col>Plate glass</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Glass</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plate iron</col>, <cd>wrought iron
plates.</cd> -- <col>Plate layer</col>, <cd>a workman who lays
down the rails of a railway and fixes them to the sleepers or
ties.</cd> -- <col>Plate mark</col>, <cd>a special mark or
emblematic figure stamped upon gold or silver plate, to indicate
the place of manufacture, the degree of purity, and the like;
thus, the local mark for London is a lion.</cd> -- <col>Plate
paper</col>, <cd>a heavy spongy paper, for printing from engraved
plates. <au>Fairholt</au>.</cd> -- <col>Plate press</col>, <cd>a
press with a flat carriage and a roller, -- used for printing
from engraved steel or copper plates.</cd> -- <col>Plate
printer</col>, <cd>one who prints from engraved plates.</cd> --
<col>Plate printing</col>, <cd>the act or process of printing
from an engraved plate or plates.</cd> -- <col>Plate
tracery</col>. <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Tracery</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plate wheel</col>
<fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>a wheel, the rim and hub of which are
connected by a continuous plate of metal, instead of by arms or
spokes.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plated</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Plating</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
cover or overlay with gold, silver, or other metals, either by a
mechanical process, as hammering, or by a chemical process, as
electrotyping.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cover or overlay with plates of metal; to arm
with metal for defense.</def>

<q>Thus <qex>plated</qex> in habiliments of war.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To adorn with plated metal; <as>as, a
<ex>plated</ex> harness</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To beat into thin, flat pieces, or
lamin\'91.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To calender; <as>as, to <ex>plate</ex>
paper</as>.</def>

<hw>Pla*teau"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. F.

<plw>Plateaus</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>. <ety>[F., fr. OF.
<ets>platel</ets>, properly a little plate. See

especially, a broad, level, elevated area of land; a
table-land.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An ornamental dish for the table; a tray or
salver.</def>

the bivalve mollusks.</def>

<hw>Pla"tel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. See
<er>Plateau</er>.]</ety> <def>A small dish.</def>

<hw>Plat"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>platine</ets>, fr. <ets>plat</ets> flat. See <er>Plate</er>,
and cf. <er>Platin</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The part of a printing press which presses the paper against
the type and by which the impression is made.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Hence, an analogous part of a typewriter, on which the paper
rests to receive an impression.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The
movable table of a machine tool, as a planer, on which the work
is fastened, and presented to the action of the tool; -- also
called <altname>table</altname>.</def>

<hw>Plat"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who plates
or coats articles with gold or silver; <as>as, a silver
<ex>plater</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A machine for calendering paper.</def>

<hw>Plat"form`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Plat</ets>, a. + <ets>-form</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>plateforme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A plat; a plan; a
sketch; a model; a pattern. Used also figuratively.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A place laid out after a model.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>lf the <qex>platform</qex> just reflects the order.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Any flat or horizontal surface; especially, one
that is raised above some particular level, as a framework of
timber or boards horizontally joined so as to form a roof, or a
raised floor, or portion of a floor; a landing; a dais; a stage,
for speakers, performers, or workmen; a standing place.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A declaration of the principles upon which a
person, a sect, or a party proposes to stand; a declared policy
or system; <as>as, the Saybrook <ex>platform</ex>; a political
<ex>platform</ex>.</as></def> \'bdThe <xex>platform</xex> of
Geneva.\'b8

<au>Hooker.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A light deck, usually placed
in a section of the hold or over the floor of the magazine. See
<er>Orlop</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Platform car</col>, <cd>a railway car without permanent
raised sides or covering; a f<?/at.</cd> -- <col>Platform
scale</col>, <cd>a weighing machine, with a flat platform on
which objects are weighed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plat"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<hw>Plat"i*no*type</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<fld>(Photog.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A permanent photographic

<hw>Plat"i*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Of, pertaining to, or containing,
platinum; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in

<hw>Plat"i*num</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Sp. <ets>platina</ets>, from <ets>plata</ets> silver, LL.
<ets>plata</ets> a thin plate of metal. See <er>Plate</er>, and
cf. <er>Platina</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A metallic
element, intermediate in value between silver and gold, occurring
native or alloyed with other metals, also as the platinum
arsenide (sperrylite). It is heavy tin-white metal which is
ductile and malleable, but very infusible, and characterized by
its resistance to strong chemical reagents. It is used for
crucibles, for stills for sulphuric acid, rarely for coin, and in
the form of foil and wire for many purposes. Specific gravity
21.5. Atomic weight 194.3. Symbol Pt. Formerly called
<altname>platina</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Platinum black</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a soft,
dull black powder, consisting of finely divided metallic platinum
obtained by reduction and precipitation from its solutions. It
absorbs oxygen to a high degree, and is employed as an
oxidizer.</cd> -- <col>Platinum lamp</col> <fld>(Elec.)</fld>,
<cd>a kind of incandescent lamp of which the luminous medium is
platinum. See under <er>Incandescent</er>.</cd> -- <col>Platinum
metals</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>the group of metallic
elements which in their chemical and physical properties resemble
platinum. These consist of the <xex>light platinum group<xex>,
viz., rhodium, ruthenium, and palladium, whose specific gravities
are about 12; and the <xex>heavy platinum group<xex>, viz.,
osmium, iridium, and platinum, whose specific gravities are over
21.</cd> -- <col>Platinum sponge</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>,
<cd>metallic platinum in a gray, porous, spongy form, obtained by
reducing the double chloride of platinum and ammonium. It absorbs
oxygen, hydrogen, and certain other gases, to a high degree, and
is employed as an agent in oxidizing.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plat"i*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., from
<ets>plat</ets> flat. See <er>Plate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being flat, thin, or insipid; flat

<q>To hammer one golden grain of wit into a sheet of infinite
<qex>platitude</qex>.</q>
<qau>Motley.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A thought or remark which is flat, dull, trite,
or weak; a truism; a commonplace.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pla*ton"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pla*ton"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Platonicus</ets>, Gr. <?/: cf. F.
<ets>platonique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining
to Plato, or his philosophy, school, or opinions.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pure, passionless; nonsexual;
philosophical.</def>

<cs><col>Platonic bodies</col>, <cd>the five regular geometrical
solids; namely, the tetrahedron, hexahedron or cube, octahedron,
dodecahedron, and icosahedron.</cd> -- <col>Platonic love</col>,
<cd>a pure, spiritual affection, subsisting between persons of
opposite sex, unmixed with carnal desires, and regarding the mind
only and its excellences; -- a species of love for which Plato
was a warm advocate.</cd><-- = Platonic relation --> --
<col>Platonic year</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>a period of
time determined by the revolution of the equinoxes, or the space
of time in which the stars and constellations return to their
former places in respect to the equinoxes; -- called also
<altname>great year</altname>. This revolution, which is caused
by the precession of the equinoxes, is accomplished in about
26,000 years. <au>Barlow</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pla*ton"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A follower of Plato; a
Platonist.</def>

<hw>Pla*ton"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a Platonic
manner.</def>

<hw>Pla"to*nism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>Platonisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The doctrines or
philosophy by Plato or of his followers.</def>

<note><hand/ Plato believed God to be an infinitely wise, just,
and powerful Spirit; and also that he formed the visible universe
out of pre\'89xistent amorphous matter, according to perfect
patterns of ideas eternally existent in his own mind. Philosophy
he considered as being a knowledge of the true nature of things,
as discoverable in those eternal ideas after which all things
were fashioned. In other words, it is the knowledge of what is
eternal, exists necessarily, and is unchangeable; not of the
temporary, the dependent, and changeable; and of course it is not
obtained through the senses; neither is it the product of the
understanding, which concerns itself only with the variable and
transitory; nor is it the result of experience and observation;
but it is the product of our <xex>reason</xex>, which, as
partaking of the divine nature, has innate ideas resembling the
eternal ideas of God. By contemplating these innate ideas,
reasoning about them, and comparing them with their copies in the
visible universe, reason can attain that true knowledge of things
which is called <xex>philosophy</xex>. Plato's professed
followers, the Academics, and the New Platonists, differed
considerably from him, yet are called
<xex>Platonists</xex>.</note>

<au>Murdock.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An elevated rational and ethical conception of
the laws and forces of the universe; sometimes, imaginative or
fantastic philosophical notions.</def>

<hw>Pla"to*nist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
adheres to the philosophy of Plato; a follower of Plato.</def>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>Pla"to*nize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Platonized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Platonizing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To adopt the opinion of
Plato or his followers.</def>

<au>Milner.</au>

<hw>Pla"to*nize</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To explain by, or
accomodate to, the Platonic philosophy.</def>

<au>Enfield.</au>

<hw>Plau"dit</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From L.

<qex>plausibilities</qex>.</q>
<qau>E. Vaughan.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality of being plausible;
speciousness.</def>

<q>To give any <qex>plausibility</qex> to a scheme.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Anything plausible or specious.</def>

<au>R. Browning.</au>

<hw>Plau"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plausibilis</ets> praiseworthy, from <ets>plaudere</ets>,
<ets>plausum</ets>, to applaud, clap the hands, strike,
beat.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Worthy of being applauded;
praiseworthy; commendable; ready.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hacket.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Obtaining approbation; specifically pleasing;
apparently right; specious; <as>as, a <ex>plausible</ex> pretext;
<ex>plausible</ex> manners; a <ex>plausible</ex>
delusion.</as></def> \'bd<xex>Plausible</xex> and popular
arguments.\'b8

<au>Clarendon.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Using specious arguments or discourse; <as>as, a
<ex>plausible</ex> speaker</as>.</def>

<-- 4 appearing worthy of belief [MW10].  Now the most common
sense, and a good sense, rather than the traditional bad sense.
-->

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Plausible</er>, <er>Specious</er>.</syn> <usage>
<xex>Plausible</xex> denotes that which seems reasonable, yet
leaves distrust in the judgment. <xex>Specious</xex> describes
that which presents a fair appearance to the view and yet covers
something false. <xex>Specious</xex> refers more definitely to
the act or purpose of false representation; <xex>plausible</xex>
has more reference to the effect on the beholder or hearer. An
argument may by <xex>specious</xex> when it is not
<xex>plausible</xex> because its sophistry is so easily
discovered.</usage>

<hw>Plau"si*ble*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
render plausible.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Plau"si*ble*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Quality of being
plausible.</def>

<hw>Plau"si*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a
plausible manner.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Contentedly, readily.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The Romans <qex>plausibly</qex> did give consent.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Plau"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plaudere</ets>, <ets>plausum</ets>, to applaud.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Applauding; manifesting praise.</def>

<au>Young.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Plausible, specious.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Play</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Played</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Playing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>pleien</ets>, AS. <ets>plegian</ets>,
<ets>plegan</ets>, to play, akin to <ets>plega</ets> play, game,
quick motion, and probably to OS. <ets>plegan</ets> to promise,
pledge, D. <ets>plegen</ets> to care for, attend to, be wont, G.
<ets>pflegen</ets>; of unknown origin. <root/28. Cf.
<er>Plight</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To engage
in sport or lively recreation; to exercise for the sake of
amusement; to frolic; to spot.</def>

<q>As Cannace was <qex>playing</qex> in her walk.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>The lamb thy riot dooms to bleed to-day,
Had he thy reason, would he skip and <qex>play</qex>!</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>And some, the darlings of their Lord,
<qex>Play</qex> smiling with the flame and sword.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To act with levity or thoughtlessness; to
trifle; to be careless.</def>

<q>\'bdNay,\'b8 quod this monk, \'bdI have no lust to
<qex>pleye</qex>.\'b8</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Men are apt to <qex>play</qex> with their healths.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To contend, or take part, in a game; <as>as, to
<ex>play</ex> ball</as>; hence, to gamble; <as>as, he
<ex>played</ex> for heavy stakes</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To perform on an instrument of music; <as>as, to
<ex>play</ex> on a flute</as>.</def>

<q>One that . . . can <qex>play</qex> well on an instrument.</q>
<qau>Ezek. xxxiii. 32.</qau>

<q><qex>Play</qex>, my friend, and charm the charmer.</q>
<qau>Granville.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To act; to behave; to practice deception.</def>

<q>His mother <qex>played</qex> false with a smith.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To move in any manner; especially, to move
regularly with alternate or reciprocating motion; to operate; to
act; <as>as, the fountain <ex>plays</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The heart beats, the blood circulates, the lungs
<qex>play</qex>.</q>
<qau>Cheyne.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To move gayly; to wanton; to disport.</def>

<q>Even as the waving sedges <qex>play</qex> with wind.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The setting sun
<qex>Plays</qex> on their shining arms and burnished helmets.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>All fame is foreign but of true desert,
<qex>Plays</qex> round the head, but comes not to the heart.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To act on the stage; to personate a
character.</def>

<q>A lord will hear your <qex>play</qex> to-night.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Courts are theaters where some men <qex>play</qex>.</q>
<qau>Donne.</qau>

<cs><col>To play into a person's hands</col>, <cd>to act, or to
manage matters, to his advantage or benefit.</cd> -- <col>To play
off</col>, <cd>to affect; to feign; to practice artifice.</cd> --
<col>To play upon</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To make sport of; to
deceive.</cd>

<q>Art thou alive?
Or is it fantasy that <qex>plays upon</qex> our eyesight.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To use in a droll manner; to give a droll
expression or application to; as, <xex>to play upon</xex>
words.</cd></cs>
<-- play around -->

<hw>Play</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To put in action
or motion; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex> cannon upon a fortification;
to <ex>play</ex> a trump.</as></def>

<q>First Peace and Silence all disputes control,
Then Order <qex>plays</qex> the soul.</q>
<qau>Herbert.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To perform music upon; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex>
the flute or the organ</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To perform, as a piece of music, on an
instrument; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex> a waltz on the
violin</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To bring into sportive or wanton action; to
exhibit in action; to execute; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex>
tricks</as>.</def>

<q>Nature here
Wantoned as in her prime, and <qex>played</qex> at will
Her virgin fancies.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To act or perform (a play); to represent in
music action; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex> a comedy</as>; also, to
act in the character of; to represent by acting; to simulate; to
behave like; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex> King Lear; to <ex>play</ex>
the woman.</as></def>

<q>Thou canst <qex>play</qex> the rational if thou wilt.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To engage in, or go together with, as a contest
for amusement or for a wager or prize; <as>as, to <ex>play</ex> a
game at baseball</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To keep in play, as a hooked fish, in order to
land it.</def>

<cs><col>To play off</col>, <cd>to display; to show; to put in
exercise; as, <xex>to play off<xex> tricks.</cd> -- <col>To play
one's cards</col>, <cd>to manage one's means or opportunities; to
contrive.</cd> -- <col>Played out</col>, <cd>tired out;
exhausted; at the end of one's resources.</cd>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cs>

<hw>Play</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Amusement; sport;
frolic; gambols.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any exercise, or series of actions, intended for
amusement or diversion; a game.</def>

<q>John naturally loved rough <qex>play</qex>.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The act or practice of contending for victory,
amusement, or a prize, as at dice, cards, or billiards; gaming;
<as>as, to lose a fortune in <ex>play</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Action; use; employment; exercise; practice;
<as>as, fair <ex>play</ex>; sword <ex>play</ex>; a <ex>play</ex>
of wit.</as></def> \'bdThe next who comes in <xex>play</xex>.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A dramatic composition; a comedy or tragedy; a
composition in which characters are represented by dialogue and
action.</def>

<q>A <qex>play</qex> ought to be a just image of human
nature.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The representation or exhibition of a comedy or
tragedy; <as>as, he attends ever <ex>play</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Performance on an instrument of music.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>Motion; movement, regular or irregular; <as>as,
the <ex>play</ex> of a wheel or piston</as>; hence, also, room
for motion; free and easy action.</def> \'bdTo give them
<xex>play</xex>, front and rear.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The joints are let exactly into one another, that they have no
<qex>play</qex> between them.</q>
<qau>Moxon.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>Hence, liberty of acting; room for enlargement
or display; scope; <as>as, to give full <ex>play</ex> to
mirth</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Play actor</col>, <cd>an actor of dramas.
<au>Prynne</au>.</cd> -- <col>Play debt</col>, <cd>a gambling
debt. <au>Arbuthnot</au>.</cd> -- <col>Play pleasure</col>,
<cd>idle amusement. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Bacon</au>.</cd> --
<col>A play upon words</col>, <cd>the use of a word in such a way
as to be capable of double meaning; punning.</cd> -- <col>Play of
colors</col>, <cd>prismatic variation of colors.</cd> --
<mcol><col>To bring into play</col>, <col>To come into
play</col></mcol>, <cd>to bring or come into use or
exercise.</cd> -- <col>To hold in play</col>, <cd>to keep
occupied or employed.</cd></cs>
<-- in play. (a) (baseball, football) [of a ball] to still be
subject to action so as to affect the game, true as long as the
specific play has not been completed.  Opposite of out of play,
out of bounds. (b) (Corporate Finance) subject to acquisition or
merger; said of companies which have been discussed as potential
acquisitions by potentially acquiring companies. -->

<q>I, with two more to help me,
Will <qex>hold</qex> the foe <qex>in play</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Plea</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>plee</ets>, <ets>plai</ets>, <ets>plait</ets>, fr. OF.
<ets>plait</ets>, <ets>plaid</ets>, <ets>plet</ets>, LL.
<ets>placitum</ets> judgment, decision, assembly, court, fr. L.
<ets>placitum</ets> that which is pleasing, an opinion,
sentiment, from <ets>placere</ets> to please. See
<er>Please</er>, and cf. <er>Placit</er>, <er>Plead</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>That which is alleged by a
party in support of his cause; in a stricter sense, an allegation
of fact in a cause, as distinguished from a <xex>demurrer</xex>;
in a still more limited sense, and in modern practice, the
defendant's answer to the plaintiff's declaration and demand.
That which the plaintiff alleges in his declaration is answered
and repelled or justified by the defendant's <xex>plea</xex>. In
chancery practice, a <xex>plea</xex> is a special answer showing
or relying upon one or more things as a cause why the suit should
be either dismissed, delayed, or barred. In criminal practice,
the <xex>plea</xex> is the defendant's formal answer to the
indictment or information presented against him.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A cause in court; a lawsuit;
<as>as, the Court of Common <ex>Pleas</ex></as>. See under
<er>Common</er>.</def>

<q>The Supreme Judicial Court shall have cognizance of
<qex>pleas</qex> real, personal, and mixed.</q>
<qau>Laws of Massachusetts.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is alleged or pleaded, in defense or
in justification; an excuse; an apology.</def> \'bdNecessity, the
tyrant's <xex>plea</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>No <qex>plea</qex> must serve; 't is cruelty to spare.</q>
<qau>Denham.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An urgent prayer or entreaty.</def>

<cs><col>Pleas of the crown</col> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld>,
<cd>criminal actions.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pleach</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pleached</er>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pleaching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>plaissier</ets> to bend, and also F. <ets>plisser</ets> to
plait, L. <ets>plicare</ets>, <ets>plicitum</ets>, to fold, lay,
or wind together. Cf. <er>Plash</er> to pleach.]</ety> <def>To
unite by interweaving, as branches of trees; to plash; to
interlock.</def> \'bdThe <xex>pleached</xex> bower.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Plead</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pleaded</er>
(<mark>colloq.</mark> <er>Plead</er> <pr>(?)</pr> or
<er>Pled</er>); <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pleading</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>pleden</ets>,
<ets>plaiden</ets>, OF. plaidier, F. <ets>plaider</ets>, fr. LL.
<ets>placitare</ets>, fr. <ets>placitum</ets>. See
<er>Plea</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To argue in support of a
claim, or in defense against the claim of another; to urge
reasons for or against a thing; to attempt to persuade one by
argument or supplication; to speak by way of persuasion; <as>as,
to <ex>plead</ex> for the life of a criminal; to <ex>plead</ex>
with a judge or with a father.</as></def>

<q>O that one might <qex>plead</qex> for a man with God, as a man
<qex>pleadeth</qex> for his neighbor!</q>
<qau>Job xvi. 21.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To present an answer, by
allegation of fact, to the declaration of a plaintiff; to deny
the plaintiff's declaration and demand, or to allege facts which
show that ought not to recover in the suit; in a less strict
sense, to make an allegation of fact in a cause; to carry on the
allegations of the respective parties in a cause; to carry on a
suit or plea.</def>

<au>Blackstone. Burrill. Stephen.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To contend; to struggle.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Plead</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
discuss, defend, and attempt to maintain by arguments or reasons
presented to a tribunal or person having uthority to determine;
to argue at the bar; <as>as, to <ex>plead</ex> a cause before a
court or jury</as>.</def>

<q>Every man should <qex>plead</qex> his own matter.</q>
<qau>Sir T. More.</qau>

<note><hand/ In this sense, <xex>argue</xex> is more generally
used by lawyers.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To allege or cite in a legal plea or defense, or
for repelling a demand in law; to answer to an indictment;
<as>as, to <ex>plead</ex> usury; to <ex>plead</ex> statute of
limitations; to <ex>plead</ex> not guilty.</as></def>

<au>Kent.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To allege or adduce in proof, support, or
vendication; to offer in excuse; <as>as, the law of nations may
be <ex>pleaded</ex> in favor of the rights of
ambassadors</as>.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>I will neither <qex>plead</qex> my age nor sickness, in excuse
of faults.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Plead"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable of
being pleaded; capable of being alleged in proof, defense, or
vindication; <as>as, a right or privilege <ex>pleadable</ex> at
law</as>.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Plead"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plaideur</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who pleads; one
who argues for or against; an advotate.</def>

<q>So fair a <qex>pleader</qex> any cause may gain.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who draws up or forms
pleas; the draughtsman of pleas or pleadings in the widest sense;
<as>as, a special <ex>pleader</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Plead"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of advocating,
defending, or supporting, a cause by arguments.</def>

<hw>Plead"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pleading
manner.</def>

<hw>Plead"ings</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The mutual pleas and replies of the
plaintiff and defendant, or written statements of the parties in
support of their claims, proceeding from the declaration of the
plaintiff, until issue is joined, and the question made to rest
on some single point.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pleas"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plaisance</ets>. See <er>Please</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Pleasure; merriment; gayety; delight; kindness.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark> <au>Shak.</au> \'bdFull great
<xex>pleasance</xex>.\'b8 <au>Chaucer</au>. \'bdA realm of
<xex>pleasance</xex>.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A secluded part of a garden.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>The <qex>pleasances</qex> of old Elizabethan houses.</q>
<qau>Ruskin.</qau>

<hw>Pleas"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plaisant</ets>. See <er>Please</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Pleasing; grateful to the mind or to the senses; agreeable;
<as>as, a <ex>pleasant</ex> journey; <ex>pleasant</ex>
weather.</as></def>

<q>Behold, how good and <qex>pleasant</qex> it is for brethren to
dwell together in unity!</q>
<qau>Ps. cxxxiii. 1.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Cheerful; enlivening; gay; sprightly; humorous;
sportive; <as>as, <ex>pleasant</ex> company; a <ex>pleasant</ex>
fellow.</as></def>

<q>From grave to light, from <qex>pleasant</qex> to serve.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Pleasing; gratifying; agreeable; cheerful;
good-humored; enlivening; gay; lively; merry; sportive; humorous;
jocose; amusing; witty.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Pleasant</er>,
<er>Pleasing</er>, <er>Agreeable</er>. <xex>Agreeable</xex> is
applied to that which agrees with, or is in harmony with, one's
tastes, character, etc. <xex>Pleasant</xex> and
<xex>pleasing</xex> denote a stronger degree of the agreeable.
<xex>Pleasant</xex> refers rather to the state or condition;
<xex>pleasing</xex>, to the act or effect. Where they are applied
to the same object, <xex>pleasing</xex> is more energetic than
<xex>pleasant</xex>; <as>as, she is always <ex>pleasant</ex> and
always <ex>pleasing</ex></as>. The distinction, however, is not
radical and not rightly observed.</usage>

<hw>Pleas"ant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A wit; a humorist; a
buffoon.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pleas"ant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a pleasant
manner.</def>

<hw>Pleas"ant*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state or quality
of being pleasant.</def>

<hw>Pleas"ant*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pleasantries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>plaisanterie</ets>. See <er>Pleasant</er>.]</ety> <def>That
which denotes or promotes pleasure or good humor; cheerfulness;
gayety; merriment; especially, an agreeable playfulness in
conversation; a jocose or humorous remark; badinage.</def>

<q>The grave abound in <qex>pleasantries</qex>, the dull in
repartees and points of wit.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>The keen observation and ironical <qex>pleasantry</qex> of a
finished man of the world.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pleas"ant-tongued`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
pleasing speech.</def>

<hw>Please</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pleased</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Pleasing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>plesen</ets>, OF. <ets>plaisir</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>placere</ets>, akin to <ets>placare</ets> to reconcile. Cf.
<er>Complacent</er>, <er>Placable</er>, <er>Placid</er>,
<er>Plea</er>, <er>Plead</er>, <er>Pleasure</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To give pleasure to; to excite agreeable
sensations or emotions in; to make glad; to gratify; to content;
to satisfy.</def>

<q>I pray to God that it may <qex>plesen</qex> you.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>What next I bring shall <qex>please</qex> thee, be
assured.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have or take pleasure in; hence, to choose;
to wish; to desire; to will.</def>

<q>Whatsoever the Lord <qex>pleased</qex>, that did he.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxxxv. 6.</qau>

<q>A man doing as he wills, and doing as he <qex>pleases</qex>,
are the same things in common speech.</q>
<qau>J. Edwards.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To be the will or pleasure of; to seem good to;
-- used impersonally.</def> \'bdIt <xex>pleased</xex> the Father
that in him should all fullness dwell.\'b8

<au>Col. i. 19.</au>

<q>To-morrow, may it <qex>please</qex> you.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>To be pleased in</col> <or/
<col>with</col></mcol>, <cd>to have complacency in; to take
pleasure in.</cd> -- <col>To be pleased to do a thing</col>,
<cd>to take pleasure in doing it; to have the will to do it; to
think proper to do it.</cd></cs>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Please</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To afford or impart pleasure; to excite agreeable
emotions.</def>

<q>What <qex>pleasing</qex> scemed, for her now
<qex>pleases</qex> more.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>For we that live to <qex>please</qex>, must <qex>please</qex>
to live.</q>
<qau>Johnson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have pleasure; to be willing, as a matter of
affording pleasure or showing favor; to vouchsafe; to
consent.</def>

<q>Heavenly stranger, <qex>please</qex> to taste
These bounties.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>That he would <qex>please</qex> 8give me my liberty.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

pleasure.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pleas"ed*ly</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<pos>adv.</pos> -- <wf>Pleas"ed*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Please"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An officious
person who courts favor servilely; a pickthank.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pleas"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pleases or gratifies.</def>

<hw>Pleas"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Giving pleasure or
satisfaction; causing agreeable emotion; agreeable; delightful;
<as>as, a <ex>pleasing</ex> prospect; <ex>pleasing</ex>
manners.</as></def>  \'bd<xex>Pleasing</xex> harmony.\'b8
<au>Shak.</au> \'bd<xex>Pleasing</xex> features.\'b8
<au>Macaulay</au>. -- <wordforms><wf>Pleas"ing*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos> -- <wf>Pleas"ing*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<syn>Syn. -- Gratifying; delightful; agreeable. See
<er>Pleasant</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pleas"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An object of
pleasure.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pleas"ur*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of affording pleasure or satisfaction; gratifying; abounding in
pleasantness or pleasantry.</def>

<q>Planting of orchards is very . . . <qex>pleasurable</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>O, sir, you are very <qex>pleasurable</qex>.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<hw>Pleas"ure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plaisir</ets>, originally an infinitive. See
<er>Please</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The gratification of the
senses or of the mind; agreeable sensations or emotions; the
excitement, relish, or happiness produced by the expectation or
the enjoyment of something good, delightful, or satisfying; --
opposed to <ant>pain</ant>, <ant>sorrow</ant>, etc.</def>

<q>At thy right hand there are <qex>pleasures</qex> for
evermore.</q>
<qau>Ps. xvi. 11.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Amusement; sport; diversion; self-indulgence;
frivolous or dissipating enjoyment; hence, sensual gratification;
-- opposed to <xex>labor</xex>, <xex>service</xex>,
<xex>duty</xex>, <xex>self-denial</xex>, etc.</def> \'bdNot sunk
in carnal <xex>pleasure</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>He that loveth <qex>pleasure</qex> shall be a poor man.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxi. 17.</qau>

<q>Lovers of <qex>pleasures</qex> more than lovers of God.</q>
<qau>2 Tim. iii. 4.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>What the will dictates or prefers as gratifying
or satisfying; hence, will; choice; wish; purpose.</def> \'bdHe
will do his <xex>pleasure</xex> on Babylon.\'b8

<au>Isa. xlviii. 14.</au>

<q>Use your <qex>pleasure</qex>; if your love do not presuade you
to come, let not my letter.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which pleases; a favor; a
gratification.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Festus, willing to do the Jews a <qex>pleasure</qex></q>
<qau>Acts xxv. 9.</qau>

<cs><col>At pleasure</col>, <cd>by arbitrary will or choice.
<au>Dryden</au>.</cd> -- <col>To take pleasure in</col>, <cd>to
have enjoyment in.</cd> <au>Ps. cxlvii. 11</au>.</cs>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pleasure</xex> is used adjectively, or in the
formation of self-explaining compounds; as, <xex>pleasure</xex>
boat, <xex>pleasure</xex> ground; <xex>pleasure</xex> house,
etc.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Enjoyment; gratification; satisfaction; comfort;
solace; joy; gladness; delight; will; choice; preference;
purpose; command; favor; kindness.</syn>

<hw>Pleas"ure</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pleasured</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pleasuring</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To give or afford
pleasure to; to please; to gratify.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>[Rolled] his hoop to <qex>pleasure</qex> Edith.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Pleas"ure</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To take pleasure; to
seek pursue pleasure; <as>as, to go
<ex>pleasuring</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Plebe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pl\'8abe</ets>, fr. L. <ets>plebs</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The common people; the mob.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>plebe</qex> with thirst and fury prest.</q>
<qau>Sylvester.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Cf. <er>Plebeian</er>.]</ety> <def>A member of
the lowest class in the military academy at West Point.</def>
<mark>[Cant, U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Ple*be"ian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plebeius</ets>, from <ets>plebs</ets>, <ets>plebis</ets>,
the common people: cf. F. <ets>pl\'82b\'82ien</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the Roman <xex>plebs</xex>,
or common people.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the common people; vulgar;
common; <as>as, <ex>plebeian</ex> sports; a <ex>plebeian</ex>
throng.</as></def>

<hw>Ple*be"ian</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the
<xex>plebs</xex>, or common people of ancient Rome, in
distinction from <xex>patrician</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of the common people, or lower rank of
men.</def>

<hw>Ple*be"iance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Plebeianism.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Plebeians, collectively.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Ple*be"ian*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pl\'82b\'82ianisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
quality or state of being plebeian.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The conduct or manners of plebeians;
vulgarity.</def>

<hw>Ple*be"ian*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plebeianized</er>

<er>Plebeianizing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To render plebeian,

<hw>Ple*bic"o*list</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plebs</ets> the common people + <ets>colere</ets> to

<hw>Pleb`i*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<q>You begin with the attempt to popularize learning . . . but
you will end in the <qex>plebification</qex> of knowledge.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>Ple*bis"ci*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to plebiscite.</def>

<au>The Century.</au>

<hw>Pleb"i*scite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pl\'82biscite</ets>, fr. L. <ets>plebiscitum</ets>.]</ety>
<def>A vote by universal male suffrage; especially, in France, a
popular vote, as first sanctioned by the National Constitution of
1791.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>plebiscit</asp>.]</altsp>

<q><qex>Plebiscite</qex> we have lately taken, in popular use,
from the French.</q>
<qau>Fitzed. Hall.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Ple`bis*ci"tum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
fr. <ets>plebs</ets>, <ets>plebis</ets>, common people +
<ets>scitum</ets> decree.]</ety> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>A
law enacted by the common people, under the superintendence of a
tribune or some subordinate plebeian magistrate, without the
intervention of the senate.</def>

<ets>plectilis</ets>.]</ety> <def>Woven; plaited.</def>

<hw>Plec"tog*nath</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Plectognathi.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
Plectognathi.</def></def2>

<hw>\'d8Plec*to"gna*thi</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/ twisted (fr. <?/ to plait, twist) + <?/
jaw.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of fishes
generally having the maxillary bone united with the premaxillary,
and the articular united with the dentary.</def>

<note><hand/ The upper jaw is immovably joined to the skull; the
ventral fins are rudimentary or wanting; and the body is covered
with bony plates, spines, or small rough ossicles, like shagreen.
The order includes the diodons, filefishes, globefishes, and
trunkfishes.</note>

<mhw>{ <hw>Plec`tog*nath"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Plec-tog"na*thous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Plectognathi.</def>

<hw>\'d8Plec`to*spon"dy*li</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ plaited + <?/, <?/, a vertebra.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An extensive suborder of fresh-water
physostomous fishes having the anterior vertebr\'91 united and
much modified; the Eventognathi.</def>

<hw>Plec`to*spon"dy*lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Plectospondyli.</def>

<hw>Pledge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>plege</ets>, <ets>pleige</ets>, pledge, guaranty, LL.
<ets>plegium</ets>, <ets>plivium</ets>; akin to OF.
<ets>plevir</ets> to bail, guaranty, perhaps fr. L.
<ets>praebere</ets> to proffer, offer (<ets>sc.</ets>
<ets>fidem</ets> a trust, a promise of security), but cf. also E.
<ets>play</ets>. <root/28. Cf. <er>Prebend</er>,
<er>Replevin</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The
transfer of possession of personal property from a debtor to a
creditor as security for a debt or engagement; also, the contract
created between the debtor and creditor by a thing being so
delivered or deposited, forming a species of bailment; also, that
which is so delivered or deposited; something put in pawn.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pledge</xex> is ordinarily confined to personal
property; the title or ownership does not pass by it; possession
is essential to it. In all these points it differs from a
mortgage [see <er>Mortgage</er>]; and in the last, from the
<xex>hypotheca</xex> of the Roman law. See
<er>Hypotheca</er>.</note>

<au>Story. Kent.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Old Eng. Law)</fld> <def>A person who
undertook, or became responsible, for another; a bail; a surety;
a hostage.</def> \'bdI am Grumio's <xex>pledge</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A hypothecation without transfer of
possession.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Anything given or considered as a security for
the performance of an act; a guarantee; <as>as, mutual interest
is the best <ex>pledge</ex> for the performance of
treaties</as>.</def> \'bdThat voice, their liveliest
<xex>pledge</xex> of hope.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A promise or agreement by which one binds one's
self to do, or to refrain from doing, something; especially, a
solemn promise in writing to refrain from using intoxicating
liquors or the like; <as>as, to sign the <ex>pledge</ex>; the
mayor had made no <ex>pledges</ex>.</as></def>

<-- esp. in "take the pledge" -->

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A sentiment to which assent is given by drinking
one's health; a toast; a health.</def>

<cs><col>Dead pledge</col>. <ety>[A translation of <er>LL</er>.
<ets>mortuum vadium<ets>.] <fld>(Law)<fld> <cd>A mortgage. See
<er>Mortgage</er>.</cd> -- <col>Living pledge</col>. <ety>[A
translation of LL. <ets>vivum vadium<ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>The conveyance of an estate to another for
money borrowed, to be held by him until the debt is paid out of
the rents and profits.</cd> -- <col>To hold in pledge</col>,
<cd>to keep as security.</cd> -- <col>To put in pledge</col>,
<cd>to pawn; to give as security.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Earnest</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pledge</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pledged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pledging</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>pleiger</ets> to give security. See <er>Pledge</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To deposit, as a chattel,
in pledge or pawn; to leave in possession of another as security;
<as>as, <ex>to pledge</ex> one's watch</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To give or pass as a security; to guarantee; to
engage; to plight; <as>as, to <ex>pledge</ex> one's word and
honor</as>.</def>

<q>We mutually <qex>pledge</qex> to each other our lives, our
fortunes, and our sacred honor.</q>
<qau>The Declaration of Independence.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To secure performance of, as by a pledge.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To <qex>pledge</qex> my vow, I give my hand.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To bind or engage by promise or declaration; to
engage solemnly; <as>as, to <ex>pledge</ex> one's
self</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To invite another to drink, by drinking of the
cup first, and then handing it to him, as a pledge of good will;
hence, to drink the health of; to toast.</def>

<q><qex>Pledge</qex> me, my friend, and drink till thou be'st
wise.</q>
<qau>Cowley.</qau>

<hw>Pledg*ee"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The one to
whom a pledge is given, or to whom property pledged is
delivered.</def>

<hw>Pledge"less</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no
pledge.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pledge*or"</hw>, <hw>Pledg*or"</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who
pledges, or delivers anything in pledge; a pledger; -- opposed to
<ant>pledgee</ant>.</def>

<note><hand/ This word analogically requires the <xex>e</xex>
after <xex>g</xex>, but the spelling <xex>pledgor</xex> is
perhaps commoner.</note>

<hw>Pledg"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pledges.</def>

<hw>Ple"ia*des</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[L., fr. Gr. (<?/)]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Myth.)</fld>
<def>The seven daughters of Atlas and the nymph Pleione, fabled
to have been made by Jupiter a constellation in the sky.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>A group of small stars in
the neck of the constellation Taurus.</def>

<au>Job xxxviii. 31.</au>

<note><hand/ Alcyone, the brightest of these, a star of the third
magnitude, was considered by M\'84dler the central point around
which our universe is revolving, but there is no sufficient
evidence of such motion. Only six pleiads are distinctly visible
to the naked eye, whence the ancients supposed that a sister had
concealed herself out of shame for having loved a mortal,
Sisyphus.</note>

<hw>Plen"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Plenties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, in <au>Shak</plu>.</au>

<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

the world.</q>

<hw>Ple`o*mor"phism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.

<def>The property of crystallizing under two or more distinct

<xex>trimorphism</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The theory that the various
genera of bacteria are phases or variations of growth of a number
of Protean species, each of which may exhibit, according to
undetermined conditions, all or some of the forms characteristic
of the different genera and species.</def><-- thoroughly
discredited, except for a few apparent examples of such a
phenomenon. -->

<plu>pl. <plw>Pleurapophyses</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.

<pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<cs><col>Pleurisy root</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The large tuberous root of a kind of milkweed (<spn>Asclepias
tuberosa</spn>) which is used as a remedy for pleuritic and other
diseases</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The plant itself, which has deep
orange-colored flowers; -- called also <altname>butterfly
weed</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pleu`ro*per`i*to*ne"um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pleuro-</ets> + <ets>peritoneum</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The pleural and peritoneal membranes, or

the inclosed viscera; the peritoneum; -- used especially in the
case of those animals in which the body cavity is not
divided.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Peritoneum</xex> is now often used in the sense
of <xex>pleuroperitoneum</xex>, the pleur\'91 being regarded as a
part of the peritoneum, when the body cavity is undivided.</note>

<hw>Pleu`ro*pneu*mo"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Flexible in disposition; readily yielding to

reason.</q>

<hw>\'d8Pli"ca</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL., a

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A diseased state in plants in
which there is an excessive development of small entangled twigs,
instead of ordinary branches.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The bend of the wing of a
bird.</def>

<hw>Plight</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <mark>obs.</mark> <def><pos>imp. &

<hw>Plight</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>pliten</ets>;
probably through Old French, fr. LL. <ets>plectare</ets>, L.
<ets>plectere</ets>. See <er>Plait</er>, <er>Ply</er>.]</ety>
<def>To weave; to braid; to fold; to
plait.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdTo sew and
<xex>plight</xex>.\'b8<-- in the sense of fold, = pleat [plait 2
in MW10]-->

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>A <qex>plighted</qex> garment of divers colors.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Plight</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A network; a
plait; a fold; rarely a garment.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bdMany a folded <xex>plight</xex>.\'b8<-- = pleat -->

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Plight</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>pliht</ets> danger,
engagement, AS. <ets>pliht</ets> danger, fr. <ets>ple\'a2n</ets>
to risk; akin to D. <ets>plicht</ets> duty, G.
<ets>pflicht</ets>, Dan. <ets>pligt</ets>. <root/28. Cf.
<er>Play</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is exposed to
risk; that which is plighted or pledged; security; a gage; a
pledge.</def> \'bdThat lord whose hand must take my
<xex>plight</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Perh. the same word as <ets>plight</ets> a
pledge, but at least influenced by OF. <ets>plite</ets>,
<ets>pliste</ets>, <ets>ploit</ets>, <ets>ploi</ets>, a
condition, state; cf. E. <ets>plight</ets> to fold, and F.
<ets>pli</ets> a fold, habit, <ets>plier</ets> to fold, E.
<ets>ply</ets>.]</ety> <def>Condition; state; -- risk, or
exposure to danger, often being implied; <as>as, a luckless
<ex>plight</ex></as>.</def> \'bdYour <xex>plight</xex> is
pitied.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To bring our craft all in another <qex>plight</qex></q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Plight</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plighted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Plighting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>plihtan</ets> to
expose to danger, <ets>pliht</ets> danger;cf. D.
ver<ets>plichten</ets> to oblige, engage, impose a duty, G.
ver<ets>pflichten</ets>, Sw. f\'94r<ets>plikta</ets>, Dan.
for<ets>pligte</ets>. See <er>Plight</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pledge; to give as a pledge for the
performance of some act; as, to <xex>plight</xex> faith, honor,
word; -- never applied to property or goods. \'bd To do them
<xex>plighte</xex> their troth.\'b8</q>

<au>Piers Plowman.</au>

<q>He <qex>plighted</qex> his right hand
Unto another love, and to another land.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Here my inviolable faith I <qex>plight</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To promise; to engage; to betroth.</def>

<q>Before its setting hour, divide
The bridegroom from the <qex>plighted</qex> bride.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<hw>Plight"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, plights.</def>

<hw>Plim</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Plump</er>.]</ety> <def>To swell, as grain or wood with
water.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Grose.</au>

<hw>Plim"soll's mark`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<def>A mark conspicuously painted on the port side of all British
sea-going merchant vessels, to indicate the limit of submergence
allowed by law; -- so called from Samuel <ets>Plimsoll</ets>, by
whose efforts the act of Parliament to prevent overloading was
procured.</def>

<hw>Plinth</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plinthus</ets>, Gr. <?/ a brick or tile, a plinth, perh.
akin to E. <ets>flint</ets>: cf. F. <ets>plinthe</ets>.]</ety>
<def>(Arch.) In classical architecture, a vertically faced member
immediately below the circular base of a column; also, the lowest
member of a pedestal; hence, in general, the lowest member of a
base; a sub-base; a block upon which the moldings of an
architrave or trim are stopped at the bottom. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Column</er>.</def>

<hw>Pli"o*cene</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <altsp>[Written
also <ets>pleiocene</ets>.]</altsp> <ety>[Gr. <?/ more + <?/ new,
recent.]</ety> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Of, pertaining to, or
characterizing, the most recent division of the Tertiary
age.</def>

<hw>Pli"o*cene</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>The
Pliocene period or deposits.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pli`o*hip"pus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. E. <ets>plio</ets>cene + Gr. <?/ horse.]</ety>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An extinct genus of horses from the
Pliocene deposits. Each foot had a single toe (or hoof), as in
the common horse.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pli`o*sau"rus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
from Gr. <?/ greater + <?/ lizard.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld>
<def>An extinct genus of marine reptiles allied to Plesiosaurus,
but having a much shorter neck.</def>

<ets>plete</ets>.]</ety> <def>An instrument of punishment or
torture resembling the knout, used in Russia.</def>

<hw>Ploc</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A mixture of hair and tar for covering
the bottom of a ship.</def>

<hw>\'d8Plo"ce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/ complication, fr. <?/ to entwine.]</ety> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld>
<def>A figure in which a word is separated or repeated by way of
emphasis, so as not only to signify the individual thing denoted
by it, but also its peculiar attribute or quality; <as>as,
\'bdHis <ex>wife</ex>'s a <ex>wife</ex> indeed</as>.\'b8</def>

<au>Bailey.</au>

<hw>Plod</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plodded</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Plodding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Gf. Gael. <ets>plod</ets> a
clod, a pool; also, to strike or pelt with a clod or
clods.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To travel slowly but steadily; to
trudge.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To toil; to drudge; especially, to study
laboriously and patiently.</def> \'bd<xex>Plodding</xex>
schoolmen.\'b8

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>Plod</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To walk on slowly or
heavily.</def>

<q>The ploughman homeward <qex>plods</qex> his weary way.</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<hw>Plod"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who plods;
a drudge.</def>

<hw>Plod"ding</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Progressing

<as>as, a <ex>plodding</ex> peddler; a <ex>plodding</ex> student;
a man of <ex>plodding</ex> habits.</as></def>
