<hw>Plot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>plot</ets>; cf. Goth. <ets>plats</ets> a patch. Cf.
<er>Plat</er> a piece of ground.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A small
extent of ground; a plat; <as>as, a garden
<ex>plot</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A plantation laid out.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Surv.)</fld> <def>A plan or draught of a field,
farm, estate, etc., drawn to a scale.</def>

<hw>Plot</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plotted</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plotting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To make a plot,
map, pr plan, of; to mark the position of on a plan; to
delineate.</def>

<q> This treatise <qex>plotteth</qex> down Cornwall as it now
standeth.</q>
<qau>Carew.</qau>

<hw>Plot</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev. from
<ets>complot</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any scheme,
stratagem, secret design, or plan, of a complicated nature,
adapted to the accomplishment of some purpose, usually a
treacherous and mischievous one; a conspiracy; an intrigue;
<as>as, the Rye-house <ex>Plot</ex></as>.</def>

<q>I have overheard a <qex>plot</qex> of death.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>O, think what anxious moments pass between
The birth of <qex>plots</qex> and their last fatal periods!</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A share in such a plot or scheme; a
participation in any stratagem or conspiracy.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>And when Christ saith. Who marries the divorced commits
adultery, it is to be understood, if he had any <qex>plot</qex>
in the divorce.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<-- p. 101  -->

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Contrivance; deep reach thought; ability to plot
or intrigue.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdA man of much
<xex>plot</xex>.\'b8

<au>Denham.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A plan; a purpose.</def> \'bdNo other
<xex>plot</xex> in their religion but serve Got and save their
souls.\'b8

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>In fiction, the story of a play, novel, romance,
or poem, comprising a complication of incidents which are
gradually unfolded, sometimes by unexpected means.</def>

<q>If the <qex>plot</qex> or intrigue must be natural, and such
as springs from the subject, then the winding up of the
<qex>plot</qex> must be a probable consequence of all that went
before.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Intrigue; stratagem; conspiracy; cabal; combination;
contrivance.</syn>

<hw>Plot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
form a scheme of mischief against another, especially against a
government or those who administer it; to conspire.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The wicked <qex>plotteth</qex> against the just.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxvii. 12.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To contrive a plan or stratagem; to
scheme.</def>

<q>The prince did <qex>plot</qex> to be secretly gone.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<hw>Plot</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To plan; to scheme; to
devise; to contrive secretly.</def> \'bd<xex>Plotting</xex> an
unprofitable crime.\'b8 <au>Dryden</au>. \'bd<xex>Plotting</xex>
now the fall of others.\'b8

<au>Milton</au>

plots.</def>

philosopher of the third century, who taught that the human soul
emanates from the divine Being, to whom it reunited at
death.</def>

<hw>Plov"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>plovier</ets>, F. <ets>pluvier</ets>, prop., the rain bird,
fr. LL. (assumed) <ets>pluviarius</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pluvia</ets>
rain, from <ets>pluere</ets> to rain; akin to E.
<ets>float</ets>, G. <ets>fliessen</ets> to flow. See
<er>Float</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any
one of numerous species of limicoline birds belonging to the
family <spn>Charadrid\'91</spn>, and especially those belonging
to the subfamily <spn>Charadrins\'91</spn>. They are prized as
game birds.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any grallatorial bird
allied to, or resembling, the true plovers, as the crab plover
(<spn>Dromas ardeola</spn>); the American upland, plover
(<spn>Bartramia longicauda</spn>); and other species of
sandpipers.</def>

<note><hand/ Among the more important species are the
<stype>blackbellied, <or/ blackbreasted, plover</stype>
(<spn>Charadrius squatarola</spn>) of America and Europe; --
called also <altname>gray plover</altname>, <altname>bull-head
plover</altname>, <altname>Swiss plover</altname>, <altname>sea
plover</altname>, and <altname>oxeye</altname>; the <stype>golden
plover</stype> (see under <er>Golden</er>); the <stype>ring <or/
ringed plover</stype> (<spn>\'92gialitis hiaticula</spn>). See
<er>Ringneck</er>. The <stype>piping plover</stype>
(<spn>\'92gialitis meloda</spn>); <stype>Wilson's plover</stype>
(<spn>\'92. Wilsonia</spn>); the <stype>mountain plover</stype>
(<spn>\'92. montana</spn>); and the <stype>semipalmated
plover</stype> (<spn>\'92. semipalmata</spn>), are all small
American species.</note>

<cs><col>Bastard plover</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
lapwing.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Long-legged</col>, <or/
<col>yellow-legged</col>, <col>plover</col></mcol>. <cd>See
<er>Tattler</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plover's page</col>, <cd>the
dunlin.</cd> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> -- <mcol><col>Rock
plover</col>, <or/ <col>Stone plover</col></mcol>, <cd>the
black-bellied plover.</cd> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> --
<col>Whistling plover</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The golden
plover</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The black-bellied plover.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Plow</hw>, <hw>Plough</hw>  }</mhw> <pr>(plou)</pr>,
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>plouh</ets>, <ets>plou</ets>, AS.
<ets>pl\'d3h</ets>; akin to D. <ets>ploeg</ets>, G.
<ets>pflug</ets>, OHG. <ets>pfluog</ets>, <ets>pfluoh</ets>,
Icel. <ets>pl\'d3gr</ets>, Sw. <ets>plog</ets>, Dan.
<ets>ploug</ets>, <ets>plov</ets>, Russ. <ets>plug'</ets>, Lith.
<ets>plugas</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A well-known
implement, drawn by horses, mules, oxen, or other power, for
turning up the soil to prepare it for bearing crops; also used to
furrow or break up the soil for other purposes; <as>as, the
subsoil <ex>plow</ex>; the draining <ex>plow</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Where fern succeeds ungrateful to the <qex>plow</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: Agriculture; husbandry.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A carucate of land; a plowland.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<q>Johan, mine eldest son, shall have <qex>plowes</qex> five.</q>
<qau>Tale of Gamelyn.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A joiner's plane for making grooves; a grooving
plane.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Bookbinding)</fld> <def>An implement for
trimming or shaving off the edges of books.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Charles's
Wain</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Ice plow</col>, <cd>a plow used for cutting ice on
rivers, ponds, etc.</cd>, into cakes suitable for storing.
<mark>[U. S.]</mark> -- <col>Mackerel plow</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Mackerel</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plow alms</col>, <cd>a penny
formerly paid by every plowland to the church.
<au>Cowell</au>.</cd> -- <col>Plow beam</col>, <cd>that part of
the frame of a plow to which the draught is applied. See
<er>Beam</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 9.</cd> -- <col>Plow Monday</col>,
<cd>the Monday after Twelth Day, or the end of Christmas
holidays.</cd> -- <col>Plow staff</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A kind
of long-handled spade or paddle for cleaning the plowshare; a
paddle staff</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A plow handle.</cd> --
<col>Snow plow</col>, <cd>a structure, usually <LAMBDA/-shaped,
for removing snow from sidewalks, railroads, etc., -- drawn or
driven by a horse or a locomotive.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Plow</hw>, <hw>Plough</hw>, }</mhw> <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plowed</er>
<pr>(ploud)</pr> or <er>Ploughed</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Plowing</er> or <er>Ploughing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To turn up, break up, or trench, with a plow; to till with,
or as with, a plow; <as>as, to <ex>plow</ex> the ground; to
<ex>plow</ex> a field.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To furrow; to make furrows, grooves, or ridges
in; to run through, as in sailing.</def>

<q>Let patient Octavia <qex>plow</qex> thy visage up
With her prepared nails.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>With speed we <qex>plow</qex> the watery way.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bookbinding)</fld> <def>To trim, or shave off
the edges of, as a book or paper, with a plow. See <er>Plow</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 5.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Joinery)</fld> <def>To cut a groove in, as in a
plank, or the edge of a board; especially, a rectangular groove
to receive the end of a shelf or tread, the edge of a panel, a
tongue, etc.</def>

<cs><col>To plow in</col>, <cd>to cover by plowing; <as>as,
<ex>to plow in<ex> wheat</as>.</cd> -- <col>To plow up</col>,
<cd>to turn out of the ground by plowing.</cd></cs><-- <col>plow
ahead</col>, <cd>to continue in spite of obstacles or resistence
by others.</cd> <note>Often used in a bad sense, meaning to
continue obstinately in spite of the contrary advice of
others.</note> <col>plow through</col>, <cd>to execute a
difficult or laborious task steadily, esp. one containing many
parts; as, he plowed through the stack of correspondence until
all had been answered.</cd>  -->

<hw>Pluck</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plucked</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Plucking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>pluccian</ets>;
akin to LG. & D. <ets>plukken</ets>, G. <ets>pfl\'81cken</ets>,
Icel. <ets>plokka</ets>, <ets>plukka</ets>, Dan.
<ets>plukke</ets>, Sw. <ets>plocka</ets>. <?/27.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pull; to draw.</def>

<q>Its own nature . . . <qex>plucks</qex> on its own
dissolution.</q>
<qau>Je<?/. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Especially, to pull with sudden force or effort,
or to pull off or out from something, with a twitch; to twitch;
also, to gather, to pick; <as>as, to <ex>pluck</ex> feathers from
a fowl; to <ex>pluck</ex> hair or wool from a skin; to
<ex>pluck</ex> grapes.</as></def>

<q>I come to <qex>pluck</qex> your berries harsh and crude.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>E'en children followed, with endearing wile,
And <qex>plucked</qex> his gown to share the good man's
smile.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To strip of, or as of, feathers; <as>as, to
<ex>pluck</ex> a fowl</as>.</def>

<q>They which pass by the way do <qex>pluck</qex> her.</q>
<qau>Ps. lxxx.<?/2.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Universities)</fld> <def>To reject at an
examination for degrees.</def>

<au>C. Bront\'82.</au>

<cs><col>To pluck away</col>, <cd>to pull away, or to separate by
pulling; to tear away.</cd> -- <col>To pluck down</col>, <cd>to
pull down; to demolish; to reduce to a lower state.</cd> --
<col>to pluck off</col>, <cd>to pull or tear off; <as>as, <ex>to
pluck off<ex> the skin</as>.</cd> -- <col>to pluck up</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To tear up by the roots or from the foundation;
to eradicate; to exterminate; to destroy; <as>as, <ex>to pluck
up<ex> a plant; <ex>to pluk up<ex> a nation</as></cd>. <au>Jer.
xii. 17</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To gather up; to summon; <as>as,
<ex>to pluck up<ex> courage</as>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pluck</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make a motion of pulling
or twitching; -- usually with <xex>at</xex>; <as>as, to
<ex>pluck</ex> at one's gown</as>.</def>

<hw>Pluck</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
plucking; a pull; a twitch.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Prob. so called as being <ets>plucked</ets> out
after the animal is killed; or cf. Gael. & Ir. <ets>pluc</ets> a
lump, a knot, a bunch.]</ety> <def>The heart, liver, and lights
of an animal.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Spirit; courage; indomitable resolution;
fortitude.</def>

<q>Decay of English spirit, decay of manly <qex>pluck</qex>.</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The act of plucking, or the state of being
plucked, at college. See <er>Pluck</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>,
4.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The lyrie.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Plucked</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having courage
and spirit.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pluck"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or
that which, plucks.</def>

<q>Thou setter up and <qex>plucker</qex> down of kings.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A machine for straightening and cleaning
wool.</def>

<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Pluckier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;

<qau>Barham.</qau>

in puffs.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Plug</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to D.
<ets>plug</ets>, G. <ets>pflock</ets>, Dan. <ets>pl\'94k</ets>,
<ets>plug</ets>, Sw. <ets>plugg</ets>; cf. W.
<ets>ploc</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any piece of wood,

stopple.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A flat oblong cake of pressed tobacco.</def>
<mark>[U. S.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A high, tapering silk hat.</def> <mark>[Slang,
U.S.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A worthless horse.</def> <mark>[Slang,
U.S.]</mark>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Building)</fld> <def>A block of wood let into a
wall, to afford a hold for nails.</def>

<cs><col>Fire plug</col>, <cd>a street hydrant to which hose may
be attached.</cd> <mark>[U. S.]</mark> -- <col>Hawse
plug</col></mcol> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a plug to stop a hawse
hole.</cd> -- <col>Plug and feather</col>. <fld>(Stone
Working)</fld> <cd>See <er>Feather</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 7.</cd>
-- <col>Plug centerbit</col>, <cd>a centerbit ending in a small
cylinder instead of a point, so as to follow and enlarge a hole
previously made, or to form a counterbore around it.</cd> --
<col>Plug rod</col> <fld>(Steam Eng.)</fld> <cd>, a rod attached
to the beam for working the valves, as in the Cornish
engine.</cd> -- <col>Plug valve</col> <fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>a
tapering valve, which turns in a case like the <xex>plug<xex> of
a faucet.</cd></cs>

<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To stop with a plug; to make

<hw>Plug"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, plugs.</def>

<hw>Plug"ging</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of

<hw>Plum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[AS.<ets>pl<umac/me</ets>, fr. L. <ets>prunum</ets>; akin to
Gr. <?/, <?/. Cf. <er>Prune</er> a dried plum.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The edible drupaceous fruit of
the <spn>Prunus domestica</spn>, and of several other species of
<spn>Prunus</spn>; also, the tree itself, usually called
<altname>plum tree</altname>.</def>

<q>The bullace, the damson, and the numerous varieties of
<qex>plum</qex>, of our gardens, although growing into thornless
trees, are believed to be varieties of the blackthorn, produced
by long cultivation.</q>
<qau>G. Bentham.</qau>

<-- the types marked <col> are in bold format, like collocations.
-->
<note><hand/ Two or three hundred varieties of plums derived from
the <spn>Prunus domestica</spn> are described; among them the
<xex>greengage</xex>, the <xex>Orleans</xex>, the <xex>purple
gage</xex>, or <xex>Reine Claude Violette</xex>, and the
<xex>German prune</xex>, are some of the best known.</note>

<note><hand/ Among the true plums are; <col>Beach plum</col>, the
<spn>Prunus maritima</spn>, and its crimson or purple globular
drupes, -- <col>Bullace plum</col>. See <er>Bullace</er>. --
<col>Chickasaw plum</col>, the American <spn>Prunus
Chicasa</spn>, and its round red drupes. -- <col>Orleans
plum</col>, a dark reddish purple plum of medium size, much grown
in England for sale in the markets. -- <col>Wild plum of
America</col>, <spn>Prunus Americana</spn>, with red or yellow
fruit, the original of the <stype>Iowa plum</stype> and several
other varieties.

   Among plants called <xex>plum</xex>, but of other genera than
<spn>Prunus</spn>, are; <col>Australian plum</col>,
<spn>Cargillia arborea</spn> and <spn>C. australis</spn>, of the
same family with the persimmon. -- <col>Blood plum</col>, the
West African <spn>H\'91matostaphes Barteri</spn>. -- <col>Cocoa
plum</col>, the Spanish nectarine. See under <er>Nectarine</er>.
-- <col>Date plum</col>. See under <er>Date</er>. --
<col>Gingerbread plum</col>, the West African <spn>Parinarium
macrophyllum</spn>. -- <col>Gopher plum</col>, the Ogeechee lime.
-- <mcol><col>Gray plum</col>, <col>Guinea plum</col></mcol>. See
under <er>Guinea</er>. -- <col>Indian plum</col>, several species
of <spn>Flacourtia</spn>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A grape dried in the sun; a raisin.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A handsome fortune or property; formerly, in
cant language, the sum of \'9c100,000 sterling; also, the person
possessing it.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Plum bird</col>, <col>Plum budder</col></mcol>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the European bullfinch.</cd> --
<col>Plum gouger</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a weevil, or
curculio (<spn>Coccotorus scutellaris</spn>), which destroys
plums. It makes round holes in the pulp, for the reception of its
eggs. The larva bores into the stone and eats the kernel.</cd> --
<col>Plum weevil</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an American
weevil which is very destructive to plums, nectarines cherries,
and many other stone fruits. It lays its eggs in crescent-shaped
incisions made with its jaws. The larva lives upon the pulp
around the stone. Called also <altname>turk</altname>, and
<altname>plum curculio</altname>. See <xex>Illust<xex>. under
<er>Curculio</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Plu"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Plum\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A feather.</def>

<hw>Plum"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., from
<ets>plume</ets> a feather.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The
entire clothing of a bird.</def>

<note><hand/ It consist of the <xex>contour feathers</xex>, or
the ordinary feathers covering the head, neck, and body; the
<xex>tail feathers</xex>, with their upper and lower coverts; the
<xex>wing feathers</xex>, including primaries, secondaries, and
tertiaries, with their coverts; and the <xex>down</xex> which
lies beneath the contour feathers. See <xex>Illust</xex>. under
<er>Bird</er>.</note>

<hw>Plu*mas"sa*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>plumasseau</ets>.]</ety> <def>A plume or collection of
ornamental feathers.</def>

<hw>\'d8Plu`mas`sier"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>One who prepares or deals in ornamental
plumes or feathers.</def>

<hw>Plumb</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>plomb</ets>, L. <ets>plumbum</ets> lead, a leaden ball or
bullet; cf. Gr. <?/, <?/, <?/. Cf. <er>Plummet</er>,
<er>Plunge</er>.]</ety> <def>A little mass or weight of lead, or
the like, attached to a line, and used by builders, etc., to
indicate a vertical direction; a plummet; a plumb bob. See
<cref>Plumb line</cref>, below.</def>

<cs><col>Plumb bob</col>. <cd>See <er>Bob</er>, 4.</cd> --
<col>Plumb joint</col>, <cd>in sheet-metal work, a lap joint,
fastened by solder.</cd> -- <col>Plumb level</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Level</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plumb line</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>The cord by which a plumb bob is suspended; a plummet</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A line directed to the center of gravity of the
earth.</cd> -- <col>Plumb rule</col>, <cd>a narrow board with a
plumb line, used by builders and carpenters.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plumb</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Perpendicular; vertical;
conforming the direction of a line attached to a plumb; <as>as,
the wall is <ex>plumb</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Plumb</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a plumb direction;
perpendicularly.</def> \'bd<xex>Plumb</xex> down he falls.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Plumb</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plumbed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plumbing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To adjust by a plumb line; to cause to be perpendicular;
<as>as, to <ex>plumb</ex> a building or a wall</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To sound with a plumb or plummet, as the depth
of water; hence, to examine by test; to ascertain the depth,
quality, dimension, etc.; to sound; to fathom; to test.</def>

<q>He did not attempt to <qex>plumb</qex> his intellect.</q>
<qau>Ld. Lytton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To seal with lead; <as>as, to <ex>plumb</ex> a
drainpipe</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To supply, as a building, with a system of
plumbing.</def>

<hw>Plumb"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Leadwork</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Plum*ba"gin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plumbago</ets> leadwort, fr. <ets>plumbum</ets> lead; cf. F.
<ets>plombagin</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A
crystalline substance said to be found in the root of a certain
plant of the Leadwort (<spn>Plumbago</spn>) family.</def>

<-- p. 102  -->

<hw>Plum`ba*gin"e*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

(<spn>Plumbagine\'91</spn>) of gamopetalous herbs, of which
plumbago is the type. The order includes also the marsh rosemary,
the thrift, and a few other genera.</def>

<def>Resembling plumbago; consisting of, or containing, plumbago;

<hw>Plumb"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<hw>Plum"bism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Plumbum</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A diseased
condition, produced by the absorption of lead, common among
workers in this metal or in its compounds, as among painters,
typesetters, etc. It is characterized by various symptoms, as
lead colic, lead line, and wrist drop. See under <er>Colic</er>,
<er>Lead</er>, and <er>Wrist</er>.</def>

<hw>Plum"bous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From

to, or containing, lead; -- used specifically to designate those
compounds in which it has a lower valence as contrasted with
<xex>plumbic</xex> compounds.</def>

<hw>Plume</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>pluma</ets>. Cf. <er>Fly</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A feather; esp., a soft, downy feather, or a
long, conspicuous, or handsome feather.</def>

<q>Wings . . . of many a colored <qex>plume</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An ornamental tuft of
feathers.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A feather, or group of feathers, worn as an
ornament; a waving ornament of hair, or other material resembling
feathers.</def>

<q>His high <qex>plume</qex>, that nodded o'er his head.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A token of honor or prowess; that on which one
prides himself; a prize or reward.</def> \'bdAmbitious to win
from me some <xex>plume</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A large and flexible panicle
of inflorescence resembling a feather, such as is seen in certain
large ornamental grasses.</def>

<cs><col>Plume bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any bird
that yields ornamental plumes, especially the species of
Epimarchus from New Guinea, and some of the herons and egrets, as
the white heron of Florida (<spn>Ardea candidissima</spn>).</cd>
-- <col>Plume grass</col>. <fld>(Bot)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A
kind of grass (<spn>Erianthus saccharoides</spn>) with the
spikelets arranged in great silky plumes, growing in swamps in
the Southern United States</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The still finer
<spn>E. Ravenn\'91</spn> from the Mediterranean region. The name
is sometimes extended to the whole genus.</cd> -- <col>Plume
moth</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of numerous small,
slender moths, belonging to the family
<spn>Pterophorid\'91</spn>. Most of them have the wings deeply
divided into two or more plumelike lobes. Some species are
injurious to the grapevine.</cd> -- <col>Plume nutmeg</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an aromatic Australian tree
(<spn>Atherosperma moschata</spn>), whose numerous carpels are
tipped with long plumose persistent styles.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plume</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plumed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pluming</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>plumer</ets> to
pluck, to strip, L. <ets>plumare</ets> to cover with
feathers.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To pick and adjust the plumes
or feathers of; to dress or prink.</def>

<q><qex>Pluming</qex> her wings among the breezy bowers.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To strip of feathers; to pluck; to strip; to
pillage; also, to peel.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon. Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To adorn with feathers or plumes.</def>
\'bdFarewell the <xex>plumed</xex> troop.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To pride; to vaunt; to boast; -- used
reflexively; <as>as, he <ex>plumes</ex> himself on his
skill</as>.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<cs><col>Plumed adder</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an African
viper (<spn>Vipera, <or/ Clotho, cornuta</spn>), having a
plumelike structure over each eye. It is venomous, and is related
to the African puff adder. Called also <altname>horned
viper</altname> and <altname>hornsman</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Plumed partridge</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
California mountain quail (<spn>Oreortyx pictus</spn>). See
<cref>Mountain quail</cref>, under <er>Mountain</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plum"met</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>plommet</ets>, OF. <ets>plommet</ets>, fr. <ets>plom</ets>,
<ets>plum</ets>, lead, F. <ets>plomb</ets>. See
<er>Plumb</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A piece of lead attached
to a line, used in sounding the depth of water.</def>

<q>I'll sink him deeper than e'er <qex>plummet</qex> sounded.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A plumb bob or a plumb line. See under
<er>Plumb</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence, any weight.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A piece of lead formerly used by school children
to rule paper for writing.</def>

<cs><col>Plummet line</col>, <cd>a line with a plummet; a
sounding line.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plum"ming</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Plumb</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>The operation of
finding, by means of a mine dial, the place where to sink an air
shaft, or to bring an adit to the work, or to find which way the
lode inclines.</def>

<hw>Plum"my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Plum</er>.]</ety> <def>Of the nature of a plum; desirable;
profitable; advantageous.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> \'bdFor
the sake of getting something <xex>plummy</xex>.\'b8

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Plu*mose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Plu"mous</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>plumosus</ets>,
fr. <ets>pluma</ets> feather: cf. F. <ets>plumeux</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having feathers or plumes.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having hairs, or other p\'a0rts, arranged along
an axis like a feather; feathery; plumelike; <as>as, a
<ex>plumose</ex> leaf; <ex>plumose</ex> tentacles.</as></def>

<hw>Plu"mo*site</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Jamesonite</er>.</def>

<hw>Plu*mos"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being plumose.</def>

<hw>Plum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Plumper</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Plumpest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>plomp</ets> rude, clumsy; akin to D. <ets>plomp</ets>, G.,
Dan., & Sw. <ets>plump</ets>; probably of imitative origin. Cf.
<er>Plump</er>, <pos>adv.<pos>]</ety> <def>Well rounded or filled
out; full; fleshy; fat; <as>as, a <ex>plump</ex> baby;
<ex>plump</ex> cheeks.</as></def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The god of wine did his <qex>plump</qex> clusters bring.</q>
<qau>T. Carew.</qau>

<hw>Plum</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A knot; a cluster; a group; a
crowd; a flock; <as>as, a <ex>plump</ex> of trees, fowls, or
spears</as>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>To visit islands and the <qex>plumps</qex> of men.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>Plump</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D. <ets>plompen</ets>,
G. <ets>plumpen</ets>, Sw. <ets>plumpa</ets>, Dan.
<ets>plumpe</ets>. See <er>Plump</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To grow plump; to swell out; <as>as, her cheeks
have <ex>plumped</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To drop or fall suddenly or heavily, all at
once.</def>\'bdDulcissa <xex>plumps</xex> into a chair.\'b8

<au>Spectator.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To <er>give</er> a plumper. See
<er>Plumper</er>, <er>2</er>.</def>

<hw>Plump</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Plumped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plumping</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make
plump; to fill (out) or support; -- often with
<xex>up</xex>.</def><-- as, to <ex>plump up</ex> the pillows -->

<q>To <qex>plump</qex> up the hollowness of their history with
improbable miracles.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cast or let drop all at once, suddenly and
heavily; <as>as, to <ex>plump</ex> a stone into water</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To give (a vote), as a plumper. See
<er>Plumper</er>, <er>2</er>.</def>

<hw>Plump</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D. <ets>plomp</ets>,
interj., G. <ets>plump</ets>, <ets>plumps</ets>. Cf.
<er>Plump</er>, <pos>a.<pos> &<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <def>Directly;
suddenly; perpendicularly.</def> \'bdFall <xex>plump</xex>.\'b8

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<hw>Plump"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, plumps or swells out something else;
hence, something carried in the mouth to distend the
cheeks.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(English Elections)</fld> <def>A vote given to
one candidate only, when two or more are to be elected, thus
giving him the advantage over the others. A person who gives his
vote thus is said to <xex>plump</xex>, or to <xex>plump</xex> his
vote.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A voter who plumps his vote.</def>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A downright, unqualified lie.</def>
<mark>[Colloq. or Low]</mark>

<hw>Plump"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Fully; roundly; plainly;
without reserve.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Plump"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being plump.</def>

<hw>Plump"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Plump; fat;
sleek.</def> \'bd<xex>Plumpy</xex> Bacchus.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Plu"mule</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Plun"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plundered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Plundering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[G. <ets>pl\'81ndern</ets>
to plunder, <ets>plunder</ets> frippery, baggage.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To take the goods of by force, or without right;
to pillage; to spoil; to sack; to strip; to rob; <as>as, to
<ex>plunder</ex> travelers</as>.</def>

<q>Nebuchadnezzar <qex>plunders</qex> the temple of God.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take by pillage; to appropriate forcibly;
<as>as, the enemy <ex>plundered</ex> all the goods they
found</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To pillage; despoil; sack; rifle; strip; rob.</syn>

<hw>Plun"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of plundering or pillaging; robbery. See
<xex>Syn</xex>. of <er>Pillage</er>.</def>

<q>Inroads and <qex>plunders</qex> of the Saracens.</q>
<qau>Sir T. North.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is taken by open force from an enemy;
pillage; spoil; booty; also, that which is taken by theft or
fraud.</def> \'bdHe shared in the <xex>plunder</xex>.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Personal property and effects; baggage or
luggage.</def> <mark>[Slang, Southwestern U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Plun"der*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Mar.
Law)</fld> <def>The embezzlement of goods on shipboard.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<hw>Plun"der*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
plunders or pillages.</def>

<hw>Plunge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Plunged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Plunging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>ploungen</ets>, OF.
<ets>plongier</ets>, F. <ets>plonger</ets>, fr. (assumed) LL.
<ets>plumbicare</ets>, fr. L. <ets>plumbum</ets> lead. See
<er>Plumb</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To thrust into water, or
into any substance that is penetrable; to immerse; to cause to
penetrate or enter quickly and forcibly; to thrust; <as>as, to
<ex>plunge</ex> the body into water; to <ex>plunge</ex> a dagger
into the breast</as>.  Also used figuratively; <as>as, to
<ex>plunge</ex> a nation into war</as>.</def> \'bdTo
<xex>plunge</xex> the boy in pleasing sleep.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>Bound and <qex>plunged</qex> him into a cell.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<q>We shall be <qex>plunged</qex> into perpetual errors.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To baptize by immersion.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To entangle; to embarrass; to overcome.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Plunged</qex> and graveled with three lines of
Seneca.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>Plunge</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To thrust or
cast one's self into water or other fluid; to submerge one's
self; to dive, or to rush in; <as>as, he <ex>plunged</ex> into
the river</as>. Also used figuratively; <as>as, to
<ex>plunge</ex> into debt</as>.</def>

<q>Forced to <qex>plunge</qex> naked in the raging sea.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>To <qex>plunge</qex> into guilt of a murther.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pitch or throw one's self headlong or
violently forward, as a horse does.</def>

<q>Some wild colt, which . . . flings and <qex>plunges</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To bet heavily and with seeming recklessness on
a race, or other contest; in an extended sense, to risk large
sums in hazardous speculations.</def> <mark>[Cant]</mark>

<cs><col>Plunging fire</col> <fld>(Gun.)</fld>, <cd>firing
directed upon an enemy from an elevated position.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plunge</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
thrusting into or submerging; a dive, leap, rush, or pitch into,
or as into, water; <as>as, to take the water with a
<ex>plunge</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, a desperate hazard or act; a state of
being submerged or overwhelmed with difficulties.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>She was brought to that <qex>plunge</qex>, to conceal her
husband's murder or accuse her son.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<q>And with thou not reach out a friendly arm,
To raise me from amidst this <qex>plunge</qex> of sorrows?</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The act of pitching or throwing one's self
headlong or violently forward, like an unruly horse.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Heavy and reckless betting in horse racing;
hazardous speculation.</def> <mark>[Cant]</mark>

<cs><col>Plunge bath</col>, <cd>an immersion by plunging; also, a
large bath in which the bather can wholly immerse himself.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Plunge</col>, <or/ <col>plunging</col>,
<col>battery</col></mcol> <fld>(Elec.)</fld>, <cd>a voltaic
battery so arranged that the plates can be plunged into, or
withdrawn from, the exciting liquid at pleasure.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plun"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, plunges; a diver.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A long solid cylinder, used, instead of a piston
or bucket, as a forcer in pumps.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who bets heavily and recklessly on a race; a
reckless speculator.</def> <mark>[Cant]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Pottery)</fld> <def>A boiler in which clay is
beaten by a wheel to a creamy consistence.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Gun.)</fld> <def>The firing pin of a
breechloader.</def>

<cs><col>Plunger bucket</col>, <cd>a piston, without a valve, in
a pump.</cd> -- <col>Plunger pole</col>, <cd>the pump rod of a
pumping engine.</cd> -- <col>Plunger pump</col>, <cd>a pump, as
for water, having a plunger, instead of a piston, to act upon the
water. It may be single-acting or double-acting</cd></cs>

<hw>Plun"ket</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of blue
color; also, anciently, a kind of cloth, generally blue.</def>

<hw>Plu"per`fect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plus</ets> more + <ets>perfectus</ets> perfect; cf. F.
<ets>plus-que-parfait</ets>, L.
<ets>plusquamperfectum</ets>.]</ety> <def>More than perfect; past
perfect; -- said of the tense which denotes that an action or
event was completed at or before the time of another past action
or event.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>The pluperfect tense;
also, a verb in the pluperfect tense.</def></def2>

<hw>Plu"ral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pluralis</ets>, from <ets>plus</ets>, <ets>pluris</ets>,
more; cf. F. <ets>pluriel</ets>, OF. <ets>plurel</ets>. See
<er>Plus</er>.]</ety> <def>Relating to, or containing, more than
one; designating two or more; <as>as, a <ex>plural</ex>
word</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Plural</qex> faith, which is too much by one.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Plural number</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>the number
which designates more than one. See <er>Number</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 8.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plu"ral</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The
plural number; that form of a word which expresses or denotes
more than one; a word in the plural form.</def>

<hw>Plu"ral*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being plural, or in the plural
number.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>The state of a pluralist; the
holding of more than one ecclesiastical living at a time.</def>
<mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Plu"ral*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>A
clerk or clergyman who holds more than one ecclesiastical
benefice.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<q>Of the parochial clergy, a large proportion were
<qex>pluralists</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Plu*ral"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>pluralities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>pluralitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pluralit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state of being plural, or consisting of more
than one; a number consisting of two or more of the same kind;
<as>as, a <ex>plurality</ex> of worlds; the <ex>plurality</ex> of
a verb.</as></def>

<-- p. 103  -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The greater number; a majority; also, the
greatest of several numbers; in elections, the excess of the
votes given for one candidate over those given for another, or
for any other, candidate. When there are more than two
candidates, the one who receives the <xex>plurality</xex> of
votes may have less than a majority. See <er>Majority</er>.</def>

<q>Take the <qex>plurality</qex> of the world, and they are
neither wise nor good.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>See <cref>Plurality of
benefices</cref>, below.</def>

<cs><col>Plurality of benefices</col> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld>, <cd>the
possession by one clergyman of more than one benefice or living.
Each benefice thus held is called a <xex>plurality<xex>.
<mark>[Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Plu`ral*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of pluralizing.</def>

<au>H. Spencer.</au>

<hw>Plu"ral*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pluralized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pluralizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make plural by
using the plural termination; to attribute plurality to; to
express in the plural form.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To multiply; to make manifold.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Plu"ral*ize</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To take a
plural; to assume a plural form; <as>as, a noun
<ex>pluralizes</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Earle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>To hold more than one
benefice at the same time.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Plu"ral*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>A pluralist.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Plu"ral*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a plural manner or

<cd>many-celled sporangia, each cell containing a single spore,

<hw>Plu"ri*sy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>plus</ets>, <ets>pluris</ets>, more.]</ety>
<def>Superabundance; excess; plethora.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Plus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L., more; akin to
Gr. <?/, <?/, and E. <ets>full</ets>. See <er>Full</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>, and cf. <er>Pi\'97</er>, <er>Pleonasm</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>More, required to be added;
positive, as distinguished from negative; -- opposed to
<ant>minus</ant>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, in a literary sense, additional; real;
actual.</def>

<q>Success goes invariably with a certain <qex>plus</qex> or
positive power.</q>
<qau>Emerson.</qau>

<cs><col>Plus sign</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>the sign (+)
which denotes addition, or a positive quantity.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plush</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pluche</ets>, <ets>peluche</ets> (cf. It.
<ets>peluzzo</ets>), fr. L. <ets>pilus</ets> hair. See
<er>pile</er> hair, and cf. <er>Peruke</er>.]</ety> <def>A
textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer and softer
than the nap of velvet.</def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<hw>Plush"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like plush;
soft and shaggy.</def>

<au>H. Kingsley.</au>

<cs><col>Pluto monkey</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a

having side whiskers. The general color is black, more or less
grizzled; the frontal band is white.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plu*toc"ra*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/;

<hw>Plu*to"ni*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A Plutonist.</def>

<hw>Plu*ton"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>plutonique</ets>. See <er>Pluto</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to Pluto; Plutonian; hence, pertaining to
the interior of the earth; subterranean.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of, pertaining to, or designating, the system of
the Plutonists; igneous; <as>as, the <ex>Plutonic</ex>
theory</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Plutonic action</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>, <cd>the
influence of volcanic heat and other subterranean forces under
pressure.</cd> -- <col>Plutonic rocks</col> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>,
<cd>granite, porphyry, and some other igneous rocks, supposed to
have consolidated from a melted state at a great depth from the
surface. Cf. <cref>Intrusive rocks</cref>, under
<er>Intrusive</er>.</cd> -- <col>Plutonic theory</col>.
<fld>(Geol.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Plutonism</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Plu"to*nism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>plutonisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>The theory, early advanced in
geology, that the successive rocks of the earth\'b6s crust were
formed by igneous fusion; -- opposed to the <xex>Neptunian
theory</xex>.</def>

<hw>Plu"to*nist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>plutoniste</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who adopts the geological
theory of igneous fusion; a Plutonian. See
<er>Plutonism</er>.</def>

<hw>Plu"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <fld>(Class. Myth.)</fld> <def>The son of Jason and
Ceres, and the god of wealth. He was represented as bearing a
cornucopia, and as blind, because his gifts were bestowed without
discrimination of merit.</def>

<hw>Plu"vi*al</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L. <ets>pluvialis</ets>,

<hw>Plu"vi*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Ply</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Plied</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Plying</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>plien</ets>, F. <ets>plier</ets> to fold, to bend, fr. L.
<ets>plicare</ets>; akin to Gr. <?/, G. <ets>flechten</ets>. Cf.
<er>Apply</er>, <er>Complex</er>, <er>Display</er>,
<er>Duplicity</er>, <er>Employ</er>, <er>Exploit</er>,
<er>Implicate</er>, <er>Plait</er>, <er>Pliant</er>,
<er>Flax</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bend.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>As men may warm wax with handes <qex>plie</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To lay on closely, or in folds; to work upon
steadily, or with repeated acts; to press upon; to urge
importunately; <as>as, to <ex>ply</ex> one with questions, with
solicitations, or with drink</as>.</def>

<q>And <qex>plies</qex> him with redoubled strokes</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>He <qex>plies</qex> the duke at morning and at night.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To employ diligently; to use steadily.</def>

<q>Go <qex>ply</qex> thy needle; meddle not.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To practice or perform with diligence; to work
at.</def>

<q>Their bloody task, unwearied, still they <qex>ply</qex>.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<hw>Ply</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bend; to
yield.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>It would rather burst atwo than <qex>plye</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>The willow <qex>plied</qex>, and gave way to the gust.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To act, go, or work diligently and steadily;
especially, to do something by repeated actions; to go back and
forth; <as>as, a steamer <ex>plies</ex> between certain
ports</as>.</def>

<q>Ere half these authors be read (which will soon be with
<qex>plying</qex> hard and daily).</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He was forced to <qex>ply</qex> in the streets as a
porter.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>The heavy hammers and mallets <qex>plied</qex>.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To work to windward; to
beat.</def>

<hw>Ply</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pli</ets>, fr.
<ets>plier</ets>. See <er>Ply</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A fold; a plait; a turn or twist, as of a
cord.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Bent; turn; direction; bias.</def>

<q>The late learners can not so well take the <qex>ply</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Boswell, and others of Goldsmith's contemporaries, . . . did
not understand the secret <qex>plies</qex> of his character.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<q>The czar's mind had taken a strange <qex>ply</qex>, which it
retained to the last.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Ply</xex> is used in composition to designate
folds, or the number of webs interwoven; as, a
three-<xex>ply</xex> carpet.</note>

<hw>Ply"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or that
which, plies</def>; specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <pluf>pl.</pluf>
<def>A kind of balance used in raising and letting down a
drawbridge. It consists of timbers joined in the form of a St.
Andrew's cross.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>See
<er>Pliers</er>.</def>

<hw>Plyght</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. & n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Plight</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Plym"outh Breth"ren</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>The members of a
religious sect which first appeared at Plymouth, England, about
1830. They protest against sectarianism, and reject all official
ministry or clergy. Also called <altname>Brethren</altname>,
<altname>Christian Brethren</altname>,
<altname>Plymouthists</altname>, etc. The
<stype>Darbyites</stype> are a division of the Brethren.</def>

<hw>Pne*om"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
to breathe + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>
<def>A spirometer.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pneu*mat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pneu*mat"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pneumaticus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, <?/, wind, air, <?/ to
blow, breathe; cf. OHG. <ets>fnehan</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pneumatique</ets>. Cf. <er>Pneumonia</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Consisting of, or resembling, air; having the
properties of an elastic fluid; gaseous; opposed to
<xex>dense</xex> or <xex>solid</xex>.</def>

<q>The <qex>pneumatical</qex> substance being, in some bodies,
the native spirit of the body.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to air, or to elastic fluids or
their properties; pertaining to pneumatics; <as>as,
<ex>pneumatic</ex> experiments</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Pneumatical</xex> discoveries.\'b8

<au>Stewart.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Moved or worked by pressure or flow of air;
<as>as, a <ex>pneumatic</ex> instrument; a <ex>pneumatic</ex>
engine.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Fitted to contain air; Having
cavities filled with air; <as>as, <ex>pneumatic</ex> cells;
<ex>pneumatic</ex> bones.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Pneumatic action</col>, <or/ <col>Pneumatic
lever</col></mcol> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>a contrivance for
overcoming the resistance of the keys and other movable parts in
an organ, by causing compressed air from the wind chest to move
them.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic dispatch</col>, <cd>a system of
tubes, leading to various points, through which letters,
packages, etc., are sent, by the flow and pressure of air.</cd>
-- <col>Pneumatic elevator</col>, <cd>a hoisting machine worked
by compressed air.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic pile</col>, <cd>a
tubular pile or cylinder of large diameter sunk by atmospheric
pressure.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic pump</col>, <cd>an
air-exhausting or forcing pump.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic
railway</col>. <cd>See <cref>Atmospheric railway</cref>, under
<er>Atmospheric</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic syringe</col>, <cd>a
stout tube closed at one end, and provided with a piston, for
showing that the heat produced by compressing a gas will ignite
substances.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic trough</col>, <cd>a trough,
generally made of wood or sheet metal, having a perforated shelf,
and used, when filled with water or mercury, for collecting gases
in chemical operations.</cd> -- <col>Pneumatic tube</col>.
<cd>See <cref>Pneumatic dispatch</cref>, above.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pneu`ma*tic"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The state of being pneumatic, or of
having a cavity or cavities filled with air; <as>as, the
<ex>pneumaticity</ex> of the bones of birds</as>.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mat"ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pneumatique</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That branch of science which treats of the
mechanical properties of air and other elastic fluids, as of
their weight, pressure, elasticity, etc. See
<er>Mechanics</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Philos. & Theol.)</fld> <def>The scientific
study or knowledge of spiritual beings and their relations to
God, angels, and men.</def>

<hw>Pleu"ma*to-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A combining form from Gr.
<?/, <?/, <xex>wind</xex>, <xex>air</xex>, <xex>breath</xex>,
<xex>respiration</xex>; <as>as, <ex>pneumato</ex>graph,
<ex>pneumato</ex>logy</as>.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mat"o*cele</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pneumato-</ets> + Gr. <?/ a tumor; cf. F.
<ets>pneumatoc\'8ale</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
distention of the scrotum by air; also, hernia of the
lungs.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mat"o*cyst</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pneumato-</ets> + <ets>cyst</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A cyst or sac of a siphonophore,
containing air, and serving as a float, as in Physalia.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mat"o*garm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pneumato-</ets> + <ets>-gram</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A tracing of the respiratory
movements, obtained by a pneumatograph or stethograph.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mat"o*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pneumato-</ets> + <ets>-graph</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>An instrument for recording the
movements of the thorax or chest wall during respiration; -- also
called <altname>stethograph</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pneu`ma*to*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Pneu`mo*coc"cus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

<def>A form of micrococcus found in the sputum (and elsewhere) of

<hw>Pneu`mo*gas"tric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pneumo-</ets> + <ets>gastric</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the lungs and the
stomach.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>The pneumogastric
nerve.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Pneumogastric nerve</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>one of
the tenth pair of cranial nerves which are distributed to the
pharynx, esophagus, larynx, lungs, heart, stomach, liver, and
spleen, and, in fishes and many amphibia, to the branchial
apparatus and also to the sides of the body.</cd></cs>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>Pneu*mol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pneu*mom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pneumo-</ets> + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A spirometer.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mom"e*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Measurement of the capacity of the lungs for air.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>Pneu*mo"ni*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/, fr. <?/, pl. <?/ the lungs, also, <?/, which is perh.
the original form. Cf. <er>Pneumatio</er>,
<er>Pulmonary</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Inflammation of
the lungs.</def>


<note><hand/ <mcol><col>Catarrhal pneumonia</col>, <or/
<col>Broncho-pneumonia</col></mcol>, is inflammation of the lung
tissue, associated with catarrh and with marked evidences of
inflammation of bronchial membranes, often chronic; -- also
called <altname>lobular pneumonia</altname>, from its affecting
single lobules at a time. -- <col>Croupous pneumonia</col>, or
ordinary pneumonia, is an acute affection characterized by sudden
onset with a chill, high fever, rapid course, and sudden decline;
-- also called <altname>lobar pneumonia</altname>, from its
affecting a whole lobe of the lung at once. See under
<er>Croupous</er>. -- <col>Fibroid pneumonia</col> is an
inflammation of the interstitial connective tissue lying between
the lobules of the lungs, and is very slow in its course,
producing shrinking and atrophy of the lungs.</note>

<hw>Pneu*mon"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/:
cf. F. <ets>pneumonique</ets>.]</ety> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Of or
pertaining to the lungs; pulmonic.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of or
pertaining to pneumonia; <as>as, <ex>pneumonic</ex>
symptoms</as>.</def>

<hw>Pneu*mon"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
medicine for affections of the lungs.</def>

<hw>Pneu`mo*nit"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to pneumonitis.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pneu`mo*ni"tis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Pneumo-</er>, and <er>-itis</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Inflammation of the lungs;
pneumonia.</def>

<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>A spirometer; a pneumometer.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pneu`mo*noph"o*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ a lung + <?/ to bear.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The division of Siphonophora which
includes the Physalia and allied genera; -- called also
<spn>Pneumatophor\'91</spn>.</def>

<ets>pneumonie</ets>.]</ety> <def>See <er>Pneumonia</er>.</def>

<hw>Poach</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Poached</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Poaching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>pocher</ets> to
place in a pocket, to poach eggs (the yolk of the egg being as it
were <ets>pouched</ets> in the white), from <ets>poche</ets>
pocket, pouch. See <er>Pouch</er>, <pos>v.<pos>
&<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cook, as eggs, by
breaking them into boiling water; also, to cook with butter after
breaking in a vessel.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To rob of game; to pocket and convey away by
stealth, as game; hence, to plunder.</def>

<au>Garth.</au>

<hw>Poach</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To steal or pocket game, or
to carry it away privately, as in a bag; to kill or destroy game
contrary to law, especially by night; to hunt or fish unlawfully;
<as>as, to <ex>poach</ex> for rabbits or for salmon</as>.</def>

<hw>Poach</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF. <ets>pocher</ets>
to thrust or dig out with the fingers, to bruise (the eyes), F.
<ets>pouce</ets> thumb, L. <ets>pollex</ets>, and also E.
<ets>poach</ets> to cook eggs, to plunder, and <ets>poke</ets> to
thrust against.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To stab; to pierce; to
spear, \as fish.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Carew.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To force, drive, or plunge into anything.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>His horse <qex>poching</qex> one of his legs into some hollow
ground.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To make soft or muddy by trampling</def>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To begin and not complete.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Poach</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become soft or
muddy.</def>

<q>Chalky and clay lands . . . chap in summer, and
<qex>poach</qex> in winter.</q>
<qau>Mortimer.</qau>

<hw>Poach"ard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Poach</er> to stab.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pocard</asp>, <asp>pochard</asp>.]</altsp>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A common European duck
(<spn>Aythya ferina</spn>); -- called also
<altname>goldhead</altname>, <altname>poker</altname>, and
<altname>fresh-water, <or/ red-headed</altname>,
<altname>widgeon</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The American
redhead, which is closely allied to the European poachard.</def>

<cs><col>Red-crested poachard</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an
Old World duck (<spn>Branta rufina</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Scaup
poachard</col>, <cd>the scaup duck.</cd> -- <col>Tufted
poachard</col>, <cd>a scaup duck (<spn>Aythya, <or/ Fuligula
cristata</spn>), native of Europe and Asia.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pock</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pokke</ets>, AS. <ets>pocc</ets>, <ets>poc</ets>; akin to D.
<ets>pok</ets>, G. <ets>pocke</ets>, and perh. to E.
<ets>poke</ets> a pocket. Cf. <er>Pox</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A pustule raised on the surface of the
body in variolous and vaccine diseases.</def>

<q>Of <qex>pokkes</qex> and of scab every sore.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Pock"arred</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Pockmarked</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pock"-bro`ken</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Broken
out, or marked, with smallpox; pock-fretten.</def>

<hw>Pock"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>poket</ets>, Prov. F. & OF. <ets>poquette</ets>, F.
<ets>pochette</ets>, dim. fr. <ets>poque</ets>,
<ets>pouque</ets>, F. <ets>poche</ets>; probably of Teutonic
origin. See <er>Poke</er> a pocket, and cf. <er>Poach</er> to
cook eggs, to plunder, and <er>Pouch</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A bag or pouch; especially; a small bag inserted in a
garment for carrying small articles, particularly money; hence,
figuratively, money; wealth.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of several bags attached to a billiard
table, into which the balls are driven.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A large bag or sack used in packing various
articles, as ginger, hops, cowries, etc.</def>

<note><hand/ In the wool or hop trade, the <xex>pocket</xex>
contains half sack, or about 168 Ibs.; but it is a variable
quantity, the articles being sold by actual weight.</note>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A hole or space covered by a
movable piece of board, as in a floor, boxing, partitions, or the
like.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Mining.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A cavity in a
rock containing a nugget of gold, or other mineral; a small body
of ore contained in such a cavity.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A hole
containing water.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Nat.)</fld> <def>A strip of canvas, sewn upon a
sail so that a batten or a light spar can placed in the
interspace.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Pouch</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pocket</xex> is often used adjectively, or in
the formation of compound words usually of obvious signification;
as, <xex>pocket</xex> comb, <xex>pocket</xex> compass,
<xex>pocket</xex> edition, <xex>pocket</xex> handkerchief,
<xex>pocket</xex> money, <xex>pocket</xex> picking, or
<xex>pocket</xex>-picking, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Out of pocket</col>. <cd>See under <er>Out</er>,
<pos>prep.</pos></cd> -- <col>Pocket borough</col>, <cd>a borough
\'bdowned\'b8 by some person.</cd> See under <er>Borough</er>.
<mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Pocket gopher</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of American
rodents of the genera <spn>Geomys</spn>, and <spn>Thomomys</spn>,
family <spn>Geomyd\'91</spn>. They have large external cheek
pouches, and are fossorial in their habits. they inhabit North
America, from the Mississippi Valley west to the Pacific. Called
also <altname>pouched gopher</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Pocket
mouse</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any species of American
mice of the family <spn>Saccomyid\'91</spn>. They have external
cheek pouches. Some of them are adapted for leaping (genus
<spn>Dipadomys</spn>), and are called <stype>kangaroo
mice</stype>. They are native of the Southwestern United States,
Mexico, etc.</cd> -- <col>Pocket piece</col>, <cd>a piece of
money kept in the pocket and not spent.</cd> -- <col>Pocket
pistol</col>, <cd>a pistol to be carried in the pocket.</cd> --
<col>Pocket sheriff</col> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld>, <cd>a sheriff
appointed by the sole authority of the crown, without a
nomination by the judges in the exchequer.
<au>Burrill</au>.</cd></cs>
<-- <col>deep pocket, <or/ deep pockets</col>, <cd>wealth or
substantial financial assets.</cd> <note>Used esp. in legal
actions, where plaintiffs desire to find a defendant with "deep
pockets", so as to be able to actually obtain the sum of damages
which may be judged due to him.  This contrasts with a
"judgment-proof" defendant, one who has neither assets nor
insurance, and against whom a judgment for monetary damages would
be worthless.</note>  -->

<hw>Pock"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pocketed</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pocketing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To put, or conceal, in the pocket; <as>as, to
<ex>pocket</ex> the change</as>.</def>

<q>He would <qex>pocket</qex> the expense of the license.</q>
<qau>Sterne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take clandestinely or fraudulently.</def>

<q>He <qex>pocketed</qex> pay in the names of men who had long
been dead.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<cs><col>To pocket a ball</col> <fld>(Billiards)</fld>, <cd>to
drive a ball into a pocket of the table.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To
pocket an insult</col>, <col>affront</col>, etc.</mcol>, <cd>to
receive an affront without open resentment, or without seeking
redress. \'bdI must <xex>pocket<xex> up these
<xex>wrongs<xex>.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>\'d8Po"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Podia</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., fr. Gr. <?/, dim.
of <?/, <?/, foot. See <er>Pew</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A low wall, serving as a foundation, a
substructure, or a terrace wall.</def> It is especially employed
by arch\'91ologists in two senses: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The dwarf
wall surrounding the arena of an amphitheater, from the top of
which the seats began</def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The masonry under
the stylobate of a temple, sometimes a mere foundation, sometimes
containing chambers</def>. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Column</er>.

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A young coalfish.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pod`oph*thal"mi*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Podophthalmic</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The stalk-eyed Crustacea, -- an order
of Crustacea having the eyes supported on movable stalks. It
includes the crabs, lobsters, and prawns. Called also
<altname>Podophthalmata</altname>, and
<altname>Decapoda</altname>.</def>

<hw>Po"em</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>po\'89ma</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to make, to compose, to
write, especially in verse: cf. F. <ets>po\'89me</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A metrical composition; a composition in verse
written in certain measures, whether in blank verse or in rhyme,
and characterized by imagination and poetic diction; --
contradistinguished from <xex>prose</xex>; <as>as, the
<ex>poems</ex> of Homer or of Milton</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A composition, not in verse, of which the
language is highly imaginative or impassioned; <as>as, a prose
<ex>poem</ex>; the <ex>poems</ex> of Ossian.</as></def>

<hw>Po"e*sy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>Po"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A <qex>poet</qex> is a maker, as the word signifies.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Po"et*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>poeterie</ets>. See <er>Poet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The art of apprehending and interpreting ideas by the
faculty of imagination; the art of idealizing in thought and in
expression.</def>

<q>For <qex>poetry</qex> is the blossom and the fragrance of all
human knowledge, human thoughts, human passions, emotions,
language.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Imaginative language or composition, whether
expressed rhythmically or in prose. Specifically: Metrical
composition; verse; rhyme; poems collectively; <as>as, heroic
<ex>poetry</ex>; dramatic <ex>poetry</ex>; lyric or Pindaric
<ex>poetry</ex>.</as></def> \'bdThe planetlike music of
<xex>poetry</xex>.\'b8

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<q>She taketh most delight
In music, instruments, and <qex>poetry</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Poign"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., p. pr.

<hw>\'d8Poin`ci*a"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
Named after M. de <ets>Poinci</ets>, a governor of the French
West Indies.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A prickly tropical
shrub (<spn>C\'91salpinia, <plain>formerly</plain> Poinciana,
pulcherrima</spn>), with bipinnate leaves, and racemes of showy
orange-red flowers with long crimson filaments.</def>

<note><hand/ The genus <spn>Poinciana</spn> is kept up for three
trees of Eastern Africa, the Mascarene Islands, and India.</note>

<hw>Poind</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See

cattle.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Scot.]</mark>

<au>Flavel.</au>

<hw>\'d8Poin*set"ti*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.

<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A Mexican shrub (<spn>Euphorbia
