<hw>\'d8Pol`y*ch\'91"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/ many + <?/ hair.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the two principal groups of
Ch\'91topoda. It includes those that have prominent parapodia and
fascicles of set\'91. See <xex>Illust</xex>. under
<er>Parapodia</er>.</def>

<hw>Pol`y*con"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<cs><col>Polyconic projection</col> <fld>(Map Making)</fld>,
<cd>a projection of the earth's surface, or any portion thereof,
by which each narrow zone is projected upon a conical surface
that touches the sphere along this zone, the conical surface
being then unrolled. This projection differs from <xex>conic
projection<xex> in that latter assumes but one cone for the whole
map. Polyconic projection is that in use in the United States
coast and geodetic survey.</cd></cs>

<hw>Po*lyg"a*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to polygamy; characterized by,

<contr>monogamous</contr>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Pairing with more than one
female.</def>

<q>Most deer, cattle, and sheep are <qex>polygamous</qex>.</q>
<qau>Darwin.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Belonging to the Polygamia;
bearing both hermaphrodite and unisexual flowers on the same

<hw>Po*lyg"a*my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/;
cf. F. <ets>polygamie</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The having
of a plurality of wives or husbands at the same time; usually,
the marriage of a man to more than one woman, or the practice of
having several wives, at the same time; -- opposed to
<xex>monogamy</xex>; <as>as, the nations of the East practiced
<ex>polygamy</ex></as>. See the Note under <er>Bigamy</er>, and
cf. <er>Polyandry</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The state or habit of
having more than one mate.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The condition or state of a
plant which bears both perfect and unisexual flowers.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*gon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
polygonal; <?/ many + <?/ angle: cf. F.
<ets>polygone</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A plane
figure having many angles, and consequently many sides; esp., one
whose perimeter consists of more than four sides; any figure
having many angles.</def>

<cs><col>Polygon of forces</col> <fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>a
polygonal figure, the sides of which, taken successively,
represent, in length and direction, several forces acting
simultaneously upon one point, so that the side necessary to
complete the figure represents the resultant of those forces. Cf.
<xex>Parallelogram of forces<xex>, under
<er>Parallelogram</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pol`y*go*na"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Polygonum</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Of or
pertaining to a natural order of apetalous plants
(<spn>Polygonace\'91</spn>), of which the knotweeds (species of
<spn>Polygonum</spn>) are the type, and which includes also the
docks (<spn>Rumex</spn>), the buckwheat, rhubarb, sea grape
(<spn>Coccoloba</spn>), and several other genera.</def>

<hw>Po*lyg"o*nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having
many angles.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pol`y*gor"di*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Poly-</er>, and <er>Gordius</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of marine annelids, believed
to be an ancient or ancestral type. It is remarkable for its
simplicity of structure and want of parapodia. It is the type of
the order Archiannelida, or Gymnotoma. See <er>Loeven's
larva</er>.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*gram</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
marked with many stripes; <?/ many + <?/ a line.]</ety> <def>A
figure consisting of many lines.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Barlow.</au>

<hw>Pol"y*graph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
writing much; <?/ much, many + <?/ to write: cf. F.
<ets>polygraphe</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An instrument for
multiplying copies of a writing; a manifold writer; a copying
machine.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In bibliography, a collection of different
works, either by one or several authors.</def>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pol`y*graph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pol`y*graph"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>polygraphique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to,
or employed in, polygraphy; <as>as, a <ex>polygraphic</ex>
instrument</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Done with a polygraph; <as>as, a
<ex>polygraphic</ex> copy</as>.</def>

<hw>Po*lyg"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/;
<?/ much + <?/ to write:  cf. F. <ets>polygraphie</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Much writing; writing of many books.</def>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The art of writing in various ciphers, and of

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The art or practice of using a polygraph.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*mer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Polymeric</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Any one of two
or more substances related to each other by polymerism;
specifically, a substance produced from another substance by
chemical polymerization.</def> <mark>[Formerly also written
polymere.]</mark>

<hw>Pol`y*mer"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Poly-</ets> + Gr. <?/ part.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Having the same percentage composition (that is, having the
same elements united in the same proportion by weight), but
different molecular weights; -- often used with <xex>with</xex>;
thus, cyanic acid (<chform>CNOH</chform>), fulminic acid
(<chform>C2N2O2H2</chform>), and cyanuric acid
(<chform>C3N3O3H3</chform>), are <xex>polymeric</xex> with each
other.</def>

<note><hand/ The figures expressing the number of atoms of each
element in a number of polymeric substances are respectively
multiples and factors of each other, or have some simple common
divisor. The relation may be merely a numerical one, as in the
example given above, or a chemical one, as in the case of
aldehyde, paraldehyde, and metaldehyde.</note>

<-- 2. consisting of multiple units linked together by covalent
bonds to form a larger molecule -->

<hw>Po*lym"er*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The state, quality, or
relation of two or more polymeric substances.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The act or process of forming polymers.</def>

<hw>Pol`y*mer`i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The act or process of changing to a
polymeric form; the condition resulting from such change.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*mer*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To cause polymerization of; to produce
polymers from; to increase the molecular weight of, without
changing the atomic proportions; thus, certain acids
<xex>polymerize</xex> aldehyde.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*mer*ize</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>To change into another substance having the same atomic
proportions, but a higher molecular weight; to undergo
polymerization; thus, aldehyde <xex>polymerizes</xex> in forming
paraldehyde.</def>

<hw>Pol`y*phe"mus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>Polyphemus</ets> the one-eyed Cyclops who was blinded by
Ulysses.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A very large American
moth (<spn>Telea polyphemus</spn>) belonging to the Silkworm
family (<spn>Bombycid\'91</spn>). Its larva, which is very large,
bright green, with silvery tubercles, and with oblique white
stripes on the sides, feeds on the oak, chestnut, willow, cherry,
apple, and other trees. It produces a large amount of strong
silk. Called also <altname>American silkworm</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*phone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A character
or vocal sign representing more than one sound, as
<xex>read</xex>, which is pronounced <xex>r\'c7d</xex> or
<xex>r\'cbd</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pol`y*phon"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/;
<?/ many + <?/ sound: cf. F. <ets>polyphone</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having a multiplicity of sounds.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Characterized by polyphony; <as>as, Assyrian
<ex>polyphonic</ex> characters</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Consisting of several tone
series, or melodic parts, progressing simultaneously according to
the laws of counterpoint; contrapuntal; <as>as, a
<ex>polyphonic</ex> composition</as>; -- opposed to
<contr>homophonic</contr>, or <contr>monodic</contr>.</def>

<hw>Po*lyph"o*nism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Polyphony.</def>

<hw>Po*lyph"o*nist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A proficient in the art of multiplying sounds; a
ventriloquist.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A master of polyphony; a
contrapuntist.</def>

<hw>Po*lyph"o*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Polyphonic</er>.</def>

<hw>Po*lyph"o*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Multiplicity of sounds, as in the
reverberations of an echo.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Plurality of sounds and articulations expressed
by the same vocal sign.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Composition in mutually
related, equally important parts which share the melody among
them; contrapuntal composition; -- opposed to
<xex>homophony</xex>, in which the melody is given to one part
only, the others filling out the harmony. See
<er>Counterpoint</er>.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*phore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Poly-</ets> + Gr. <?/ to bear.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A receptacle which bears many
ovaries.</def>

<hw>Pol`y*phy*let"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Poly-</ets> + Gr. <?/ clan.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, or characterized by, descent from more than
one root form, or from many different root forms; polygenetic; --
opposed to <ant>monophyletic</ant>.</def>

<hw>Po*lyph"yl*lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/; <?/ many + <?/ leaf.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Many-leaved; <as>as, a <ex>polyphyllous</ex> calyx or
perianth</as>.</def>

<hw>Pol"y*po`di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.

<hw>\'d8Po*lyp"o*rus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Polypori</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/
many + <?/ a pore.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of fungi
having the under surface full of minute pores; also, any fungus
of this genus.</def>

<note><hand/ <spn>Polyporus fomentarius</spn> was formerly dried
and cut in slices for tinder, called <xex>amadou</xex>. <spn>P.
betulinus</spn> is common in America, and forms very large thick
white semicircular excrescences on birch trees. Several species
of <spn>Polyporous</spn> are considered edible.</note>

<hw>Pome"gran`ate</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pomgarnet</ets>, OF. <ets>pome de grenate</ets>, F.
<ets>grenade</ets>, L. <ets>pomum</ets> a fruit +

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The fruit of the tree
<spn>Punica Granatum</spn>; also, the tree itself (see
<er>Balaustine</er>), which is native in the Orient, but is
successfully cultivated in many warm countries, and as a house
plant in colder climates. The fruit is as large as an orange, and
has a hard rind containing many rather large seeds, each one
separately covered with crimson, acid pulp.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A carved or embroidered ornament resembling a
pomegranate.</def>

<hw>Pom"pa*dour</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A crimson

<hw>Pom"pa*no</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp.
<ets>p\'a0mpano</ets>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pampano</asp>.]</altsp> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Any one of several species of marine fishes of the genus
<spn>Trachynotus</spn>, of which four species are found on the
Atlantic coast of the United States; -- called also
<altname>palometa</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ They have a brilliant silvery or golden luster, and
are highly esteemed as food fishes. The round pompano (<spn>T.
thomboides</spn>) and the Carolina pompano (<spn>T.
Carolinus</spn>) are the most common. Other species occur on the
Pacific coast.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A California harvest fish (<spn>Stromateus
simillimus</spn>), highly valued as a food fish.</def>

<cs><col>Pompano shell</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small
bivalve shell of the genus <spn>Donax</spn>; -- so called because
eaten by the pompano. <mark>[Florida]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Pond</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably
originally, an inclosed body of water, and the same word as
<ets>pound</ets>. See <er>Pound</er> an inclosure.]</ety> <def>A
body of water, naturally or artificially confined, and usually of
less extent than a lake.</def> \'bdThrough <xex>pond</xex> or
pool.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<cs><col>Pond hen</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the American
coot. See <er>Coot</er> <sd>(a)</sd>.</cd> -- <col>Pond
lily</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the water lily. See under
<er>Water</er>, and <xex>Illust<xex>. under
<er>Nymph\'91a</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pond snail</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any gastropod living in fresh-water
ponds or lakes. The most common kinds are air-breathing snails
(<spn>Pulmonifera</spn>) belonging to Limn\'91a, Physa,
Planorbis, and allied genera. The operculated species are
pectinibranchs, belonging to <spn>Melantho</spn>,
<spn>Valvata</spn>, and various other genera.</cd><-- Some
general are italicised, otheres not.  Why?? Thus in orig. --> --
<col>Pond spice</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an American shrub
(<spn>Tetranthera geniculata</spn>) of the Laurel family, with
small oval leaves, and axillary clusters of little yellow
flowers. The whole plant is spicy. It grows in ponds and swamps
from Virginia to Florida.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Pond tortoise</col>,
<col>Pond turtle</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
freshwater tortoise of the family <spn>Emydid\'91</spn>. Numerous
species are found in North America.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1113 -->

<hw>Pond</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To make into a
pond; to collect, as water, in a pond by damming.</def>

<hw>Pond</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See <er>Ponder</er>.]</ety>
<def>To ponder.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Pleaseth you, <qex>pond</qex> your suppliant's plaint.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Pon"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pondered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pondering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>ponderare</ets>,
fr. <ets>pondus</ets>, <ets>ponderis</ets>, a weight, fr.
<ets>pendere</ets> to weigh: cf. F. <ets>pond\'82rer</ets>. See
<er>Pendant</er>, and cf.  <er>Pound</er> a weight.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To weigh.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To weigh in the mind; to view with deliberation;
to examine carefully; to consider attentively.</def>

<q><qex>Ponder</qex> the path of thy feet.</q>
<qau>Prov. iv. 26.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To <er>Ponder</er>, <er>Consider</er>,
<er>Muse</er>.</syn> <usage> To <xex>consider</xex> means to view
or contemplate with fixed thought. To <xex>ponder</xex> is to
dwell upon with long and anxious attention, with a view to some
practical result or decision. To <xex>muse</xex> is simply to
think upon continuously with no definite object, or for the
pleasure it gives. We <xex>consider</xex> any subject which is
fairly brought before us; we <xex>ponder</xex> a concern
involving great interests; we <xex>muse</xex> on the events of
childhood.</usage>

<hw>Pon"der</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To think; to deliberate;
to muse; -- usually followed by <xex>on</xex> or
<xex>over</xex>.</def>

<au>Longfellow.</au>

<hw>Pon`der*a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>pond\'82rabilit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or
state of being ponderable.</def>

<hw>Pon"der*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ponderabilis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pond\'82rable</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Capable of being weighed; having appreciable weight.</def>
-- <wordforms><wf>Pon"der*a*ble*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pon"der*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pond\'82ral</ets>.]</ety> <def>Estimated or ascertained by
weight; -- distinguished from <xex>numeral</xex>; <as>as, a
<ex>ponderal</ex> drachma</as>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<hw>Pon"der*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ponderans</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>ponderare</ets> to weigh:
cf. OF. <ets>ponderant</ets> of weight.]</ety> <def>Weight;
gravity.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Gregory.</au>

<hw>Pond"fish`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of numerous species of
American fresh-water fishes belonging to the family
<spn>Centrarchid\'91</spn>; -- called also <altname>pond
perch</altname>, and <altname>sunfish</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The common pondfish of New England (<spn>Lepomis
gibbosus</spn>) is called also <altname>bream</altname>,
<altname>pumpkin seed</altname>, and <altname>sunny</altname>.
See <er>Sunfish</er>. The long-eared pondfish (<spn>Lepomis
auritus</spn>) of the Eastern United States is distinguished by
its very long opercular flap.</note>

<hw>Pond"weed`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>

which many species are found in ponds or slow-moving
rivers.</def>

<cs><col>Choke pondweed</col>, <cd>an American water weed
(<spn>Anarcharis, <or/ Elodea, Canadensis</spn>.) See
<er>Anacharis</er>.</cd> -- <col>Horned pondweed</col>, <cd>the
<spn>Zannichellia palustris</spn>, a slender, branching aquatic
plant, having pointed nutlets.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pon"iard</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>\'d8Pons</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Pon"tiff</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<er>Pontoon</er>.]</ety> <def>A high priest.</def> Especially:
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>One of the sacred college, in ancient Rome,

<def>The chief priest</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld>
<def>The pope.</def>

<hw>Pon*toon"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>ponton</ets> (cf. It. <ets>pontone</ets>), from L.
<ets>ponto</ets>, <ets>-onis</ets>, fr. <ets>pons</ets>,
<ets>pontis</ets>, a bridge, perhaps originally, a way, path: cf.
Gr. <?/ path, Skr. <ets>path</ets>, <ets>pathi</ets>,
<ets>panthan</ets>. Cf. <er>Punt</er> a boat.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>A wooden flat-bottomed boat, a metallic
cylinder, or a frame covered with canvas, India rubber, etc.,
forming a portable float, used in building bridges quickly for
the passage of troops.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A low, flat vessel,
resembling a barge, furnished with cranes, capstans, and other
machinery, used in careening ships, raising weights, drawing
piles, etc., chiefly in the Mediterranean; a lighter.</def>

<cs><col>Pontoon bridge</col>, <cd>a bridge formed with
pontoons.</cd> -- <col>Pontoon train</col>, <cd>the carriages of
the pontoons, and the materials they carry for making a pontoon
bridge.</cd></cs>

<note><hand/ The French spelling <xex>ponton</xex> often appears
in scientific works, but <xex>pontoon</xex> is more common
form.</note>

<hw>Pon*toon"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act, art, or
process of constructing pontoon bridges.</def> \'bdArmy
instruction in <xex>pontooning</xex>.\'b8

<au>Gen. W. T. Shermah.</au>

overhead bracing can not be used.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Poo"koo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the

<hw>Pool</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>p\'d3l</ets>; akin to LG. <ets>pool</ets>, <ets>pohl</ets>,
D. <ets>poel</ets>, G. <ets>pfuhl</ets>; cf. Icel.
<ets>pollr</ets>, also W. <ets>pwll</ets>, Gael.
<ets>poll</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A small and rather deep
collection of (usually) fresh water, as one supplied by a spring,
or occurring in the course of a stream; a reservoir for water;
<as>as, the <ex>pools</ex> of Solomon</as>.</def>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<q>Charity will hardly water the ground where it must first fill
a <qex>pool</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>The sleepy <qex>pool</qex> above the dam.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small body of standing or stagnant water; a
puddle.</def> \'bdThe filthy mantled <xex>pool</xex> beyond your
cell.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pool</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>poule</ets>, properly,
a hen. See <er>Pullet</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>poule</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The stake played for
in certain games of cards, billiards, etc.; an aggregated stake
to which each player has contributed a snare; also, the
receptacle for the stakes.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A game at billiards, in which each of the
players stakes a certain sum, the winner taking the whole; also,
in public billiard rooms, a game in which the loser pays the
entrance fee for all who engage in the game; a game of skill in
pocketing the balls on a pool table.</def>

<note><hand/ This game is played variously, but commonly with
fifteen balls, besides one cue ball, the contest being to drive
the most balls into the pockets.</note>

<q>He plays <qex>pool</qex> at the billiard houses.</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In rifle shooting, a contest in which each
competitor pays a certain sum for every shot he makes, the net
proceeds being divided among the winners.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Any gambling or commercial venture in which
several persons join.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A combination of persons contributing money to
be used for the purpose of increasing or depressing the market
price of stocks, grain, or other commodities; also, the aggregate
of the sums so contributed; <as>as, the <ex>pool</ex> took all
the wheat offered below the limit; he put $10,000 into the
<ex>pool</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Railroads)</fld> <def>A mutual arrangement
between competing lines, by which the receipts of all are
aggregated, and then distributed <xex>pro rata</xex> according to
agreement.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An aggregation of properties or
rights, belonging to different people in a community, in a common
fund, to be charged with common liabilities.</def>

<cs><col>Pin pool</col>, <cd>a variety of the game of billiards
in which small wooden pins are set up to be knocked down by the
balls.</cd> -- <col>Pool ball</col>, <cd>one of the colored ivory
balls used in playing the game at billiards called
<xex>pool<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Pool snipe</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the European redshank.</cd>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Pool table</col></mcol>, <cd>a
billiard table with pockets.</cd></cs><-- pool hall, a commercial
establishment where customers may play pool for a fee.  pool
room, (a) a room containing a pool table as its most prominent
feature. (b) pool hall. -->

<hw>Pool</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pooled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pooling</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To put together; to
contribute to a common fund, on the basis of a mutual division of
profits or losses; to make a common interest of; <as>as, the
companies <ex>pooled</ex> their traffic</as>.</def>

<q>Finally, it favors the <qex>pooling</qex>of all issues.</q>
<qau>U. S. Grant.</qau>

<hw>Pool</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To combine or contribute
with others, as for a commercial, speculative, or gambling
transaction.</def>

<hw>Pool"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A stick for
stirring a tan vat.</def>

<hw>Pool"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The act of
uniting, or an agreement to unite, an aggregation of properties
belonging to different persons, with a view to common liabilities
or profits.</def>

<hw>Poon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Canarese
<ets>ponne</ets>.]</ety> <def>A name for several East Indian, or
their wood, used for the masts and spars of vessels, as
<spn>Calophyllum angustifolium</spn>, <spn>C. inophullum</spn>,
and <spn>Sterculia f\'d2tida</spn>; -- called also
<altname>peon</altname>.</def>

<hw>Poo"nac</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of oil
cake prepared from the cocoanut. See <cref>Oil cake</cref>, under
<er>Cake</er>.</def>

<hw>Poon"ga oil`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A kind of oil used in
India for lamps, and for boiling with dammar for pitching
vessels. It is pressed from the seeds of a leguminous tree
(<spn>Pongamia glabra</spn>).</def>

<hw>Poop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<def>See 2d <er>Poppy</er>.</def>

<hw>Poop</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pooped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pooping</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. D. <ets>poepen</ets>.
See <er>Pop</er>.]</ety> <def>To make a noise; to pop; also, to
break wind.</def>

<hw>Poop</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>poupe</ets>; cf. Sp. &
Pg. <ets>popa</ets>, It. <ets>poppa</ets>; all fr. L.
<ets>puppis</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A deck raised
above the after part of a vessel; the hindmost or after part of a
vessel's hull; also, a cabin covered by such a deck. See
<cref>Poop deck</cref>, under <er>Deck</er>. See also
<er>Roundhouse</er>.</def>

<q>With wind in <qex>poop</qex>, the vessel plows the sea.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>The <qex>poop</qex> was beaten gold.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Poop</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>To break over the poop or stern, as a wave.</def> \'bdA sea
which he thought was going to <xex>poop</xex> her.\'b8 <au>Lord
Dufferin</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>To strike in the stern, as by
collision.</def>

<hw>Pooped</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p. & a.</pos>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Having a poop; furnished
with a poop.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Struck on the poop.</def>
<-- (c) Tired; exhausted, fatigued.

   pooped out a. pooped[c].
 -->

<hw>Poop"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<def>The act or shock of striking a vessel's stern by a following
wave or vessel.</def>

<-- p. 1114 -->

<hw>Poor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Poorer</er> <pr>(?; 254)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Poorest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>poure</ets> or <ets>povre</ets>, OF. <ets>povre</ets>, F.
<ets>pauvre</ets>, L. <ets>pauper</ets>; the first syllable of
which is probably akin to <ets>paucus</ets> few (see
<er>Paucity</er>, <er>Few</er>), and the second to
<ets>parare</ets> to prepare, procure. See <er>Few</er>, and cf.
<er>Parade</er>, <er>Pauper</er>, <er>Poverty</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Destitute of property; wanting in material
riches or goods; needy; indigent.</def>

<note><hand/ It is often synonymous with <xex>indigent</xex> and
with <xex>necessitous</xex> denoting extreme want. It is also
applied to persons who are not entirely destitute of property,
but who are not rich; as, a <xex>poor</xex> man or woman;
<xex>poor</xex> people.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>So completely destitute of
property as to be entitled to maintenance from the public.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> Hence, in very various applications: <def>Destitute
of such qualities as are desirable, or might naturally be
expected</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Wanting in fat, plumpness,
or fleshiness; lean; emaciated; meager; <as>as, a <ex>poor</ex>
horse, ox, dog, etc</as>.</def> \'bdSeven other kine came up
after them, <xex>poor</xex> and very ill-favored and
lean-fleshed.\'b8 <au>Gen. xli. 19</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Wanting in strength or vigor; feeble; dejected; <as>as,
<ex>poor</ex> health; <ex>poor</ex> spirits.</def> \'bdHis genius
. . . <xex>poor</xex> and cowardly.\'b8 <au>Bacon</au>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>Of little value or worth; not good; inferior;
shabby; mean; <as>as, <ex>poor</ex> clothes</as>; <ex>poor</ex>
lodgings.</def> \'bdA <xex>poor</xex> vessel.\'b8
<au>Clarendon</au>. <sd>(d)</sd> <def>Destitute of fertility;
exhausted; barren; sterile; -- said of land; <as>as,
<ex>poor</ex> soil</as>.</def> <sd>(e)</sd> <def>Destitute of
beauty, fitness, or merit; <as>as, a <ex>poor</ex>
discourse</as>; a <ex>poor</ex> picture.</def> <sd>(f)</sd>
<def>Without prosperous conditions or good results; unfavorable;
unfortunate; unconformable; <as>as, a <ex>poor</ex>
business</as>; the sick man had a <ex>poor</ex> night</as>.</def>
<sd>(g)</sd> <def>Inadequate; insufficient; insignificant;
<as>as, a <ex>poor</ex> excuse</as>.</def>

<q>That I have wronged no man will be a <qex>poor</qex> plea or
apology at the last day.</q>
<qau>Calamy.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Worthy of pity or sympathy; -- used also
sometimes as a term of endearment, or as an expression of
modesty, and sometimes as a word of contempt.</def>

<q>And for mine own <qex>poor</qex> part,
Look you, I'll go pray.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Poor</qex>, little, pretty, fluttering thing.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Free from self-assertion; not proud or arrogant;
meek.</def> \'bdBlessed are the <xex>poor</xex> in spirit.\'b8

<au>Matt. v. 3.</au>

<cs><col>Poor law</col>, <cd>a law providing for, or regulating,
the relief or support of the poor.</cd> -- <col>Poor man's
treacle</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>garlic; -- so called because
it was thought to be an antidote to animal poison.
<mark>[Eng]</mark> <au>Dr. Prior</au>.</cd> -- <col>Poor man's
weatherglass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the red-flowered
pimpernel (<spn>Anagallis arvensis</spn>), which opens its
blossoms only in fair weather.</cd> -- <col>Poor rate</col>,
<cd>an assessment or tax, as in an English parish, for the relief
or support of the poor.</cd> -- <col>Poor soldier</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the friar bird.</cd> -- <col>The
poor</col>, <cd>those who are destitute of property; the
indigent; the needy. In a legal sense, those who depend on
charity or maintenance by the public.</cd>  \'bdI have observed
the more public provisions are made for <xex>the poor<xex>, the
less they provide for themselves.\'b8 <au>Franklin</au>.</cs>

<hw>Poor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A small European codfish (<spn>Gadus minutus</spn>); --
called also <altname>power cod</altname>.</def>

<hw>Poor"box`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A receptacle
in which money given for the poor is placed.</def>

<hw>Poor"house`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A dwelling
for a number of paupers maintained at public expense; an
almshouse; a workhouse.</def>

<hw>Poor"-john`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small European fish, similar to the
cod, but of inferior quality.</def>

<q><qex>Poor-john</qex> and apple pies are all our fare.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Harrington.</qau>

<hw>Poor"li*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being poorly; ill health.</def>

<hw>Poor"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>In a poor
manner or condition; without plenty, or sufficiency, or suitable
provision for comfort; <as>as, to live
<ex>poorly</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>With little or no success; indifferently; with
little profit or advantage; <as>as, to do <ex>poorly</ex> in
business</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Meanly; without spirit.</def>

<q>Nor is their courage or their wealth so low,
That from his wars they <qex>poorly</qex> would retire.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Without skill or merit; <as>as, he performs
<ex>poorly</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Poorly off</col>, <cd>not well off; not rich.</cd></cs>

<hw>Poor"ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Somewhat ill; indisposed;
not in health.</def> \'bdHaving been <xex>poorly</xex> in
health.\'b8

<au>T. Scott.</au>

<hw>Poor"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state of
being poor (in any of the senses of the adjective).</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Poor"-spir`it*ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of a
mean spirit; cowardly; base.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Poor"-spir`it*ed*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Poor"-will`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called
in imitation of its note.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A
bird of the Western United States (<spn>Phal\'91noptilus
Nutalli</spn>) allied to the whip-poor-will.</def>

<hw>Poor"-wil`lie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So
called in imitation of its note.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>The bar-tailed godwit.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Of imitative
origin. Cf. <er>Poop</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A small,
sharp, quick explosive sound or report; <as>as, to go off with a
<ex>pop</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An unintoxicating beverage which expels the cork
with a pop from the bottle containing it; <as>as, ginger
<ex>pop</ex>; lemon <ex>pop</ex>, etc.</as></def>

<au>Hood.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The European
redwing.</def> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<cs><col>Pop corn</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>Corn, or maize, of
peculiar excellence for popping; especially, a kind the grains of
which are small and compact</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Popped corn;
which has been popped.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pop</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Popped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Popping</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make a pop, or
sharp, quick sound; <as>as, the muskets <ex>popped</ex> away on
all sides</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To enter, or issue forth, with a quick, sudden
movement; to move from place to place suddenly; to dart; -- with
<xex>in</xex>, <xex>out</xex>, <xex>upon</xex>, <xex>off</xex>,
etc.</def>

<q>He that killed my king . . . 
<qex>Popp'd</qex> in between the election and my hopes.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A trick of <qex>popping</qex> up and down every moment.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To burst open with a pop, when heated over a
fire; <as>as, this corn <ex>pops</ex> well</as>.</def>

<hw>Pop</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To thrust or push
suddenly; to offer suddenly; to bring suddenly and unexpectedly
to notice; <as>as, to <ex>pop</ex> one's head in at the
door</as>.</def>

<q>He <qex>popped</qex> a paper into his hand.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cause to pop; to cause to burst open by heat,
as grains of Indian corn; <as>as, to <ex>pop</ex> corn or
chestnuts</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To pop off</col>, <cd>to thrust away, or put off
promptly; as, to <xex>pop<xex> one off with a denial.
<au>Locke</au>.</cd> -- <col>To pop the question</col>, <cd>to
make an offer of marriage to a lady. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cd>
<au>Dickens.</au></cs>

<hw>Pop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Like a pop;
suddenly; unexpectedly.</def> \'bd<xex>Pop</xex> goes his
plate.\'b8

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<hw>Pope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.

Church.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A fish; the ruff.</def>

<cs><col>Pope Joan</col>, <cd>a game at cards played on a round

gland surrounded with fat in the middle of the thigh of an ox or

<hw>Pop"in*jay</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>popingay</ets>, <ets>papejay</ets>, OF. <ets>papegai</ets>,
<ets>papegaut</ets>; cf. Pr. <ets>papagai</ets>, Sp. & Pg.
<ets>papagayo</ets>, It. <ets>pappagallo</ets>, LGr. <?/, NGr.
<?/; in which the first syllables are perhaps imitative of the
bird's chatter, and the last either fr. L. <ets>gallus</ets>
cock, or the same word as E. <ets>jay</ets>, F. <ets>geai</ets>.
Cf. <er>Papagay</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The green

<hw>Pop"lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>popler</ets>, OF. <ets>poplier</ets>, F.
<ets>peuplier</ets>, fr. L. <ets>populus</ets> poplar.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Any tree of the genus
<spn>Populus</spn>; also, the timber, which is soft, and capable
of many uses.</def>

<note><hand/ The aspen poplar is <spn>Populus tremula</spn> and
<spn>P. tremuloides</spn>; Balsam poplar is <spn>P.
balsamifera</spn>; Lombardy poplar (<spn>P. dilatata</spn>) is a
tall, spiry tree; white poplar is <spn>Populus alba</spn>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The timber of the tulip tree; -- called also
<altname>white poplar</altname>.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

many varieties, usually made of silk and worsted, -- used
especially for women's dresses.</def>

<cs><col>Irish poplin</col>, <cd>a fabric with silk warp and
worsted weft, made in Ireland.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pop"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

<hw>Pop"py</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Poppies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE. <ets>popy</ets>,
AS. <ets>popig</ets>, L. <ets>papaver</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any plant or species of the genus
<spn>Papaver</spn>, herbs with showy polypetalous flowers and a
milky juice. From one species (<spn>Papaver somniferum</spn>)
opium is obtained, though all the species contain it to some
extent; also, a flower of the plant. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Capsule</er>.</def>

<cs><col>California poppy</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any
yellow-flowered plant of the genus <spn>Eschscholtzia</spn>.</cd>
-- <col>Corn poppy</col>. <cd>See under <er>Corn</er>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Horn</col>, <or/ <col>Horned</col>,
<col>poppy</col></mcol>. <cd>See under <er>Horn</er>.</cd> --
<col>Poppy bee</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a leaf-cutting
bee (<spn>Anthocopa papaveris</spn>) which uses pieces cut from
poppy petals for the lining of its cells; -- called also
<altname>upholsterer bee</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Prickly
poppy</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd><spn>Argemone Mexicana</spn>,
a yellow-flowered plant of the Poppy family, but as prickly as a
thistle.</cd> -- <col>Poppy seed</col>, <cd>the seed the opium
poppy (<spn>P. somniferum</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Spatling
poppy</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a species of Silene (<spn>S.
inflata</spn>). See <er>Catchfly</er>.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pop"py</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pop"py*head`</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>poup\'82e</ets>
doll, puppet. See <er>Puppet</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<def>A raised ornament frequently having the form of a final. It
is generally used on the tops of the upright ends or elbows which
terminate seats, etc., in Gothic churches.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*lace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>populace</ets>, fr. It. <ets>popolaccio</ets>,
<ets>popolazzo</ets>, fr. <ets>popolo</ets> people, L.
<ets>populus</ets>. See <er>People</er>.]</ety> <def>The common
people; the vulgar; the multitude, -- comprehending all persons
not distinguished by rank, office, education, or
profession.</def>

<au>Pope.</au>

<q>To . . . calm the peers and please the
<qex>populace</qex>.</q>
<qau>Daniel.</qau>

<q>They . . . call us Britain's barbarous
<qex>populaces</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Mob; people; commonalty.</syn>

<hw>Pop"u*la*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Populace.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Feltham.</au>

<hw>Pop"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>popularis</ets>, fr. <ets>populus</ets> people: cf. F.
<ets>populaire</ets>. See <er>People</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to the common people, or to the whole body
of the people, as distinguished from a select portion; <as>as,
the <ex>popular</ex> voice; <ex>popular</ex>
elections.</as></def> \'bd<xex>Popular</xex> states.\'b8
<au>Bacon</au>. \'bdSo the <xex>popular</xex> vote inclines.\'b8
<au>Milton</au>.

<q>The commonly held in <qex>popular</qex> estimation are
greatest at a distance.</q>
<qau>J. H. Newman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Suitable to common people; easy to be
comprehended; not abstruse; familiar; plain.</def>

<q>Homilies are plain <qex>popular</qex> instructions.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Adapted to the means of the common people;
possessed or obtainable by the many; hence, cheap; common;
ordinary; inferior; <as>as, <ex>popular</ex> prices;
<ex>popular</ex> amusements.</as></def>

<q>The smallest figs, called <qex>popular</qex> figs, . . . are,
of all others, the basest and of least account.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Beloved or approved by the people; pleasing to
people in general, or to many people; <as>as, a <ex>popular</ex>
preacher; a <ex>popular</ex> law; a <ex>popular</ex>
administration.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Devoted to the common people; studious of the
favor of the populace.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Such <qex>popular</qex> humanity is treason.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Prevailing among the people; epidemic; <as>as, a
<ex>popular</ex> disease</as>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<cs><col>Popular action</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd> an action in
which any person may sue for penalty imposed by
statute.</cd></cs>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pop`u*la"res</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>The people or the people's party, in ancient
Rome, as opposed to the <xex>optimates</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pop`u*lar"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Popularities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>popularitas</ets> an effort to please the people: cf. F.
<ets>popularit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or
state of being popular; especially, the state of being esteemed
by, or of being in favor with, the people at large; good will or
favor proceeding from the people; <as>as, the <ex>popularity</ex>
of a law, statesman, or a book</as>.</def>

<q>A <qex>popularity</qex> which has lasted down to our time.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being adapted or
pleasing to common, poor, or vulgar people; hence, cheapness;
inferiority; vulgarity.</def>

<q>This gallant laboring to avoid <qex>popularity</qex> falls
into a habit of affectation.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Something which obtains, or is intended to
obtain, the favor of the vulgar; claptrap.</def>

<q><qex>Popularities</qex>, and circumstances which . . . sway
the ordinary judgment.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The act of courting the favor of the
people.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdIndicted . . . for
<xex>popularity</xex> and ambition.\'b8

<au>Holland.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Public sentiment; general passion.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>A little time be allowed for the madness of
<qex>popularity</qex> to cease.</q>
<qau>Bancroft.</qau>

<hw>Pop`u*lar*i*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of making popular, or of introducing among the people.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*lar*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Popularized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Popularizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>populariser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To make popular; to make
suitable or acceptable to the common people; to make generally
known; <as>as, to <ex>popularize</ex> philosophy</as>.</def>
\'bdThe <xex>popularizing</xex> of religious teaching.\'b8

<au>Milman.</au>

<hw>Pop"u*lar*i`zer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
popularizes.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*lar*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a popular manner;
so as to be generally favored or accepted by the people;
commonly; currently; <as>as, the story was <ex>popularity</ex>
reported</as>.</def>

<q>The victor knight,
Bareheaded, <qex>popularly</qex> low had bowed.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pop"u*lar*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state
of being popular; popularity.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pop"u*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Populated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Populating</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To furnish with
inhabitants, either by natural increase or by immigration or
colonization; to cause to be inhabited; to people.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*late</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To propagate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Great shoals of people which go on to <qex>populate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<hw>Pop`u*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>populatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>population</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process of populating; multiplication
of inhabitants.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The whole number of people, or inhabitants, in a
country, or portion of a country; <as>as, a <ex>population</ex>
of ten millions</as>.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*la`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
populates.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*li*cide`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>populus</ets> people + <ets>caedere</ets> to kill.]</ety>

<hw>Pop"u*lin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>populus</ets> poplar: cf. F. <ets>populine</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A glycoside, related to salicin, found in
the bark of certain species of the poplar (<spn>Populus</spn>),
and extracted as a sweet white crystalline substance.</def>

<hw>Pop"u*lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>populosus</ets>, fr. <ets>populus</ets> people: cf. F.
<ets>populeux</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Abounding in people;
full of inhabitants; containing many inhabitants in proportion to
the extent of the country.</def>

<q>Heaven, yet <qex>populous</qex>, retains
Number sufficient to possess her realms.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Popular; famous.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>J. Webster.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Common; vulgar.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Arden of Feversham.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Numerous; in large number.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe dust . . . raised by your
<xex>populous</xex> troops.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Por"ce*lain</hw> <pr>(277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>porcelaine</ets>, It. <ets>porcellana</ets>, orig., the
porcelain shell, or Venus shell (<ets>Cypr\'91a
porcellana</ets>), from a dim. fr. L. <ets>porcus</ets> pig,
probably from the resemblance of the shell in shape to a pig's
back. Porcelain was called after this shell, either on account of
its smoothness and whiteness, or because it was believed to be
made from it. See <er>Pork</er>.]</ety> <def>A fine translucent
or semitransculent kind of earthenware, made first in China and
Japan, but now also in Europe and America; -- called also
<altname>China</altname>, or <altname>China ware</altname>.</def>

<q><qex>Porcelain</qex>, by being pure, is apt to break.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Ivory porcelain</col>, <cd>porcelain with a surface like
ivory, produced by depolishing. See <er>Depolishing</er>.</cd> --
<col>Porcelain clay</col>. <cd>See under <er>Clay</er>.</cd> --
<col>Porcelain crab</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any crab of
the genus <spn>Porcellana</spn> and allied genera (family
<spn>Porcellanid\'91</spn>). They have a smooth, polished
carapace.</cd> -- <col>Porcelain jasper</col>. <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<cd>See <er>Porcelanite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Porcelain
printing</col>, <cd>the transferring of an impression of an
engraving to porcelain.</cd> -- <col>Porcelain shell</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a cowry.</cd></cs>

<hw>Por"ce*lain*ized</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Baked like potter's lay; -- applied to
clay shales that have been converted by heat into a substance
resembling porcelain.</def>

<hw>Por`cel*la"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having a smooth, compact
shell without pores; -- said of certain Foraminifera.</def>

<hw>Por"ce*la*nite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<hw>Porch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>porche</ets>, L. <ets>porticus</ets>, fr. <ets>porta</ets> a
gate, entrance, or passage. See <er>Port</er> a gate, and cf.
<er>Portico</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A
covered and inclosed entrance to a building, whether taken from
the interior, and forming a sort of vestibule within the main
wall, or projecting without and with a separate roof. Sometimes
the porch is large enough to serve as a covered walk. See also
<cref>Carriage porch</cref>, under <er>Carriage</er>, and
<er>Loggia</er>.</def>

<q>The graceless Helen in the <qex>porch</qex> I spied
Of Vesta's temple.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A portico; a covered walk.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Repair to Pompey's <qex>porch</qex>, where you shall find find
us.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>The Porch</col>, <cd>a public portico, or great hall, in
Athens, where Zeno, the philosopher, taught his disciples; hence,
sometimes used as equivalent to <xex>the school of the
Stoics<xex>. It was called <grk>"h poiki`lh stoa`</grk>. [See
<er>Poicile</er>.]</cd></cs>

<hw>Por"cine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>porcinus</ets>, from <ets>porcus</ets> a swine. See
<er>Pork</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to swine;
characteristic of the hog.</def> \'bd<xex>Porcine</xex>
cheeks.\'b8

<au>G. Eliot.</au>

<hw>Por"cu*pine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>porkepyn</ets>, <ets>porpentine</ets>, OF.
<ets>porc-espi</ets>, F. <ets>porc-\'82pic</ets> (cf. It.
<ets>porco spino</ets>, <ets>porco spinoso</ets>, Sp. <ets>puerco
espino</ets>, <ets>puerco espin</ets>, fr. L. <ets>porcus</ets>
swine + <ets>spina</ets> thorn, spine). The last part of the
French word is perhaps a corruption from the It. or Sp.; cf. F.
<ets>\'82pi</ets> ear, a spike of grain, L. <ets>spica</ets>. See
<er>Pork</er>, <er>Spike</er> a large nail,
<er>Spine</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any
Old Word rodent of the genus <spn>Hystrix</spn>, having the back
covered with long, sharp, erectile spines or quills, sometimes a
foot long. The common species of Europe and Asia (<spn>Hystrix
cristata</spn>) is the best known.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of
<spn>Erethizon</spn> and related genera, native of America. They
are related to the true porcupines, but have shorter spines, and
are arboreal in their habits. The Canada porcupine
(<spn>Erethizon dorsatus</spn>) is a well known species.</def>

<cs><col>Porcupine ant-eater</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
echidna.</cd> -- <col>Porcupine crab</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a large spiny Japanese crab (<spn>Acantholithodes
hystrix</spn>).</cd> -- <col>Porcupine disease</col>
<fld>(Med.)</fld>. <cd>See <er>Ichthyosis</er>.</cd> --
<col>Porcupine fish</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
plectognath fish having the body covered with spines which become
erect when the body is inflated. See <er>Diodon</er>, and
<er>Globefish</er>.</cd> -- <col>Porcupine grass</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a grass (<spn>Stipa spartea</spn>) with
grains bearing a stout twisted awn, which, by coiling and
uncoiling through changes in moisture, propels the sharp-pointed
and barbellate grain into the wool and flesh of sheep. It is
found from Illinois westward. See <xex>Illustration<xex> in
Appendix.</cd> -- <col>Porcupine wood</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>the hard outer wood of the cocoa palm; -- so called because,
when cut horizontally, the markings of the wood resemble the
quills of a porcupine.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>porus</ets>, Gr. <?/ a passage, a pore. See <er>Fare</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One of the minute orifices
in an animal or vegetable membrane, for transpiration,
absorption, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A minute opening or passageway; an interstice
between the constituent particles or molecules of a body; <as>as,
the <ex>pores</ex> of stones</as>.</def>

<hw>Pore</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pored</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Poring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>poren</ets>, of
uncertain origin; cf. D. <ets>porren</ets> to poke, thrust, Gael.
<ets>purr</ets>.]</ety> <def>To look or gaze steadily in reading
or studying; to fix the attention; to be absorbed; -- often with
<xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex>, and now usually with
<xex>over</xex>.</def>\'bdPainfully to <xex>pore</xex> upon a
book.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The eye grows weary with <qex>poring</qex> perpetually on the
same thing.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Po*rif"e*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. L. <ets>porus</ets> pore + <ets>ferre</ets> to
bear.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A grand division of the
Invertebrata, including the sponges; -- called also
<spn>Spongi\'91</spn>, <spn>Spongida</spn>, and
<spn>Spongiozoa</spn>. The principal divisions are
Calcispongi\'91, Keratosa or Fibrospongi\'91, and Silicea.</def>

<hw>Po"rism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/ a
thing procured, a deduction from a demonstration, fr. <?/ to
bring, provide: cf. F. <ets>porisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A proposition affirming the possibility
of finding such conditions as will render a certain determinate
problem indeterminate or capable of innumerable solutions.</def>

<au>Playfair.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gr. Geom.)</fld> <def>A corollary.</def>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<note><hand/ Three books of <xex>porisms</xex> of Euclid have
been lost, but several attempts to determine the nature of these
propositions and to restore them have been made by modern
geometers.</note>

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any coral of the genus Porites, or

<hw>\'d8Po*ri"tes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ a pore.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An important
genus of reef-building corals having small twelve-rayed calicles,
and a very porous coral. Some species are branched, others grow
in large massive or globular forms.</def>

<hw>Pork</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>porc</ets>, L. <ets>porcus</ets> hog, pig. See

<hw>Pork"wood`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>The coarse-grained brownish yellow wood of a small tree
(<spn>Pisonia obtusata</spn>) of Florida and the West Indies.
Also called <altname>pigeon wood</altname>,
<altname>beefwood</altname>, and
<altname>corkwood</altname>.</def>

<hw>Por*nog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<hw>Por"ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>poreux</ets>. See <er>Pore</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety>
<def>Full of pores; having interstices in the skin or in the
substance of the body; having spiracles or passages for fluids;
permeable by liquids; <as>as, a <ex>porous</ex> skin;
<ex>porous</ex> wood.</as></def> \'bdThe veins of
<xex>porous</xex> earth.\'b8

manner.</def>

<hw>Por"ous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality
of being porous.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The open parts; the interstices of
anything.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<qau>Sir K. Digby.</qau>

<hw>Por"phy*rite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A rock with a porphyritic structure;
<as>as, augite <ex>porphyrite</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Por`phy*rit"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>porphyritique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Relating
to, or resembling, porphyry, that is, characterized by the
presence of distinct crystals, as of feldspar, quartz, or augite,
in a relatively fine-grained base, often aphanitic or
cryptocrystalline.</def>

<hw>Por`phy*ri*za"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of porphyrizing, or the state of being porphyrized.</def>

<hw>Por`phy*rize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>porphyriser</ets>, Gr. <?/ to purplish.]</ety> <def>To cause
to resemble porphyry; to make spotted in composition, like
porphyry.</def>

<hw>Por`phy*ro*gen"i*tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[LL. <ets>porphyro genitus</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/; <?/ purple +
root of <?/ to be born.]</ety> <def>The principle of succession
in royal families, especially among the Eastern Roman emperors,
by which a younger son, if born after the accession of his father
to the throne, was preferred to an elder son who was not so
born.</def>

<au>Sir T. Palgrave.</au>

<hw>Por"phy*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Porphyries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>porphyre</ets>, L. <ets>porphyrites</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/ like
purple, fr. <?/ purple. See <er>Purple</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A term used somewhat loosely to designate
a rock consisting of a fine-grained base (usually feldspathic)
through which crystals, as of feldspar or quartz, are
disseminated. There are red, purple, and green varieties, which
are highly esteemed as marbles.</def>

<cs><col>Porphyry shell</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
handsome marine gastropod shell (<spn>Oliva porphyria</spn>),
having a dark red or brown polished surface, marked with light
spots, like porphyry.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Por"pi*ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
from Gr. <?/ brooch.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of
bright-colored Siphonophora found floating in the warmer parts of
the ocean. The individuals are round and disk-shaped, with a
large zooid in the center of the under side, surrounded by
smaller nutritive and reproductive zooids, and by slender
dactylozooids near the margin. The disk contains a central float,
or pneumatocyst.</def>

<hw>Por"poise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>porpeys</ets>, OF. <ets>porpeis</ets>, literally, hog fish,
from L. <ets>porcus</ets> swine + <ets>piscis</ets> fish. See
<er>Pork</er>, and <er>Fish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any small cetacean of the genus
<spn>Phoc\'91na</spn>, especially <spn>P. communis</spn>, or
<spn>P. phoc\'91na</spn>, of Europe, and the closely allied
American species (<spn>P. Americana</spn>). The color is dusky or
blackish above, paler beneath. They are closely allied to the
dolphins, but have a shorter snout. Called also <altname>harbor
porpoise</altname>, <altname>herring hag</altname>,
<altname>puffing pig</altname>, and
<altname>snuffer</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A true dolphin
(<spn>Delphinus</spn>); -- often so called by sailors.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Skunk porpoise</col>, <or/ <col>Bay
porpoise</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a North American
porpoise (<spn>Lagenorhynchus acutus</spn>), larger than the
common species, and with broad stripes of white and yellow on the
sides. See <xex>Illustration<xex> in Appendix.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Por`po*ri"no</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[It.]</ety> <def>A composition of quicksilver, tin, and
sulphur, forming a yellow powder, sometimes used by medi\'91val
artists, for the sake of economy, instead of gold.</def>

<au>Fairholt.</au>

<hw>Por"pus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Por"ridge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably
corrupted fr. <ets>pottage</ets>; perh. influenced by OE.
<ets>porree</ets> a kind of pottage, OF. <ets>porr\'82e</ets>,
fr. L. <ets>porrum</ets>, <ets>porrus</ets>, leek. See
<er>Pottage</er>, and cf. <er>Porringer</er>.]</ety> <def>A food
made by boiling some leguminous or farinaceous substance, or the
meal of it, in water or in milk, making of broth or thin pudding;
<as>as, barley <ex>porridge</ex>, milk <ex>porridge</ex>, bean
<ex>porridge</ex>, etc</as>.</def>

<hw>Por"rin*ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pottanger</ets>, for <ets>pottager</ets>; cf. F.
<ets>potager</ets> a soup basin. See <er>Porridge</er>.]</ety>
<def>A porridge dish; esp., a bowl or cup from which children eat
or are fed; <as>as, a silver <ex>porringer</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<hw>Port</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<ets>Oporto</ets>, in Portugal, i. e., <ets><?/ porto</ets> the
port, L. <ets>portus</ets>. See <er>Port</er> harbor.]</ety>
<def>A dark red or purple astringent wine made in Portugal. It
contains a large percentage of alcohol.</def>

<hw>Port</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>port</ets>, L.
<ets>portus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>port</ets>. See <er>Farm</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>, <er>Ford</er>, and 1st, 3d, & 4h
<er>Port</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A place where ships may
ride secure from storms; a sheltered inlet, bay, or cove; a
harbor; a haven. Used also figuratively.</def>

<-- p. 1116 -->

<q>Peering in maps for <qex>ports</qex> and piers and roads.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>We are in <qex>port</qex> if we have Thee.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In law and commercial usage, a harbor where
vessels are admitted to discharge and receive cargoes, from
whence they depart and where they finish their voyages.</def>

<cs><col>Free port</col>. <cd>See under <er>Free</er>.</cd> --
<col>Port bar</col>. <fld>(Naut,)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A
boom</cd>. See <er>Boom</er>, 4, also <er>Bar</er>, 3.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A bar, as of sand, at the mouth of, or in, a
port.</cd> -- <col>Port charges</col> <fld>(Com.)</fld>,
<cd>charges, as wharfage, etc., to which a ship or its cargo is
subjected in a harbor.</cd> -- <col>Port of entry</col>, <cd>a
harbor where a customhouse is established for the legal entry of
merchandise.</cd> -- <col>Port toll</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a
payment made for the privilege of bringing goods into port.</cd>
-- <col>Port warden</col>, <cd>the officer in charge of a port; a
harbor master.</cd></cs>

<hw>Port</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>porte</ets>, L. <ets>porta</ets>, akin to <ets>portus</ets>;
cf. AS. <ets>porte</ets>, fr. L. <ets>porta</ets>. See
<er>Port</er> a harbor, and cf. <er>Porte</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A passageway; an opening or entrance to an
inclosed place; a gate; a door; a portal.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>Him I accuse
The city <qex>ports</qex> by this hath entered.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Form their ivory <qex>port</qex> the cherubim
Forth issuing.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>An opening in the side of a
vessel; an embrasure through which cannon may be discharged; a
porthole; also, the shutters which close such an opening.</def>

<q>Her <qex>ports</qex> being within sixteen inches of the
water.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A passageway in a machine,
through which a fluid, as steam, water, etc., may pass, as from a
valve to the interior of the cylinder of a steam engine; an
opening in a valve seat, or valve face.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Air port</col>, <col>Bridle port</col></mcol>,
<cd>etc. See under <er>Air</er>, <er>Bridle</er>, etc.</cd> --
<col>Port bar</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a bar to secure the
ports of a ship in a gale.</cd> -- <col>Port lid</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a lid or hanging for closing the
portholes of a vessel.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Steam port</col>, <and/
<col>Exhaust port</col></mcol> <fld>(Steam Engine)</fld>, <cd>the
ports of the cylinder communicating with the valve or valves, for
the entrance or exit of the steam, respectively.</cd></cs>

<hw>Port</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Ported</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Porting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>porter</ets>, L.
<ets>portare</ets> to carry. See <er>Port</er> demeanor.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To carry; to bear; to transport.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>They are easily <qex>ported</qex> by boat into other
shires.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <def>To throw, as a musket,
diagonally across the body, with the lock in front, the right
hand grasping the small of the stock, and the barrel sloping
upward and crossing the point of the left shoulder; <as>as, to
<ex>port</ex> arms</as>.</def>

<q>Began to hem him round with <qex>ported</qex> spears.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><col>Port arms</col>, <cd>a position in the manual of arms,
executed as above.</cd></cs>

<hw>Port</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>port</ets>, fr.
<ets>porter</ets> to carry, L. <ets>portare</ets>, prob. akin to
E. <ets>fare</ets>, v. See <er>Port</er> harbor, and cf.
<er>Comport</er>, <er>Export</er>, <er>Sport</er>.]</ety>
<def>The manner in which a person bears himself; deportment;
carriage; bearing; demeanor; hence, manner or style of living;
<as>as, a proud <ex>port</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>And of his <qex>port</qex> as meek as is a maid.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>The necessities of pomp, grandeur, and a suitable
<qex>port</qex> in the world.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Port</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Etymology uncertain.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>The larboard or left side of a ship
(looking from the stern toward the bow); <as>as, a vessel heels
to <ex>port</ex></as>. See <er>Note</er> under <er>Larboard</er>.
Also used adjectively.</def>

<hw>Port</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>To turn
or put to the left or larboard side of a ship; -- said of the
helm, and used chiefly in the imperative, as a command; <as>as,
<ex>port</ex> your helm</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Por"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Port\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., a gate. See
<er>Port</er> a hole.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The part of the liver or other organ where its vessels and
nerves enter; the hilus.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The foramen of
Monro.</def>

<au>B. G. Wilder.</au>

<hw>Port`a*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being portable; fitness to be carried.</def>

<hw>Port"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>portabilis</ets>, fr. <ets>portare</ets> to carry: cf. F.
<ets>portable</ets>. See <er>Port</er> demeanor.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being borne or carried; easily
transported; conveyed without difficulty; <as>as, a
<ex>portable</ex> bed, desk, engine</as>.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Possible to be endured; supportable.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>How light and <qex>portable</qex> my pain seems now!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Por"tage</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., from

carry (goods, boats, etc.) overland between navigable

<hw>Por"tage group`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[So called from the
township of <ets>Portage</ets> in New York.]</ety>
<fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A subdivision of the Chemung period in
American geology. See <xex>Chart</xex> of <er>Geology</er>.</def>

<hw>Por"ta*gue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Portuguese</er>.]</ety> <def>A Portuguese gold coin formerly
current, and variously estimated to be worth from three and one
half to four and one half pounds sterling.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <altsp>[Written also <asp>portegue</asp> and
<asp>portigue</asp>.]</altsp>

<q>Ten thousand <qex>portagues</qex>, besides great pearls.</q>
<qau>Marlowe.</qau>

<hw>Por"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>portal</ets>, F. <ets>portail</ets>, LL. <ets>portale</ets>,
fr. L. <ets>porta</ets> a gate. See <er>Port</er> a gate.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A door or gate; hence, a way of entrance or
exit, especially one that is grand and imposing.</def>

<q>Thick with sparkling orient gems
The <qex>portal</qex> shone.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>From out the fiery <qex>portal</qex> of the east.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The lesser gate,
where there are two of different dimensions.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Formerly, a small square corner in a room separated from the
rest of the apartment by wainscoting, forming a short passage to
another apartment.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>By analogy with the
French <xex>portail</xex>, used by recent writers for the whole
architectural composition which surrounds and includes the
doorways and porches of a church.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bridge Building)</fld> <def>The space, at one
end, between opposite trusses when these are terminated by
inclined braces.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A prayer book or breviary; a portass.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<cs><col>Portal bracing</col> <fld>(Bridge Building)</fld>, <cd>a
combination of struts and ties which lie in the plane of the
inclined braces at a portal, serving to transfer wind pressure
from the upper parts of the trusses to an abutment or pier of the
bridge.</cd></cs>

<hw>Por"tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>Of or pertaining to a porta, especially the porta of the
liver; <as>as, the <ex>portal</ex> vein, which enters the liver
at the porta, and divides into capillaries after the manner of an
artery</as>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Portal</xex> is applied to other veins which
break up into capillaries; as, the renal <xex>portal</xex> veins
in the frog.</note>

<hw>\'d8Por`ta*men"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.,
fr. <ets>portare</ets> to carry.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>In
singing, or in the use of the bow, a gradual carrying or lifting
of the voice or sound very smoothly from one note to another; a
gliding from tone to tone.</def>

<hw>Por"tance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Port</er>, carriage, demeanor.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser. Shak.</au>

<hw>Por"tass</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>porte-hors</ets> a kind of prayer book, so called from being
portable; cf. LL. <ets>portiforium</ets>.]</ety> <def>A breviary;
a prayer book.</def> <altsp>[Written variously
<asp>portace</asp>, <asp>portasse</asp>, <asp>portesse</asp>,
<asp>portise</asp>, <asp>porthose</asp>, <asp>portos</asp>,
<asp>portus</asp>, <asp>portuse</asp>, etc.]</altsp>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser. Camden.</au>

<q>By God and by this <qex>porthors</qex> I you swear.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Por"tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>portatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>portare</ets> to carry.]</ety>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Borne not erect, but diagonally athwart an
escutcheon; <as>as, a cross <ex>portate</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Por"ta*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>portatif</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Portable.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Capable of holding up or
carrying; <as>as, the <ex>portative</ex> force of a magnet, of
atmospheric pressure, or of capillarity</as>.</def>

<hw>Port"cluse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
portcullis.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Port`cray"on</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>porte-crayon</ets>; <ets>porter</ets> to carry +
<ets>crayon</ets> a crayon.]</ety> <def>A metallic handle with a

<hw>Port*cul"lis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>porte coulisse</ets>, <ets>cole\'8bce</ets>, a sliding door,
fr. L. <ets>colare</ets>, <ets>colatum</ets>, to filter, to
strain: cf. F. <ets>couler</ets> to glide. See <er>Port</er> a
gate, and cf. <er>Cullis</er>, <er>Colander</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Fort.)</fld> <def>A grating of iron or of
timbers pointed with iron, hung over the gateway of a fortress,
to be let down to prevent the entrance of an enemy.</def> \'bdLet
the <xex>portcullis</xex> fall.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<q>She . . . the huge <qex>portcullis</qex> high updrew.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An English coin of the reign of Elizabeth,
struck for the use of the East India Company; -- so called from
its bearing the figure of a portcullis on the reverse.</def>

<hw>Port*cul"lis</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &
p. p.</pos> <er>Portcullised</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Portcullising</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To obstruct
with, or as with, a portcullis; to shut; to bar.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Porte</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>porte</ets> a gate, L. <ets>porta</ets>. See <er>Port</er> a
gate.]</ety> <def>The Ottoman court; the government of the
Turkish empire, officially called the <altname>Sublime
Porte</altname>, from the gate (<xex>port</xex>) of the sultan's
palace at which justice was administered.</def>

<hw>\'d8Porte"-co`ch\'8are"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F. See <er>Port</er> a gate, and <er>Coach</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A large doorway allowing vehicles to
drive into or through a building. It is common to have the
entrance door open upon the passage of the
<xex>porte-coch\'8are</xex>. Also, a porch over a driveway before
an entrance door.</def>

<hw>Port"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having

<q>We took the sevenfold-<qex>ported</qex> Thebes.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>Por"te*gue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See

<hw>Porte"mon*naie`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,

<hw>Por-tend"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Portended</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Portending</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>portendre</ets>, <ets>portentum</ets>, to foretell, to
predict, to impend, from an old preposition used in comp. +
<ets>tendere</ets> to stretch. See <er>Position</er>,
<er>Tend</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To indicate (events,
misfortunes, etc.) as in future; to foreshow; to foretoken; to
bode; -- now used esp. of unpropitious signs.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>Many signs <qex>portended</qex> a dark and stormy day.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To stretch out before.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
\'bdDoomed to feel the great Idomeneus' <xex>portended</xex>
steel.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To foreshow; foretoken; betoken; forebode; augur;
presage; foreshadow; threaten.</syn>

<hw>Por*ten"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
foreshowing; foreboding.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Por*tent"</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>portentum</ets>. See <er>Portend</er>.]</ety> <def>That
which portends, or foretoken; esp., that which portends evil; a
sign of coming calamity; an omen; a sign.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>My loss by dire <qex>portents</qex> the god foretold.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Por*tent"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Presaging;
foreshadowing.</def>

<hw>Por*tent"ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>portentosus</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of the nature of
a portent; containing portents; foreschadowing, esp.
foreschadowing ill; ominous.</def>

<q>For, I believe, they are <qex>portentous</qex> things.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Victories of strange and almost <qex>portentous</qex>
splendor.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: Monstrous; prodigious; wonderful;
dreadful; <as>as, a beast of <ex>portentous</ex> size</as>.</def>

<au>Roscommon.</au>

<hw>Por"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>portier</ets>, L. <ets>portarius</ets>, from
<ets>porta</ets> a gate, door. See <er>Port</er> a gate.]</ety>
<def>A man who has charge of a door or gate; a doorkeeper; one
who waits at the door to receive messages.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>To him the <qex>porter</qex> openeth.</q>
<qau>John x. 3.</qau>

<hw>Por"ter</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>porteur</ets>, fr.
<ets>porter</ets> to carry, L. <ets>portare</ets>. See
<er>Port</er> to carry.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A carrier; one
who carries or conveys burdens, luggage, etc.; for hire.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Forging)</fld> <def>A bar of iron or steel at
the end of which a forging is made; esp., a long, large bar, to
the end of which a heavy forging is attached, and by means of
which the forging is lifted and handled is hammering and heating;
-- called also <altname>porter bar</altname>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A malt liquor, of a dark color and moderately
bitter taste, possessing tonic and intoxicating qualities.</def>

<note><hand/ Porter is said to be so called as having been first
used chiefly by the London <xex>porters</xex>, and this
application of the word is supposed to be not older than
1750.</note>

<hw>Por"ter*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The work of a porter; the occupation of a carrier or of a
doorkeeper.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Money charged or paid for the carriage of
burdens or parcels by a porter.</def>

<hw>Por"ter*ess</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Portress</er>.</def>

<hw>Por"ter*house</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A house where porter
is sold.</def>

<hw>Port"fire`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A case of

mealed powder, -- used principally to ignite the priming in
proving guns, and as an incendiary material in shells.</def>

<hw>Port*fol"io</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<ex>portfolio</ex>.</as></def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Port"greve`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Port"grave`</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw><ety>[AS. <ets>portger\'c7fa</ets>;

<hw>Por"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., from L.
<ets>portio</ets>, akin to <ets>pars</ets>, <ets>partis</ets>, a
part. See <er>Part</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>That which is divided off or separated, as a part from a
whole; a separated part of anything.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A part considered by itself, though not actually
cut off or separated from the whole.</def>

<q>These are parts of his ways; but how little a
<qex>portion</qex> is heard of him!</q>
<qau>Job xxvi. 14.</qau>

<q><qex>Portions</qex> and parcels of the dreadful past.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A part assigned; allotment; share; fate.</def>

<q>The lord of that servant . . . will appoint him his
<qex>portion</qex> with the unbelievers.</q>
<qau>Luke xii. 46.</qau>

<q>Man's <qex>portion</qex> is to die and rise again.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The part of an estate given to a child or heir,
or descending to him by law, and distributed to him in the
settlement of the estate; an inheritance.</def>

<q>Give me the <qex>portion</qex> of goods that falleth to
me.</q>
<qau>Luke xv. 12.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A wife's fortune; a dowry.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Division; share; parcel; quantity; allotment;
dividend.</syn>  -- <usage><er>Portion</er>, <er>Part</er>.
<xex>Part</xex> is generic, having a simple reference to some
<xex>whole</xex>. <xex>Portion</xex> has the additional idea of
such a division as bears reference to an individual, or is
allotted to some object; <as>as, a <ex>portion</ex> of one's
time; a <ex>portion</ex> of Scripture</as>.</usage>

<hw>Por"tion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Portioned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Portioning</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
separate or divide into portions or shares; to parcel; to
distribute.</def>

<q>And <qex>portion</qex> to his tribes the wide domain.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To endow with a portion or inheritance.</def>

<q>Him <qex>portioned</qex> maids, apprenticed orphans,
blest.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<-- p. 1117 -->
