<hw>Por"tion*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<au>Shipley.</au>

portion.</def>

<hw>Por"tise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Portass</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Port"land ce*ment"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A cement having
the color of the Portland stone of England, made by calcining an
artificial mixture of carbonate of lime and clay, or sometimes
certain natural limestones or chalky clays. It contains a large
proportion of clay, and hardens under water.</def>

<hw>Port"land stone"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A yellowish-white
calcareous freestone from the Isle of Portland in England, much
used in building.</def>

<hw>Port"land vase`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A celebrated cinerary
urn or vase found in the tomb of the Emperor Alexander Severus.
It is owned by the Duke of Portland, and kept in the British
Museum.</def>

<hw>Port"last</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<def>The portoise. See <er>Portoise</er>.</def>

<hw>Port"li*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being portly; dignity of mien or of
personal appearance; stateliness.</def>

<q>Such pride is praise; such <qex>portliness</qex> is honor.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Bulkiness; corpulence.</def>

<hw>Port"ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From <er>Port</er>
demeanor.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Having a dignified port or
mien; of a noble appearance; imposing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Bulky; corpulent.</def> \'bdA <xex>portly</xex>
personage.\'b8

<au>Dickens.</au>

<hw>Port"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Portmen</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>An inhabitant or
burgess of a port, esp. of one of the Cinque Ports.</def>

<hw>Port*man"teau</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Portmanteaus</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>porte-manteau</ets>; <ets>porter</ets> to carry +

<hw>Por"toir</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF., fr.

<hw>Por"toise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perhaps fr.
OF. <ets>porteis</ets> portative, portable.]</ety>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>The gunwale of a ship.</def>

<cs><col>To lower the yards a-portoise</col>, <cd>to lower them
to the gunwale.</cd> -- <col>To ride a portoise</col>, <cd>to
ride an anchor with the lower yards and topmasts struck or
lowered, as in a gale of wind.</cd></cs>

<hw>Port"pane</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>portare</ets> to carry + <ets>panis</ets> bread; prob.
through French.]</ety> <def>A cloth for carrying bread, so as not

<hw>Por"trait</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,
originally p. p. of <ets>portraire</ets> to portray. See
<er>Portray</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The likeness of a
person, painted, drawn, or engraved; commonly, a representation
of the human face painted from real life.</def>

<q>In <qex>portraits</qex>, the grace, and, we may add, the
likeness, consists more in the general air than in the exact
similitude of every feature.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Reynolds.</qau>

<note><hand/ The meaning of the word is sometimes extended so as
to include a photographic likeness.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, any graphic or vivid delineation or
description of a person; <as>as, a <ex>portrait</ex> in
words</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Portrait bust</col>, <or/ <col>Portrait
statue</col></mcol>, <cd>a bust or statue representing the actual
features or person of an individual; -- in distinction from an
<xex>ideal bust<xex> or <xex>statue<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Por"trait</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To portray; to
draw.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Por"trait*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A portrait
painter.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Hamerton.</au>

<hw>Por"trai*ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>portraiture</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A portrait; a
likeness; a painted resemblance; hence, that which is copied from
some example or model.</def>

<q>For, by the image of my cause, I see
The <qex>portraiture</qex> of his.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Divinity maketh the love of ourselves the pattern; the love of
our neighbors but the <qex>portraiture</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pictures, collectively; painting.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The art or practice of making portraits.</def>

<au>Walpole.</au>

<hw>Por"trai*ture</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To represent by a
portrait, or as by a portrait; to portray.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shaftesbury.</au>

<hw>Por*tray"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>pourtray</asp>.]</altsp> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>portrayed</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Portraying</er>.] <ety>[OE. <ets>pourtraien</ets>,
OF. <ets>portraire</ets>, <ets>pourtraire</ets>, F.
<ets>portraire</ets>, fr. L. <ets>protrahere</ets>,
<ets>protractum</ets>, to draw or drag forth; <ets>pro</ets>
forward, forth + <ets>trahere</ets> to draw. See <er>Trace</er>,
<pos>v. t.</pos>, and cf. <er>Protract</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To paint or draw the likeness of; <as>as, to
<ex>portray</ex> a king on horseback</as>.</def>

<q>Take a tile, and lay it before thee, and <qex>portray</qex>
upon it the city, even Jerusalem.</q>
<qau>Ezek. iv. 1.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, figuratively, to describe in words.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To adorn with pictures.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Spear and helmets thronged, and shields
Various with boastful arguments <qex>potrayed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

process of portraying; description; delineation.</def>

<hw>Por*tray"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
portrays.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Port-roy"al*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Eccl.
Hist.)</fld> <def>One of the dwellers in the Cistercian convent
of Port Royal des Champs, near Paris, when it was the home of the
Jansenists in the 17th century, among them being Arnauld, Pascal,
and other famous scholars. Cf. <er>Jansenist</er>.</def>

<hw>Port"sale`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Port</ets> gate + <ets>sale</ets>.]</ety> <def>Public

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>\'d8Por`tu*la"ca</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
purslane.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of polypetalous
plants; also, any plant of the genus.</def>

<note><hand/ <spn>Portulaca oleracea</spn> is the common
purslane. <spn>P. grandiflora</spn> is a South American herb,
widely cultivated for its showy crimson, scarlet, yellow, or
white, ephemeral blossoms.</note>

<hw>Por`tu*la*ca"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to a natural order of
plants (<spn>Portulacace\'91</spn>), of which Portulaca is the
type, and which includes also the spring beauty
(<spn>Claytonia</spn>) and other genera.</def>

<hw>Pose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>gepose</ets>; of uncertain origin; cf. W. <ets>pas</ets> a
cough, Skr. <ets>k\'bes</ets> to cough, and E.
<ets>wheeze</ets>.]</ety> <def>A cold in the head; catarrh.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pose</ets>, fr. <ets>poser</ets>. See <er>Pose</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety> <def>The attitude or position of a person; the
position of the body or of any member of the body; especially, a
position formally assumed for the sake of effect; an artificial
position; <as>as, the <ex>pose</ex> of an actor; the
<ex>pose</ex> of an artist's model or of a statue.</as></def>

<hw>Pose</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Posed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Posing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>poser</ets> to place,
to put, L. <ets>pausare</ets> to pause, in LL. also, to place,
put, fr. L. <ets>pausa</ets> a pause, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to make to
cease, prob. akin to E. <ets>few</ets>. In compounds, this word
appears corresponding to L. <ets>ponere</ets> to put, place, the
substitution in French having been probably due to confusion of
this word with L. <ets>positio</ets> position, fr.
<ets>ponere</ets>. See <er>Few</er>, and cf. <er>Appose</er>,
<er>Dispose</er>, <er>Oppose</er>, <er>Pause</er>,
<er>Repose</er>, <er>Position</er>.]</ety> <def>To place in an
attitude or fixed position, for the sake of effect; to arrange
the posture and drapery of (a person) in a studied manner;
<as>as, to <ex>pose</ex> a model for a picture; to <ex>pose</ex>
a sitter for a portrait.</as></def>

<hw>Pose</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To assume and maintain a
studied attitude, with studied arrangement of drapery; to strike
an attitude; to attitudinize; figuratively, to assume or affect a
certain character; <as>as, she <ex>poses</ex> as a
prude</as>.</def>

<q>He . . . <qex>posed</qex> before her as a hero.</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<hw>Pose</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Shortened from
<ets>appose</ets>, for <ets>oppose</ets>. See 2d <er>Appose</er>,
<er>Oppose</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To interrogate; to
question.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdShe . . .
<xex>posed</xex> him and sifted him.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To question with a view to puzzling; to
embarrass by questioning or scrutiny; to bring to a stand.</def>

<q>A question wherewith a learned Pharisee thought to
<qex>pose</qex> and puzzle him.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<hw>Posed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Firm; determined;
fixed.</def> \'bdA most <xex>posed</xex> . . . and grave
behavior.\'b8 <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Urquhart.</au>

<hw>Pos"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or that
which, puzzles; a difficult or inexplicable question or
fact.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Po"sied</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Inscribed with
a posy.</def>

<q>In <qex>poised</qex> lockets bribe the fair.</q>
<qau>Gay.</qau>

<hw>Pos"ing*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>So as to
pose or puzzle.</def>

<hw>Pos"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Posited</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Positing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>ponere</ets>, <ets>positum</ets>, to place. See
<er>Position</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To dispose or set
firmly or fixedly; to place or dispose in relation to other
objects.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>To assume as real or
conceded; <as>as, to <ex>posit</ex> a principle</as>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<hw>Po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>position</ets>, L. <ets>positio</ets>, fr.
<ets>ponere</ets>, <ets>positum</ets>, to put, place; prob. for
<ets>posino</ets>, fr. an old preposition used only in comp.
(akin to Gr. <?/) + <ets>sinere</ets> to leave, let, permit,
place. See <er>Site</er>, and cf. <er>Composite</er>,
<er>Compound</er>, <pos>v.<pos>, <er>Depone</er>,
<er>Deposit</er>, <er>Expound</er>, <er>Impostor</er>,
<er>Opposite</er>, <er>Propound</er>, <er>Pose</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>, <er>Posit</er>, <er>Post</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The state of being posited, or placed; the
manner in which anything is placed; attitude; condition; <as>as,
a firm, an inclined, or an upright <ex>position</ex></as>.</def>

<q>We have different prospects of the same thing, according to
our different <qex>positions</qex> to it.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The spot where a person or thing is placed or
takes a place; site; place; station; situation; <as>as, the
<ex>position</ex> of man in creation; the fleet changed its
<ex>position</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: The ground which any one takes in an
argument or controversy; the point of view from which any one
proceeds to a discussion; also, a principle laid down as the
basis of reasoning; a proposition; a thesis; <as>as, to define
one's <ex>position</ex>; to appear in a false
<ex>position</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Let not the proof of any <qex>position</qex> depend on the
<qex>positions</qex> that follow, but always on those which go
before.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Relative place or standing; social or official
rank; <as>as, a person of <ex>position</ex>; hence, office; post;
<as>as, to lose one's <ex>position</ex></as>.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Arith.)</fld> <def>A method of solving a
problem by one or two suppositions; -- called also the
<altname>rule of trial and error</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Angle of position</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>the
angle which any line (as that joining two stars) makes with
another fixed line, specifically with a circle of
declination.</cd> -- <col>Double position</col>
<fld>(Arith.)</fld>, <cd>the method of solving problems by
proceeding with each of two assumed numbers, according to the
conditions of the problem, and by comparing the difference of the
results with those of the numbers, deducing the correction to be
applied to one of them to obtain the true result.</cd> --
<col>Guns of position</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>heavy
fieldpieces, not designed for quick movements.</cd> --
<col>Position finder</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a range finder.
See under <er>Range</er>.</cd> -- <col>Position micrometer</col>,
<cd>a micrometer applied to the tube of an astronomical telescope
for measuring angles of position in the field of view.</cd> --
<col>Single position</col> <fld>(Arith.)</fld>, <cd>the method of
solving problems, in which the result obtained by operating with
an assumed number is to the true result as the number assumed is
to the number required.</cd> -- <col>Strategic position</col>
<fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a position taken up by an army or a large
detachment of troops for the purpose of checking or observing an
opposing force.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Situation; station; place; condition; attitude;
posture; proposition; assertion; thesis.</syn>

<hw>Po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
indicate the position of; to place.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Encyc. Brit.</au>

<hw>Po*si"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to position.</def>

<q>Ascribing unto plants <qex>positional</qex> operations.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<hw>Pos"i*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>positif</ets>, F. <ets>positif</ets>, L.
<ets>positivus</ets>. See <er>Position</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having a real position, existence, or energy; existing in
fact; real; actual; -- opposed to <xex>negative</xex>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Positive</xex> good.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Derived from an object by itself; not dependent
on changing circumstances or relations; absolute; -- opposed to
<xex>relative</xex>; <as>as, the idea of beauty is not
<ex>positive</ex>, but depends on the different tastes
individuals</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Definitely laid down; explicitly stated; clearly
expressed; -- opposed to <xex>implied</xex>; <as>as, a
<ex>positive</ex> declaration or promise</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Positive</qex> words, that he would not bear arms against
King Edward's son.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Hence: Not admitting of any doubt, condition,
qualification, or discretion; not dependent on circumstances or
probabilities; not speculative; compelling assent or obedience;
peremptory; indisputable; decisive; <as>as, <ex>positive</ex>
instructions; <ex>positive</ex> truth; <ex>positive</ex>
proof.</as></def> \'bd'T is <xex>positive</xex> 'gainst all
exceptions.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Prescribed by express enactment or institution;
settled by arbitrary appointment; said of laws.</def>

<q>In laws, that which is natural bindeth universally; that which
is <qex>positive</qex>, not so.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Fully assured; confident; certain; sometimes,
overconfident; dogmatic; overbearing; -- said of persons.</def>

<q>Some <qex>positive</qex>, persisting fops we know,
That, if once wrong, will needs be always.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Having the power of direct action or influence;
<as>as, a <ex>positive</ex> voice in legislation</as>.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Photog.)</fld> <def>Corresponding with the
original in respect to the position of lights and shades, instead
of having the lights and shades reversed; <as>as, a
<ex>positive</ex> picture</as>.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Electro-positive.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Hence, basic;
metallic; not acid; -- opposed to <xex>negative</xex>, and said
of metals, bases, and basic radicals.</def>

<cs><col>Positive crystals</col> <fld>(Opt.)</fld>, <cd>a doubly
refracting crystal in which the index of refraction for the
extraordinary ray is greater than for the ordinary ray, and the
former is refracted nearer to the axis than the latter, as quartz
and ice; -- opposed to <xex>negative crystal<xex>, or one in
which this characteristic is reversed, as Iceland spar,
tourmaline, etc.</cd> -- <col>Positive degree</col>
<fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>that state of an adjective or adverb
which denotes simple quality, without comparison or relation to
increase or diminution; as, <xex>wise<xex>, <xex>noble<xex>.</cd>
-- <col>Positive electricity</col> <fld>(Elec)</fld>, <cd>the
kind of electricity which is developed when glass is rubbed with
silk, or which appears at that pole of a voltaic battery attached
to the plate that is not attacked by the exciting liquid; --
formerly called <altname>vitreous electricity</altname>; --
opposed to <ant>negative electricity</ant>.</cd> -- <col>Positive
eyepiece</col>. <cd>See under <er>Eyepiece</er>.</cd> --
<col>Positive law</col>. <cd>See <cref>Municipal law</cref>,
under <er>Law</er>.</cd> -- <col>Positive motion</col>
<fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>motion which is derived from a driver
through unyielding intermediate pieces, or by direct contact, and
not through elastic connections, nor by means of friction,
gravity, etc.; definite motion.</cd> -- <col>Positive
philosophy</col>. <cd>See <er>Positivism</er>.</cd> --
<col>Positive pole</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <cd>The
pole of a battery or pile which yields positive or vitreous
electricity; -- opposed to <ant>negative pole</ant>.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Magnetism)</fld> <cd>The north pole</cd>.
<mark>[R.]</mark> -- <col>Positive quantity</col>
<fld>(Alg.)</fld>, <cd>an affirmative quantity, or one affected
by the sign <xex>plus<xex> [+].</cd> -- <col>Positive
rotation</col> <fld>(Mech.)</fld>, <cd>left-handed rotation.</cd>
-- <col>Positive sign</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>the sign [+]
denoting <xex>plus<xex>, or <xex>more<xex>, or
addition.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pos"i*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
capable of being affirmed; reality.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which settles by absolute
appointment.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The positive degree or
form.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Photog.)</fld> <def>A picture in which the
lights and shades correspond in position with those of the
original, instead of being reversed, as in a
<xex>negative</xex>.</def>

<au>R. Hunt.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>The positive plate of a
voltaic or electrolytic cell.</def>

<hw>Pos"i*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a positive
manner; absolutely; really; expressly; with certainty;
indubitably; peremptorily; dogmatically; -- opposed to
<xex>negatively</xex>.</def>

<q>Good and evil which is removed may be esteemed good or evil
comparatively, and <qex>positively</qex> simply.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord,
Before I <qex>positively</qex> speak herein.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I would ask . . . whether . . . the divine law does not
<qex>positively</qex> require humility and meekness.</q>
<qau>Sprat.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Positively charged</col> <or/
<col>electrified</col></mcol> <fld>(Elec.)</fld>, <cd>having a
charge of positive electricity; -- opposed to <ant>negatively
electrified</ant>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pos"i*tive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state
of being positive; reality; actualness; certainty; confidence;
peremptoriness; dogmatism. See <er>Positive</er>,
<pos>a.</pos></def>

<q><qex>Positiveness</qex>, pedantry, and ill manners.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<q>The <qex>positiveness</qex> of sins of commission lies both in
the habitude of the will and in the executed act too; the
<qex>positiveness</qex> of sins of omission is in the habitude of
the will only.</q>
<qau>Norris.</qau>

<hw>Pos"i*tiv*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A system
of philosophy originated by M. Auguste Comte, which deals only
with <xex>positives</xex>. It excludes from philosophy everything
but the natural phenomena or properties of knowable things,
together with their invariable relations of coexistence and
succession, as occurring in time and space. Such relations are
denominated <xex>laws</xex>, which are to be discovered by
observation, experiment, and comparison. This philosophy holds
all inquiry into <xex>causes</xex>, both efficient and final, to
be useless and unprofitable.</def>

<hw>Pos"i*tiv*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A believer in
positivism.</def> -- <def2><pos>a.</pos> <def>Relating to
positivism.</def></def2>

<hw>Pos`i*tiv"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Positiveness.</def>

<au>J. Morley.</au>

<hw>Pos"i*ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Posture</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pos"net</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>po\'87onet</ets>, dim. of <ets>po\'87on</ets> a pot, a
vessel.]</ety> <def>A little basin; a porringer; a skillet.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pos`o*log"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pos`o*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>posologique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Pertaining to
posology.</def>

<hw>Po*sol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
how much + <ets>-logy</ets>: cf. F. <ets>posologie</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The science or doctrine of doses;
dosology.</def>

<-- p. 1118 -->

<hw>Pos"po*lite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pol.
<ets>pospolite ruszenie</ets> a general summons to arms, an
arriere-ban; <ets>pospolity</ets> general + <ets>ruszenie</ets> a
stirring.]</ety> <def>A kind of militia in Poland, consisting of
the gentry, which, in case of invasion, was summoned to the
defense of the country.</def>

<hw>Poss</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Push</er>.]</ety> <def>To push; to dash; to throw.</def>
<mark>[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<q>A cat . . . <qex>possed</qex> them [the rats] about.</q>
<qau>Piers Plowman.</qau>

<hw>Pos"se</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See <er>Posse
comitatus</er>.</def>

<cs><col>In posse</col>. <cd>See <er>In posse</er> in the
Vocabulary.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pos"se com`i*ta"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L.
<ets>posse</ets> to be able, to have power + LL.
<ets>comitatus</ets> a county, from <ets>comes</ets>,
<ets>comitis</ets>, a count. See <er>County</er>, and
<er>Power</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The power of the county, or the
citizens who may be summoned by the sheriff to assist the
authorities in suppressing a riot, or executing any legal precept
which is forcibly opposed.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A collection of people; a throng; a
rabble.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<note><hand/ The word <xex>comitatus</xex> is often omitted, and
<xex>posse</xex> alone used. \'bdA whole <xex>posse</xex> of
enthusiasts.\'b8</note>

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<q>As if the passion that rules were the sheriff of the place,
and came off with all the <qex>posse</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>Pos*sess"</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Possessed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Possessing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>possessus</ets>,
p. p. of <ets>possidere</ets> to have, possess, from an
inseparable prep. (cf. <er>Position</er>) + <ets>sedere</ets> to
sit. See <er>Sit</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To occupy in
person; to hold or actually have in one's own keeping; to have
and to hold.</def>

<q>Houses and fields and vineyards shall be <qex>possessed</qex>
again in this land.</q>
<qau>Jer. xxxii. 15.</qau>

<q>Yet beauty, though injurious, hath strange power,
After offense returning, to regain
Love once <qex>possessed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have the legal title to; to have a just right
to; to be master of; to own; to have; <as>as, to <ex>possess</ex>
property, an estate, a book</as>.</def>

<q>I am yours, and all that I <qex>possess</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To obtain occupation or possession of; to
accomplish; to gain; to seize.</def>

<q>How . . . to <qex>possess</qex> the purpose they desired.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To enter into and influence; to control the will
of; to fill; to affect; -- said especially of evil spirits,
passions, etc.</def> \'bdWeakness <xex>possesseth</xex> me.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Those which were <qex>possessed</qex> with devils.</q>
<qau>Matt. iv. 24.</qau>

<q>For ten inspired, ten thousand are <qex>possessed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Roscommon.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To put in possession; to make the owner or
holder of property, power, knowledge, etc.; to acquaint; to
inform; -- followed by <xex>of</xex> or <xex>with</xex> before
the thing possessed, and now commonly used reflexively.</def>

<q>I have <qex>possessed</qex> your grace of what I purpose.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Record a gift . . . of all he dies <qex>possessed</qex>
Unto his son.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>We <qex>possessed</qex> our selves of the kingdom of
Naples.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>To <qex>possess</qex> our minds with an habitual good
intention.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To have; hold; occupy; control; own.</syn> <usage>
-- <er>Possess</er>, <er>Have</er>. <xex>Have</xex> is the more
general word. To <xex>possess</xex> denotes to <xex>have as a
property</xex>. It usually implies more permanence or
definiteness of control or ownership than is involved in
<xex>having</xex>. A man does not <xex>possess</xex> his wife and
children: they are (so to speak) part of himself. For the same
reason, we <xex>have</xex> the faculties of reason,
understanding, will, sound judgment, etc.: they are exercises of
the mind, not <xex>possessions</xex>.</usage>

<hw>Pos*ses"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>possession</ets>, L. <ets>possessio</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of possessing, or holding as
one's own.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The having, holding, or
detention of property in one's power or command; actual seizin or
occupancy; ownership, whether rightful or wrongful.</def>

<note><hand/ Possession may be either actual or constructive;
actual, when a party has the immediate occupancy; constructive,
when he has only the right to such occupancy.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The thing possessed; that which any one
occupies, owns, or controls; in the plural, property in the
aggregate; wealth; dominion; <as>as, foreign
<ex>possessions</ex></as>.</def>

<q>When the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful,
for he had great <qex>possessions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Matt. xix. 22.</qau>

<q>Ananias, with Sapphira his wife, sold a
<qex>possession</qex>.</q>
<qau>Acts v. 1.</qau>

<q>The house of Jacob shall possess their
<qex>possessions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ob. 17.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The state of being possessed or controlled, as
by an evil spirit, or violent passions; madness; frenzy; <as>as,
demoniacal <ex>possession</ex></as>.</def>

<q>How long hath this <qex>possession</qex> held the man?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To give possession</col>, <cd>to put in another's power
or occupancy.</cd> -- <col>To put in possession</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To invest with ownership or occupancy; to
provide or furnish with; as, <xex>to put<xex> one <xex>in
possession<xex> of facts or information</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>To place one in charge of property recovered
in ejectment or writ of entry.</cd> -- <col>To take
possession</col>, <cd>to enter upon, or to bring within one's
power or occupancy.</cd> -- <col>Writ of possession</col>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a precept directing a sheriff to put a
person in peaceable possession of property recovered in ejectment
or writ of entry.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pos*ses"sion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To invest with
property.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pos*ses"sion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to possession; arising from possession.</def>

<hw>Pos*ses"sion*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A possessor; a property holder.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Possessioners</xex> of riches.\'b8

<au>E. Hall.</au>

<q>Having been of old freemen and <qex>possessioners</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An invidious name for a member of any religious
community endowed with property in lands, buildings, etc., as
contrasted with mendicant friars.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Wyclif.</au>

<hw>Pos`ses*si"val</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to the possessive case; <as>as, a <ex>possessival</ex>
termination</as>.</def>

<au>Earle.</au>

<hw>Pos*sess"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>possessivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>possessif</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to possession; having or indicating
possession.</def>

<cs><col>Possessive case</col> <fld>(Eng. Gram.)</fld>, <cd>the
genitive case; the case of nouns and pronouns which expresses
ownership, origin, or some possessive relation of one thing to
another; as, <xex>Homer's<xex> admirers; the <xex>pear's<xex>
flavor; the <xex>dog's<xex> faithfulness.</cd> -- <col>Possessive
pronoun</col>, <cd>a pronoun denoting ownership; as,
<xex>his<xex> name; <xex>her<xex> home; <xex>my<xex>
book.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pos*sess"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The possessive case.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>A possessive pronoun, or a
word in the possessive case.</def>

<hw>Pos*sess"ive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a possessive
manner.</def>

<hw>Pos*sess"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf. F.
<ets>possesseur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who possesses; one who
occupies, holds, owns, or controls; one who has actual
participation or enjoyment, generally of that which is desirable;
a proprietor.</def> \'bd<xex>Possessors</xex> of eternal
glory.\'b8

<au>Law.</au>

<q>As if he had been <qex>possessor</qex> of the whole world.</q>
<qau>Sharp.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Owner; proprietor; master; holder; occupant.</syn>

<hw>Pos*sess"o*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>possessorius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>possessoire</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to possession, either as a fact or a right;
of the nature of possession; <as>as, a <ex>possessory</ex>
interest; a <ex>possessory</ex> lord.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Possessory action</col> <or/
<col>suit</col></mcol> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>an action to regain
or obtain possession of something. See under
<er>Petitory</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pos"set</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[W.
<ets>posel</ets> curdled milk, posset.]</ety> <def>A beverage
composed of hot milk curdled by some strong infusion, as by wine,
etc., -- much in favor formerly.</def> \'bdI have drugged their
<xex>posset</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pos"set</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Posseted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Posseting</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To curdle; to
turn, as milk; to coagulate; <as>as, to <ex>posset</ex> the
blood</as>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To treat with possets; to pamper.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdShe was cosseted and
<xex>posseted</xex>.\'b8

<au>O. W. Holmes.</au>

<hw>Pos`si*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Possibilities</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>possibilit\'82</ets>, L. <ets>possibilitas</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being possible; the
power of happening, being, or existing.</def> \'bdAll
<xex>possibility</xex> of error.\'b8 <au>Hooker</au>. \'bdLatent
<xex>possibilities</xex> of excellence.\'b8

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is possible; a contingency; a thing
or event that may not happen; a contingent interest, as in real
or personal estate.</def>

<au>South. Burrill.</au>

<hw>Pos"si*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>possibilis</ets>, fr. <ets>posse</ets> to be able, to have
power; <ets>potis</ets> able, capable + <ets>esse</ets> to be.
See <er>Potent</er>, <er>Am</er>, and cf. <er>Host</er> a
landlord.]</ety> <def>Capable of existing or occurring, or of
being conceived or thought of; able to happen; capable of being
done; not contrary to the nature of things; -- sometimes used to
express extreme improbability; barely able to be, or to come to
pass; <as>as, possibly he is honest, as it is <ex>possible</ex>
that Judas meant no wrong</as>.</def>

<q>With God all things are <qex>possible</qex>.</q>
<qau>Matt. xix. 26.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Practicable; likely. See <er>Practicable</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pos"si*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a possible manner;
by possible means; especially, by extreme, remote, or improbable
intervention, change, or exercise of power; by a chance; perhaps;
<as>as, <ex>possibly</ex> he may recover</as>.</def>

<q>Can we . . . <qex>possibly</qex> his love desert?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>When <qex>possibly</qex> I can, I will return.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pos"sum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Shortened from
<ets>opossum</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An
opossum.</def> <mark>[Colloq. U. S.]</mark>

<cs><mcol><col>To play possum</col>, <col>To act
possum</col></mcol>, <cd>to feign ignorance, indifference or
inattention, with the intent to deceive; to dissemble; -- in
allusion to the habit of the opossum, which feigns death when
attacked or alarmed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Post-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L. <ets>post</ets> behind,
after; cf. Skr. <ets>pa\'87c\'be</ets>behind, afterwards.]</ety>
<def>A prefix signifying <xex>behind</xex>, <xex>back</xex>,
<xex>after</xex>; <as>as, <ex>post</ex>commissure,
<ex>post</ex>dot, <ex>post</ex>script</as>.</def>

<hw>Post</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>aposter</ets> to place
in a post or position, generally for a bad purpose.]</ety>
<def>Hired to do what is wrong; suborned.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir E. Sandys.</au>

<hw>Post</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS., fr. L. <ets>postis</ets>,
akin to <ets>ponere</ets>, <ets>positum</ets>, to place. See
<er>Position</er>, and cf. 4th <er>Post</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A piece of timber, metal, or other solid substance, fixed,
or to be fixed, firmly in an upright position, especially when
intended as a stay or support to something else; a pillar;
<as>as, a hitching <ex>post</ex>; a fence <ex>post</ex>; the
<ex>posts</ex> of a house.</as></def>

<q>They shall take of the blood, and strike it on the two side
<qex>posts</qex> and on the upper doorpost of the houses.</q>
<qau>Ex. xii. 7.</qau>

<q>Then by main force pulled up, and on his shoulders bore,
The gates of Azza, <qex>post</qex> and massy bar.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Unto his order he was a noble <qex>post</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Post</xex>, in the sense of an upright timber
or strut, is used in composition, in such words as
king-<xex>post</xex>, queen-<xex>post</xex>,
crown-<xex>post</xex>, gate<xex>post</xex>, etc.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The doorpost of a victualer's shop or inn, on
which were chalked the scores of customers; hence, a score; a
debt.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>When God sends coin
I will discharge your <qex>post</qex>.</q>
<qau>S. Rowlands.</qau>

<cs><col>From pillar to post</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Pillar</er>.</cd> -- <col>Knight of the post</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Knight</er>.</cd> -- <col>Post hanger</col>
<fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a bearing for a revolving shaft, adapted
to be fastened to a post.</cd> -- <col>Post hole</col>, <cd>a
hole in the ground to set the foot of a post in.</cd> --
<col>Post mill</col>, <cd>a form of windmill so constructed that
the whole fabric rests on a vertical axis firmly fastened to the
ground, and capable of being turned as the direction of the wind
varies.</cd> -- <col>Post and stall</col> <fld>(Coal
Mining)</fld>, <cd>a mode of working in which pillars of coal are
left to support the roof of the mine.</cd></cs>

<hw>Post</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>poste</ets>, LL.
<ets>posta</ets> station, post (where horses were kept),
properly, a fixed or set place, fem. fr. L. <ets>positus</ets>
placed, p. p. of <ets>ponere</ets>. See <er>Position</er>, and
cf. <er>Post</er> a pillar.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The place at
which anything is stopped, placed, or fixed; a station.</def>
Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A station, or one of a series of
stations, established for the refreshment and accommodation of
travelers on some recognized route; <as>as, a stage or railway
<ex>post</ex></as></def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A military station;
the place at which a soldier or a body of troops is stationed;
also, the troops at such a station</def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The
piece of ground to which a sentinel's walk is limited.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A messenger who goes from station; an express;
especially, one who is employed by the government to carry
letters and parcels regularly from one place to another; a letter
carrier; a postman.</def>

<q>In certain places there be always fresh <qex>posts</qex>, to
carry that further which is brought unto them by the other.</q>
<qau>Abp. Abbot.</qau>

<q>I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,
Receiving them from such a worthless <qex>post</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An established conveyance for letters from one
place or station to another; especially, the governmental system
in any country for carrying and distributing letters and parcels;
the post office; the mail; hence, the carriage by which the mail
is transported.</def>

<q>I send you the fair copy of the poem on dullness, which I
should not care to hazard by the common <qex>post</qex>.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Haste or speed, like that of a messenger or mail
carrier.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdIn <xex>post</xex> he
came.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>One who has charge of a station, especially of a
postal station.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He held office of postmaster, or, as it was then called,
<qex>post</qex>, for several years.</q>
<qau>Palfrey.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A station, office, or position of service,
trust, or emolument; <as>as, the <ex>post</ex> of duty; the
<ex>post</ex> of danger.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>post</qex> of honor is a private station.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A size of printing and writing paper. See the
Table under <er>Paper</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Post and pair</col>, <cd>an old game at cards, in which
each player a hand of three cards. <au>B. Jonson</au>.</cd> --
<col>Post bag</col>, <cd>a mail bag.</cd> -- <col>Post
bill</col>, <cd>a bill of letters mailed by a postmaster.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Post chaise</col>, or <col>Post coach</col></mcol>,
<cd>a carriage usually with four wheels, for the conveyance of
travelers who travel post.</cd> <col>Post day</col>, <cd>a day on
which the mall arrives or departs.</cd> -- <col>Post
hackney</col>, <cd>a hired post horse. <au>Sir H.
Wotton</au>.</cd> -- <col>Post horn</col>, <cd>a horn, or
trumpet, carried and blown by a carrier of the public mail, or by
a coachman.</cd> -- <col>Post horse</col>, <cd>a horse stationed,
intended, or used for the post.</cd> -- <col>Post hour</col>,
<cd>hour for posting letters. <au>Dickens</au>.</cd> -- <col>Post
office</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>An office under governmental
superintendence, where letters, papers, and other mailable
matter, are received and distributed; a place appointed for
attending to all business connected with the mail</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The governmental system for forwarding mail
matter.</cd> -- <col>Postoffice order</col>. <cd>See <cref>Money
order</cref>, under <er>Money</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Post
road</col>, <or/ <col>Post route</col></mcol>, <cd>a road or way
over which the mail is carried.</cd> -- <col>Post town</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A town in which post horses are kept</cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A town in which a post office is established by
law.</cd> -- <col>To ride post</col>, <cd>to ride, as a carrier
of dispatches, from place to place; hence, to ride rapidly, with
as little delay as possible.</cd> -- <col>To travel post</col>,
<cd>to travel, as a post does, by relays of horses, or by keeping
one carriage to which fresh horses are attached at each stopping
place.</cd></cs>

<hw>Post</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Posted</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Posting</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
attach to a post, a wall, or other usual place of affixing public
notices; to placard; <as>as, to <ex>post</ex> a notice; to
<ex>post</ex> playbills.</as></def>

<note><hand/ Formerly, a large post was erected before the
sheriff's office, or in some public place, upon which legal
notices were displayed. This way of advertisement has not
entirely gone of use.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hold up to public blame or reproach; to
advertise opprobriously; to denounce by public proclamation;
<as>as, to <ex>post</ex> one for cowardice</as>.</def>

<q>On pain of being <qex>posted</qex> to your sorrow
Fail not, at four, to meet me.</q>
<qau>Granville.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To enter (a name) on a list, as for service,
promotion, or the like.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To assign to a station; to set; to place;
<as>as, to <ex>post</ex> a sentinel</as>.</def> \'bdIt might be
to obtain a ship for a lieutenant, . . . or to get him
<xex>posted</xex>.\'b8

<au>De Quincey.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Bookkeeping)</fld> <def>To carry, as an
account, from the journal to the ledger; <as>as, to <ex>post</ex>
an account</as>; to transfer, as accounts, to the ledger.</def>

<q>You have not <qex>posted</qex> your books these ten years.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To place in the care of the post; to mail;
<as>as, to <ex>post</ex> a letter</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To inform; to give the news to; to make (one)
acquainted with the details of a subject; -- often with
<xex>up</xex>.</def>

<q>Thoroughly <qex>posted</qex> up in the politics and literature
of the day.</q>
<qau>Lond. Sat. Rev.</qau>

<cs><col>To post off</col>, <cd>to put off; to delay.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdWhy did I, venturously, <xex>post
off<xex> so great a business?\'b8 <au>Baxter</au>.</cd> --
<col>To post over</col>, <cd>to hurry over. <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
<au>Fuller</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Post</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF. <ets>poster</ets>.
See 4th <er>Post</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To travel with
post horses; figuratively, to travel in haste.</def>
\'bd<xex>Post</xex> seedily to my lord your husband.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>And <qex>post</qex> o'er land and ocean without rest.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Man.)</fld> <def>To rise and sink in the
saddle, in accordance with the motion of the horse, esp. in
trotting.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Post</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With post horses; hence, in
haste; <as>as, to travel <ex>post</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Post`-ab*do"men</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>post-</ets> + <ets>abdomen</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>That part of a crustacean behind the
cephalothorax; -- more commonly called
<altname>abdomen</altname>.</def>

<hw>Post"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable of
being carried by, or as by, post.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>W. Montagu.</au>

<hw>Post"act`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An act done
afterward.</def>

<hw>Post"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The price
established by law to be paid for the conveyance of a letter or
other mailable matter by a public post.</def>

<cs><col>Postage stamp</col>, <cd>a government stamp required to
be put upon articles sent by mail in payment of the postage, esp.
an adhesive stamp issued and sold for that purpose.</cd></cs>

<hw>Post"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>postal</ets>.]</ety> <def>Belonging to the post office or
mail service; <as>as, <ex>postal</ex> arrangements;
<ex>postal</ex> authorities.</as></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Postal card</col>, <or/ <col>Post
card</col></mcol>, <cd>a card sold by the government for
transmission through the mails, at a lower rate of postage than a
sealed letter. The message is written on one side of the card,
and the direction on the other.</cd> -- <col>Postal money
order</col>. <cd>See <cref>Money order</cref>, under
<er>Money</er>.</cd> -- <col>Postal note</col>, <cd>an order
payable to bearer, for a sum of money (in the United States less
than five dollars under existing law), issued from one post
office and payable at another specified office.</cd> --
<col>Postal Union</col>, <cd>a union for postal purposes entered
into by the most important powers, or governments, which have
agreed to transport mail matter through their several territories
at a stipulated rate.</cd></cs>

<hw>Post*a"nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>post-</ets> + <ets>anal</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>Situated behind, or posterior to, the anus.</def>

<hw>Post*ax"i*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>post-</ets> + <ets>axial</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>Situated behind any transverse axis in the body of an
animal; caudal; posterior; especially, behind, or on the caudal
or posterior (that is, ulnar or fibular) side of, the axis of a
vertebrate limb.</def>

<-- p. 1119 -->

<hw>Post"boy`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who rides post horses; a position; a courier.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A boy who carries letters from the post.</def>

<hw>Post"-cap`tain</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
captain of a war vessel whose name appeared, or was
\'bdposted,\'b8 in the seniority list of the British navy, as
distinguished from a commander whose name was not so posted. The
term was also used in the United States navy; but no such
commission as <xex>post-captain</xex> was ever recognized in
either service, and the term has fallen into disuse.</def>

<hw>\'d8Post"ca`va</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Postcav\'91</plw> </plu>. <ety>[NL. See <er>Post-</er>, and
<er>Cave</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The

<hw>Post"date`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Postdated</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Postdating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>post-</ets> + <ets>date</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
date after the real time; <as>as, to <ex>postdate</ex> a
contract, that is, to date it later than the time when it was in
fact made</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To affix a date to after the event.</def>

<hw>Post"date`</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Made or done after the
date assigned.</def>

<q>Of these [predictions] some were <qex>postdate</qex>;
cunningly made after the thing came to pass.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Post"date`</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A date put to a bill of
exchange or other paper, later than that when it was actually
made.</def>

<hw>Post*te"ri*or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>posterior</ets>, compar. of <ets>posterus</ets> coming
after, from <ets>post</ets> after. See <er>Post-</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Later in time; hence, later in the order of
proceeding or moving; coming after; -- opposed to
<xex>prior</xex>.</def>

<q>Hesiod was <qex>posterior</qex> to Homer.</q>
<qau>Broome.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Situated behind; hinder; -- opposed to
<xex>anterior</xex>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>At or toward the caudal
extremity; caudal; -- in human anatomy often used for
<xex>dorsal</xex>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>On the side next the axis of
inflorescence; -- said of an axillary flower.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Pos*te`ri*or"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.

later or subsequent; <as>as, <ex>posteriority</ex> of time, or of
an event</as>; -- opposed to <contr>priority</contr>.</def>

<hw>Pos*te"ri*or*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Subsequently in time; also, behind in position.</def>

<hw>Pos*te"ri*ors</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>The
hinder parts, as of an animal's body.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Pos*ter"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>posteritas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>post\'82rit\'82</ets>. See
<er>Posterior</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The race that
proceeds from a progenitor; offspring to the furthest generation;
the aggregate number of persons who are descended from an
ancestor of a generation; descendants; -- contrasted with
<xex>ancestry</xex>; <as>as, the <ex>posterity</ex> of
Abraham</as>.</def>

<q>If [the crown] should not stand in thy
<qex>posterity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Succeeding generations; future times.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Their names shall be transmitted to <qex>posterity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Their names shall be transmitted to <qex>posterity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Smalridge.</qau>

<hw>Post"hu*mous</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>posthumus</ets>, <ets>postumus</ets>, properly, last; hence,

<ets>posterior</ets>. See <er>Posterior</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Born after the death of the father, or taken from the dead

<ex>posthumous</ex> reputation</as>.</def>

<hw>Pos"til</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

homily or commentary on a passage of Scripture; <as>as, the first
<ex>postils</ex> were composed by order of
Charlemagne</as>.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>\'d8Post`li*min"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Post*lim"i*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>The return to his own

<au>Burrill.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Internat. Law)</fld> <def>The right by virtue
of which persons and things taken by an enemy in war are restored
to their former state when coming again under the power of the

<au>Kent.</au>

<hw>Post`me*rid"i*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig., belonging to the after portion of life;

<hw>\'d8Post-mor"tem</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.,
after death.]</ety> <def>After death; <as>as,
<ex>post-mortem</ex> rigidity</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Post-mortem examination</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>an
examination of the body made after the death of the patient; an
autopsy.</cd></cs><-- also, simply post-mortem.; (Fig.) any
inquiry after the failure of an enterprise to determine the casue
of failure -->

<hw>Post*pone"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Postponed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Postponing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>postponere</ets>,
<ets>postpositum</ets>; <ets>post</ets> after + <ets>ponere</ets>
to place, put. See <er>Post-</er>, and <er>Position</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To defer to a future or later time; to put off;
also, to cause to be deferred or put off; to delay; to adjourn;
<as>as, to <ex>postpone</ex> the consideration of a bill to the
following day, or indefinitely</as>.</def>

<q>His praise <qex>postponed</qex>, and never to be paid.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To place after, behind, or below something, in
respect to precedence, preference, value, or importance.</def>

<q>All other considerations should give way and be
<qex>postponed</qex> to this.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To adjourn; defer; delay; procrastinate.</syn>

<hw>Post*pone"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of postponing; a deferring, or putting off, to a future time; a
temporary delay.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<ets>postponens</ets>, p. pr.]</ety> <def>The act of postponing,

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Pos"tu*lant</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,
fr. L. <ets>postulans</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>postulare</ets>. See
<er>Postulate</er>.]</ety> <def>One who makes a request or
demand; hence, a candidate.</def>

<hw>Pos"tu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>postulatum</ets> a demand, request, prop. p. p. of
<ets>postulare</ets> to demand, prob. a dim. of
<ets>poscere</ets> to demand, prob. for <ets>porcscere</ets>;
akin to G. <ets>forschen</ets> to search, investigate, Skr.
<ets>prach</ets> to ask, and L. <ets>precari</ets> to pray: cf.
F. <ets>postulat</ets>. See <er>Pray</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Something demanded or asserted; especially, a position or
supposition assumed without proof, or one which is considered as
self-evident; a truth to which assent may be demanded or
challenged, without argument or evidence.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>The enunciation of a
self-evident problem, in distinction from an <xex>axiom</xex>,
which is the enunciation of a self-evident theorem.</def>

<q>The distinction between a <qex>postulate</qex> and an axiom
lies in this, -- that the latter is admitted to be self-evident,
while the former may be agreed upon between two reasoners, and
admitted by both, but not as proposition which it would be
impossible to deny.</q>
<qau>Eng. Cyc.</qau>

<hw>Pos"tu*late</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Postulated.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hudibras.</au>

<hw>Pos"tu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Postulated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Postulating</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To beg, or
assume without proof; <as>as, to <ex>postulate</ex>
conclusions</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take without express consent; to
assume.</def>

<q>The Byzantine emperors appear to have . . .
<qex>postulated</qex> a sort of paramount supremacy over this
nation.</q>
<qau>W. Tooke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To invite earnestly; to solicit.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Burnet.</au>

without proof; <as>as, a <ex>postulated</ex>
inference</as>.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pos"tur*al</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or

<hw>Pos"ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>positura</ets>, fr. <ets>ponere</ets>,
<ets>positum</ets>, to place. See <er>Position</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The position of the body; the situation or
disposition of the several parts of the body with respect to each
other, or for a particular purpose; especially <fld>(Fine
Arts)</fld>, the position of a figure with regard to the several
principal members by which action is expressed; attitude.</def>

<q>Atalanta, the <qex>posture</qex> of whose limbs was so lively
expressed . . . one would have sworn the very picture had
run.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<q>In most strange <qex>postures</qex>
We have seen him set himself.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>The <qex>posture</qex> of a poetic figure is a description of
his heroes in the performance of such or such an action.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Place; position; situation.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>His [man's] noblest <qex>posture</qex> and station in this
world.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>State or condition, whether of external
circumstances, or of internal feeling and will; disposition;
mood; <as>as, a <ex>posture</ex> of defense; the <ex>posture</ex>
of affairs.</as></def>

<q>The several <qex>postures</qex> of his devout soul.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Attitude; position. See <er>Attitude</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pos"ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Postured</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Posturing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To place in a particular
position or attitude; to dispose the parts of, with reference to
a particular purpose; <as>as, to <ex>posture</ex> one's self; to
<ex>posture</ex> a model.</as></def>

<au>Howell.</au>

<hw>Pos"ture</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To assume a
particular posture or attitude; to contort the body into
artificial attitudes, as an acrobat or contortionist; also, to
pose.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: To assume a character; <as>as, to
<ex>posture</ex> as a saint</as>.</def>

<hw>Po"sy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Posies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Contr. fr.
<ets>poesy</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A brief poetical
sentiment; hence, any brief sentiment, motto, or legend;
especially, one inscribed on a ring.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>posy</xex> of a ring.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Probably so called from the use of flowers as
having an enigmatical significance. <ets>Wedgwood</ets>.]</ety>
<def>A flower; a bouquet; a nosegay.</def> \'bdBridegroom's
<xex>posies</xex>.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>We make a difference between suffering thistles to grow among
us, and wearing them for <qex>posies</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Pot</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to LG.
<ets>pott</ets>, D. <ets>pot</ets>, Dan. <ets>potte</ets>, Sw.
<ets>potta</ets>, Icel. <ets>pottr</ets>, F. <ets>pot</ets>; of
unknown origin.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A metallic or earthen
vessel, appropriated to any of a great variety of uses, as for
boiling meat or vegetables, for holding liquids, for plants,
etc.; <as>as, a quart <ex>pot</ex>; a flower <ex>pot</ex>; a bean
<ex>pot</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An earthen or pewter cup for liquors; a
mug.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The quantity contained in a pot; a potful;
<as>as, a <ex>pot</ex> of ale</as>.</def> \'bdGive her a
<xex>pot</xex> and a cake.\'b8

<au>De Foe.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A metal or earthenware extension of a flue above
the top of a chimney; a chimney pot.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>A crucible; <as>as, a graphite <ex>pot</ex>; a
melting <ex>pot</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A wicker vessel for catching fish, eels,
etc.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A perforated cask for draining sugar.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>A size of paper. See <er>Pott</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Jack pot</col>. <cd>See under 2d <er>Jack</er>.</cd> --
<col>Pot cheese</col>, <cd>cottage cheese. See under
<er>Cottage</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pot companion</col>, <cd>a
companion in drinking.</cd> -- <col>Pot hanger</col>, <cd>a
pothook.</cd> -- <col>Pot herb</col>, <cd>any plant, the leaves
or stems of which are boiled for food, as spinach,
lamb's-quarters, purslane, and many others.</cd> -- <col>Pot
hunter</col>, <cd>one who kills anything and everything that will
help to fill has bag; also, a hunter who shoots game for the
table or for the market.</cd> -- <col>Pot metal</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The metal from which iron pots are made,
different from common pig iron</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>An alloy of
copper with lead used for making large vessels for various
purposes in the arts</cd>. <au>Ure</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>A kind
of stained glass, the colors of which are incorporated with the
melted glass in the pot.</cd> <au>Knight</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pot
plant</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>either of the trees which bear
the monkey-pot.</cd> -- <col>Pot wheel</col>
<fld>(Hydraul.)</fld>, <cd>a noria.</cd> -- <col>To go to
pot</col>, <cd>to go to destruction; to come to an end of
usefulness; to become refuse. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Dryden.</au>   <au>J. G. Saxe.</au>

<hw>Pot</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Potted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Potting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To place or inclose in
pots</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To preserve seasoned in
pots</def>. \'bd<xex>Potted</xex> fowl and fish.\'b8
<au>Dryden</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>To set out or cover in pots;
<as>as, <ex>potted</ex> plants or bulbs</as></def>. <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>To drain; <as>as, to <ex>pot</ex> sugar, by taking it from
the cooler, and placing it in hogsheads, etc., having perforated
heads, through which the molasses drains off</as>.</def> <au>B.
Edwards</au>. <sd>(d)</sd> <fld>(Billiards)</fld> <def>To
pocket.</def>

<hw>Pot</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To tipple; to drink.</def>
<mark>[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<q>It is less labor to plow than to <qex>pot</qex> it.</q>
<qau>Feltham.</qau>

<hw>Po"ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>potabilis</ets>, fr. <ets>potare</ets> to drink; akin to Gr.
<grk>po`tos</grk> a drinking, <grk>po`sis</grk> a drink, Skr.
<ets>p\'be</ets> to drink, OIr. <ets>ibim</ets> I drink. Cf.
<er>Poison</er>, <er>Bib</er>, <er>Imbibe</er>.]</ety> <def>Fit
to be drunk; drinkable.</def> \'bdWater fresh and
<xex>potable</xex>.\'b8 <au>Bacon</au>. -- <def2><pos>n.</pos>
<def>A potable liquid; a beverage.</def> \'bdUseful in
<xex>potables</xex>.\'b8</def2>

<au>J. Philips.</au>

<hw>Pot"ash`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pot</ets> + <ets>ash</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The hydroxide of potassium hydrate, a hard
white brittle substance, <chform>KOH</chform>, having strong
caustic and alkaline properties; -- hence called also
<altname>caustic potash</altname>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The
impure potassium carbonate obtained by leaching wood ashes,
either as a strong solution (<xex>lye</xex>), or as a white
crystalline (<xex>pearlash</xex>).</def>

<hw>Pot"ash`es</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Potash.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Po*tas"sa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr. E.
<ets>potash</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Potassium oxide.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Potassium hydroxide, commonly called <altname>caustic
potash</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pot`ass*am"ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Potass</ets>ium + <ets>amide</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A yellowish brown substance obtained by
heating potassium in ammonia.</def>

<hw>Pot*tas"sic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or containing,
potassium.</def>

<hw>Po*tas"si*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Potassa</er>, <er>Potash</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>An Alkali element, occurring abundantly but always combined,
as in the chloride, sulphate, carbonate, or silicate, in the
minerals sylvite, kainite, orthoclase, muscovite, etc. Atomic
weight 39.0. Symbol K (<xex>Kalium</xex>).</def>

<note><hand/ It is reduced from the carbonate as a soft white
metal, lighter than water, which oxidizes with the greatest
readiness, and, to be preserved, must be kept under liquid
hydrocarbons, as naphtha or kerosene. Its compounds are very
important, being used in glass making, soap making, in
fertilizers, and in many drugs and chemicals.</note>

<cs><col>Potassium permanganate</col>, <cd>the salt
<chform>KMnO4</chform>, crystallizing in dark red prisms having a
greenish surface color, and dissolving in water with a beautiful
purple red color; -- used as an oxidizer and disinfectant. The
name <altname>chameleon mineral</altname> is applied to this salt
and also to potassium manganate.</cd> -- <col>Potassium
bitartrate</col>. <cd>See <cref>Cream of tartar</cref>, under
<er>Cream</er>.</cd></cs>

<ety>[<ets>Potass</ets>ium + <ets>ox</ets>ygen +
<ets>-yl</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The radical
<chform>KO</chform>, derived from, and supposed to exist in,
potassium hydroxide and other compounds.</def>

<hw>Po*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>potatio</ets>, fr. <ets>potare</ets>. See

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Po*ta"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Potatoes</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Sp.
<ets>patata</ets> potato, <ets>batata</ets> sweet potato, from
the native American name (probably <ets>batata</ets>) in
Hayti.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A plant
(<spn>Solanum tuberosum</spn>) of the Nightshade family, and its
esculent farinaceous tuber, of which there are numerous varieties
used for food. It is native of South America, but a form of the
species is found native as far north as New Mexico.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The sweet potato (see below).</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Potato beetle</col>, <col>Potato bug</col></mcol>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A beetle (<spn>Doryphora
decemlineata</spn>) which feeds, both in the larval and adult
stages, upon the leaves of the potato, often doing great damage.
Called also <altname>Colorado potato beetle</altname>, and
<altname>Doryphora</altname>.</cd> See <er>Colorado beetle</er>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The <spn>Lema trilineata</spn>, a smaller and
more slender striped beetle which feeds upon the potato plant,
bur does less injury than the preceding species.</cd> --
<col>Potato fly</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of
several species of blister beetles infesting the potato vine. The
black species (<spn>Lytta atrata</spn>), the striped (<spn>L.
vittata</spn>), and the gray (<spn>L. cinerea, <or/
Fabricii</spn>) are the most common. See <cref>Blister
beetle</cref>, under <er>Blister</er>.</cd> -- <col>Potato
rot</col>, <cd>a disease of the tubers of the potato, supposed to
be caused by a kind of mold (<spn>Peronospora infestans</spn>),
which is first seen upon the leaves and stems.</cd> --
<col>Potato weevil</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>an American
weevil (<spn>Baridius trinotatus</spn>) whose larva lives in and
kills the stalks of potato vines, often causing serious damage to
the crop.</cd> -- <col>Potato whisky</col>, <cd>a strong, fiery
liquor, having a hot, smoky taste, and rich in amyl alcohol
(<xex>fusel oil<xex>); it is made from potatoes or potato
starch.</cd> -- <col>Potato worm</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>the large green larva of a sphinx, or hawk moth
(<spn>Macrosila quinquemaculata</spn>); -- called also
<altname>tomato worm</altname>. See <xex>Illust<xex>. under
<er>Tomato</er>.</cd> -- <col>Seaside potato</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd><spn>Ipom\'d2a Pes-Capr\'91</spn>, a kind
of morning-glory with rounded and emarginate or bilobed
leaves.</cd> <mark>[West Indies]</mark> -- <col>Sweet
potato</col></mcol> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a climbing plant
(<spn>Ipom\'d2a Balatas</spn>) allied to the morning-glory. Its
farinaceous tubers have a sweetish taste, and are used, when
cooked, for food. It is probably a native of Brazil, but is
cultivated extensively in the warmer parts of every continent,
and even as far north as New Jersey. The name <xex>potato<xex>
was applied to this plant before it was to the <spn>Solanum
tuberosum</spn>, and this is the \'bdpotato\'b8 of the Southern
United States.</cd> -- <col>Wild potato</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A vine (<spn>Ipom\'d2a pandurata</spn>) having a
pale purplish flower and an enormous root. It is common in sandy
places in the United States.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A similar
tropical American plant (<spn>I. fastigiata</spn>) which it is
thought may have been the original stock of the sweet
potato.</cd></cs>

<hw>Po"ten*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>potentia</ets>, from <ets>potens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>,
potent. See <er>Potent</er>, and cf. <er>Potance</er>,
<er>Potence</er>, <er>Puissance</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or
state of being potent; physical or moral power; inherent
strength; energy; ability to effect a purpose; capability;
efficacy; influence.</def> \'bdDrugs of <xex>potency</xex>.\'b8

<au>Hawthorne.</au>

<q>A place of <qex>potency</qex> and away o' the state.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Po"tent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>potens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>posse</ets>
to be able, to have power, fr. <ets>potis</ets> able, capable
(akin to Skr. <ets>pati</ets> master, lord) + <ets>esse</ets> to
be. See <er>Host</er> a landlord, <er>Am</er>, and cf.
<er>Despot</er>, <er>Podesta</er>, <er>Possible</er>,
<er>Power</er>, <er>Puissant</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Producing great physical effects; forcible; powerful'
efficacious; <as>as, a <ex>potent</ex> medicine</as>.</def>
\'bdHarsh and <xex>potent</xex> injuries.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Moses once more his <qex>potent</qex> rod extends.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Having great authority, control, or dominion;
puissant; mighty; influential; <as>as, a <ex>potent</ex>
prince</as>.</def> \'bdA <xex>potent</xex> dukedom.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Most <qex>potent</qex>, grave, and reverend signiors.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Powerful, in an intellectual or moral sense;
having great influence; <as>as, <ex>potent</ex> interest; a
<ex>potent</ex> argument.</as></def>

<cs><col>Cross potent</col>. <fld>(Her.)</fld> <cd>See
<xex>Illust<xex>. (7) of <er>Cross</er>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Powerful; mighty; puissant; strong; able; efficient;
forcible; efficacious; cogent; influential.</syn>

<hw>Po"tent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A prince; a
potentate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[See <er>Potence</er>.]</ety> <def>A staff or
crutch.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>One of the furs; a surface
composed of patches which are supposed to represent crutch heads;
they are always alternately argent and azure, unless otherwise
specially mentioned.</def>

<cs><col>Counter potent</col> <fld>(Her.)</fld>, <cd>a fur
differing from potent in the arrangement of the
patches.</cd></cs>

<hw>Po"ten*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>potentatus</ets>, fr. <ets>potentare</ets> to exercise
power: cf. F. <ets>potentat</ets>. See <er>Potent</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>One who is potent; one who possesses
great power or sway; a prince, sovereign, or monarch.</def>

<q>The blessed and only <qex>potentate</qex>.</q>
<qau>1 Tim. vi. 15.</qau>

<q>Cherub and seraph, <qex>potentates</qex> and thrones.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Po*ten"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>potentiel</ets>. See <er>Potency</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Being potent; endowed with energy adequate to a result;
efficacious; influential.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdAnd hath
in his effect a voice <xex>potential</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Existing in possibility, not in actuality.</def>
\'bdA <xex>potential</xex> hero.\'b8

<au>Carlyle.</au>

<q><qex>Potential</qex> existence means merely that the thing may
be at ome time; <qex>actual</qex> existence, that it now is.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<cs><col>Potential cautery</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Cautery</er>.</cd> -- <col>Potential energy</col>.
<fld>(Mech.)</fld> <cd>See the Note under <er>Energy</er>.</cd>
-- <mcol><col>Potential mood</col>, <or/ <col>mode</col></mcol>
<fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>that form of the verb which is used to
express possibility, liberty, power, will, obligation, or
necessity, by the use of <xex>may<xex>, <xex>can<xex>,
<xex>must<xex>, <xex>might<xex>, <xex>could<xex>,
<xex>would<xex>, or <xex>should<xex>; as, I <xex>may go<xex>; he
<xex>can write<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Po*ten"tial</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything
that may be possible; a possibility; potentially.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>In the theory of gravitation,
or of other forces acting in space, a function of the rectangular
coordinates which determine the position of a point, such that
its differential coefficients with respect to the co\'94rdinates
are equal to the components of the force at the point considered;
-- also called <altname>potential function</altname>, or
<altname>force function</altname>. It is called also
<stype>Newtonian potential</stype> when the force is directed to
a fixed center and is inversely as the square of the distance
from the center.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>The energy of an electrical
charge measured by its power to do work; hence, the degree of
electrification as referred to some standard, as that of the
earth; electro-motive force.</def>

<hw>Po*ten`ti*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being potential; possibility, not actuality;
inherent capability or disposition, not actually exhibited.</def>

<hw>Po*ten"tial*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>With power; potently.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In a potential manner; possibly, not
positively.</def>

<q>The duration of human souls is only <qex>potentially</qex>
infinite.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<hw>Po*ten"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Potentiated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Potentiating</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To render active or
potent.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Po*ten`ti*om"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Potential</ets> + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Elec.)</fld> <def>An instrument for measuring or comparing

<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Potentized</er>; <pos>p.

<hw>Pot"hole`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A circular
hole formed in the rocky beds of rivers by the grinding action of
stones or gravel whirled round by the water in what was at first
a natural depression of the rock.</def>

and criminals; -- so named from the field south of Jerusalem,
mentioned in <au>Matt. xxvii. 7</au>.</cd> -- <col>Potter's

are whirled like a <xex>potter's wheel</xex>.\'b8 <au>Shak</au>.
<col>Potter wasp</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small
solitary wasp (<spn>Eumenes fraternal</spn>) which constructs a
globular nest of mud and sand in which it deposits insect
larv\'91, such as cankerworms, as food for its young.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pouch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<def>A bulkhead in the hold of a vessel, to prevent grain, etc.,
from shifting.</def>

<hw>Pounce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>ponce</ets> pumice, pounce, fr. L. <ets>pumex</ets>,
<ets>-icis</ets>, pumice. See <er>Pumice</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A fine powder, as of sandarac, or cuttlefish bone, --
formerly used to prevent ink from spreading on manuscript.</def>

<-- p. 1122 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Charcoal dust, or some other colored powder for
making patterns through perforated designs, -- used by
embroiderers, lace makers, etc.</def>

<cs><col>Pounce box</col>, <cd>a box for sprinkling pounce.</cd>
-- <col>Pounce paper</col>, <cd>a transparent paper for
tracing.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pounce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pounded</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pouncing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To sprinkle or rub with pounce;
<as>as, to <ex>pounce</ex> paper, or a pattern</as>.</def>

<hw>Pounce</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prob. through French, from
an assumed LL. <ets>punctiare</ets> to prick, L.
<ets>pungere</ets>, <ets>punctum</ets>. See <er>Puncheon</er>,
<er>Punch</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The claw
or talon of a bird of prey.</def>

<au>Spenser. Burke.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A punch or stamp.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
\'bdA <xex>pounce</xex> to print money with.\'b8

<au>Withals.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Cloth worked in eyelet holes.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Homilies.</au>

<hw>Pounce</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To strike or
seize with the talons; to pierce, as with the talons.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>Stooped from his highest pitch to <qex>pounce</qex> a
wren.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>Now <qex>pounce</qex> him lightly,
And as he roars and rages, let's go deeper.</q>
<qau>J. Fletcher.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To punch; to perforate; to stamp holes in, or
dots on, by way of ornament.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Elyot.</au>

<hw>Pounce</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To fall suddenly and seize
with the claws; -- with <xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex>; <as>as,
a hawk <ex>pounces</ex> upon a chicken</as>. Also used
figuratively.</def>

<q>Derision is never so agonizing as when it <qex>pounces</qex>
on the wanderings of misguided sensibility.</q>
<qau>Jeffrey.</qau>

<hw>Pounced</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Furnished with claws or talons; <as>as, the <ex>pounced</ex>
young of the eagle</as>.</def>

<au>Thomson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Ornamented with perforations or dots.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdGilt bowls <xex>pounced</xex> and
pierced.\'b8

<au>Holinshed.</au>

<hw>Poun"cet box`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>poncette</ets>, fr. <ets>ponce</ets> pounce. See
<er>Pounce</er> a powder.]</ety> <def>A box with a perforated
lid, for sprinkling pounce, or for holding perfumes.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Poun"cing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The art or practice of transferring a design by means of
