<hw>Pound</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pounded</er>; <pos>p. pr.
& vb. n.</pos> <er>Pounding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pounen</ets>, AS. <ets>punian</ets> to bruise. Cf.
<er>Pun</er> a play on words.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To strike
repeatedly with some heavy instrument; to beat.</def>

<q>With cruel blows she <qex>pounds</qex> her blubbered
cheeks.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To comminute and pulverize by beating; to bruise
or break into fine particles with a pestle or other heavy
instrument; <as>as, to <ex>pound</ex> spice or salt</as>.</def>

<hw>Pound</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To strike heavy
blows; to beat.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>To make a jarring noise, as
in running; <as>as, the engine <ex>pounds</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pound</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>pund</ets> an
inclosure: cf. <ets>forpyndan</ets> to turn away, or to repress,
also Icel. <ets>pynda</ets> to extort, torment, Ir.
<ets>pont</ets>, pond, pound. Cf. <er>Pinder</er>,
<er>Pinfold</er>, <er>Pin</er> to inclose, <er>Pond</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An inclosure, maintained by public authority, in
which cattle or other animals are confined when taken in
trespassing, or when going at large in violation of law; a
pinfold.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A level stretch in a canal between locks.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Fishing)</fld> <def>A kind of net, having a
large inclosure with a narrow entrance into which fish are
directed by wings spreading outward.</def>

<cs><col>Pound covert</col>, <cd>a pound that is close or covered
over, as a shed.</cd> -- <col>Pound overt</col>, <cd>a pound that
is open overhead.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pound</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To confine in, or as in, a
pound; to impound.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pound</hw>, <pos>n</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Pounds</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr>, collectively <plw>Pound</plw> pr
<plw>Pounds</plw></plu>. <ety>[AS. <ets>pund</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>pondo</ets>, akin to <ets>pondus</ets> a weight,
<ets>pendere</ets> top weigh. See <er>Pendant</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A certain specified weight; especially, a legal
standard consisting of an established number of ounces.</def>

<note><hand/ The pound in general use in the United States and in
England is the <xex>pound avoirdupois</xex>, which is divided
into sixteen ounces, and contains 7,000 grains. The <xex>pound
troy</xex> is divided into twelve ounces, and contains 5,760
grains. 144 pounds avoirdupois are equal to 175 pounds troy
weight. See <er>Avoirdupois</er>, and <er>Troy</er>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A British denomination of money of account,
equivalent to twenty shillings sterling, and equal in value to
about $4.86. There is no coin known by this name, but the gold
sovereign is of the same value.</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>pound</xex> sterling was in Saxon times,
about <sc>A. D.</sc> 671, a <xex>pound</xex> troy of silver, and
a shilling was its twentieth part; consequently the latter was
three times as large as it is at present.</note>

<au>Peacham.</au>

<hw>Pound"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
sum deducted from a pound, or a certain sum paid for each pound;
a commission.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A subsidy of twelve pence in the pound, formerly
granted to the crown on all goods exported or imported, and if by
aliens, more.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The sum allowed to a sheriff or
other officer upon the amount realized by an execution; --
estimated in England, and formerly in the United States, at so
much of the pound.</def>

<au>Burrill. Bouvier.</au>

<hw>Pound"age</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To collect, as
poundage; to assess, or rate, by poundage.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pound"age</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See 3d
<er>Pound</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Confinement of cattle, or
other animals, in a public pound.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A charge paid for the release of impounded
cattle.</def>

<hw>Pound"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From 5th
<er>Pound</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics & Mech.)</fld> <def>A unit
of force based upon the pound, foot, and second, being the force
which, acting on a pound avoirdupois for one second, causes it to
acquire by the of that time a velocity of one foot per second. It
is about equal to the weight of half an ounce, and is 13,825
dynes.</def>

<hw>Pound"-breach`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
breaking of a public pound for releasing impounded animals.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pound"cake`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of
rich, sweet cake; -- so called from the ingredients being used by
pounds, or in equal quantities.</def>

<hw>Pound"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, pounds, as a stamp in an ore
mill.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An instrument used for pounding; a pestle.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A person or thing, so called with reference to a
certain number of pounds in value, weight, capacity, etc.;
<as>as, a cannon carrying a twelve-pound ball is called a twelve
<ex>pounder</ex></as>.</def>

<note><hand/ Before the English reform act of 1867, one who was
an elector by virtue of paying ten pounds rent was called a ten
<xex>pounder</xex>.</note>

<hw>Pound"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of beating, bruising, or breaking up; a
beating.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A pounded or pulverized substance.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdCovered with the <xex>poundings</xex> of
these rocks.\'b8

<au>J. S. Blackie.</au>

<hw>Pound/keep`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
keeper of a pound.</def>

<hw>Pound"*rate`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A rate or

<hw>Pour</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Poured</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pouring</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>pouren</ets>, of uncertain origin; cf. W.
<ets>bwrw</ets> to cast, throw, shed, <ets>bwrw gwlaw</ets> to
rain.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cause to flow in a stream, as a
liquid or anything flowing like a liquid, either out of a vessel
or into it; <as>as, to <ex>pour</ex> water from a pail; to
<ex>pour</ex> wine into a decanter; to <ex>pour</ex> oil upon the
waters; to <ex>pour</ex> out sand or dust.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To send forth as in a stream or a flood; to
emit; to let escape freely or wholly.</def>

<q>I . . . have <qex>poured</qex> out my soul before the
Lord.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. i. 15.</qau>

<q>Now will I shortly <qex>pour</qex> out my fury upon thee.</q>
<qau>Ezek. vii. 8.</qau>

<q>London doth <qex>pour</qex> out her citizens !</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Wherefore did Nature <qex>pour</qex> her bounties forth
With such a full and unwithdrawing hand ?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To send forth from, as in a stream; to discharge
uninterruptedly.</def>

<q>Is it for thee the linnet <qex>pours</qex> his throat ?</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Pour</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To flow, pass, or issue in a
stream, or as a stream; to fall continuously and abundantly;
<as>as, the rain <ex>pours</ex>; the people <ex>poured</ex> out
of the theater.</as></def>

<q>In the rude throng <qex>pour</qex> on with furious pace.</q>
<qau>Gay.</qau>

<hw>Pour</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A stream, or something like a
stream; a flood.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> \'bdA
<xex>pour</xex> of rain.\'b8

<au>Miss Ferrier.</au>

<hw>Pout</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<hw>Pov"ert</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Poverty.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pov"er*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>poverte</ets>, OF. <ets>povert\'82</ets>, F.
<ets>pauvret\'82</ets>, fr. L. <ets>paupertas</ets>, fr.
<ets>pauper</ets> poor. See <er>Poor</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The quality or state of being poor or indigent; want or
scarcity of means of subsistence; indigence; need.</def>
\'bdSwathed in numblest <xex>poverty</xex>.\'b8

<au>Keble.</au>

<q>The drunkard and the glutton shall come to
<qex>poverty</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxiii. 21.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any deficiency of elements or resources that are
needed or desired, or that constitute richness; <as>as,
<ex>poverty</ex> of soil; <ex>poverty</ex> of the blood;
<ex>poverty</ex> of ideas.</as></def>

<cs><col>Poverty grass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name given
to several slender grasses (as <spn>Aristida dichotoma</spn>, and
<spn>Danthonia spicata</spn>) which often spring up on old and
worn-out fields.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Indigence; penury; beggary; need; lack; want;
scantiness; sparingness; meagerness; jejuneness.</syn> <usage>
<er>Poverty</er>, <er>Indigence</er>, <er>Pauperism</er>.
<xex>Poverty</xex> is a relative term; what is <xex>poverty</xex>
to a monarch, would be competence for a day laborer.
<xex>Indigence</xex> implies extreme distress, and almost
absolute destitution. <xex>Pauperism</xex> denotes entire
dependence upon public charity, and, therefore, often a hopeless
and degraded state.</usage>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pow"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pow"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>
}</mhw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small British
lake whitefish (<spn>Coregonus clupeoides</spn>, or <spn>C.
ferus</spn>); -- called also <altname>gwyniad</altname> and
<altname>lake herring</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pow"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>poudre</ets>, <ets>pouldre</ets>, F. <ets>poudre</ets>, OF.
also <ets>poldre</ets>, <ets>puldre</ets>, L. <ets>pulvis</ets>,
<ets>pulveris</ets>: cf. <ets>pollen</ets> fine flour, mill dust,
E. <ets>pollen</ets>. Cf. <er>Polverine</er>,
<er>Pulverize</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The fine particles to
which any dry substance is reduced by pounding, grinding, or
triturating, or into which it falls by decay; dust.</def>

<q>Grind their bones to <qex>powder</qex> small.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An explosive mixture used in gunnery, blasting,
etc.; gunpowder. See <er>Gunpowder</er>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Atlas powder</col>, <col>Baking
powder</col></mcol>, <cd>etc. See under <er>Atlas</er>,
<er>Baking</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Powder down</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the peculiar dust, or exfoliation, of
powder-down feathers.</cd> -- <col>Powder-down feather</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>one of a peculiar kind of modified
feathers which sometimes form patches on certain parts of some
birds. They have a greasy texture and a scaly exfoliation.</cd>
-- <col>Powder-down patch</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a tuft
or patch of powder-down feathers.</cd> -- <col>Powder hose</col>,
<cd>a tube of strong linen, about an inch in diameter, filled
with powder and used in firing mines. <au>Farrow</au>.</cd> --
<col>Powder hoy</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a vessel specially
fitted to carry powder for the supply of war ships. They are
usually painted red and carry a red flag.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Powder magazine</col>, <or/ <col>Powder
room</col></mcol>. <cd>See <er>Magazine</er>, 2.</cd> --
<col>Powder mine</col>, <cd>a mine exploded by gunpowder. See
<er>Mine</er>.</cd> -- <col>Powder monkey</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a boy formerly employed on war vessels to
carry powder; a powder boy.</cd> -- <col>Powder post</col>.
<cd>See <cref>Dry rot</cref>, under <er>Dry</er>.</cd> --
<col>Powder puff</col>. <cd>See <er>Puff</er>,
<pos>n.</pos></cd></cs>

<hw>Pow"der</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Powdered</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Powdering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>poudrer</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To reduce to fine
particles; to pound, grind, or rub into a powder; to comminute;
to pulverize; to triturate.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To sprinkle with powder, or as with powder; to
be sprinkle; <as>as, to <ex>powder</ex> the hair</as>.</def>

<q>A circling zone thou seest
<qex>Powdered</qex> with stars.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To sprinkle with salt; to corn, as meat.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pow"der</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be reduced
to powder; to become like powder; <as>as, some salts
<ex>powder</ex> easily</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To use powder on the hair or skin; <as>as, she
paints and <ex>powders</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pow"dered</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Reduced to a powder; sprinkled with, or as with,
powder.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Sprinkled with salt; salted; corned.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q><qex>Powdered</qex> beef, pickled meats.</q>
<qau>Harvey.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Sem\'82</er>.</def>

<au>Walpole.</au>

<hw>Pow"der*flask`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A flask
in which gunpowder is carried, having a charging tube at the
end.</def>

<hw>Pow"der*horn`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A horn in
which gunpowder is carried.</def>

<hw>Pow"der*ing</hw>, <def><pos>a. & n.</pos> from
<er>Powder</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos></def>

<cs><col>Powdering tub</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A tub or vessel in
which meat is corned or salted</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A heated
tub in which an infected lecher was placed for cure</cd>.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pow"der*mill`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A mill in
which gunpowder is made.</def>

<hw>Pow"der-post`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Affected with dry rot; reduced to dust by rot. See <cref>Dry
rot</cref>, under <er>Dry</er>.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Pow"der*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Easily crumbling to pieces; friable; loose; <as>as, a
<ex>powdery</ex> spar</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Sprinkled or covered with powder; dusty; <as>as,
the <ex>powdery</ex> bloom on plums</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Resembling powder; consisting of powder.</def>
\'bdThe <xex>powdery</xex> snow.\'b8

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<hw>Pow"dike</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Scot.
<ets>pow</ets>, <ets>pou</ets>, a pool, a watery or marshy place,
fr. E. <ets>pool</ets>.]</ety> <def>A dike a marsh or fen.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<hw>Pow"dry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>See
<er>Powdery</er>.</def>

<hw>Pow"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Same as <er>Poor</er>, the fish.</def>

<hw>Pow"er</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>pouer</ets>,
<ets>poer</ets>, OF. <ets>poeir</ets>, <ets>pooir</ets>, F.
<ets>pouvoir</ets>, n. & v., fr. LL. <ets>potere</ets>, for L.
<ets>posse</ets>, <ets>potesse</ets>, to be able, to have power.
See <er>Possible</er>, <er>Potent</er>, and cf. <er>Posse
comitatus</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Ability to act, regarded
as latent or inherent; the faculty of doing or performing
something; capacity for action or performance; capability of
producing an effect, whether physical or moral: potency; might;
<as>as, a man of great <ex>power</ex>; the <ex>power</ex> of
capillary attraction; money gives <ex>power</ex>.</as></def>
\'bdOne next himself in <xex>power</xex>, and next in crime.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Ability, regarded as put forth or exerted;
strength, force, or energy in action; <as>as, the <ex>power</ex>
of steam in moving an engine; the <ex>power</ex> of truth, or of
argument, in producing conviction; the <ex>power</ex> of
enthusiasm.</as></def> \'bdThe <xex>power</xex> of fancy.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Capacity of undergoing or suffering; fitness to
be acted upon; susceptibility; -- called also <altname>passive
power</altname>; <as>as, great <ex>power</ex> of
endurance</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Power</qex>, then, is active and passive; faculty is
active <qex>power</qex> or capacity; capacity is passive
<qex>power</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The exercise of a faculty; the employment of
strength; the exercise of any kind of control; influence;
dominion; sway; command; government.</def>

<q><qex>Power</qex> is no blessing in itself but when it is
employed to protect the innocent.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The agent exercising an ability to act; an
individual invested with authority; an institution, or
government, which exercises control; <as>as, the great
<ex>powers</ex> of Europe</as>; hence, often, a superhuman agent;
a spirit; a divinity.</def> \'bdThe <xex>powers</xex> of
darkness.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>And the <qex>powers</qex> of the heavens shall be shaken.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxiv. 29.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>A military or naval force; an army or navy; a
great host.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>Never such a <qex>power</qex> . . . 
Was levied in the body of a land.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<-- p. 1123 -->

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A large quantity; a great number; <as>as, a
<ex>power</ex> o<?/ good things</as>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<au>Richardson.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The rate at
which mechanical energy is exerted or mechanical work performed,
as by an engine or other machine, or an animal, working
continuously; <as>as, an engine of twenty horse
<ex>power</ex></as>.</def>

<note><hand/ The English unit of power used most commonly is the
<xex>horse power</xex>. See <er>Horse power</er>.</note>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A mechanical agent; that from which useful
mechanical energy is derived; <as>as, water <ex>power</ex>; steam
<ex>power</ex>; hand <ex>power</ex>, etc.</as></def> <sd>(c)</sd>
<def>Applied force; force producing motion or pressure; as, the
<xex>power</xex> applied at one and of a lever to lift a weight
at the other end</def>.

<note><hand/ This use in mechanics, of <xex>power</xex> as a
synonym for <xex>force</xex>, is improper and is becoming
obsolete.</note>

<sd>(d)</sd> <def>A machine acted upon by an animal, and serving
as a motor to drive other machinery; <as>as, a dog
<ex>power</ex></as></def>.

<note><hand/ <xex>Power</xex> is used adjectively, denoting,
driven, or adapted to be driven, by machinery, and not actuated
directly by the hand or foot; as, a <xex>power</xex> lathe; a
<xex>power</xex> loom; a <xex>power</xex> press.</note>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The product arising from the
multiplication of a number into itself; <as>as, a square is the
second <ex>power</ex>, and a cube is third <ex>power</ex>, of a
number</as>.</def>

<sn>10.</sn> <pr>(<?/)</pr> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>Mental or
moral ability to act; one of the faculties which are possessed by
the mind or soul; <as>as, the <ex>power</ex> of thinking,
reasoning, judging, willing, fearing, hoping, etc</as>.</def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<q>The guiltiness of my mind, the sudden surprise of my
<qex>powers</qex>, drove the grossness . . . into a received
belief.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>11.</sn> <fld>(Optics)</fld> <def>The degree to which a lens,
mirror, or any optical instrument, magnifies; in the telescope,
and usually in the microscope, the number of times it multiplies,
or augments, the apparent diameter of an object; sometimes, in
microscopes, the number of times it multiplies the apparent
surface.</def>

<sn>12.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An authority enabling a person
to dispose of an interest vested either in himself or in another
person; ownership by appointment.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<sn>13.</sn> <def>Hence, vested authority to act in a given case;
<as>as, the business was referred to a committee with
<ex>power</ex></as>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Power</xex> may be predicated of inanimate
agents, like the winds and waves, electricity and magnetism,
gravitation, etc., or of animal and intelligent beings; and when
predicated of these beings, it may indicate physical, mental, or
moral ability or capacity.</note>

<cs><col>Mechanical powers</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Mechanical</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Power loom</col>, <or/
<col>Power press</col></mcol>. <cd>See Def. 8 <sd>(d)</sd>,
note.</cd> -- <col>Power of attorney</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Attorney</er>.</cd> -- <col>Power of a point</col> (relative
to a given curve) <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>the result of
substituting the co\'94rdinates of any point in that expression
which being put equal to zero forms the equation of the curve;
as, <mathex>x<exp>2</exp> + y<exp>2</exp> - 100</mathex> is the
<xex>power of the point</xex> <it>x, y</it>, relative to the
circle <mathex>x<exp>2</exp> + y<exp>2</exp> - 100 =
0</mathex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pow"er*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Capable of being effected or accomplished by the application
of power; possible.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>J. Young.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of exerting power; powerful.</def>

<au>Camden.</au>

<hw>Pow"er*ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Full of power; capable of producing great effects of any
kind; potent; mighty; efficacious; intense; <as>as, a
<ex>powerful</ex> man or beast; a <ex>powerful</ex> engine; a
<ex>powerful</ex> argument; a <ex>powerful</ex> light; a
<ex>powerful</ex> vessel.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>powerful</qex> grace that lies
In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>Large; capacious; -- said of
veins of ore.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Mighty; strong; potent; forcible; efficacious;
energetic; intense.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pow"er*ful*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pow"er*ful*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pow"er*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Destitute of power,
force, or energy; weak; impotent; not able to produce any
effect.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pow"er*less*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos> -- <wf>Pow"er*less*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pow"pow`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
priest, or conjurer, among the North American Indians.</def>

<q>Be it sagamore, sachem, or <qex>powwow</qex>.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conjuration attended with great noise and
confusion, and often with feasting, dancing, etc., performed by
Indians for the cure of diseases, to procure success in hunting
or in war, and for other purposes.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: Any assembly characterized by noise and
confusion; a noisy frolic or gathering.</def> <mark>[Colloq. U.
S.]</mark>

<-- 4. Any meeting assembled to discuss an issue; a parley. -->

<hw>Pow"wow`</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To use
conjuration, with noise and confusion, for the cure of disease,
etc., as among the North American Indians.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence: To hold a noisy, disorderly
meeting.</def> <mark>[Colloq. U. S.]</mark>

<-- 4. To hold a meeting to discuss an issue. -->

<hw>Pox</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>pocks</ets>, OE. <ets>pokkes</ets>. See <er>Pock</er>. It is
plural in form but is used as a singular.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Strictly, a disease by pustules or
eruptions of any kind, but chiefly or wholly restricted to three
or four diseases, -- the smallpox, the chicken pox, and the
vaccine and the venereal diseases.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Pox</xex>, when used without an epithet, as in
imprecations, formerly signified <xex>smallpox</xex>; but it now
signifies <xex>syphilis</xex>.</note>

<hw>Pox</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<er>Poxing</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To infect with the pox, or
syphilis.</def>

<hw>Prac"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Practical</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Practical.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Artful; deceitful; skillful.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdCunning sleights and <xex>practick</xex>
knavery.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Prac"ti*ca*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being practicable; practicableness;
feasibility.</def> \'bdThe <xex>practicability</xex> of such a
project.\'b8

<au>Stewart.</au>

<hw>Prac"ti*ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>practicare</ets> to act, transact, fr. L.
<ets>practicus</ets> active, Gr. <?/: cf. F.
<ets>practicable</ets>, <ets>pratiquer</ets> to practice. See
<er>Practical</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That may be practiced
or performed; capable of being done or accomplished with
available means or resources; feasible; <as>as, a
<ex>practicable</ex> method; a <ex>practicable</ex> aim; a
<ex>practicable</ex> good.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being used; passable; <as>as, a
<ex>practicable</ex> weapon; a <ex>practicable</ex>
road.</as></def>

<cs><col>Practicable breach</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>a breach
which admits of approach and entrance by an assailing
party.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Possible; feasible. -- <er>Practicable</er>,
<er>Possible</er>. A thing may be <xex>possible</xex>, i. e., not
forbidden by any law of nature, and yet may not now be
<xex>practicable</xex> for want of the means requisite to its
performance.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>Prac"ti*ca*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos> --
<wf>Prac"ti*ca*bly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Prac"ti*cal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>practicus</ets> active, Gr. <?/ fit for doing or performing,
practical, active, fr. <?/ to do, work, effect: cf. F.
<ets>pratique</ets>, formerly also <ets>practique</ets>. Cf.
<er>Pragmatic</er>, <er>Practice</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of
or pertaining to practice or action.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being turned to use or account;
useful, in distinction from <contr>ideal</contr> or
<contr>theoretical</contr>; <as>as, <ex>practical</ex>
chemistry</as>.</def> \'bdMan's <xex>practical</xex>
understanding.\'b8 <au>South</au>. \'bdFor all
<xex>practical</xex> purposes.\'b8 <au>Macaulay</au>.

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Evincing practice or skill; capable of applying
knowledge to some useful end; <as>as, a <ex>practical</ex> man; a
<ex>practical</ex> mind.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Derived from practice; <as>as,
<ex>practical</ex> skill</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Practical joke</col>, <cd>a joke put in practice; a joke
the fun of which consists in something done, in distinction from
something said; esp., a trick played upon a person.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prac`ti*cal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being practical; practicalness.</def>

<hw>Prac"ti*cal*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>1. In
a practical way; not theoretically; really; <as>as, to look at
things <ex>practically</ex>; <ex>practically</ex>
worthless.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>By means of practice or use; by experience or
experiment; <as>as, <ex>practically</ex> wise or skillful;
<ex>practically</ex> acquainted with a subject.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In practice or use; <as>as, a medicine
<ex>practically</ex> safe; theoretically wrong, but
<ex>practically</ex> right.</as></def>

<-- <sn>4.</sn> <def>Almost.</def> -->

<hw>Prac"ti*cal*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Practicality</er>.</def>

<hw>Prac"ti*cal*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
render practical.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Practicalizing</xex> influences.\'b8

<au>J. S. Mill.</au>

<hw>Prac"tice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>praktike</ets>, <ets>practique</ets>, F.
<ets>pratique</ets>, formerly also, <ets>practique</ets>, LL.
<ets>practica</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ practical. See
<er>Practical</er>, and cf. <er>Pratique</er>,
<er>Pretty</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Frequently repeated or
customary action; habitual performance; a succession of acts of a
similar kind; usage; habit; custom; <as>as, the <ex>practice</ex>
of rising early; the <ex>practice</ex> of making regular entries
of accounts; the <ex>practice</ex> of daily exercise.</as></def>
<-- also commonly practise -->

<q>A heart . . . exercised with covetous
<qex>practices</qex>.</q>
<qau>2 Pet. ii. 14.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Customary or constant use; state of being
used.</def>

<q>Obsolete words may be revived when they are more sounding or
more significant than those in <qex>practice</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Skill or dexterity acquired by use;
expertness.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdHis nice fence and his
active <xex>practice</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Actual performance; application of knowledge; --
opposed to <xex>theory</xex>.</def>

<q>There are two functions of the soul, -- contemplation and
<qex>practice</qex>.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<q>There is a distinction, but no opposition, between theory and
<qex>practice</qex>; each, to a certain extent, supposes the
other; theory is dependent on <qex>practice</qex>;
<qex>practice</qex> must have preceded theory.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Systematic exercise for instruction or
discipline; <as>as, the troops are called out for
<ex>practice</ex>; she neglected <ex>practice</ex> in
music.</as></def>
<-- practice makes perfect.  MW10 2a. -->

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Application of science to the wants of men; the
exercise of any profession; professional business; <as>as, the
<ex>practice</ex> of medicine or law; a large or lucrative
<ex>practice</ex>.</as></def>

<q><qex>Practice</qex> is exercise of an art, or the application
of a science in life, which application is itself an art.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Skillful or artful management; dexterity in
contrivance or the use of means; art; stratagem; artifice; plot;
-- usually in a bad sense.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>He sought to have that by <qex>practice</qex> which he could
not by prayer.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A easy and concise method of
applying the rules of arithmetic to questions which occur in
trade and business.</def>

<sn>9.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The form, manner, and order of
conducting and carrying on suits and prosecutions through their
various stages, according to the principles of law and the rules
laid down by the courts.</def>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Custom; usage; habit; manner.</syn>

<hw>Prac"tice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Practiced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Practicing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Often written
<ets>practise</ets>, <ets>practised</ets>,
<ets>practising</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To do or perform
frequently, customarily, or habitually; to make a practice of;
<as>as, to <ex>practice</ex> gaming</as>.</def> \'bdIncline not
my heart . . . <xex>practice</xex> wicked works.\'b8
<-- also commonly practise -->

<au>Ps. cxli. 4.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exercise, or follow, as a profession, trade,
art, etc., <as>as, to <ex>practice</ex> law or
medicine</as>.</def><-- MW10 1c. -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exercise one's self in, for instruction or
improvement, or to acquire discipline or dexterity; <as>as, to
<ex>practice</ex> gunnery; to <ex>practice</ex> music.</as></def>
<-- MW10 2a -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To put into practice; to carry out; to act upon;
to commit; to execute; to do.</def> \'bdAught but Talbot's shadow
whereon to <xex>practice</xex> your severity.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>As this advice ye <qex>practice</qex> or neglect.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To make use of; to employ.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>In malice to this good knight's wife, I <qex>practiced</qex>
Ubaldo and Ricardo to corrupt her.</q>
<qau>Massinger.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To teach or accustom by practice; to
train.</def>

<q>In church they are taught to love God; after church they are
<qex>practiced</qex> to love their neighbor.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<hw>Prac"tice</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[Often written
<ets>practise</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To perform certain
acts frequently or customarily, either for instruction, profit,
or amusement; <as>as, to <ex>practice</ex> with the broadsword or
with the rifle; to <ex>practice</ex> on the piano.</as></def>
<-- also commonly <asp>practise</asp> -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To learn by practice; to form a habit.</def>

<q>They shall <qex>practice</qex> how to live secure.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q><qex>Practice</qex> first over yourself to reign.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To try artifices or stratagems.</def>

<q>He will <qex>practice</qex> against thee by poison.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To apply theoretical science or knowledge, esp.
by way of experiment; to exercise or pursue an employment or
profession, esp. that of medicine or of law.</def>

<q>[I am] little inclined to <qex>practice</qex> on others, and
as little that others should <qex>practice</qex> on me.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<hw>Prac"ticed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Often
written <ets>practised</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Experienced; expert; skilled; <as>as, a <ex>practiced</ex>
marksman</as>.</def> \'bdA <xex>practiced</xex> picklock.\'b8

<au>Ld. Lytton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Used habitually; learned by practice.</def>

<hw>Prac"ti*cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Often
written <ets>practiser</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who
practices, or puts in practice; one who customarily performs
certain acts.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who exercises a profession; a
practitioner.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who uses art or stratagem.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Prac*ti"cian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>praticien</ets>, OF. also <ets>practicien</ets>.]</ety>
<def>One who is acquainted with, or skilled in, anything by
practice; a practitioner.</def>

<hw>Prac"tick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Practice.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Prac"ti*sant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An agent
or confederate in treachery.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Prac"tise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos> <def>See
<er>Practice</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The analogy of the English language requires that
the noun and verb which are pronounced alike should agree in
spelling. Thus we have <xex>notice</xex> (n. & v.),
<xex>noticed</xex>, <xex>noticing</xex>, <xex>noticer</xex>;
<xex>poultice</xex> (n. & v.); <xex>apprentice</xex> (n. & v.);
<xex>office</xex> (n. & v.), <xex>officer</xex> (n.);
<xex>lattice</xex> (n.), <xex>latticed</xex> (a.);
<xex>benefice</xex> (n.), <xex>beneficed</xex> (a.), etc. Cf.
<xex>sacrifice</xex> (<?/; n. & v.), <xex>surmise</xex> (<?/; n.
& v.), <xex>promise</xex> (<?/; n. & v.); <xex>compromise</xex>
(<?/; n. & v.), etc. Contrast <xex>advice</xex> (<?/; n.), and
<xex>advise</xex> (<?/); <xex>device</xex> (<?/), and
<xex>devise</xex> (<?/), etc.</note>

<hw>\'d8Pr\'91m`u*ni"re</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Corrupted from L. <ets>praemonere</ets> to forewarn, cite.
See <er>Admonish</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The offense of introducing foreign authority into England,
the penalties for which were originally intended to depress the
civil power of the pope in the kingdom.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The writ grounded on that offense.</def> <au>Wharton</au>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>The penalty ascribed for the offense of
<xex>pr\'91munire</xex>.</def>

<q>Wolsey incurred a <qex>pr\'91munire</qex>, and forfeited his
honor, estate, and life.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<note><hand/ The penalties of <xex>pr\'91munire</xex> were
subsequently applied to many other offenses; but prosecutions
upon a <xex>pr\'91munire</xex> are at this day unheard of in the
English courts.</note>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

subject to the penalties of pr\'91munire.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>T. Ward.</au>

<hw>Pr\'91*tex"ta</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<plw>Pr\'91textas</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. (sc.
<ets>toga</ets>), fr. <ets>praetextus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>praetexere</ets> to weave before, to fringe, border;

virilis</xex>, or until about the completion of his fourteenth
year, and by girls until their marriage. It was also worn by
magistrates and priests.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Prag*mat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Prag*mat"ic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pragmaticus</ets> busy, active, skilled in business,
especially in law and state affairs, systematic, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/
a thing done, business, fr. <?/ to do: cf. F.
<ets>pragmatique</ets>. See <er>Practical</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to business or to affairs; of
the nature of business; practical; material; businesslike in
habit or manner.</def>

<q>The next day . . . I began to be very
<qex>pragmatical</qex>.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<q>We can not always be contemplative, diligent, or
<qex>pragmatical</qex>, abroad; but have need of some delightful
intermissions.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Low, <qex>pragmatical</qex>, earthly views of the gospel.</q>
<qau>Hare.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Busy; specifically, busy in an objectionable
way; officious; fussy and positive; meddlesome.</def>
\'bd<xex>Pragmatical</xex> officers of justice.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<q>The fellow grew so <qex>pragmatical</qex> that he took upon
him the government of my whole family.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Philosophical; dealing with causes, reasons, and
effects, rather than with details and circumstances; -- said of
literature.</def> \'bd<xex>Pragmatic</xex> history.\'b8 <au>Sir
W. Hamilton</au>. \'bd<xex>Pragmatic</xex> poetry.\'b8 <au>M.
Arnold</au>.

<cs><col>Pragmatic sanction</col>, <cd>a solemn ordinance or
decree issued by the head or legislature of a state upon weighty
matters; -- a term derived from the Byzantine empire. In European
history, two decrees under this name are particularly celebrated.
One of these, issued by Charles VII. of France, <sc>A. D.</sc>
1438, was the foundation of the liberties of the Gallican church;
the other, issued by Charles VI. of Germany, <sc>A. D.</sc> 1724,
settled his hereditary dominions on his eldest daughter, the
Archduchess Maria Theresa.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prag*mat"ic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One skilled
in affairs.</def>

<q>My attorney and solicitor too; a fine
<qex>pragmatic</qex>.</q>
<qau>B. Jonson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A solemn public ordinance or decree.</def>

<q>A royal <qex>pragmatic</qex> was accordingly passed.</q>
<qau>Prescott.</qau>

<hw>Prag*mat"ic*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
a pragmatical manner.</def>

<hw>Prag*mat"ic*al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being pragmatical.</def>

<hw>Prag"ma*tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being pragmatic; in literature, the
pragmatic, or philosophical, method.</def>

<q>The narration of this apparently trifling circumstance belongs
to the <qex>pragmatism</qex> of the history.</q>
<qau>A. Murphy.</qau>

<hw>Prag"ma*tist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is
pragmatic.</def>

<hw>Prag"ma*tize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
consider, represent, or embody (something unreal) as fact; to
materialize.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdA <xex>pragmatized</xex>
metaphor.\'b8

<au>Tylor.</au>

<hw>\'d8Prai`ri`al"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.,
fr. <ets>prairie</ets> meadow.]</ety> <def>The ninth month of the
French Republican calendar, which dated from September 22, 1792.
It began May, 20, and ended June 18. See
<er>Vendemiaire</er>.</def>

<hw>Prai"rie</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., an
extensive meadow, OF. <ets>praerie</ets>, LL.
<ets>prataria</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pratum</ets> a meadow.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>An extensive tract of level or rolling land,
destitute of trees, covered with coarse grass, and usually
characterized by a deep, fertile soil. They abound throughout the
Mississippi valley, between the Alleghanies and the Rocky
mountains.</def>

<q>From the forests and the <qex>prairies</qex>,
From the great lakes of the northland.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A meadow or tract of grass; especially, a so
called natural meadow.</def>

<cs><col>Prairie chicken</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
American grouse of the genus <spn>Tympanuchus</spn>, especially
<spn>T. Americanus</spn> (formerly <spn>T. cupido</spn>), which
inhabits the prairies of the central United States. Applied also
to the sharp-tailed grouse.</cd> -- <col>Prairie clover</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any plant of the leguminous genus
<spn>Petalostemon</spn>, having small rosy or white flowers in
dense terminal heads or spikes. Several species occur in the
prairies of the United States.</cd> -- <col>Prairie dock</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a coarse composite plant (<spn>Silphium
terebinthaceum</spn>) with large rough leaves and yellow flowers,
found in the Western prairies.</cd> -- <col>Prairie dog</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a small American rodent (<spn>Cynomys
Ludovicianus</spn>) allied to the marmots. It inhabits the plains
west of the Mississippi. The prairie dogs burrow in the ground in
large warrens, and have a sharp bark like that of a dog. Called
also <altname>prairie marmot</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Prairie
grouse</col>. <cd>Same as <cref>Prairie chicken</cref>,
above.</cd> -- <col>Prairie hare</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>a large long-eared Western hare (<spn>Lepus
campestris</spn>). See <cref>Jack rabbit</cref>, under 2d
<er>Jack</er>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Prairie hawk</col>,
<col>Prairie falcon</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
falcon of Western North America (<spn>Falco Mexicanus</spn>). The
upper parts are brown. The tail has transverse bands of white;
the under parts, longitudinal streaks and spots of brown.</cd> --
<col>Prairie hen</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>Same as
<cref>Prairie chicken</cref>, above.</cd> -- <col>Prairie
itch</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>an affection of the skin
attended with intense itching, which is observed in the Northern
and Western United States; -- also called <altname>swamp
itch</altname>, <altname>winter itch</altname>.</cd> --
<col>Prairie marmot</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>Same as
<cref>Prairie dog</cref>, above.</cd> -- <col>Prairie mole</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large American mole (<spn>Scalops
argentatus</spn>), native of the Western prairies.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Prairie pigeon</col>, <col>plover</col>, <or/
<col>snipe</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the upland
plover. See <er>Plover</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2.</cd> --
<col>Prairie rattlesnake</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
massasauga.</cd> -- <col>Prairie snake</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a large harmless American snake
(<spn>Masticophis flavigularis</spn>). It is pale yellow, tinged
with brown above.</cd> -- <col>Prairie squirrel</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any American ground squirrel of the
genus <spn>Spermophilus</spn>, inhabiting prairies; -- called
also <altname>gopher</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Prairie turnip</col>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the edible turnip-shaped farinaceous root
of a leguminous plant (<spn>Psoralea esculenta</spn>) of the
Upper Missouri region; also, the plant itself. Called also
<altname>pomme blanche</altname>, and <altname>pomme de
prairie</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Prairie warbler</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a bright-colored American warbler
(<spn>Dendroica discolor</spn>). The back is olive yellow, with a
group of reddish spots in the middle; the under parts and the
parts around the eyes are bright yellow; the sides of the throat
and spots along the sides, black; three outer tail feathers
partly white.</cd> -- <col>Prairie wolf</col>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Coyote</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prais"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Fit to be
praised; praise-worthy; laudable; commendable.</def>

<au>Wyclif (2 Tim. ii. 15).</au>

<hw>Prais"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a praisable
manner.</def>

<hw>Praise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Praised</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Praising</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>preisen</ets>, OF.
<ets>preisier</ets>, <ets>prisier</ets>, F. <ets>priser</ets>, L.
<ets>pretiare</ets> to prize, fr. <ets>pretium</ets> price. See
<er>Price</er>, <pos>n.<pos>, and cf. <er>Appreciate</er>,
<er>Praise</er>, <pos>n.<pos>, <er>Prize</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To commend; to applaud; to
express approbation of; to laud; -- applied to a person or his
acts.</def> \'bdI <xex>praise</xex> well thy wit.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Let her own works <qex>praise</qex> her in the gates.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxxi. 31.</qau>

<q>We <qex>praise</qex> not Hector, though his name, we know,
Is great in arms; 't is hard to <qex>praise</qex> a foe.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To extol in words or song; to magnify; to
glorify on account of perfections or excellent works; to do honor
to; to display the excellence of; -- applied especially to the
Divine Being.</def>

<q><qex>Praise</qex> ye him, all his angels; <qex>praise</qex> ye
him, all his hosts!</q>
<qau>Ps. cxlviii. 2.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To value; to appraise.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Piers Plowman.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- To commend; laud; eulogize; celebrate; glorify;
magnify.</syn> <usage> -- To <er>Praise</er>, <er>Applaud</er>,
<er>Extol</er>. To <xex>praise</xex> is to set at high price; to
<xex>applaud</xex> is to greet with clapping; to <xex>extol</xex>
is to bear aloft, to exalt. We may <xex>praise</xex> in the
exercise of calm judgment; we usually <xex>applaud</xex> from
impulse, and on account of some specific act; we <xex>extol</xex>
under the influence of high admiration, and usually in strong, if
not extravagant, language.</usage>

<hw>Praise</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>preis</ets>, OF.
<ets>preis</ets> price, worth, value, estimation. See
<er>Praise</er>, <pos>v.<pos>, <er>Price</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Commendation for worth; approval expressed; honor rendered
because of excellence or worth; laudation; approbation.</def>

<q>There are men who always confound the <qex>praise</qex> of
goodness with the practice.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Praise</xex> may be expressed by an individual,
and thus differs from <xex>fame</xex>, <xex>renown</xex>, and
<xex>celebrity</xex>, which are always the expression of the
approbation of numbers, or public commendation.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Especially, the joyful tribute of gratitude or
homage rendered to the Divine Being; the act of glorifying or
extolling the Creator; worship, particularly worship by song,
distinction from prayer and other acts of worship; <as>as, a
service of <ex>praise</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The object, ground, or reason of praise.</def>

<q>He is thy <qex>praise</qex>, and he is thy God.</q>
<qau>Deut. x.<?/<?/.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Encomium; honor; eulogy; panegyric; plaudit;
applause; acclaim; eclat; commendation; laudation.</syn>

<ets>pr\'bek<rsdot/ta</ets> original, natural, usual, common,
vulgar.]</ety> <def>Any one of the popular dialects descended
from, or akin to, Sanskrit; -- in distinction from the Sanskrit,
which was used as a literary and learned language when no longer
spoken by the people. Pali is one of the <xex>Prakrit</xex>
dialects.</def>

<hw>Prance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To walk or strut about in a pompous, showy
manner, or with warlike parade.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pran"gos</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the
native name in Afghanistan.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus
of umbelliferous plants, one species of which (<spn>P.
pabularia</spn>), found in Thibet, Cashmere, Afghanistan, etc.,
has been used as fodder for cattle. It has decompound leaves with
very long narrow divisions, and a highly fragrant smell
resembling that of new clover hay.</def>

<hw>Prawn</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>prane</ets>, of unknown origin; cf. L. <ets>perna</ets> a
sea mussel.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of numerous
species of large shrimplike Crustacea having slender legs and
long antenn\'91. They mostly belong to the genera
<xex>Pandalus</xex>, <xex>Pal\'91mon</xex>,
<xex>Pal\'91monetes</xex>, and <xex>Peneus</xex>, and are much
used as food. The common English prawn in <xex>Pal\'91mon
serratus</xex>.</def>

<note><hand/ The name is often applied to any large
shrimp.</note>

instrument, similar to the phenakistoscope, for presenting to
view, or projecting upon a screen, images the natural motions of
real objects.</def>

<hw>Pray</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prayed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Praying</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>preien</ets>, OF. <ets>preier</ets>, F.
<ets>prier</ets>, L. <ets>precari</ets>, fr. <ets>prex</ets>,
<ets>precis</ets>, a prayer, a request; akin to Skr.
<ets>prach</ets> to ask, AS. <ets>frignan</ets>,
<ets>fr\'c6nan</ets>, <ets>fricgan</ets>, G. <ets>fragen</ets>,
Goth. <ets>fra\'a1hnan</ets>. Cf. <er>Deprecate</er>,
<er>Imprecate</er>, <er>Precarious</er>.]</ety> <def>To make
request with earnestness or zeal, as for something desired; to
make entreaty or supplication; to offer prayer to a deity or
divine being as a religious act; specifically, to address the
Supreme Being with adoration, confession, supplication, and
thanksgiving.</def>

<q> And to his goddess pitously he <qex>preyde</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>When thou <qex>prayest</qex>, enter into thy closet, and when
thou hast shut thy door, <qex>pray</qex> to thy Father which is
in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret shall reward thee
openly.</q>
<qau>Matt. vi. 6.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>I pray</col>, <or/ (by ellipsis)
<col>Pray</col></mcol>, <cd>I beg; I request; I entreat you; --
used in asking a question, making a request, introducing a
petition, etc.; as, <xex>Pray<xex>, allow me to go.</cd></cs>

<q>I <qex>pray</qex>, sir. why am I beaten?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To entreat; supplicate; beg; implore; invoke;
beseech; petition.</syn>

<hw>Pray</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To address
earnest request to; to supplicate; to entreat; to implore; to
beseech.</def>

<q>And as this earl was <qex>preyed</qex>, so did he.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>We <qex>pray</qex> you . . . by ye reconciled to God.</q>
<qau>2 Cor. v. 20.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To ask earnestly for; to seek to obtain by
supplication; to entreat for.</def>

<q>I know not how to <qex>pray</qex> your patience.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To effect or accomplish by praying; <as>as, to
<ex>pray</ex> a soul out of purgatory</as>.</def>

<au>Milman.</au>

<cs><col>To pray in aid</col>. <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>To call in as a helper one who has an interest in the
cause</cd>. <au>Bacon</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A phrase often used
to signify claiming the benefit of an argument. See under
<er>Aid</er>.</cd></cs>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<hw>Pray"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who prays;
a supplicant.</def>

<hw>Prayer</hw> <pr>(<?/; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>preiere<ets>, OF. <ets>preiere<ets>, F. <ets>pri\'8are<ets>,
fr. L. <ets>precarius<ets> obtained by prayer, fr.
<ets>precari<ets> to pray. See <er>Pray</er>, <pos>v.
i.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of praying, or of asking
a favor; earnest request or entreaty; hence, a petition or
memorial addressed to a court or a legislative body.</def>
\'bdTheir meek <xex>preyere<xex>.\'b8

<au>Chaucer</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of addressing supplication to a
divinity, especially to the true God; the offering of adoration,
confession, supplication, and thanksgiving to the Supreme Being;
<as>as, public <ex>prayer</ex>; secret
<ex>prayer</ex>.</as></def>

<q>As he is famed for mildness, peace, and <qex>prayer</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The form of words used in praying; a formula of
supplication; an expressed petition; especially, a supplication
addressed to God; <as>as, a written or extemporaneous
<ex>prayer</ex>; to repeat one's <ex>prayers</ex>.</as></def>

<q>He made those excellent <qex>prayers</qex> which were
published immediately after his death.</q>
<qau>Bp. Fell.</qau>

<cs><col>Prayer book</col>, <cd>a book containing devotional
prayers.</cd> -- <col>Prayer meeting</col>, <cd>a meeting or
gathering for prayer to God.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Petition; orison; supplication; entreaty;
suit.</syn>

<hw>Prayer"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Given to
prayer; praying much or often; devotional.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>prayerful</xex> man.\'b8 <au>J. S. Blackie</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>Prayer"ful*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Prayer"ful*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Prayer"less</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not
using prayer; habitually neglecting prayer to God; without
prayer.</def> \'bdThe next time you go <xex>prayerless</xex> to
bed.\'b8

<au>Baxter.</au>

-- <wordforms><wf>Prayer"less*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Prayer"less*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pray"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <def><pos>a. & n.</pos> from
<er>Pray</er>, <pos>v.</pos></def>

<cs><mcol><col>Praying insect</col>, <col>locust</col>, <or/
mantis</mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a mantis, especially
<spn>Mantis religiosa</spn>. See <er>Mantis</er>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Praying machine</col>, <or/ <col>Praying
wheel</col></mcol>, <cd>a wheel on which prayers are pasted by
Buddhist priests, who then put the wheel in rapid revolution.
Each turn in supposed to have the efficacy of an oral repetition
of all the prayers on the wheel.  Sometimes it is moved by a
stream.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pray"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With supplication to
God.</def>

<hw>Pre-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L. <ets>prae</ets>, adv. &
prep., before, akin to <ets>pro</ets>, and to E. <ets>for</ets>,
prep.: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82-</ets>. See <er>Pro-</er>, and cf.
<er>Prior</er>.]</ety> <def>A prefix denoting <xex>priority</xex>
(of time, place, or rank); <as>as, <ex>precede</ex>, to go
before; <ex>pre</ex>cursor, a forerunner; <ex>pre</ex>fix, to fix
or place before</as>; <ex>pre</ex>\'89minent eminent before or
above others. <ex>Pre-</ex> is sometimes used intensively, <as>as
in <ex>pre</ex>potent, very potent</as>.</def> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>pr\'91-</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pre*ac`cu*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Previous accusation.</def>

<hw>Preace</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. & n.</pos>
<def>Press.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Preach</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preached</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preaching</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>prechen</ets>,
OF. <ets>preechier</ets>, F. <ets>pr\'88cher</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>praedicare</ets> to cry in public, to proclaim;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>dicare</ets> to make known,
<ets>dicere</ets> to say; or perhaps from (assumed) LL.
<ets>praedictare</ets>. See <er>Diction</er>, and cf.
<er>Predicate</er>, <er>Predict</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
proclaim or publish tidings; specifically, to proclaim the
gospel; to discourse publicly on a religious subject, or from a
text of Scripture; to deliver a sermon.</def>

<q>How shall they <qex>preach</qex>, except they be sent?</q>
<qau>Rom. x. 15.</qau>

<q>From that time Jesus began to <qex>preach</qex>.</q>
<qau>Matt. iv. 17.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To give serious advice on morals or religion; to
discourse in the manner of a preacher.</def>

<hw>Preach</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To proclaim by
public discourse; to utter in a sermon or a formal religious
harangue.</def>

<q>That Cristes gospel truly wolde <qex>preche</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>The Lord hath anointed me to <qex>preach</qex> good tidings
unto the meek.</q>
<qau>Isa. lxi. 1.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To inculcate in public discourse; to urge with
earnestness by public teaching.</def> \'bdI have
<xex>preached</xex> righteousness in the great congregation.\'b8

<au>Ps. xl. 9.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To deliver or pronounce; <as>as, to
<ex>preach</ex> a sermon</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To teach or instruct by preaching; to inform by
preaching.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdAs ye are
<xex>preached</xex>.\'b8

<au>Southey.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To advise or recommend earnestly.</def>

<q>My master <qex>preaches</qex> patience to him.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>To preach down</col>, <cd>to oppress, or humiliate by
preaching. <xex>Tennyson<xex>.</cd> -- <col>To preach up</col>,
<cd>to exalt by preaching; to preach in support of; as, <xex>to
preach up<xex> equality.</cd></cs>

<hw>Preach</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pr\'88che</ets>,
fr. <ets>pr\'88cher</ets>. See <er>Preach</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <def>A religious discourse.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>Preach"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. OF.
<ets>preeschierre</ets>, <ets>prescheur</ets>, F.
<ets>pr\'88cheur</ets>, L. <ets>praedicator</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who preaches; one who discourses publicly on
religious subjects.</def>

<q>How shall they hear without a <qex>preacher</qex>?</q>
<qau>Rom. x. 14.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who inculcates anything with
earnestness.</def>

<q>No <qex>preacher</qex> is listened to but Time.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<cs><col>Preacher bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a
toucan.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre"end</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82bende</ets> (cf. It. & Sp. <ets>prebenda</ets>), from
L. <ets>praebenda</ets>, from L. <ets>praebere</ets> to hold
forth, afford, contr. fr. <ets>praehibere</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>

<hw>Pre"cant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pre*ca"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>precarius</ets> obtained by begging or prayer, depending on
request or on the will of another, fr. <ets>precari</ets> to
pray, beg. See <er>Pray</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Depending
on the will or pleasure of another; held by courtesy; liable to
be changed or lost at the pleasure of another; <as>as,
<ex>precarious</ex> privileges</as>.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Held by a doubtful tenure; depending on unknown
causes or events; exposed to constant risk; not to be depended on
for certainty or stability; uncertain; <as>as, a
<ex>precarious</ex> state of health; <ex>precarious</ex>
fortunes.</as></def> \'bdIntervals of partial and
<xex>precarious</xex> liberty.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Uncertain; unsettled; unsteady; doubtful; dubious;
equivocal.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Precarious</er>,
<er>Uncertain</er>. <xex>Precarious</xex> in stronger than
<xex>uncertain</xex>. Derived originally from the Latin
<xex>precari</xex>, it first signified \'bdgranted to
entreaty,\'b8 and, hence, \'bdwholly dependent on the will of
another.\'b8 Thus it came to express the highest species of
uncertainty, and is applied to such things as depend wholly on
future casualties.</usage>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pre*ca"ri*ous*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pre*ca"ri*ous*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>precatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of praying;
supplication; entreaty.</def>

<au>Cotton.</au>

<def>Suppliant; beseeching.</def>

<cs><col>Precatory words</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>words of
recommendation, request, entreaty, wish, or expectation, employed
in wills, as distinguished from <xex>express directions<xex>; --
in some cases creating a trust.</cd></cs>

<au>Jarman.</au>

<hw>Pre*cau"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82cation</ets>, L. <ets>praecautio</ets>, fr.
<ets>praecavere</ets>, <ets>praecautum</ets>, to guard against
beforehand; <ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>cavere</ets> be on
one's guard. See <er>Pre-</er>, and <er>Caution</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Previous caution or care; caution previously
employed to prevent mischief or secure good; <as>as, his life was
saved by <ex>precaution</ex></as>.</def>

<q>They [ancient philosophers] treasured up their supposed
discoveries with miserable <qex>precaution</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. H. Newman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A measure taken beforehand to ward off evil or
secure good or success; a precautionary act; <as>as, to take
<ex>precautions</ex> against accident</as>.</def>

<hw>Pre*cau"tion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82cautionner</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To warn or
caution beforehand.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<-- p. 1126 -->

<hw>Pre`ce*da"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Preceding; antecedent; previous.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>Pre*cede"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preceded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Preceding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecedere</ets>, <ets>praecessum</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>cedere</ets> to go, to be in motion: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82ceder</ets>. See <er>Pre-</er>, and
<er>Cede</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To go before in order of
time; to occur first with relation to anything.</def> \'bdHarm
<xex>precedes</xex> not sin.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To go before in place, rank, or
importance.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to be preceded; to preface; to
introduce; -- used with <xex>by</xex> or <xex>with</xex> before
the instrumental object.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>It is usual to <qex>precede</qex> hostilities by a public
declaration.</q>
<qau>Kent.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pre*ced"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pre*ced"en*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82c\'82dence</ets>. See <er>Precede</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or state of preceding or going before in
order of time; priority; <as>as, one event has
<ex>precedence</ex> of another</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act or state of going or being before in
rank or dignity, or the place of honor; right to a more honorable
place; superior rank; <as>as, barons have <ex>precedence</ex> of
commoners</as>.</def>

<q>Which of them [the different desires] has the
<qex>precedency</qex> in determining the will to the next
action?</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Antecedence; priority; pre\'89minence; preference;
superiority.</syn>

<hw>Pre*ced"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecedens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>praecedere</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82c\'82dent</ets>. See
<er>Precede</er>.]</ety> <def>Going before; anterior; preceding;
antecedent; <as>as, <ex>precedent</ex> services</as>.</def>
<au>Shak.</au> \'bdA <xex>precedent</xex> injury.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<cs><col>Condition precedent</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a
condition which precede the vesting of an estate, or the accruing
of a right.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prec"e*dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Something done or said that may serve as an example to
authorize a subsequent act of the same kind; an authoritative
example.</def>

<q>Examples for cases can but direct as <qex>precedents</qex>
only.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A preceding circumstance or condition; an
antecedent; hence, a prognostic; a token; a sign.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A rough draught of a writing which precedes a
finished copy.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A judicial decision which
serves as a rule for future determinations in similar or
analogous cases; an authority to be followed in courts of
justice; forms of proceeding to be followed in similar
cases.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Example; antecedent.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Precedent</er>, <er>Example</er>. An <xex>example</xex> in a
similar case which may serve as a rule or guide, but has no
authority out of itself. A <xex>precedent</xex> is something
which comes down to us from the past with the sanction of usage
and of common consent. We quote <xex>examples</xex> in
literature, and <xex>precedents</xex> in law.</usage>

<hw>Prec"e*dent*ed</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having a precedent;
authorized or sanctioned by an example of a like kind.</def>

<au>Walpole.</au>

<hw>Prec`e*den"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of the
nature of a precedent; having force as an example for imitation;
<as>as, <ex>precedential</ex> transactions</as>.</def>

<q>All their actions in that time are not <qex>precedential</qex>
to warrant posterity.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Pre*ced"ent*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Beforehand; antecedently.</def>

<hw>Pre*ced"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Going

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>In the direction toward
which stars appear to move. See <er>Following</er>, 2.</def>

<hw>Pre*cen"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pre"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pre*ces"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<def>The act of going before, or forward.</def>

<cs><col>Lunisolar precession</col>. <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <cd>See
under <er>Lunisolar</er>.</cd> -- <col>Planetary
precession</col>, <cd>that part of the precession of the
equinoxes which depends on the action of the planets alone.</cd>
-- <col>Precession of the equinoxes</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>,
<cd>the slow backward motion of the equinoctial points along the
ecliptic, at the rate of 50.2<sec/ annually, caused by the action
of the sun, moon, and planets, upon the protuberant matter about
the earth's equator, in connection with its diurnal rotation; --
so called because either equinox, owing to its westerly motion,
comes to the meridian sooner each day than the point it would
have occupied without the motion of precession, and thus
<xex>precedes<xex> that point continually with reference to the
time of transit and motion.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*ces"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to pression; <as>as, the <ex>precessional</ex>
movement of the equinoxes</as>.</def>

<hw>Pre"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OF.

<q>She is more <qex>precious</qex> than rules.</q>
<qau>Prov. iii. 15.</qau>

<q>Many things which are most <qex>precious</qex> are neglected

<qau>Hooker.</qau>

rascal.</note>

<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

of being precious; costliness; dearness.</def>

<hw>Prec"i*pice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<mhw>{ <hw>Pre*cip"i*tance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pre*cip"i*tan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[From <er>Precipitant</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state
of being precipitant, or precipitate; headlong hurry; excessive
or rash haste in resolving, forming an opinion, or executing a
purpose; precipitation; <as>as, the <ex>precipitancy</ex> of
youth</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Precipitance</xex> of judgment.\'b8

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecipitans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>praecipitare</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82cipitant</ets>. See
<er>Precipitate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Falling or rushing
headlong; rushing swiftly, violently, or recklessly; moving
precipitately.</def>

<q>They leave their little lives
Above the clouds, <qex>precipitant</qex> to earth.</q>
<qau>J. Philips.</qau>

<q>Should he return, that troop so blithe and bold,
<qex>Precipitant</qex> in fear would wing their flight.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unexpectedly or foolishly brought on or
hastened; rashly hurried; hasty; sudden; reckless.</def> <au>Jer.
Taylor</au>. \'bd<xex>Precipitant</xex> rebellion.\'b8 <au>Eikon
Basilike</au>.

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tant</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Any force or reagent which causes the formation of a
precipitate.</def>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tant*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With rash or

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tant*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecipitatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praecipitare</ets> to
precipitate, fr. <ets>praeceps</ets> headlong. See
<er>Precipice</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Overhasty; rash;
<as>as, the king was too <ex>precipitate</ex> in declaring
war</as>.</def>

<au>Clarendon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lacking due deliberation or care; hurried; said
or done before the time; <as>as, a <ex>precipitate</ex>
measure</as>.</def> \'bdThe rapidity of our too
<xex>precipitate</xex> course.\'b8

<au>Landor.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Falling, flowing, or rushing, with steep
descent; headlong.</def>

<q><qex>Precipitate</qex> the furious torrent flows.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Ending quickly in death; brief and fatal;
<as>as, a <ex>precipitate</ex> case of disease</as>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
<ets>praecipitatum</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82cipit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An
insoluble substance separated from a solution in a concrete state
by the action of some reagent added to the solution, or of some
force, such as heat or cold. The precipitate may fall to the
bottom (whence the name), may be diffused through the solution,
or may float at or near the surface.</def>

<cs><col>Red precipitate</col> <fld>(Old. Chem)</fld>,
<cd>mercuric oxide (<chform>HgO</chform>) a heavy red crystalline
powder obtained by heating mercuric nitrate, or by heating
mercury in the air. Prepared in the latter manner, it was the
<altname>precipitate per se</altname> of the alchemists.</cd> --
<col>White precipitate</col> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A heavy white amorphous powder (<chform>NH2.HgCl</chform>)
obtained by adding ammonia to a solution of mercuric chloride or
corrosive sublimate; -- formerly called also <altname>infusible
white precipitate</altname>, and now <altname>amido-mercuric
chloride</altname>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A white crystalline
substance obtained by adding a solution of corrosive sublimate to
a solution of sal ammoniac (ammonium chloride); -- formerly
called also <altname>fusible white
precipitate</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Precipitated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Precipitating</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw
headlong; to cast down from a precipice or height.</def>

<q>She and her horse had been <qex>precipitated</qex> to the
pebbled region of the river.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To urge or press on with eager haste or
violence; to cause to happen, or come to a crisis, suddenly or
too soon; <as>as, <ex>precipitate</ex> a journey, or a
conflict</as>.</def>

<q>Back to his sight <qex>precipitates</qex> her steps.</q>
<qau>Glover.</qau>

<q>If they be daring, it may <qex>precipitate</qex> their
designs, and prove dangerous.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To separate from a solution,
or other medium, in the form of a precipitate; <as>as, water
<ex>precipitates</ex> camphor when in solution with
alcohol</as>.</def>

<q>The light vapor of the preceding evening had been
<qex>precipitated</qex> by the cold.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
dash or fall headlong.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>So many fathom down <qex>precipitating</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hasten without preparation.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To separate from a solution
as a precipitate. See <er>Precipitate</er>, <pos>n.</pos></def>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tate*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
a precipitate manner; headlong; hastily; rashly.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Pre*cip`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecipitatio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82cipitation</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
precipitating, or the state of being precipitated, or thrown
headlong.</def>

<q>In peril of <qex>precipitation</qex>
From off rock Tarpeian.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A falling, flowing, or rushing downward with
violence and rapidity.</def>

<q>The hurry, <qex>precipitation</qex>, and rapid motion of the
water, returning . . . towards the sea.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Great hurry; rash, tumultuous haste;
impetuosity.</def> \'bdThe <xex>precipitation</xex> of
inexperience.\'b8

<au>Rambler.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The act or process from a
solution.</def>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*ta`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecipitator</ets> an overthrower.]</ety> <def>One who
precipitates, or urges on with vehemence or rashness.</def>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>Pre*cip"i*tous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeceps</ets>, <ets>-cipitis</ets>: cf. OF.
<ets>precipiteux</ets>. See <er>Precipice</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Steep, like a precipice; <as>as, a

<hw>\'d8Pr<?/`cis"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. See
<er>Precise</er>.]</ety> <def>A concise or abridged statement or
view; an abstract; a summary.</def>

<hw>Pre*cise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecisus</ets> cut off, brief, concise, p. p. of
<ets>praecidere</ets> to cut off in front, to cut off;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>caedere</ets> to cut: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82cis</ets>. Cf. <er>Concise</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Having determinate limitations; exactly or sharply defined
or stated; definite; exact; nice; not vague or equivocal; <as>as,
<ex>precise</ex> rules of morality</as>.</def>

<q>The law in this point is not <qex>precise</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>For the hour <qex>precise</qex>
Exacts our parting hence.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Strictly adhering or conforming to rule; very
nice or exact; punctilious in conduct or ceremony; formal;
ceremonious.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>He was ever <qex>precise</qex> in promise-keeping.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Accurate; exact; definite; correct; scrupulous;
punctilious; particular; nice; formal. See
<er>Accurate</er>.</syn>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pre*cise"ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pre*cise"ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre*ci"sian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who limits, or restrains.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An overprecise person; one rigidly or
ceremoniously exact in the observance of rules; a formalist; --
formerly applied to the English Puritans.</def>

<q>The most dissolute cavaliers stood aghast at the dissoluteness
of the emancipated <qex>precisian</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pre*ci"sian*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being a precisian; the practice of a
precisian.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pre*ci"sian*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A precisian.</def>

<hw>Pre*ci"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82cision</ets>, L. <ets>praecisio</ets> a cutting off.
See <er>Precise</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of being
precise; exact limitation; exactness; accuracy; strict conformity
to a rule or a standard; definiteness.</def>

<q>I have left out the utmost <qex>precisions</qex> of
fractions.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Preciseness; exactness; accuracy; nicety.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>Precision</er>, <er>Preciseness</er>.
<xex>Precision</xex> is always used in a good sense; <as>as,
<ex>precision</ex> of thought or language; <ex>precision</ex> in
military evolutions</as>. <xex>Preciseness</xex> is sometimes
applied to persons or their conduct in a disparaging sense, and
<xex>precise</xex> is often used in the same way.</usage>

<hw>Pre*ci"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Cutting
off; <fld>(Logic)</fld> exactly limiting by cutting off all that
is not absolutely relative to the purpose; <as>as,
<ex>precisive</ex> censure; <ex>precisive</ex>
abstraction.</as></def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<-- p. 1127 -->

<hw>Pre*clude"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Precluded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Precluding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecludere</ets>, <ets>praeclusum</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>claudere</ets> to shut. See <er>Close</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To put a barrier before;
hence, to shut out; to hinder; to stop; to impede.</def>

<q>The valves <qex>preclude</qex> the blood from entering the
veins.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To shut out by anticipative action; to prevent
or hinder by necessary consequence or implication; to deter
action of, access to, employment of, etc.; to render ineffectual;
to obviate by anticipation.</def>

<q>This much will obviate and <qex>preclude</qex> the
objections.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<hw>Pre*clu"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeclusio</ets>. See <er>Preclude</er>.]</ety> <def>The act
of precluding, or the state of being precluded; a shutting
out.</def>

<hw>Pre*clu"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Shutting
out; precluding, or tending to preclude; hindering.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pre*clu"sive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8Pre"co*ces</hw>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <ety>[NL.]</ety>
