<hw>Pre*co"cious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praecox</ets>, <ets>-ocis</ets>, and <ets>praecoquus</ets>,
fr. <ets>praecoquere</ets> to cook or ripen beforehand;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>coquere</ets> to cook. See 3d
<er>Cook</er>, and cf. <er>Apricot</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Ripe or mature before the proper or natural time; early or
prematurely ripe or developed; <as>as, <ex>precocious</ex>
trees</as>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Developed more than is natural or usual at a
given age; exceeding what is to be expected of one's years; too
forward; -- used especially of mental forwardness; <as>as, a
<ex>precocious</ex> child; <ex>precocious</ex>
talents.</as></def>

<hw>Pre*co"cious*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a precocious
manner.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pre*co"cious*ness</hw>, <hw>Pre*coc"i*ty</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82cocit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being precocious; untimely ripeness; premature development,
especially of the mental powers; forwardness.</def>

<q>Saucy <qex>precociousness</qex> in learning.</q>
<qau>Bp. Mannyngham.</qau>

<q>That <qex>precocity</qex> which sometimes distinguishes
uncommon genius.</q>
<qau>Wirt.</qau>

<hw>Pre*des"ti*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praedestinatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praedestinare</ets> to

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pre*des"ti*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Predestinated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Predestinating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Predestine</er>.]</ety> <def>To predetermine or foreordain;
to appoint or ordain beforehand by an unchangeable purpose or
decree; to pre\'89lect.</def>

<q>Whom he did foreknow, he also did <qex>predestinate</qex> to
be conformed to the image of his Son.</q>
<qau>Rom. viii. 29.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To predetermine; foreordain; preordain; decree;
predestine; foredoom.</syn>

<hw>Pre*des`ti*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praedestinatio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82destination</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
predestinating.</def>

<q><qex>Predestination</qex> had overruled their will.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>The purpose of Good from
eternity respecting all events; especially, the preordination of
men to everlasting happiness or misery. See
<er>Calvinism</er>.</def>

<hw>Pre*des"ti*na*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Determining beforehand; predestinating.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pre*des"ti*na`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>pr\'82destinateur</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who
predestinates, or foreordains.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who holds to the doctrine of predestination;
a predestinarian.</def>

<au>Cowley.</au>

<hw>Pred"i*ca*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

praiseworthy. See <er>Predicate</er>.]</ety> <def>Capable of

<hw>Pred"i*ca*ble</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything
affirmable of another; especially, a general attribute or notion
as affirmable of, or applicable to, many individuals.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>One of the five most general
relations of attributes involved in logical arrangements, namely,
genus, species, difference, property, and accident.</def>

<hw>Pre*dic"a*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82dicament</ets>, L. <ets>praedicamentum</ets>. See
<er>Predicate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A class or kind

situation or state; especially, an unfortunate or trying position
or condition.</def> \'bdO woeful sympathy; piteous
<xex>predicament</xex>!\'b8

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>See <er>Category</er>.</def>

<hw>Pred"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Predicated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Predicating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praedicatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praedicare</ets> to cry in
public, to proclaim. See <er>Preach</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To assert to belong to something; to affirm (one thing of
another); <as>as, to <ex>predicate</ex> whiteness of
snow</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To found; to base.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<note><hand/ <xex>Predicate</xex> is sometimes used in the United
States for <xex>found</xex> or <xex>base</xex>; as, to
<xex>predicate</xex> an argument <xex>on</xex> certain
principles; to <xex>predicate</xex> a statement <xex>on</xex>
information received. <xex>Predicate</xex> is a term in logic,
and used only in a single case, namely, when we affirm one thing
<xex>of</xex> another. \'bdSimilitude is not
<xex>predicated</xex> of essences or substances, but of figures
and qualities only.\'b8</note>

<au>Cudworth.</au>

<hw>Pred"i*cate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To affirm something
of another thing; to make an affirmation.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<hw>Pred"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praedicatum</ets>, neut. of <ets>praedicatus</ets>, p. p.
<ets>praedicare</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82dicat</ets>. See
<er>Predicate</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>That which is affirmed or denied of the
subject. In these propositions, \'bd<xex>Paper is
white</xex>,\'b8  \'bd<xex>Ink is not white</xex>,\'b8 
<xex>whiteness</xex> is the <xex>predicate</xex> affirmed of
paper and denied of ink.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The word or words in a
proposition which express what is affirmed of the subject.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Affirmation; declaration.</syn>

<hw>Pred"i*cate</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praedicatus</ets>, p. p.]</ety> <def>Predicated.</def>

<hw>Pre`dis*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Predisposed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Predisposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>pre-</ets> +
<ets>dispose</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82disposer</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To dispose or incline beforehand; to give a
predisposition or bias to; <as>as, to <ex>predispose</ex> the
mind to friendship</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make fit or susceptible beforehand; to give a
tendency to; <as>as, debility <ex>predisposes</ex> the body to
disease</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Predisposing causes</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>causes
which render the body liable to disease; predisponent
causes.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*dis`po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<pos>n.</pos><ety>[Pref. <ets>pre-</ets> +

<ets>pr\'82disposition</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
predisposing, or the state of being predisposed; previous
inclination, tendency, or propensity; predilection; -- applied to
the mind; <as>as, a <ex>predisposition</ex> to anger</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Previous fitness or adaptation to any change,
impression, or purpose; susceptibility; -- applied to material
things; <as>as, the <ex>predisposition</ex> of the body to
disease</as>.</def>

<hw>Pre*\'89mp"tion</hw> <pr>(?; 215)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>pre-</ets> + <ets>emption</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82emption</ets>. See <er>Redeem</er>.]</ety> <def>The
act or right of purchasing before others.</def> Specifically:
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The privilege or prerogative formerly enjoyed
by the king of buying provisions for his household in preference
to others.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The right
of an actual settler upon public lands (particularly those of the
United States) to purchase a certain portion at a fixed price in
preference to all other applicants.</def> <au>Abbott.</au>

who holds a prior to purchase certain public land.</def>

<hw>Pre`\'89n*gage"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

to bind or attach previously; to preoccupy.</def>

<q>But he was <qex>pre\'89ngaged</qex> by former ties.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pre`\'89n*gage"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Prior engagement, obligation, or attachment, as by contract,
promise, or affection.</def>

<q>My <qex>pre\'89ngagements</qex> to other themes were not
unknown to those for whom I was to write.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<-- in orig, "perexamined" had no dieresis over the second "e"
because it was broken by a hyphen at the end of a line.  Thus
this transcription is in such cases style of the original rather
than typographically identical.  Similarly, above at "preengaged"
and below, at "preexist" -->

<hw>Pref"ace</hw> <pr>(?; 48)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82face</ets>; cf. Sp. <ets>prefacio</ets>,
<ets>prefacion</ets>, It. <ets>prefazio</ets>,
<ets>prefazione</ets>; all fr. L. <ets>praefatio</ets>, fr.
<ets>praefari</ets> to speak or say beforehand; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>fari</ets>, <ets>fatus</ets>, to speak. See
<er>Fate</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Something spoken as
introductory to a discourse, or written as introductory to a book
or essay; a proem; an introduction, or series of preliminary
remarks.</def>

<q>This superficial tale
Is but a <qex>preface</qex> of her worthy praise.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Heaven's high behest no <qex>preface</qex> needs.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>The prelude or
introduction to the canon of the Mass.</def>

<au>Addis & Arnold.</au>

<cs><col>Proper preface</col> <fld>(Ch. of Eng. & Prot. Epis.
Ch.)</fld>, <cd>a portion of the communion service, preceding the
prayer of consecration, appointed for certain seasons.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Introduction; preliminary; preamble; proem; prelude;
prologue.</syn>

<hw>Pre"fect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praefectus</ets>, fr. <ets>praefectus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>praeficere</ets> to set over; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>facere</ets> to make: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82fet</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A Roman officer who controlled or superintended
a particular command, charge, department, etc.; <as>as, the
<ex>prefect</ex> of the aqueducts; the <ex>prefect</ex> of a
camp, of a fleet, of the city guard, of provisions; the pretorian
<ex>prefect</ex>, who was commander of the troops guarding the
emperor's person.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A superintendent of a department who has control
of its police establishment, together with extensive powers of
municipal regulation.</def> <mark>[France]</mark>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>In the Greek and Roman Catholic churches, a
title of certain dignitaries below the rank of bishop.</def>

<cs><col>Apostolic prefect</col> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld>, <cd>the
head of a mission, not of episcopal rank.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*fer"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preferred</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preferring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82f\'82rer</ets>, L. <ets>praeferre</ets>;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>ferre</ets> to bear or carry. See
1st <er>Bear</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To carry or bring
(something) forward, or before one; hence, to bring for
consideration, acceptance, judgment, etc.; to offer; to present;
to proffer; to address; -- said especially of a request, prayer,
petition, claim, charge, etc.</def>

<q>He spake, and to her hand <qex>preferred</qex> the bowl.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>Presently <qex>prefer</qex> his suit to C\'91sar.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Three tongues <qex>prefer</qex> strange orisons on high.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To go before, or be before, in estimation; to
outrank; to surpass.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThough
maidenhood <xex>prefer</xex> bigamy.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to go before; hence, to advance before
others, as to an office or dignity; to raise; to exalt; to
promote; <as>as, to <ex>prefer</ex> an officer to the rank of
general</as>.</def>

<q>I would <qex>prefer</qex> him to a better place.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To set above or before something else in
estimation, favor, or liking; to regard or honor before another;
to hold in greater favor; to choose rather; -- often followed by
<xex>to</xex>, <xex>before</xex>, or <xex>above</xex>.</def>

<q>If I <qex>prefer</qex> not Jerusalem above my chief joy.</q>
<qau>Ps. cxxxvii. 6.</qau>

<q><qex>Preferred</qex> an infamous peace before a most just
war.</q>
<qau>Knolles.</qau>

<cs><col>Preferred stock</col>, <cd>stock which takes a dividend
before other capital stock; -- called also <altname>preference
stock</altname> and <altname>preferential
stock</altname>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To choose; elect. See <er>Choose</er>.</syn>

<hw>Preg"nant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praegnans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>genere</ets>, <ets>gignere</ets>, to beget: cf. F.

<er>Kin</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Being with young, as a female; having conceived;

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Heavy with important contents, significance, or
issue; full of consequence or results; weighty; <as>as,

argument.\'b8 <au>Prynne</au>. \'bd A <xex>pregnant</xex>
brevity.\'b8<-- pregnant silence -->

<au>E. Everett.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Full of promise; abounding in ability,
resources, etc.; <as>as, a <ex>pregnant</ex> youth</as>.</def>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<q>Wherein the <qex>pregnant</qex> enemy does much.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

in which more is implied than is said; as, the beasts

trembling with fright.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prehn"ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[So called

structure, and rarely in distinct crystals. It is a hydrous
silicate of alumina and lime.</def>

<hw>Prehn*it"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

substance; -- probably so called from the resemblance of the
wartlike crystals to the mammill\'91 on the surface of
prehnite.</def>

<hw>Pre*judge"</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prejudged</er>
<pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prejudging</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>pre</ets> +
<ets>judge</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82juger</ets>. Cf.
<er>Prejudicate</er>, <er>Prejudice</er>.]</ety> <def>To judge
before hearing, or before full and sufficient examination; to
decide or sentence by anticipation; to condemn beforehand.</def>

<q>The committee of council hath <qex>prejudged</qex> the whole
case, by calling the united sense of both houses of
Parliament\'bd a universal clamor.\'b8</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

of prejudging; decision before sufficient examination.</def>

<hw>Pre*ju"di*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Biased by opinions formed prematurely;

<hw>Pre*ju"di*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prejudicated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prejudicating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Prejudge</er>.]</ety> <def>To determine beforehand,
especially to disadvantage; to prejudge.</def>

<q>Our dearest friend
<qex>Prejudicates</qex> the business.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<au>Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<def>With prejudice.</def>

<hw>Pre*ju`di*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of prejudicating, or of judging without
due examination of facts and evidence; prejudgment.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A preliminary
inquiry and determination about something which belongs to a
matter in dispute.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A previous treatment
and decision of a point; a precedent.</def>

<hw>Pre*ju"di*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Forming a judgment without due examination;
prejudging.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Prej"u*dice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82judice</ets>, L. <ets>praejudicium</ets>;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>judicium</ets> judgment. See
<er>Prejudicate</er>, <er>Judicial</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Foresight.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Naught might hinder his quick <qex>prejudize</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An opinion or judgment formed without due
examination; prejudgment; a leaning toward one side of a question
from other considerations than those belonging to it; an
unreasonable predilection for, or objection against, anything;
especially, an opinion or leaning adverse to anything, without
just grounds, or before sufficient knowledge.</def>

<q>Though often misled by <qex>prejudice</qex> and passion, he
was emphatically an honest man.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A bias on the part of judge,
juror, or witness which interferes with fairness of
judgment.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Mischief; hurt; damage; injury; detriment.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<q>England and France might, through their amity,
Breed him some <qex>prejudice</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Prejudgment; prepossession; bias; harm; hurt;
damage; detriment; mischief; disadvantage.</syn>

<hw>Prej"u*dice</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Prejudiced</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Prejudicing</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pr\'82judicier</ets>. See <er>Prejudice</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cause to have prejudice;
to prepossess with opinions formed without due knowledge or
examination; to bias the mind of, by hasty and incorrect notions;
to give an unreasonable bent to, as to one side or the other of a
cause; <as>as, to <ex>prejudice</ex> a critic or a
juryman</as>.</def>

<q>Suffer not any beloved study to <qex>prejudice</qex> your mind
so far as to despise all other learning.</q>
<qau>I. Watts</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To obstruct or injure by prejudices, or by
previous bias of the mind; hence, generally, to hurt; to damage;
to injure; to impair; <as>as, to <ex>prejudice</ex> a good
cause</as>.</def>

<q>Seek how may <qex>prejudice</qex> the foe.</q>
<qau>Shak</qau>

<hw>Prej`u*di"cial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praejudicialis</ets> belonging to a preceding judgment: cf.
F. <ets>pr\'82judiciel</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Biased, possessed, or blinded by prejudices;
<as>as, to look with a <ex>prejudicial</ex> eye</as>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holyday.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Tending to obstruct or impair; hurtful;
injurious; disadvantageous; detrimental.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<q>His going away . . . was most <qex>prejudicial</qex> and most
ruinous to the king's affairs.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<hw>Prel"a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Prel"ate</hw> <pr>(?; 48)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82lat</ets>, LL. <ets>praelatus</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>praelatus</ets>, used as p. p. of <ets>praeferre</ets> to
prefer, but from a different root. See <er>Elate</er>.]</ety>
<def>A clergyman of a superior order, as an archbishop or a
bishop, having authority over the lower clergy; a dignitary of
the church.</def>

<note><hand/ This word and the words derived from it are often
used invidiously, in English ecclesiastical history, by
dissenters, respecting the Established Church system.</note>

<q>Hear him but reason in divinity, . . . 
You would desire the king were made a <qex>prelate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pre*lim"i*na*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.

measures; <ex>preliminary</ex> examinations.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Introductory; preparatory; prefatory; proemial;
previous; prior; precedent; antecedent.</syn>

<hw>Pre*lim"i*na*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Preliminaries</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>That which
precedes the main discourse, work, design, or business; something
introductory or preparatory; <as>as, the <ex>preliminaries</ex>
to a negotiation or duel; to take one's <ex>preliminaries</ex>
the year before entering college.</as></def>

<syn>Syn. -- Introduction; preface; prelude.</syn>

<hw>Pre"lude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82lude</ets> (cf. It. <ets>preludio</ets>, LL.
<ets>praeludium</ets>), fr. L. <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>ludus</ets> play. See <er>Prelude</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety> <def>An introductory performance, preceding and
preparing for the principal matter; a preliminary part, movement,
strain, etc.; especially <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, a strain introducing
the theme or chief subject; a movement introductory to a fugue,
yet independent; -- with recent composers often synonymous with
<xex>overture</xex>.</def>

<q>The last Georgic was a good <qex>prelude</qex> to the
\'92nis</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<q>The cause is more than the <qex>prelude</qex>, the effect is
more than the sequel, of the fact.</q>
<qau>Whewell.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Preface; introduction; preliminary; preamble;
forerunner; harbinger; precursor.</syn>

<hw>Pre*lude"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preluded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Preluding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeludere</ets>, <ets>praelusum</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>ludere</ets> to play: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82luder</ets>. See <er>Ludicrous</er>.]</ety> <def>To
play an introduction or prelude; to give a prefatory performance;
to serve as prelude.</def>

<q>The musicians <qex>preluded</qex> on their instruments.</q>
<qau>Sir. W. Scott.</qau>

<q>We are <qex>preluding</qex> too largely, and must come at once
to the point.</q>
<qau>Jeffrey.</qau>

<hw>Pre*lude"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
introduce with a previous performance; to play or perform a
prelude to; <as>as, to <ex>prelude</ex> a concert with a lively
air</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To serve as prelude to; to precede as
introductory.</def>

<q>[Music] <qex>preluding</qex> some great tragedy.</q>
<qau>Longfellow</qau>

<hw>Pre*lud"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, preludes; one who plays a prelude.</def>

<au>Mason.</au>

pertaining to a prelude; of the nature of a prelude;

<def>Preludial.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Pre*lum"bar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Situated immediately in front of the
loins;- applied to the dorsal part of the abdomen.</def>

<hw>Pre*lu"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Prelude</er>.]</ety> <def>Of the nature of a prelude;
introductory; indicating that something of a like kind is to

<au>Thomson.</au>

--<wordforms><wf>Pre*lu"sive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre`ma*ture"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praematurus</ets>; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>maturus</ets> ripe. See <er>Mature</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Mature or ripe before the proper time; <as>as, the
<ex>premature</ex> fruits of a hotbed</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Happening, arriving, existing, or performed
before the proper or usual time; adopted too soon; too early;
untimely; <as>as, a <ex>premature</ex> fall of snow; a
<ex>premature</ex> birth; a <ex>premature</ex> opinion;
<ex>premature</ex> decay.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Arriving or received without due authentication
or evidence; <as>as, a <ex>premature</ex> report</as>.</def>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pre`ma*ture"ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pre`ma*ture"ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre`ma*tu"ri*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82maturit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being premature; early, or untimely, ripeness; <as>as, the
<ex>prematurity</ex> of genius</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pre"max*il"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Premaxill\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL. See
<er>Pre-</er>, and <er>Maxilla</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>A bone on either side of the middle line between the nose
and mouth, forming the anterior part of each half of the upper
jawbone; the intermaxilla. In man the premaxill\'91 become united
and form the incisor part of the maxillary bone.</def>

pertaining to the premaxill\'91; intermaxillary.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A premaxilla.</def></def2>

<hw>Pre*med"i*tate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<er>Premeditating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.

<hw>Prem"ise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Premises</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <altsp>[Written also,
less properly, <asp>premiss</asp>.]</altsp> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82misse</ets>, fr. L. <ets>praemissus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>praemittere</ets> to send before; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>mittere</ets> to send. See <er>Mission</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A proposition antecedently supposed or proved;
something previously stated or assumed as the basis of further
argument; a condition; a supposition.</def>

<q>The <qex>premises</qex> observed,
Thy will by my performance shall be served.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Logic)</fld> <def>Either of the first two
propositions of a syllogism, from which the conclusion is
drawn.</def>

<note>
\'bdAll sinners deserve punishment: A B is a sinner.\'b8

These propositions, which are the <xex>premises</xex>, being true
or admitted, the conclusion follows, that A B deserves
punishment.</note>

<q>While the <qex>premises</qex> stand firm, it is impossible to
shake the conclusion.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Matters
previously stated or set forth; esp., that part in the beginning
of a deed, the office of which is to express the grantor and
grantee, and the land or thing granted or conveyed, and all that
precedes the <xex>habendum</xex>; the thing demised or
granted.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>A piece of real estate; a
building and its adjuncts; <as>as, to lease <ex>premises</ex>; to
trespass on another's <ex>premises</ex>.</as></def>

<hw>Pre*mise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Premised</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Premising</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From L.
<ets>praemissus</ets>, p. p., or E. <ets>premise</ets>, n. See
<er>Premise</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To send
before the time, or beforehand; hence, to cause to be before
something else; to employ previously.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The <qex>premised</qex> flames of the last day.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>If venesection and a cathartic be <qex>premised</qex>.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To set forth beforehand, or as introductory to
the main subject; to offer previously, as something to explain or
aid in understanding what follows; especially, to lay down
premises or first propositions, on which rest the subsequent
reasonings.</def>

<q>I <qex>premise</qex> these particulars that the reader may
know that I enter upon it as a very ungrateful task.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Pre*mise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make a
premise; to set forth something as a premise.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Prem"iss</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Premise.</def>

<au> Whately. I. Watts</au>

<hw>Pre*mit"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
premise.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Donne.</au>

<hw>Pre"mi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Premiums</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>praemium</ets>, originally, what one has got before or
better than others; <ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>emere</ets> to
take, buy. See <er>Redeem</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A reward
or recompense; a prize to be won by being before another, or
others, in a competition; reward or prize to be adjudged; a
bounty; <as>as, a <ex>premium</ex> for good behavior or
scholarship, for discoveries, etc</as>.</def>

<q> To think it not the necessity, but the <qex>premium</qex> and
privilege of life, to eat and sleep without any regard to
glory.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<q>The law that obliges parishes to support the poor offers a
<qex>premium</qex> for the encouragement of idleness.</q>
<qau>Franklin.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Something offered or given for the loan of
money; bonus; -- sometimes synonymous with <xex>interest</xex>,
but generally signifying a sum in addition to the capital.</def>

<q>People were tempted to lend, by great <qex>premiums</qex> and
large interest.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sum of money paid to underwriters for
insurance, or for undertaking to indemnify for losses of any
kind.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A sum in advance of, or in addition to, the
nominal or par value of anything; <as>as, gold was at a
<ex>premium</ex>; he sold his stock at a
<ex>premium</ex>.</as></def>

<hw>Pre*oc"cu*pate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To anticipate; to take before.</def>

<hw>Pre*oc`cu*pa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anticipation of objections.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Pre*oc"cu*py</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preoccupied</er>
<pr>(-p\'c6d)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preoccupying</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82occuper</ets>. See <er>Preoccupate</er>,
<er>Occupy</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To take possession of
before another; <as>as, to <ex>preoccupy</ex> a country not
before held</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To prepossess; to engage, occupy, or engross the
attention of, beforehand; hence, to prejudice.</def>

<q>I Think it more respectful to the reader to leave something to
reflections than to <qex>preoccupy</qex> his judgment.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<hw>Pre*oc"u*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Placed just in front of the eyes, as
the antenn\'91 of certain insects.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos>
<def>One of the scales just in front of the eye of a reptile or
fish.</def></def2>

<hw>Pre*om"i*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
ominate beforehand; to portend.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pre*par"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being prepared.</def> \'bdMedicine <xex>preparable</xex> by
art.\'b8

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Prep`a*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82paration</ets>, L. <ets>praeparatio</ets>. See
<er>Prepare</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of preparing or fitting beforehand for a
particular purpose, use, service, or condition; previous
arrangement or adaptation; a making ready; <as>as, the
<ex>preparation</ex> of land for a crop of wheat; the
<ex>preparation</ex> of troops for a campaign.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being prepared or made ready;
preparedness; readiness; fitness; <as>as, a nation in good
<ex>preparation</ex> for war</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which makes ready, prepares the way, or
introduces; a preparatory act or measure.</def>

<q>I will show what <qex>preparations</qex> there were in nature
for this dissolution.</q>
<qau>T. Burnet.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which is prepared, made, or compounded by a
certain process or for a particular purpose; a combination.
Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> Any medicinal substance fitted for
use. <sd>(b)</sd> Anything treated for preservation or
examination as a specimen. <sd>(c)</sd> Something prepared for
use in cookery.</def>

<q>I wish the chemists had been more sparing who magnify their
<qex>preparations</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<q>In the <qex>preparations</qex> of cookery, the most volatile
parts of vegetables are destroyed.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>An army or fleet.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>The holding over of a note
from one chord into the next chord, where it forms a temporary
discord, until resolved in the chord that follows; the
anticipation of a discordant note in the preceding concord, so
that the ear is prepared for the shock. See
<er>Suspension</er>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Accomplishment; qualification.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pre*par"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82paratif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to prepare or make
ready; having the power of preparing, qualifying, or fitting;
preparatory.</def>

<q>Laborious quest of knowledge <qex>preparative</qex> to this
work.</q>
<qau> South.</qau>

\'bdA <xex>preparative</xex> unto sermons.\'b8

<au>Hooker.</au>

<au>Agassiz.</au>

<hw>Pre*par"a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<ets>pr\'82paratoire</ets>.]</ety> <def>Preparing the way for

<hw>Pre*pare"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prepare<?/</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preparing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>pr\'82parer</ets>,
L. <ets>praeparare</ets>; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>parare</ets> to make ready. See <er>Pare</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To fit, adapt, or qualify for a particular
purpose or condition; to make ready; to put into a state for use
or application; <as>as, to <ex>prepare</ex> ground for seed; to
<ex>prepare</ex> a lesson.</as></def>

<q>Our souls, not yet <qex>prepared</qex> for upper light.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To procure as suitable or necessary; to get
ready; to provide; <as>as, to <ex>prepare</ex> ammunition and
provisions for troops; to <ex>prepare</ex> ships for defence; to
<ex>prepare</ex> an entertainment.</as></def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>That they may <qex>prepare</qex> a city for habitation.</q>
<qau>Ps. cvii. 36</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To fit; adjust; adapt; qualify; equip; provide;
form; make; make; ready.</syn>

<-- p. 1131 -->

<xex>prepare</xex> for dinner.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make one's self ready; to get ready; to take
the necessary previous measures; <as>as, to <ex>prepare</ex> for
death</as>.</def>

<hw>Pre*pon"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
preponderate</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pre*pon"der*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pre*pon"der*an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>pr\'82pond\'82rance</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being preponderant;
superiority or excess of weight, influence, or power, etc.; an
outweighing.</def>

<q>The mind should . . . reject or receive proportionably to the
<qex>preponderancy</qex> of the greater grounds of
probability.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>In a few weeks he had changed the relative position of all the
states in Europe, and had restored the equilibrium which the
<qex>preponderance</qex> of one power had destroyed.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Gun.)</fld> <def>The excess of weight of that
part of a canon behind the trunnions over that in front of
them.</def>

<hw>Pre*pon"der*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeponderans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>: cf. F. 
<ets>pr\'82pond\'82rant</ets>. See <er>Preponderate</er>.]</ety>
<def>Preponderating; outweighing; overbalancing; -- used
literally and figuratively; <as>as, a <ex>preponderant</ex>
weight; of <ex>preponderant</ex> importance.</as></def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pre*pon"der*ant*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre*pon"der*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preponderated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preponderating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. 
<ets>praeponderatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praeponderare</ets>;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>ponderare</ets> to weigh, fr.,
<ets>pondus</ets>, <ets>ponderis</ets>, a weight. See
<er>Ponder</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To outweigh; to overpower by weight; to exceed
in weight; to overbalance.</def>

<q>An inconsiderable weight, by distance from the center of the
balance, will <qex>preponderate</qex> greater magnitudes.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To overpower by stronger or moral power.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to prefer; to incline; to decide.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The desire to spare Christian blood <qex>preponderates</qex>
him for peace.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Pre*pon"der*ate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To exceed in
weight; hence, to incline or descend, as the scale of a balance;
figuratively, to exceed in influence, power, etc.; hence; to
incline to one side; <as>as, the affirmative side
<ex>preponderated</ex></as>.</def>

<q>That is no just balance in which the heaviest side will not
<qex>preponderate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Wilkins.</qau>

<hw>Pre*pon"der*a`ting*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>In a preponderating manner; preponderantly.</def>

<ets>praeponderatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act or state of

of reasons</as>.</def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<hw>Pre*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>Prep`o*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praepositio</ets>, fr. <ets>praeponere</ets> to place
before; <ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>ponere</ets> to put, place:
cf. F.  <ets>pr\'82position</ets>. See <er>Position</er>, and cf.
<er>Provost</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>A word employed to connect a
noun or a pronoun, in an adjectival or adverbial sense, with some
other word; a particle used with a noun or pronoun (in English
always in the objective case) to make a phrase limiting some
other word; -- so called because usually placed before the word
with which it is phrased; <as>as, a bridge <xex>of</xex> iron; he
comes <xex>from</xex> town; it is good <xex>for</xex> food; he
escaped <xex>by</xex> running.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A proposition; an exposition; a discourse.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He made a long <qex>preposition</qex> and oration.</q>
<qau>Fabyan.</qau>

<hw>Pre`pos*sess"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prepossessed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prepossessing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To preoccupy, as ground or land; to take
previous possession of.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To preoccupy, as the mind or heart, so as to
preclude other things; hence, to bias or prejudice; to give a
previous inclination to, for or against anything; esp., to induce
a favorable opinion beforehand, or at the outset.</def>

<q>It created him enemies, and <qex>prepossessed</qex> the lord
general.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<hw>Pre`pos*ses"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Preoccupation; prior possession.</def>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Preoccupation of the mind by an opinion, or

impression; bias; -- generally, but not always, used in a
favorable sense; <as>as, the <ex>prepossessions</ex> of

<hw>Pre*pos"ter*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos><ety>[L.
<ets>praeposterus</ets>; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>posterus</ets> coming after, latter. See
<er>Posterior</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having that first which ought to be last;
inverted in order.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The method I take may be censured as <qex>preposterous</qex>,
because I thus treat last of the antediluvian earth, which was
first in the order of nature.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Contrary to nature or reason; not adapted to the
end; utterly and glaringly foolish; unreasonably absurd;
perverted.</def> \'bdMost <xex>preposterous</xex>
conclusions.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Preposterous</qex> ass, that never read so far!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Absurd; perverted; wrong; irrational; foolish;
monstrous. See <er>Absurd</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pre"puce</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82puce</ets>, L. <ets>praeputium</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The foreskin.</def>

<hw>Pre*pu"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the prepuce.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pre*raph"a*el*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pre*raph"a*el*i`tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Fine Arts)</fld> <def>The doctrine or practice of a school
of modern painters who profess to be followers of the painters
before Raphael. Its adherents advocate careful study from nature,
delicacy and minuteness of workmanship, and an exalted and
delicate conception of the subject.</def>

<hw>Pre*raph"a*el*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to the style called preraphaelitism; <as>as, a
<ex>preraphaelite</ex> figure; a <ex>preraphaelite</ex>
landscape.</as></def>

<au>Ruskin.</au>

<hw>Pre*raph"a*el*ite</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who favors or
practices art as it was before Raphael; one who favors or
advocates preraphaelitism.</def>

<hw>Pre*reg"nant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
reigns before another; a sovereign predecessor.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Warner.</au>

<hw>Pre`re*mote</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <def>More remote
in previous time or prior order.</def>

<q>In some cases two more links of causation may be introduced;
one of them may be termed the <qex>preremote</qex> cause, the
other the postremote effect.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<hw>Pre`re*quire"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
require beforehand.</def>

<q>Some things are <qex>prerequired</qex> of us.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<hw>Pre*req"ui*site</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Previously required; necessary as a preliminary to any
proposed effect or end; <as>as, <ex>prerequisite</ex> conditions
of success</as>.</def>

<hw>Pre*req"ui*site</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Something previously
required, or necessary to an end or effect proposed.</def>

<q>The necessary <qex>prerequisites</qex> of freedom.</q>
<qau> Goldsmith.</qau>

<hw>Pre`re*solve"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preresolved</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preresolving</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To resolve beforehand;
to predetermine.</def>

<au> Sir E. Dering.</au>

<hw>Pre*rog"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82rogative</ets>, from L. <ets>praerogativa</ets>
precedence in voting, preference, privilege, fr.
<ets>praerogativus</ets> that is asked before others for his
opinion, that votes before or first, fr. <ets>praerogare</ets> to
ask before another; <ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>rogare</ets> to
ask. See <er>Rogation</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>An exclusive or peculiar privilege; prior and
indefeasible right; fundamental and essential possession; -- used
generally of an official and hereditary right which may be
asserted without question, and for the exercise of which there is
no responsibility or accountability as to the fact and the manner
of its exercise.</def>

<q>The two faculties that are the <qex>prerogative</qex> of man
-- the powers of abstraction and imagination.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<q>An unconstitutional exercise of his
<qex>prerogative</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Precedence; pre\'89minence; first rank.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Then give me leave to have <qex>prerogative</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<note><hand/ The term came into general use in the conflicts
between the Crown and Parliaments of Great Britain, especially in
the time of the Stuarts.</note>

<cs><col>Prerogative Court</col> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld>, <cd>a
court which formerly had authority in the matter of wills and
administrations, where the deceased left <xex>bona
notabilia<xex>, or effects of the value of five pounds, in two or
more different dioceses. <au>Blackstone</au>.</cd> --
<col>Prerogative office</col>, <cd>the office in which wills
proved in the Prerogative Court were registered.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Privilege; right. See <er>Privilege</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pre*rog"a*tived</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Endowed
with a prerogative, or exclusive privilege.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pre*rog"a*tive*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
prerogative.</def>

<hw>Pre"sage</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82sage</ets>, L. <ets>praesagium</ets>, from
<ets>praesagire</ets>. See <er>Presage</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Something which foreshows or portends a future
event; a prognostic; an omen; an augury.</def> \'bdJoy and shout
-- <xex>presage</xex> of victory.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Power to look the future, or the exercise of
that power; foreknowledge; presentiment.</def>

<q>If there be aught of <qex>presage</qex> in the mind.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Prognostic; omen; token; sign; presentiment.</syn>

<hw>Pre*sage"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Presaged</er>
<pr>(-s<amac/jd")</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Presaging</er>. ]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82sager</ets>, L. <ets>praesagire</ets>: <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>sagire</ets> to perceive acutely or sharply. See
<er>Sagacious</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To have a presentiment of; to feel beforehand;
to foreknow.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To foretell; to predict; to foreshow; to
indicate.</def>

<q>My dreams <qex>presage</qex> some joyful news at hand.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pre*sage"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To form or utter a
prediction; -- sometimes used with <xex>of</xex>.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pre*sage"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of
presages; ominous.</def>

<q>Dark in the glass of some <qex>presageful</qex> mood.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Pres"by*ope</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>One who has presbyopia; a farsighted
person.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pres`by*o"pi*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/
old, n., an old man + <?/, <?/, the eye.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>A defect of vision consequent upon advancing age. It is due
to rigidity of the crystalline lens, which produce<?/ difficulty
of accommodation and recession of the near point of vision, so
that objects very near the eyes can not be seen distinctly
without the use of convex glasses. Called also
<altname>presbytia</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pres`by*op"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Affected
by presbyopia; also, remedying presbyopia; farsighted.</def>

<hw>Pres"by*o`py</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>presbyopie</ets>.]</ety> <def>See <er>Presbyopia</er>.</def>

<hw>Pres"by*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L. an
elder, fr. Gr. <?/. See <er>Priest</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>An elder in the early Christian church. See 2d
Citation under <er>Bishop</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 1.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Ch. of Eng.  & Prot. Epis. Ch.)</fld> <def>One
ordained to the second order in the ministry; -- called also
<altname>priest</altname>.</def>

<q>I rather term the one sort <qex>presbyter</qex> than
priest.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<q>New <qex>presbyter</qex> is but old priest writ large.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Presbyterian Ch.)</fld> <def>A member of a
presbytery whether lay or clerical.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A Presbyterian.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hudibras.</au>

<cs><col>Reformed Presbyterians</col>. <cd>See

<hw>Pres`by*te"ri*an*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>presbyt\'82rianisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>That
form of church government which invests presbyters with all
spiritual power, and admits no prelates over them; also, the
faith and polity of the Presbyterian churches, taken
collectively.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pres`by*te"ri*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Presbytery</er>, 4.</def>

<hw>Pres"by*ter*ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
office or station of a presbyter; presbyterate.</def>

<hw>Pres"by*ter*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Presbyteries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>presbyterium</ets>, Gr. <?/. See <er>Presbyter</er>, and cf.
<er>Presbyterium</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A body of elders in the early Christian
church.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Presbyterian Ch.)</fld> <def>A judicatory
consisting of all the ministers within a certain district, and
one layman, who is a ruling elder, from each parish or church,
commissioned to represent the church in conjunction with the
pastor. This body has a general jurisdiction over the churches
under its care, and next below the provincial synod in
authority.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The Presbyterian religion of polity.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Tatler.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>That part of the
church reserved for the officiating priest.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The residence of a priest or clergyman.</def>

<au> Gwilt.</au>

<hw>Pre"sci*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<-- p. 1132 -->

<hw>Pre/sci*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praesciens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cut off; to abstract.</def>

<hw>Pre*scribe"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prescribed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prescribing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praescribere</ets>, <ets>praescriptum</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>scriebe</ets> to write. See <er>Scribe</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay down authoritatively as a guide,
direction, or rule of action; to impose as a peremptory order; to
dictate; to appoint; to direct.</def>

<q><qex>Prescribe</qex> not us our duties.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Let streams <qex>prescribe</qex> their fountains where to
run.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To direct, as a remedy to be
used by a patient; as, the doctor <xex>prescribed</xex>
quinine.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To appoint; order; command; dictate; ordain;
institute; establish.</syn>

<hw>Pre*scribe"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To give
directions; to dictate.</def>

<q>A forwardness to <qex>prescribe</qex> to their opinions.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To influence by long use</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To write or to give medical
directions; to indicate remedies; as, to <xex>prescribe</xex> for
a patient in a fever.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To claim by prescription; to
claim a title to a thing on the ground of immemorial use and
enjoyment, that is, by a custom having the force of law.</def>

<hw>Pre*scrib"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
prescribes.</def>

<hw>Pre"script</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praescriptus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praescribere</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>prescrit</ets>. See <er>Prescribe</er>.]</ety>
<def>Directed; prescribed.</def> \'bd A <xex>prescript</xex> from
of words.\'b8

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Pre"script</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praescriptum</ets>: cf. OF. <ets>prescript</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Direction; precept; model prescribed.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A medical prescription.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Fell.</au>

<hw>Pre*scrip`ti*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n</pos><def>,
The quality or state of being prescriptible.</def>

<au>Story.</au>

<hw>Pre*scrip"ti*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>prescriptible</ets>. ]</ety> <def>Depending on, or
derived from, prescription; proper to be prescribed.</def>

<au>Grafton.</au>

<hw>Pre*scrip"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prescription</ets>, L. <ets>praescriptio</ets>,an
inscription, preface, precept, demurrer, prescription (in sense
3), fr. <ets>praescribere</ets>. See <er>Prescribe</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of prescribing, directing, or dictating;
direction; precept; also, that which is prescribed.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A direction of a remedy or of
remedies for a disease, and the manner of using them; a medical
recipe; also, a prescribed remedy.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A prescribing for title; the
claim of title to a thing by virtue immemorial use and enjoyment;
the right or title acquired by possession had during the time and
in the manner fixed by law.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>That profound reverence for law and <qex>prescription</qex>
which
has long been characteristic of Englishmen.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Prescription</xex> differs from
<xex>custom</xex>, which is a local usage, while
<xex>prescription</xex> is personal, annexed to the person only.
<xex>Prescription</xex> only extends to incorporeal rights, such
as aright of way, or of common. What the law gives of <xex>common
rights</xex> is not the subject of <xex>prescription</xex>.
<xex>Blackstone</xex>. <xex>Cruise</xex>. <xex>Kent</xex>. In
Scotch law, <xex>prescription</xex> is employed in the sense in
which <xex>limitation</xex> is used in England and America,
namely, to express that operation of the lapse of time by which
obligations are extinguished or title protected. <xex>Sir
T</xex>. <xex>Craig</xex>. <xex>Erskine</xex>.</note>

<hw>Pre*scrip"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praescriptivus</ets> of a demurrer or legal
exception.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Consisting in, or
acquired by, immemorial or long-continued use and enjoyment;
<as>as, a <ex>prescriptive</ex> right of title</as>; pleading the
continuance and authority of long custom.</def>

<q>The right to be drowsy in protracted toil has become
<qex>prescriptive</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. M. Mason.</qau>

<hw>Pre*scrip"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
prescription.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pre*scu"tum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Prescuta</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Pr\'91-</er>, and <er>Scutum</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The first of the four pieces composing
the dorsal part, or tergum, of a thoracic segment of an insect.
It is usually small and inconspicuous.</def>

<hw>Pre"se*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82s\'82ance</ets>. See <er>Preside</er>.]</ety>
<def>Priority of place in sitting.</def><mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Carew.</au>

<hw>Pre`se*lect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
select beforehand.</def>

<hw>Pres"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82sence</ets>, L. <ets>praesentia</ets>. See
<er>Present</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The state of being
present, or of being within sight or call, or at hand; -- opposed
to <xex>absence</xex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The place in which one is present; the part of
space within one's ken, call, influence, etc.; neighborhood
without the intervention of anything that forbids
intercourse.</def>

<q>Wrath shell be no more
Thenceforth, but in thy <qex>presence</qex> joy entire.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Specifically, neighborhood to the person of one
of superior of exalted rank; also, presence chamber.</def>

<q>In such a <qex>presence</qex> here to plead my thoughts.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>An't please your grace, the two great cardinals.
Wait in the <qex>presence</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The whole of the personal qualities of an
individual; person; personality; especially, the person of a
superior, as a sovereign.</def>

<q>The Sovran <qex>Presence</qex> thus replied.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>An assembly, especially of person of rank or
nobility; noble company.</def>

<q>Odmar, of all this <qex>presence</qex> does contain,
Give her your wreath whom you esteem most fair.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Port, mien; air; personal appearence.</def>
\'bdRather dignity of presence than beauty of aspect.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>A graceful <qex>presence</qex> bespeaks acceptance.</q>
<qau> Collier.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Presence chamber</col>, <or/ <col>Presence
room</col></mcol>, <cd>the room in which a great personage
receives company. <au>Addison</au>.\'bd <xex>Chambers of
presence<xex>.\'b8  <au>Bacon</au>.</cd> -- <col>Presence of
mind</col>, <cd>that state of the mind in which all its faculties
are alert, prompt, and acting harmoniously in obedience to the
will, enabling one to reach, as it were spontaneously or by
intuition, just conclusions in sudden emergencies.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre`sen*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Previous sensation, notion, or idea.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Pre*sen"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praesensio</ets>, fr. <ets>praesentire</ets> to perceive
beforehand. See <er>Presentient</er>.]</ety> <def>Previous
perception.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pres"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82sent</ets>, L. <ets>praesens</ets>,<ets>-entis</ets>,
that is before one, in sight or at hand, p. p. of
<ets>praeesse</ets> to be before; <ets>prae</ets> before + 
<ets>esse</ets> to be. See <er>Essence</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Being at hand, within reach or call, within
certain contemplated limits; -- opposed to
<xex>absent</xex>.</def>

<q>These things have I spoken unto you, being yet
<qex>present</qex> with you.</q>
<qau>John xiv. 25.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Now existing, or in process; begun but not
ended; now in view, or under consideration; being at this time;
not past or future; <as>as, the <ex>present</ex> session of
Congress; the <ex>present</ex> state of affairs; the
<ex>present</ex> instance.</as></def>

<q>I'll bring thee to the <qex>present</qex> business</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Not delayed; immediate; instant;
coincident.</def>  \'bdA <xex>present</xex> recompense.\'b8 \'bdA
<xex>present</xex> pardon.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>An ambassador . . . desires a <qex>present</qex> audience.</q>
<qau>Massinger.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Ready; quick in emergency; as a
<xex>present</xex> wit.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Favorably attentive; propitious.</def>
<mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<q>To find a god so <qex>present</qex> to my prayer.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Present tense</col> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>the tense or
form of a verb which expresses action or being in the present
time; as, I <xex>am writing<xex>, I <xex>write<xex>, or I <xex>do
write<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pres"ent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82sent</ets>. See <er>Present</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Present time; the time being; time in progress
now, or at the moment contemplated; as, at this
<xex>present</xex>.</def>

<q>Past and <qex>present</qex>, wound in one.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Present
letters or instrument, as a deed of conveyance, a lease, letter
of attorney, or other writing; as in the phrase, \'bd Know all
men by these <xex>presents</xex>,\'b8 that is, by the writing
itself, \'bd per has literas <xex>praesentes</xex>; \'b8 -- in
this sense, rarely used in the singular.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>A present tense, or the form
of the verb denoting the present tense.</def>

<cs><col>At present</col>, <cd>at the present time; now.</cd> --
<col>For the present</col>, <cd>for the tine being;
temporarily.</cd> -- <col>In present</col>, <cd>at once, without
delay. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdWith them, <xex>in present<xex>,
half his kingdom; the rest to follow at his death.\'b8</cd>
<au>Milton.</au></cs>

<hw>Pre*sent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Presented</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Presenting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82senter</ets>, L. <ets>praesentare</ets>, fr.
<ets>praesens</ets>, a.  See <er>Present</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring or introduce into
the presence of some one, especially of a superior; to introduce
formally; to offer for acquaintance; <as>as, to <ex>present</ex>
an envoy to the king</as>; (with the reciprocal pronoun) to come
into the presence of a superior.</def>

<q>Now there was a day when the sons of God came to
<qex>present</qex> themselves before the lord.</q>
<qau>Job i. 6</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exhibit or offer to view or notice; to lay
before one's perception or cognizance; to set forth; to
<xex>present</xex> a fine appearance.</def>

<q>Lectorides's memory is ever . . . <qex>presenting</qex> him
with the thoughts of other persons.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To pass over, esp. in a ceremonious manner; to
give in charge or possession; to deliver; to make over.</def>

<q>So ladies in romance assist their knight,
<qex>Present</qex> the spear, and arm him for the fight.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To make a gift of; to bestow; to give, generally
in a formal or ceremonious manner; to grant; to confer.</def>

<q>My last, least offering, I <qex>present</qex> thee now.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Hence: To endow; to bestow a gift upon; to
favor, as with a donation; also, to court by gifts.</def>

<q>Octavia <qex>presented</qex> the poet for him admirable elegy
on her son Marcellus.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To present; to personate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> In specific uses; <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To nominate to an
ecclesiastical benefice; to offer to the bishop or ordinary as a
candidate for institution.</def>

<q>The patron of a church may <qex>present</qex> his clerk to a
parsonage or vicarage; that is, may offer him to the bishop of
the diocese to be instituted.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>To nominate for support at a public school or
other institution </def>. <au>Lamb</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>To lay
before a public body, or an official, for consideration, as
before a legislature, a court of judicature, a corporation, etc.;
<as>as, to <ex>present</ex> a memorial, petition, remonstrance,
or indictment</as>.</def> <sd>(d)</sd> <def>To lay before a court
as an object of inquiry; to give notice officially of, as a crime
of offence; to find or represent judicially; <as>as, a grand jury
<ex>present</ex> certain offenses or nuisances, or whatever they
think to be public injuries</as></def>. <sd>(e)</sd> <def>To
bring an indictment against </def>. <mark>[U.S]</mark>
<sd>(f)</sd> <def>To aim, point, or direct, as a weapon; <as>as,
to <ex>present</ex> a pistol or the point of a sword to the
breast of another</as></def>.

<cs><col>Pesent arms</col> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>, <cd>the command in
response to which the gun is carried perpendicularly in front of
the center of the body, and held there with the left hand
grasping it at the lower band, and the right hand grasping the
small of the stock, in token of respect, as in saluting a
superior officer; also, the position taken at such a
command.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*sent"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To
appear at the mouth of the uterus so as to be perceptible to the
finger in vaginal examination; -- said of a part of an infant
during labor.</def>

<hw>Pres"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82sent</ets> .]</ety> <def>Anything presented or given;
a gift; a donative; <as>as, a Christmas
<ex>present</ex></as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Gift; donation; donative; benefaction. See
<er>Gift</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pre*sent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Mil.)</fld>
<def>The position of a soldier in presenting arms; <as>as, to
stand at <ex>present</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pre*sent"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82sentable</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable or
admitting of being presented; suitable to be exhibited,
represented, or offered; fit to be brought forward or set forth;
hence, fitted to be introduced to another, or to go into society;
<as>as, ideas that are <ex>presentable</ex> in simple language;
she is not <ex>presentable</ex> in such a gown.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Admitting of the presentation of a clergiman;
<as>as, a church <ex>presentable</ex></as>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<hw>Pres`en*ta"ne*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praesentaneus</ets>. See <er>Present</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>Ready; quick; immediate in effect;
<as>as, <ex>presentaneous</ex> poison</as>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Harvey.</au>

<hw>Pres`en*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praesentatio</ets> a showing, representation: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82sentation</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
presenting, or the state of being presented; a setting forth; an
offering; bestowal.</def>

<q>Prayers are sometimes a <qex>presentation</qex> of mere
desires.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> Hence, <def>exhibition; representation; display;
appearance; semblance; show.</def>

<q>Under the <qex>presentation</qex> of the shoots his wit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is presented or given; a present; a
gift, <as>as, the picture was a <ex>presentation</ex></as>.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>The act of offering a
clergyman to the bishop or ordinary for institution in a
benefice; the right of presenting a clergyman.</def>

<q>If the bishop admits the patron's <qex>presentation</qex>, the
clerk so admitted is next to be instituted by him.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The particular position of the
child during labor relatively to the passage though which it is
to be brought forth; -- specifically designated by the part which
first appears at the mouth of the uterus; <as>as, a breech
<ex>presentation</ex></as>.</def>

<cs><col>Presentation copy</col>, <cd>a copy of a book,
engraving, etc., presented to some one by the author or artist,
as a token of regard.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*sent"a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Admitting the presentation of a clergyman;
<as>as, a <ex>presentative</ex> parsonage</as>.</def>

<au>Spelman.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Metaph.)</fld> <def>Capable of being directly

<q>The latter term, <qex>presentative</qex> faculty, I use . . .
in contrast and correlation to a \'bdrepresentative
faculty.\'b8</q>

<hw>Pres"ent*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>At present; at this time; now.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The towns and forts you <qex>presently</qex> have.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>At once; without delay; forthwith; also, less
definitely, soon; shortly; before long; after a little while; by
and by.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>And <qex>presently</qex> the fig tree withered away.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxi. 19.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>With actual presence; actually .</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>His precious body and blood <qex>presently three</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bp. Gardiner.</qau>

<hw>Pre*sent"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of presenting, or the state of being presented;
presentation.</def> \'bd Upon the heels of my
<xex>presentment</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Setting forth to view; delineation; appearance;
representation; exhibition.</def>

<q>Power to cheat the eye with blear illusion,
And give it false <qex>presentment</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The notice taken
by a grand jury of any offence from their own knowledge or
observation, without any bill of indictment laid before them,
<as>as, the <ex>presentment</ex> of a nuisance, a libel, or the
like</as>; also, an inquisition of office and indictment by a
grand jury; an official accusation presented to a tribunal by the
grand jury in an indictment, or the act of offering an
indictment; also, the indictment itself.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The official notice (formerly required to be given in court)
of the surrender of a copyhold estate.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<cs><col>Presentment of a bill of exchange</col>, <cd>the
offering of a bill to the drawee for acceptance, or to the
acceptor for payment. See <cref>Bill of exchange</cref>, under
<er>Bill</er>.</cd></cs>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<hw>Pre*serv"a*to*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Preservatories</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A preservative.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pre*serve"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preserved</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Preserving</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82server</ets>, from L. <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>servare</ets> to save, preserve; cf. L.
<ets>praeservare</ets> to observe beforehand. See
<er>Serve</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To keep or save from
injury or destruction; to guard or defend from evil, harm,
danger, etc.; to protect.</def>

<q>O Lord, thou <qex>preserved</qex> man and beast.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxvi. 6.</qau>

<q>Now, good angels <qex>preserve</qex> the king.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To save from decay by the use of some
preservative substance, as sugar, salt, etc.; to season and
prepare for remaining in a good state, as fruits, meat, etc.;
<as>as, to <ex>preserve</ex> peaches or grapes</as>.</def>

<q>You can not <qex>preserve</qex> it from tainting.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To maintain throughout; to keep intact; <as>as,
to <ex>preserve</ex> appearances; to <ex>preserve</ex>
silence.</as></def>

<cs><col>To preserve game</col>, <cd>to protect it from
extermination.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To keep; save; secure; uphold; sustain; defend;
spare; protect; guard; shield. See <er>Keep</er>.</syn>

<au>Shak.</au>

preparation; esp., fruit cooked with sugar; -- commonly in the
plural.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A place in which game, fish, etc., are preserved
for purposes of sport, or for food.</def>

<hw>Pre*side"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Presided</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Presiding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praesidere</ets>; <ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>sedere</ets>
to sit: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82sider</ets>. See <er>Sit</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To be set, or to sit, in the place of authority;
to occupy the place of president, chairman, moderator, director,
etc.; to direct, control, and regulate, as chief officer; <as>as,
to <ex>preside</ex> at a public meeting; to <ex>preside</ex> over

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exercise superintendence; to watch
over.</def>

<q>Some o'er the public magazines <qex>preside</qex>.</q>

<er>Presidency</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pres"i*den*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Presidencies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82sidence</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The function or
condition of one who presides; superintendence; control and
care.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The office of president; <as>as, Washington was
elected to the <ex>presidency</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The term during which a president holds his
office; <as>as, during the <ex>presidency</ex> of
Madison</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>One of the three great divisions of British
India, the Bengal, Madras, and Bombay Presidencies, each of which
had a council of which its governor was president.</def>

<hw>Pres"i*dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Precedent.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pres"i*dent</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Occupying the first rank
or chief place; having the highest authority; presiding.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>His angels <qex>president</qex>
In every province.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pres"i*dent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82sident</ets>, L. <ets>praesidens</ets>,
<ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>praesidere</ets>. See
<er>Preside</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who is elected or
appointed to preside; a presiding officer, as of a legislative
body.</def> Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The chief officer of
a corporation, company, institution, society, or the like</def>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The chief executive officer of the government
in certain republics; <as>as, the <ex>president</ex> of the
United States</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A protector; a guardian; a presiding
genius</def>. <mark>[Obs.]</mark></q>

<q>Just Apollo, <qex>president</qex> of verse.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<hw>Pres`i*den"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Presiding or watching over.</def>
\'bd<xex>Presidential</xex> angels.\'b8

<ex>presidential</ex> chair; a <ex>presidential</ex>

office and dignity of president; presidency.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>Pre*sphe"noid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<cs><col>Presphenoid bone</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>the
anterior part of the body of the sphenoid bone in front of the
basisphenoid. It is usually a separate bone in the young or
fetus, but becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult.</cd></cs>
