<hw>Press</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>An East Indian insectivore (<spn>Tupaia ferruginea</spn>).
It is arboreal in its habits, and has a bushy tail. The fur is
soft, and varies from rusty red to maroon and to brownish
black.</def>

<hw>Press</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Corrupt. fr.
<ets>prest</ets> ready money advanced, a loan; hence, earnest
money given soldiers on entering service. See <er>Prest</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <def>To force into service, particularly into
naval service; to impress.</def>

<q>To peaceful peasant to the wars is <qex>pressed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Press</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For <ets>prest</ets>,
confused with <ets>press</ets>.]</ety> <def>A commission to force
men into public service, particularly into the navy.</def>

<q>I have misused the king's <qex>press</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Press gang</col>, <or/
<col>Pressgang</col></mcol>, <cd>a detachment of seamen under the
command of an officer empowered to force men into the naval
service. See <cref>Impress gang</cref>, under
<er>Impress</er>.</cd> -- <col>Press money</col>, <cd>money paid
to a man enlisted into public service. See <cref>Prest
money</cref>, under <er>Prest</er>, <pos>a.</pos></cd></cs>

<hw>Press</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pressed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pressing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>presser</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pressare</ets> to press, fr.
<ets>premere</ets>, <ets>pressum</ets>, to press. Cf.
<er>Print</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To urge, or
act upon, with force, as weight; to act upon by pushing or
thrusting, in distinction from pulling; to crowd or compel by a
gradual and continued exertion; to bear upon; to squeeze; to
compress; <as>as, we <ex>press</ex> the ground with the feet when
we walk; we <ex>press</ex> the couch on which we repose; we
<ex>press</ex> substances with the hands, fingers, or arms; we
are <ex>pressed</ex> in a crowd.</as></def>

<q>Good measure, <qex>pressed</qex> down, and shaken
together.</q>
<qau>Luke vi. 38.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To squeeze, in order to extract the juice or
contents of; to squeeze out, or express, from something.</def>

<q>From sweet kernels <qex>pressed</qex>,
She tempers dulcet creams.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>And I took the grapes, and <qex>pressed</qex> them into
Pharaoh's cup, and I gave the cup into Pharaoh's hand.</q>
<qau>Gen. xl. 11.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To squeeze in or with suitable instruments or
apparatus, in order to compact, make dense, or smooth; <as>as, to
<ex>press</ex> cotton bales, paper, etc</as>.; to smooth by
ironing; <as>as, to <ex>press</ex> clothes</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To embrace closely; to hug.</def>

<q>Leucothoe shook at these alarms,
And <qex>pressed</qex> Palemon closer in her arms.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To oppress; to bear hard upon.</def>

<q><qex>Press</qex> not a falling man too far.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To straiten; to distress; <as>as, to be
<ex>pressed</ex> with want or hunger</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To exercise very powerful or irresistible
influence upon or over; to constrain; to force; to compel.</def>

<q>Paul was <qex>pressed</qex> in the spirit, and testified to
the Jews that Jesus was Christ.</q>
<qau>Acts xviii. 5.</qau>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To try to force (something upon some one); to
urge or inculcate with earnestness or importunity; to enforce;
<as>as, to <ex>press</ex> divine truth on an audience</as>.</def>

<q>He <qex>pressed</qex> a letter upon me within this hour.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>Be sure to <qex>press</qex> upon him every motive.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To drive with violence; to hurry; to urge on; to
ply hard; <as>as, to <ex>press</ex> a horse in a race</as>.</def>

<q>The posts . . . went cut, being hastened and
<qex>pressed</qex> on, by the king's commandment.</q>
<qau>Esther viii. 14.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>Press</xex> differs from <xex>drive</xex> and
<xex>strike</xex> in usually denoting a slow or continued
application of force; whereas <xex>drive</xex> and
<xex>strike</xex> denote a sudden impulse of force.</note>

<cs><col>Pressed brick</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Brick</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Press</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To exert
pressure; to bear heavily; to push, crowd, or urge with steady
force.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To move on with urging and crowding; to make
one's way with violence or effort; to bear onward forcibly; to
crowd; to throng; to encroach.</def>

<q>They <qex>pressed</qex> upon him for to touch him.</q>
<qau>Mark iii. 10.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To urge with vehemence or importunity; to exert
a strong or compelling influence; <as>as, an argument
<ex>presses</ex> upon the judgment</as>.</def>

<hw>Press</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>presse</ets>. See 4th
<er>Press</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An apparatus or machine
by which any substance or body is pressed, squeezed, stamped, or
shaped, or by which an impression of a body is taken; sometimes,
the place or building containing a press or presses.</def>

<note><hand/ Presses are differently constructed for various
purposes in the arts, their specific uses being commonly
designated; <as>as, a cotton <ex>press</ex>, a wine
<ex>press</ex>, a cider <ex>press</ex>, a copying <ex>press</ex>,
etc</as>. See <er>Drill press</er>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, a printing press.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The art or business of printing and publishing;
hence, printed publications, taken collectively, more especially
newspapers or the persons employed in writing for them; <as>as, a
free <ex>press</ex> is a blessing, a licentious <ex>press</ex> is
a curse</as>.</def><-- "the press" usually refers to newspaper
reporters -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An upright case or closet for the safe keeping
of articles; <as>as, a clothes <ex>press</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The act of pressing or thronging forward.</def>

<q>In their throng and <qex>press</qex> to that last hold.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Urgent demands of business or affairs; urgency;
<as>as, a <ex>press</ex> of engagements</as>.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>A multitude of individuals crowded together; <?/
crowd of single things; a throng.</def>

<q>They could not come nigh unto him for the
<qex>press</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mark ii. 4.</qau>

<cs><col>Cylinder press</col>, <cd>a printing press in which the
impression is produced by a revolving cylinder under which the
form passes; also, one in which the form of type or plates is
curved around a cylinder, instead of resting on a flat bed.</cd>
<col>Hydrostatic press</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Hydrostatic</er>.</cd> -- <col>Liberty of the press</col>,
<cd>the free right of publishing books, pamphlets, or papers,
without previous restraint or censorship, subject only to
punishment for libelous, seditious, or morally pernicious
matters.</cd> -- <col>Press bed</col>, <cd>a bed that may be
folded, and inclosed, in a press or closet.
<au>Boswell</au>.</cd> -- <col>Press of sail</col>,
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>as much sail as the state of the wind
will permit.</cd></cs>

<hw>Press"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, presses.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Presser bar</col>, <or/ <col>Presser
wheel</col></mcol> <fld>(Knitting machine)</fld>, <cd>a bar or
wheel which closes the barbs of the needles to enable the loops
of the yarn to pass over them.</cd> -- <col>Presser foot</col>,
<cd>the part of a sewing machine which rests on the cloth and
presses it down upon the table of the machine.</cd></cs>

<wordforms><wf>Press"ing*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pres`si*ros"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Press"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>Causing, or giving rise to, pressure
or to an increase of pressure; <as>as, <ex>pressor</ex> nerve
fibers, stimulation of which excites the vasomotor center, thus
causing a stronger contraction of the arteries and consequently
an increase of the arterial blood pressure</as>; -- opposed to
<contr>depressor</contr>.</def>

<au>Landois & Stirling.</au>

<hw>Press"back`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To pack,
or prepare for packing, by means of a press.</def>

<hw>Pres"sur*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pressure.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The juice of the grape extracted by the press;
also, a fee paid for the use of a wine press.</def>

<hw>Pres"sure</hw> <pr>(?; 138)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.,
fr. L. <ets>pressura</ets>, fr. <ets>premere</ets>. See 4th
<er>Press</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of pressing, or
the condition of being pressed; compression; a squeezing; a
crushing; <as>as, a <ex>pressure</ex> of the hand</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A contrasting force or impulse of any kind;
<as>as, the <ex>pressure</ex> of poverty; the <ex>pressure</ex>
of taxes; the <ex>pressure</ex> of motives on the mind; the
<ex>pressure</ex> of civilization.</as></def>

<q>Where the <qex>pressure</qex> of danger was not felt.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Affliction; distress; grievance.</def>

<q>My people's <qex>pressures</qex> are grievous.</q>
<qau>Eikon Basilike.</qau>

<q>In the midst of his great troubles and
<qex>pressures</qex>.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Urgency; <as>as, the <ex>pressure</ex> of
business</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Impression; stamp; character impressed.</def>

<q>All saws of books, all forms, all <qex>pressures</qex>
past.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>The action of a force against
some obstacle or opposing force; a force in the nature of a
thrust, distributed over a surface, often estimated with
reference to the upon a unit's area.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Atmospheric pressure</col>, <col>Center of
pressure</col>, etc.</mcol> <cd>See under <er>Atmospheric</er>,
<er>Center</er>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Back pressure</col>
<fld>(Steam engine)</fld>, <cd>pressure which resists the motion
of the piston, as the pressure of exhaust steam which does not
find free outlet.</cd> -- <col>Fluid pressure</col>, <cd>pressure
like that exerted by a fluid. It is a thrust which is normal and
equally intense in all directions around a point.
<au>Rankine</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pressure gauge</col>, <cd>a gauge
for indicating fluid pressure; a manometer.</cd></cs>

<hw>Press"work`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The art of
printing from the surface of type, plates, or engravings in
relief, by means of a press; the work so done.</def>

<au>MacKellar.</au>

<hw>Prest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <def><pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> of
<er>Press</er>.</def>

<hw>Prest</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>prest</ets>, F.
<ets>pr\'88t</ets>, fr. L. <ets>praestus</ets> ready. Cf.
<er>Presto</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Ready; prompt;
prepared.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>All <qex>prest</qex> to such battle he was.</q>
<qau>R. of Gloucester.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Neat; tidy; proper.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Tusser.</au>

<cs><col>Prest money</col>, <cd>money formerly paid to men when
they enlisted into the British service; -- so called because it
bound those that received it to be ready for service when called
upon.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prest</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF. <ets>prest</ets>, F.
<ets>pr\'88t</ets>, fr. OF. <ets>prester</ets> to lend, F.
<ets>pr\'88ter</ets>, fr. L. <ets>praestare</ets> to stand
before, to become surety for, to fulfill, offer, supply;
<ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>stare</ets> to stand. See
<er>Pre-</er>, and <er>Stand</er>, and cf. <er>Press</er> to
force into service.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Ready money; a loan
of money.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Requiring of the city a <qex>prest</qex> of six thousand
marks.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A duty in money formerly paid
by the sheriff on his account in the exchequer, or for money left
or remaining in his hands.</def>

<au>Cowell.</au>

<hw>Prest</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To give as a loan; to

<q>Sums of money . . . <qex>prested</qex> out in loan.</q>
<qau>E. Hall.</qau>

<hw>Pres*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<fld>(O. Eng. Law)</fld> <def>A payment of money; a toll or duty;
also, the rendering of a service.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<-- p. 1134 -->

<cs><col>Prestation money</col>, <cd>a sum of money paid yearly
by archdeacons and other dignitaries to their bishop.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pres"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr. Gr.
<?/, from <?/ to kindle or burn, and <?/ to blow up, swell out by
blowing.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A meteor or exhalation formerly
supposed to be thrown from the clouds with such violence that by
collision it is set on fire.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>One of the veins of the neck
when swollen with anger or other excitement.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pres`ti*dig"i*tal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Nimble-fingered; having fingers fit for prestidigitation, or
juggling.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>  \'bdHis
<xex>prestidigital</xex> hand.\'b8

<au>Charles Reade.</au>

<hw>Pres`ti*dig`i*ta"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Legerdemain; sleight of hand; juggling.</def>

<hw>Pres`ti*dig"i*ta`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>praesto</ets> ready + <ets>digitus</ets> finger:
cf. F. <ets>prestidigitateur</ets>.]</ety> <def>One skilled in
legerdemain or sleight of hand; a juggler.</def>

<hw>Pres"tige</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>praestigum</ets> delusion, illusion,
<ets>praestigae</ets> deceptions, jugglers' tricks, prob. fr.
<ets>prae</ets> before + the root of <ets>stinguere</ets> to
extinguish, originally, to prick. See <er>Stick</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Delusion; illusion;
trick.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The sophisms of infidelity, and the <qex>prestiges</qex> of
imposture.</q>
<qau>Bp. Warburton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Weight or influence derived from past success;
expectation of future achievements founded on those already
accomplished; force or charm derived from acknowledged character
or reputation.</def> \'bdThe <xex>prestige</xex> of his name must
go for something.\'b8

<au>Sir G. C. Lewis.</au>

<hw>Pres*tig`i*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praestigiare</ets> to deceive by juggling tricks, fr.
<ets>praestigae</ets>. See <er>Prestige</er>.]</ety>
<def>Legerdemain; prestidigitation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pres*tig"i*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praestigiator</ets>.]</ety> <def>A juggler;
prestidigitator.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Pres*tig"i*a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Consisting of impostures; juggling.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>Pres*tig"i*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praestigiosus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Practicing tricks;
juggling.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Cotton Mather.</au>

<hw>Pres"ti*mo*ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL.
<ets>praestimonium</ets>, fr. L. <ets>praestare</ets> to furnish,
supply: cf. F. <ets>prestimonie</ets>. See <er>Prest</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <fld>(Canon Law)</fld> <def>A fund for the
support of a priest, without the title of a benefice. The patron
in the collator.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pres*tis"si*mo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<ety>[It., superl. of <ets>presto</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>
<def>Very quickly; with great rapidity.</def>

<hw>Pres"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <ety>[It. or Sp.
<ets>presto</ets> quick, quickly. See <er>Prest</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Quickly; immediately; in
haste; suddenly.</def>

<q><qex>Presto</qex>! begone! 'tis here again.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>Quickly; rapidly; -- a
direction for a quick, lively movement or performance; quicker
than allegro, or any rate of time except prestissimo.</def>

<hw>Pres*stric"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pre*sum"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82sumable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Such as may be presumed or
supposed to be true; that seems entitled to belief without direct
evidence.</def>

<hw>Pre*sum"a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a presumable
manner; by, or according to, presumption.</def>

<hw>Pre*sume"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Presumed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Presuming</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>pr\'82sumer</ets>,
L. <ets>praesumere</ets>, <ets>praesumptum</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>sumere</ets> to take. See <er>Assume</er>,
<er>Redeem</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To assume or take
beforehand; esp., to do or undertake without leave or authority
previously obtained.</def>

<q>Dare he <qex>presume</qex> to scorn us in this manner?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Bold deed thou hast <qex>presumed</qex>, adventurous Eve.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To take or suppose to be true, or entitled to
belief, without examination or proof, or on the strength of
probability; to take for granted; to infer; to suppose.</def>

<q>Every man is to be <qex>presumed</qex> innocent till he is
proved to be guilty.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<q>What rests but that the mortal sentence pass, . . . 
Which he <qex>presumes</qex> already vain and void,
Because not yet inflicted?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pre*sume"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To suppose
or assume something to be, or to be true, on grounds deemed
valid, though not amounting to proof; to believe by anticipation;
to infer; <as>as, we may <ex>presume</ex> too far</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To venture, go, or act, by an assumption of
leave or authority not granted; to go beyond what is warranted by
the circumstances of the case; to venture beyond license; to take
liberties; -- often with <xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex> before
the ground of confidence.</def>

<q>Do not <qex>presume</qex> too much upon my love.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>This man <qex>presumes</qex> upon his parts.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>Pre*sum"ed*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
presumption.</def>

<hw>Pre*sum"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
presumes; also, an arrogant person.</def>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>Pre*sum"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Confidently;
arrogantly.</def>

<hw>Pre*sump"tion</hw> <pr>(?; 215)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praesumptio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82somption</ets>, OF.
also <ets>presumpcion</ets>. See <er>Presume</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of presuming, or believing upon probable
evidence; the act of assuming or taking for granted; belief upon
incomplete proof.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Ground for presuming; evidence probable, but not
conclusive; strong probability; reasonable supposition; <as>as,
the <ex>presumption</ex> is that an event has taken
place</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is presumed or assumed; that which is
supposed or believed to be real or true, on evidence that is
probable but not conclusive.</def> \'bdIn contradiction to these
very plausible <xex>presumptions</xex>.\'b8

<au>De Quincey.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The act of venturing beyond due beyond due
bounds; an overstepping of the bounds of reverence, respect, or
courtesy; forward, overconfident, or arrogant opinion or conduct;
presumptuousness; arrogance; effrontery.</def>

<q>Thy son I killed for his <qex>presumption</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I had the <qex>presumption</qex> to dedicate to you a very
unfinished piece.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Conclusive presumption</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Conclusive</er>.</cd> -- <col>Presumption of fact</col>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>an argument of a fact from a fact; an
inference as to the existence of one fact not certainly known,
from the existence of some other fact known or proved, founded on
a previous experience of their connection; supposition of the
truth or real existence of something, without direct or positive
proof of the fact, but grounded on circumstantial or probable
evidence which entitles it to belief. <au>Burrill</au>.
<au>Best</au>. <au>Wharton</au>.</cd> -- <col>Presumption of
law</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a postulate applied in advance to
all cases of a particular class; <it>e. g.</it>, the presumption
of innocence and of regularity of records. Such a presumption is
rebuttable or irrebuttable.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*sump"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82somptif</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Based on
presumption or probability; grounded on probable evidence;
probable; <as>as, <ex>presumptive</ex> proof</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Presumptuous; arrogant.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<cs><col>Presumptive evidence</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>that
which is derived from circumstances which necessarily or usually
attend a fact, as distinct from direct evidence or positive
proof; indirect or circumstantial evidence.
\'bd<xex>Presumptive<xex> evidence of felony should be cautiously
admitted.\'b8 <au>Blackstone</au>. The distinction, however,
between direct and presumptive (or circumstantial) evidence is
now generally abandoned; all evidence being now more or less
direct and more or less presumptive.</cd> -- <col>Presumptive
heir</col>. <cd>See <cref>Heir presumptive</cref>, under
<er>Heir</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pre*sump"tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By presumption,
or supposition grounded or probability; presumably.</def>

<hw>Pre*sump"tu*ous</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>praesumptuosus</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82somptueux</ets>, OF. also <ets>presumptuous</ets>. See
<er>Presumption</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Full of
presumption; presuming; overconfident or venturesome; audacious;
rash; taking liberties unduly; arrogant; insolent; <as>as, a
<ex>presumptuous</ex> commander; <ex>presumptuous</ex>
conduct.</as></def>

<q>A class of <qex>presumptuous</qex> men, whom age has not made
cautious, nor adversity wise.</q>
<qau>Buckminster.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Founded on presumption; <as>as, a
<ex>presumptuous</ex> idea</as>.</def> \'bdFalse,
<xex>presumptuous</xex> hope.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Done with hold design, rash confidence, or in
violation of known duty; willful.</def> \'bdKeep back the servant
also from <xex>presumptuous</xex> sins.\'b8

<au>Ps. xix. 13.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Overconfident; foolhardy; rash; presuming; forward;
arrogant; insolent.</syn>

<hw>Pre*sump"tu*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
presumptuous manner; arrogantly.</def>

<hw>Pre*sump"tu*ous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being presumptuous.</def>

<hw>Pre`sup*pos"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Presupposition.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>
\'bd<xex>Presupposal</xex> of knowledge.\'b8

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>Pre`sup*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Presupposed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Presupposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Pref. <ets>pre-</ets> +
<ets>suppose</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82supposer</ets>.]</ety>
<def>To suppose beforehand; to imply as antecedent; to take for
granted; to assume; <as>as, creation <ex>presupposes</ex> a
creator</as>.</def>

<q>Each [kind of knowledge] <qex>presupposes</qex> many necessary
things learned in other sciences, and known beforehand.</q>
<qau>Hooker.</qau>

<hw>Pre*sup`po*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>pre-</ets> +<ets> supposition</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82supposition</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
presupposing; an antecedent implication; presumption.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is presupposed; a previous
supposition or surmise.</def>

<hw>Pre`sur*mise"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A surmise
previously formed.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<mhw><hw>Pre*tence"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>,
<hw>Pre*tence"ful</hw>, <pos>a.</pos>, <hw>Pre*tence"*less</hw>,

<hw>Pre*tend"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pretended</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pretending</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pretenden</ets> to lay claim to, F. <ets>pr\'82tendre</ets>,
L. <ets>praetendere</ets>, <ets>praetentum</ets>, to stretch
forward, pretend, simulate, assert; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>tendere</ets> to stretch. See <er>Tend</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos> ]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay a claim to; to allege a
title to; to claim.</def>

<q>Chiefs shall be grudged the part which they
<qex>pretend</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hold before, or put forward, as a cloak or
disguise for something else; to exhibit as a veil for something
hidden.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Lest that too heavenly form, <qex>pretended</qex>
To hellish falsehood, snare them.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To hold out, or represent, falsely; to put
forward, or offer, as true or real (something untrue or unreal);
to show hypocritically, or for the purpose of deceiving; to
simulate; to feign; <as>as, to <ex>pretend</ex>
friendship</as>.</def>

<q>This let him know,
Lest, willfully transgressing, he <qex>pretend</qex>
Surprisal.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To intend; to design; to plot; to attempt.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Such as shall <qex>pretend</qex>
Malicious practices against his state.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To hold before one; to extend.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdHis target always over her
<xex>pretended</xex>.\'b8

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Pre*tend"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To put in,
or make, a claim, truly or falsely; to allege a title; to lay
claim to, or strive after, something; -- usually with
<xex>to</xex>.</def> \'bdCountries that <xex>pretend</xex> to
freedom.\'b8

<au>Swift.</au>

<q>For to what fine he would anon <qex>pretend</qex>,
That know I well.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hold out the appearance of being, possessing,
or performing; to profess; to make believe; to feign; to sham;
<as>as, to <ex>pretend</ex> to be asleep</as>.</def>  \'bd[He]
<xex>pretended</xex> to drink the waters.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

pretender; a claimant.</def>

friend</as>.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pre*tend"ed*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre*tend"ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of pretending; pretense.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Daniel.</au>

<hw>Pre*tend"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who lays claim, or asserts a title (to something); a
claimant.</def> Specifically, <def><xex>The pretender</xex>
<fld>(Eng. Hist.)</fld>, the son or the grandson of James II.,
the heir of the royal family of Stuart, who laid claim to the
throne of Great Britain, from which the house was excluded by
law.</def>

<q>It is the shallow, unimproved intellects that are the
confident <qex>pretenders</qex> to certainty.</q>
<qau>Glanvill.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who pretends, simulates, or feigns.</def>

<hw>Pre*tend"er*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The character,
right, or claim of a pretender.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Pre*tend"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>As by right or
title; arrogantly; presumptuously.</def>

<au>Collier.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pre*tense"</hw>, <hw>Pre*tence</hw>  }</mhw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[LL. <ets>praetensus</ets>, for
L. <ets>praetentus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praetendere</ets>. See
<er>Pretend</er>, and cf. <er>Tension</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of laying claim; the claim laid; assumption;
pretension.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>Primogeniture can not have any <qex>pretense</qex> to a right
of solely inheriting property or power.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<q>I went to Lambeth with Sir R. Brown's <qex>pretense</qex> to
the wardenship of Merton College, Oxford.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of holding out, or offering, to others
something false or feigned; presentation of what is deceptive or
hypocritical; deception by showing what is unreal and concealing
what is real; false show; simulation; <as>as, <ex>pretense</ex>
of illness; under <ex>pretense</ex> of patriotism; on
<ex>pretense</ex> of revenging C\'91sar's death.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is pretended; false, deceptive, or
hypocritical show, argument, or reason; pretext; feint.</def>

<q>Let not the Trojans, with a feigned <qex>pretense</qex>
Of proffered peace, delude the Latian prince.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Intention; design.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>A very <qex>pretense</qex> and purpose of unkindness.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<note><hand/ See the <er>Note</er> under <er>Offense</er>.</note>

<syn>Syn. -- Mask; appearance; color; show; pretext;
excuse.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Pretense</er>, <er>Pretext</er>. A
<xex>pretense</xex> is something held out as real when it is not
so, thus falsifying the truth. A <xex>pretext</xex> is something
woven up in order to cover or conceal one's true motives,
feelings, or reasons. <xex>Pretext</xex> is often, but not
always, used in a bad sense.</usage>

<hw>Pre*tensed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pretended;
feigned.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> --
<wordforms><wf>Pre*tens"ed*ly</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></wordforms>

<hw>Pre*tense"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Abounding
in pretenses.</def>

<hw>Pre*tense"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Not having or making
pretenses.</def>

<hw>Pre*ten"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82tention</ets>. See <er>Pretend</er>,
<er>Tension</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of pretending,
or laying claim; the act of asserting right or title.</def>

<q>The arrogant <qex>pretensions</qex> of Glengarry contributed
to protract the discussion.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A claim made, whether true or false; a right
alleged or assumed; a holding out the appearance of possessing a
certain character; <as>as, <ex>pretensions</ex> to
scholarship</as>.</def>

<q>This was but an invention and <qex>pretension</qex> given out
by the Spaniards.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Men indulge those opinions and practices that favor their
<qex>pretensions</qex>.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<hw>Pre*ten"ta*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>pre-</ets> + <ets>tentative</ets>: cf. L.
<ets>praetentare</ets> to try beforehand.]</ety> <def>Fitted for
trial beforehand; experimental.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>Pre*ten"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82tentieux</ets>. See <er>Pretend</er>.]</ety> <def>Full
of pretension; disposed to lay claim to more than is one's;
presuming; assuming.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pre*ten"tious*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pre*ten"tious*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pre"ter-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L. <ets>praeter</ets> past,
beyond, originally a compar. of <ets>prae</ets> before. See
<er>For</er>, <ets>prep</ets>.]</ety> <def>A prefix signifying
<xex>past</xex>, <xex>by</xex>, <xex>beyond</xex>, <xex>more
than</xex>; <as>as, <ex>preter-</ex> mission, a permitting to go
by; <ex>preter</ex>natural, beyond or more than is
natural.</as></def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pr\'91ter</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pre`ter*hu"man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>preter-</ets> + <ets>human</ets>.]</ety> <def>More than
human.</def>

<hw>Pre*te"ri*ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeteriens</ets>, p. pr. See <er>Preterit</er>.]</ety>
<def>Passed through; antecedent; previous; <as>as,
<ex>preterient</ex> states</as>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pre`ter*im*per"fect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a. & n.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>preter-</ets> + <ets>imperfect</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Old name of the tense also called
<altname>imperfect</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pret"er*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>preter-</ets> + <ets>-ist</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
whose chief interest is in the past; one who regards the past
with most pleasure or favor.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>One who believes the
prophecies of the Apocalypse to have been already
fulfilled.</def>

<au>Farrar.</au>

<hw>Pret"er*it</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeteritus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praeterire</ets> to go or
pass by; <ets>praeter</ets> beyond, by + <ets>ire</ets> to go:
cf. F. <ets>pr\'82t\'82rit</ets>. See <er>Issue</er>.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>preterite</asp> and
<asp>pr\'91terite</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>
<def>Past; -- applied to a tense which expresses an action or
state as past.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Belonging wholly to the past; passed by.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Things and persons as thoroughly <qex>preterite</qex> as
Romulus or Numa.</q>
<qau>Lowell.</qau>

<hw>Pret"er*it</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The
preterit; also, a word in the preterit tense.</def>

<hw>Pret"er*ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a. & n.</pos> <def>Same
as <er>Preterit</er>.</def>

<hw>Pret"er*ite*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Preteritness</er>.</def>

<hw>Pre`ter*i"tion</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praeteritio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82t\'82rition</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
passing, or going past; the state of being past.</def>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>A figure by which, in
pretending to pass over anything, a summary mention of it is
made; <as>as, \'bdI will not say, he is valiant, he is learned,
he is just</as>.\'b8  Called also
<altname>paraleipsis</altname>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The omission by a testator of
some one of his heirs who is entitled to a portion.</def>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>Used only or chiefly in the preterit or
past tenses, as certain verbs.</def>

<hw>Pret"er*it*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being past.</def>

<au>Bentley. Lowell.</au>

<hw>Pre`ter*nat"u*ral</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Pre*tex"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praetexere</ets>. See <er>Pretext</er>.]</ety> <def>To

<hw>Pre"text</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82texte</ets>, L. <ets>praetextum</ets>, fr.
<ets>praetextus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praetexere</ets> to weave
before, allege as an excuse; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>texere</ets> to weave. See <er>Text</er>.]</ety>
<def>Ostensible reason or motive assigned or assumed as a color
or cover for the real reason or motive; pretense; disguise.</def>

<q>They suck the blood of those they depend on, under a
<qex>pretext</qex> of service and kindness.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<q>With how much or how little <qex>pretext</qex> of reason.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Pretense; excuse; semblance; disguise; appearance.
See <er>Pretense</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pre"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praetor</ets>, for <ets>praeitor</ets>, fr.
<ets>praeire</ets> to go before; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>ire</ets> to go. See <er>Issue</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>A civil officer or magistrate among
the ancient Romans.</def>

<note><hand/ Originally the <xex>pretor</xex> was a kind of third
consul; but at an early period two pretors were appointed, the
first of whom (<xex>praetor urbanus</xex>) was a kind of mayor or
city judge; the other (<xex>praetor peregrinus</xex>) was a judge
of cases in which one or both of the parties were foreigners.
Still later, the number of pretors, or judges, was further
increased.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, a mayor or magistrate.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pre*to"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praetorians</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82torien</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to a pretor or magistrate; judicial;
exercised by, or belonging to, a pretor; <as>as,
<ex>pretorian</ex> power or authority</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Pretorian bands</col> <or/ <col>guards</col>, <or/
<col>Pretorians</col></mcol> <fld>(Rom. Hist.)</fld>, <cd>the
emperor's bodyguards, instituted by the Emperor Augustus in nine
cohorts of 1,000 men each.</cd> -- <col>Pretorian gate</col>
<fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld>, <cd>that one of the four gates in a
camp which lay next the enemy.</cd></cs>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<hw>Pre*to"ri*an</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A soldier of the

<def>The general's tent in a Roman camp; hence, a council of war,

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The official residence of a governor of a

<qau>Jeffrey.</qau>

<hw>Pret"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Prettier</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Prettiest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>prati</ets>, AS. <ets>pr\'91ttig</ets>,
<ets>pr\'91tig</ets>, crafty, sly, akin to <ets>pr\'91t</ets>,
<ets>pr\'91tt</ets>, deceit, trickery, Icel. <ets>prettugr</ets>
tricky, <ets>prettr</ets> a trick; probably fr. Latin, perhaps
through Celtic; cf. W. <ets>praith</ets> act, deed, practice, LL.
<ets>practica</ets> execution, practice, plot. See
<er>Practice</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pleasing by delicacy
or grace; attracting, but not striking or impressing; of a
pleasing and attractive form a color; having slight or diminutive
beauty; neat or elegant without elevation or grandeur;
pleasingly, but not grandly, conceived or expressed; <as>as, a
<ex>pretty</ex> face; a <ex>pretty</ex> flower; a <ex>pretty</ex>
poem.</as></def>

<q>This is the <qex>prettiest</qex> lowborn lass that ever
Ran on the greensward.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Moderately large; considerable; <as>as, he had
saved a <ex>pretty</ex> fortune</as>.</def> \'bdWavering a
<xex>pretty</xex> while.\'b8

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Affectedly nice; foppish; -- used in an ill
sense.</def>

<q>The <qex>pretty</qex> gentleman is the most complaisant in the
world.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Mean; despicable; contemptible; -- used
ironically; <as>as, a <ex>pretty</ex> trick; a <ex>pretty</ex>
fellow.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Stout; strong and brave; intrepid;
valiant.</def> <mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<q>[He] observed they were <qex>pretty</qex> men, meaning not
handsome.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Elegant; neat; fine. See <er>Handsome</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pret"ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In some
degree; moderately; considerably; rather; almost; -- less
emphatic than <xex>very</xex>; <as>as, I am <ex>pretty</ex> sure
of the fact; <ex>pretty</ex> cold weather.</as></def>

<q><qex>Pretty</qex> plainly professes himself a sincere
Christian.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<hw>Pret"ty*ish</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Somewhat pretty.</def>

<au>Walpole.</au>

of a pretty style, manner, etc.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Ed. Rev.</au>

or speaking prettily.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Pret"zel</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[G.

<hw>Pre*vail"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prevailed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prevailing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>pr\'82valoir</ets>, OF. <ets>prevaleir</ets>, L.
<ets>praevalere</ets>; <ets>prae</ets> before + <ets>valere</ets>
to be strong, able, or worth. See <er>Valiant</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To overcome; to gain the victory or superiority;
to gain the advantage; to have the upper hand, or the mastery; to
succeed; -- sometimes with <xex>over</xex> or
<xex>against</xex>.</def>

<q>When Moses held up his hand, Israel <qex>prevailed</qex>, and
when he let down his hand, Amalek <qex>prevailed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ex. xvii. 11.</qau>

<q>So David <qex>prevailed</qex> over the Philistine.</q>
<qau>1 Sam. xvii. 50.</qau>

<q>This kingdom could never <qex>prevail</qex> against the united
power of <qex>England</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be in force; to have effect, power, or
influence; to be predominant; to have currency or prevalence; to
obtain; <as>as, the practice <ex>prevails</ex> this
day</as>.</def>

<q>This custom makes the short-sighted bigots, and the warier
skeptics, as far as it <qex>prevails</qex>.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To persuade or induce; -- with <xex>on</xex>,
<xex>upon</xex>, or <xex>with</xex>; <as>as, I
<ex>prevailed</ex>on him to wait</as>.</def>

<q>He was <qex>prevailed</qex> with to restrain the Earl.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q><qex>Prevail</qex> upon some judicious friend to be your
constant hearer, and allow him the utmost freedom.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Pre*vail"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Having
superior force or influence; efficacious; persuasive.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Saints shall assist thee with <qex>prevailing</qex>
prayers.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Predominant; prevalent; most general; <as>as,
the <ex>prevailing</ex> disease of a climate; a
<ex>prevailing</ex> opinion.</as></def>

<syn>Syn.  See <er>Prevalent</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pre*vail"ing*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>So as to
prevail.</def>

<hw>Pre*vail"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Prevalence; superior influence; efficacy.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Prev"a*lence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praevalentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pr\'82valence</ets>. See
<er>Prevail</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or condition of being
prevalent; superior strength, force, or influence; general
existence, reception, or practice; wide extension; <as>as, the
<ex>prevalence</ex> of virtue, of a fashion, or of a disease; the
<ex>prevalence</ex> of a rumor.</as></def>

<q>The duke better knew what kind of argument were of
<qex>prevalence</qex> with him.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<hw>Prev"a*len*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Prevalence</er>.</def>

<hw>Prev"a*lent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praevalens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>praevalere</ets>. See <er>Prevail</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Gaining advantage or superiority; having superior force,
influence, or efficacy; prevailing; predominant; successful;
victorious.</def>

<q>Brennus told the Roman embassadors, that <qex>prevalent</qex>
arms were as good as any title.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Most generally received or current; most widely
adopted or practiced; also, generally or extensively existing;
widespread; prevailing; <as>as, a <ex>prevalent</ex> observance;
<ex>prevalent</ex> disease.</as></def>

<q>This was the most received and <qex>prevalent</qex>
opinion.</q>
<qau>Woodward.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Prevailing; predominant; successful; efficacious;
powerful.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Prevalent</er>,
<er>Prevailing</er>. What customarily prevails is
<xex>prevalent</xex>; <as>as, a <ex>prevalent</ex> fashion</as>.
What actually prevails is <xex>prevailing</xex>; <as>as, the
<ex>prevailing</ex> winds are west</as>. Hence,
<xex>prevailing</xex> is the livelier and more pointed word,
since it represents a thing in action. It is sometimes the
stronger word, since a thing may prevail sufficiently to be
called <xex>prevalent</xex>, and yet require greater strength to
make it actually <xex>prevailing</xex>.</usage>

<hw>Prev"a*lent"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a prevalent
manner.</def>

<au>Prior.</au>

<hw>Pre*var"i*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prevaricated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prevaricating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praevaricatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>praevaricari</ets> to
walk crookedly, to collude; <ets>prae</ets> before +
<ets>varicare</ets> to straddle, fr. <ets>varicus</ets>
straddling, <ets>varus</ets> bent. See <er>Varicose</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To shift or turn from one side to the other,
from the direct course, or from truth; to speak with
equivocation; to shuffle; to quibble; <as>as, he
<ex>prevaricates</ex> in his statement</as>.</def>

<q>He <qex>prevaricates</qex> with his own understanding.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Civil Law)</fld> <def>To collude, as where an
informer colludes with the defendant, and makes a sham
prosecution.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld> <def>To undertake a thing
falsely and deceitfully, with the purpose of defeating or
destroying it.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To evade; equivocate; quibble; shuffle.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>Prevaricate</er>, <er>Evade</er>,
<er>Equivocate</er>. One who <xex>evades</xex> a question
ostensibly answers it, but really turns aside to some other
point. He who <xex>equivocate</xex> uses words which have a
double meaning, so that in one sense he can claim to have said
the truth, though he does in fact deceive, and intends to do it.
He who <xex>prevaricates</xex> talks all round the question,
hoping to \'bddodge\'b8 it, and disclose nothing.</usage>

<hw>Pre*var"i*cate</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To evade by a
quibble; to transgress; to pervert.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Pre*var`i*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praevaricatio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82varication</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
prevaricating, shuffling, or quibbling, to evade the truth or the
disclosure of truth; a deviation from the truth and fair
dealing.</def>

<q>The august tribunal of the skies, where no
<qex>prevarication</qex> shall avail.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A secret abuse in the exercise of a public
office.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Roman Law)</fld>
<def>The collusion of an informer with the defendant, for the
purpose of making a sham prosecution.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Common Law)</fld> <def>A false or deceitful seeming to
undertake a thing for the purpose of defeating or destroying
it.</def>

<au>Cowell.</au>

<hw>Pre*var"i*ca`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>praevaricator</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pr\'82varicateur</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who
prevaricates.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Roman Law)</fld> <def>A sham dealer; one who
colludes with a defendant in a sham prosecution.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who betrays or abuses a trust.</def>

<au>Prynne.</au>

<hw>Preve</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i. & i.</pos> <def>To
prove.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pre*vent"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prevented</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Preventing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>praevenire</ets>, <ets>praeventum</ets>; <ets>prae</ets>
before + <ets>venire</ets> to come. See <er>Come</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To go before; to precede; hence, to go before as
a guide; to direct.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>We which are alive and remain unto the coming of the Lord
shall not <qex>prevent</qex> them which are asleep.</q>
<qau>1 Thess. iv. 15.</qau>

<q>We pray thee that thy grace may always <qex>prevent</qex> and
follow us.</q>
<qau>Bk. of Common Prayer.</qau>

<q>Then had I come, <qex>preventing</qex> Sheba's queen.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be beforehand with; to anticipate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Their ready guilt <qex>preventing</qex> thy commands.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To intercept; to hinder; to frustrate; to stop;
to thwart.</def> \'bdThis vile purpose to <xex>prevent</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Perhaps forestalling night <qex>prevented</qex> them.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pre*vent"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To come before the
usual time.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Strawberries . . . will <qex>prevent</qex> and come early.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

often used adverbially for <xex>previously</xex>.
\'bd<xex>Previous to<xex> publication.\'bd <au>M. Arnold</au>. 
\'bdA policy . . . his friends had advised <xex>previous to</xex>

former.</syn>

<hw>Prey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>preie</ets>, F. <ets>proie</ets>, L. <ets>praeda</ets>,
probably for <ets>praeheda</ets>. See <er>Prehensile</er>, and
cf. <er>Depredate</er>, <er>Predatory</er>.]</ety> <def>Anything,
as goods, etc., taken or got by violence; anything taken by force
from an enemy in war; spoil; booty; plunder.</def>

<q>And they brought the captives, and the <qex>prey</qex>, and
the spoil, unto Moses, and Eleazar the priest.</q>
<qau>Num. xxxi. 12.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is or may be seized by animals or
birds to be devoured; hence, a person given up as a victim.</def>

<q>The old lion perisheth for lack of <qex>prey</qex>.</q>
<qau>Job iv. ii.</qau>

<q>Already sees herself the monster's <qex>prey</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The act of devouring other creatures;
ravage.</def>

<q>Hog in sloth, fox in stealth, . . . lion in
<qex>prey</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><col>Beast of prey</col>, <cd>a carnivorous animal; one that
feeds on the flesh of other animals.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prey</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Preyed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Preying</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OF. <ets>preier</ets>, <ets>preer</ets>, L.
<ets>praedari</ets>, fr. <ets>praeda</ets>. See <er>Prey</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <def>To take booty; to gather spoil; to
ravage; to take food by violence.</def>

<q>More pity that the eagle should be mewed,
While kites and buzzards <qex>prey</qex> at liberty.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>To prey on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To take prey from; to despoil; to pillage; to
rob</cd>. <au>Shak.</au> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To seize as prey; to
take for food by violence; to seize and devour.</cd>
<au>Shak.</au> <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To wear away gradually; to cause
to waste or pine away; as, the trouble <xex>preyed upon<xex> his
mind.</cd></cs>

<au>Addison.</au>

that which, preys; a plunderer; a waster; a devourer.</def>

<hw>Pri`a*pe"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. L.

Pros.)</fld> <def>A species of hexameter verse so constructed as

amphimacer in the third; -- applied also to a regular hexameter
verse when so constructed as to be divisible into two portions of

<hw>Price</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pris</ets>, OF. <ets>pris</ets>, F. <ets>prix</ets>, L.
<ets>pretium</ets>; cf. Gr. <?/ I sell <?/ to buy, Skr.
<ets>pa<?/</ets> to buy, OI. <ets>renim</ets> I sell. Cf.
<er>Appreciate</er>, <er>Depreciate</er>, <er>Interpret</er>,
<er>Praise</er>, <pos>n.<pos> & <pos>v.<pos>, <er>Precious</er>,
<er>Prize</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The sum or amount of
money at which a thing is valued, or the value which a seller
sets on his goods in market; that for which something is bought
or sold, or offered for sale; equivalent in money or other means
of exchange; current value or rate paid or demanded in market or
in barter; cost.</def> \'bdBuy wine and milk without money and
without <xex>price</xex>.\'b8

<au>Isa. lv. 1.</au>

<q>We can afford no more at such a <qex>price</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Value; estimation; excellence; worth.</def>

<q>Her <qex>price</qex> is far above rubies.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxxi. 10.</qau>

<q>New treasures still, of countless <qex>price</qex>.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Reward; recompense; <as>as, the <ex>price</ex>
of industry</as>.</def>

<q>'T is the <qex>price</qex> of toil,
The knave deserves it when he tills the soil.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<cs><mcol><col>Price current</col>, <or/ <col>Price
list</col></mcol>, <cd>a statement or list of the prevailing
prices of merchandise, stocks, specie, bills of exchange, etc.,
published statedly or occasionally.</cd></cs>

<def>A hydrous borate of lime, from Oregon.</def>

<hw>Price"less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Too valuable

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of no value; worthless.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Prick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>prica</ets>, <ets>pricca</ets>, <ets>pricu</ets>; akin to
LG. <ets>prick</ets>, <ets>pricke</ets>, D. <ets>prik</ets>, Dan.
<ets>prik</ets>, <ets>prikke</ets>, Sw. <ets>prick</ets>. Cf.
<er>Prick</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which
pricks, penetrates, or punctures; a sharp and slender thing; a
pointed instrument; a goad; a spur, etc.; a point; a
skewer.</def>

<q>Pins, wooden <qex>pricks</qex>, nails, sprigs of rosemary.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>It is hard for thee to kick against the <qex>pricks</qex>.</q>
<qau>Acts ix. 5.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of pricking, or the sensation of being
pricked; a sharp, stinging pain; figuratively, remorse.</def>
\'bdThe <xex>pricks</xex> of conscience.\'b8

<au>A. Tucker.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A mark made by a pointed instrument; a puncture;
a point.</def> Hence: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A point or mark on the
dial, noting the hour</def>. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe
<xex>prick</xex> of noon.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The point on a target at which an archer aims; the mark; the
pin</def>. \'bdThey that shooten nearest the
<xex>prick</xex>.\'b8 <au>Spenser</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A mark
denoting degree; degree; pitch</def>. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdTo
<xex>prick</xex> of highest praise forth to advance.\'b8
<xex>Spenser</xex>. <sd>(d)</sd> <def>A mathematical point; --
regularly used in old English translations of Euclid</def>.
<sd>(e)</sd> <def>The footprint of a hare.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A small roll; <as>as, a
<ex>prick</ex> of spun yarn; a <ex>prick</ex> of
tobacco.</as></def>

<hw>Prick</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pricked</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pricking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>prician</ets>;
akin to LG. <ets>pricken</ets>, D. <ets>prikken</ets>, Dan.
<ets>prikke</ets>, Sw. <ets>pricka</ets>. See <er>Prick</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>, and cf. <er>Prink</er>, <er>Prig</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pierce slightly with a sharp-pointed
instrument or substance; to make a puncture in, or to make by
puncturing; to drive a fine point into; <as>as, to <ex>prick</ex>
one with a pin, needle, etc.; to <ex>prick</ex> a card; to
<ex>prick</ex> holes in paper.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To fix by the point; to attach or hang by
puncturing; <as>as, to <ex>prick</ex> a knife into a
board</as>.</def>

<au>Sir I. Newton.</au>

<q>The cooks <qex>prick</qex> it [a slice] on a prong of
iron.</q>
<qau>Sandys.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To mark or denote by a puncture; to designate by
pricking; to choose; to mark; -- sometimes with
<xex>off</xex>.</def>

<q>Some who are <qex>pricked</qex> for sheriffs.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Let the soldiers for duty be carefully <qex>pricked</qex>
off.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<q>Those many, then, shall die: their names are
<qex>pricked</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To mark the outline of by puncturing; to trace
or form by pricking; to mark by punctured dots; <as>as, to
<ex>prick</ex> a pattern for embroidery; to <ex>prick</ex> the
notes of a musical composition.</as></def>

<au>Cowper.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To ride or guide with spurs; to spur; to goad;
to incite; to urge on; -- sometimes with <xex>on</xex>, or
<xex>off</xex>.</def>

<q>Who <qex>pricketh</qex> his blind horse over the fallows.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>The season <qex>pricketh</qex> every gentle heart.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>My duty <qex>pricks</qex> me on to utter that.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To affect with sharp pain; to sting, as with
remorse.</def> \'bdI was <xex>pricked</xex> with some
reproof.\'b8

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<q>Now when they heard this, they were <qex>pricked</qex> in
their heart.</q>
<qau>Acts ii. 37.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To make sharp; to erect into a point; to raise,
as something pointed; -- said especially of the ears of an
animal, as a horse or dog; and usually followed by <xex>up</xex>;
-- hence, <xex>to prick up the ears</xex>, to listen sharply; to
have the attention and interest strongly engaged.</def> \'bdThe
courser . . . <xex>pricks</xex> up his ears.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>8.</sn> <def>To render acid or pungent.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hudibras.</au>

<sn>9.</sn> <def>To dress; to prink; -- usually with
<xex>up</xex>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>10.</sn> <fld>(Naut)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To run a middle
seam through, as the cloth of a sail.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>To
trace on a chart, as a ship's course.</def>

<sn>11.</sn> <fld>(Far.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To drive a nail
into (a horse's foot), so as to cause lameness.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>To nick.</def>

<hw>Prick</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be
punctured; to suffer or feel a sharp pain, as by puncture;
<as>as, a sore finger <ex>pricks</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To spur onward; to ride on horseback.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>A gentle knight was <qex>pricking</qex> on the plain.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To become sharp or acid; to turn sour, as
wine.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To aim at a point or mark.</def>

<au>Hawkins.</au>

<hw>Prick"-eared`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having erect, pointed ears; -- said of
certain dogs.</def>

<q>Thou <qex>prick-eared</qex> cur of Iceland.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Prick"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who, or that which, pricks; a pointed instrument; a
sharp point; a prickle.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who spurs forward; a light horseman.</def>

<q>The <qex>prickers</qex>, who rode foremost, . . . halted.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A priming wire; a priming needle, -- used in
blasting and gunnery.</def>

<au>Knight.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A small marline spike having
generally a wooden handle, -- used in sailmaking.</def>

<au>R. H. Dana, Ir.</au>

<hw>Prick"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Perhaps so

second year. See <er>Note</er> under 3d <er>Buck</er>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Prick"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of
piercing or puncturing with a sharp point.</def> \'bdThere is
that speaketh like the <xex>prickings</xex> of a sword.\'b8

<au>Prov. xii. 18 [1583].</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Far.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The driving of a
nail into a horse's foot so as to produce lameness.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Same as <er>Nicking</er>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sensation of being pricked.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The mark or trace left by a hare's foot; a
prick; also, the act of tracing a hare by its footmarks.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Dressing one's self for show; prinking.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prick"ing-up</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>The first coating of plaster in work of
three coats upon laths. Its surface is scratched once to form a
better key for the next coat. In the United States called
<altname>scratch coat</altname>.</def>

<au>Brande & C.</au>

<hw>Pric"kle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS.
<ets>pricele</ets>, <ets>pricle</ets>; akin to LG.
<ets>prickel</ets>, D. <ets>prikkel</ets>. See <er>Prick</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A little prick; a small,

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A kind of willow basket; -- a term still used in
some branches of trade.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sieve of filberts, -- about fifty
pounds.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Prick"ly</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Full of sharp points or
prickles; armed or covered with prickles; <as>as, a
<ex>prickly</ex> shrub</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Prickly ash</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a prickly shrub
(<spn>Xanthoxylum Americanum</spn>) with yellowish flowers
appearing with the leaves. All parts of the plant are pungent and
aromatic. The southern species is <spn>X. Carolinianum</spn>.
<au>Gray</au>.</cd> -- <col>Prickly heat</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>,
<cd>a noncontagious cutaneous eruption of red pimples, attended
with intense itching and tingling of the parts affected. It is
due to inflammation of the sweat glands, and is often brought on
by overheating the skin in hot weather.</cd> -- <col>Prickly
pear</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a name given to several plants
of the cactaceous genus <spn>Opuntia</spn>, American plants
consisting of fleshy, leafless, usually flattened, and often
prickly joints inserted upon each other. The sessile flowers have
many petals and numerous stamens. The edible fruit is a large
pear-shaped berry containing many flattish seeds. The common
species of the Northern Atlantic States is <spn>Opuntia
vulgaris</spn>. In the South and West are many others, and in
tropical America more than a hundred more. <spn>O.
vulgaris</spn>, <spn>O. Ficus-Indica</spn>, and <spn>O.
Tuna</spn> are abundantly introduced in the Mediterranean region,
and <spn>O. Dillenii</spn> has become common in India.</cd> --
<col>Prickly pole</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a West Indian palm
(<spn>Bactris Plumierana</spn>), the slender trunk of which bears
many rings of long black prickles.</cd> -- <col>Prickly
withe</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a West Indian cactaceous plant
(<spn>Cereus triangularis</spn>) having prickly, slender,
climbing, triangular stems.</cd> -- <col>Prickly rat</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of South
American burrowing rodents belonging to <spn>Ctenomys</spn> and
allied genera. The hair is usually intermingled with sharp
spines.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prick"mad`am</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>trique-madame</ets>. Cf. <er>Tripmadam</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A name given to several species of
stonecrop, used as ingredients of vermifuge medicines. See
<er>Stonecrop</er>.</def>

<hw>Prick"punch`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A pointed
steel punch, to prick a mark on metal.</def>

<hw>Prick"shaft`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An
arrow.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prick"song`</hw> <pr>(?; 115)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Prick</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>, 4.]</ety> <def>Music written,
or noted, with dots or points; -- so called from the points or
dots with which it is noted down.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He fights as you sing <qex>pricksong</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Prick"wood`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A shrub (<spn>Euonymus Europ\'91us</spn>);
-- so named from the use of its wood for goads, skewers, and shoe
pegs. Called also <altname>spindle tree</altname>.</def>

<hw>Prick"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Stiff and
sharp; prickly.</def>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>Pride</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. AS.
<ets>lamprede</ets>, LL. <ets>lampreda</ets>, E.
<ets>lamprey</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A small
European lamprey (<spn>Petromyzon branchialis</spn>); -- called
also <altname>prid</altname>, and
<altname>sandpiper</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pride</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[AS. <ets>pr<ymac/te</ets>;
akin to Icel. <ets>pr<ymac/<edh/i</ets> honor, ornament,
<ets>pr<?/<?/a</ets> to adorn, Dan. <ets>pryde</ets>, Sw.
<ets>pryda</ets>; cf. W. <ets>prydus</ets> comely. See
<er>Proud</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of
being proud; inordinate self-esteem; an unreasonable conceit of
one's own superiority in talents, beauty, wealth, rank, etc.,
which manifests itself in lofty airs, distance, reserve, and
often in contempt of others.</def>

<q>Those that walk in <qex>pride</qex> he is able to abase.</q>
<qau>Dan. iv. 37.</qau>

<q><qex>Pride</qex> that dines on vanity sups on contempt.</q>
<qau>Franklin.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A sense of one's own worth, and abhorrence of
what is beneath or unworthy of one; lofty self-respect; noble
self-esteem; elevation of character; dignified bearing; proud
delight; -- in a good sense.</def>

<q>Thus to relieve the wretched was his <qex>pride</qex>.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<q>A people which takes no <qex>pride</qex> in the noble
achievements of remote ancestors will never achieve anything
worthy to be remembered with <qex>pride</qex> by remote
descendants.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Proud or disdainful behavior or treatment;
insolence or arrogance of demeanor; haughty bearing and conduct;
insolent exultation; disdain.</def>

<q>Let not the foot of <qex>pride</qex> come against me.</q>
<qau>Ps. xxxvi. 11.</qau>

<q>That hardly we escaped the <qex>pride</qex> of France.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That of which one is proud; that which excites
boasting or self-gratulation; the occasion or ground of
self-esteem, or of arrogant and presumptuous confidence, as
beauty, ornament, noble character, children, etc.</def>

<q>Lofty trees yclad with summer's <qex>pride</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>I will cut off the <qex>pride</qex> of the Philistines.</q>
<qau>Zech. ix. 6.</qau>

<q>A bold peasantry, their country's <qex>pride</qex>.</q>
<qau>Goldsmith.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Show; ostentation; glory.</def>

<q><qex>Pride</qex>, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Highest pitch; elevation reached; loftiness;
prime; glory; <as>as, to be in the <ex>pride</ex> of one's
life</as>.</def>

<q>A falcon, towering in her <qex>pride</qex> of place.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Consciousness of power; fullness of animal
spirits; mettle; wantonness; hence, lust; sexual desire; esp., an
excitement of sexual appetite in a female beast.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<cs><mcol><col>Pride of India</col>, <or/ <col>Pride of
China</col></mcol>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Margosa</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pride of the desert</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the camel.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Self-exaltation; conceit; hauteur; haughtiness;
lordliness; loftiness.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Pride</er>,
<er>Vanity</er>. <xex>Pride</xex> is a high or an excessive
esteem of one's self for some real or imagined superiority, as
rank, wealth, talents, character, etc. <xex>Vanity</xex> is the
love of being admired, praised, exalted, etc., by others.
<xex>Vanity</xex> is an ostentation of <xex>pride</xex>; but one
may have great <xex>pride</xex> without displaying it.
<xex>Vanity</xex>, which is etymologically \'bdemptiness,\'b8 is
applied especially to the exhibition of pride in
superficialities, as beauty, dress, wealth, etc.</usage>

<hw>Pride</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Prided</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Priding</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To indulge in pride, or
self-esteem; to rate highly; to plume; -- used reflexively.</def>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<q>Pluming and <qex>priding</qex> himself in all his
services.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<hw>Pride</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To be proud; to
glory.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Priest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>prest</ets>, <ets>preost</ets>, AS. <ets>pre\'a2st</ets>,
fr. L. <ets>presbyter</ets>, Gr. <?/ elder, older, n., an elder,
compar. of <?/ an old man, the first syllable of which is
probably akin to L. <ets>pristinus</ets>. Cf. <er>Pristine</er>,
<er>Presbyter</er>.]</ety>

<-- p. 1137 -->

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Christian Church)</fld> <def>A presbyter elder;
a minister</def>; specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(R. C. Ch. &
Gr. Ch.)</fld> <def>One who is authorized to consecrate the host
and to say Mass; but especially, one of the lowest order
possessing this power</def>. <au>Murdock</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Ch. of Eng. &  Prot. Epis. Ch.)</fld> <def>A presbyter; one
who belongs to the intermediate order between bishop and deacon.
He is authorized to perform all ministerial services except those
of ordination and confirmation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who officiates at the altar, or performs the
rites of sacrifice; one who acts as a mediator between men and
the divinity or the gods in any form of religion; <as>as,
Buddhist <ex>priests</ex></as>.</def> \'bdThe <xex>priests</xex>
of Dagon.\'b8

<au>1 Sam. v. 5.</au>

<q>Then the <qex>priest</qex> of Jupiter . . . brought oxen and
garlands . . . and would have done sacrifice with the people.</q>
<au>Acts xiv. 13.</au>

<q>Every <qex>priest</qex> taken from among men is ordained for
men in things pertaining to God, that he may offer both gifts and
sacrifices for sins.</q>
<qau>Heb. v. 1.</qau>

<note><hand/ In the New Testament presbyters are not called
<xex>priests</xex>; but Christ is designated as a
<xex>priest</xex>, and as a high <xex>priest</xex>, and all
Christians are designated <xex>priests</xex>.</note>

<hw>Priest</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To ordain as
priest.</def>

<hw>Priest"cap`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Fort.)</fld> <def>A form of redan, so named from its shape;

<hw>Priest"craft`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Priestly
policy; the policy of a priesthood; esp., in an ill sense, fraud
or imposition in religious concerns; management by priests to
gain wealth and power by working upon the religious motives or
credulity of others.</def>

<q>It is better that men should be governed by
<qex>priestcraft</qex> than by violence.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>
