<hw>Pro"bate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>probatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>probare</ets> to prove. See
<er>Prove</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Proof.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Skelton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Official proof;
especially, the proof before a competent officer or tribunal that
an instrument offered, purporting to be the last will and
testament of a person deceased, is indeed his lawful act; the
copy of a will proved, under the seal of the Court of Probate,
delivered to the executors with a certificate of its having been
proved</def>. <au>Bouvier</au>. <au>Burrill</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The right or jurisdiction of proving wills</def>.

<hw>Pro"bate</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or belonging to a
probate, or court of probate; <as>as, a <ex>probate</ex>
record</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Probate Court</col>, <or/ <col>Court of
Probate</col></mcol>, <cd>a court for the probate of wills.</cd>
-- <col>Probate duty</col>, <cd>a government tax on property
passing by will. <mark>[Eng.]</mark></cd></cs>

<hw>Pro"bate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To obtain
the official approval of, as of an instrument purporting to be
the last will and testament; <as>as, the executor has
<ex>probated</ex> the will</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*ba"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>probatio</ets>, fr. <ets>probare</ets> to try, examine,
prove: cf. F. <ets>probation</ets>. See <er>Prove</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of proving; also, that which proves
anything; proof.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>When by miracle God dispensed great gifts to the laity, . . .
he gave <qex>probation</qex> that he intended that all should
prophesy and preach.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any proceeding designed to ascertain truth, to
determine character, qualification, etc.; examination; trial;
<as>as, to engage a person on <ex>probation</ex></as>. Hence,
specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> The novitiate which a person must pass
in a convent, to probe his or her virtue and ability to bear the
severities of the rule. <sd>(b)</sd> The trial of a ministerial
candidate's qualifications prior to his ordination, or to his
settlement as a pastor. <sd>(c)</sd> Moral trial; the state of
man in the present life, in which he has the opportunity of
proving his character, and becoming qualified for a happier
state.</def>

<q>No [view of human life] seems so reasonable as that which
regards it as a state of <qex>probation</qex>.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<hw>Pro*ba"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Probationary.</def>

<hw>Pro*ba"tion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to probation; serving for trial.</def>

<q>To consider this life . . . as a <qex>probationary</qex>
state.</q>
<qau>Paley.</qau>

<hw>Pro*ba"tion*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

And candidate of heaven.</q>

<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*ba"tion*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A state of

<hw>Probe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Probed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Probing</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[L. <ets>probare</ets> to try, examine. See
<er>Prove</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To examine, as a wound, an ulcer, or some cavity
of the body, with a probe.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Fig.: to search to the bottom; to scrutinize or
examine thoroughly.</def>

<au> Dryden.</au>

<q>The growing disposition to <qex>probe</qex> the legality of
all acts, of the crown.</q>
<qau>Hallam.</qau>

<hw>Probe</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Surg.)</fld> <def>An
instrument for examining the depth or other circumstances of a
wound, ulcer, or cavity, or the direction of a sinus, of for
exploring for bullets, for stones in the bladder, etc.</def>

<au>Parr.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Probe</col>, <or/ <col>Probe-pointed</col>,
<col>scissors</col></mcol> <fld>(Surg.)</fld>, <cd>scissors used
to open wounds, the blade of which, to be thrust into the
orifice, has a button at the end.</cd></cs>

<au>Wiseman.</au>

<hw>Pro"bea`gle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>See <er>Porbeagle</er>.</def>

<hw>Probe"-point`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Surg.)</fld> <def>Having a blunt or button-shaped
extremity; -- said of cutting instruments.</def>

<hw>Prob"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>probit\'82</ets>, fr. L. <ets>probitas</ets>, fr.
<ets>probus</ets> good, proper, honest. Cf.
<er>Prove</er>.]</ety> <def>Tried virtue or integrity; approved
moral excellence; honesty; rectitude; uprightness.</def>
\'bd<xex>Probity</xex> of mind.\'b8

<au>Pope.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Probity</er>, <er>Integrity</er>.</syn> <usage>
<xex>Probity</xex> denotes unimpeachable honesty and virtue,
shown especially by the performance of those obligations, called
<xex>imperfect</xex>, which the laws of the state do not reach,
and can not enforce. <xex>Integrity</xex> denotes a
<xex>whole</xex>-hearted honesty, and especially that which
excludes all injustice that might favor one's self. It has a
peculiar reference to uprightness in mutual dealings, transfer of
property, and the execution of trusts for others.</usage>

<hw>Prob"lem</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>probl\'8ame</ets>, L. <ets>problema</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/
anything thrown forward, a question proposed for solution, fr.
<?/ to throw or lay before; <?/ before, forward + <?/ to throw.
Cf. <er>Parable</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A question proposed for solution; a matter
stated for examination or proof; hence, a matter difficult of
solution or settlement; a doubtful case; a question involving
doubt.</def>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Anything which is required to
be done; as, in geometry, to bisect a line, to draw a
perpendicular; or, in algebra, to find an unknown quantity.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Problem</xex> differs from <xex>theorem</xex>
in this, that a problem is something to be done, as to bisect a
triangle, to describe a circle, etc.; a theorem is something to
be proved, as that all the angles of a triangle are equal to two
right angles.</note>

<cs><col>Plane problem</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a problem
that can be solved by the use of the rule and compass.</cd> --
<col>Solid problem</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a problem
requiring in its geometric solution the use of a conic section or
higher curve.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Prob`lem*at"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Prob`lem*at"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>problematicus</ets>, Gr. <?/: cf. F.
<ets>probl\'82matique</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having the nature of a
problem; not shown in fact; questionable; uncertain; unsettled;
doubtful.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Prob`lem*at"ic*al*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<q>Diligent inquiries into remote and <qex>problematical</qex>
guilt leave a gate wide open to . . . informers.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Prob"lem*a*tist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
proposes problems.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<hw>Prob"lem*a*tize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
propose problems.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdHear him
<xex>problematize</xex>.\'b8

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Pro*bos"ci*date</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Proboscis</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Having a
proboscis; proboscidial.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro`bos*cid"e*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<def>An order of large mammal<?/ including the elephants and

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Proboscidian.</def>

<hw>Pro`bos*cid"i*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Proboscidate.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*bos`ci*dif"e*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Proboscis</er>, and <er>-ferous</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An extensive division of
pectinibranchiate gastropods, including those that have a long
retractile proboscis, with the mouth at the end, as the cones,
whelks, tritons, and cowries. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<er>Gastropoda</er>, and of <er>Winkle</er>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A subdivision of the
t\'91nioglossate gastropods, including the fig-shells
(<spn>Pyrula</spn>), the helmet shells (<spn>Cassis</spn>), the
tritons, and allied genera.</def>

<hw>Pro`bos*cid"i*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Having the form or uses of a proboscis; <as>as, a
<ex>proboscidiform</ex> mouth</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*bos"cis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Proboscides</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. fr. Gr. <?/;
<?/ before + <?/ to feed, graze.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A hollow organ or tube
attached to the head, or connected with the mouth, of various
animals, and generally used in taking food or drink; a snout; a
trunk.</def>

<note><hand/ The proboscis of an elephant is a flexible muscular
elongation of the nose. The proboscis of insects is usually a
chitinous tube formed by the modified maxill\'91, or by the
labium. See <xex>Illusts</xex>. of <er>Hemiptera</er> and
<er>Lepidoptera</er>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>By extension, applied to
various tubelike mouth organs of the lower animals that can be
everted or protruded.</def>

<note><hand/ The proboscis of annelids and of mollusks is usually
a portion of the pharynx that can be everted or protruded. That
of nemerteans is a special long internal organ, not connected
with the mouth, and not used in feeding, but capable of being
protruded from a pore in the head. See <xex>Illust</xex>. in
Appendix.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The nose.</def> <mark>[Jocose]</mark>

<cs><col>Proboscis monkey</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Kahau</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pro*cam"bi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.

<hw>Pro`cat*arc"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/ beginning beforehand. fr. <?/ to begin first; <?/ before +
<?/ to begin; <?/ intens. + <?/ to begin: cf. F.
<ets>procatarctique</ets>. ]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld>
<def>Beginning; predisposing; exciting; initial.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<note><hand/ The words <xex>procatarctic causes</xex> have been
used with different significations. Thus they have been employed
synonymously with <xex>prime causes</xex>, <xex>exciting
causes</xex>, and <xex>predisposing</xex> or <xex>remote
causes</xex>.</note>

<q>The physician inquires into the <qex>procatarctic</qex>
causes.</q>
<qau>Harvey.</qau>

<hw>\'d8Pro`cat*arx"is</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<au>Quincy.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pro`ce*den"do</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abl.
of the gerundive of L. <ets>procedere</ets>. see
<er>Proceed</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
writ by which a cause which has been removed on insufficient
grounds from an inferior to a superior court by
<xex>certiorari</xex>, or otherwise, is sent down again to the
same court, <xex>to be proceeded in</xex> there.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>In English practice, a writ issuing out of
chancery in cases where the judges of subordinate courts delay
giving judgment, commanding them to proceed to judgment.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>A writ by which the commission of the justice
of the peace is revived, after having been suspended.</def>

<au>Tomlins. Burrill.</au>

<hw>Pro*ce"dure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>proc\'82dure</ets>. See <er>Proceed</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act or manner of proceeding or moving forward; progress;
process; operation; conduct</def>. \'bdThe true
<xex>procedure</xex> of conscience.\'b8

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A step taken; an act performed; a proceeding;
the steps taken in an action or other legal proceeding.</def>
\'bdGracious <xex>procedures</xex>.\'b8

<au>I. Taylor.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which results; issue; product.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pro*ceed"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Proceeded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Proceeding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>proc\'82der</ets>. fr. L. <ets>procedere</ets>,
<ets>processum</ets>, to go before, to proceed; <ets>pro</ets>
forward + <ets>cedere</ets> to move. See <er>Cede</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To move, pass, or go forward or onward; to
advance; to continue or renew motion begun; <as>as, to
<ex>proceed</ex> on a journey</as>.</def>

<q>If thou <qex>proceed</qex> in this thy insolence.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pass from one point, topic, or stage, to
another; <as>as, to <ex>proceed</ex> with a story or
argument</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To issue or come forth as from a source or
origin; to come from; <as>as, light <ex>proceeds</ex> from the
sun</as>.</def>

<q>I <qex>proceeded</qex> forth and came from God.</q>
<qau>John viii. 42.</qau>

<q>It <qex>proceeds</qex> from policy, not love.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To go on in an orderly or regulated manner; to
begin and carry on a series of acts or measures; to act by
method; to prosecute a design.</def>

<q>He that <qex>proceeds</qex> upon other principles in his
inquiry.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To be transacted; to take place; to occur.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He will, after his sour fashion, tell you
What hath <qex>proceeded</qex> worthy note to-day.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To have application or effect; to operate.</def>

<q>This rule only <qex>proceeds</qex> and takes place when a
person can not of common law condemn another by his sentence.</q>
<qau>Ayliffe.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To begin and carry on a legal
process.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To advance; go on; continue; progress; issue; arise;
emanate.</syn>

<hw>Pro*ceed"ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of one who proceeds, or who prosecutes a
design or transaction; progress or movement from one thing to
another; a measure or step taken in a course of business; a
transaction; <as>as, an illegal <ex>proceeding</ex>; a cautious
or a violent <ex>proceeding</ex>.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>proceedings</qex> of the high commission.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The course of
procedure in the prosecution of an action at law.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<cs><col>Proceedings of a society</col>, <cd>the published record
of its action, or of things done at its meetings.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Procedure; measure; step, See
<er>Transaction</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro"ceeds</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos> <def>That
which comes forth or results; effect; yield; issue; product; sum
accruing from a sale, etc.</def>

<hw>Proc"ess</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>proc\'8as</ets>,
L. <ets>processus</ets>. See <er>Proceed</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of proceeding; continued forward
movement; procedure; progress; advance.</def> \'bdLong
<xex>process</xex> of time.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The thoughts of men are widened with the <qex>process</qex> of
the suns.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau><-- = advance of time? -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A series of actions, motions, or occurrences;
progressive act or transaction; continuous operation; normal or
actual course or procedure; regular proceeding; <as>as, the
<ex>process</ex> of vegetation or decomposition; a chemical
<ex>process</ex>; <ex>processes</ex> of nature.</as></def>

<q>Tell her the <qex>process</qex> of Antonio's end.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A statement of events; a narrative.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Anat. & Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any marked
prominence or projecting part, especially of a bone;
anapophysis.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The whole course of proceedings
in a cause real or personal, civil or criminal, from the
beginning to the end of the suit; strictly, the means used for
bringing the defendant into court to answer to the action; -- a
generic term for writs of the class called
<xex>judicial</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Deacon's process</col> <ety>[from H. <ets>Deacon<ets>,
who introduced it]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a method of
obtaining chlorine gas by passing hydrochloric acid gas over
heated slag which has been previously saturated with a solution
of some metallic salt, as sulphate of copper.</cd> -- <col>Final
process</col> <fld>(Practice)</fld>, <cd>a writ of execution in
an action at law. <au>Burrill</au>.</cd> -- <col>In
process</col>, <cd>in the condition of advance, accomplishment,
transaction, or the like; begun, and not completed.</cd> --
<col>Jury process</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>the process by
which a jury is summoned in a cause, and by which their
attendance is enforced. <au>Burrill</au>.</cd> -- <col>Leblanc's
process</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>the process of
manufacturing soda by treating salt with sulphuric acid, reducing
the sodium sulphate so formed to sodium sulphide by roasting with
charcoal, and converting the sodium sulphide to sodium carbonate
by roasting with lime.</cd> -- <col>Mesne process</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Mesne</er>.</cd> -- <col>Process milling</col>, <cd>the
process of high milling for grinding flour. See under
<er>Milling</er>.</cd> -- <col>Reversible process</col>
<fld>(Thermodynamics)</fld>, <cd>any process consisting of a
cycle of operations such that the different operations of the
cycle can be performed in reverse order with a reversal of their
effects.</cd></cs>

<-- p. 1142 -->

<hw>Pro*ces"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>processio</ets>. See <er>Proceed</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of proceeding, moving on, advancing, or
issuing; regular, orderly, or ceremonious progress; continuous
course.</def>

<au>Bp. Pearson.</au>

<q>That the <qex>procession</qex> of their life might be</q>
<q>More equable, majestic, pure, and free.</q>
<qau>Trench.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is moving onward in an orderly,
stately, or solemn manner; a train of persons advancing in order;
a ceremonious train; a retinue; <as>as, a <ex>procession</ex> of
mourners; the Lord Mayor's <ex>procession</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Here comes the townsmen on <qex>procession</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>An orderly and ceremonial
progress of persons, either from the sacristy to the choir, or
from the choir around the church, within or without.</def>

<au>Shipley.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>An old term
for litanies which were said in procession and not
kneeling.</def>

<au>Shipley.</au>

<cs><col>Procession of the Holy Ghost</col>, <cd>a theological
term applied to the relation of the Holy Spirit to the Father and
the Son, the Eastern Church affirming that the Spirit proceeds
from the Father only, and the Western Church that the Spirit
proceeds from the Father and the Son. <au>Shipley</au>.</cd> --
<col>Procession week</col>, <cd>a name for Rogation week, when
processions were made; Cross-week. <au>Shipley</au>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*ces"sion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To
ascertain, mark, and establish the boundary lines of, as

<hw>Pro*ces"sion*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<cs><col>Processionary moth</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
moth of the genus <spn>Cnethocampa</spn>, especially <spn>C.
processionea</spn> of Europe, whose larv\'91 make large webs on

<hw>Pro*ces"sive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Proceeding; advancing.</def>

<q>Because it is language, -- ergo, <qex>processive</qex>.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<-- (Biochemistry) acting from one end of a polymer, and
continuing to act on the same polymer, rather than detaching and
re-binding randomly to other molecules.  Said of polymerases or
hydrolytic enzymes.  Opposed to "distributive".  Colloquially,
(laboratory slang)  processive and distributive enzymes may be
referred to as "clingers" and "hoppers", respectively. -->

<hw>\'d8Pro`c\'8as" ver`bal"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[ F.]</ety>
<fld>(French Law)</fld> <def>An authentic minute of an official
act, or statement of facts.</def>

<hw>Pro"chein</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prochain</ets>, fr. L. (assumed) <ets>proximanus</ets>, fr.
<ets>proximus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Next; nearest.</def>

<hw>Pro*claim"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Proclaimed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Proclaiming</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>proclamen</ets>, L. <ets>proclamare</ets>; <ets>pro</ets>
before, forward + <ets>clamare</ets> to call or cry out: cf. F.
<ets>proclamer</ets>. See <er>Claim</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make known by public announcement; to give
wide publicity to; to publish abroad; to promulgate; to declare;
<as>as, to <ex>proclaim</ex> war or peace</as>.</def>

<q>To <qex>proclaim</qex> liberty to the captives.</q>
<qau>Isa. lxi. 1.</qau>

<q>For the apparel oft <qex>proclaims</qex> the man.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Throughout the host <qex>proclaim</qex>
A solemn council forthwith to be held.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To outlaw by public proclamation.</def>

<q>I heard myself <qex>proclaimed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To publish; promulgate; declare; announce.  See
<er>Announce</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*claim"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
proclaims.</def>

<hw>Proc`la*ma"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>proclamation</ets>, L. <ets>proclamatio</ets>. See
<er>Proclaim</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of proclaiming; official or general
notice; publication.</def>

<q>King Asa made a <qex>proclamation</qex> throughout all Judah;
none was exempted.</q>
<qau>1 Kings xv. 22.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is proclaimed, publicly announced, or
officially declared; a published ordinance; <as>as, the
<ex>proclamation</ex> of a king; a Thanksgiving
<ex>proclamation</ex>.</as></def>

<hw>Pro*cras"ti*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Procrastinated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Procrastinating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>procrastinatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>procrastinare</ets> to
procrastinate; <ets>pro</ets> forward + <ets>crastinus</ets> of
to-morrow, fr. <ets>cras</ets> to-morrow.]</ety> <def>To put off
till to-morrow, or from day to day; to defer; to postpone; to
delay; <as>as, to <ex>procrastinate</ex> repentance</as>.</def>

<au> Dr. H. More.</au>

<q>Hopeless and helpless \'92geon wend,
But to <qex>procrastinate</qex> his lifeless end.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To postpone; adjourn; defer; delay; retard;
protract; prolong.</syn>

<hw>Pro*cras"ti*nate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To delay; to be
dilatory.</def>

<q>I <qex>procrastinate</qex> more than I did twenty years
ago.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Pro*cras`ti*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>procrastinatio</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>procrastination</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act or habit of
procrastinating, or putting off to a future time; delay;
dilatoriness.</def>

<q><qex>Procrastination</qex> is the thief of time.</q>
<qau>Young.</qau>

<hw>Proc"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>proketour</ets>, contr. fr. <ets>procurator</ets>. See
<er>Procurator</er>.]</ety> <def>One who is employed to manage to
affairs of another.</def> Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
person appointed to collect alms for those who could not go out
to beg for themselves, as lepers, the bedridden, etc.; hence a
beggar.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Nares</au>.  <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Eng. Law)</fld> <def>An officer employed in admiralty and
ecclesiastical causes. He answers to an <xex>attorney</xex> at
common law, or to a <xex>solicitor</xex> in equity.</def>
<au>Wharton</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Ch. of Eng.)</fld> <def>A
representative of the clergy in convocation</def>. <sd>(d)</sd>
<def>An officer in a university or college whose duty it is to
enforce obedience to the laws of the institution.</def>

<-- hall proctor.  a proctor(d) who maintains order within the
hallways of a school, esp. during a shange of class.  THe post is
often occupied by a student -->

<hw>Proc"u*ra*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Procuracies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[LL.
<ets>procuratia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>procuratie</ets>. See
<er>Procuration</er>, and cf,. <er>Proxy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The office or act of a proctor or procurator;
management for another.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Authority to act for another; a proxy.</def>

<hw>Proc`u*ra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>procuratio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>procuration</ets>. See
<er>Procure</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of procuring; procurement.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The management of another's affairs.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The instrument by which a person is empowered to
transact the affairs of another; a proxy.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Ch. of Eng.)</fld> <def>A sum of money paid
formerly to the bishop or archdeacon, now to the ecclesiastical
commissioners, by an incumbent, as a commutation for
entertainment at the time of visitation; -- called also
<altname>proxy</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Procuration money</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>money paid
for procuring a loan.</cd> <au>Blackstone.</au></cs>

<hw>Proc"u*ra`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf.
F. <ets>procurateur</ets>. See <er>Procure</er>, and cf.
<er>Proctor</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who manages another's
affairs, either generally or in a special matter; an agent; a
proctor.</def>

<au>Chaucer. Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld> <def>A governor of a
province under the emperors; also, one who had charge of the
imperial revenues in a province; <as>as, the <ex>procurator</ex>
of Judea</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Procurator fiscal</col> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld>,
<cd>public prosecutor, or district attorney.</cd></cs>

<hw>Proc`u*ra*to"ri*al</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to a procurator, or proctor; made by a
proctor.</def>

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<hw>Proc"u*ra`tor*ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
office or term of a procurator.</def>

<au>Bp. Pearson.</au>

<hw>Pro*cu"ra*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>procuratorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to, or authorizing,
procuration.</def>

<hw>Pro*cure"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Procured</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Procuring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>procurer</ets>, L.
<ets>procurare</ets>, <ets>procuratum</ets>, to take care of;
<ets>pro</ets> for + <ets>curare</ets> to take care, fr.
<ets>cura</ets> care. See <er>Cure</er>, and cf.
<er>Proctor</er>, <er>Proxy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring into possession; to cause to accrue to,
or to come into possession of; to acquire or provide for one's
self or for another; to gain; to get; to obtain by any means, as
by purchase or loan.</def>

<q>If we <qex>procure</qex> not to ourselves more woe.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To contrive; to bring about; to effect; to
cause.</def>

<q>By all means possible they <qex>procure</qex> to have gold and
silver among them in reproach.</q>
<qau>Robynson (More's Utopia) .</qau>

<q>Proceed, Solinus, to <qex>procure</qex> my fall.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To solicit; to entreat.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The famous Briton prince and faery knight, . . . 
Of the fair Alma greatly were <qex>procured</qex>
To make there longer sojourn and abode.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<-- p. 1143 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To cause to come; to bring; to attract.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>What unaccustomed cause <qex>procures</qex> her hither?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To obtain for illicit intercourse or
prostitution.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Attain</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*cure"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To pimp.</def>

<au> Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To manage business for another in court.</def>
<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*cure"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of procuring or obtaining; obtainment;
attainment.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Efficient contrivance; management; agency.</def>

<q>They think it done
By her <qex>procurement</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pro*cur"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>procureur</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who procures, or obtains; one who, or that
which, brings on, or causes to be done, esp. by corrupt
means.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who procures the gratification of lust for
another; a pimp; a pander.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Pro*cur"ess</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A female procurer, or
pander.</def>

<hw>Pro"cy*on</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
constellation which rises before the Dog Star, Gr. <?/; <?/
before + <?/ a dog. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <def>a star of the first
magnitude in the constellation <xex>Canis Minor</xex>, or the
Little Dog.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of mammals
including the raccoon.</def>

<hw>Prod</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Gael. & Ir.
<ets>brod</ets> goad, prickle, sting, and E. <ets>brad</ets>,
also W. <ets>procio</ets> to poke, thrust.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A pointed instrument for pricking or puncturing,
as a goad, an awl, a skewer, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A prick or stab which a pointed
instrument.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A light kind of crossbow; -- in the sense, often
spelled <xex>prodd</xex>.</def>

<au>Fairholt.</au>

<hw>Prod</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Prodded</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Prodding</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To thrust some
pointed instrument into; to prick with something sharp; <as>as,
to <ex>prod</ex> a soldier with a bayonet; to <ex>prod</ex>
oxen</as>; hence, to goad, to incite, to worry; <as>as, to
<ex>prod</ex> a student</as>.</def>

<au> H. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Prodd</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A crossbow. See
<er>Prod</er>, 3.</def>

<hw>Prod"i*gal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prodigus</ets>, from <ets>prodigere</ets> to drive forth, to
squander away; <ets>pro</ets> forward, forth + <ets>agere</ets>
to drive; cf. F. <ets>prodigue</ets>. See <er>Agent</er>. ]</ety>
<def>Given to extravagant expenditure; expending money or other
things without necessity; recklessly or viciously profuse;
lavish; wasteful; not frugal or economical; <as>as, a
<ex>prodigal</ex> man; the <ex>prodigal</ex> son;
<ex>prodigal</ex> giving; <ex>prodigal</ex> expenses.</as></def>

<q>In fighting fields [patriots]  were <qex>prodigal</qex> of
blood.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Profuse; lavish; extravagant; squandering; wasteful.
See <er>Profuse</er>.</syn>

<hw>Prod"i*gal</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who expends money
extravagantly, viciously, or without necessity; one that is
profuse or lavish in any expenditure; a waster; a
spendthrift.</def> \'bdNoble <xex>prodigals</xex> of life.\'b8

<au>Trench.</au>

<hw>Prod`i*gal"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prodigalit\'82</ets>, L. <ets>prodigalitas</ets>. See
<er>Prodigal</er>.]</ety> <def>Extravagance in expenditure,
particularly of money; excessive liberality; profusion; waste; --
opposed to <xex>frugality</xex>, <xex>economy</xex>, and
<xex>parsimony</xex>.</def>\'bdThe <xex>prodigality</xex> of his
wit.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Prod"i*gal*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To
act as a prodigal; to spend liberally.</def>

<au>Sherwood.</au>

<hw>Prod"i*gal*ize</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To expend
lavishly.</def>

<au> Ld. Lytton.</au>

<hw>Prod"i*gal*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a prodigal
manner; with profusion of expense; extravagantly; wasteful;
profusely; lavishly; <as>as, an estate <ex>prodigally</ex>
dissipated</as>.</def>

<q>Nature not bounteous now, but lavish grows;
Our paths with flowers she <qex>prodigally</qex> strows.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Prod"i*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
squander.</def>

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<hw>Prod"i*gence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prodigentia</ets>, fr. <ets>prodigens</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>prodigere</ets>. See <er>Prodigal</er>. ]</ety> <def>Waste;
profusion; prodigality.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Hall.</au>

<hw>Pro*di"gious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prodigiosus</ets>, fr. <ets>prodigium</ets> a prodigy; cf.
F. <ets>prodigieux</ets>. See <er>Prodigy</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of the nature of a prodigy; marvelous;
wonderful; portentous.</def> <mark>[Obs. or R.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>It is <qex>prodigious</qex> to have thunder in a clear
sky.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Extraordinary in bulk, extent, quantity, or
degree; very great; vast; huge; immense; <as>as, a
<ex>prodigious</ex> mountain; a <ex>prodigious</ex> creature; a
<ex>prodigious</ex> blunder.</as></def> 
\'bd<xex>Prodigious</xex> might.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Huge; enormous; monstrous; portentous; marvelous;
amazing; astonishing; extraordinary.</syn>

<hw>Pro*di"gious*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Enormously; wonderfully; astonishingly; <as>as,
<ex>prodigiously</ex> great</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Very much; extremely; <as>as, he was
<ex>prodigiously</ex> pleased</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<au>Pope.</au>

<hw>Pro*di"gious*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being prodigious; the state of having qualities that
excite wonder or astonishment; enormousness; vastness.</def>

<hw>Prod"i*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Prodigies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[ L.
<ets>prodigium</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before + (perh.) a word
appearing in <ets>adagium</ets> adage: cf. F. <ets>prodige</ets>.
Cf. <er>Adage</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Something extraordinary, or out of the usual
course of nature, from which omens are drawn; a portent; <as>as,
eclipses and meteors were anciently deemed
<ex>prodigies</ex></as>.</def>

<q>So many terrors, voices, <qex>prodigies</qex>,
May warn thee, as a sure foregoing sign.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything so extraordinary as to excite wonder or
astonishment; a marvel; <as>as, a <ex>prodigy</ex> of
learning</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A production out of ordinary course of nature;
an abnormal development; a monster.</def>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Wonder; miracle; portent; marvel; monster.</syn>

<hw>Pro*di"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proditio</ets>, from <ets>prodere</ets> to give forth,
betray: cf. OF. <ets>prodition</ets>.]</ety> <def>Disclosure;
treachery; treason.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Ainsworth.</au>

<hw>Pro"i*tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<def>A traitor.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prod`i*to"ri*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
OF. <ets>proditoire</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Treacherous; perfidious; traitorous.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Daniel.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Apt to make unexpected revelations.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdNature is <xex>proditorious</xex>.\'b8

<au>Sir H. Wotton.</au>

<hw>Prod"i*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Treacherous.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to prodromes; <as>as, the
<ex>prodromal</ex> stage of a disease</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro"drome</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<ets>prodrome</ets>.]</ety> <def>A forerunner; a precursor.</def>

<hw>Prod"ro*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Precursory.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Prod"ro*mus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A prodrome.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A preliminary course or publication; -- used
esp. in the titles of elementary works.</def>

<hw>Pro*duce"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Produced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Producing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>producere</ets>,
<ets>productum</ets>, to bring forward, beget, produce;
<ets>pro</ets> forward, forth + <ets>ducere</ets> to lead. See
<er>Duke</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To bring forward; to lead forth; to offer to
view or notice; to exhibit; to show; <as>as, to <ex>produce</ex>
a witness or evidence in court</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Produce</qex> your cause, saith the Lord.</q>
<qau>Isa. xli. 21.</qau>

<q>Your parents did not <qex>produce</qex> you much into the
world.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To bring forth, as young, or as a natural
product or growth; to give birth to; to bear; to generate; to
propagate; to yield; to furnish; <as>as, the earth
<ex>produces</ex> grass; trees <ex>produce</ex> fruit; the clouds
<ex>produce</ex> rain.</as></def>

<q>This soil <qex>produces</qex> all sorts of palm trees.</q>
<qau>Sandys.</qau>

<q>[They] <qex>produce</qex> prodigious births of body or
mind.</q>
<qau> Milton.</qau>

<q>The greatest jurist his country had <qex>produced</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to be or to happen; to originate, as an
effect or result; to bring about; <as>as, disease
<ex>produces</ex> pain; vice <ex>produces</ex> misery.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To give being or form to; to manufacture; to
make; <as>as, a manufacturer <ex>produces</ex> excellent
wares</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To yield or furnish; to gain; <as>as, money at
interest <ex>produces</ex> an income; capital <ex>produces</ex>
profit.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To draw out; to extend; to lengthen; to prolong;
<as>as, to <ex>produce</ex> a man's life to
threescore</as>.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>To extend; -- applied to a
line, surface, or solid; <as>as, to <ex>produce</ex> a side of a
triangle</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*duce"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To yield or furnish
appropriate offspring, crops, effects, consequences, or
results.</def>

<hw>Prod"uce</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That
which is produced, brought forth, or yielded; product; yield;
proceeds; result of labor, especially of agricultural labors;
hence, specifically, agricultural products.</def>

<hw>Pro*duce"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Production.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*du"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>producens</ets>, p. pr.]</ety> <def>One who produces, or
offers to notice.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<hw>Pro*du"cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who produces, brings forth, or
generates.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who grows agricultural products, or
manufactures crude materials into articles of use.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Iron & Steel Manuf.)</fld> <def>A furnace for
producing combustible gas which is used for fuel.</def>

<hw>Pro*du`ci*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being producible.</def>

<au>Barrow.</au>

<hw>Pro*du"ci*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being produced, brought forward, brought forth, generated,
made, or extended.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pro*du"ci*ble*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Prod"uct</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>productus</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>producere</ets>. See
<er>Produce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Anything that is produced, whether as the result
of generation, growth, labor, or thought, or by the operation of
involuntary causes; <as>as, the <ex>products</ex> of the season,
or of the farm; the <ex>products</ex> of manufactures; the
<ex>products</ex> of the brain.</as></def>

<q>There are the <qex>product</qex>
Of those ill-mated marriages.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>These institutions are the <qex>products</qex> of
enthusiasm.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>The number or sum obtained by
adding one number or quantity to itself as many times as there
are units in another number; the number resulting from the
multiplication of two or more numbers; <as>as, the
<ex>product</ex> of the multiplication of 7 by 5 is 35</as>. In
general, the result of any kind of multiplication. See the Note
under <er>Multiplication</er>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Produce; production; fruit; result; effect;
consequence; outcome; work; performance.</syn>

<hw>Pro*duct"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To produce; to bring forward.</def>
\'bd<xex>Producted</xex> to . . . examination.\'b8
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Foxe.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To lengthen out; to extend.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He that doth much . . . <qex>products</qex> his mortality.</q>
<qau>Hackett.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To produce; to make.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holinshed.</au>

<hw>Pro*duct`i*bil"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
state of being productible; producibility.</def>

<au>Ruskin.</au>

<hw>Pro*duct"i*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>productible</ets>.]</ety> <def>Capable of being produced;
producible.</def>

<hw>Pro*duc"tile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>productilis</ets>, fr. <ets>producere</ets> to stretch
out.]</ety> <def>Capable of being extended or prolonged;
extensible; ductile.</def>

<hw>Pro*duc"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>productio</ets> a lengthening, prolonging: cf. F.
<ets>production</ets>. See <er>Produce</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or process or producing, bringing forth,
or exhibiting to view; <as>as, the <ex>production</ex> of
commodities, of a witness</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is produced, yielded, or made,
whether naturally, or by the application of intelligence and
labor; <as>as, the <ex>productions</ex> of the earth; the
<ex>productions</ex> of handicraft; the <ex>productions</ex> of
intellect or genius.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The act of lengthening out or prolonging.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Product; produce; fruit; work; performance;
composition.</syn>

<hw>Pro*duc"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>productif</ets>, L. <ets>productivus</ets> fit for
prolongation.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the quality or power of producing;
yielding or furnishing results; <as>as, <ex>productive</ex> soil;
<ex>productive</ex> enterprises; <ex>productive</ex> labor, that
which increases the number or amount of products.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Bringing into being; causing to exist;
producing; originative; <as>as, an age <ex>productive</ex> of
great men; a spirit <ex>productive</ex> of heroic
achievements.</as></def>

<q>And kindle with thy own <qex>productive</qex> fire.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<q>This is turning nobility into a principle of virtue, and
making it <qex>productive</qex> of merit.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Producing, or able to produce, in large measure;
fertile; profitable.</def>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pro*duc"tive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pro*duc"tive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pro`duc*tiv"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being productive; productiveness.</def>

<au>Emerson.</au>

<q>Not indeed as the product, but as the producing power, the
<qex>productivity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<hw>Pro*duc"tress</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A female
producer.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*duc"tus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Product</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An extinct
genus of brachiopods, very characteristic of the Carboniferous
rocks.</def>

<hw>Pro`e*gu"mi*nal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.

<q>Thus much may serve by way of <qex>proem</qex>.</q>

<hw>Pro"em</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To preface.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>South.</au>

<hw>Pro*em"bry*o</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>pro-</ets> + <ets>embryo</ets>. ]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>The series of cells formed in the ovule of a
flowering plant after fertilization, but before the formation of
the embryo.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The primary growth from the
spore in certain cryptogamous plants; <as>as, the
<ex>proembryo</ex>, or protonema, of mosses</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*e"mi*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Introductory; prefatory; preliminary.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Hammond.</au>

<hw>Pro`emp*to"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
from Gr. <?/ to fall in before; <?/ before + <?/ in + <?/ to
fall.]</ety> <fld>(Chron.)</fld> <def>The addition of a day to

<er>Metemptosis</er>.</def>

<hw>Pro"face</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>interj.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>prou face</ets>, <ets>prou fasse</ets>; <ets>prou</ets>

<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Master page, good master page, sit. <qex>Proface</qex>!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Prof"a*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
profane.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prof`a*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>profanatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>profanation</ets>. See
<er>Profane</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of violating sacred things, or of
treating them with contempt or irreverence; irreverent or too
familiar treatment or use of what is sacred; desecration; <as>as,
the <ex>profanation</ex> of the Sabbath; the <ex>profanation</ex>
of a sanctuary; the <ex>profanation</ex> of the name of
God.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of treating with abuse or disrespect, or
with undue publicity, or lack of delicacy.</def>

<q>'T were <qex>profanation</qex> of our joys
To tell the laity our love.</q>
<qau>Donne.</qau>

<hw>Pro*fane"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>profanus</ets>, properly, before the temple, i. e., without
the temple, unholy; <ets>pro</ets> before + <ets>fanum</ets>
temple. See 1st <er>Fane</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Not sacred or holy; not possessing peculiar
sanctity; unconsecrated; hence, relating to matters other than
sacred; secular; -- opposed to <xex>sacred</xex>,
<xex>religious</xex>, or <xex>inspired</xex>; <as>as, a
<ex>profane</ex> place</as>.</def> \'bd<xex>Profane</xex>
authors.\'b8

<au>I. Disraeli.</au>

<q>The <qex>profane</qex> wreath was suspended before the
shrine.</q>
<qau>Gibbon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Unclean; impure; polluted; unholy.</def>

<q>Nothing is <qex>profane</qex> that serveth to holy things.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Raleigh.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Treating sacred things with contempt,
disrespect, irreverence, or undue familiarity; irreverent;
impious. Hence, specifically; Irreverent in language; taking the
name of God in vain; given to swearing; blasphemous; <as>as, a
<ex>profane</ex> person, word, oath, or tongue</as>.</def> <au>1
Tim. i. 9.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Secular; temporal; worldly; unsanctified;
unhallowed; unholy; irreligious; irreverent; ungodly; wicked;
godless; impious. See <er>Impious</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*fane"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Profaned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Profaning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>profanare</ets>: cf. F. <ets>profaner</ets>. See
<er>Profane</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To violate, as anything sacred; to treat with
abuse, irreverence, obloquy, or contempt; to desecrate; to
pollute; <as>as, to <ex>profane</ex> the name of God; to
<ex>profane</ex> the Scriptures, or the ordinance of
God.</as></def>

<q>The priests in the temple <qex>profane</qex> the sabbath.</q>
<qau>Matt. xii. 5.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put to a wrong or unworthy use; to make a
base employment of; to debase; to abuse; to defile.</def>

<q>So idly to <qex>profane</qex> the precious time.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pro*fane"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a profane
manner.</def>

<q>The character of God <qex>profanely</qex> impeached.</q>
<qau>Dr. T. Dwight.</qau>

<hw>Pro*fane"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or state
of being profane; especially, the use of profane language.</def>

<hw>Pro*fan"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
treats sacred things with irreverence, or defiles what is holy;
one who uses profane language.</def>

<au>Hooker.</au>

<hw>Pro*fan"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>profanitas</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being profane;
profaneness; irreverence; esp., the use of profane language;
blasphemy.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is profane; profane language or
acts.</def>

<q>The brisk interchange of <qex>profanity</qex> and folly.</q>
<qau>Buckminster.</qau>

<hw>Pro*fec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Proficient</er>.]</ety> <def>A setting out; a going forward;
advance; progression.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pro`fec*ti"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>profectitius</ets>, fr. <ets>proficisci</ets> to set out,
proceed.]</ety> <def>Proceeding from, as from a parent; derived,
as from an ancestor.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>The threefold distinction of <qex>profectitious</qex>,
adventitious, and professional was ascertained.</q>
<qau>Gibbon.</qau>

<hw>Pro"fert</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., he brings
forward, 3d pers. pr. of <ets>proferre</ets>. See
<er>Proffer</er>. ]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The exhibition or
production of a record or paper in open court, or an allegation
that it is in court.</def>

<hw>Pro*fess"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Professed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Professing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>prof\'8as</ets>,
masc., <ets>professe</ets>, fem., professed (monk or nun), L.
<ets>professus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>profiteri</ets> to profess;
<ets>pro</ets> before, forward + <ets>fateri</ets> to confess,
own. See <er>Confess</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make open declaration of, as of one's
knowledge, belief, action, etc.; to avow or acknowledge; to
confess publicly; to own or admit freely.</def> \'bdHear me
<xex>profess</xex> sincerely.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>The best and wisest of them all <qex>professed</qex>
To know this only, that he nothing knew.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<-- p. 1144 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To set up a claim to; to make presence to;
hence, to put on or present an appearance of.</def>

<q>I do <qex>profess</qex> to be no less than I seem.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To present to knowledge of, to proclaim one's
self versed in; to make one's self a teacher or practitioner of,
to set up as an authority respecting; to declare (one's self to
be such); <as>as, he <ex>professes</ex> surgery; to
<ex>profess</ex> one's self a physician.</as></def>

<hw>Pro*fess"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To take a profession upon one's self by a public
declaration; to confess.</def>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To declare friendship.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pro*vessel"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Openly
declared, avowed, acknowledged, or claimed; <as>as, a
<ex>professed</ex> foe; a <ex>professed</ex> tyrant; a
<ex>professed</ex> Christian.</as></def>

<cs><col>The professed</col> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <cd>, a
certain class among the Jesuits bound by a special vow. See the
note under <er>Jesuit</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*fess"ed*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
profession.</def>

<hw>Pro*fes"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>professio</ets>.  See <er>Profess</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of professing or
claiming; open declaration; public avowal or acknowledgment;
<as>as, <ex>professions</ex> of friendship; a <ex>profession</ex>
of faith.</as></def>

<q>A solemn vow, promise, and <qex>profession</qex>.</q>
<qau>Bk. of Com. Prayer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which one professed; a declaration; an
avowal; a claim; <as>as, his <ex>professions</ex> are
insincere</as>.</def>

<q>The Indians quickly perceive the coincidence or the
contradiction between <qex>professions</qex> and conduct.</q>
<qau>J. Morse.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That of which one professed knowledge; the
occupation, if not mechanical, agricultural, or the like, to
which one devotes one's self; the business which one professes to
understand, and to follow for subsistence; calling; vocation;
employment; <as>as, the <ex>profession</ex> of arms; the
<ex>profession</ex> of a clergyman, lawyer, or physician; the
<ex>profession</ex> of lecturer on chemistry.</as></def>

<q>Hi tried five or six <qex>professions</qex> in turn.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<note><hand/ <xex>The three professions</xex>, or <xex>learned
professions</xex>, are, especially, theology, law, and
medicine.</note>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The collective body of persons engaged in a
calling; <as>as, the <ex>profession</ex> distrust him</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Eccl. Law.)</fld> <def>The act of entering, or
becoming a member of, a religious order.</def>

<hw>Pro*fes"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to a profession, or calling; conforming to
the rules or standards of a profession; following a profession;
<as>as, <ex>professional</ex> knowledge; <ex>professional</ex>
conduct.</as></def>  \'bdPride, not personal, but
<xex>professional</xex>.\'b8  <au>Macaulay</au>. \'bdA
<xex>professional</xex> sneerer.\'b8 <au>De Quincey</au>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Engaged in by professionals; <as>as, a
<ex>professional</ex> race</as>; -- opposed to
<contr>amateur</contr>.</def>

<hw>Pro*fes"sion*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A person who
prosecutes anything professionally, or for a livelihood, and not
in the character of an amateur; a professional worker.</def>

<hw>Pro*fes"sion*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
following of a profession, sport, etc., as an occupation; --
opposed to <ant>amateurism</ant>.</def>

<hw>Pro*fes"sion*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>professional
person.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*fes"sion*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
professional manner or capacity; by profession or calling; in the
exercise of one's profession; one employed
<xex>professionally</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pro*fess"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
teacher, a public teacher: cf. F. <ets>professeur</ets>. See
<er>Profess</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who professed, or
makes open declaration of, his sentiments or opinions;
especially, one who makes a public avowal of his belief in the
Scriptures and his faith in Christ, and thus unites himself to
the visible church.</def> \'bd<xex>Professors</xex> of
religion.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who professed, or publicly teaches, any
science or branch of learning; especially, an officer in a
university, college, or other seminary, whose business it is to
read lectures, or instruct students, in a particular branch of
learning; as a <xex>professor</xex> of theology, of botany, of
mathematics, or of political economy.</def>

<hw>Prof"fer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<ets>proferen</ets>, F. <ets>prof\'82rer</ets>, fr. L.

<hw>Pro*fi"cient</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pro"file</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.

<def>An outline, or contour; <as>as, the <ex>profile</ex> of an
apple</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Paint & Sculp.)</fld> <def>A human head
represented sidewise, or in a side view; the side face or half
face.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>A section of any
member, made at right angles with its main lines, showing the
exact shape of moldings and the like.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Civil Engin.)</fld> <def>A drawing exhibiting a vertical
section of the ground along a surveyed line, or graded work, as
of a railway, showing elevations, depressions, grades, etc.</def>

<-- 4. a short biography.
  5. [NW10] a set of data, often in graphical form, describing
some significant features of something (e.g. a person,
corporation); esp. a graph showing the results of tests ot some
attribute of a person.
 6. public notice, used esp. in the phrase "(keep/maintain) a low
profile", i.e. avoid public notice, avoid publicity. -->

<hw>Pro"fil*ing</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Fort.)</fld> <def>In

<hw>Pro"fil*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who takes

<hw>Pro"fit</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>profectus</ets> advance, progress, profit, fr.
<ets>profectum</ets>. See <er>Proficient</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Acquisition beyond expenditure; excess of value received for
producing, keeping, or selling, over cost; hence, pecuniary gain
in any transaction or occupation; emolument; <as>as, a
<ex>profit</ex> on the sale of goods</as>.</def>

<q>Let no man anticipate uncertain <qex>profits</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Accession of good; valuable results; useful
consequences; benefit; avail; gain; as, an office of
<xex>profit</xex>,</def>

<q>This I speak for your own <qex>profit</qex>.</q>
<qau>1 Cor. vii. 35.</qau>

<q>If you dare do yourself a <qex>profit</qex> and a right.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Benefit; avail; service; improvement; advancement;
gain; emolument.</syn>

<hw>Prof"it</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Profited</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Profiting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>profiter</ets>.
See <er>Profit</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <def>To be of service
to; to be good to; to help on; to benefit; to advantage; to
avail; to aid; <as>as, truth <ex>profits</ex> all men</as>.</def>

<q>The word preached did not <qex>profit them</qex>.</q>
<qau>Heb. iv. 2.</qau>

<q>It is a great means of <qex>profiting</qex> yourself, to copy
diligently excellent pieces and beautiful designs.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Prof"it</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To gain
advantage; to make improvement; to improve; to gain; to
advance.</def>

<q>I <qex>profit</qex> not by thy talk.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be of use or advantage; to do or bring
good.</def>

<q>Riches <qex>profit</qex> not in the day of wrath.</q>
<qau>Prov. xi. 4.</qau>

<hw>Prof"it*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>profitable</ets>.]</ety> <def>Yielding or bringing profit or

<q>What was so <qex>profitable</qex> to the empire became fatal
to the
emperor.</q>
<qau>Arbuthnot.</qau>

<hw>Prof"li*ga*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Profligate</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>The quality of
state of being profligate; a profligate or very vicious course of
life; a state of being abandoned in moral principle and in vice;
dissoluteness.</def>

<hw>Prof"li*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>profligatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>profligare</ets> to strike
or dash to the ground, to destroy; <ets>pro</ets> before + a word
akin to <ets>fligere</ets> to strike. See
<er>Afflict</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Overthrown; beaten; conquered.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The foe is <qex>profligate</qex>, and run.</q>
<qau>Hudibras.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Broken down in respect of rectitude, principle,
virtue, or decency; openly and shamelessly immoral or vicious;
dissolute; <as>as, <ex>profligate</ex> man or wretch</as>.</def>

<q>A race more <qex>profligate</qex> than we.</q>
<qau>Roscommon.</qau>

<q>Made prostitute and <qex>profligate</qex> muse.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Abandoned; corrupt; dissolute; vitiated; depraved;
vicious; wicked. See <er>Abandoned</er>.</syn>

<hw>Prof"li*gate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An abandoned person;
one openly and shamelessly vicious; a dissolute person.</def>
\'bdSuch a <xex>profligate</xex> as Antony.\'b8

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Pro*found"</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>profond</ets>,
L. <ets>profundus</ets>; pro before, forward + <ets>fundus</ets>
the bottom. See <er>Found</er> to establish, <er>Bottom</er>
lowest part.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Descending far below the
surface; opening or reaching to a great depth; deep.</def> \'bdA
gulf <xex>profound</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Intellectually deep; entering far into subjects;
reaching to the bottom of a matter, or of a branch of learning;
thorough; <as>as, a <ex>profound</ex> investigation or treatise;
a <ex>profound</ex> scholar; <ex>profound</ex> wisdom.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Characterized by intensity; deeply felt;
pervading; overmastering; far-reaching; strongly impressed;
<as>as, a <ex>profound</ex> sleep</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Profound</xex> sciatica.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Of the <qex>profound</qex> corruption of this class there can
be no doubt.</q>
<qau>Milman.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Bending low, exhibiting or expressing deep
humility; lowly; submissive; <as>as, a <ex>profound</ex>
bow</as>.</def>

<q>What humble gestures! What <qex>profound</qex> reverence!</q>
<qau>Dupp<?/.</qau>

<hw>Pro*fuse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>profusus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>profundere</ets> to pour forth
or out; <ets>pro</ets> forward, forth + <ets>fundere</ets> to
pour: cf. F. <ets>profus</ets>. See <er>Fuse</er> to melt.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Pouring forth with fullness or exuberance;
bountiful; exceedingly liberal; giving without stint; <as>as, a
<ex>profuse</ex> government; <ex>profuse</ex>
hospitality.</as></def>

<q>A green, shady bank, <qex>profuse</qex> of flowers.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Superabundant; excessive; prodigal; lavish;
<as>as, <ex>profuse</ex> expenditure</as>.</def>
\'bd<xex>Profuse</xex> ornament.\'b8

<au>Kames.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Lavish; exuberant; bountiful; prodigal;
extravagant.</syn>  -- <usage><er>Profuse</er>, <er>Lavish</er>,
<er>Prodigal</er>. <xex>Profuse</xex> denotes pouring out (as
money, etc.) with great fullness or freeness; as,
<xex>profuse</xex> in his expenditures, thanks, promises, etc.
<xex>Lavish</xex> is stronger, implying unnecessary or wasteful
excess; as, <xex>lavish</xex> of his bounties, favors, praises,
etc.  <xex>Prodigal</xex> is stronger still, denoting unmeasured
or reckless profusion; as, <xex>prodigal</xex> of one's strength,
life, or blood, to secure some object.  <au>Dryden.</au></usage>

<hw>Pro*fuse"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To pour
out; to give or spend liberally; to lavish; to squander.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chapman.</au>

<hw>Pro*fuse"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
profuse manner.</def>

<hw>Pro*fuse"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Extravagance;
profusion.</def>

<qex>profuseness</qex>.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<hw>Prog"ne</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a swallow,

<hw>Prog*no"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.

<hw>Pros*nos"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/.
See <er>Prognosis</er>.]</ety> <def>Indicating something future
by signs or symptoms; foreshowing; aiding in prognosis; <as>as,
the <ex>prognostic</ex> symptoms of a disease;
<ex>prognostic</ex> signs.</as></def>

<hw>Prog*nos"tic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prognosticum</ets>, Gr. <?/: cf. F. <ets>pronostic</ets>,
<ets>prognostic</ets>. See <er>Prognostic</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which prognosticates; a sign by which a
future event may be known or foretold; an indication; a sign or
omen; hence, a foretelling; a prediction.</def>

<q>That choice would inevitably be considered by the country
as a <qex>prognostic</qex> of the highest import.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A sign or symptom indicating
the course and termination of a disease.</def>

<au>Parr.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Sign; omen; presage; token; indication.</syn>

<hw>Prog*nos"tic</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
prognosticate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prog*nos"tic*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Capable of being prognosticated or foretold.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Prog*nos"ti*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prognosticated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prognosticating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[See
<er>Prognostic</er>.]</ety> <def>To indicate as future; to
foretell from signs or symptoms; to prophesy; to foreshow; to
predict; <as>as, to <ex>prognosticate</ex> evil</as>.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<q>I neither will nor can <qex>prognosticate</qex>
To the young gaping heir his father's fate.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To foreshow; foretoken; betoken; forebode; presage;
predict; prophesy.</syn>

<hw>Pro"gram</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Programme</er>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*gram"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Programmata</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[ L. See
<er>Programme</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Gr. Antiq.)</fld> <def>Any law, which, after it
had passed the Athenian senate, was fixed on a tablet for public
inspection previously to its being proposed to the general
assembly of the people.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An edict published for public information; an
official bulletin; a public proclamation.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>See <er>Programme</er>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A preface.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au> T. Warton.</au>

<hw>Pro"gramme</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>programma</ets> a public proclamation, manifesto, Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/ to write before or in public; <?/ before, forth + <?/ to
write; cf. F. <ets>programme</ets>. See <er>Graphic</er>.]</ety>
<def>That which is written or printed as a public notice or
advertisement; a scheme; a prospectus; especially, a brief
outline or explanation of the order to be pursued, or the
subjects embraced, in any public exercise, performance, or
entertainment; a preliminary sketch.</def>

<cs><col>Programme music</col> <fld>(Mus.)</fld>, <cd>descriptive
instrumental music which requires an argument or programme to
explain the meaning of its several movements.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prog"ress</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>progressus</ets>, from <ets>progredi</ets>, p. p.
<ets>progressus</ets>, to go forth or forward; <ets>pro</ets>
forward + <ets>gradi</ets> to step, go: cf. F.
<ets>progr\'8as</ets>. See <er>Grade</er>.]</ety>

<-- each subdefinition implicitly begins with "a moving forward .
. . " -->
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A moving or going forward; a proceeding onward;
an advance</def>; specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <def>In actual
space, as the <xex>progress</xex> of a ship, carriage, etc.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>In the growth of an animal or plant;
increase.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>In business of any kind;
<as>as, the <ex>progress</ex> of a negotiation; the
<ex>progress</ex> of art.</as></def> <sd>(d)</sd> <def>In
knowledge; in proficiency; <as>as, the <ex>progress</ex> of a
child at school</as>.</def> <sd>(e)</sd> <def>Toward ideal
completeness or perfection in respect of quality or condition; --
applied to individuals, communities, or the race; <as>as, social,
moral, religious, or political <ex>progress</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A journey of state; a circuit; especially, one
made by a sovereign through parts of his own dominions.</def>

<q>The king being returned from his <qex>progresse</qex>.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau><-- sic. -->

<hw>Pro*gress"</hw> <pr>(?; <xex>formerly pronounced like</xex>
<er>Progress</er>, <pos>n.</pos>)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Progressed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Progressing</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make progress; to move forward in space; to
continue onward in course; to proceed; to advance; to go on;
<as>as, railroads are <ex>progressing</ex></as>.</def> \'bdAs his
recovery <xex>progressed</xex>.\'b8

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<q>Let me wipe off this honorable dew,
That silverly doth <qex>progress</qex> on thy checks.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>They <qex>progress</qex> in that style in proportion as their
pieces are treated with contempt.</q>
<qau>Washington.</qau>

<q>The war had <qex>progressed</qex> for some time.</q>
<qau>Marshall.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make improvement; to advance.</def>

<au>Bayard.</au>

<q>If man <qex>progresses</qex>, art must <qex>progress</qex>
too.</q>
<qau>Caird.</qau>

<hw>Prog"ress</hw> <pr>(?; see <er>Progress</er>, <pos>v.
i.</pos>)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To make progress in; to
pass through.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pro*gres"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>progressio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>progression</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of moving forward; a proceeding in a
course; motion onward.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Course; passage; lapse or process of time.</def>

<q>I hope, in a short <qex>progression</qex>, you will be wholly
immerged in the delices and joys of religion.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Regular or proportional
advance in increase or decrease of numbers; continued proportion,
arithmetical, geometrical, or harmonic.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mus.)</fld> <def>A regular succession of tones
or chords; the movement of the parts in harmony; the order of the
modulations in a piece from key to key.</def>

<cs><col>Arithmetical progression</col>, <cd>a progression in
which the terms increase or decrease by equal differences, as the
numbers <lbrace2/<matrix2x5><row>2, 4, 6, 8, 10</row><row>10, 8,
6, 4, 2</row></matrix2x5><rbrace2/ by the difference 2.</cd>

 -- <col>Geometrical progression</col>, <cd>a progression in
which the terms increase or decrease by equal ratios, as the
numbers <lbrace2/<matrix2x5><row>2, 4, 8, 16, 32,
64</row><row>64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2</row></matrix2x5><rbrace2/ by a
continual multiplication or division by 2.</cd>

-- <col>Harmonic progression</col>, <cd>a progression in which
the terms are the reciprocals of quantities in arithmetical
progression, as <frac12/, <frac14/, <frac16/, <frac18/,
<frac110/.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*gres"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to progression; tending to, or capable of,
progress.</def>

<hw>Pro*gres"sion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who holds to a belief in the progression of
society toward perfection.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who maintains the doctrine of progression in
organic forms; -- opposed to <xex>uniformitarian</xex>.</def>

<au>H. Spencer.</au>

<hw>Prog"ress*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
makes, or holds to, progress; a progressionist.</def>

<hw>Pro*gress"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>progressif</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Moving forward; proceeding onward; advancing;
evincing progress; increasing; <as>as, <ex>progressive</ex>
motion or course</as>; -- opposed to <ex>retrograde</ex>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Improving; <as>as, art is in a
<ex>progressive</ex> state</as>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Progressive euchre</col> <or/
<col>whist</col></mcol>, <cd>a way of playing at card parties, by
which after every game, the losers at the first table go to the
last table, and the winners at all the tables, except the first,
move up to the next table.</cd> -- <col>Progressive muscular
atrophy</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a nervous disorder
characterized by continuous atrophy of the muscles.</cd></cs>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pro*gress"ive*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pro*gress"ive*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

prog.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>P. Fletcher.</au>

<hw>Progue</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A sharp point; a goad.</def>

<hw>Pro"heme</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Proem.</def>
