<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Pro*hib"it</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prohibited</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Prohibiting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>prohibitus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>prohibere</ets> to prohibit;
<ets>pro</ets> before, forth + <ets>habere</ets> to have, hold.
See <er>Habit</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To forbid by authority; to interdict; <as>as,
God <ex>prohibited</ex> Adam from eating of the fruit of a
certain tree</as>; we <ex>prohibit</ex> a person from doing a
thing, and also the doing of the thing; <as>as, the law
<ex>prohibits</ex> men from stealing, or it <ex>prohibits</ex>
stealing</as>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Prohibit</xex> was formerly followed by
<xex>to</xex> with the infinitive, but is now commonly followed
by <xex>from</xex> with the verbal noun in
<xex>-ing</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To hinder; to debar; to prevent; to
preclude.</def>

<q>Gates of burning adamant,
Barred over us, <qex>prohibit</qex> all egress.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To forbid; interdict; debar; prevent; hinder.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>Prohibit</er>, <er>Forbid</er>. To
<xex>forbid</xex> is Anglo-Saxon, and is more familiar; to
<xex>prohibit</xex> is Latin, and is more formal or official. A
parent <xex>forbids</xex> his child to be out late at night; he
<xex>prohibits</xex> his intercourse with the profane and
vicious.</usage>

<hw>Pro*hib"it*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
prohibits or forbids; a forbidder; an interdicter.</def>

<hw>Pro`hi*bi"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prohibitio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prohibition</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of prohibiting; a declaration or
injunction forbidding some action; interdict.</def>

<q>The law of God, in the ten commandments, consists mostly of
<qex>prohibitions</qex>.</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, the forbidding by law of the sale
of alcoholic liquors as beverages.</def>

<cs><col>Writ of prohibition</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>a writ
issued by a superior tribunal, directed to an inferior court,
commanding the latter to cease from the prosecution of a suit
depending before it.</cd></cs>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<note><hand/ By ellipsis, <xex>prohibition</xex> is used for the
writ itself.</note>

<hw>Pro`hi*bi"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who favors prohibitory duties on foreign
goods in commerce; a protectionist.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who favors the prohibition of the sale (or
of the sale and manufacture) of alcoholic liquors as
beverages.</def>

<hw>Pro*hib"it*ive</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>prohibitif</ets>.]</ety> <def>That prohibits; prohibitory;
<as>as, a tax whose effect is <ex>prohibitive</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*hib"it*o*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prohibitorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to prohibit,
forbid, or exclude; implying prohibition; forbidding; <as>as, a
<ex>prohibitory</ex> law; a <ex>prohibitory</ex>
price.</as></def>
<-- in the latter sense (price or cost) usu. prohibitive. -->

<cs><col>Prohibitory index</col>. <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <cd>See
under <er>Index</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Proin</hw> <pr>(proin)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Prune</er> to trim.]</ety> <def>To lop; to trim; to prune; to
adorn.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>The sprigs that did about it grow
He <qex>proined</qex> from the leafy arms.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<hw>Proin</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To employed in
pruning.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Proj"ect</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>project</ets>, F. <ets>projet</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>projectus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>projicere</ets> to project;
<ets>pro</ets> forward + <ets>jacere</ets> to throw. See
<er>Jet</er> a shooting forth, and cf. <er>Projet</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The place from which a thing projects, or starts
forth.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Holland.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is projected or designed; something
intended or devised; a scheme; a design; a plan.</def>

<q>Vented much policy, and <qex>projects</qex> deep.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q><qex>Projects</qex> of happiness devised by human reason.</q>
<qau>Rogers.</qau>

<q>He entered into the <qex>project</qex> with his customary
ardor.</q>
<qau>Prescott.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An idle scheme; an impracticable design; <as>as,
a man given to <ex>projects</ex></as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Design; scheme; plan; purpose.</syn> <usage> --
<er>Project</er>, <er>Design</er>.  A <xex>project</xex> is
something of a practical nature thrown out for consideration as
to its being done. A <xex>design</xex> is a project when matured
and settled, as a thing to be accomplished. An ingenious man has
many <xex>projects</xex>, but, if governed by sound sense, will
be slow in forming them into <xex>designs</xex>. See also
<er>Scheme</er>.</usage>

<hw>Pro*ject"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Projected</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Projecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
OF. <ets>projecter</ets>, F. <ets>projeter</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To throw or cast forward; to shoot forth.</def>

<q>Before his feet herself she did <qex>project</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Behold! th' ascending villas on my side
<qex>Project</qex> long shadows o'er the crystal tide.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cast forward or revolve in the mind; to
contrive; to devise; to scheme; <as>as, to <ex>project</ex> a
plan</as>.</def>

<q>What sit then <qex>projecting</qex> peace and war?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Persp.)</fld> <def>To draw or exhibit, as the
form of anything; to delineate; <as>as, to <ex>project</ex> a
sphere, a map, an ellipse, and the like</as>; -- sometimes with
<xex>on</xex>, <xex>upon</xex>, <xex>into</xex>, etc.; <as>as, to
<ex>project</ex> a line or point upon a plane</as>. See
<er>Projection</er>, 4.</def>

<hw>Pro*ject"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To shoot forward; to extend beyond something
else; to be prominent; to jut; <as>as, the cornice
<ex>projects</ex>; branches <ex>project</ex> from the
tree.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To form a project; to scheme.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>Pro*ject"ile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>projectile</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Projecting or impelling forward; <as>as, a
<ex>projectile</ex> force</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Caused or imparted by impulse or projection;
impelled forward; <as>as, <ex>projectile</ex> motion</as>.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<hw>Pro*ject"ile</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>projectile</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A body projected, or impelled forward, by force;
especially, a missile adapted to be shot from a firearm.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>A part of
mechanics which treats of the motion, range, time of flight,
etc., of bodies thrown or driven through the air by an impelling
force.</def><-- = ballistics? -->

<-- projectile vomiting, vomiting with such force as to expel the
vomitus over a distance. -->

<hw>Pro*jec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>projectio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>projection</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of throwing or shooting forward.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A jutting out; also, a part jutting out, as of a
building; an extension beyond something else.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The act of scheming or planning; also, that
which is planned; contrivance; design; plan.</def>

<au>Davenant.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Persp.)</fld> <def>The representation of
something; delineation; plan; especially, the representation of
any object on a perspective plane, or such a delineation as would
result were the chief points of the object thrown forward upon
the plane, each in the direction of a line drawn through it from
a given point of sight, or central point; <as>as, the
<ex>projection</ex> of a sphere</as>. The several kinds of
projection differ according to the assumed point of sight and
plane of projection in each.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Geog.)</fld> <def>Any method of representing
the surface of the earth upon a plane.</def>

<cs><col>Conical projection</col>, <cd>a mode of representing the
sphere, the <xex>spherical surface<xex> being projected upon the
surface of a cone tangent to the sphere, the point of sight being
at the center of the sphere.</cd> -- <col>Cylindric
projection</col>, <cd>a mode of representing the sphere, the
<xex>spherical surface<xex> being projected upon the surface of a
cylinder touching the sphere, the point of sight being at the
center of the sphere.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Globular</col>,
<col>Gnomonic</col>, <col>Orthographic</col>,
<col>projection</col>,etc.</mcol> <cd>See under
<er>Globular</er>, <er>Gnomonic</er>, etc.</cd> --
<col>Mercator's projection</col>, <cd>a mode of representing the
sphere in which the meridians are drawn parallel to each other,
and the parallels of latitude are straight lines whose distance
from each other increases with their distance from the equator,
so that at all places the degrees of latitude and longitude have
to each other the same ratio as on the sphere itself.</cd> --
<col>Oblique projection</col>, <cd>a projection made by parallel
lines drawn from every point of a figure and meeting the plane of
projection obliquely.</cd> -- <col>Polar projection</col>, <cd>a
projection of the sphere in which the point of sight is at the
center, and the plane of projection passes through one of the
polar circles.</cd> -- <col>Powder of projection</col>
<fld>(Alchemy.)</fld>, <cd>a certain powder cast into a crucible
or other vessel containing prepared metal or other matter which
is to be thereby transmuted into gold.</cd> -- <col>Projection of
a point on a plane</col> <fld>(Descriptive Geom.)</fld>, <cd>the
foot of a perpendicular to the plane drawn through the
point.</cd> -- <col>Projection of a straight line of a
plane</col>, <cd>the straight line of the plane connecting the
feet of the perpendiculars let fall from the extremities of the
given line.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Protuberance</er>.</syn>

<-- projectionist.  one who operates a projector[2]; esp. one who
is employed to operate a movie projector in a movie theater -->

contrivance; projection.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Clarendon.</au>

<hw>Pro*ject"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

<au>L'Estrange.</au>

<-- an optical instrument which projects an image from a
transparency onto a projection screen or other surface, using an

  Slide projector; movie projector.  Overhead projector. -->

<hw>\'d8Pro*lep"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A figure by

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chron.)</fld> <def>An error in chronology,

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The application of an
adjective to a noun in anticipation, or to denote the result, of
the action of the verb; <as>as, to strike one
<ex>dumb</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*lif"er*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>To produce zooids by

<hw>Pro*lif`er*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The continuous development of

<au>Virchow.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The production of numerous

succession.</def>

<hw>Pro*lif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proles</ets> offspring + <ets>-ferous</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Bearing offspring; -- applied
to a flower from within which another is produced, or to a branch
or frond from which another rises, or to a plant which is
reproduced by buds or gemm\'91.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Producing
young by budding.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Producing sexual zooids
by budding; -- said of the blastostyle of a hydroid.</def>
<sd>(c)</sd> <def>Producing a cluster of branchlets from a larger
branch; -- said of corals.</def>

<cs><col>Proliferous cyst</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a cyst
that produces highly-organized or even vascular
structures.</cd></cs>

<au>Paget.</au>

<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pro*lif"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prolifique</ets>, fr. L. <ets>proles</ets> offspring (from
<ets>pro</ets> for, forward + the root of <ets>alere</ets> to
nourish) + <ets>facere</ets> to make. See <er>Adult</er>,
<er>Old</er>, and <er>Fact</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having the quality of generating; producing
young or fruit; generative; fruitful; productive; -- applied to
plants producing fruit, animals producing young, etc.; -- usually
with the implied idea of frequent or numerous production; <as>as,
a <ex>prolific</ex> tree, female, and the like</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Serving to produce; fruitful of results; active;
<as>as, a <ex>prolific</ex> brain; a controversy
<ex>prolific</ex> of evil.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Proliferous.</def>

<hw>Pro*lif"ic*a*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Prolificness.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

young or fruit abundantly; fruitful; prolific.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pro*lif"ic*al*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pro*lif`i*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>prolification</ets>, LL. <ets>prolificatio</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The generation of young.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Reproduction by the growth of
a plant, or part of a plant, directly from an older one, or by
gemm\'91.</def>

<hw>Pro*lif"ic*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being prolific; fruitfulness;
prolificacy.</def>

<hw>Pro*lix"</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prolixus</ets> extended, long, prolix, probably fr.
<ets>pro</ets> before, forward + <ets>liqui</ets> to flow, akin
to <ets>liquidus</ets> liquid; cf. OL. <ets>lixa</ets> water: cf.
F. <ets>prolixe</ets>. See <er>Liquid</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Extending to a great length; unnecessarily long;
minute in narration or argument; excessively particular in
detail; -- rarely used except with reference to discourse written
or spoken; <as>as, a <ex>prolix</ex> oration; a <ex>prolix</ex>
poem; a <ex>prolix</ex> sermon.</as></def>

<q>With wig <qex>prolix</qex>, down flowing to his waist.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Indulging in protracted discourse; tedious;
wearisome; -- applied to a speaker or writer.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Long; diffuse; prolonged; protracted; tedious;
tiresome; wearisome.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Prolix</er>,
<er>Diffuse</er>. A <xex>prolix</xex> writer delights in
circumlocution, extended detail, and trifling particulars. A
<xex>diffuse</xex> writer is fond of amplifying, and abounds in
epithets, figures, and illustrations.  <xex>Diffuseness</xex>
often arises from an exuberance of imagination;
<xex>prolixity</xex> is generally connected with a want of
it.</usage>

<hw>Pro*lix"ious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Dilatory;
tedious; superfluous.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdLay by all
nicety, and <xex>prolixious</xex> blushes.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pro*lix"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prolixitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prolixit\'82</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The quality or state of being prolix; great length; minute
detail; <as>as, <ex>prolixity</ex> in discourses and
writings</as>.</def> \'bdFor fulsomeness of his
<xex>prolixitee</xex>.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Idly running on with vain <qex>prolixity</qex>.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<hw>Pro*lix"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a prolix
manner.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pro*lix"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Prolixity.</def>

<au>Adam Smith.</au>

<hw>Pro*long"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prolonged</er>

<er>Prolonging</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>prolonger</ets>,
L. <ets>prolongare</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before, forth +
<ets>longus</ets> long. See <er>Long</er>, <pos>a.<pos>, and cf.
<er>Prolongate</er>, <er>Purloin</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To extend in space or length; <as>as, to
<ex>prolong</ex> a line</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To lengthen in time; to extend the duration of;
to draw out; to continue; <as>as, to <ex>prolong</ex> one's
days</as>.</def>

<au> Shak.</au>

<hw>\'d8Prom"e*rops</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ before + <?/ bee-eater.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Any one of several species of very brilliant birds belonging
to <xex>Promerops</xex>, <xex>Epimarchus</xex>, and allied
genera, closely related to the paradise birds, and mostly native
of New Guinea. They have a long curved beak and a long graduated
tail.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*me"the*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.
See <er>Prometheus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A
large American bombycid moth (<spn>Callosamia promethea</spn>).
Its larva feeds on the sassafras, wild cherry, and other trees,
and suspends its cocoon from a branch by a silken band.</def>

<hw>Pro*me"the*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pro*me"the*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
Gr. <?/, from <?/ to have forethought for.]</ety> <fld>(Class.
Myth.)</fld> <def>The son of Iapetus (one of the Titans) and
Clymene, fabled by the poets to have surpassed all mankind in
knowledge, and to have formed men of clay to whom he gave life by
means of fire stolen from heaven. Jupiter, being angry at this,
sent Mercury to bind Prometheus to Mount Caucasus, where a
vulture preyed upon his liver.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Prom"i*nence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Prom"i*nen*cy</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prominentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prominence</ets>. See
<er>Prominent</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being prominent; a
standing out from something; conspicuousness.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is prominent; a protuberance.</def>

<cs><col>Solar prominences</col>. <fld>(Astron.)</fld> <cd>See
<cref>Solar Protuberances</cref>, under
<er>Protuberance</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prom"i*nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prominens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>prominere</ets> to jut out, to project; <ets>pro</ets>
before, forward + <ets>minere</ets> (in comp.) to jut, project:
cf. F. <ets>prominent</ets>. See <er>Imminent</er>,
<er>Eminent</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Standing out, or projecting, beyond the line
surface of something; jutting; protuberant; in high relief;
<as>as, a <ex>prominent</ex> figure on a vase</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence; Distinctly manifest; likely to attract
attention from its size or position; conspicuous; <as>as, a
<ex>prominent</ex> feature of the face; a <ex>prominent</ex>
building.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Eminent; distinguished above others; <as>as, a
<ex>prominent</ex> character</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Prominent' moth</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any
moth of the family <spn>Notodontid\'91</spn>; a notodontian; --
so called because the larva has a hump or prominence on its back.
Several of the species are injurious to fruit trees.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prom"i*nent*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a prominent
manner.</def>

<hw>Pro`mis*cu"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Promiscuousness; confusion.</def>

<au>H. Spencer.</au>

<hw>Pro*mis"cu*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>promiscuus</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before, in place of, for +
<ets>miscere</ets> to mix. See <er>Mix</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Consisting of individuals united in a body or
mass without order; mingled; confused; undistinguished; <as>as, a
<ex>promiscuous</ex> crowd or mass</as>.</def>

<q>A wild, where weeds and flowers <qex>promiscuous</qex>
shoot.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Distributed or applied without order or
discrimination; not restricted to an individual; common;
indiscriminate; <as>as, <ex>promiscuous</ex> love or
intercourse</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*mis"cu*ous*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a promiscuous
manner.</def>

<hw>Pro*mis"cu*ous*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being promiscuous.</def>

<hw>Prom"ise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>promesse</ets>, L. <ets>promissum</ets>, fr.
<ets>promittere</ets>, <ets>promissum</ets>, to put forth,
foretell, promise; <ets>pro</ets> forward, for +
<ets>mittere</ets> to send. See <er>Mission</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>In general, a declaration, written or verbal,
made by one person to another, which binds the person who makes
it to do, or to forbear to do, a specified act; a declaration
which gives to the person to whom it is made a right to expect or
to claim the performance or forbearance of a specified act.</def>

<q>For if the inheritance be of the law, it is no more of
<qex>promise</qex>: but God gave it to Abraham by
<qex>promise</qex>.</q>
<qau>Gal. iii. 18.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>An engagement by one person to
another, either in words or in writing, but properly not under
seal, for the performance or nonperformance of some particular
thing.  The word <xex>promise</xex> is used to denote the mere
engagement of a person, without regard to the consideration for
it, or the corresponding duty of the party to whom it is
made.</def>

<au>Chitty. Parsons. Burrill.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which causes hope, expectation, or
assurance; especially, that which affords expectation of future
distinction; <as>as, a youth of great
<ex>promise</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>My native country was full of youthful <qex>promise</qex>.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Bestowal, fulfillment, or grant of what is
promised.</def>

<q>He . . . commanded them that they should not depart from
Jerusalem, but wait for the <qex>promise</qex> of the Father.</q>
<qau>Acts i. 4.</qau>

<hw>Prom"ise</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Promised</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Promising</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To engage to do, give, make, or to refrain from
doing, giving, or making, or the like; to covenant; to engage;
<as>as, to <ex>promise</ex> a visit; to <ex>promise</ex> a
cessation of hostilities; to <ex>promise</ex> the payment of
money.</as></def> \'bdTo <xex>promise</xex> aid.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To afford reason to expect; to cause hope or
assurance of; <as>as, the clouds <ex>promise</ex>
rain</as>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To make declaration of or give assurance of, as
some benefit to be conferred; to pledge or engage to bestow;
<as>as, the proprietors <ex>promised</ex> large tracts of land;
the city <ex>promised</ex> a reward.</as></def>

<cs><col>Promised land</col>. <cd>See <cref>Land of
promise</cref>, under <er>Land</er>.</cd> -- <col>To promise
one's self</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To resolve; to
determine; to vow</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To be assured; to have
strong confidence.</cd></cs>

<q>I dare <qex>promise myself</qex> you will attest the truth of
all I have advanced.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<hw>Prom"ise</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To give assurance by a promise, or binding
declaration.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To afford hopes or expectation; to give ground
to expect good; rarely, to give reason to expect evil.</def>

<q>Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?
I fear it, I <qex>promise</qex> you.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

therein, or on demand, or at sight, a certain sum of money,
absolutely and at all events; -- frequently called a
<altname>note of hand</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prom"ont</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Promontory.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Drayton.</au>

<hw>Prom"on*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Promontories</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[ L.
<ets>promonturium</ets>, <ets>promunturium</ets>; <ets>pro</ets>
before + <ets>mons</ets>, <ets>montis</ets>, mountain: cf. F.
<ets>promontoire</ets>. See <er>Mount</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Phys. Geog.)</fld> <def>A high point of land or
rock projecting into the sea beyond the line of coast; a
headland; a high cape.</def>

<q>Like one that stands upon a <qex>promontory</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A projecting part.
Especially: <sd>(a)</sd> The projecting angle of the ventral side
of the sacrum where it joins the last lumbar vertebra.
<sd>(b)</sd> A prominence on the inner wall of the tympanum of
the ear.</def>

<hw>Pro*mer`pho*log"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Relating to promorphology; <as>as, a
<ex>promorphological</ex> conception</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro`mor*phol"o*gist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>One versed in the science of
promorphology.</def>

<hw>Pro`mor*phol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Pref. <ets>pro-</ets> + <ets>morphology</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Crystallography of organic forms; -- a
division of morphology created by Haeckel. It is essentially
stereometric, and relates to a mathematical conception of organic
forms. See <er>Tectology</er>.</def>

<hw>Pro*mote"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Promoted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Promoting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>promotus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>promovere</ets> to move
forward, to promote; <ets>pro</ets> forward + <ets>movere</ets>
to move. See <er>Move</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To contribute to the growth, enlargement, or
prosperity of (any process or thing that is in course); to
forward; to further; to encourage; to advance; to excite; <as>as,
to <ex>promote</ex> learning; to <ex>promote</ex> disorder; to
<ex>promote</ex> a business venture.</as></def> \'bdBorn to
<xex>promote</xex> all truth.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To exalt in station, rank, or honor; to elevate;
to raise; to prefer; to advance; <as>as, to promote an
officer</as>.</def>

<q>I will <qex>promote</qex> thee unto very great honor.</q>
<qau>Num. xxii. 17.</qau>

<q>Exalt her, and she shall <qex>promote</qex> thee.</q>
<qau>Prov. iv. 18.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To forward; advance; further; patronize; help;
exalt; prefer; elevate; dignify.</syn>

<hw>Pro*mote"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To urge on or incite
another, as to strife; also, to inform against a person.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*mot"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, forwards, advances, or
promotes; an encourager; <as>as, a <ex>promoter</ex> of charity
or philosophy</as>.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Specifically, one who sets on foot, and takes
the preliminary steps in, a scheme for the organization of a
corporation, a joint-stock company, or the like.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One who excites; <as>as, a <ex>promoter</ex> of
sedition</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An informer; a makebate.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Tusser.</au>

<hw>Pro*mot"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>promotio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>promotion</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
act of promoting, advancing, or encouraging; the act of exalting
in rank or honor; also, the condition of being advanced,
encouraged, or exalted in honor; preferment.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q><qex>Promotion</qex> cometh neither from the east, nor from
the west, nor from the south.</q>
<qau>Ps. lxxv. 6.</qau>

<hw>Pro*mo"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Tending to
advance, promote, or encourage.</def>

<au>Hume.</au>

<hw>Pro*move"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Promote</er>.]</ety> <def>To move forward; to advance; to
promote.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bp. Fell.</au>

<hw>Pro*mov"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
promoter.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Promt</hw> <pr>(?; 215)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Prompter</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Promptest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>prompt</ets>, L. <ets>promptus</ets>, properly, brought
forth (to light or view), hence, visible, evident, at hand,
ready, quick, -- p. p. of <ets>promere</ets> to take or bring
forth; <ets>pro</ets> forth + <ets>emere</ets> to take. See
<er>Redeem</er>. ]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Ready and quick to act as occasion demands;
meeting requirements readily; not slow, dilatory, or hesitating
in decision or action; responding on the instant; immediate;
<as>as, <ex>prompt</ex> in obedience or compliance</as>; -- said
of persons.</def>

<q>Very discerning and <qex>prompt</qex> in giving orders.</q>
<qau>Clarendon.</qau>

<q>Tell him I am <qex>prompt</qex>
To lay my crown at's feet.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Any you, perhaps, too <qex>prompt</qex> in your replies.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Done or rendered quickly, readily, or
immediately; given without delay or hesitation; -- said of
conduct; <as>as, <ex>prompt</ex> assistance</as>.</def>

<q>When Washington heard the voice of his country in distress,
his obedience was <qex>prompt</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ames.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Easy; unobstructed.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>The reception of the light into the body of the building was
very <qex>prompt</qex>.</q>
<qau>Sir H. Wotton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Ready; expeditious; quick; agile; alert; brisk;
nimble.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Prompt</er>, <er>Ready</er>,
<er>Expeditious</er>. One who is <xex>ready</xex> is prepared to
act at the moment. One who is <xex>prompt</xex> acts at the
moment. One who is <xex>expeditious</xex> carries through an
undertaking with constant promptness.</usage>

<hw>Prompt</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Com.)</fld> <def>A limit of
time given for payment of an account for produce purchased, this
limit varying with different goods. See
<er>Prompt-note</er>.</def>

<q>To cover any probable difference of price which might arise
before the expiration of the <qex>prompt</qex>, which for this
article [tea] is three months.</q>
<qau>J. S. Mill.</qau>

<hw>Prompt</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Prompted</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prompting</er>.]</wordforms>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To assist or induce the action of; to move to
action; to instigate; to incite.</def>

<q>God first . . . <qex>prompted</qex> on the infirmities of the
infant world by temporal prosperity.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To suggest; to dictate.</def>

<q>And whispering angles <qex>prompt</qex> her golden dreams.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To remind, as an actor or an orator, of words or
topics forgotten.</def>

<hw>Prompt"-book`</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
book used by a prompter of a theater.</def>

<hw>Prompt"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, prompts; one who
admonishes or incites to action.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who reminds another, as an actor or an
orator, of the words to be spoken next; specifically, one
employed for this purpose in a theater.</def>

<hw>Prompt"i*tude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>promptitudo</ets>. See <er>Prompt</er>,
<pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>The quality of being prompt; quickness
of decision and action when occasion demands; alacrity; <as>as,
<ex>promptitude</ex> in obedience</as>.</def>

<q>Men of action, of <qex>promptitude</qex>, and of courage.</q>
<qau>I. Taylor.</qau>

<hw>Prompt"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a prompt
manner.</def>

<hw>Prompt"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Promptitude; readiness; quickness of decision or
action.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Cheerful willingness; alacrity.</def>

<hw>Prompt"-note`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Com.)</fld> <def>A memorandum of a sale, and time when
payment is due, given to the purchaser at a sale of goods.</def>

<hw>Promp"tu*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to preparation.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Promp"tu*a*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>promptuarium</ets>, fr. <ets>promptuarius</ets> belonging to
distribution, distributing: cf, F. <ets>promptuaire</ets>. See
<er>Prompt</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>That from which

<au>Woodward.</au>

<hw>Promp"ture</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

<au>Shak. Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pro*mul"gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Promulgated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Promulgating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>promulgatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>promulgare</ets> to
promulgate; of unknown origin. Cf. <er>Promulge</er>.]</ety>
<def>To make known by open declaration, as laws, decrees, or
tidings; to publish; <as>as, to <ex>promulgate</ex> the secrets
of a council</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To publish; declare; proclaim. See
<er>Announce</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro`mul*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>promulgatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>promulgation</ets>.]</ety>
<def>The act of promulgating; publication; open declaration;
<as>as, the <ex>promulgation</ex> of the gospel</as>.</def>

<au>South.</au>

<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>One who promulgates or publishes.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Pro*mulge"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Promulged</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Promulging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>promulguer</ets>.

<hw>\'d8Pro*na"os</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.

<hw>Pro"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pronatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>pronare</ets> to bend forward.
See <ets>Prone</ets>.]</ety> <def>Somewhat prone; inclined;
<as>as, <ex>pronate</ex> trees</as>.</def>

<au>Kane.</au>

<hw>Pro*na"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pronation</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The act of turning the palm or palmar surface of the
forefoot downward.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>That motion of the
forearm whereby the palm or palmar, surface is turned
downward.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The position of the limb
resulting from the act of pronation. Opposed to
<xex>supination</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pro*na"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A muscle which produces pronation.</def>

<hw>Prone</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pronus</ets>, akin to Gr. <?/, <?/, Skr. <ets>pravana</ets>
sloping, inclined, and also to L. <ets>pro</ets> forward, for.
See <er>Pro-</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Bending forward; inclined; not erect.</def>

<q>Towards him they bend
With awful reverence <qex>prone</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Prostrate; flat; esp., lying with the face down;
-- opposed to <xex>supine</xex>.</def>

<q>Which, as the wind,
Blew where it listed, laying all things <qex>prone</qex>.</q>
<qau>Byron.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Headlong; running downward or headlong.</def>
\'bdDown thither <xex>prone</xex> in flight.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Sloping, with reference to a line or surface;
declivous; inclined; not level.</def>

<q>Since the floods demand,
For their descent, a <qex>prone</qex> and sinking land.</q>
<qau>Blackmore.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Inclined; propense; disposed; -- applied to the
mind or affections, usually in an ill sense. Followed by
<xex>to</xex>.</def> \'bd<xex>Prone</xex> to mischief.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Poets are nearly all <qex>prone</qex> to melancholy.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<hw>Prone"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a prone manner or
position.</def>

<hw>Prone"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being prone, or of
bending downward; <as>as, the <ex>proneness</ex> of beasts is
opposed to the erectness of man</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of lying with the face down; --
opposed to <xex>supineness</xex>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Descent; declivity; <as>as, the
<ex>proneness</ex> of a hill</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Inclination of mind, heart, or temper;
propension; disposition; <as>as, <ex>proneness</ex> to
self-gratification</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*neph"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the pronephros.</def>

<ety>[ NL., fr. Gr. <?/ before + <?/ a kidney.]</ety>

<hw>Prong</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D.
<ets>prangen</ets> to pinch, press, LG. <ets>prange</ets> a
stick, or W. <ets>procio</ets> to thrust, E. <ets>prowl</ets>,
<ets>pang</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A sharp-pointed instrument.</def>

<q>Prick it on a <qex>prong</qex> of iron.</q>
<qau>Sandys.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The tine of a fork, or of a similar instrument;
<as>as, a fork of two or three <ex>prongs</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A sharp
projection, as of an antler.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The fang of
a tooth.</def>

<hw>Prong"-hoe`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A hoe with
prongs to break the earth.</def>

<hw>Prong"horn`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An American antelope (<spn>Antilocapra
Americana</spn>), native of the plain near the Rocky Mountains.
The upper parts are mostly yellowish brown; the under parts, the
sides of the head and throat, and the buttocks, are white. The
horny sheath of the horns is shed annually. Called also
<altname>cabr\'82e</altname>, <altname>cabut</altname>,
<altname>prongbuck</altname>, and <altname>pronghorned
antelope</altname>.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Pro"noun</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Pref.
<ets>pro-</ets> + <ets>noun</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pronom</ets>, L.
<ets>pronomen</ets>. See <er>Noun</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>
<def>A word used instead of a noun or name, to avoid the
repetition of it. The personal pronouns in English are
<xex>I</xex>, <xex>thou</xex> or <xex>you</xex>, <xex>he</xex>,
<xex>she</xex>, <xex>it</xex>, <xex>we</xex>, <xex>ye</xex>, and
<xex>they</xex>.</def><-- accusatives? me, them, us -->

<hw>Pro*nounce"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pronounced</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pronounging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>prononcer</ets>, L.
<ets>pronunciare</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before, forth +
<ets>nunciare</ets>, <ets>nuntiare</ets>, to announce. See
<er>Announce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To utter articulately; to speak out or
distinctly; to utter, as words or syllables; to speak with the
proper sound and accent <as>as, adults rarely learn to
<ex>pronounce</ex> a foreign language correctly</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To utter officially or solemnly; to deliver, as
a decree or sentence; <as>as, to <ex>pronounce</ex> sentence of
death</as>.</def>

<q>Sternly he <qex>pronounced</qex>
The rigid interdiction.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To speak or utter rhetorically; to deliver; to
recite; <as>as, to <ex>pronounce</ex> an oration</as>.</def>

<q>Speak the speech, I pray you, as I <qex>pronounced</qex> it to
you.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To declare or affirm; <as>as, he
<ex>pronounced</ex> the book to be a libel; he
<ex>pronounced</ex> the act to be a fraud.</as></def>

<q>The God who hallowed thee and blessed,
<qex>Pronouncing</qex> thee all good.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To deliver; utter; speak. See
<er>Deliver</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*nounce"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To give a pronunciation; to articulate; <as>as,
to <ex>pronounce</ex> faultlessly</as>.</def>

<au>Earle.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make declaration; to utter on opinion; to
speak with confidence.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>Pro*nounce"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Pronouncement;
declaration; pronunciation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Milton.</au>

L. <ets>pronunciabilis</ets> declarative.]</ety> <def>Capable of
being pronounced.</def>

<hw>Pro*nounced"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prononc\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>Strongly marked; unequivocal;
decided. <note>[A Gallicism]</note></def>

<q>[His]  views became every day more <qex>pronounced</qex>.</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<hw>Pro*nounce"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of pronouncing; a declaration; a formal announcement.</def>

<hw>Pro*noun"cer</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
pronounces, utters, or declares; also, a pronouncing book.</def>

<hw>Pro*noun"cing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or indicating, pronunciation; <as>as, a
<ex>pronouncing</ex> dictionary</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*nu"bi*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pronuba</ets> bridesmaid; <ets>pro</ets> before +
<ets>nubere</ets> to marry.]</ety> <def>Presiding over
marriage.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*nu"cle*us</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pronuclei</plw> <pr>(-<imac/)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL. See
<er>Pro-</er>, and <er>Nucleus</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Biol.)</fld>
<def>One of the two bodies or nuclei (called <xex>male</xex> and
<xex>female pronuclei</xex>) which unite to form the first
segmentation nucleus of an impregnated ovum.</def>

<note><hand/ In the maturing of the ovum preparatory to
impregnation, a part of the germinal vesicle (see <cref>Polar
body</cref>, under <er>Polar</er>) becomes converted into a
number of small vesicles, which aggregate themselves into a
single clear nucleus. which travels towards the center of the egg
and is called the <xex>female pronucleus</xex>. In impregnation,
the spermatozo\'94n which enters the egg soon loses its tail,
while the head forms a nucleus, called the <xex>male
pronucleus</xex>, which gradually travels towards the female
pronucleus and eventually fuses with it, forming the first
segmentation nucleus.</note>

<hw>Pro*nun"cial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to pronunciation; pronunciative.</def>

<hw>Pro*nun`ci*a*men"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
proclamation or manifesto; a formal announcement or
declaration.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*nun`ci*a`mi"en"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Sp. See <er>Pronounce</er>.]</ety> <def>See
<er>Pronunciamento</er>.</def>

<hw>Pro*nun`ci*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?; 277)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F. <ets>pronunciation</ets>, L. <ets>pronunciatio</ets>.
See <er>Pronounce</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of uttering with articulation; the act
of giving the proper sound and accent; utterance; <as>as, the
<ex>pronunciation</ex> of syllables of words; distinct or
indistinct <ex>pronunciation</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The mode of uttering words or sentences.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>The art of manner of uttering
a discourse publicly with propriety and gracefulness; -- now
called <altname>delivery</altname>.</def>

<au>J. Q. Adams.</au>

<hw>Pro*nun"ci*a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pronunciativus</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to pronunciation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Uttering confidently; dogmatical.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pro*nun"ci*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a
reciter.]</ety> <def>One who pronounces; a pronouncer.</def>

<hw>Pro*nun"ci*a*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of

<hw>Proof</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>prove</ets>, <ets>proeve</ets>, F. <ets>preuve</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>proba</ets>, fr. <ets>probare</ets> to prove. See
<er>Prove</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Any effort, process, or operation designed to
establish or discover a fact or truth; an act of testing; a test;
a trial.</def>

<q>For whatsoever mother wit or art
Could work, he put in <qex>proof</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>You shall have many <qex>proofs</qex> to show your skill.</q>
<qau>Ford.</qau>

<q>Formerly, a very rude mode of ascertaining the strength of
spirits was practiced, called the <qex>proof</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ure.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That degree of evidence which convinces the mind
of any truth or fact, and produces belief; a test by facts or
arguments that induce, or tend to induce, certainty of the
judgment; conclusive evidence; demonstration.</def>

<q>I'll have some <qex>proof</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>It is no <qex>proof</qex> of a man's understanding to be able
to confirm whatever he pleases.</q>
<qau>Emerson.</qau>

<note><hand/ Properly speaking, <xex>proof</xex> is the effect or
result of evidence, evidence is the medium of proof. Cf.
<er>Demonstration</er>, 1.</note>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The quality or state of having been proved or
tried; firmness or hardness that resists impression, or does not
yield to force; impenetrability of physical bodies.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Firmness of mind; stability not to be
shaken.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>A trial impression, as from
type, taken for correction or examination; -- called also
<altname>proof sheet</altname>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A process for testing the
accuracy of an operation performed.  Cf. <er>Prove</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>, 5.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Armor of excellent or tried quality, and deemed
impenetrable; properly, <xex>armor of proof</xex>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><col>Artist's proof</col>, <cd>a very early proof impression
of an engraving, or the like; -- often distinguished by the
artist's signature.</cd> -- <col>Proof reader</col>, <cd>one who
reads, and marks correction in, proofs. See def. 5,
above.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Testimony; evidence; reason; argument; trial;
demonstration. See <er>Testimony</er>.</syn>

<hw>Proof</hw>, <pos>a.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Used in proving or testing; <as>as, a
<ex>proof</ex> load, or <ex>proof</ex> charge</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Firm or successful in resisting; <as>as,
<ex>proof</ex> against harm; water<ex>proof</ex>;
bomb<ex>proof</ex>.</as></def>

<q>I . . . have found thee
<qex>Proof</qex> against all temptation.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>This was a good, stout <qex>proof</qex> article of faith.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Being of a certain standard as to strength; --
said of alcoholic liquors.</def><-- in the United States, "proof"
is a measure of alcohol concentration expressed as percent of the
concentration of "proof spirit" defined below, i.e. a beverage of
100 proof is 50% alcohol by volume. -->

<cs><col>Proof charge</col> <fld>(Firearms)</fld>, <cd>a charge
of powder and ball, greater than the service charge, fired in an
arm, as a gun or cannon, to test its strength.</cd> -- <col>Proof
impression</col>. <cd>See under <er>Impression</er>.</cd> --
<col>Proof load</col> <fld>(Engin.)</fld>, <cd>the greatest load
than can be applied to a piece, as a beam, column, etc., without
straining the piece beyond the elastic limit.</cd> -- <col>Proof
sheet</col>. <cd>See <er>Proof</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 5.</cd> --
<col>Proof spirit</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>a strong
distilled liquor, or mixture of alcohol and water, containing not
less than a standard amount of alcohol. In the United States
\'bdproof spirit is defined by law to be that mixture of alcohol
and water which contains one half of its volume of alcohol, the
alcohol when at a temperature of 60<deg/ Fahrenheit being of
specific gravity 0.7939 referred to water at its maximum density
as unity. Proof spirit has at 60<deg/ Fahrenheit a specific
gravity of 0.93353, 100 parts by volume of the same consisting of
50 parts of absolute alcohol and 53.71 parts of water,\'b8 the
apparent excess of water being due to contraction of the liquids
on mixture. In England proof spirit is defined by Act 58, George
III., to be such as shall at a temperature of 51<deg/ Fahrenheit
weigh exactly the <frac12x13/ part of an equal measure of
distilled water. This contains 49.3 per cent by weight, or 57.09
by volume, of alcohol. Stronger spirits, as those of about 60,
70, and 80 per cent of alcohol, are sometimes called
<xex>second<xex>, <xex>third<xex>, and <xex>fourth proof
spirits<xex> respectively.</cd> -- <col>Proof staff</col>, <cd>a
straight-edge used by millers to test the flatness of a
stone.</cd> -- <col>Proof stick</col> <fld>(Sugar Manuf.)</fld>,
<cd>a rod in the side of a vacuum pan, for testing the
consistency of the sirup.</cd> -- <col>Proof text</col>, <cd>a
passage of Scripture used to prove a doctrine.</cd></cs>
<-- <mcol><col>proof coin</col> or <col>proof</col></mcol>, <cd>a
coin which has been specially struck, to produce the finest
specimen of its type.</cd> <note>Usually such coins are
double-struck from polished dies, and the raised features are
sometimes frosted.  They thus have sharper features and more
mirror-like fields than production coins (i.e. those coins struck
for circulation); they are considered by coin collectors as the
most desirable specimens of each coin, and usually sell at a
premium to their corresponding production coins.</note>  -->

<hw>Proof`-arm"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To arm
with proof armor; to arm securely; <as>as, to <ex>proof-arm</ex>
herself</as>.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<hw>Prop</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Propped</er>

<er>Propping</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Akin to LG. & D.
<ets>proppen</ets> to cram, stuff, thrust into, stop, G.
<ets>pfropfen</ets>, Dan. <ets>proppe</ets>, Sw.
<ets>proppa</ets>; of uncertain origin, cf. G.
<ets>pfropfen</ets> to graft, fr. L. <ets>propago</ets> set,
layer of a plant, slip, shoot. Cf. 3d. <er>Prop</er>,
<er>Propagate</er>.]</ety> <def>To support, or prevent from

<ex>prop</ex> up a fence or an old building</as>;

sky.</q>

<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I <qex>prop</qex> myself upon those few supports that are left
me.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Prop</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to LG., D., & Dan.
<ets>prop</ets> stopple, stopper, cork, Sw. <ets>propp</ets>, G.
<ets>pfropf</ets>. See <er>Prop</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety>
<def>That which sustains an incumbent weight; that on which
anything rests or leans for support; a support; a stay; <as>as, a
<ex>prop</ex> for a building</as>.</def> \'bdTwo <xex>props</xex>
of virtue.\'b8

<hw>Prop"a*ga*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Propagate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Capable of being propagated, or of being
continued or multiplied by natural generation or
production.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Capable of being spread or extended by any
means; -- said of tenets, doctrines, or principles.</def>

<hw>Prop`a*gan"da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev.
fr. L. <ets>de propaganda fide</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>propagande</ets>. See <er>Propagate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A
congregation of cardinals, established in 1622, charged with the
management of missions.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>The college of
the Propaganda, instituted by Urban VIII. (1623-1644) to educate
priests for missions in all parts of the world.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, any organization or plan for spreading a
particular doctrine or a system of principles.</def>

<hw>Prop`a*gan"dism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>propagandisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>The art or practice of
propagating tenets or principles; zeal in propagating one's
opinions.</def>

<hw>Prop`a*gan"dist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>propagandiste</ets>.]</ety> <def>A person who devotes
himself to the spread of any system of principles.</def>
\'bdPolitical <xex>propagandists</xex>.\'b8

<au>Walsh.</au>

<-- propagandize.  To spread one's beliefs.  Often used in a
negative sense, meaning to deliberately make misleading or false
statements so as to convert others to one's beliefs, or to
convince others to vote for a particular political candidate. -->

<hw>Prop"a*gate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Propagated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Propagating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>propagatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>propagare</ets> to
propagate, akin to <ets>propages</ets>, <ets>propago</ets>, a
layer of a plant, slip, shoot. See <er>Pro-</er>, and cf.
<er>Pact</er>, <er>Prop</er>, <er>Prune</er>, <pos>v.
t.</pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cause to continue or multiply by generation,
or successive production; -- applied to animals and plants;
<as>as, to <ex>propagate</ex> a breed of horses or sheep; to
<ex>propagate</ex> a species of fruit tree.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cause to spread to extend; to impel or
continue forward in space; <as>as, to <ex>propagate</ex> sound or
light</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To spread from person to person; to extend the
knowledge of; to originate and spread; to carry from place to
place; to disseminate; <as>as, to <ex>propagate</ex> a story or
report; to <ex>propagate</ex> the Christian religion.</as></def>

<q>The infection was <qex>propagated</qex> insensibly.</q>
<qau>De Foe.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To multiply; to increase.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,
Which thou wilt <qex>propagate</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To generate; to produce.</def>

<q>Motion <qex>propagated</qex> motion, and life threw off
life.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To multiply; continue; increase; spread; diffuse;
disseminate; promote.</syn>

<hw>Prop"a*gate</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To have young or
issue; to be produced or multiplied by generation, or by new
shoots or plants; <as>as, rabbits <ex>propagate</ex>
rapidly</as>.</def>

<q>No need that thou
Should'st <qex>propagate</qex>, already infinite.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<ets>propagatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>propagation</ets>.]</ety>

multiplication of the kind by generation or successive
production; <as>as, the <ex>propagation</ex> of animals or
plants</as>.</def>

<q>There is not in nature any spontaneous generation, but all
come by <qex>propagation</qex>.</q>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pro*pel"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>Pro*pel"ler</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that which, propels.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A contrivance for propelling a steam vessel,
usually consisting of a screw placed in the stern under water,
and made to revolve by an engine; a propeller wheel.</def>
<-- (b) an analogous device, rotated by an engine at high speed
to provide the forward thrust which propels an airplane through
the atmosphere. On each engine is a propeller consisting of a set
of at least two elongated blades attached symmetrically to a
central rotor. -->

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A steamboat thus propelled; a screw
steamer.</def>

<cs><col>Propeller wheel</col>,<cd>the screw, usually having two
or more blades, used in propelling a vessel.</cd><-- propeller
blade, the elongated part of an airplane propeller --></cs>

<hw>Prop"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>propre</ets>, F. <ets>propre</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>proprius</ets>. Cf. <er>Appropriate</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Belonging to one; one's own; individual.</def>
\'bdHis <xex>proper</xex> good\'b8 [<it>i. e.</it>, his
<xex>own</xex> possessions]. <au>Chaucer</au>. \'bdMy
<xex>proper</xex> son.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>Now learn the difference, at your <qex>proper</qex> cost,
Betwixt true valor and an empty boast.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Belonging to the natural or essential
constitution; peculiar; not common; particular; <as>as, every
animal has his <ex>proper</ex> instincts and
appetites</as>.</def>

<q>Those high and peculiar attributes . . . which constitute our
<qex>proper</qex> humanity.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Befitting one's nature, qualities, etc.;
suitable in all respect; appropriate; right; fit; decent; <as>as,
water is the <ex>proper</ex> element for fish; a <ex>proper</ex>
dress.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>proper</qex> study of mankind is man.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<q>In Athens all was pleasure, mirth, and play,
All <qex>proper</qex> to the spring, and sprightly May.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Becoming in appearance; well formed;
handsome.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark> \'bdThou art a
<xex>proper</xex> man.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Moses . . . was hid three months of his parents, because they
saw he was a <qex>proper</qex> child.</q>
<qau>Heb. xi. 23.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>Pertaining to one of a species, but not common
to the whole; not appellative; -- opposed to <xex>common</xex>;
<as>as, a <ex>proper</ex> name; Dublin is the <ex>proper</ex>
name of a city.</as></def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Rightly so called; strictly considered; <as>as,
Greece <ex>proper</ex>; the garden <ex>proper</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Represented in its natural
color; -- said of any object used as a charge.</def>

<cs><col>In proper</col>, <cd>individually; privately.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Jer. Taylor</au>.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Proper flower</col> <or/ <col>corolla</col></mcol>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>one of the single florets, or corollets,
in an aggregate or compound flower.</cd> -- <col>Proper
fraction</col> <fld>(Arith.)</fld> <cd>a fraction in which the
numerator is less than the denominator.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Proper
nectary</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a nectary separate from the
petals and other parts of the flower.</cd> -- <col>Proper
noun</col></mcol> <fld>(Gram.)</fld>, <cd>a name belonging to an
individual, by which it is distinguished from others of the same
class; -- opposed to <ant>common noun</ant>; as, <xex>John<xex>,
<xex>Boston<xex>, <xex>America<xex>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Proper
perianth</col> <or/ <col>involucre</col></mcol>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>that which incloses only a single
flower.</cd> -- <col>Proper receptacle</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>a receptacle which supports only a single flower or
fructification.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prop"er</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>Properly; hence, to a
great degree; very; <as>as, <ex>proper</ex> good</as>.</def>
<mark>[Colloq & Vulgar]</mark>

<ets>properatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>properare</ets> to
hasten.]</ety> <def>To hasten, or press forward.</def>

<plu>pl. <plw>Properispomena</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ to circumflex on the penult; <?/ before +
<?/ to circumflex. See <er>Perispomenon</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Gr.
Gram.)</fld> <def>A word which has the circumflex accent on the

<hw>Prop"er*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>In a proper manner; suitably; fitly; strictly;
rightly; <as>as, a word <ex>properly</ex> applied; a dress
<ex>properly</ex> adjusted.</as></def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Individually; after one's own manner.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Now, harkeneth, how I bare me <qex>properly</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Prop"er*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality of being proper.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Tallness; comeliness.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Udall.</au>

<hw>Prop"er*tied</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Possessing
property; holding real estate, or other investments of
money.</def> \'bdThe <xex>propertied</xex> and satisfied
classes.\'b8

<au>M. Arnold.</au>

<hw>Prop"er*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Properties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>proprete</ets>, OF. <ets>propret\'82</ets> property, F.
<ets>propret\'82</ets> neatness, cleanliness,
<ets>propri\'82t\'82</ets> property, fr. L.
<ets>proprietas</ets>. See <er>Proper</er>, <pos>a.<pos>, and cf.
<er>Propriety</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is proper to anything; a peculiar
quality of a thing; that which is inherent in a subject, or
naturally essential to it; an attribute; <as>as, sweetness is a
<ex>property</ex> of sugar</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Property</qex> is correctly a synonym for peculiar
quality; but it is frequently used as coextensive with quality in
general.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

<note><hand/ In physical science, the properties of matter are
distinguished to the three following classes: 1. <xex>Physical
properties</xex>, or those which result from the relations of
bodies to the physical agents, light, heat, electricity,
gravitation, cohesion, adhesion, etc., and which are exhibited
without a change in the composition or kind of matter acted on.
They are color, luster, opacity, transparency, hardness,
sonorousness, density, crystalline form, solubility, capability
of osmotic diffusion, vaporization, boiling, fusion, etc.  2.
<xex>Chemical properties</xex>, or those which are conditioned by
affinity and composition; thus, combustion, explosion, and
certain solutions are reactions occasioned by chemical
properties. Chemical properties are identical when there is
identity of composition and structure, and change according as
the composition changes. 3. <xex>Organoleptic properties</xex>,
or those forming a class which can not be included in either of
the other two divisions. They manifest themselves in the contact
of substances with the organs of taste, touch, and smell, or
otherwise affect the living organism, as in the manner of
medicines and poisons.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An acquired or artificial quality; that which is
given by art, or bestowed by man; <as>as, the poem has the
<ex>properties</ex> which constitute excellence</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The exclusive right of possessing, enjoying, and
disposing of a thing; ownership; title.</def>

<q>Here I disclaim all my paternal care,
Propinquity and <qex>property</qex> of blood.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Shall man assume a <qex>property</qex> in man?</q>
<qau>Wordsworth.</qau>

<-- p. 1149 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That to which a person has a legal title,
whether in his possession or not; thing owned; an estate, whether
in lands, goods, or money; <as>as, a man of large
<ex>property</ex>, or small <ex>property</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>All the adjuncts of a play
except the scenery and the dresses of the actors; stage
requisites.</def>

<q>I will draw a bill of <qex>properties</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Propriety; correctness.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Camden.</au>

<cs><col>Literary property</col>. <fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>See under
<er>Literary</er>.</cd> -- <col>Property man</col><-- or prop man
-->, <cd>one who has charge of the \'bdproperties\'b8 of a
theater.</cd></cs>

<hw>Proph"e*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl</plu>.

<hw>Proph"et</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.

<hw>Pro`pi*on"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pro</ets>to-</ets> + <ets>Gr. <grk>pi`wn</grk>
fat.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, derived from,
or designating, an organic acid which is produced in the
distillation of wood, in the fermentation of various organic
substances, as glycerin, calcium lactate, etc., and is obtained
as a colorless liquid having a sharp, pungent odor. Propionic
acid is so called because it is the <xex>first</xex> or lowest
member of the <xex>fatty acid</xex> series whose salts have a
fatty feel.</def>

<hw>Pro*pi"ti*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>

<hw>Pro*pi`ti*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of appeasing the wrath and conciliating

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>That which propitiates;
atonement or atoning sacrifice; specifically, the influence or
effects of the death of Christ in appeasing the divine justice,
and conciliating the divine favor.</def>

<hw>Pro*pi"tious</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>propitius</ets>, perhaps originally a term of augury
meaning, flying forward (<ets>pro</ets>) or well; cf. Skr.
<ets>pat</ets> to fly, E. <ets>petition</ets>,
<ets>feather</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Convenient; auspicious; favorable; kind; <as>as,
a <ex>propitious</ex> season; a <ex>propitious</ex>
breeze.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, kind; gracious; merciful; helpful; --
said of a person or a divinity.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>And now t' assuage the force of this new flame,
And make thee [Love] more <qex>propitious</qex> in my need.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Auspicious; favorable; kind.</syn>  --
<usage><er>Propitious</er>, <er>Auspicious</er>.
<xex>Auspicious</xex> (from the ancient idea of
<xex>auspices</xex>, or omens) denotes \'bdindicative of
success,\'b8 or \'bdfavored by incidental occurrences;\'b8 as, an
<xex>auspicious</xex> opening; an <xex>auspicious</xex> event.
<xex>Propitious</xex> denotes that which efficaciously protect us
in some undertaking, speeds our exertions, and decides our
success; as, <xex>propitious</xex> gales; <xex>propitious</xex>
influences.</usage>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pro*pi"tious*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Pro*pi"tious*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as <er>Proleg</er>.</def>

<hw>Pro*po"di*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

the parts of the limbs to which they belong.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*po`di*a"le</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<?/ before + <?/, dim. of <?/, <?/, foot.]</ety>

thing, the <xex>propodialia</xex> being the humerus and
femur.</def>

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The sixth joint of a typical leg of a
crustacean; usually, the penultimate joint.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro*po"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Propodia</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL. See
<er>Propodiale</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>

<ets>proponere</ets> to propose. See <er>Propound</er>.]</ety>
<def>To propose; to bring forward.</def>

<hw>Pro*po"nent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proponens</ets>, p. pr.]</ety> <def>Making proposals;
proposing.</def>

<hw>Pro*po"nent</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>One who makes a proposal, or lays down a
proposition.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The propounder of a
thing.</def>

<hw>Pro*por"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr.
L. <ets>proportio</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before +
<ets>portio</ets> part or share. See <er>Portion</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The relation or adaptation of one portion to
another, or to the whole, as respect magnitude, quantity, or
degree; comparative relation; ratio; <as>as, the
<ex>proportion</ex> of the parts of a building, or of the
body</as>.</def>

<q>The image of Christ, made after his own
<qex>proportion</qex>.</q>
<qau>Ridley.</qau>

<q>Formed in the best <qex>proportions</qex> of her sex.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<q>Documents are authentic and facts are true precisely in
<qex>proportion</qex> to the support which they afford to his
theory.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Harmonic relation between parts, or between
different things of the same kind; symmetrical arrangement or
adjustment; symmetry; <as>as, to be out of
<ex>proportion</ex></as>.</def> \'bdLet us prophesy according to
the <xex>proportion</xex> of faith.\'b8

<au>Rom. xii. 6.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The portion one receives when a whole is
distributed by a rule or principle; equal or proper share;
lot.</def>

<q>Let the women . . . do the same things in their
<qex>proportions</qex> and capacities.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A part considered comparatively; a share.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The equality or
similarity of ratios, especially of geometrical ratios; or a
relation among quantities such that the quotient of the first
divided by the second is equal to that of the third divided by
the fourth; -- called also <altname>geometrical
proportion</altname>, in distinction from <xex>arithmetical
proportion</xex>, or that in which the difference of the first
and second is equal to the difference of the third and
fourth.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Proportion</xex> in the mathematical sense
differs from <xex>ratio</xex>. <xex>Ratio</xex> is the relation
of two quantities of the same kind, as the ratio of 5 to 10, or
the ratio of 8 to 16. <xex>Proportion</xex> is the sameness or
likeness of two such relations. Thus, 5 to 10 as 8 to 16; that
is, 5 bears the same relation to 10 as 8 does to 16. Hence, such
numbers are said to be in <xex>proportion</xex>.
<xex>Proportion</xex> is expressed by symbols thus:

<mathex>a:b::c:d</mathex>, or <mathex>a:b = c:d</mathex>, or
<mathex><fract>a/b</fract> = <fract>c/d</fract></mathex>.
</note>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The rule of three, in arithmetic, in which the
three given terms, together with the one sought, are
proportional</def>.

<cs><mcol><col>Continued proportion</col>, <col>Inverse
proportion</col>, etc.</mcol> <cd>See under <er>Continued</er>,
<er>Inverse</er>, etc.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Harmonical</col>, <or/
<col>Musical</col>, <col>proportion</col></mcol>, <cd>a relation
of three or four quantities, such that the first is to the last
as the difference between the first two is to the difference
between the last two; thus, 2, 3, 6, are in harmonical
proportion; for 2 is to 6 as 1 to 3. Thus, 24, 16, 12, 9, are
harmonical, for <mathex>24:9::8:3</mathex>.</cd> -- <col>In
proportion</col>, <cd>according as; to the degree that.
\'bd<xex>In proportion<xex> as they are metaphysically true, they
are morally and politically false.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>Pro*por"tion</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. &
p. p.</pos> <er>Proportioned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Proportioning</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>proportionner</ets>. Cf. <er>Proportionate</er>,
<pos>v.<pos>]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To adjust in a suitable proportion, as one thing
or one part to another; <as>as, to <ex>proportion</ex> the size
of a building to its height; to <ex>proportion</ex> our
expenditures to our income.</as></def>

<q>In the loss of an object we do not <qex>proportion</qex> our
grief to the real value . . . but to the value our fancies set
upon it.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To form with symmetry or suitableness, as the
parts of the body.</def>

<q>Nature had <qex>proportioned</qex> her without any fault.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To divide into equal or just shares; to
apportion.</def>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Capable of being proportioned, or made proportional; also,
proportional; proportionate.</def> --
<wordforms><wf>Pro*por"tion*a*ble*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<q>But eloquence may exist without a <qex>proportionable</qex>
degree of wisdom.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<q> <qex>Proportionable</qex>, which is no longer much favored,
was of our [i. e., English writers'] own coining.</q>
<qau>Fitzed. Hall.</qau>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*a*bly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>Proportionally.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proportionalis</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>proportionnel</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Having a due proportion, or comparative
relation; being in suitable proportion or degree; <as>as, the
parts of an edifice are <ex>proportional</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Relating to, or securing, proportion.</def>

<au>Hutton.</au>

<cs><col>3</col>. <fld>(Math.)</fld> <cd>Constituting a
proportion; having the same, or a constant, ratio; <as>as,
<ex>proportional<ex> quantities; momentum is <ex>proportional<ex>
to quantity of matter</as>.</cd></cs>

<cs><col>Proportional logarithms</col>, <cd>logistic logarithms.
See under <er>Logistic</er>.</cd> -- <col>Proportional
scale</col>, <cd>a scale on which are marked parts proportional
to the logarithms of the natural numbers; a logarithmic
scale.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Proportional scales</col>,
<col>compasses</col>, <col>dividers</col>, etc.</mcol>
<fld>(Draughting)</fld>, <cd>instruments used in making copies of
drawings, or drawings of objects, on an enlarged or reduced
scale.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*al</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>Any number or quantity in a
proportion; <as>as, a mean <ex>proportional</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>The combining weight or
equivalent of an element.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*por`tion*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>proportionnalit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
state of being in proportion.</def>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In
proportion; in due degree; adapted relatively; <as>as, all parts
of the building are <ex>proportionally</ex> large</as>.</def>

<au>Sir I. Newton.</au>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proportionatus</ets>. See <er>Proportion</er>.]</ety>
<def>Adjusted to something else according to a proportion;
proportional.</def>

<au>Longfellow.</au>

<q>What is <qex>proportionate</qex> to his transgression.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Proportionated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Proportionating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Proportion</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <def>To make
proportional; to adjust according to a settled rate, or to due
comparative relation; to proportion; <as>as, to
<ex>proportionate</ex> punishment to crimes</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*por"tion*ate*ly</hw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>In a proportionate manner; with due proportion;
proportionally.</def>

<au>Sir M. Hale.</au>

<def>Without proportion; unsymmetrical.</def>
