<hw>Pro*pos"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Propose</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is proposed,
or propounded for consideration or acceptance; a scheme or
design; terms or conditions proposed; offer; <as>as, to make
<ex>proposals</ex> for a treaty of peace; to offer
<ex>proposals</ex> for erecting a building; to make
<ex>proposals</ex> of marriage.</as></def> \'bdTo put forth
<xex>proposals</xex> for a book.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The offer by a party of what he
has in view as to an intended business transaction, which, with
acceptance, constitutes a contract.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Proffer; tender; overture. See
<er>Proposition</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*pose"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Proposed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Proposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>proposer</ets>;
pref. <ets>pro-</ets> (L. <ets>pro</ets> for, forward) +
<ets>poser</ets> to place. See <er>Pose</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To set forth.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>That being <qex>proposed</qex> brimfull of wine, one scarce
could lift it up.</q>
<qau>Chapman.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To offer for consideration, discussion,
acceptance, or adoption; <as>as, to <ex>propose</ex> terms of
peace; to <ex>propose</ex> a question for discussion; to
<ex>propose</ex> an alliance; to <ex>propose</ex> a person for
office.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To set before one's self or others as a purpose
formed; hence, to purpose; to intend.</def>

<q>I <qex>propose</qex> to relate, in several volumes, the
history of the people of New England.</q>

<au>Palfrey.</au>

<cs><col>To propose to one's self</col>, <cd>to intend; to
design.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*pose"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To speak;
to converse.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice,
<qex>Proposing</qex> with the prince and Claudio.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To form or declare a purpose or intention; to
lay a scheme; to design; <as>as, man <ex>proposes</ex>, but God
disposes</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To offer one's self in marriage.</def>

<hw>Pro*pose"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>propos</ets>, L.
<ets>propositum</ets>. See <er>Propound</er>, <er>Purpose</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <def>Talk; discourse.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pro*pos"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who proposes or offers anything for consideration or
adoption.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A speaker; an orator.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Prop`o*si"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>propositio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>proposition</ets>. See
<er>Propound</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of setting or
placing before; the act of offering.</def> \'bdOblations for the
altar of <xex>proposition</xex>.\'b8

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is proposed; that which is offered,
as for consideration, acceptance, or adoption; a proposal;
<as>as, the enemy made <ex>propositions</ex> of peace; his
<ex>proposition</ex> was not accepted.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A statement of religious doctrine; an article of
faith; creed; <as>as, the <ex>propositions</ex> of Wyclif and
Huss</as>.</def>

<q>Some persons . . . change their <qex>propositions</qex>
according as their temporal necessities or advantages do
turn.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Gram. & Logic)</fld> <def>A complete sentence,
or part of a sentence consisting of a subject and predicate
united by a copula; a thought expressed or propounded in
language; a from of speech in which a predicate is affirmed or
denied of a subject; <as>as, <ex>snow is white</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Math.)</fld> <def>A statement in terms of a
truth to be demonstrated, or of an operation to be
performed.</def>

<note><hand/ It is called a <xex>theorem</xex> when it is
something to be proved, and a <xex>problem</xex> when it is
something to be done.</note>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Rhet.)</fld> <def>That which is offered or
affirmed as the subject of the discourse; anything stated or
affirmed for discussion or illustration.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Poetry)</fld> <def>The part of a poem in which
the author states the subject or matter of it.</def>

<cs><col>Leaves of proposition</col> <fld>(Jewish Antiq.)</fld>,
<cd>the showbread.</cd></cs>

<au>Wyclif (Luke vi. 4).</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Proposal; offer; statement; declaration.</syn>
<usage> -- <er>Proposition</er>, <er>Proposal</er>. These words
are both from the Latin verb <xex>proponere</xex>, to set forth,
and as here compared they mark different forms or stages of a
negotiation. A <xex>proposition</xex> is something presented for
discussion or consideration; <as>as, <ex>propositions</ex> of
peace</as>. A <xex>proposal</xex> is some definite thing offered
by one party to be accepted or rejected by the other. If the
<xex>proposition</xex> is favorably received, it is usually
followed by <xex>proposals</xex> which complete the
arrangement.</usage>

<hw>Prop`o*si"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Pertaining to, or in the nature of, a proposition;
considered as a proposition; <as>as, a <ex>propositional</ex>
sense</as>.</def>

<au>I. Watts.</au>

<hw>Pro*pound"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Propounded</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Propounding</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[From
earlier <ets>propone</ets>, L. <ets>proponere</ets>,
<ets>propositum</ets>, to set forth, propose, propound;
<ets>pro</ets> for, before + <ets>ponere</ets> to put. See
<er>Position</er>, and cf. <er>Provost</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To offer for consideration; to exhibit; to propose; <as>as,
to <ex>propound</ex> a question; to <ex>propound</ex> an
argument.</as></def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<q>And darest thou to the Son of God <qex>propound</qex>
To worship thee, accursed?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>It is strange folly to set ourselves no mark, to
<qex>propound</qex> no end, in the hearing of the gospel.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>To propose or name as a
candidate for admission to communion with a church.</def>

<hw>Pro*pound"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
propounds, proposes, or offers for consideration.</def>

<au>Chillingworth.</au>

<hw>Pro*pre"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>propraetor</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> for, before +
<ets>praetor</ets> a pretor.]</ety> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld>
<def>A magistrate who, having been pretor at home, was appointed
to the government of a province.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>propr\'91tor</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pro*pri"e*ta*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Proprietaries</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.
<ets>proprietarius</ets>: cf. F. <ets>propri\'82taire</ets>. See
<er>Propriety</er>, and cf. <er>Proprietor</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A proprietor or owner; one who has exclusive
title to a thing; one who possesses, or holds the title to, a
thing in his own right.</def>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A body proprietors, taken collectively.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>A monk who had reserved goods
and effects to himself, notwithstanding his renunciation of all
at the time of profession.</def>

<hw>Pro*pri"e*ta*ry</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proprietarius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Belonging, or pertaining,
to a proprietor; considered as property; owned; <as>as,
<ex>proprietary</ex> medicine</as>.</def>

<cs><col>Proprietary articles</col>, <cd>manufactured articles
which some person or persons have exclusive right to make and
sell.</cd></cs>

<au>U. S. Statutes.</au>

<hw>Pro*pri"e*tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
older <ets>proprietary</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>propri\'82tarie</ets>.]</ety> <def>One who has the legal
right or exclusive title to anything, whether in possession or
not; an owner; <as>as, the proprietor of farm or of a
mill</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*pri`e*to"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to ownership; proprietary; <as>as,
<ex>proprietorial</ex> rights</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*pri"e*tor*ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
state of being proprietor; ownership.</def>

<hw>Pro*pri"e*tress</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
female proprietor.</def>

<hw>Pro*pri"e*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Proprieties</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>propri\'82t\'82</ets>, L. <ets>proprietas</ets>, fr.
<ets>proprius</ets> one's own, proper. See <er>Property</er>,
<er>Proper</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Individual right to hold
property; ownership by personal title; property.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdOnles this <xex>propriety</xex> be
exiled.\'b8

<au>Robynson (More's Utopia).</au>

<q>So are the <qex>proprieties</qex> of a wife to be disposed of
by her lord, and yet all are for her provisions, it being a part
of his need to refresh and supply hers.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is proper or peculiar; an inherent
property or quality; peculiarity.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<q>We find no mention hereof in ancient zo\'94graphers, . . . who
seldom forget <qex>proprieties</qex> of such a nature.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The quality or state of being proper;
suitableness to an acknowledged or correct standard or rule;
consonance with established principles, rules, or customs;
fitness; appropriateness; <as>as, <ex>propriety</ex> of behavior,
language, manners, etc.</as></def> \'bdThe rule of
<xex>propriety</xex>,\'b8

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Pro`ro*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prorogatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prorogation</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of counting in duration;
prolongation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>South.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of proroguing; the ending of the session
of Parliament, and postponing of its business, by the command of
the sovereign.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<note><hand/ After an adjournment all things continue as they
were at the adjournment; whereas, after a <xex>prorogation</xex>,
bill introduced and nut passed are as if they had never been
begun at all.</note>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<hw>Pro*rogue"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prorogued</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Proroguing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>proroger</ets>, L.
<ets>prorogare</ets>, <ets>prorogatum</ets>; <ets>pro</ets>
forward + <ets>rogare</ets> to ask, to ask one for his opinion or
vote, or about a law. See <er>Rogation</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To protract; to prolong; to extend.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>He <qex>prorogued</qex> his government.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To defer; to delay; to postpone; <as>as, to
<ex>prorogue</ex>death; to <ex>prorogue</ex> a
marriage.</as></def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To end the session of a parliament by an order
of the sovereign, thus deferring its business.</def>

<q>Parliament was <qex>prorogued</qex> to [meet at]
Westminster.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

<q>The Parliament was again <qex>prorogued</qex> to a distant
day.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To adjourn; postpone; defer. See
<er>Adjourn</er>.</syn>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pro*sa"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pro*sa"ic*al</hw>

<hw>Pro*scribe"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Proscribed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Proscribing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>proscribere</ets>, <ets>proscriptum</ets>, to write before,
to publish, proscribe; <ets>pro</ets> before +
<ets>scribere</ets> to write. See <er>Scribe</er>. The sense of
this word originated in the Roman practice of writing the names
of persons doomed to death, and posting the list in
public.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To doom to destruction; to put
out of the protection of law; to outlaw; to exile; <as>as, Sylla
and Marius <ex>proscribed</ex> each other's adherents</as>.</def>

<q>Robert Vere, Earl of Oxford, . . . was banished the realm, and
<qex>proscribed</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To denounce and condemn; to interdict; to
prohibit; <as>as, the Puritans <ex>proscribed</ex>
theaters</as>.</def>

<q>The Arian doctrines were <qex>proscribed</qex> and
anathematized in the famous Council of Nice.</q>
<qau>Waterland.</qau>

<hw>Pro*scrib"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who,
or that which, proscribes, denounces, or prohibits.</def>

<hw>Pro"script</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Proscribe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A proscription; a
prohibition; an interdict.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who is proscribed.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*scrip"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proscriptio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>proscription</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of proscribing; a dooming to death or
exile; outlawry; specifically, among the ancient Romans, the
public offer of a reward for the head of a political enemy;
<as>as, under the triumvirate, many of the best Roman citizens
fell by <ex>proscription</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Every victory by either party had been followed by a
sanguinary <qex>proscription</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being proscribed; denunciation;
interdiction; prohibition.</def>

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<hw>Pro*scrip"tion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Proscriptive.</def>

<hw>Pro*scrip"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
proscribes.</def>

<hw>Pro*scrip"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to proscription; consisting in, or of the nature of,
proscription; proscribing.</def> <au>Burke</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>Pro*scrip"tive*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Prose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prose</ets>, L. <ets>prosa</ets>, fr. <ets>prorsus</ets>,
<ets>prosus</ets>, straight forward, straight on, for
<ets>proversus</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> forward + <ets>versus</ets>,
p. p. of <ets>vertere</ets> to turn. See <er>Verse</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The ordinary language of men in speaking or
writing; language not cast in poetical measure or rhythm; --
contradistinguished from <xex>verse</xex>, or <xex>metrical
composition</xex>.</def>

<q>I speak in <qex>prose</qex>, and let him rymes make.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>Things unattempted yet in <qex>prose</qex> or rhyme.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>I wish our clever young poets would remember my homely
definitions of <qex>prose</qex> and poetry, that is;
<qex>prose</qex> -- words in their best order; poetry -- the best
order.</q>
<qau>Coleridge.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, language which evinces little imagination
or animation; dull and commonplace discourse.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A hymn with no regular
meter, sometimes introduced into the Mass. See
<er>Sequence</er>.</def>

<hw>Prose</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Pertaining to, or
composed of, prose; not in verse; <as>as, <ex>prose</ex>
composition</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Possessing or exhibiting unpoetical
characteristics; plain; dull; prosaic; <as>as, the <ex>prose</ex>
duties of life</as>.</def>

<hw>Prose</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Prosed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prosing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To write in
prose.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To write or repeat in a dull, tedious, or prosy
way.</def>

<hw>Prose</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To write
prose.</def>

<q><qex>Prosing</qex> or versing, but chiefly this latter.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pro*sec"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., an
anatomist, from <ets>prosecare</ets> to cut up; <ets>pro</ets>
before + <ets>secare</ets> to cut.]</ety> <def>One who makes
dissections for anatomical illustration; usually, the assistant
of a professional anatomist.</def>

<hw>Pros"e*cu`ta*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Capable of being prosecuted; liable to prosecution.</def>

<-- p. 1151 -->

<hw>Pros"e*cute</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prosecuted</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prosecuting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>prosecutus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>prosequi</ets> to follow,
pursue. See <er>Pursue</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To follow or pursue with a view to reach,
execute, or accomplish; to endeavor to obtain or complete; to
carry on; to continue; <as>as, to <ex>prosecute</ex> a scheme,
hope, or claim</as>.</def>

<q>I am beloved Hermia;
Why should not I, then, <qex>prosecute</qex> my right ?</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To seek to obtain by legal process; <as>as, to
<ex>prosecute</ex> a right or a claim in a court of
law</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To pursue with the intention of
punishing; to accuse of some crime or breach of law, or to pursue
for redress or punishment, before a legal tribunal; to proceed
against judicially; <as>as, to <ex>prosecute</ex> a man for
trespass, or for a riot</as>.</def>

<q>To acquit themselves and <qex>prosecute</qex> their foes.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pros"e*cute</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To follow
after.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Latimer.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To institute and carry on a
legal prosecution; <as>as, to <ex>prosecute</ex> for public
offenses</as>.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pros`e*cu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prosecutio</ets> a following.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
act or process of prosecuting, or of endeavoring to gain or
accomplish something; pursuit by efforts of body or mind; <as>as,
the <ex>prosecution</ex> of a scheme, plan, design, or
undertaking; the <ex>prosecution</ex> of war.</as></def>

<q>Keeping a sharp eye on her domestics . . . in
<qex>prosecution</qex> of their various duties.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The institution
and carrying on of a suit in a court of law or equity, to obtain
some right, or to redress and punish some wrong; the carrying on
of a judicial proceeding in behalf of a <xex>complaining</xex>
party, as distinguished from <xex>defense</xex>.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>The institution, or commencement, and
continuance of a criminal suit; the process of exhibiting formal
charges against an offender before a legal tribunal, and pursuing
them to final judgment on behalf of the state or government, as
by indictment or information.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The party
by whom criminal proceedings are instituted.</def>

<au>Blackstone. Burrill. Mozley & W.</au>

<hw>Pros"e*cu`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
L.<ets>prosecutor</ets> an attendant.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who prosecutes or carries on any purpose, plan, or
business.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The person who institutes and
carries on a criminal suit against another in the name of the
government.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pros"e*cu`trix</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <def>A female prosecutor.</def>

<hw>Pros"e*lyte</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>proselite</ets>, OF. <ets>proselite</ets>, F.
<ets>proselytus</ets>, Gr. <?/, adj., that has come, n., a new
comer, especially, one who has come over from heathenism to the
Jewish religion; <?/ toward, to + (prob.) the root of <?/ to
come.]</ety> <def>A new convert especially a convert to some
religion or religious sect, or to some particular opinion,
system, or party; thus, a Gentile converted to Judaism, or a
pagan converted to Christianity, is a <xex>proselyte</xex>.</def>

<q>Ye [Scribes and Pharisees] compass sea and land to make one
<qex>proselyte</qex>.</q>
<qau>Matt. xxiii. 15.</qau>

<q>Fresh confidence the speculatist takes
From every harebrained <qex>proselyte</qex> he makes.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Convert</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pros"e*lyte</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>Pros"e*ly*tism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pros\'82lytisme</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or

a religious sect, or to any opinion, system, or party.</def>

<q>They were possessed of a spirit of <qex>proselytism</qex> in
the most fanatical degree.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Conversion to a religion, system, or
party.</def>

<hw>Pros"pect</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prospectus</ets>, fr. <ets>prospicere</ets>,
<ets>prospectum</ets>, to look forward; <ets>pro</ets> before,
forward + <ets>specere</ets>, <ets>spicere</ets>, look, to see:
cf. OF. <ets>prospect</ets>. See <er>Spy</er>, <pos>v.<pos>, and
cf. <er>Prospectus</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which is
embraced by eye in vision; the region which the eye overlooks at
one time; view; scene; outlook.</def>

<q>His eye discovers unaware
The goodly <qex>prospect</qex> of some foreign land.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Especially, a picturesque or widely extended
view; a landscape; hence, a sketch of a landscape</def>.</q>

<q>I went to Putney . . . to take <qex>prospects</qex> in
crayon.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A position affording a fine view; a
lookout.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Him God beholding from his <qex>prospect</qex> high.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Relative position of the front of a building or
other structure; face; relative aspect.</def>

<q>And their <qex>prospect</qex> was toward the south.</q>
<qau>Ezek. xl. 44.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The act of looking forward; foresight;
anticipation; <as>as, a <ex>prospect</ex> of the future
state</as>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<q>Is he a prudent man as to his temporal estate, that lays
designs only for a day, without any <qex>prospect</qex> to, or
provision for, the remaining part of life ?</q>
<qau>Tillotson.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>That which is hoped for; ground for hope or
expectation; expectation; probable result; <as>as, the
<ex>prospect</ex> of success</as>.</def> \'bdTo brighter
<xex>prospects</xex> born.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>These swell their <qex>prospects</qex>d exalt their pride,
When offers are disdain'd, and love deny'd.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<er>Prospecting</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To look over; to explore
or examine for something; <as>as, to <ex>prospect</ex> a district
for gold</as>.</def>

<hw>Pros"pect</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make a search; to
seek; to explore, as for mines or the like; <as>as, to
<ex>prospect</ex> for gold</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*spec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
of looking forward, or of providing for future wants;
foresight.</def>

<hw>Pro*spec"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prospectivus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prospectif</ets>. See
<er>Prospect</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or
pertaining to a prospect; furnishing a prospect;
perspective.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Time's long and dark <qex>prospective</qex> glass.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Looking forward in time; acting with foresight;
-- opposed to <xex>retrospective</xex>.</def>

<q>The French king of Sweden are circumspect, industrious, and
<qex>prospective</qex>, too, in this affair.</q>
<qau>Sir J. Child.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Being within view or consideration, as a future
event or contingency; relating to the future: expected; <as>as, a
<ex>prospective</ex> benefit</as>.</def>

<q>Points on which the promises, at the time of ordination, had
no <qex>prospective</qex> bearing.</q>
<qau>W. Jay.</qau>

<hw>Pro*spec"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A perspective glass.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer. Beau. & Fl.</au>

<hw>Pros"per</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prospered</er>

<q>All things concur to<qex>prosper</qex> our design.</q>

<hw>Pros"per</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To be
successful; to succeed; to be fortunate or prosperous; to thrive;
to make gain.</def>

<q>They, in their earthly Canaan placed,
Long time shall dwell and <qex>prosper</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To grow; to increase.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Black cherry trees <qex>prosper</qex> even to considerable
timber.</q>
<qau>Evelyn.</qau>

<hw>Pros*per"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prosp\'82rit\'82</ets>, L. <ets>prosperitas</ets>. See
<er>Prosperous</er>.]</ety> <def>The state of being prosperous;
advance or gain in anything good or desirable; successful
progress in any business or enterprise; attainment of the object
desired; good fortune; success; <as>as, commercial
<ex>prosperity</ex>; national <ex>prosperity</ex>.</as></def>

<q>Now <qex>prosperity</qex> begins to mellow.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q><qex>Prosperities</qex> can only be enjoyed by them who fear
not at all to lose the<?/<?/.</q>
<qau> Jer. Taylor.</qau>

favorable; auspicious; lucky. See <er>Fortunate</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pros"ti*tute</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prostituted</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prostituting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>prostitutus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>prostituere</ets> to
prostitute; <ets>pro</ets> before, forth + <ets>statuere</ets> to
put, place. See <er>Statute</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
offer, as a woman, to a lewd use; to give up to lewdness for
hire.</def> \'bdDo not <xex>prostitute</xex> thy daughter.\'b8

<au>Lev. xix. 29.  </au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To devote to base or unworthy purposes; to give
up to low or indiscriminate use; <as>as, to <ex>prostitute</ex>
talents; to <ex>prostitute</ex> official powers.</as></def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pros"ti*tute</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prostitutus</ets>, p. p.]</ety> <def>Openly given up to
lewdness; devoted to base or infamous purposes.</def>

<q>Made bold by want, and <qex>prostitute</qex> for bread.</q>
<qau>Prior</qau>

<hw>Pros"ti*tute</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prostituta</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A woman giver to
indiscriminate lewdness; a strumpet; a harlot.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A base hireling; a mercenary; one who offers
himself to infamous employments for hire.</def>

<q>No hireling she, no <qex>prostitute</qex> to praise.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<hw>Pros`ti*tu"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prostitutio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prostitution</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or practice of prostituting or offering
the body to an indiscriminate intercourse with men; common
lewdness of a woman.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of setting one's self to sale, or of
devoting to infamous purposes what is in one's power; <as>as, the
<ex>prostitution</ex> of abilities; the <ex>prostitution</ex> of
the press.</as></def>  \'bdMental <xex>prostitution</xex>.\'b8

<au>Byron.</au>

<hw>Pros"ti*tu`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[L.]</ety> <def>One who prostitutes; one who submits
himself, of or offers another, to vile purposes.</def>

<au>Bp. Hurd.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pro*sto"mi*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Prostomia</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/

mouth.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pro*sto"mi*al</wf> <pr>(#)</pr>,
<pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pros"trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prostratus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>prosternere</ets> to
prostrate; <ets>pro</ets> before, forward + <ets>sternere</ets>
to spread out, throw down. See <er>Stratum</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Lying at length, or with the body extended on
the ground or other surface; stretched out; as, to sleep
<xex>prostrate</xex></def>

<au>Elyot.</au>

<q>Groveling and <qex>prostrate</qex> on yon lake of fire.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Lying at mercy, as a supplicant.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Lying in a humble, lowly, or suppliant
posture.</def>

<q>Prostrate fall
Before him reverent, and there confess
Humbly our faults.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Trailing on the ground;
procumbent.</def>

<hw>Pros"trate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prostrated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prostrating</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lay fiat;
to throw down; to level; to fell; <as>as, to <ex>prostrate</ex>
the body; to <ex>prostrate</ex> trees or plants.</as></def>

<au>Evelyn.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>to overthrow; to demolish; to destroy; to
deprive of efficiency; to ruin; <as>as, to <ex>prostrate</ex> a
village; to <ex>prostrate</ex> a government; to
<ex>prostrate</ex> law or justice.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To throw down, or cause to fall in humility or
adoration; to cause to bow in humble reverence; used reflexively;
<as>as, he <ex>prostrated</ex> himself</as>.</def>

<au>Milman.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To cause to sink totally; to deprive of
strength; to reduce; <as>as, a person <ex>prostrated</ex> by
fever</as>.</def>

<hw>Pros*tra"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prostratio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prostration</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of prostrating, throwing down, or laying
fiat; <as>as, the <ex>prostration</ex> of the body</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of falling down, or of bowing in
humility or adoration; primarily, the act of falling on the face,
but usually applied to kneeling or bowing in reverence and
worship.</def>

<q>A greater <qex>prostration</qex> of reason than of body.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The condition of being prostrate; great
depression; lowness; dejection; <as>as, a <ex>postration</ex> of
spirits</as>.</def> \'bdA sudden <xex>prostration</xex> of
strength.\'b8

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A latent, not an exhausted,
state of the vital energies; great oppression of natural strength
and vigor.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Prostration</xex>, in its medical use, is
analogous to the state of a spring lying under such a weight that
it is incapable of action; while <xex>exhaustion</xex> is
analogous to the state of a spring deprived of its elastic
powers. The word, however, is often used to denote any great
depression of the vital powers.</note>

<ets>prostylus</ets>, Gr. <?/; <?/ before + <?/ pillar, column:
cf. F. <ets>prostyle</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld> <def>Having
columns in front.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A prostyle
portico or building.</def></def2>

prosaic.</def>

placing or placed before, fr. <?/ to place in front; <?/ before +

<-- Protactinium.  A radioactive chemical element.  Atomic symbol

<hw>Pro"ta*gon</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + Gr. <?/ a contest. See.</pos>
<er>Protagonist</er>. So called because it was the first
definitely ascertained principle of the brain.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A nitrogenous phosphorized
principle found in brain tissue. By decomposition it yields
neurine, fatty acids, and other bodies.</def>

<hw>Pro*tag"o*nist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.

conflict, or the like.</def>

<q>Shakespeare, the <qex>protagonist</qex> on the great of modern
poetry.</q>
<qau>De Quincey.</qau>

<hw>Pro"ta*min</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
first.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>An amorphous
nitrogenous substance found in the spermatic fluid of salmon. It
is soluble in water, which an alkaline reaction, and unites with
acids and metallic bases.</def>

<hw>Pro*tect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Protected</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Protecting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>protectus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>protegere</ets>, literally,
to cover in front; <ets>pro</ets> before + <ets>tegere</ets> to
cover. See <er>Tegument</er>.]</ety> <def>To cover or shield from
danger or injury; to defend; to guard; to preserve in safety;
<as>as, a father <ex>protects</ex> his children</as>.</def>

<q>The gods of Greece <qex>protect</qex> you!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To guard; shield; preserve. See
<er>Defend</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*tect"ing*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By
way of protection; in a protective manner.</def>

<hw>Pro*tec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>protectio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>protection</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of protecting, or the state of being
protected; preservation from loss, injury, or annoyance; defense;
shelter; <as>as, the weak need <ex>protection</ex></as>.</def>

<q>To your <qex>protection</qex> I commend me, gods.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which protects or preserves from injury; a
defense; a shield; a refuge.</def>

<q>Let them rise up . . . and be your <qex>protection</qex>.</q>
<qau>Deut. xxxii. 38.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A writing that protects or secures from
molestation or arrest; a pass; a safe-conduct; a passport.</def>

<q>He . . . gave them <qex>protections</qex> under his hand.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Polit. Econ.)</fld> <def>A theory, or a policy,
of protecting the producers in a country from foreign competition
in the home market by the imposition of such discriminating
duties on goods of foreign production as will restrict or prevent
their importation; -- opposed to <xex>free trade</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>Writ of protection</col>. <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A writ by which the king formerly exempted a person from
arrest; -- now disused</cd>. <mark>[Eng.]</mark>
<au>Blackstone</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A judicial writ issued to a
person required to attend court, as party, juror, etc., intended
to secure him from arrest in coming, staying, and
returning.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Preservation; defense; guard; shelter; refuge;
security; safety.</syn>

<hw>Pro*tec"tion*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Polit. Econ.)</fld> <def>The doctrine or policy of
protectionists. See <er>Protection</er>, <er>4</er>.</def>

<hw>Pro*tec"tion*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Polit.
Econ.)</fld> <def>One who favors protection. See
<er>Protection</er>, <er>4</er>.</def>

<hw>Pro*tect"ive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>protectif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Affording protection;
sheltering; defensive.</def> \'bd The favor of a
<xex>protective</xex> Providence.\'b8

<au>Feltham.</au>

<cs><col>Protective coloring</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>coloring which serves for the concealment and preservation of
a living organism. Cf. <er>Mimicry</er>. <au>Wallace</au>.</cd>
-- <col>Protective tariff</col> <fld>(Polit. Econ.)</fld>, <cd>a
tariff designed to secure protection (see <er>Protection</er>,
<er>4</er>.), as distinguished from a tariff designed to raise
revenue. See <er>Tariff</er>, and <er>Protection</er>,
<er>4</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*tect"ive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being protective.</def>

<au>W. Pater.</au>

<hw>Pro*tect"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.: cf. F.
<ets>protecteur</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who, or that
which, defends or shields from injury, evil, oppression, etc.; a
defender; a guardian; a patron.</def>

<q>For the world's <qex>protector</qex> shall be known.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Hist.)</fld> <def>One having the care of
the kingdom during the king's minority; a regent.</def>

<q>Is it concluded he shall be <qex>protector</qex> !</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A cardinal, from one of
the more considerable Roman Catholic nations, who looks after the
interests of his people at Rome; also, a cardinal who has the
same relation to a college, religious order, etc.</def>

<cs><col>Lord Protector</col> <fld>(Eng. Hist.)</fld>, <cd>the
title of Oliver Cromwell as supreme governor of the British
Commonwealth (1653-1658).</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*tect"or*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to a protector; protectorial; <as>as,
<ex>protectoral</ex> power</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*tect"or*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>protectorat</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Government by a
protector; -- applied especially to the government of England by
Oliver Cromwell.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The authority assumed by a superior power over
an inferior or a dependent one, whereby the former protects the
latter from invasion and shares in the management of its
affairs.</def>

<hw>Pro"te*id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
first.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a class of
amorphous nitrogenous principles, containing, as a rule, a small
amount of sulphur; an albuminoid, as blood fibrin, casein of
milk, etc.  Proteids are present in nearly all animal fluids and
make up the greater part of animal tissues and organs. They are
also important constituents of vegetable tissues.  See 2d Note
under <er>Food</er>.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pro"te*id</wf>,
<pos>a.</pos></wordforms><-- older term for protein. -->

<hw>\'d8Pro`te*id"e*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Proteus</er>, and <er>-oid</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of aquatic amphibians having
prominent external gills and four legs. It includes Proteus and
Menobranchus (<spn>Necturus</spn>). Called also
<altname>Proteoidea</altname>, and
<altname>Proteida</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pro*te"i*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Changeable in form; resembling a
Proteus, or an am\'d2ba.</def>

<hw>Pro"te*in</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<grk>prw^tos</grk> first: cf. <grk>prwtei^on</grk> the first
place.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A body now known
as alkali albumin, but originally considered to be the basis of
all albuminous substances, whence its name.</def><-- This
definition is no longer used.  Proetin is now defined as any
polymer of an amino acid joined by peptide (amide) bonds.  Most
natural proteins have alpha-amino acids as the monomeric
constituents.  All classical enzymes are composed of protein, and
control most of the biochemical transformations carrie dout in
living cells.  They may be soluble, as casein, albumins, and
other globular proteins, or insoluble (e. g. "structural
proteins"), as collagen or keratin.  "albumin", an older term for
protein, is now used primarily to refer to certain specific
soluble globular proteins found in eggs or blood serum, e.g. 
Bovine serum albumin, used as an enzymatically inert protein in
biochemical research.  -->

<cs><col>Protein crystal</col>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Crystalloid</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 2.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*test"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Protested</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Protesting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.
<ets>protester</ets>, L. <ets>protestari</ets>, <ets>pro</ets>
before + <ets>testari</ets> to be a witness, <ets>testis</ets> a
witness. See <er>Testify</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To affirm
in a public or formal manner; to bear witness; to declare
solemnly; to avow.</def>

<q>He <qex>protest</qex> that his measures are pacific.</q>
<qau>Landor.</qau>

<q>The lady doth <qex>protest</qex> too much, methinks.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make a solemn declaration (often a written
one) expressive of opposition; -- with <xex>against</xex>;
<as>as, he <ex>protest</ex> against your votes</as>.</def>

<au>Denham.</au>

<q>The conscience has power . . . to <qex>protest</qex> againts
the exorbitancies of the passions.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To affirm; asseverate; assert; aver; attest;
testify; declare; profess. See <er>Affirm</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*test"</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make a
solemn declaration or affirmation of; to proclaim; to display;
<as>as, to <ex>protest</ex> one's loyalty</as>.</def>

<q>I will <qex>protest</qex> your cowardice.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To call as a witness in affirming or denying, or
to prove an affirmation; to appeal to.</def>

<q>Fiercely [they] opposed
My journey strange, with clamorous uproar
<qex>Protesting</qex> fate supreme.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<cs><col>To protest a bill <or/ note</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>,
<cd>to make a solemn written declaration, in due form, on behalf
of the holder, against all parties liable for any loss or damage
to be sustained by the nonacceptance or the nonpayment of the
bill or note, as the case may be. This should be made by a notary
public, whose seal it is the usual practice to affix.</cd></cs>

<au>Kent. Story.</au>

<hw>Pro"test</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>prot\'88t</ets>, It. <ets>protesto</ets>. See
<er>Protest</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A solemn
declaration of opinion, commonly a formal objection against some
act; especially, a formal and solemn declaration, in writing, of
dissent from the proceedings of a legislative body; <as>as, the
<ex>protest</ex> of lords in Parliament</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>A solemn
declaration in writing, in due form, made by a notary public,
usually under his notarial seal, on behalf of the holder of a
bill or note, protesting against all parties liable for any loss
or damage by the nonacceptance or nonpayment of the bill, or by
the nonpayment of the note, as the case may be.</def>
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>A declaration made by the master of a vessel
before a notary, consul, or other authorized officer, upon his
arrival in port after a disaster, stating the particulars of it,
and showing that any damage or loss sustained was not owing to
the fault of the vessel, her officers or crew, but to the perils
of the sea, etc., ads the case may be, and protesting against
them.</def> <sd>(c)</sd> <def>A declaration made by a party,
before or while paying a tax, duty, or the like, demanded of him,
which he deems illegal, denying the justice of the demand, and
asserting his rights and claims, in order to show that the
payment was not voluntary.</def> <au>Story</au>. <au>Kent</au>.

<hw>Prot"es*tan*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Protestantism.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Prot"es*tant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>protestant</ets>, fr. L. <ets>protestans</ets>,
<ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of <ets>protestare</ets>. See
<er>Protest</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <def>One who protests; --
originally applied to those who adhered to Luther, and protested
against, or made a solemn declaration of dissent from, a decree
of the Emperor Charles V. and the Diet of Spires, in 1529,
against the Reformers, and appealed to a general council; -- now
used in a popular sense to designate any Christian who does not
belong to the Roman Catholic or the Greek Church.</def>

<-- p. 1153 -->

<hw>Prot"es*tant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.

protesting.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the faith and practice of
those Christians who reject the authority of the Roman Catholic
Church; <as>as, <ex>Protestant</ex> writers</as>.</def>

<sn>1.</sn> A combining form prefix signifying <xex>first,

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Denoting the

<xex>proto</xex>chloride, etc.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Sometimes
used as equivalent to <xex>mono-</xex>, as indicating that the
compound has but <xex>one atom</xex> of the element to the name
of which it is prefixed. Also used adjectively.</def>

<hw>Pro"to*phyte</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + Gr. <?/ a plant.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Any unicellular plant, or plant forming

<note><hand/ The protophytes (<spn>Protophyta</spn>) are by some
botanists considered an independent branch or class of the
vegetable kingdom, and made to include the lowest forms of both
fungi and alg\'91, as slime molds, Bacteria, the nostocs, etc.
Cf. <er>Carpophyte</er>, and <er>O\'94phyte</er>.</note>

<hw>Pro"to*plasm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + Gr. <?/ form, fr. <?/ to mold.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>The viscid and more or less granular
material of vegetable and animal cells, possessed of vital
properties by which the processes of nutrition, secretion, and
growth go forward; the so-called \'bd physical basis of life;\'b8
the original cell substance, cytoplasm, cytoblastema, bioplasm
sarcode, etc.</def>

<note><hand/ The lowest forms of animal and vegetable life
(unicellular organisms) consist of <xex>simple</xex> or
<xex>unaltered protoplasm</xex>; the tissues of the higher
organisms, of <xex>differentiated protoplasm</xex>.</note>

<hw>Pro`to*plas*mat"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Protoplasmic.</def>

<hw>Pro`to*plas"mic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to the first formation of living
bodies.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to
protoplasm; consisting of, or resembling, protoplasm.</def>

<hw>Pro"to*plast</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>protoplastus</ets> the first man, Gr. <?/ formed or created
first; <?/ first + <?/ formed, fr. <?/ to form.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>The thing first formed; that of which there are
subsequent copies or reproductions; the original.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>A first-formed organized
body; the first individual, or pair of individuals, of a
species.</def>

<q>A species is a class of individuals, each of which is
hypothetically considered to be the descendant of the same
<qex>protoplast</qex>, or of the same pair of
<qex>protoplasts</qex>.</q>
<qau>Latham.</qau>

<-- 3. a plant or bacterial cell which has lost its cell wall. As
a consequence, protoplasts typically assume a spherical shape,
and are unable to resist rupture in a liquid of low osmolarity;
but they may live and in some cases divide, provided that the
osmotic pressure of the medium is sufficient to prevent expansion
to the point of rupture.  -->

of the best-known.</def>

proportion of silicic acid, or having but one atom of silicon in
the molecule.</def>

<hw>Pro`to*so"mite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + <ets>somite</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the primitive segments, or
metameres, of an animal.</def>

<hw>Pro`to*sul"phide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + <ets>sulphide</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>That one of a series of sulphides of any
element which has the lowest proportion of sulphur; a sulphide
with but one atom of sulphur in the molecule.</def>

<hw>Pro`to*sul"phu*ret</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + <ets>sulphuret</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A protosulphide.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<ety>[NL. See <er>Proto-</er>, and <er>Trachea</er>.]</ety>

<hw>Pro"to*type</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., from
L. <ets>prototypus</ets> original, primitive, Gr. <?/, <?/; <?/
first + <?/ type, model. See <er>Proto-</er>, and
<er>Type</er>]</ety> <def>An original or model after which
anything is copied; the pattern of anything to be engraved, or
otherwise copied, cast, or the like; a primary form; exemplar;
archetype.</def>

<q>They will turn their backs on it, like their great precursor
and <qex>prototype</qex>.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<hw>Pro`to*ver"te*bra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Protovertebr\'91</plw> </plu>. <ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> +
<ets>vertebra</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>One of the
primitive masses, or segments, into which the mesoblast of the
vertebrate embryo breaks up on either side of the anterior part
of the notochord; a mesoblastic, or protovertebral, somite. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>Ectoderm</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ The protovertebr\'91 were long regarded as rudiments
of the permanent vertebr\'91, but they are now known to give rise
to the dorsal muscles and other structures as well as the
vertebral column. See <er>Myotome</er>.</note>

<hw>Pro`to*ver"te*bral</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
protovertebr\'91.</def>

<hw>Pro*tox"ide</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proto-</ets> + <ets>oxide</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>protoxide</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>That one of
a series of oxides having the lowest proportion of oxygen. See
<er>Proto-</er>, 2 <sd>(b)</sd>.</def>

<cs><col>protoxide of nitrogen</col>, <cd>laughing gas, now
called <altname>hyponitrous oxide</altname><--, used as an
anaesthetic in dentistry; now (1950-1996) called nitrous oxide,
<chform>NO</chform> -->. See under <er>Laughing</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pro*tox"i*dize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>To combine with oxygen, as any elementary
substance, in such proportion as to form a protoxide.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro`to*zo"a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ first + <?/ an animal.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The lowest of the grand divisions of
the animal kingdom.</def>

<note><hand/ The entire animal consists of a single cell which is
variously modified; but in many species a number of these simple
zooids are united together so as to form a compound body or
organism, as in the Foraminifera and Vorticell\'91. The
reproduction takes place by fission, or by the breaking up of the
contents of the body after encystment, each portion becoming a
distinct animal, or in other ways, but never by true eggs. The
principal divisions are Rhizopoda, Gregarin\'91, and Infusoria.
See also <er>Foraminifera</er>, <er>Heliozoa</er>,
<er>Protoplasta</er>, <er>Radiolaria</er>, <er>Flagellata</er>,
<er>Ciliata</er>.</note>

<hw>Pro`to*zo"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
<er>Protozoa</er>.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>One of the
Protozoa.</def></def2>

<hw>Pro`to*zo"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Protozoa.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>Containing remains of the
earliest discovered life of the globe, which included mollusks,
radiates and protozoans.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro`to*zo"\'94n</hw> <pr>(-<ocr/n)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Protozoa</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.]</ety>

Protozoa.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A single zooid of a compound
protozoan.</def>

<hw>Pro*tract"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Protracted</er>; <pos>p.
pr. vb. n.</pos> <er>Protracting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>protractus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>protrahere</ets> to forth,
protract; <ets>pro</ets> forward + <ets>trahere</ets> to draw.
See <er>Portrait</er>, <er>Portray</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To draw out or lengthen in time or (rarely) in space; to
continue; to prolong; <as>as, to <ex>protract</ex> an argument;
to <ex>protract</ex> a war.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To put off to a distant time; to delay; to
defer; <as>as, to <ex>protract</ex> a decision or
duty</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Surv.)</fld> <def>To draw to a scale; to lay
down the lines and angles of, with scale and protractor; to
plot.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>To extend; to protrude;
<as>as, the cat can <ex>protract</ex> its claws</as>; -- opposed
to <contr>retract</contr>.</def>

<hw>Pro*tract"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>protractus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tedious continuance or
delay.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

continued for many successive days.</cd> <mark>[U.

<hw>Pro*tu"ber*ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>protub\'82rance</ets>. See <er>Protuberant</er>.]</ety>
<def>That which is protuberant swelled or pushed beyond the
surrounding or adjacent surface; a swelling or tumor on the body;
a prominence; a bunch or knob; an elevation.</def>

<cs><col>Solar protuberances</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>,
<cd>certain rose-colored masses on the limb of the sun which are
seen to extend beyond the edge of the moon at the time of a solar
eclipse. They may be discovered with the spectroscope on any
clear day. Called also <altname>solar prominences</altname>. See
<xex>Illust<xex>. in Append.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- <er>Projection</er>, <er>Protuberance</er>.
<xex>protuberance</xex> differs from <xex>projection</xex>, being
applied to parts that rise from the surface with a gradual ascent
or small angle; whereas a <xex>projection</xex> may be at a right
angle with the surface.</syn>

<hw>Pro*tu"ber*an*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being protuberant; protuberance;
prominence.</def>

<hw>Pro*tu"ber*ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>protuberans</ets>, <ets>-antis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>protuberare</ets>. See <er>Protuberate</er>.]</ety>
<def>Prominent, or excessively prominent; bulging beyond the
surrounding or adjacent surface; swelling; <as>as, a
<ex>protuberant</ex> joint; a <ex>protuberant</ex>
eye.</as></def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pro*tu"ber*ant*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pro*tu"ber*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>protuberare</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> forward + <ets>tuber</ets>
a hump, protuberance. See <er>Tuber</er>.]</ety> <def>To swell,
or be prominent, beyond the adjacent surface; to bulge out.</def>

<au>S. Sharp.</au>

<hw>Pro*tu`ber*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
act of swelling beyond the surrounding surface.</def>

<au>Cooke (1615).</au>

<hw>Pro*tu"ber*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Protuberant.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pro"tyle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Proud</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Prouder</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Proudest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>proud</ets>, <ets>prout</ets>, <ets>prud</ets>,
<ets>prut</ets>, AS. <ets>pr<umac/t</ets>; akin to Icel.
pr<umac/<edh/r stately, handsome, Dan. <ets>prud</ets> handsome.
Cf. <er>Pride</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Feeling or
manifesting pride, in a good or bad sense</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>Possessing or showing too great self-esteem; overrating
one's excellences; hence, arrogant; haughty; lordly;
presumptuous.</def>

<q>Nor much expect
A foe so <qex>proud</qex> will first the weaker seek.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>O death, made <qex>proud</qex> with pure and princely beauty
!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>And shades impervious to the <qex>proud</qex> world's
glare.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>Having a feeling of high self-respect or
self-esteem; exulting (in); elated; -- often with <xex>of</xex>;
<as>as, <ex>proud</ex> of one's country</as></def>.
\'bd<xex>Proud</xex> to be checked and soothed.\'b8

<au>Keble.</au>

<q>Are we proud men <qex>proud</qex> of being proud ?</q>
<qau>Thackeray.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Giving reason or occasion for pride or
self-gratulation; worthy of admiration; grand; splendid;
magnificent; admirable; ostentatious.</def>  \'bdOf shadow
<xex>proud</xex>.\'b8 <au>Chapman</au>. \'bd<xex>Proud</xex>
titles.\'b8 <au>Shak.</au> \'bd The <xex>proud</xex> temple's
height.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>Till tower, and dome, and bridge-way <qex>proud</qex>
Are mantled with a golden cloud.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Excited by sexual desire; -- applied
particularly to the females of some animals.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<note><hand/ <xex>Proud</xex> is often used with participles in
the formation of compounds which, for the most part, are
self-explaining; as, <xex>proud</xex>-crested,
<xex>proud</xex>-minded, <xex>proud</xex>-swelling.</note>

<cs><col>Proud flesh</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>a fungous
growth or excrescence of granulations resembling flesh, in a
wound or ulcer.</cd></cs>

<hw>Proud"ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Somewhat
proud.</def>

<au>Ash.</au>

<hw>Proud"ling</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A proud or haughty
person.</def>

<au>Sylvester.</au>

<hw>Proud"ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a proud manner; with
lofty airs or mien; haughtily; arrogantly; boastfully.</def>

<q><qex>Proudly</qex> he marches on, and void of fear.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Proud"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality of being
proud; pride.</def>

<q>Set aside all arrogancy and <qex>proudness</qex>.</q>
<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<hw>Proust"ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the
French chemist, J. L. <ets>Proust</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>A sulphide of arsenic and silver of a beautiful
cochineal-red color, occurring in rhombohedral crystals, and also
massive; ruby silver.</def>

<hw>Prove</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Proved</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Proving</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>prover</ets>, F. <ets>prouver</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>probare</ets> to try, approve, prove, fr. <ets>probus</ets>
good, proper. Cf. <er>Probable</er>, <er>Proof</er>,
<er>Probe</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To try or to ascertain by
an experiment, or by a test or standard; to test; <as>as, to
<ex>prove</ex> the strength of gunpowder or of ordnance; to
<ex>prove</ex> the contents of a vessel by a standard
measure.</as></def>

<q>Thou hast <qex>proved</qex> mine heart.</q>
<qau>Ps. xvii. 3.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To evince, establish, or ascertain, as truth,
reality, or fact, by argument, testimony, or other
evidence.</def>

<q>They have inferred much from slender premises, and conjectured
when they could not <qex>prove</qex>.</q>
<qau>J. H. Newman.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To ascertain or establish the genuineness or
validity of; to verify; <as>as, to <ex>prove</ex> a
will</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To gain experience of the good or evil of; to
know by trial; to experience; to suffer.</def>

<q>Where she, captived long, great woes did <qex>prove</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Arith.)</fld> <def>To test, evince, ascertain,
or verify, as the correctness of any operation or result; thus,
in subtraction, if the difference between two numbers, added to
the lesser number, makes a sum equal to the greater, the
correctness of the subtraction is <xex>proved</xex>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Printing)</fld> <def>To take a trial impression
of; to take a proof of; <as>as, to <ex>prove</ex> a
page</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To try; verify; justify; confirm; establish; evince;
manifest; show; demonstrate.</syn>

<hw>Prove</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make trial;
to essay.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To be found by experience, trial, or result; to
turn out to be; <as>as, a medicine <ex>proves</ex> salutary; the
report <ex>proves</ex> false.</as></def> \'bdThe case
<xex>proves</xex> mortal.\'b8 <au>Arbuthnot</au>.

<q>So life a winter's morn may <qex>prove</qex>.</q>
<qau>Keble.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To succeed; to turn out as expected.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe experiment <xex>proved</xex> not.\'b8

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pro*vect"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>provectus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>provehere</ets> to carry
forward.]</ety> <def>Carried forward; advanced.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bd<xex>Provect</xex> in years.\'b8

<au>Sir T. Flyot.</au>

<hw>Pro*vec"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>provectio</ets> an advancement.]</ety> <fld>(Philol.)</fld>
<def>A carrying forward, as of a final letter, to a following
word; <as>as, for example, a <ex>nickname</ex> for <ex>an
ekename</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*ved"i*tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.
<ets>proveditore</ets>, <ets>provveditore</ets>, fr.
<ets>provedere</ets>, L. <ets>providere</ets>. See
<er>Provide</er>, and cf. <er>Purveyor</er>,
<er>Provedore</er>.]</ety> <def>One employed to procure supplies,
as for an army, a steamer, etc.; a purveyor; one who provides for
another.</def>

<au>Jer. Taylor.</au>

<hw>Prov"e*dore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. Sp.
<ets>proveedor</ets>. See <er>Proveditor</er>.]</ety> <def>A
proveditor; a purveyor.</def>

<q>Busied with the duties of a <qex>provedore</qex>.</q>
<qau>W. Irving.</qau>

<hw>Prov"en</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>p. p. <or/ a.</pos>
<def>Proved.</def> \'bdAccusations firmly <xex>proven</xex> in
his mind.\'b8

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<q>Of this which was the principal charge, and was generally
believed to be<qex>proven</qex>, he was acquitted.</q>
<qau>Jowett (Thucyd. ).</qau>

<cs><col>Not proven</col> <fld>(Scots Law)</fld>, <cd>a verdict
of a jury that the guilt of the accused is not made out, though
not disproved.</cd></cs>

<au>Mozley & W.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pro`ven`<cced/al"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[F., fr. <ets>Provence</ets>, fr. L. <ets>provincia</ets>
province. See <er>Provincial</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining
to Provence or its inhabitants.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pro`ven`<cced/al"</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A native or inhabitant of Provence in
France.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The Provencal language. See <er>Langue
d'oc</er>.</def>

<hw>Prov"ence rose`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[<ets>Provence</ets>
the place + <ets>rose</ets>.]</ety> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The cabbage
rose (<spn>Rosa centifolia</spn>).</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>A name
of many kinds of roses which are hybrids of <spn>Rosa
centifolia</spn> and <spn>R. Gallica</spn>.</def>

<hw>Pro*ven"cial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Proven<cced/al</er>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to Provence
in France.</def>

<hw>Prov"end</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Provand</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prov"en*der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>provende</ets>, F. <ets>provende</ets>, provisions,
provender, fr. LL.  <ets>praebenda</ets> (<ets>prae</ets> and
<ets>pro</ets> being confused), a daily allowance of provisions,
a prebend. See <er>Prebend</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Dry food
for domestic animals, as hay, straw, corn, oats, or a mixture of
ground grain; feed.</def> \'bdHay or other
<xex>provender</xex>.\'b8

<au>Mortimer.</au>

<q>Good <qex>provender</qex> laboring horses would have.</q>
<qau>Tusser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Food or provisions.</def> <mark>[R or
Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prov"ent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Provand</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>
