<hw>\'d8Pro`ven*tri"u*lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Pro-</er>, and <er>Ventricle</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The glandular stomach of birds, situated
just above the crop.</def>

<hw>Prov"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, proves.</def>

<hw>Prov"erb</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>proverbe</ets>, F. <ets>proverbe</ets>, from L.
<ets>proverbium</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before, for +
<ets>verbum</ets> a word. See <er>Verb</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>An old and common saying; a phrase which is often repeated;
especially, a sentence which briefly and forcibly expresses some
practical truth, or the result of experience and observation; a
maxim; a saw; an adage.</def>

<au>Chaucer. Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A striking or paradoxical assertion; an obscure
saying; an enigma; a parable.</def>

<q>His disciples said unto him, Lo, now speakest thou plainly,
and speakest no <qex>proverb</qex>.</q>
<qau>John xvi. 29.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A familiar illustration; a subject of
contemptuous reference.</def>

<q>Thou shalt become an astonishment, a <qex>proverb</qex>, and a
by word, among all nations.</q>
<qau>Deut. xxviii. 37.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A drama exemplifying a proverb.</def>

<cs><col>Book of Proverbs</col>, <cd>a canonical book of the Old
Testament, containing a great variety of wise maxims.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Maxim; aphorism; apothegm; adage; saw.</syn>

<hw>Prov"erb</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To name in,
or as, a proverb.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>Am I not sung and <qex>proverbed</qex> for a fool ?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To provide with a proverb.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<q>I am <qex>proverbed</qex> with a grandsire phrase.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Prov"erb</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To write or utter
proverbs.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*ver"bi*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proverbialis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>proverbial</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Mentioned or comprised in a proverb; used as a
proverb; hence, commonly known; <as>as, a <ex>proverbial</ex>
expression; his meanness was <ex>proverbial</ex>.</as></def>

<q>In case of excesses, I take the German <qex>proverbial</qex>
cure, by a hair of the same beast, to be the worst.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Temple.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to proverbs; resembling a
proverb.</def> \'bdA <xex>proverbial</xex> obscurity.\'b8

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Pro*ver"bi*al*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A
proverbial phrase.</def>

<hw>Pro*ver"bi*al*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who makes much
use of proverbs in speech or writing; one who composes, collects,
or studies proverbs.</def>

<hw>Pro*ver"bi*al*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>
<ety>[Cf. F. <ets>proverbialiser</ets>.]</ety> <def>To turn into
a proverb; to speak in proverbs.</def>

<hw>Pro*ver"bi*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a proverbial
manner; by way of proverb; hence, commonly; universally; <as>as,
it is <ex>proverbially</ex> said; the bee is
<ex>proverbially</ex> busy.</as></def>

<hw>Pro*vex"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>provehere</ets> to advance. Cf. <er>Provect</er>.]</ety>
<def>Great advance in age.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pro*vide"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Provided</er>; <pos>p.
pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Providing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L.
<ets>providere</ets>, <ets>provisum</ets>; <ets>pro</ets> before
+ <ets>videre</ets> to see. See <er>Vision</er>, and cf.
<er>Prudent</er>, <er>Purvey</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
look out for in advance; to procure beforehand; to get, collect,
or make ready for future use; to prepare.</def>
\'bd<xex>Provide</xex> us all things necessary.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To supply; to afford; to contribute.</def>

<q>Bring me berries, or such cooling fruit
As the kind, hospitable woods <qex>provide</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To furnish; to supply; -- formerly followed by
<xex>of</xex>, now by <xex>with</xex>.</def> \'bdAnd yet
<xex>provided</xex> him of but one.\'b8 <au>Jer. Taylor</au>.
\'bdRome . . . was well <xex>provided</xex> with corn.\'b8
<au>Arbuthnot</au>.

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To establish as a previous condition; to
stipulate; <as>as, the contract <ex>provides</ex> that the work
be well done</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To foresee.</def> <note>[A
<xex>Latinism</xex>]</note> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To appoint to an ecclesiastical benefice before
it is vacant. See <er>Provisor</er>.</def>

<au>Prescott.</au>

<hw>Pro*vide"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To procure
supplies or means in advance; to take measures beforehand in view
of an expected or a possible future need, especially a danger or
an evil; -- followed by <xex>against or for</xex>; <as>as, to
<ex>provide</ex> against the inclemency of the weather; to
<ex>provide</ex> for the education of a child.</as></def>

<q>Government is a contrivance of human wisdom to
<qex>provide</qex> for human wants.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To stipulate previously; to condition; <as>as,
the agreement <ex>provides</ex> for an early completion of the
work</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*vid"ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>conj.</pos> <def>On
condition; by stipulation; with the understanding; if; -- usually
followed by <xex>that</xex>; <as>as, <ex>provided</ex> that
nothing in this act shall prejudice the rights of any person
whatever</as>.</def>

<q><qex>Provided</qex> the deductions are logical, they seem
almost indifferent to their truth.</q>
<qau>G. H. Lewes.</qau>

<note><hand/ This word is strictly a participle, and the word
<xex>being</xex> is understood, the participle
<xex>provided</xex> agreeing with the whole sentence absolute,
and being equivalent to <xex>this condition being previously
stipulated or established</xex>.</note>

<hw>Prov"i*dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>providentia</ets>: cf. F. <ets>providence</ets>. See
<er>Provident</er>, and cf. <er>Prudence</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of providing or preparing for future use or
application; a making ready; preparation.</def>

<q><qex>Providence</qex> for war is the best prevention of
it.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Foresight; care; especially, the foresight and
care which God manifests for his creatures; hence, God himself,
regarded as exercising a constant wise prescience.</def>

<q>The world was all before them, where to choose
Their place of rest, and <qex>Providence</qex> their guide.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Theol.)</fld> <def>A manifestation of the care
and superintendence which God exercises over his creatures; an
event ordained by divine direction.</def>

<q>He that hath a numerous family, and many to provide for, needs
a greater <qex>providence</qex> of God.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<-- p. 1155 -->

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Prudence in the management of one's concerns;
economy; frugality.</def>

<q>It is a high point of <qex>providence</qex> in a prince to
cast an eye rather upon actions than persons.</q>
<qau>Quarles.</qau>

<hw>Prov"i*dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>providens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, <ets>p</ets>.
<ets>pr</ets>. of <ets>providere</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>provident</ets>. See <er>Provide</er>, and cf.
<er>Prudent</er>.]</ety> <def>Foreseeing wants and making
provision to supply them; prudent in preparing for future
exigencies; cautious; economical; -- sometimes followed by
<xex>of</xex>; <as>as, a<ex>provident</ex> man; an animal
<ex>provident</ex> of the future.</as></def>

<q>And of our good and of our dignity,
How <qex>provident</qex> he is.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Forecasting; cautious; careful; prudent; frugal;
economical.</syn>

<hw>Prov`i*den"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>providentiel</ets>.]</ety> <def>Effected by, or referable
to, divine direction or superintendence; <as>as, the
<ex>providential</ex> contrivance of thing; a
<ex>providential</ex> escape.</as></def> --
<wordforms><wf>Prov"i*den"tial*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Prov"i*dent*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
provident manner.</def>

<hw>Prov"i*dent*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality or
state of being provident; carefulness; prudence; economy.</def>

<hw>Pro*vid"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
provides, furnishes, or supplies; one who procures what is
wanted.</def>

<hw>Prov"i*dore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Provedore</er>.]</ety> <def>One who makes provision; a
purveyor.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>De Foe.</au>

<hw>Prov"ince</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>provincia</ets>; prob. fr. <ets>pro</ets> before, for + the
root of <ets>vincere</ets> to conquer. See
<er>Victor</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Roman Hist.)</fld>
<def>A country or region, more or less remote from the city of
Rome, brought under the Roman government; a conquered country
beyond the limits of Italy.</def>

<au>Wyclif (Acts xiii. 34). Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A country or region dependent on a distant
authority; a portion of an empire or state, esp. one remote from
the capital.</def> \'bdKingdoms and <xex>provinces</xex>.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A region of country; a tract; a district.</def>

<q>Over many a tract
of heaven they marched, and many a <qex>province</qex> wide.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Other <qex>provinces</qex> of the intellectual world.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A region under the supervision or direction of
any special person; the district or division of a country,
especially an ecclesiastical division, over which one has
jurisdiction; <as>as, the <ex>province</ex> of Canterbury, or
that in which the archbishop of Canterbury exercises
ecclesiastical authority</as>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The proper or appropriate business or duty of a
person or body; office; charge; jurisdiction; sphere.</def>

<q>The woman's<qex>province</qex> is to be careful in her
economy, and chaste in her affection.</q>
<qau>Tattler.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Specif.: Any political division of the Dominion
of Canada, having a governor, a local legislature, and
representation in the Dominion parliament. Hence, colloquially,
<xex>The Provinces</xex>, the Dominion of Canada.</def>

<hw>Pro*vin"cial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>provincialis</ets>: cf. F. <ets>provincial</ets>. See
<er>Province</er>, and cf. <er>Provencal</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Of or pertaining to province; constituting a province;
<as>as, a <ex>provincial</ex> government; a <ex>provincial</ex>
dialect.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Exhibiting the ways or manners of a province;
characteristic of the inhabitants of a province; not
cosmopolitan; countrified; not polished; rude; hence, narrow;
illiberal.</def> \'bd<xex>Provincial</xex> airs and graces.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to an ecclesiastical province,
or to the jurisdiction of an archbishop; not ecumenical; <as>as,
a <ex>provincial</ex> synod</as>.</def>

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to Provence; Provencal.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>With two <qex>Provincial</qex> roses on my razed shoes.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pro*vin"cial</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A person
belonging to a province; one who is provincial.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A monastic superior, who,
under the general of his order, has the direction of all the
religious houses of the same fraternity in a given district,
called a <xex>province</xex> of the order.</def>

<hw>Pro*vin"cial*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>provincialisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>A word, or a manner of
speaking, peculiar to a province or a district remote from the
mother country or from the metropolis; a provincial
characteristic; hence, narrowness; illiberality.</def>

<au>M. Arnold.</au>

<hw>Pro*vin"cial*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who lives in a
province; a provincial.</def>

<hw>Pro*vin`ci*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
quality or state of being provincial; peculiarity of language
characteristic of a province.</def>

<au>T. Warton.</au>

<hw>Pro*vin"cial*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Provincialized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Provincializing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To render provincial.</def>

<au>M. Arnold.</au>

<hw>Pro*vin"cial*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a provincial
manner.</def>

<hw>Pro*vin"ci*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To
convert into a province or provinces.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Howell.</au>

<hw>Pro*vine"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>provingner</ets>, fr. <ets>provin</ets> a set, layer of a
plant, OF. <ets>provain</ets>, from L. <ets>propago</ets>,
<ets>-aginis</ets>, akin to <ets>propagare</ets> to propagate.
See <er>Propagate</er>, <er>Prune</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety>
<def>To lay a stock or branch of a vine in the ground for
propagation.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<hw>Pro*vi"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>provisio</ets>:  cf. F.  <ets>provision</ets>. See
<er>Provide</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of providing,
or making previous preparation.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is provided or prepared; that which
is brought together or arranged in advance; measures taken
beforehand; preparation.</def>

<q>Making <qex>provision</qex> for the relief of strangers.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Especially, a stock of food; any kind of
eatables collected or stored; -- often in the plural.</def>

<q>And of <qex>provisions</qex> laid in large,
For man and beast.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which is stipulated in advance; a
condition; a previous agreement; a proviso; <as>as, the
<ex>provisions</ex> of a contract; the statute has many
<ex>provisions</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <def>A canonical term for
regular induction into a benefice, comprehending nomination,
collation, and installation.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Hist.)</fld> <def>A nomination by the pope
to a benefice before it became vacant, depriving the patron of
his right of presentation.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<hw>Pro*vi"sion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Provisioned</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Provisioning</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To supply with food; to
victual; <as>as, to <ex>provision</ex> a garrison</as>.</def>

<q>They were <qex>provisioned</qex> for a journey.</q>
<qau>Palfrey.</qau>

<hw>Pro*vi"sion*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>provisionnel</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of the nature of a
provision; serving as a provision for the time being; -- used of
partial or temporary arrangements; <as>as, a <ex>provisional</ex>
government; a <ex>provisional</ex> treaty.</as></def>

<hw>Pro*vi"sion*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>By way of
provision for the time being; temporarily.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Pro*vi"sion*a*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Provisional.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>Pro*vi"so</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Provisos</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L., (it) being
provided, abl. of <ets>provisus</ets>, p. p. of
<ets>providere</ets>. See <er>Provide</er>, and cf.
<er>Purview</er>.]</ety> <def>An article or clause in any
statute, agreement, contract, grant, or other writing, by which a
condition is introduced, usually beginning with the word
<xex>provided</xex>; a conditional stipulation that affects an
agreement, contract, law, grant, or the like; <as>as, the
contract was impaired by its <ex>proviso</ex></as>.</def>

<q>He doth deny his prisoners,
But with <qex>proviso</qex> and exception.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pro*vi"sor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr.
<ets>providere</ets>: cf. F. <ets>proviseur</ets>. See
<er>Provide</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who provides; a
purveyor.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThe chief
<xex>provisor</xex> of our horse.\'b8

<au>Ford.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(R. C. Ch.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The
purveyor, steward, or treasurer of a religious house.</def>
<au>Cowell</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>One who is regularly inducted
into a benefice. See <er>Provision</er>, 5.</def>  <au>P.
Plowman</au>.

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Hist.)</fld> <def>One who procures or
receives a papal provision. See <er>Provision</er>, 6.</def>

<hw>Pro*vi"so*ri*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
provisory manner; conditionally; subject to a proviso; <as>as, to
admit a doctrine <ex>provisorily</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Sir W. Hamilton.</au>

<hw>Pro*vi"sor*ship</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
office or position of a provisor.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>J. Webster.</au>

<hw>Pro*vi"so*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>provisoire</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of the nature of a
proviso; containing a proviso or condition; conditional; <as>as,
a <ex>provisory</ex> clause</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Making temporary provision; provisional.</def>

<hw>Prov`o*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>provocation</ets>, L. <ets>provocatio</ets>. See
<er>Provoke</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of provoking,
or causing vexation or, anger.</def>

<au>Fabyan.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which provokes, or excites anger; the cause
of resentment; <as>as, to give <ex>provocation</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Paley.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Incitement; stimulus; <as>as,
<ex>provocation</ex> to mirth</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Such prior insult or injury as
may be supposed, under the circumstances, to create hot blood,
and to excuse an assault made in retort or redress.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>An appeal to a court. <note>[A
Latinism]</note></def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Ayliffe.</au>

<hw>Pro*vo"ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>provocativus</ets>: cf. OF. <ets>provocatif</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Serving or tending to provoke, excite, or stimulate;
exciting.</def>

<hw>Pro*vo"ca*tive</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Anything that is
provocative; a stimulant; <as>as, a <ex>provocative</ex> of
appetite</as>.</def>

<hw>Pro*vo"ca*tive*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Quality of being
provocative.</def>

<hw>Pro*vo"ca*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Provocative.</def>

<hw>Pro*vok"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That may
be provoked.</def>

<hw>Pro*voke"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Provoked</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Provoking</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>provoquer</ets>,
L. <ets>provocare</ets> to call forth; <ets>pro</ets> forth +
<ets>vocare</ets> to call, fr. <ets>vox</ets>, <ets>vocis</ets>,
voice, cry, call. See <er>Voice</er>.]</ety> <def>To call forth;
to call into being or action; esp., to incense to action, a
faculty or passion, as love, hate, or ambition; hence, commonly,
to incite, as a person, to action by a challenge, by taunts, or
by defiance; to exasperate; to irritate; to offend intolerably;
to cause to retaliate.</def>

<q>Obey his voice, <qex>provoke</qex> him not.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxiii. 21.</qau>

<q>Ye fathers, <qex>provoke</qex> not your children to wrath.</q>
<qau>Eph. vi. 4.</qau>

<q>Such acts
Of contumacy will <qex>provoke</qex> the Highest
To make death in us live.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Can honor's voice <qex>provoke</qex> the silent dust?</q>
<qau>Gray.</qau>

<q>To the poet the meaning is what he pleases to make it, what it
<qex>provokes</qex> in his own soul.</q>
<qau> J. Burroughs.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To irritate; arouse; stir up; awake; excite; incite;
anger. See <er>Irritate</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pro*voke"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To cause
provocation or anger.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To appeal. <note>[A Latinism]</note></def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<hw>Pro*voke"ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act
that which, provokes; one who excites anger or other passion, or
incites to action; <as>as, a <ex>provoker</ex> of
sedition</as>.</def>

<q>Drink, sir, is a great <qex>provoker</qex> of three
things.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pro*vok"ing</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having the power or
quality of exciting resentment; tending to awaken passion or
vexation; <as>as, <ex>provoking</ex> words or
treatment</as>.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pro*vok"ing*ly</wf>,
<pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Prov"ost</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>provost</ets> (L. <ets>prae</ets> and <ets>pro</ets> being
confused), F. <ets>prev\'93t</ets>, fr. L. <ets>praepositus</ets>
placed before, a chief, fr. <ets>praeponere</ets> to place
before: cf. AS. <ets>pr\'befost</ets>, <ets>pr<omac/fast</ets>.
See <er>Preposition</er>, and cf. <er>Propound</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A person who is appointed to superintend, or
preside over, something; the chief magistrate in some cities and
towns; <as>as, the <ex>provost</ex> of Edinburgh or of Glasgow,
answering to the mayor of other cities; the <ex>provost</ex> of a
college, answering to president; the <ex>provost</ex> or head of
certain collegiate churches.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The keeper of a prison.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Shak.</au>

<note><hand/ In France, formerly, a <xex>provost</xex> was an
inferior judge who had cognizance of civil causes. The <xex>grand
provost of France</xex>, <xex>or of the household</xex>, had
jurisdiction in the king's house, and over its officers.</note>

<cs><col>Provost marshal</col><cd> <pr>(often pronounced
<?/)</pr>. <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Mil.)</fld> <cd>An officer
appointed in every army, in the field, to secure the prisoners
confined on charges of a general nature. He also performs such
other duties pertaining to police and discipline as the
regulations of the service or the commander's orders impose upon
him.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <fld>(Nav.)</fld> <cd>An officer who has
charge of prisoners on trial by court-martial, serves notices to
witnesses, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prov"ost*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The office of a
provost.</def>

<hw>Prow</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>proue</ets> (cf. Sp. & Pg. <ets>proa</ets>, It.
<ets>prua</ets>), L. <ets>prora</ets>, Gr. <?/, akin to <?/
before. See <er>Pro-</er>, and cf. <er>Prore</er>.]</ety>
<def>The fore part of a vessel; the bow; the stem; hence, the
vessel itself.</def>

<au>Wordsworth.</au>

<q>The floating vessel swum
Uplifted, and secure with beaked <qex>prow</qex>
rode tilting o'er the waves.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Prow</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>See
<er>Proa</er>.</def>

<hw>Prow</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos>
<er>Prower</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>superl.</pos>
<er>Prowest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.<ets>prou</ets>,
<ets>preu</ets>, F. <ets>preux</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pro</ets>,
<ets>prod</ets>, in <ets>prodesse</ets> to be useful. See
<er>Pro-</er>, and cf. <er>Prude</er>.]</ety> <def>Valiant;
brave; gallant; courageous.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<au>Tennyson.</au>

<q>The <qex>prowest</qex> knight that ever field did fight.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Prow</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. & OF. <ets>prou</ets>. See
<er>Prow</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>Benefit; profit; good;
advantage.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>That shall be for your hele and for your <qex>prow</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<hw>Prow"ess</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>proece</ets>, <ets>proesce</ets>, F. <ets>prouesse</ets>.
See <er>Prow</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <def>Distinguished
bravery; valor; especially, military bravery and skill;

<au>Chaucer. Sir P. Sidney.</au>

<q>He by his <qex>prowess</qex> conquered all France.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Prowl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Prowled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Prowling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>prollen</ets> to
search about; of uncertain origin, perh. for <ets>proglen</ets>,
a dim. of <ets>prog</ets> to beg, or <ets>proke</ets> to poke.
Cf. <er>Proke</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To rove over,
through, or about in a stealthy manner; esp., to search in, as
for prey or booty.</def>

<q>He <qex>prowls</qex> each place, still in new colors
decked.</q>
<qau> Sir P. Sidney.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To collect by plunder; <as>as, to <ex>prowl</ex>
money</as>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prowl</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To rove or wander
stealthily, esp. for prey, as a wild beast; hence, to prey; to
plunder.</def>

<hw>Prox"i*mad</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Proximal</ets> + L. <ets>ad</ets> to.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Toward a proximal part; on the proximal
side of; proximally.</def>

<hw>Prox"i*mal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Toward or nearest, as to a body, or center of motion of
dependence; proximate.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Biol.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Situated near
the point of attachment or origin; <as>as, the <ex>proximal</ex>
part of a limb</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of or pertaining to
that which is proximal; <as>as, the <ex>proximal</ex> bones of a
limb</as>. Opposed to <xex>distal</xex>.</def>

<hw>Prox"i*mal*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>On or toward a proximal part; proximad.</def>

<hw>Prox"i*mate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proximatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>proximare</ets> to come
near, to approach, fr. <ets>proximus</ets> the nearest, nest,
superl. of <ets>propior</ets> nearer, and <ets>prope</ets>, adv.,
near.]</ety> <def>Nearest; next immediately preceding or
following.</def> \'bd<xex>Proximate</xex> ancestors.\'b8

<au>J. S. Harford.</au>

<q>The <qex>proximate</qex> natural causes of it [the
deluge].</q>
<qau>T. Burnet.</qau>

<cs><col>Proximate analysis</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>an
analysis which determines the proximate principles of any
substance, as contrasted with an <xex>ultimate
analysis<xex>.</cd> -- <col>Proximate cause</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>A cause which immediately precedes and produces the effect,
as distinguished from the <xex>remote<xex>, <xex>mediate<xex>,
<xex>or predisposing<xex> cause.</cd> <au>I. Watts</au>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>That which in ordinary natural sequence produces
a specific result, no independent disturbing agencies
intervening.</cd> -- <col>Proximate principle</col>
<fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld>, <cd>one of a class of bodies
existing ready formed in animal and vegetable tissues, and
separable by chemical analysis, as albumin, sugar, collagen, fat,
etc.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Nearest; next; closest; immediate; direct.</syn>

<hw>Prox"i*mate*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a proximate
manner, position, or degree; immediately.</def>

<hw>Prox"ime</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proximus</ets>. See <er>Proximate</er>.]</ety> <def>Next;
immediately preceding or following.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prox*im"i*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Proximate.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prox*im"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>proximitas</ets>: cf. F. <ets>proximit\'82</ets> See
<er>Proximate</er>, and cf. <er>Propinquity</er>,
<er>Approach</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of being next
in time, place, causation, influence, etc.; immediate nearness,
either in place, blood, or alliance.</def>

<q>If he plead <qex>proximity</qex> of blood
That empty title is with ease withstood.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Prox"i*mo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[L., on the next, abl. of
<ets>proximus</ets> next.]</ety> <def>In the next month after the
present; -- often contracted to <xex>prox.</xex>; <as>as, on the
3d <ex>proximo</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Prox"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Proxies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Contr. from
<ets>procuracy</ets>. Cf. <er>Proctor</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The agency for another who acts through the agent; authority
to act for another, esp. to vote in a legislative or corporate
capacity.</def>

<q>I have no man's <qex>proxy</qex>: I speak only for myself.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The person who is substituted or deputed to act
or vote for another.</def>

<q>Every peer . . . may make another lord of parliament his
<qex>proxy</qex>, to vote for him in his absence.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A writing by which one person authorizes another
to vote in his stead, as in a corporation meeting.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld> <def>The written appointment of
a proctor in suits in the ecclesiastical courts.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Eccl.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Procuration</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Prox"y</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To act or vote by proxy;
to do anything by the agency of another.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Prox"y*ship</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The office or agency of
a proxy.</def>

<hw>Prude</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., prudish,
originally, discreet, modest; shortened from OF.
<ets>prudefeme</ets>, <ets>preudefeme</ets>, a discreet or
excellent woman; OF. <ets>preu</ets>, <ets>prou</ets>, excellent,
brave + <ets>de</ets> of + <ets>fete</ets> woman. See
<er>Prow</er>, <pos>a.<pos>, <er>Prowess</er>.]</ety> <def>A
woman of affected modesty, reserve, or coyness; one who is
overscrupulous or sensitive; one who affects extraordinary
prudence in conduct and speech.</def>

<q>Less modest than the speech of <qex>prudes</qex>.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<hw>Pru"dence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., fr. L.
<ets>prudentia</ets>, contr. from <ets>providentia</ets>. See
<er>Prudent</er>, and cf. <er>Providence</er>.]</ety> <def>The
quality or state of being prudent; wisdom in the way of caution
and provision; discretion; carefulness; hence, also, economy;
frugality.</def>

<q><qex>Prudence</qex> is principally in reference to actions to
be done, and due means, order, seasons, and method of doing or
not doing.</q>
<qau>Sir M. Hale.</qau>

<q><qex>Prudence</qex> supposes the value of the end to be
assumed, and refers only to the adaptation of the means. It is
the relation of right means for given ends.</q>
<qau>Whewell.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Wisdom; forecast; providence; considerateness;
judiciousness; discretion; caution; circumspection; judgment. See
<er>Wisdom</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pru"den*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Prudence.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Hakluyt.</au>

<hw>Pru"dent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prudens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, contr. from
<ets>providens</ets>: cf. F. <ets>prudent</ets>. See
<er>Provident</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Sagacious in adapting
means to ends; circumspect in action, or in determining any line
of conduct; practically wise; judicious; careful; discreet;
sensible; -- opposed to <xex>rash</xex>; <as>as, a
<ex>prudent</ex> man</as>; dictated or directed by prudence or
wise forethought; evincing prudence; <as>as, <ex>prudent</ex>
behavior</as>.</def>

<q>Moses established a grave and <qex>prudent</qex> law.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Frugal; economical; not extravagant; <as>as, a
<ex>prudent</ex> woman; <ex>prudent</ex> expenditure of
money</as></def>.

<syn>Syn. -- Cautious; wary; circumspect; considerate; discreet;
judicious; provident; economical; frugal.</syn>
<-- note sensible and careful in def. above. Why not here??? -->

<hw>Pru*den"tial</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Proceeding from, or dictated or characterized by, prudence;
prudent; discreet; sometimes, selfish or pecuniary as
distinguished from higher motives or influences; <as>as,
<ex>prudential</ex> motives</as>.</def> \'bd A
<xex>prudential</xex> line of conduct.\'b8

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Exercising prudence; discretionary; advisory;
superintending or executive; <as>as, a <ex>prudential</ex>
committee</as>.</def>

<hw>Pru*den"tial</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which relates to
or demands the exercise of, discretion or prudence; -- usually in
the <pluf>pl.</pluf></def>

<q>Many stanzas, in poetic measures, contain rules relating to
common <qex>prudentials</qex> as well as to religion.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<hw>Pru*den"tial*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who is governed
by, or acts from, prudential motives.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Coleridge.</au>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<hw>Prud"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pruderies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>pruderie</ets>. See <er>Prude</er>.]</ety> <def>The quality

<hw>Prud"ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Like a prude;

<def>Frosty; covered with fine scales, hairs, dust, bloom, or the

<hw>Prune</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pruned</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pruning</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[OE. <ets>proine</ets>, probably fr. F. <ets>provigner</ets>
to lay down vine stocks for propagation; hence, probably, the
meaning, to cut away superfluous shoots. See
<er>Provine</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To lop or cut off the
superfluous parts, branches, or shoots of; to clear of useless
material; to shape or smooth by trimming; to trim: as, to
<xex>prune</xex> trees; to <xex>prune</xex> an essay.</def>

<au>Thackeray.</au>

<q>Taking into consideration how they [laws] are to be
<qex>pruned</qex> and reformed.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>Our delightful task
To <qex>prune</qex> these growing plants, and tend these
flowers.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To cut off or cut out, as useless parts.</def>

<q>Horace will our superfluous branches <qex>prune</qex>.</q>
<qau>Waller.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To preen; to prepare; to dress.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<q>His royal bird
<qex>Prunes</qex> the immortal wing and cloys his beak.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Prune</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To dress; to prink; -used
humorously or in contempt.</def>

<au>Dryden</au>.

<hw>Prune</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>prune</ets>, from L.
<ets>prunum</ets> a plum. See <er>Plum</er>.]</ety> <def>A plum;
esp., a dried plum, used in cookery; <as>as, French or Turkish
<ex>prunes</ex>; California <ex>prunes</ex>.</as></def>

<cs><col>German prune</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>a large dark
purple plum, of oval shape, often one-sided. It is much used for
preserving, either dried or in sirup.</cd> <col>Prune
tree</col></mcol>. <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>A tree of
the genus <spn>Prunus</spn> (<spn>P. domestica</spn>), which
produces prunes.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The West Indian tree,
<spn>Prunus occidentalis</spn>.</cd> -- <col>South African
prune</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the edible fruit of a
sapindaceous tree (<spn>Pappea Capensis</spn>).</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pru*nel"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
perhaps from G. <ets>br\'91une</ets> quinsy, croup.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Angina, or angina
pectoris.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Thrush.</def>

<cs><col>Prunella salt</col> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>, <cd>niter
fused and cast into little balls.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pru*nel"la</hw>, <hw>Pru*nel"lo</hw>, }</mhw>
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>prunelle</ets>, probably so called
from its color resembling that of prunes. See <er>Prune</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <def>A smooth woolen stuff, generally black,
used for making shoes; a kind of lasting; -- formerly used also
for clergymen's gowns.</def>

<hw>Pru*nelle"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F., dim. of
<ets>prune</ets>. See <er>Prune</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <def>A
kind of small and very acid French plum; -- applied especially to
the stoned and dried fruit.</def>

<hw>Pru*nel"lo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>prunelle</ets>, dim. of <ets>prune</ets>. See <er>Prune</er>
a plum.]</ety> <def>A species of dried plum; prunelle.</def>

<hw>Prun"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who prunes, or removes, what is superfluous.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any one of several species
of beetles whose larv\'91 gnaw the branches of trees so as to
cause them to fall, especially the American oak pruner
(<spn>Asemum m\'d2stum</spn>), whose larva eats the pith of oak
branches, and when mature gnaws a circular furrow on the inside
nearly to the bark. When the branches fall each contains a
pupa.</def>

<hw>Pru*nif"er*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>prunum</ets> a plum + <ets>-ferous</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Bearing plums.</def>

<hw>Prun"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of trimming, or removing what is superfluous.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Falconry)</fld> <def>That which is cast off by
bird in pruning her feathers; leavings.</def>

<au>Beau. & Fl.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Pruning hook</col>, <or/ <col>Pruning
knife</col></mcol>, <cd>cutting instrument used in pruning trees,
etc.</cd> -- <col>Pruning shears</col>, <cd>shears for pruning
trees, vines, etc.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pru"nus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., a plum
tree.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of trees with
perigynous rosaceous flowers, and a single two-ovuled carpel
which usually becomes a drupe in ripening.</def>

<note><hand/ Originally, this genus was limited to the plums,
then, by Linn\'91us, was made to include the cherries and the
apricot. Later botanists separated these into several genera, as
<spn>Prunus</spn>, <spn>Cerasus</spn>, and <spn>Armeniaca</spn>,
but now, by Bentham and Hooker, the plums, cherries, cherry
laurels, peach, almond, and nectarine are all placed in
<spn>Prunus</spn>.</note>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pru"ri*ence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pru"ri*en*cy</hw>

<hw>Prus"sian</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From

<cs><col>Prussian blue</col> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, <cd>any one of
several complex double cyanides of ferrous and ferric iron;
specifically, a dark blue amorphous substance having a coppery
luster, obtained by adding a solution of potassium ferrocyanide
(yellow prussiate of potash) to a ferric salt. It is used in
dyeing, in ink, etc. Called also <altname>Williamson's
blue</altname>, <altname>insoluble Prussian blue</altname>,
<altname>Berlin blue</altname>, etc.</cd> -- <col>Prussian
carp</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Gibel</er>.</cd> --
<col>Prussian green</col>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <cd>Same as
<altname>Berlin green</altname>, under <er>Berlin</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Prus"si*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>prussiate</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A salt of
prussic acid; a cyanide.</def>

<cs><col>Red prussiate of potash</col>. <cd>See <cref>Potassium
ferricyanide</cref>, under <er>Ferricyanide</er>.</cd>
<col>Yellow prussiate of potash</col>. <cd>See <cref>Potassium
ferrocyanide</cref>, under <er>Ferrocyanide</er>.</cd></cs>

<ets>prussique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Old Chem.)</fld>
<def>designating the acid now called hydrocyanic acid, but
formerly called <xex>prussic acid</xex>, because Prussian blue is
derived from it or its compounds. See <er>Hydrocyanic</er>.</def>

<hw>Psalm</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.

others, collected into one book of the Old Testament, or a modern
metrical version of such a hymn for public worship.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pseu`d\'91s*the"si*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pseud*h\'91"mal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>h\'91mal</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to the vascular system of

<cs><col>Pseudh\'91mal fluid</col>, <cd>the circulatory fluid, or
blood, of annelids, analogous to the blood of vertebrates. It is
often red, but is sometimes green or colorless.</cd> --
<col>Pseudh\'91mal vessels</col>, <cd>the blood vessels of
annelids.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pseu"do-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Gr. <?/ lying, false, akin
to <?/ to belie; cf. <?/ lying, <?/ a lie.]</ety> <def>A
combining form or prefix signifying <xex>false</xex>,
<xex>counterfeit</xex>, <xex>pretended</xex>,
<xex>spurious</xex>; <as>as, <ex>pseudo</ex>-apostle, a false
apostle; <ex>pseudo</ex>-clergy, false or spurious clergy;
<ex>pseudo</ex>-episcopacy, <ex>pseudo</ex>-form,
<ex>pseudo</ex>-martyr, <ex>pseudo</ex>-philosopher</as>. Also
used adjectively.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do*bac*te"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>bacteria</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Microscopic organic particles, molecular
granules, powdered inorganic substances, etc., which in form,
size, and grouping resemble bacteria.</def>

<note>The globules which divide and develop in form of chains are
organized beings; when this does not occur, we are dealing with
<xex>pseudobacteria</xex>.
<au>Sternberg.</au>
</note>

<hw>\'d8Pseu`do*c\'d2"li*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ false + <?/ hollow.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The fifth ventricle in the mammalian
brain. See <er>Ventricle</er>.</def>

<au>B. G. Wilder.</au>

<hw>Pseu"do-cone`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>cone</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the soft gelatinous cones found
in the compound eyes of certain insects, taking the place of the
crystalline cones of others.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do-cu"mene</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>cumene</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A hydrocarbon of the aromatic series,
metameric with mesitylene and cumene, found in coal tar, and
obtained as a colorless liquid.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do-dip"ter*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>dipteral</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pseudodipt\'8are</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<def>Falsely or imperfectly dipteral, as a temple with the inner
range of columns surrounding the cella omitted, so that the space
between the cella wall and the columns is very great, being equal
to two intercolumns and one column.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos>
<def>A pseudo-dipteral temple.</def></def2>

<hw>Pseu"do*dox</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/;
<?/ false + <?/ an opinion.]</ety> <def>Not true in opinion or
doctrine; false.</def> -- <def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A false
opinion or doctrine.</def> \'bdTo maintain the atheistical
<xex>pseudodox</xex> which judgeth evil good, and darkness
light.\'b8

<au>T. Adams.</au>
</def2>

<hw>\'d8Pseu`do*fi*la"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Pseudofilari<?/</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the two elongated vibratile
young formed by fission of the embryo during the development of
certain Gregarin\'91.</def>

<hw>Pseu*dog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.

<hw>\'d8Pseu`do*hal"ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;
<plu>pl. <plw>Pseudohalteres</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL.
See <er>Pseudo-</er>, and <er>Halteres</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>One of the rudimentary front wings of
certain insects (<spn>Stylops</spn>). They resemble the halteres,
or rudimentary hind wings, of Diptera.</def>

<hw>Pseu"do-heart`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>heart</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any contractile vessel of
invertebrates which is not of the nature of a real heart,
especially one of those pertaining to the excretory system.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do-hy`per*thoph"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>hypertrophic</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Falsely hypertrophic; <as>as,
<ex>pseudo-hypertrophic</ex> paralysis, a variety of paralysis in
which the muscles are apparently enlarged, but are really
degenerated and replaced by fat</as>.</def>

<hw>Pseu*dol"o*gist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/.]</ety> <def>One who utters falsehoods; a liar.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do-mon`o*cot`y*led"on*ous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,

<hw>Pseu"do*morph</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Pseudomorphous</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An irregular or
deceptive form.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>A pseudomorphous
crystal, as a crystal consisting of quartz, but having the cubic
form of fluor spar, the fluor crystal having been changed to
quartz by a process of substitution.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do*mor"phism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>The state of having, or the
property of taking, a crystalline form unlike that which belongs
to the species.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do*mor"phous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr.
<?/; <?/ false + <?/ form: cf. F. <ets>pseudomorphe</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Not having the true form.</def>

<cs><col>Pseudomorphous crystal</col>, <cd>one which has a form
that does not result from its own powers of
crystallization.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pseu`do*neu*rop"te*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.
pl.</pos> <ety>[NL. See <er>Pseudo-</er>, and
<er>Neuroptera</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>division
of insects <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> reticulated wings, as in the
Neuroptera, but having an active pupa state. It includes the
dragon flies, May flies, white ants, etc. By some zo\'94logists
they are classed with the Orthoptera; by others, with the
Neuroptera.</def>

<au>Wheatstone.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pseu`do*scor`pi*o"nes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.
pl.</pos> <ety>[NL. See <er>Pseudo-</er>, and
<er>Scorpion</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of
Arachnoidea having the palpi terminated by large claws, as in the
scorpions, but destitute of a caudal sting; the false scorpions.
Called also <spn>Pseudoscorpii</spn>, and
<spn>Pseudoscorpionina</spn>. See <xex>Illust</xex>. of
<cref>Book scorpion</cref>, under Book.</def>

<hw>Pseu"do*sphere`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>sphere</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>The surface of constant negative
curvature generated by the revolution of a tractrix. This surface
corresponds in non-Euclidian space to the sphere in ordinary
space. An important property of the surface is that any figure
drawn upon it can be displaced in any way without tearing it or
altering in size any of its elements.</def>

<hw>Pseu"do*spore`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> 
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>spore</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld><def>A peculiar reproductive cell found in some
fungi.</def>

<hw>Pseu`do-sym"me*try</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pseudo-</ets> + <ets>symmetry</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>A kind of symmetry characteristic
of certain crystals which from twinning, or other causes, come to
resemble forms of a system other than that to which they belong,
as the apparently hexagonal prisms of aragonite.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pseu`do*te*tram"e*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Pseudo-</er>, and <er>Tetramerous</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A division of beetles having the fifth
tarsal joint minute and obscure, so that there appear to be but
four joints.</def> -- <wordforms><wf>Pseu`do*te*tram"er*al</wf>
<pr>(#)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>\'d8Pseu*do"vum</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<er>Pseudo-</er>, and <er>Ovum</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>An egglike germ produced by the agamic females of some
insects and other animals, and by the larv\'91 of certain
insects. It is capable of development without fertilization. See
<xex>Illust</xex>. of <er>P\'91dogenesis</er>.</def>

<hw>Pshaw</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>interj.</pos> <ety>[Of

<altsp>[Written also <asp>psha</asp>.]</altsp>

\'bd <xex>Pshaw</xex>!\'b8</def>

wherever this topic was touched upon.</q>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>Psy`chi*at"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to psychiatria.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Psy"chic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Psy"chic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>psychicus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr. <?/ the soul, mind; cf. <?/ to
blow: cf. F. <ets>psychique</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or
pertaining to the human soul, or to the living principle in
man.</def>

<note><hand/ This term was formerly used to express the same idea
as <xex>psychological</xex>. Recent metaphysicians, however, have
employed it to mark the difference between <grk>psychh`</grk> the
living principle in man, and <grk>pney^ma</grk> the rational or
spiritual part of his nature. In this use, the word describes the
human soul in its relation to sense, appetite, and the outer
visible world, as distinguished from spiritual or rational
faculties, which have to do with the supersensible world.
<au>Heyse.</au>
</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the mind, or its functions
and diseases; mental; -- contrasted with
<xex>physical</xex>.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Psychical blindness</col>, <col>Psychical
deafness</col></mcol> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>forms of nervous
disease in which, while the senses of sight and hearing remain
unimpaired, the mind fails to appreciate the significance of the
sounds heard or the images seen.</cd> -- <col>Psychical
contagion</col>, <cd>the transference of disease, especially of a
functional nervous disease, by mere force of example.</cd> --
<col>Psychical medicine</col>, <cd>that department of medicine
which treats of mental diseases.</cd></cs><-- psychiatry? -->

<hw>Psy"chics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Psychology.</def>

<hw>Psy"chism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>psychisme</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Philos.)</fld> <def>The
doctrine of Quesne, that there is a fluid universally diffused,
end equally animating all living beings, the difference in their
actions being due to the difference of the individual
organizations.</def>

<au>Fleming.</au>

<-- p. 1158 -->

<hw>Psy"cho-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A combining form from Gr.
<?/ <xex>the soul</xex>, <xex>the mind</xex>, <xex>the
understanding</xex>; <as>as, <ex>psycho</ex>logy</as>.</def>

<hw>Psy`cho*gen"e*sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Genesis through an internal force, as opposed to
<xex>natural selection</xex>.</def>

<hw>Psy*chog"ra*phy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Psycho-</ets> + <ets>-graphy</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A description of the phenomena of mind.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Spiritualism)</fld> <def>Spirit writing.</def>

<hw>Psy*chol"o*gy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <plu>pl.
<plw>Psychologies</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu>
<ety>[<ets>Psycho-</ets> + <ets>-logy</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>psychologie</ets>. See <er>Psychical</er>.]</ety> <def>The
science of the human soul; specifically, the systematic or
scientific knowledge of the powers and functions of the human
soul, so far as they are known by consciousness; a treatise on
the human soul.</def>

<q><qex>Psychology</qex>, the science conversant about the
phenomena of the mind, or conscious subject, or self.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Hamilton.</qau>

the body.</def>

<hw>Psy"cho*pan"ny*chism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Psy`cho*phys"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of
or pertaining to psychophysics; involving the action or mutual
relations of the psychical and physical in man.</def>

<cs><col>Psychophysical time</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>the
time required for the mind to transform a sensory impression into
a motor impulse. It is an important part of
<xex>physiological<xex> or <xex>reaction time<xex>. See under
<er>Reaction</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Psy`cho*phys"ics</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Psycho-</ets> + <ets>physics</ets>.]</ety> <def>The
science of the connection between nerve action and consciousness;
the science which treats of the relations of the psychical and
physical in their conjoint operation in man; the doctrine of the
relation of function or dependence between body and soul.</def>

<au>J. Fiske.</au>

<hw>\'d8Psyl"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Psyll\'91</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[NL., from Gr. <?/
a flea.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any leaping plant louse

<spn>Psyllid\'91</spn>.</def>

<hw>Ptar"mi*gan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gael.
<ets>tarmachan</ets>; cf. Ir. <ets>tarmochan</ets>,
<ets>tarmonach</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any
grouse of the genus <spn>Lagopus</spn>, of which numerous species
are known. The feet are completely feathered. Most of the species
are brown in summer, but turn white, or nearly white, in
winter.</def>

<note><hand/ They chiefly inhabit the northern countries and high
mountains of Europe, Asia, and America. The common European
species is <spn>Lagopus mutus</spn>. The Scotch grouse, red
grouse, or moor fowl (<spn>L. Scoticus</spn>), is reddish brown,
and does not turn white in winter. The white, or willow,
ptarmigan (<spn>L. albus</spn>) is found in both Europe and
America.</note>

having the teeth of the radula arranged in long transverse rows,
somewhat like the barbs of a feather.</def>

<hw>Pter"o*pod</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<hw>\'d8Pte*rop"o*da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A class of Mollusca
in which the anterior lobes of the foot are developed in the form
of broad, thin, winglike organs, with which they swim at near the
surface of the sea.</def>

<note><hand/ The Pteropoda are divided into two orders:
<spn>Cymnosomata</spn>, which have the body entirely naked and
the head distinct from the wings; and <spn>Thecosomata</spn>,
which have a delicate transparent shell of various forms, and the
head not distinct from the wings.</note>

<hw>\'d8Pter`o*sau"ri*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>An extinct order of
flying reptiles of the Mesozoic age; the pterodactyls; -- called
also <spn>Pterodactyli</spn>, and <spn>Ornithosauria</spn>.</def>

<note><hand/ The wings were formed, like those of bats, by a
leathery expansion of the skin, principally supported by the
greatly enlarged outer or \'bd little\'b8 fingers of the hands.
The American Cretaceous pterodactyls had no teeth. See
<er>Pteranodontia</er>, and <er>Pterodactyl</er>.</note>

<hw>Pter`o*sau"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Paleon.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the

<hw>\'d8Pte*ryg"i*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>Pter"y*goid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
<?/, a wing + <ets>-oid</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<sd>(a)</sd> <def>Like a bird's wing in form; <as>as, a
<ex>pterygoid</ex> bone</as></def>. <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of,
pertaining to, or in the region of, the pterygoid bones,
pterygoid processes, or the whole sphenoid bone.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <def>A pterygoid bone.</def></def2>

<cs><col>Pterygoid bone</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>, <cd>a bone
which corresponds to the inner plate of the pterygoid process of
the human skull, but which, in all vertebrates below mammals, is
not connected with the posterior nares, but serves to connect the
palatine bones with the point of suspension of the lower
jaw.</cd> -- <col>Pterygoid process</col> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>,
<cd>a process projecting downward from either side of the
sphenoid bone, in man divided into two plates, an inner and an
outer. The posterior nares pass through the space, called the
<xex>pterygoid fossa<xex>, between the processes.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pter`y*go*max"il*la*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pterygoid</ets> + <ets>maxillary</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the inner pterygoid
plate, or pterygoid bone, and the lower jaw.</def>

<hw>Pter`y*go*pal"a*tine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the pterygoid

<hw>\'d8Pter`y*go*po"di*um</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>;

<hw>\'d8Pte*ry"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.

<hw>\'d8Pti*lop"te*ri</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>

<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An order of birds including only the
penguins.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pti*lo"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr <?/ a feather.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Pterylosis</er>.</def>

<hw>Ptis"an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>ptisana</ets> peeled barley, barley water, Gr. <?/, from <?/
to peel, husk; cf. F. <ets>ptisane</ets>,
<ets>tisane</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A decoction of barley
with other ingredients; a farinaceous drink.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>An aqueous medicine,
containing little, if any, medicinal agent; a tea or
tisane.</def>

<hw>Ptol`e*ma"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to <xex>Ptolemy</xex>, the geographer and
astronomer.</def>

<cs><col>Ptolemaic system</col> <fld>(Astron.)</fld>, <cd>the
system maintained by Ptolemy, who supposed the earth to be fixed
in the center of the universe, with the sun and stars revolving
around it. This theory was received for ages, until superseded by
the Copernican system.</cd></cs>

<hw>Ptol"e*ma`ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
accepts the astronomical system of Ptolemy.</def>

<hw>Pto"ma*ine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From Gr.
<?/ a dead body.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>One of a
class of animal bases or alkaloids formed in the putrefaction of
various kinds of albuminous matter, and closely related to the
vegetable alkaloids; a cadaveric poison. The ptomaines, as a
class, have their origin in dead matter, by which they are to be
distinguished from the <xex>leucomaines</xex>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pto"sis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ a falling.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Drooping of the
upper eyelid, produced by paralysis of its levator muscle.</def>

<-- p. 1159 -->

<hw>Pty"a*lin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
spittle. See <er>Ptyalism</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol.
Chem.)</fld> <def>An unorganized amylolytic ferment, on enzyme,
present in human mixed saliva and in the saliva of some
animals.</def>

<hw>Pty"a*lism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/,
fr. <?/ to spit much, fr. <?/ spittle, fr. <?/ to spit: cf. F.
<ets>ptyalisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Salivation, or an excessive
flow of saliva.</def>

<au>Quain.</au>

<hw>Pty*al"o*gogue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
spittle + <?/ driving.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
ptysmagogue.</def>

<hw>Ptys"ma*gogue</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
spittle + <?/ driving: cf. F. <ets>ptysmagogue</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A medicine that promotes the discharge of
saliva.</def>

<hw>\'d8Ptyx"is</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL., fr.
Gr. <?/ a folding.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The way in which
a leaf is sometimes folded in the bud.</def>

<hw>Pub"ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Perhaps fr.
<ets>bubble</ets>.]</ety> <def>Puffed out, pursy; pudgy;
fat.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Drant.</au>

<hw>Pu"ber*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From L.
<ets>puber</ets>, <ets>pubes</ets>, grown up, adult.]</ety>
<def>Of or pertaining to puberty.</def>

<hw>Pu"ber*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pubertas</ets>, fr. <ets>puber</ets>, <ets>pubes</ets>,
adult: cf. F. <ets>pubert\'82</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
earliest age at which persons are capable of begetting or bearing
children, usually considered, in temperate climates, to be about
fourteen years in males and twelve in females.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The period when a plant first
bears flowers.</def>

<hw>Pu*ber"u*lent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Pubis</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Very minutely
downy.</def>

<hw>Pu"bes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., the hair
which appears on the body at puberty, from <ets>pubes</ets>
adult.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>The hair which appears upon the lower part of the
hypogastric region at the age of puberty.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>Hence (as more commonly used), the lower part of the
hypogastric region; the pubic region.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The down of plants; a downy or
villous substance which grows on plants; pubescence.</def>

<hw>Pu*bes"cence</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pubescence</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality or
state of being pubescent, or of having arrived at puberty.</def>

<au>Sir T. Browne.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A covering of soft short hairs, or down, as one
some plants and insects; also, the state of being so
covered.</def>

<hw>Pu*bes"cen*cy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Pubescence.</def>

<hw>Pu*bes"cent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pubescens</ets>, <ets>-entis</ets>, p. pr. of
<ets>pubescere</ets> to reach puberty, to grow hairy or mossy,
fr. <ets>pubes</ets> pubes: cf. F. <ets>pubescent</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Arrived at puberty.</def>

<q>That . . . the men (are) <qex>pubescent</qex> at the age of
twice seven, is accounted a punctual truth.</q>
<qau>Sir T. Browne.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Covered with pubescence, or fine short hairs, as
certain insects, and the leaves of some plants.</def>

<hw>Pu"bic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>Of or pertaining to the pubes; in the region of the pubes;
<as>as, the <ex>pubic</ex> bone; the <ex>pubic</ex> region, or
the lower part of the hypogastric region</as>. See
<er>Pubes</er>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of or pertaining to the
pubis.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pu"bis</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL. See
<er>Pubes</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The ventral and
anterior of the three principal bones composing either half of
the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.</def>

<hw>Pub"lic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>publicus</ets>, <ets>poblicus</ets>, fr. <ets>populus</ets>
people: cf. F. <ets>public</ets>. See <er>People</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the people; belonging to the
people; relating to, or affecting, a nation, state, or community;
-- opposed to <xex>private</xex>; <as>as, the <ex>public</ex>
treasury</as>.</def>

<q>To the <qex>public</qex> good
Private respects must yield.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>He [Alexander Hamilton] touched the dead corpse of the
<qex>public</qex> credit, and it sprung upon its feet.</q>
<qau>D. Webster.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Open to the knowledge or view of all; general;
common; notorious; <as>as, <ex>public</ex> report;
<ex>public</ex> scandal.</as></def>

<q>Joseph, . . . not willing to make her a <qex>public</qex>
example, was minded to put her away privily.</q>
<qau>Matt. i. 19.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Open to common or general use; <as>as, a
<ex>public</ex> road; a <ex>public</ex> house.</as></def> \'bdThe
<xex>public</xex> street.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>Public act</col> <or/ <col>statute</col></mcol>
<fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>an act or statute affecting matters of
public concern. Of such statutes the courts take judicial
notice.</cd> -- <col>Public credit</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Credit</er>.</cd> -- <col>Public funds</col>. <cd>See
<er>Fund</er>, 3.</cd> -- <col>Public house</col>, <cd>an inn, or
house of entertainment.</cd> -- <col>Public law</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>See <cref>International law</cref>, under
<er>International</er>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A public act or
statute.</cd> -- <col>Public nuisance</col>. <fld>(Law)</fld>
<cd>See under <er>Nuisance</er>.</cd> -- <col>Public
orator</col>. <fld>(Eng. Universities)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Orator</er>, 3.</cd> -- <col>Public stores</col>,
<cd>military and naval stores, equipments, etc.</cd> --
<col>Public works</col>, <cd>all fixed works built by civil
engineers for public use, as railways, docks, canals, etc.; but
strictly, military and civil engineering works constructed at the
public cost.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pub"lic</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The general body
of mankind, or of a nation, state, or community; the people,
indefinitely; <as>as, the American <ex>public</ex></as>; also, a
particular body or aggregation of people; <as>as, an author's
<ex>public</ex></as>.</def>

<q>The <qex>public</qex> is more disposed to censure than to
praise.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A public house; an inn.</def>
<mark>[Scot.]</mark>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<cs><col>In public</col>, <cd>openly; before an audience or the
people at large; not in private or secrecy. \'bdWe are to speak
<xex>in public<xex>.\'b8</cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pub"li*can</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>publicanus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>publicain</ets>. See
<er>Public</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Rom. Antiq.)</fld>
<def>A farmer of the taxes and public revenues; hence, a
collector of toll or tribute. The inferior officers of this class
were often oppressive in their exactions, and were regarded with
great detestation.</def>

<q>As Jesus at meat . . . many <qex>publicans</qex> and sinners
came and sat down with him and his disciples.</q>
<qau>Matt. 1x. 10.</qau>

<q>How like a fawning <qex>publican</qex> he looks!</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The keeper of an inn or public house; one
licensed to retail beer, spirits, or wine.</def>

<hw>Pub`li*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>publicatio</ets> confiscation: cf. F.
<ets>publication</ets>. See <er>Publish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act of publishing or making known; notification to the
people at large, either by words, writing, or printing;
proclamation; divulgation; promulgation; <as>as, the
<ex>publication</ex> of the law at Mount Sinai; the
<ex>publication</ex> of the gospel; the <ex>publication</ex> of
statutes or edicts.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of offering a book, pamphlet, engraving,
etc., to the public by sale or by gratuitous distribution.</def>

<q>The <qex>publication</qex> of these papers was not owing to
our folly, but that of others.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>That which is published or made known;
especially, any book, pamphlet, etc., offered for sale or to
public notice; <as>as, a daily or monthly
<ex>publication</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>An act done in public.</def> <mark>[R. &
Obs.]</mark>

<q>His jealousy . . . attends the business, the recreations, the
<qex>publications</qex>, and retirements of every man.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<cs><col>Publication of a libel</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>such
an exhibition of a libel as brings it to the notice of at least
one person other than the person libeled.</cd> --
<col>Publication of a will</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>the
delivery of a will, as his own, by a testator to witnesses who
attest it.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pub"lic-heart`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Public-spirited.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pub"li*cist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>publiciste</ets>.]</ety> <def>A writer on the laws of nature
and nations; one who is versed in the science of public right,
the principles of government, etc.</def>

<q>The Whig leaders, however, were much more desirous to get rid
of Episcopacy than to prove themselves consummate
<qex>publicists</qex> and logicians.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pub*lic"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>publicit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being public, or open to the knowledge of a community; notoriety;
publicness.</def>

<hw>Pub"lic*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>With exposure to popular view or notice; without
concealment; openly; <as>as, property <ex>publicly</ex> offered
for sale; an opinion <ex>publicly</ex> avowed; a declaration
<ex>publicly</ex> made.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>In the name of the community.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Pub"lic-mind`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Public-spirited. --
<wordforms><wf>Pub"lic-mind`ed*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pub"lic*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The quality

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The quality or state of belonging to the

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Pub"lic-spir`it*ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<ex>public-spirited</ex> men</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Dictated by a regard to public good; <as>as, a

<hw>Pub"lish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Published</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Publishing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>publier</ets>, L.
<ets>publicare</ets>, <ets>publicatum</ets>. See <er>Public</er>,
and <er>-ish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make public; to
make known to mankind, or to people in general; to divulge, as a
private transaction; to promulgate or proclaim, as a law or an
edict.</def>

<q><qex>Published</qex> was the bounty of her name.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>The unwearied sun, from day to day,
Does his Creator's power display,
And <qex>publishes</qex> to every land
The work of an almighty hand.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make known by posting, or by reading in a
church; <as>as, to <ex>publish</ex> banns of marriage</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To send forth, as a book, newspaper, musical
piece, or other printed work, either for sale or for general
distribution; to print, and issue from the press.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To utter, or put into circulation; <as>as, to
<ex>publish</ex> counterfeit paper</as>.</def>
<mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<cs><col>To publish a will</col> <fld>(Law)</fld>, <cd>to
acknowledge it before the witnesses as the testator's last will
and testament.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- To announce; proclaim; advertise; declare;
promulgate; disclose; divulge; reveal. See
<er>Announce</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pub"lish*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being published; suitable for publication.</def>

<hw>Pub"lish*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
publishes; <as>as, a <ex>publisher</ex> of a book or
magazine</as>.</def>

<q>For love of you, not hate unto my friend,
Hath made me <qex>publisher</qex> of this pretense.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pub"lish*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>The act or process of making publicly known;
publication.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A public notice of intended marriage, required
by the laws of some States.</def> <mark>[U.S.]</mark>

<hw>Puc*coon"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From the

canescens</spn>); also, the pigment itself.</def>

<hw>Puck</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pouke</ets>; cf. OSw. <ets>puke</ets>, Icel.
<ets>p<umac/ki</ets> an evil demon, W. <ets>pwca</ets> a

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Medi\'91val Myth.)</fld> <def>A celebrated

<au>Shak.</au>

Hobgoblin, and on him doth fall.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The goatsucker.</def>
<mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Puck"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t. & i.</pos>

<hw>Pud"der</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Puddered</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Puddering</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf.
<er>Pother</er>.]</ety> <def>To make a tumult or bustle; to
splash; to make a pother or fuss; to potter; to meddle.</def>

<q><qex>Puddering</qex> in the designs or doings of others.</q>
<qau>Barrow.</qau>

<q>Others <qex>pudder</qex> into their food with their broad
nebs.</q>
<qau>Holland.</qau>

<hw>Pud"der</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To perplex; to embarrass;
to confuse; to bother; <as>as, to <ex>pudder</ex> a
man</as>.</def>

<au>Locke.</au>

<hw>Pud"der</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A pother; a tumult; a
confused noise; turmoil; bustle.</def> \'bdAll in a
<xex>pudder</xex>.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Pud"ding</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>boudin</ets> black pudding, sausage, L. <ets>botulus</ets>,
<ets>botellus</ets>, a sausage, G. & Sw. <ets>pudding</ets>
pudding, Dan. <ets>podding</ets>, <ets>pudding</ets>, LG.
<ets>puddig</ets> thick, stumpy, W. <ets>poten</ets>,
<ets>potten</ets>, also E. <ets>pod</ets>, <ets>pout</ets>,
v.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A species of food of a soft or
moderately hard consistence, variously made, but often a compound
of flour or meal, with milk and eggs, etc.</def>

<q>And solid <qex>pudding</qex> against empty praise.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything resembling, or of the softness and
consistency of, pudding.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An intestine; especially, an intestine stuffed
with meat, etc.; a sausage.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>Any food or victuals.</def>

<q>Eat your <qex>pudding</qex>, slave, and hold your tongue.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Puddening</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Pudding grass</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the true
pennyroyal (<spn>Mentha Pulegium</spn>), formerly used to flavor
stuffing for roast meat. <au>Dr. Prior</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pudding
pie</col>, <cd>a pudding with meat baked in it. <au>Taylor
(1630)</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pudding pipe</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>,
<cd>the long, cylindrical pod of the leguminous tree <spn>Cassia
Fistula</spn>. The seeds are separately imbedded in a sweetish
pulp. See <er>Cassia</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pudding sleeve</col>,
<cd>a full sleeve like that of the English clerical gown.
<au>Swift</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pudding stone</col>. 
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <cd>See <er>Conglomerate</er>, <pos>n.</pos>,
2.</cd> -- <col>Pudding time</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>The time of
dinner, pudding being formerly the dish first eaten</cd>.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Johnson</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>The nick
of time; critical time. <mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<q>Mars, that still protects the stout,
In <qex>pudding time</qex> came to his aid.</q>
<qau>Hudibras.</qau>

<hw>Pud"ding-head`ed</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Stupid.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Pud"dle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>podel</ets>; cf. LG. <ets>pudel</ets>, Ir. & Gael.
<ets>plod</ets> pool.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A small quantity of
dirty standing water; a muddy plash; a small pool.</def>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Clay, or a mixture of clay and sand, kneaded or
worked, when wet, to render it impervious to water.</def>

<cs><col>Puddle poet</col>, <cd>a low or worthless poet.
<mark>[R.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Fuller.</au>

<hw>Pud"dle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Puddled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Puddling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To make foul or muddy; to pollute with dirt; to mix dirt
with (water).</def>

<q>Some unhatched practice . . . 
Hath <qex>puddled</qex> his clear spirit.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To make dense or close, as clay or
loam, by working when wet, so as to render impervious to
water.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>To make impervious to liquids by
means of puddle; to apply puddle to.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To subject to the process of puddling, as iron,
so as to convert it from the condition of cast iron to that of
wrought iron.</def>

<au>Ure.</au>

<cs><col>Puddled steel</col>, <cd>steel made directly from cast
iron by a modification of the puddling process.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pud"dle</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To make a dirty
stir.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>R. Junius.</au>

<hw>Pud"dle-ball`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The lump
of pasty wrought iron as taken from the puddling furnace to be
hammered or rolled.</def>

<hw>Pud"dle-bar"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>An iron
bar made at a single heat from a puddle-ball hammering and
rolling.</def>

<hw>Pud"dler</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
converts cast iron into wrought iron by the process of
puddling.</def>

<hw>Pud"dling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Hydraul. Engin.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>The process of
working clay, loam, pulverized ore, etc., with water, to render
it compact, or impervious to liquids; also, the process of
rendering anything impervious to liquids by means of puddled
material.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Puddle. See <er>Puddle</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Metal.)</fld> <def>The art or process of
converting cast iron into wrought iron or steel by subjecting it
to intense heat and frequent stirring in a reverberatory furnace
in the presence of oxidizing substances, by which it is freed
from a portion of its carbon and other impurities.</def>

<cs><col>Puddling furnace</col>, <cd>a reverberatory furnace in
which cast iron is converted into wrought iron or into steel by
puddling.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pud"dly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Consisting of,
or resembling, puddles; muddy; foul.</def> \'bdThick
<xex>puddly</xex> water.\'b8

<au>Carew.</au>

<asp>purrock</asp>.]</altsp> <mark>[Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pueb"lo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Sp., a
village, L. <ets>populus</ets> people. See
<er>People</er>.]</ety> <def>A communistic building erected by
certain Indian tribes of Arizona and New Mexico. It is often of
large size and several stories high, and is usually built either
of stone or adobe. The term is also applied to any Indian village
in the same region.</def>

<cs><col>Pueblo Indians</col> <fld>(Ethnol.)</fld>, <cd>any tribe
or community of Indians living in pueblos. The principal Pueblo
tribes are the Moqui, the Zu\'a4i, the Keran, and the
Tewan.</cd></cs>

<hw>\'d8Pu*er"co</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<cs><col>Puerco beds</col><cd> (<xex>Geol<xex>.), a name given to
certain strata belonging to the earliest Eocene. They are
developed in Northwestern New Mexico, along the Rio Puerco, and
are characterized by their mammalian remains.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pu"er*ile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<q>The French have been notorious through generations for their
<qex>puerile</qex> affectation of Roman forms, models, and
historic precedents.</q>

<syn>Syn. -- Youthful; boyish; juvenile; childish; trifling;

<hw>Pu`er*il"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
