<hw>Puff</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to G. & Sw.
<ets>puff</ets> a blow, Dan. <ets>puf</ets>, D. <ets>pof</ets>;
of imitative origin. Cf. <er>Buffet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A sudden and single emission of breath from the mouth;
hence, any sudden or short blast of wind; a slight gust; a
whiff.</def> \'bd To every <xex>puff</xex> of wind a slave.\'b8

<au>Flatman.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Anything light and filled with air.
Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> A puffball. <sd>(b)</sd> kind of light
pastry. <sd>(c)</sd> A utensil of the toilet for dusting the skin
or hair with powder.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An exaggerated or empty expression of praise,
especially one in a public journal.</def>

<cs><col>Puff adder</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>Any South African viper belonging to <xex>Clotho</xex> and
allied genera. They are exceedingly venomous, and have the power
of greatly distending their bodies when irritated. The common
puff adder (<spn>Vipera, <or/ Clotho, arietans</spn>) is the
largest species, becoming over four feet long. The plumed puff
adder (<spn>C. cornuta</spn>) has a plumelike appendage over each
eye.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>A North American harmless snake
(<spn>Heterodon platyrrhinos</spn>) which has the power of
puffing up its body. Called also <altname>hog-nose
snake</altname>, <altname>flathead</altname>, <altname>spreading
adder</altname>, and <altname>blowing adder</altname>.</cd>
<col>Puff bird</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any bird
of the genus <spn>Bucco</spn>, or family <spn>Bucconid\'91</spn>.
They are small birds, usually with dull-colored and loose
plumage, and have twelve tail feathers. See <er>Barbet</er>
<sd>(b)</sd>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Puff</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Puffed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Puffing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Akin to G. <ets>puffen</ets>
to pop, buffet, puff, D. <ets>poffen</ets> to pop,
<ets>puffen</ets> to blow, Sw. <ets>puffa</ets> to push, to cuff,
Dan. <ets>puffe</ets> to pop, thump. See <er>Puff</er>,
<pos>n.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To blow in puffs, or with
short and sudden whiffs.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To blow, as an expression of scorn; -- with
<xex>at</xex>.</def>

<q>It is really to defy Heaven to <qex>puff</qex> at
damnation.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To breathe quick and hard, or with puffs, as
after violent exertion.</def>

<q>The ass comes back again, <qex>puffing</qex> and blowing, from
the chase.</q>
<qau>L' Estrange.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To swell with air; to be dilated or
inflated.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To breathe in a swelling, inflated, or pompous
manner; hence, to assume importance.</def>

<q>Then came brave Glory <qex>puffing</qex> by.</q>
<qau>Herbert.</qau>

<hw>Puff</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To drive with a
puff, or with puffs.</def>

<q>The clearing north will <qex>puff</qex> the clouds away.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To repel with words; to blow at
contemptuously.</def>

<q>I <qex>puff</qex> the prostitute away.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To cause to swell or dilate; to inflate; to
ruffle with puffs; -- often with <xex>up</xex>; as a bladder
<xex>puffed</xex> with air.</def>

<q>The sea <qex>puffed</qex> up with winds.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To inflate with pride, flattery, self-esteem, or
the like; -- often with <xex>up</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>Puffed</qex> up with military success.</q>
<qau>Jowett (Thucyd. )</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To praise with exaggeration; to flatter; to call
public attention to by praises; to praise unduly.</def> \'bd
Puffed with wonderful skill.\'b8

<au>Macaulay.</au>

<hw>Puff</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Puffed up; vain.</def>
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Fanshawe.</au>

<hw>Puff"ball`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>A kind of ball-shaped fungus (<spn>Lycoperdon
giganteum</spn>, and other species of the same genus) full of
dustlike spores when ripe; -- called also
<altname>bullfist</altname>, <altname>bullfice</altname>,
<altname>puckfist</altname>, <altname>puff</altname>, and
<altname>puffin</altname>.</def>

<hw>Puff"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One
who puffs; one who praises with noisy or extravagant
commendation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who is employed by the owner or seller of
goods sold at suction to bid up the price; a by-bidder.</def>

<au>Bouvier.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def> Any
plectognath fish which inflates its body, as the species of
<spn>Tetrodon</spn> and <spn>Diodon</spn>; -- called also
<altname>blower</altname>, <altname>puff-fish</altname>,
<altname>swellfish</altname>, and
<altname>globefish</altname>.</def><-- (of the Tetraodontidae)
They are highly poisonous due to the presence of glands
containing a potent toxin, tetrodotoxin.  Nevertheless they are
eaten as a delicacy in Japan, being prepared by specially
licensed chefs who remove the poison glands. --> <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>The common, or harbor, porpoise.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Dyeing)</fld> <def>A kier.</def>

<hw>Puff"er*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
puffing; bestowment of extravagant commendation.</def>

<hw>Puf"fin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to
<ets>puff</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An
arctic sea bird <spn>Fratercula arctica</spn>) allied to the
auks, and having a short, thick, swollen beak, whence the name;
-- called also <altname>bottle nose</altname>,
<altname>cockandy</altname>, <altname>coulterneb</altname>,
<altname>marrot</altname>, <altname>mormon</altname>,
<altname>pope</altname>, and <altname>sea parrot</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The name is also applied to other related species,
as the horned puffin (<spn>F. corniculata</spn>), the tufted
puffin (<spn>Lunda cirrhata</spn>), and the razorbill.</note>

<cs><col>Manx puffin</col>, <cd>the Manx shearwater. See under
<er>Manx</er>.</cd></cs>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The puffball.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sort of apple.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Rider's Dict. (1640).</au>

<hw>Puff"i*ness</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The quality
or state of being puffy.</def>

<hw>Puff"ing</hw>, <def><pos>a. & n.</pos> from <er>Puff</er>,

<cs><col>Puffing adder</col>. <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>Same as

<hw>Puff"-leg`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Puff"y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Swelled with air, or any soft matter; tumid with a soft
substance; bloated; fleshy; <as>as, a <ex>puffy</ex>
tumor</as>.</def> \'bd A very stout, <xex>puffy</xex> man.\'b8

<hw>Pug</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Pugged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Pugging</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. G.
<ets>pucken</ets> to thump. beat.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>To mix and stir when wet, as clay for bricks,
pottery, etc.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To fill or stop with clay by tamping; to fill in
or spread with mortar, as a floor or partition, for the purpose
of deadening sound. See <er>Pugging</er>, <er>2</er>.</def>

<hw>Pug</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Tempered clay; clay
moistened and worked so as to be plastic.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A pug mill.</def>

<cs><col>Pug mill</col>, <cd>a kind of mill for grinding and
mixing clay, either for brickmaking or the fine arts; a clay
mill. It consists essentially of an upright shaft armed with
projecting knives, which is caused to revolve in a hollow
cylinder, tub, or vat, in which the clay is placed.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pug</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Corrupted fr. <ets>puck</ets>.
See <er>Puck</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An elf, or a
hobgoblin; also same as <er>Puck</er>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A name for a monkey.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Pull</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pulled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pulling</er>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[AS. <ets>pullian</ets>; cf. LG. <ets>pulen</ets>, and Gael.
<ets>peall</ets>, <ets>piol</ets>, <ets>spiol</ets>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To draw, or attempt to draw, toward one; to draw
forcibly.</def>

<q>Ne'er <qex>pull</qex> your hat upon your brows.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>He put forth his hand . . . and <qex>pulled</qex> her in.</q>
<qau>Gen. viii. 9.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To draw apart; to tear; to rend.</def>

<q>He hath turned aside my ways, and <qex>pulled</qex> me in
pieces; he hath made me desolate.</q>
<qau>Lam. iii. 11.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To gather with the hand, or by drawing toward
one; to pluck; <as>as, to <ex>pull</ex> fruit; to <ex>pull</ex>
flax; to <ex>pull</ex> a finch.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To move or operate by the motion of drawing
towards one; <as>as, to <ex>pull</ex> a bell; to <ex>pull</ex> an
oar.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Horse Racing)</fld> <def>To hold back, and so
prevent from winning; <as>as, the favorite was
<ex>pulled</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Print.)</fld> <def>To take or make, as a proof
or impression; -- hand presses being worked by pulling a
lever.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Cricket)</fld> <def>To strike the ball in a
particular manner. See <er>Pull</er>, <pos>n.</pos>, 8.</def>

<q>Never <qex>pull</qex> a straight fast ball to leg.</q>
<qau>R. H. Lyttelton.</qau>

<cs><col>To pull and haul</col>, <cd>to draw hither and thither.
\'bd Both are equally <xex>pulled and hauled<xex> to do that
which they are unable to do. \'b8 <au>South</au>.</cd> -- <col>To
pull down</col>, <cd>to demolish; to destroy; to degrade; <as>as,
<ex>to pull down</ex> a house</as>.</cd> \'bd In political
affairs, as well as mechanical, it is easier <xex>to pull
down</xex> than build up.\'b8 <au>Howell</au>. \'bd To raise the
wretched, and <xex>pull down</xex> the proud.\'b8
<au>Roscommon</au>. <col>To pull a finch</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Finch</er>.</cd> <col>To pull off</col>, <cd>take or draw
off.</cd><-- (b) to perform (something illegal or unethical); as,
to pull off a heist [robbery]. (c) to accomplish, against the
odds.--></cs>

<-- p. 1161 -->

<hw>Pull</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To exert one's
self in an act or motion of drawing or hauling; to tug; <as>as,
to <ex>pull</ex> at a rope</as>.</def>

<cs><col>To pull apart</col>, <cd>to become separated by pulling;
<as>as, a rope will <ex>pull apart<ex></as>.</cd> -- <col>To pull
up</col>, <cd>to draw the reins; to stop; to halt.</cd> <col>To
pull through</col>, <cd>to come successfully to the end of a
difficult undertaking, a dangerous sickness, or the
like.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pull</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of pulling
or drawing with force; an effort to move something by drawing
toward one.</def>

<q>I awakened with a violent <qex>pull</qex> upon the ring which
was fastened at the top of my box.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A contest; a struggle; <as>as, a wrestling
<ex>pull</ex></as>.</def>

<au>Carew.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A pluck; loss or violence suffered.</def>
<mark>[Poetic]</mark>

<q>Two <qex>pulls</qex> at once;
His lady banished, and a limb lopped off.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A knob, handle, or lever, etc., by which
anything is pulled; <as>as, a drawer <ex>pull</ex>; a bell
<ex>pull</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>The act of rowing; <as>as, a <ex>pull</ex> on
the river</as>.</def> <mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>The act of drinking; <as>as, to take a
<ex>pull</ex> at the beer, or the mug</as>.</def>
<mark>[Slang]</mark>

<au>Dickens.</au>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>Something in one's favor in a comparison or a
contest; an advantage; means of influencing; <as>as, in weights
the favorite had the <ex>pull</ex></as>.</def>
<mark>[Slang]</mark>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Cricket)</fld> <def>A kind of stroke by which a
leg ball is sent to the off side, or an off ball to the
side.</def>

<q>The <qex>pull</qex> is not a legitimate stroke, but bad
cricket.</q>
<qau>R. A. Proctor.</qau>

<hw>Pul"let</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>polete</ets>, OF. <ets>polete</ets>, F. <ets>poulette</ets>,
dim. of <ets>poule</ets> a hen, fr. L. <ets>pullus</ets> a young
animal, a young fowl. See <er>Foal</er>, and cf. <er>Poult</er>,
<er>Poultry</er>, <er>Pool</er> stake.]</ety> <def>A young hen,
or female of the domestic fowl.</def>

<cs><col>Pullet sperm</col>, <cd>the treadle of an egg.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark></cd></cs>

<au>Shak.</au>

<hw>Pul"ley</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pulleys</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>poulie</ets>, perhaps of Teutonic origin (cf. <er>Poll</er>,
<ets>b</ets>. <ets>t</ets>.); but cf. OE. <ets>poleine</ets>,
<ets>polive</ets>, pulley, LL. <ets>polanus</ets>, and F.
<ets>poulain</ets>, properly, a colt, fr. L. <ets>pullus</ets>
young animal, foal (cf. <er>Pullet</er>, <er>Foal</er>). For the
change of sense, cf. F. <ets>poutre</ets> beam, originally, a
filly, and E. <ets>easel</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>A
wheel with a broad rim, or grooved rim, for transmitting power
from, or imparting power to, the different parts of machinery, or
for changing the direction of motion, by means of a belt, cord,
rope, or chain.</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>pulley</xex>, as one of the mechanical
powers, consists, in its simplest form, of a grooved wheel,
called a <xex>sheave</xex>, turning within a movable frame or
<xex>block</xex>, by means of a cord or rope attached at one end
to a fixed point. The force, acting on the free end of the rope,
is thus doubled, but can move the load through only half the
space traversed by itself. The rope may also pass over a sheave
in another block that is fixed. The end of the rope may be
fastened to the movable block, instead of a fixed point, with an
additional gain of power, and using either one or two sheaves in
the fixed block. Other sheaves may be added, and the power
multiplied accordingly. Such an apparatus is called by workmen a
<xex>block and tackle</xex>, or a <xex>fall and tackle</xex>. See
<er>Block</er>. A <xex>single fixed pulley</xex> gives no
increase of power, but serves simply for changing the direction
of motion.</note>

<cs><mcol><col>Band pulley</col>, <or/ <col>Belt
pulley</col></mcol>, <cd>a pulley with a broad face for
transmitting power between revolving shafts by means of a belt,
or for guiding a belt.</cd> -- <col>Cone pulley</col>. <cd>See
<er>Cone pulley</er>.</cd> -- <col>Conical pulley</col>, <cd>one
of a pair of belt pulleys, each in the shape of a truncated cone,
for varying velocities.</cd> -- <col>Fast pulley</col>, <cd>a
pulley firmly attached upon a shaft.</cd> -- <col>Loose
pulley</col>, <cd>a pulley loose on a shaft, to interrupt the
transmission of motion in machinery. See <cref>Fast and loose
pulleys</cref>, under <er>Fast</er>.</cd> <col>Parting
pulley</col>, <cd>a belt pulley made in semicircular halves,
which can be bolted together, to facilitate application to, or
removal from, a shaft.</cd> -- <col>Pulley block</col>. <cd>Same
as <er>Block</er>, <pos>n.</pos> 6.</cd> -- <col>Pulley
stile</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>the upright of the window
frame into which a pulley is fixed and along which the sash
slides.</cd> <col>Split pulley</col>, <cd>a parting
pulley.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pul"ley</hw>, <pos>b. t.</pos> <def>To raise or lift by means
of a pulley.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Howell.</au>

<hw>Pul"li*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A kind of
checked cotton or silk handkerchief.</def>

<hw>Pull"man car`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[Named after Mr.
<ets>Pullman</ets>, who introduced them.]</ety> <def>A kind of
sleeping car; also, a palace car; -- often shortened to
<altname>Pullman</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pul"lu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. i.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pullulatus</ets>, p. p. of <ets>pullulare</ets> to sprout,
from <ets>pullulus</ets> a young animal, a sprout, dim. of
<ets>pullus</ets>. See <er>pullet</er>.]</ety> <def>To germinate;
to bud; to multiply abundantly.</def>

<au>Warburton.</au>

<hw>Pul`lu*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pullulation</ets>.]</ety> <def>A germinating, or
budding.</def>

<au>Dr. H. More.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pul"lus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pulli</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A chick; a young bird in the downy
stage.</def>

<hw>Pulp</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pulpa</ets> flesh, pith, pulp of fruit: cf. F.
<ets>pulpe</ets>.]</ety> <def>A moist, slightly cohering mass,
consisting of soft, undissolved animal or vegetable matter.</def>
Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>A tissue or
part resembling pulp; especially, the soft, highly vascular and
sensitive tissue which fills the central cavity, called the
<xex>pulp cavity,</xex> of teeth.</def> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>The soft, succulent part of fruit; <as>as,
the <ex>pulp</ex> of a grape</as></def>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>The
exterior part of a coffee berry</def>. <au>B. Edwards</au>.
<sd>(d)</sd> <def>The material of which paper is made when ground
up and suspended in water.</def>

<hw>Pulp</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

pulp.</def>

<q>The other mode is to <qex>pulp</qex> the coffee immediately as
it comes from the tree. By a simple machine a man will
<qex>pulp</qex> a bushel in a minute.</q>
<qau>B. Edwards.</qau>

<hw>Pul"pit</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<q>I stand like a clerk in my <qex>pulpit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The whole body of the clergy; preachers as a

<q>I say the <qex>pulpit</qex> (in the sober use
Of its legitimate, peculiar powers)
Must stand acknowledged, while the world shall stand,
The most important and effectual guard,
Support, and ornament of virtue's cause.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A desk, or platform, for an orator or public
speaker.</def>

<-- 4. (Fig.) An office or condition of public prominence in
which a person can gain wide public attention, thereby permitting
him to exhort the public on moral or political matters. "The
presidency is a bully pulpit." -->

<hw>Pul"sate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pulsated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pulsating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>pulsatus</ets>, p.
p. of <ets>pulsare</ets> to beat, strike, v. intens. fr.
<ets>pellere</ets> to beat, strike, drive. See <er>Pulse</er> a
beating, and cf. <er>Pulse</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <def>To
throb, as a pulse; to beat, as the heart.</def>

<q>The heart of a viper or frog will continue to
<qex>pulsate</qex> long after it is taken from the body.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<hw>Pul"sa*tile</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. It.
<ets>pulsatile</ets>, Sp. <ets>pulsatil</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>Capable of being struck or beaten; played by beating or by

instrument</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Pulsating; throbbing, as a tumor.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pul`sa*til"la</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A genus of ranunculaceous
herbs including the pasque flower. This genus is now merged in
<spn>Anemone</spn>. Some species, as <spn>Anemone
Pulsatilla</spn>, <spn>Anemone pratensis</spn>, and <spn>Anemone
patens</spn>, are used medicinally.</def>

<hw>Pul*sa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pulsatio</ets> a beating or striking: cf. F.
<ets>pulsation</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>
<def>A beating or throbbing, especially of the heart or of an
artery, or in an inflamed part; a beat of the pulse.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A single beat or throb of a series.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A stroke or impulse by which some medium is
affected, as in the propagation of sounds.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Any touching of another's body
willfully or in anger. This constitutes <xex>battery</xex>.</def>

<q>By the Cornelian law, <qex>pulsation</qex> as well as
verberation is prohibited.</q>
<qau>Blackstone.</qau>

<hw>Pul"sa*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pulsatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Beating; throbbing.</def>

<hw>Pul*sa"tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A beater; a striker.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Mech.)</fld> <def>That which beats or throbs in
working.</def>

<hw>Pul"sa*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pulsatoire</ets>.]</ety> <def>Capable of pulsating;

<au>Sir H. Wotton. .</au>

<hw>Pulse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>puls</ets>, L. <ets>puls</ets>, <ets>pultis</ets>, a thick
pap or pottage made of meal, pulse, etc. See <er>Poultice</er>,
and cf. <er>Pousse</er>.]</ety> <def>Leguminous plants, or their
seeds, as beans, pease, etc.</def>

<q>If all the world
Should, in a pet of temperance, feed on pulse.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pulse</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE. <ets>pous</ets>, OF.
<ets>pous</ets>, F. <ets>pouls</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pulsus</ets> 
(sc. <ets>venarum</ets>), the beating of the pulse, the pulse,
from <ets>pellere</ets>, <ets>pulsum</ets>, to beat, strike; cf.
Gr. <?/ to swing, shake, <?/ to shake. Cf. <er>Appeal</er>,
<er>Compel</er>, <er>Impel</er>, <er>Push</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>The beating or throbbing
of the heart or blood vessels, especially of the arteries.</def>

<note><hand/ In an artery the pulse is due to the expansion and
contraction of the elastic walls of the artery by the action of
the heart upon the column of blood in the arterial system. On the
commencement of the diastole of the ventricle, the semilunar
valves are closed, and the aorta recoils by its elasticity so as
to force part of its contents into the vessels farther onwards.
These, in turn, as they already contain a certain quantity of
blood, expand, recover by an elastic recoil, and transmit the
movement with diminished intensity. Thus a series of movements,
gradually diminishing in intensity, pass along the arterial
system (see the Note under <er>Heart</er>). For the sake of
convenience, the radial artery at the wrist is generally chosen
to detect the precise character of the pulse. The pulse rate
varies with age, position, sex, stature, physical and psychical
influences, etc.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any measured or regular beat; any short, quick
motion, regularly repeated, as of a medium in the transmission of
light, sound, etc.; oscillation; vibration; pulsation; impulse;
beat; movement.</def>

<q>The measured <qex>pulse</qex> of racing oars.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<q>When the ear receives any simple sound, it is struck by a
single <qex>pulse</qex> of the air, which makes the eardrum and
the other membranous parts vibrate according to the nature and
species of the stroke.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<cs><col>Pulse glass</col>, <cd>an instrument consisting to a
glass tube with terminal bulbs, and containing ether or alcohol,
which the heat of the hand causes to boil; -- so called from the
<xex>pulsating</xex> motion of the liquid when thus warmed.</cd>
<col>Pulse wave</col> <fld>(Physiol.)</fld>, <cd>the wave of
increased pressure started by the ventricular systole, radiating
from the semilunar valves over the arterial system, and gradually
disappearing in the smaller branches.</cd>

<q>the <qex>pulse wave</qex> travels over the arterial system at
the rate of about 29.5 feet in a second.</q>
<qau>H. N. Martin.</qau>

-- <col>To feel one's pulse</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To ascertain,
by the sense of feeling, the condition of the arterial
pulse.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>Hence, to sound one's opinion; to
try to discover one's mind.</cd></cs><-- = to take the pulse of
-->

<hw>Pulse</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To beat, as the arteries;
to move in pulses or beats; to pulsate; to throb.</def>

<au>Ray.</au>

<hw>Pul*som"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pulse</ets> + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A device, with valves, for raising water by

sounds like a steam aspirator, perhaps with other attachments.

<hw>Pul"ver*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pulverized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Pulverizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>pulv\'82riser</ets>, L.

<hw>Pul"vil</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[It.
<ets>polviglio</ets>, fr. L. <ets>pulvis</ets>,

<ets>polvillo</ets>.]</ety> <def>A sweet-scented powder;
pulvillio.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pulville</asp>.]</altsp> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Gay.</au>

<hw>Pu"ma</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Peruv.
<ets>puma</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A large
American carnivore (<spn>Felis concolor</spn>), found from Canada
to Patagonia, especially among the mountains. Its color is tawny,
or brownish yellow, without spots or stripes. Called also
<altname>catamount</altname>, <altname>cougar</altname>,
<altname>American lion</altname>, <altname>mountain
lion</altname>, and <altname>panther</altname> or
<altname>painter</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pume</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A stint.</def>

<hw>Pu"mi*cate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pumicated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pumicating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[L. <ets>pumicatus</ets>,
p. p. of <ets>pumicare</ets> to pumicate, fr. <ets>pumex</ets>.
See <er>Pumice</er>.]</ety> <def>To make smooth with
pumice.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pum"ice</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pumex</ets>, <ets>pumicis</ets>, prob. akin to
<ets>spuma</ets> foam: cf. AS. <ets>pumic-</ets>st\'ben. Cf.
<er>Pounce</er> a powder, <er>Spume</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A very light porous volcanic scoria,
usually of a gray color, the pores of which are capillary and
parallel, giving it a fibrous structure. It is supposed to be
produced by the disengagement of watery vapor without liquid or
plastic lava. It is much used, esp. in the form of powder, for
smoothing and polishing. Called also <altname>pumice
stone</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pum"iced</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Far.)</fld>
<def>Affected with a kind of chronic laminitis in which there is
a growth of soft spongy horn between the coffin bone and the hoof
wall. The disease is called <xex>pumiced foot</xex>, or
<xex>pumice foot</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pu*mi`ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pumiceus</ets>.]</ety> <def>Of or pertaining to pumice;
resembling pumice.</def>

<er>Pumice</er>.</def>

<hw>Pump</hw> <pr>(p<ucr/mp)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably
so called as being worn for <ets>pomp</ets> or ornament. See
<er>Pomp</er>.]</ety> <def>A low shoe with a thin sole.</def><--
MW10 says "close-fitting shoe with moderate to high heel".  Usage
changed? -->

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Pump</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Akin to D. <ets>pomp</ets>, G.
<ets>pumpe</ets>, F. <ets>pompe</ets>; of unknown origin.]</ety>
<def>An hydraulic machine, variously constructed, for raising or
transferring fluids, consisting essentially of a moving piece or
piston working in a hollow cylinder or other cavity, with valves
properly placed for admitting or retaining the fluid as it is
drawn or driven through them by the action of the piston.</def>
<-- this definition is for a mechanical pump.  A peristaltic pump
would not fit this def.  MW10: "a device that raises, transfers,
or compresses fluids . . . by suction or pressure or both." -->

<note><hand/ for various kinds of pumps, see <er>Air pump</er>,
<er>Chain pump</er>, and <er>Force pump</er>; also, under
<er>Lifting</er>, <er>Plunger</er>, <er>Rotary</er>, etc.</note>

<cs><col>Circulating pump</col> <fld>(Steam Engine)</fld>, <cd>a
pump for driving the condensing water through the casing, or
tubes, of a surface condenser.</cd> -- <col>Pump brake</col>. 
<cd>See <cref>Pump handle</cref>, below.</cd> -- <col>Pump
dale</col>. <cd>See <er>Dale</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pump gear</col>,
<cd>the apparatus belonging to a pump. <au>Totten</au>.</cd> --
<col>Pump handle</col>, <cd>the lever, worked by hand, by which
motion is given to the bucket of a pump.</cd> -- <col>Pump
hood</col>, <cd>a semicylindrical appendage covering the upper
wheel of a chain pump.</cd> -- <col>Pump rod</col>, <cd>the rod
to which the bucket of a pump is fastened, and which is attached
to the brake or handle; the piston rod.</cd> -- <col>Pump
room</col>, <cd>a place or room at a mineral spring where the
waters are drawn and drunk.</cd> <mark>[Eng.]</mark> -- <col>Pump
spear</col>. <cd>Same as <cref>Pump rod</cref>, above.</cd> --
<col>Pump stock</col>, <cd>the stationary part, body, or barrel
of a pump.</cd> -- <col>Pump well</col>. <fld>(Naut.)</fld>
<cd>See <er>Well</er>.</cd></cs><-- vacuum pump, a pump which
creates a vacuum by removing gas (usually air) from a container.
Mechanical vacuum pump, a vacuum pump operating by the motion of
a piston or rotary blade in a chamber, as contrasted with an
aspirator.  Persistaltic pump, a pump transferring fluids by
peristaltic action on a flexible tube.  Such pumps are used where
a gentle pumping action is desired, or the transferred fluid may
be harmed in a mechanical pump; as in the infusion of fluids into
blood vessels of the body, or the pumping of explosive or easily
decomposed fluids. -->

<hw>Pump</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pumped</er> <pr>(p<ucr/mt; 215)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. &
vb. n.</pos> <er>pumping</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
raise with a pump, as water or other liquid.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To draw water, or the like, from; to from water
by means of a pump; <as>as, they <ex>pumped</ex> the well dry; to
<ex>pump</ex> a ship.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Figuratively, to draw out or obtain, as secrets
or money, by persistent questioning or plying; to question or ply
persistently in order to elicit something, as information, money,
etc.</def>

<q>But <qex>pump</qex> not me for politics.</q>
<qau>Otway.</qau>

<hw>Pump</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To work, or raise water, a
pump.</def>

<hw>Pump"age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>That which is
raised by pumps, or the work done by pumps.</def>

<q>The <qex>pumpage</qex> last year amounted to . . .
gallons.</q>
<qau>Sci. Amer.</qau>

<hw>Pump"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who pumps;
the instrument or machine used in pumping.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Pun</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. <er>Pun</er> to pound,
<er>Pound</er> to beat.]</ety> <def>A play on words which have
the same sound but different meanings; an expression in which two
different applications of a word present an odd or ludicrous
idea; a kind of quibble or equivocation.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<q>A better <qex>put</qex> on this word was made on the Beggar's
Opera, which, it was said, made Gay rich, and Rich gay.</q>
<qau>Walpole.</qau>

<hw>Pun</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>Punch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Hind.
<ets>p\'bench</ets> five, Skr. <ets>pa</ets><?/<ets>can</ets>. So
called because composed of five ingredients, viz., sugar, arrack,
spice, water, and lemon juice. See <er>Five</er>.]</ety> <def>A
beverage composed of wine or distilled liquor, water (or milk),
sugar, and the juice of lemon, with spice or mint; --
specifically named from the kind of spirit used; <as>as <ex>rum
punch</ex>, <ex>claret punch</ex>, <ex>champagne punch</ex>,
etc</as>.</def><-- (b) a nonalcoholic beverage, usually composed
of a mixture of fruit juices -->

<cs><col>Milk punch</col>, <cd>a sort of punch made with spirit,
milk, sugar, spice, etc.</cd> -- <col>Punch bowl</col>, <cd>a
large bowl in which punch is made, or from which it is
served.</cd> -- <col>Roman punch</col>, <cd>a punch frozen and
served as an ice.</cd></cs>

<hw>Punch</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Prov. E. Cf.

<q>I . . . did hear them call their fat child <qex>punch</qex>,
which pleased me mightily, that word being become a word of
common use for all that is thick and short.</q>
<qau>Pepys.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One of a breed of large, heavy draught horses;
<as>as, the Suffolk <ex>punch</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Punch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A thrust or blow.</def>
<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<hw>Punch</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev. fr.
<ets>puncheon</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A tool, usually of
steel, variously shaped at one end for different uses, and either
solid, for stamping or for perforating holes in metallic plates
and other substances, or hollow and sharpedged, for cutting out
blanks, as for buttons, steel pens, jewelry, and the like; a
die.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Pile Driving)</fld> <def>An extension piece
applied to the top of a pile; a dolly.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A prop, as for the roof of a mine.</def>

<cs><col>Bell punch</col>. <cd>See under <er>Bell</er>.</cd> --
<col>Belt punch</col> <fld>(Mach.)</fld>, <cd>a punch, or punch
pliers, for making holes for lacings in the ends of driving
belts.</cd> -- <col>Punch press</col>. <cd>See <cref>Punching
machine</cref>, under <er>Punch</er>, <pos>v. i.</pos> --
<col>Punch pliers</col></mcol>, <cd>pliers having a tubular,
sharp-edged steel punch attached to one of the jaws, for
perforating leather, paper, and the like.</cd></cs>

<hw>Punch</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.

<hw>Punc*til"io</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Punctilios</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[It.
<ets>puntiglio</ets>, or Sp. <ets>puntillo</ets>, dim. fr. L.
<ets>punctum</ets> point. See <er>Point</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety>
<def>A nice point of exactness in conduct, ceremony, or
proceeding; particularity or exactness in forms; <as>as, the
<ex>punctilios</ex> of a public ceremony</as>.</def>

<q>They will not part with the least <qex>punctilio</qex> in
their opinions and practices.</q>
<qau>Fuller</qau>.</q>

<hw>Punc*til"lous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. It.
<ets>puntiglioso</ets>, Sp. <ets>puntilloso</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Attentive to punctilio; very nice or exact in the forms of
behavior, etiquette, or mutual intercourse; precise; exact in the
smallest particulars.</def> \'bdA <xex>punctilious</xex>
observance of divine laws.\'b8 <au>Rogers</au>. \'bdVery
<xex>punctilious</xex> copies of any letters. <au>The
Nation</au>.

<q><qex>Punctilious</qex> in the simple and intelligible
instances of common life.</q>
<qau> I. Taylor.</qau>

-- <wordforms><wf>Punc*til"ious*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos> --
<wf>Punc*til"ious*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Punc"to</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A term applied to the point in fencing.</def>

<hw>Punc"tu*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>ponctuel</ets> (cf. Sp.<ets>puntual</ets>, It.
<ets>puntuale</ets>), from L. <ets>punctum</ets> point. See
<er>Point</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Consisting in a point;
limited to a point; unextended.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark> \'bdThis
<xex>punctual</xex> spot.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<q>The theory of the <qex>punctual</qex> existence of the
soul.</q>
<qau> Krauth.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Observant of nice points; punctilious;
precise.</def>

<q><qex>Punctual</qex> to tediousness in all that he relates.</q>
<qau> Bp. Burnet.</qau>

<q>So much on <qex>punctual</qex> niceties they stand.</q>
<qau>C. Pitt.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Appearing or done at, or adhering exactly to, a
regular or an appointed time; precise; prompt; <as>as, a
<ex>punctual</ex> man; a <ex>punctual</ex> payment</as>.</def>
\'bdThe race of the undeviating and <xex>punctual</xex> sun.\'b8

<au>Cowper.</au>

<q>These sharp strokes [of a pendulum], with their inexorably
steady intersections, so agree with our successive thoughts that
they seem like the <qex>punctual</qex> stops counting off our
very souls into the past.</q>
<qau> J. Martineau.</qau>

<-- p. 1163 -->

<hw>Punc"tu*al*ist</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
is very exact in observing forms and ceremonies.</def>

<au>Milton.</au>

<hw>Punc`tu*al"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ponctualit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality or state of
being punctual; especially, adherence to the exact time of an
engagement; exactness.</def>

<hw>Punc"tu*al*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
punctual manner; promptly; exactly.</def>

<hw>Punc"tu*al*ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Punctuality;
exactness.</def>

<hw>Punc"tu*ate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Punctuated</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Punctuating</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ponctuer</ets>. See <er>Punctual</er>.]</ety> <def>To mark
with points; to separate into sentences, clauses, etc., by points
or stops which mark the proper pauses in expressing the
meaning.</def>

<hw>Punc`tu*a"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>ponctuation</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Gram.)</fld> <def>The act or
art of punctuating or pointing a writing or discourse; the art or
mode of dividing literary composition into sentences, and members
of a sentence, by means of points, so as to elucidate the
author's meaning.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Punctuation</xex>, as the term is usually
understood, is chiefly performed with four points: the
<xex>period</xex> [.], the <xex>colon</xex> [:], the
<xex>semicolon</xex> [;], and the <xex>comma</xex> [,].  Other
points used in writing and printing, partly rhetorical and partly
grammatical, are the <xex>note of interrogation</xex> [?], the
<xex>note of exclamation</xex> [!], the <xex>parentheses</xex>
[()], the <xex>dash</xex> [--], and <xex>brackets</xex> [].  It
was not until the 16th century that an approach was made to the
present system of punctuation by the Manutii of Venice. With
Caxton, oblique strokes took the place of commas and
periods.</note>

<hw>Punc"tu*a*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
belonging to points of division; relating to punctuation.</def>

<q>The <qex>punctuative</qex> intonation of feeble cadence.</q>
<qau>Rush.</qau>

<hw>Punc"tu*a`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
punctuates, as in writing; specifically, a punctator.</def>

<hw>Punc"tu*ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A punctator.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Punc"tu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Punc"tu*la`ted</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[L. <ets>punctulum</ets>, dim. of <ets>punctum</ets>
point.]</ety> <def>Marked with small spots.</def>

<q>The studs have their surface <qex>punctulated</qex>, as if set
all over with other studs infinitely lesser.</q>
<qau> Woodward.</qau>

<ety>[L., point of vegetation]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>the

originates.</cd></cs>

<hw>Punc"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A small hole made by a point; a slight wound,
bite, or sting; <as>as, the <ex>puncture</ex> of a nail, needle,
or pin</as>.</def>

<q>A lion may perish by the <qex>puncture</qex> of an asp.</q>
<qau>Rambler.</qau>

<hw>Pun"gent</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Causing a sharp sensation, as of the taste,

<q><qex>Pungent</qex> radish biting infant's tongue.</q>

caustic; stinging.</def>

<qau>Swift.</qau>

<q>His <qex>pungent</qex> pen played its part in rousing the
nation.</q>
<qau>J. R. Green.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>Prickly-pointed; hard and
sharp.</def>

<hw>Pun"ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Punished</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Punishing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>punischen</ets>,
F. <ets>punir</ets>, from L. <ets>punire</ets>,
<ets>punitum</ets>, akin to <ets>poena</ets> punishment, penalty.
See <er>Pain</er>, and <er>-ish</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
impose a penalty upon; to afflict with pain, loss, or suffering
for a crime or fault, either with or without a view to the
offender's amendment; to cause to suffer in retribution; to
chasten; <as>as, to <ex>punish</ex> traitors with death; a father
<ex>punishes</ex> his child for willful disobedience.</as></def>

<q>A greater power
Now ruled him, <qex>punished</qex> in the shape he sinned.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To inflict a penalty for (an offense) upon the
offender; to repay, as a fault, crime, etc., with pain or loss;
<as>as, to <ex>punish</ex> murder or treason with
death</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To injure, as by beating; to pommel.</def>
<mark>[Low]</mark>

<syn>Syn. -- To chastise; castigate; scourge; whip; lash;
correct; discipline. See <er>Chasten</er>.</syn>

person or offenses.</def>

<q>That time was, when to be a Protestant, to be a Christian, was
by law as <qex>punishable</qex> as to be a traitor.</q>
<qau> Milton.</qau>

<hw>Pu"ny</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Pup</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See

<hw>Pup</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pupped</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pupping</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To bring forth whelps or
young, as the female of the canine species.</def>

<hw>Pu"pa</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. L.
<plw>Pup<?/</plw> <pr>(#)</pr>, E. <plw>Pupas</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>pupa</ets> girl. doll, puppet,
fem. of <ets>pupus</ets>. Cf. <er>Puppet</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any insect in that stage of its
metamorphosis which usually immediately precedes the adult, or
imago, stage.</def>

<note><hand/ Among insects belonging to the higher orders, as the
Hymenoptera, Diptera, Lepidoptera, the pupa is inactive and takes
no food; in the lower orders it is active and takes food, and
differs little from the imago except in the rudimentary state of
the sexual organs, and of the wings in those that have wings when
adult. The term <xex>pupa</xex> is sometimes applied to other
invertebrates in analogous stages of development.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of air-breathing
land snails having an elongated spiral shell.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Coarctate</col>, <or/ <col>Obtected</col>,
<col>pupa</col></mcol>, <cd>a pupa which is incased in the
dried-up skin of the larva, as in many Diptera.</cd> --
<col>Masked pupa</col>, <cd>a pupa whose limbs are bound down and
partly concealed by a chitinous covering, as in
Lepidoptera.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pu"pal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>Of or pertaining to a pupa, or the condition of a
pupa.</def>

<hw>Pu"pate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>To become a pupa.</def>

<hw>Pu*pa"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>the act of becoming a pupa.</def>

<hw>Pupe</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A pupa.</def>

<hw>Pu*pe"lo</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Cider
brandy.</def> <mark>[Local, U. S.]</mark>

<au>Bartlett.</au>

<hw>Pu*pig"er*ous</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[<ets>Pupa</ets> +
<ets>-gerous</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Bearing or
containing a pupa; -- said of dipterous larv\'91 which do not
molt when the pupa is formed within them.</def>

<hw>Pu"pil</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>pupille</ets>, n. fem., L. <ets>pupilla</ets> the pupil of
the eye, originally dim. of <ets>pupa</ets> a girl. See
<er>Puppet</er>, and cf. <er>Pupil</er> a scholar.]</ety>
<fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>The aperture in the iris; the sight,
apple, or black of the eye. See the Note under <er>Eye</er>, and
<er>Iris</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Pin-hole pupil</col> <fld>(Med.)</fld>, <cd>the pupil of
the eye when so contracted (as it sometimes is in typhus, or
opium poisoning) as to resemble a pin hole.</cd></cs>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<hw>Pu"pil</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F. <ets>pupille</ets>, n.
masc. & fem., L. <ets>pupillus</ets>, <ets>pupilla</ets>, dim. of
<ets>pupus</ets> boy, <ets>pupa</ets> girl. See <er>Puppet</er>,
and cf. <er>Pupil</er> of the eye.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A
youth or scholar of either sex under the care of an instructor or
tutor.</def>

<q>Too far in years to be a <qex>pupil</qex> now.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Tutors should behave reverently before their
<qex>pupils</qex>.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A person under a guardian; a ward.</def>

<au>Dryden.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Civil Law)</fld> <def>A boy or a girl under the
age of puberty, that is, under fourteen if a male, and under
twelve if a female.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- Learner; disciple; tyro. -- See
<er>Scholar</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pu"pil*age</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of
being a pupil.</def>

<q>As sons of kings, loving in <qex>pupilage</qex>,
 Have turned to tyrants when they came to power.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Pu`pil*lar"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pupillarit\'82</ets>. See <er>Pupillary</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Scots Law)</fld> <def>The period before puberty, or from
birth to fourteen in males, and twelve in females.</def>

<hw>Pu"pil*la*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pupillaris</ets>: cf. F.<ets>pupillaire</ets>. See
<er>Pupil</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to a
pupil or ward.</def>

<au>Johnson.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Anat.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to the pupil
of the eye.</def>

<hw>Pu`pil*lom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pupilla</ets> pupil of the eye +  <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physiol.)</fld> <def>An instrument for measuring the size
of the pupil of the pupil of the eye.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pu*pip"a*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Pupiparous</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A division of Diptera in which the young are born in a stage
like the pupa. It includes the sheep tick, horse tick, and other
parasites. Called also <altname>Homaloptera</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pu*pip"a*rous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pupa</ets> + L. <ets>parere</ets> to bring
forth.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>Bearing, or
containing, a pupa; -- said of the matured larv\'91, or larval
skins, of certain Diptera.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Of or
pertaining to the Pupipara.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pu*piv"o*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL. See <er>Pupivorous</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>
<def>A group of parasitic Hymenoptera, including the ichneumon
flies, which destroy the larv\'91 and pup\'91 of insects.</def>

<hw>Pu*piv"o*rous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pupa</ets> + L. <ets>vorare</ets> to devour.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Feeding on the pup\'91 of
insects.</def>

<hw>Pup"li*can</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<def>Publican.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<hw>Pup"pet</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>popet</ets>, OF. <ets>poupette</ets>; akin to F.
<ets>poup\'82e</ets> a doll, probably from L. <ets>puppa</ets>,
<ets>pupa</ets>, a girl, doll, puppet. Cf. <er>Poupeton</er>,
<er>Pupa</er>, <er>Pupil</er>, <er>Puppy</er>.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>poppet</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A small image in the human form; a doll.</def>

<-- p. 1164 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A similar figure moved by the hand or by a wire
in a mock drama; a marionette; a wooden actor in a play.</def>

<q>At the pipes of some carved organ move,
The gilded <qex>puppets</qex> dance.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>One controlled in his action by the will of
another; a tool; -- so used in contempt.</def>

<au>Sir W. Scott.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Mach.)</fld> <def>The upright support for the
bearing of the spindle in a lathe.</def>

<cs><col>Puppet master</col>. <cd>Same as
<er>Puppetman</er>.</cd> -- <col>Puppet play</col>, <cd>a puppet
show.</cd> -- <col>Puppet player</col>, <cd>one who manages the
motions of puppets.</cd> -- <col>Puppet show</col>, <cd>a mock
drama performed by puppets moved by wires.</cd> -- <col>Puppet
valve</col>, <cd>a valve in the form of a circular disk, which
covers a hole in its seat, and opens by moving bodily away from
the seat while remaining parallel with it, -- used in steam
engines, pumps, safety valves, etc.  Its edge is often beveled,
and fits in a conical recess in the seat when the valve is
closed. See the valves shown in <xex>Illusts</xex>. of
<xex>Plunger pump</xex>, and <xex>Safety valve</xex>, under
<er>Plunger</er>, and <er>Safety</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pup"pet*ish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Resembling
a puppet in appearance or action; of the nature of a
puppet.</def>

<hw>Pup"pet*man</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>A master of

<hw>Pup"pet*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Action or

mere form or show; affectation.</def>

<q><qex>Puppetry</qex> of the English laws of divorce.</q>
<qau>Chambers.</qau>

<hw>Pup"py</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Puppies</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[F.
<ets>poup\'82e</ets> doll, puppet. See <er>Puppet</er>, and cf.
<er>Pup</er>, <pos>n.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>The young of a canine animal, esp. of
the common dog; a whelp.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A name of contemptuous reproach for a conceited
and impertinent person.</def>

<q>I found my place taken by an ill-bred, awkward
<qex>puppy</qex> with a money bag under each arm.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Pur</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Purred</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Purring</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Of imitative
origin; cf. Prov. G.  <ets>purren</ets>.]</ety> <def>To utter a
low, murmuring, continued sound, as a cat does when
pleased.</def> <altsp>[Written also <asp>purr</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pur</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To signify or express by
purring.</def>

<au>Gray.</au>

<hw>Pur</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The low, murmuring sound made by
a cat to express contentment or pleasure.</def> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>purr</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>\'d8Pu*ra"na</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Skr.
<ets>pur\'be<?/</ets>, properly. old, ancient, fr.
<ets>pur\'be</ets> formerly.]</ety> <def>One of a class of sacred
Hindoo poetical works in the Sanskrit language which treat of the
creation, destruction, and renovation of worlds, the genealogy
and achievements of gods and heroes, the reigns of the Manus, and
the transactions of their descendants. The principal Puranas are
eighteen in number, and there are the same number of
supplementary books called <xex>Upa Puranas</xex>.</def>

<hw>Pu*ran"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Pertaining to
the Puranas.</def>

<hw>Pur"beck beds`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[So called from the
Isle of <ets>Purbeck</ets> in England.]</ety> <fld>(Geol.)</fld>
<def>The strata of the Purbeck stone, or Purbeck limestone,
belonging to the O\'94litic group. See the <xex>Chart</xex> of
<er>Geology</er>.</def>

<hw>Pur"beck stone`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <fld>(Geol.)</fld> <def>A
limestone from the Isle of Purbeck in England.</def>

<hw>Pur"blind`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>pure-blind</ets>, i. e., wholly blind. See <er>Pure</er>,
and cf. <er>Poreblind</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Wholly
blind.</def> \'bd<xex>Purblind</xex> Argus, all eyes and no
sight.\'b8

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Nearsighted, or dim-sighted; seeing obscurely;
<as>as, a <ex>purblind</ex> eye; a <ex>purblind</ex>
mole.</as></def>

<q>The saints have not so sharp eyes to see down from heaven;
they be <qex>purblind</qex>and sand-blind.</q>
<qau>Latimer.</qau>

<q>O <qex>purblind</qex> race of miserable men.</q>
<qau>Tennyson.</qau>

<hw>Pur"chas*a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable
of being bought, purchased, or obtained for a consideration;
hence, venal; corrupt.</def>

<q>Money being the counterbalance to all things
<qex>purchasable</qex> by it, as much as you take off from the
value of money, so much you add to the price of things
exchanged.</q>
<qau>Locke.</qau>

<hw>Pur"chase</hw> <pr>(?; 48)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Purchased</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Purchasing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>purchasen</ets>,
<ets>porchacen</ets>, OF. <ets>porchacier</ets>,
<ets>purchacier</ets>, to pursue, to seek eagerly, F.
<ets>pourchasser</ets>; OF. <ets>pour</ets>, <ets>por</ets>,
<ets>pur</ets>, for (L. <ets>pro</ets>) + <ets>chacier</ets> to
pursue, to chase. See <er>Chase</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To
pursue and obtain; to acquire by seeking; to gain, obtain, or
acquire.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>That loves the thing he can not <qex>purchase</qex>.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<q>Your accent is Something finer than you could
<qex>purchase</qex> in so removed a dwelling.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>His faults . . . hereditary
Rather than <qex>purchased</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To obtain by paying money or its equivalent; to
buy for a price; <as>as, to <ex>purchase</ex> land, or a
house</as>.</def>

<q>The field which Abraham <qex>purchased</qex> of the sons of
Heth.</q>
<qau>Gen. xxv. 10.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To obtain by any outlay, as of labor, danger, or
sacrifice, etc.; <as>as, to <ex>purchase</ex> favor with
flattery</as>.</def>

<q>One poor retiring minute . . . 
Would <qex>purchase</qex> thee a thousand thousand friends.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>A world who would not <qex>purchase</qex> with a bruise?</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To expiate by a fine or forfeit.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Not tears nor prayers shall <qex>purchase</qex> out
abuses.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <sd>(a)</sd> <def>To acquire by any
means except descent or inheritance.</def> <au>Blackstone</au>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <def>To buy for a price.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To apply to (anything) a device for obtaining a
mechanical advantage; to get a purchase upon, or apply a purchase
to; <as>as, to <ex>purchase</ex> a cannon</as>.</def>

<hw>Pur"chase</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To put
forth effort to obtain anything; to strive; to exert one's
self.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Duke John of Brabant <qex>purchased</qex> greatly that the
Earl of Flanders should have his daughter in marriage.</q>
<qau>Ld. Berners.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To acquire wealth or property.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>Sure our lawyers
Would not <qex>purchase</qex> half so fast.</q>
<qau>J. Webster.</qau>

<hw>Pur"chase</hw> <pr>(?; 48)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>purchds</ets>, F. <ets>pourchas</ets> eager pursuit. See
<er>Purchase</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The
act of seeking, getting, or obtaining anything.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>I'll . . . get meat to have thee,
Or lose my life in the <qex>purchase</qex>.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act of seeking and acquiring property.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The acquisition of title to, or properly in,
anything for a price; buying for money or its equivalent.</def>

<q>It is foolish to lay out money in the <qex>purchase</qex> of
repentance.</q>
<qau>Franklin.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>That which is obtained, got, or acquired, in any
manner, honestly or dishonestly; property; possession;
acquisition.</def>

<au>Chaucer. B. Jonson.</au>

<q>We met with little <qex>purchase</qex> upon this coast, except
two small vessels of Golconda.</q>
<qau>De Foe.</qau>

<q>A beauty-waning and distressed widow . . . 
Made prize and <qex>purchase</qex> of his lustful eye.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>That which is obtained for a price in money or
its equivalent.</def> \'bdThe scrip was complete evidence of his
right in the <xex>purchase</xex>.\'b8

<au>Wheaton.</au>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>Any mechanical hold, or advantage, applied to
the raising or removing of heavy bodies, as by a lever, a tackle,
capstan, and the like; also, the apparatus, tackle, or device by
which the advantage is gained.</def>

<q>A politician, to do great things, looks for a power -- what
our workmen call a <qex>purchase</qex>.</q>
<qau>Burke.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Acquisition of lands or
tenements by other means than descent or inheritance, namely, by
one's own act or agreement.</def>

<au>Blackstone.</au>

<cs><col>Purchase criminal</col>, <cd>robbery.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> <au>Spenser</au>.</cd> -- <col>Purchase
money</col>, <cd>the money paid, or contracted to be paid, for
anything bought. <au>Berkeley</au>.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Worth,
<or/ At</col>, <col>[so many] years' purchase</col></mcol>, <cd>a
phrase by which the value or cost of a thing is expressed in the
length of time required for the income to amount to the
purchasing price; as, he bought the estate at a twenty years'
purchase. To say one's life is not <xex>worth a day's
purchase<xex> in the same as saying one will not live a day, or
is in imminent peril.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur"chas*er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who purchases; one who acquires property for a
consideration, generally of money; a buyer; a vendee.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>One who acquires an estate in
lands by his own act or agreement, or who takes or obtains an
estate by any means other than by descent or inheritance.</def>

<hw>Pur"dah</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Per.
<ets>parda</ets> a curtain.]</ety> <def>A curtain or screen;
also, a cotton fabric in blue and white stripes, used for
curtains.</def>

<au>McElrath.</au>

<hw>Pure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>Compar.</pos> <er>Purer</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>superl.</pos> <er>Purest</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE.
<ets>pur</ets>, F. <ets>pur</ets>, fr. L. <ets>purus</ets>; akin
to <ets>putus</ets> pure, clear, <ets>putare</ets> to clean,
trim, prune, set in order, settle, reckon, consider, think, Skr.
<ets>p<?/</ets> to clean, and perh. E. <ets>fire</ets>. Cf.
<er>Putative</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Separate from all
heterogeneous or extraneous matter; free from mixture or
combination; clean; mere; simple; unmixed; <as>as, <ex>pure</ex>
water; <ex>pure</ex> clay; <ex>pure</ex> air; <ex>pure</ex>
compassion.</as></def>

<q>The <qex>pure</qex> fetters on his shins great.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>A guinea is <qex>pure</qex> gold if it has in it no alloy.</q>
<qau>I. Watts.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Free from moral defilement or quilt; hence,
innocent; guileless; chaste; -- applied to persons.</def>
\'bdKeep thyself <xex>pure</xex>.\'b8

<au>1 Tim. v. 22.</au>

<q>Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a
<qex>pure</qex> heart, and of a good conscience.</q>
<qau>1 Tim. i. 5.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Free from that which harms, vitiates, weakens,
or pollutes; genuine; real; perfect; -- applied to things and
actions.</def> \'bd<xex>Pure</xex> religion and impartial
laws.\'b8 <au>Tickell</au>. \'bdThe <xex>pure</xex>, fine talk of
Rome.\'b8 <au>Ascham</au>.

<q>Such was the origin of a friendship as warm and
<qex>pure</qex> as any that ancient or modern history
records.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Script.)</fld> <def>Ritually clean; fitted for
holy services.</def>

<q>Thou shalt set them in two rows, six on a row, upon the
<qex>pure</qex> table before the Lord.</q>
<qau>Lev. xxiv. 6.</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Phonetics)</fld> <def>Of a single, simple sound
or tone; -- said of some vowels and the unaspirated
consonants.</def>

<cs><col>Pure-impure</col>, <cd>completely or totally impure.
\'bdThe inhabitants were <xex>pure-impure<xex> pagans.\'b8
<au>Fuller</au>.</cd> -- <col>Pure blue</col>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<cd>See <cref>Methylene blue</cref>, under
<er>Methylene</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pure chemistry</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Chemistry</er>.</cd> -- <col>Pure mathematics</col>,
<cd>that portion of mathematics which treats of the principles of
the science, or contradistinction to <xex>applied
mathematics</xex>, which treats of the application of the
principles to the investigation of other branches of knowledge,
or to the practical wants of life.</cd> See <er>Mathematics</er>.
<au>Davies & Peck (Math. Dict. )</au> -- <col>Pure
villenage</col> <fld>(Feudal Law)</fld>, <cd>a tenure of lands by
uncertain services at the will of the lord.
<au>Blackstone</au>.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- Unmixed; clear; simple; real; true; genuine;
unadulterated; uncorrupted; unsullied; untarnished; unstained;
stainless; clean; fair; unspotted; spotless; incorrupt; chaste;
unpolluted; undefiled; immaculate; innocent; guiltless;
guileless; holy.</syn>

<hw>Pured</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Purified;
refined.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdBread of <xex>pured</xex>
wheat.\'b8  \'bd<xex>Pured</xex> gold.\'b8

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pu`r\'82e"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[F.]</ety> <def>A dish made by boiling any article of food
to a pulp and rubbing it through a sieve; <as>as, a
<ex>pur\'82e</ex> of fish, or of potatoes</as>; especially, a
soup the thickening of which is so treated.</def>

<hw>Pure"ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>In a pure manner (in any sense of the adjective).</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Nicely; prettily.</def> <mark>[Archaic]</mark>

<au>Halliwell.</au>

<hw>Pure"ness</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The state of being pure
(in any sense of the adjective).</def>

<hw>Pur"file</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Purfle</er>.]</ety> <def>A sort of ancient trimming of tinsel
and thread for women's gowns; -- called also
<altname>bobbinwork</altname>.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Piers Plowman.</au>

<hw>Pur"fle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pourfiler</ets>; <ets>pour</ets> for + <ets>fil</ets> a
thread, L. <ets>filum</ets>. See <er>Profile</er>, and cf.
<er>Purl</er> a border.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To decorate with
a wrought or flowered border; to embroider; to ornament with
metallic threads; <as>as, to <ex>purfle</ex> with blue and
white</as>.</def>

<au>P. Plowman.</au>

<q>A goodly lady clad in scarlet red,
<qex>Purfled</qex> with gold and pearl of rich assay.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>To ornament with a bordure of
emines, furs, and the like; also, with gold studs or
mountings.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pur"fle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pur"flew</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A hem,
border., or trimming, as of embroidered work.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>A border of any heraldic
fur.</def>

<hw>Pur"fled</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Ornamented;
decorated; esp., embroidered on the edges.</def>

<cs><col>Purfled work</col> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>, <cd>delicate
tracery, especially in Gothic architecture.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur"fling</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Ornamentation
on the border of a thing; specifically, the inlaid border of a
musical instrument, as a violin.</def>

<hw>Pur"ga*ment</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purgamentum</ets> offscourings, washings, expiatory
sacrifice. See <er>Purge</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>That which
is excreted; excretion.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A cathartic; a
purgative.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pur*ga"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purgatio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>purgation</ets>. See
<er>Purge</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of purging; the
act of clearing, cleansing, or putifying, by separating and
carrying off impurities, or whatever is superfluous; the
evacuation of the bowels.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The clearing of one's self from
a crime of which one was publicly suspected and accused. It was
either <xex>canonical</xex>, which was prescribed by the canon
law, the form whereof used in the spiritual court was, that the
person suspected take his oath that he was clear of the matter
objected against him, and bring his honest neighbors with him to
make oath that they believes he swore truly; or
<xex>vulgar</xex>, which was by fire or water ordeal, or by
combat. See <er>Ordeal</er>.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<q>Let him put me to my <qex>purgation</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pur"ga*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purgativus</ets>: cf. F. <ets>purgatif</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Having the power or quality of purging; cathartic.</def> --
<def2><pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A purging medicine; a
cathartic.</def></def2>

<hw>Pur"ga*tive*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a purgative
manner.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pur`ga*to"ri*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pur`ga*to"ri*an</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<def>Of or pertaining to purgatory; expiatory.</def>

<hw>Pur`ga*to"ri*an</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who holds to the
doctrine of purgatory.</def>

<au>Boswell.</au>

<hw>Pur"ga*to*ry</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purgatorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Tending to cleanse;
cleansing; expiatory.</def>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>Pur"ga*to*ry</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>purgatoire</ets>.]</ety> <def>A state or place of
purification after death; according to the Roman Catholic creed,
a place, or a state believed to exist after death, in which the
souls of persons are purified by expiating such offenses
committed in this life as do not merit eternal damnation, or in
which they fully satisfy the justice of God for sins that have
been forgiven. After this purgation from the impurities of sin,
the souls are believed to be received into heaven.</def>

<hw>Purge</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Purged</er> <pr>(?)</pr>;
<pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Purging</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F. <ets>purger</ets>, L.
<ets>purgare</ets>; <ets>purus</ets> pure + <ets>agere</ets> to
make, to do. See <er>Pure</er>, and <er>Agent</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To cleanse, clear, or purify by separating and
carrying off whatever is impure, heterogeneous, foreign, or
superfluous.</def> \'bdTill fire <xex>purge</xex> all things
new.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>To operate on as, or by means
of, a cathartic medicine, or in a similar manner.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To clarify; to defecate, as liquors.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To clear of sediment, as a boiler, or of air, as
a steam pipe, by driving off or permitting escape.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To clear from guilt, or from moral or ceremonial
defilement; <as>as, to <ex>purge</ex> one of guilt or
crime</as>.</def>

<q>When that he hath <qex>purged</qex> you from sin.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q><qex>Purge</qex> me with hyssop, and I shall be clean.</q>
<qau>Ps. li. 7.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To clear from accusation, or
the charge of a crime or misdemeanor, as by oath or in
ordeal.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To remove in cleansing; to deterge; to wash
away; -- often followed by <xex>away</xex>.</def>

<q><qex>Purge</qex> away our sins, for thy name's sake.</q>
<qau>Ps. lxxix. 9.</qau>

<q>We 'll join our cares to <qex>purge</qex> away
Our country's crimes.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<hw>Purge</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To become pure,
as by clarification.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To have or produce frequent evacuations from the
intestines, as by means of a cathartic.</def>

<hw>Purge</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F. <ets>purge</ets>. See
<er>Purge</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act
of purging.</def>

<q>The preparative for the <qex>purge</qex> of paganism of the
kingdom of Northumberland.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which purges; especially, a medicine that
evacuates the intestines; a cathartic.</def>

<au>Arbuthnot.</au>

<hw>Pur"ger</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, purges or cleanses; especially, a cathartic
medicine.</def>

<hw>Pur"ger*y</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The part of a
sugarhouse where the molasses is drained off from the
sugar.</def>

<hw>Pur"ging</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>That purges;
cleansing.</def>

<cs><col>Purging flax</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>an annual
European plant of the genus <spn>Linum</spn> (<spn>L.
catharticum</spn>); dwarf wild flax; -- so called from its use as
a cathartic medicine.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur"ging</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The act
of cleansing; excessive evacuations; especially, diarrhea.</def>

<hw>Pur"i</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>See <er>Euxanthin</er>.</def>

<hw>Pu`ri*fi*ca"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>purification</ets>, L. <ets>purificatio</ets>. See
<er>Purify</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of purifying;
the act or operation of separating and removing from anything
that which is impure or noxious, or heterogeneous or foreign to
it; <as>as, the <ex>purification</ex> of liquors, or of
metals</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The act or operation of cleansing ceremonially,
by removing any pollution or defilement.</def>

<q>When the days of her <qex>purification</qex> according to the
law of Moses were accomplished.</q>
<qau>Luke ii. 22.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A cleansing from guilt or the pollution of sin;
the extinction of sinful desires, appetites, and
inclinations.</def>

<hw>Pu"ri*fi*ca*tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
F. <ets>purificatif</ets>.]</ety> <def>Having power to purify;
tending to cleanse.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pu"ri*fi*ca`tor</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One
who, or that which, purifies; a purifier.</def>

<ets>purificatorius</ets>.]</ety> <def>Serving or tending to
purify; purificative.</def>

<hw>Pu"ri*fi`er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who, or
that which, purifies or cleanses; a cleanser; a refiner.</def>

<hw>Pu"ri*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pus</ets>, <ets>puris</ets>, pus + <ets>-form</ets>: cf. F.

<hw>Pu"ri*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr> <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Purified</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Purifying</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <ety>[F.<ets>purifier</ets>, L.
<ets>purificare</ets>; <ets>purus</ets> pure + <ets>-ficare</ets>
(in comp.) to make. See <er>Pure</er>, and <er>-fy</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>To make pure or clear from material defilement,
admixture, or imperfection; to free from extraneous or noxious
matter; <as>as, to <ex>purify</ex> liquors or metals; to
<ex>purify</ex> the blood; to <ex>purify</ex> the air.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, in figurative uses: <sd>(a)</sd> To free
from guilt or moral defilement; <as>as, to <ex>purify</ex> the
heart</as>.</def>

<q>And fit them so
<qex>Purified</qex> to receive him pure.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sd>(b)</sd> <def>To free from ceremonial or legal
defilement</def>.

<q>And Moses took the blood, and put it upon the horns of the
altar, . . . and <qex>purified</qex> the altar.</q>
<qau>Lev. viii. 15.</qau>

<q><qex>Purify</qex> both yourselves and your captives.</q>
<qau> Num. xxxi. 19.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <def>To free from improprieties or barbarisms;
<as>as, to <ex>purify</ex> a language</as></def>.

<au>Sprat.</au>

<hw>Pu"ri*fy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To grow or become pure
or clear.</def>

<hw>\'d8Pu"rim</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Heb.
