<au>Esther ix. 26.</au>

<hw>Pur"ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>purisme</ets>.]</ety> <def>Rigid purity; the quality of
being affectedly pure or nice, especially in the choice of
language; over-solicitude as to purity.</def> \'bdHis political
<xex>purism</xex>.\'b8

<au>De Quincey.</au>

<q>The English language, however, . . . had even already become
too thoroughly and essentially a mixed tongue for his doctrine of
<qex>purism</qex> to be admitted to the letter.</q>
<qau>Craik.</qau>

<hw>Pur"ist</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>puriste</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who aims at
excessive purity or nicety, esp. in the choice of language.</def>

<q>He [Fox] . . . purified vocabulary with a scrupulosity unknown
to any <qex>purist</qex>.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who maintains that the New Testament was
written in pure Greek.</def>

<au>M. Stuart.</au>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pu*ris"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pu*ris"tic*al</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to
purists or purism.</def>

<hw>Pu"ri*tan</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Purity</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Eccl. Hist.)</fld>
<def>One who, in the time of Queen Elizabeth and the first two
Stuarts, opposed traditional and formal usages, and advocated
simpler forms of faith and worship than those established by law;
-- originally, a term of reproach. The Puritans formed the bulk
of the early population of New England.</def>

<note><hand/ The <xex>Puritans</xex> were afterward distinguished
as <xex>Political Puritans</xex>, <xex>Doctrinal Puritans</xex>,
and <xex>Puritans in Discipline</xex>.</note>

<au>Hume.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who is scrupulous and strict in his
religious life; -- often used reproachfully or in contempt; one
who has overstrict notions.</def>

<q>She would make a <qex>puritan</qex> of the devil.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Pu"ri*tan</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or pertaining to the
Puritans; resembling, or characteristic of, the Puritans.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pu`ri*tan"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<hw>Pu`ri*tan"ic*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to the Puritans, or to their
doctrines and practice.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Precise in observance of legal or religious
requirements; strict; overscrupulous; rigid; -- often used by way
of reproach or contempt.</def>

<q><qex>Paritanical</qex> circles, from which plays and novels
were strictly excluded.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<q>He had all the <qex>puritanic</qex> traits, both good and
evil.</q>
<qau>Hawthorne.</qau>

<hw>Pu`ri*tan"ic*al*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
puritanical manner.</def>

<hw>Pu"ri*tan*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The
doctrines, notions, or practice of Puritans.</def>

<hw>Pu"ri*tan*ize</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Puritanized</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos> <er>Puritanizing</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <def>To agree with, or teach, the
doctrines of Puritans; to conform to the practice of
Puritans.</def>

<au>Bp. Montagu.</au>

<hw>Pu"ri*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>purete</ets>, <ets>purte</ets>, OF. <ets>purt\'82</ets>, F.
<ets>puret\'82</ets>, from L. <ets>puritas</ets>, fr.
<ets>purus</ets> pure. See <er>Pure</er>.]</ety> <def>The
condition of being pure.</def> Specifically: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>freedom from foreign admixture or deleterious matter;
<as>as, the <ex>purity</ex> of water, of wine, of drugs, of
metals</as>.</def> <sd>(b)</sd> <def>Cleanness; freedom from
foulness or dirt.</def> \'bdThe <xex>purity</xex> of a linen
vesture.\'b8 <au>Holyday</au>. <sd>(c)</sd> <def>Freedom from
guilt or the defilement of sin; innocence; chastity; <as>as,
<ex>purity</ex> of heart or of life</as>.</def> <sd>(d)</sd>
<def>Freedom from any sinister or improper motives or
views.</def> <sd>(e)</sd> <def>Freedom from foreign idioms, or
from barbarous or improper words or phrases; <as>as,
<ex>purity</ex> of style</as>.</def>

<hw>Pur"kin*je's cells`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <ety>[From J. E.
<ets>Purkinje</ets>, their discoverer.]</ety> <fld>(Anat.)</fld>
<def>Large ganglion cells forming a layer near the surface of the
cerebellum.</def>

<hw>Purl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[Contr. fr.
<ets>purfile</ets>, <ets>purfle</ets>. See
<er>Purfle</er>.]</ety> <def>To decorate with fringe or
embroidery.</def> \'bdNature's cradle more enchased and
<xex>purled</xex>.\'b8

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<hw>Purl</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>An embroidered and
puckered border; a hem or fringe, often of gold or silver twist;
also, a pleat or fold, as of a band.</def>

<q>A triumphant chariot made of carnation velvet, enriched
with<qex>purl</qex> and pearl.</q>
<qau>Sir P. Sidney</qau>.

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An inversion of stitches in knitting, which
gives to the work a ribbed or waved appearance.</def>

<cs><col>Purl stitch</col>. <cd>Same as <er>Purl</er>,
<pos>n.</pos>, 2.</cd></cs>

<hw>Purl</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Purled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Purling</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[Cf. Sw. <ets>porla</ets>,
and E. <ets>pur</ets> to murmur as a cat.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To run swiftly round, as a small stream flowing among stones
or other obstructions; to eddy; also, to make a murmuring sound,
as water does in running over or through obstructions.</def>

<q>Swift o'er the rolling pebbles, down the hills,
Louder and louder <qex>purl</qex> the falling rills.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <ety>[Perh. fr. F. <ets>perler</ets> to pearl, to
bead. See <er>Pearl</er>, <pos>v. & n.</pos>]</ety> <def>To rise
in circles, ripples, or undulations; to curl; to mantle.</def>

<q>thin winding breath which <qex>purled</qex> up to the sky.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Purl</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See 3d <er>Purl</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A circle made by the notion of a fluid; an eddy;
a ripple.</def>

<q>Whose stream an easy breath doth seem to blow,
Which on the sparkling gravel runs in <qex>purles</qex>,
As though the waves had been of silver curls.</q>
<qau>Drayton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A gentle murmur, as that produced by the running
of a liquid among obstructions; <as>as, the <ex>purl</ex> of a
brook</as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <ety>[Perh. from F.<ets>perler</ets>, v.  See
<er>Purl</er>  to mantle.]</ety> <def>Malt liquor, medicated or
spiced; formerly, ale or beer in which wormwood or other bitter
herbs had been infused, and which was regarded as tonic; at
present, hot beer mixed with gin, sugar, and spices.</def> 
\'bdDrank a glass of <xex>purl</xex> to recover appetite.\'b8
<au>Addison</au>. \'bdDrinking hot <xex>purl</xex>, and smoking
pipes.\'b8 <au>Dickens</au>.

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A tern.</def> <mark>[Prov.
Eng.]</mark>

<hw>Pur"lieu</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Corrupted (by
influence of <ets>lieu</ets> place) fr. OF.
<ets>pural\'82e</ets>, <ets>poral\'82e</ets> (equiv. to LL.
<ets>perambulatio</ets> a survey of boundaries, originally, a
going through); <ets>por</ets> (L. <ets>pro</ets>, confused,
however, with L. <ets>per</ets> through) + <ets>al\'82e</ets>.
See <er>Pro-</er>, and <er>Alley</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written
also <asp>pourlieu</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Originally,
the ground near a royal forest, which, having been unlawfully
added to the forest, was afterwards severed from it, and
disafforested so as to remit to the former owners their
rights.</def>

<q>Then as a tiger, who by chance hath spied
In some <qex>purlieu</qex> two gentle fawns at play.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, the outer portion of any place; an
adjacent district; environs; neighborhood.</def> \'bdThe
<xex>purlieus</xex> of St. James.\'b8

<q>brokers had been incessantly plying for custom in the
<qex>purlieus</qex> of the court.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pur"lin</hw>, <hw>Pur"line</hw>  }</mhw> <pr>(?)</pr>,
<pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Etymol. uncertain.]</ety> <fld>(Arch.)</fld>
<def>In root construction, a horizontal member supported on the
principals and supporting the common rafters.</def>

<hw>Purl"ing</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See 3d
<er>Purl</er>.]</ety> <def>The motion of a small stream running
among obstructions; also, the murmur it makes in so doing.</def>

<hw>Pur*loin"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Purloined</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Purloining</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.
<ets>purloignier</ets>, <ets>porloignier</ets>, to retard, delay;
<ets>pur</ets>, <ets>por</ets>, <ets>pour</ets>, for (L.
<ets>pro</ets>) + <ets>loin</ets> far, far off (L.
<ets>longe</ets>). See <er>Prolong</er>, and cf.
<er>Eloign</er>.]</ety> <def>To take or carry away for one's
self; hence, to steal; to take by theft; to filch.</def>

<q>Had from his wakeful custody <qex>purloined</qex>
The guarded gold.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>when did the muse from Fletcher scenes <qex>purloin</qex>
?</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<hw>Pur*loin"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To practice theft; to
steal.</def>

<au>Titus ii. 10.</au>

<hw>Pur*loin"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>One who
purloins.</def>

<au>Swift.</au>

<hw>Pur"par`ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pourpartie</ets>; <ets>pour</ets> for + <ets>partie</ets> a
part; cf. OF. <ets>purpart</ets> a respective part.]</ety>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>A share, part, or portion of an estate
allotted to a coparcener.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>purpart</asp>, and <asp>pourparty</asp>.]</altsp>

<q>I am forced to eat all the game of your <qex>purparties</qex>,
as well as my own thirds.</q>
<qau>Walpole.</qau>

<hw>Pur"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Purples</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[OE.
<ets>purpre</ets>, <ets>pourpre</ets>, OF. <ets>purpre</ets>,
<ets>porpre</ets>, <ets>pourpre</ets>, F. <ets>pourpre</ets>, L.
<ets>purpura</ets> purple fish, purple dye, fr. Gr. <?/ the
purple fish, a shell from the purple dye was obtained, purple
dye; cf. <?/ dark (said of the sea), purple, <?/ to grow dark
(said of the sea), to be troubled; perh. akin to L.
<ets>furere</ets> to rage, E. <ets>fury</ets>: cf. AS.
<ets>purpure</ets>. Cf. <er>Porphyry</er>,
<er>Purpure</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A color formed by, or
resembling that formed by, a combination of the primary colors
red and blue.</def>

<q>Arraying with reflected <qex>purple</qex> and gold
The clouds that on his western throne attend.</q>
<qau> Milton.</qau>

<note><hand/ The ancient words which are translated
<xex>purple</xex> are supposed to have been used for the color we
call <xex>crimson</xex>. In the gradations of color as defined in
art, <xex>purple</xex> is a mixture of red and blue. When red
predominates it is called <xex>violet</xex>, and when blue
predominates, <xex>hyacinth</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Cloth dyed a purple color, or a garment of such
color; especially, a purple robe, worn as an emblem of rank or
authority; specifically, the purple rode or mantle worn by Roman
emperors as the emblem of imperial dignity; <as>as, to put on the
imperial <ex>purple</ex></as>.</def>

<q>Thou shalt make the tabernacle with ten curtains of fine
twined linen, and <qex>purple</qex>, and scarlet.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxvi. 1.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Hence: Imperial sovereignty; royal rank,
dignity, or favor; loosely and colloquially, any exalted station;
great wealth.</def> \'bdHe was born in the <xex>purple</xex>.\'b8

<au>Gibbon.</au>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A cardinalate. See <er>Cardinal</er>.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any species of large
butterflies, usually marked with purple or blue, of the genus
<spn>Basilarchia</spn> (formerly <spn>Limenitis</spn>) <as>as,
the banded <ex>purple</ex> (<spn>B. arthemis</spn>).</as> See
<xex>Illust</xex>. under <er>Ursula</er>.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>Any shell of the genus
Purpura.</def>

<sn>7.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf><fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>See
<er>Purpura</er>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <def>A disease of wheat. Same as
<er>Earcockle</er>.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Purple</xex> is sometimes used in composition,
esp. with participles forming words of obvious signification; as,
<xex>purple</xex>-colored, <xex>purple</xex>-hued,
<xex>purple</xex>-stained, <xex>purple</xex>-tinged,
<xex>purple</xex>-tinted, and the like.</note>

<cs><col>French purple</col>. <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <cd>Same as
<er>Cudbear</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purple of Cassius</col>. <cd>See
<er>Cassius</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purple of mollusca</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>a coloring matter derived from certain
mollusks, which dyes wool, etc., of a purple or crimson color,
and is supposed to be the substance of the famous Tyrian dye. It
is obtained from Ianthina, and from several species of Purpura,
and Murex.</cd> -- <col>To be born in the purple</col>, <cd>to be
of princely birth; to be highborn.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur"ple</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Exhibiting or
possessing the color called purple, much esteemed for its
richness and beauty; of a deep red, or red and blue color;
<as>as, a <ex>purple</ex> robe</as>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Imperial; regal; -- so called from the color
having been an emblem of imperial authority.</def>

<q>Hide in the dust thy <qex>purple</qex> pride.</q>
<qau>Shelley.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Blood-red; bloody.</def>

<q>May such <qex>purple</qex> tears be alway shed.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>I view a field of blood,
And Tiber rolling with a <qex>purple</qex> blood.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<cs><col>Purple bird</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
European purple gallinule. See under <er>Gallinule</er>.</cd> --
<col>Purple copper ore</col>. <fld>(Min.)</fld> <cd>See
<er>Bornite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purple grackle</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the crow blackbird. See under
<er>Crow</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purple martin</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Martin</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purple sandpiper</col>. <cd>See
under <er>Sandpiper</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purple shell</col>.
<cd>See <er>Ianthina</er>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur"ple</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Purpled</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Purpling</er>.]</wordforms> <def>To make purple; to dye of
purple or deep red color; <as>as, hands <ex>purpled</ex> with
blood</as>.</def>

<q>When morn
<qex>Purples</qex> the east.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>Reclining soft in blissful bowers,
<qex>Purpled</qex> sweet with springing flowers.</q>
<qau> Fenton.</qau>

<hw>Pur"ple*heart`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>A strong, durable, and elastic wood of a
purplish color, obtained from several tropical American
leguminous trees of the genus <spn>Copaifera</spn> (<spn>C.
pubiflora, bracteata, <and/ officinalis</spn>). Used for
decorative veneering. See <er>Copaiba</er>.</def>

<hw>Pur"ple*wood`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Purpleheart</er>.</def>

<hw>Pur"plish</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Somewhat
purple.</def>

<au>Boyle.</au>

<hw>Pur"port</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>purport</ets>; <ets>pur</ets>, <ets>pour</ets>, for (L.
<ets>pro</ets>) + <ets>porter</ets> to bear, carry. See
<er>Port</er> demeanor.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Design or tendency; meaning; import;
tenor.</def>

<q>The whole scope and <qex>purport</qex> of that dialogue.
<qex>Norris</qex>.
With a look so piteous in <qex>purport</qex>
As if he had been loosed out of hell.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Disguise; covering.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>For she her sex under that strange <qex>purport</qex>
Did use to hide.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<hw>Pur"port</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Purported</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Purporting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF. <ets>purporter</ets>,
<ets>pourporter</ets>. See <er>Purport</er>, <pos>n.<pos>]</ety>
<def>To intend to show; to intend; to mean; to signify; to
import; -- often with an object clause or infinitive.</def>

<q>They in most grave and solemn wise unfolded
Matter which little <qex>purported</qex>.</q>
<qau>Rowe.</qau>

<hw>Pur"port*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Without purport or
meaning.</def>

<hw>Pur"pose</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>purpos</ets>, <ets>pourpos</ets>, <ets>propos</ets>, L.
<ets>propositum</ets>. See <er>Propound</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>That which a person sets before himself as an object to be
reached or accomplished; the end or aim to which the view is
directed in any plan, measure, or exertion; view; aim; design;
intention; plan.</def>

<q>He will his firste <qex>purpos</qex> modify.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>As my eternal <qex>purpose</qex> hath decreed.</q>
<qau> Milton.</qau>

<q>The flighty <qex>purpose</qex> never is o'ertook
Unless the deed go with it.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Proposal to another; discourse.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Instance; example.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>L'Estrange.</au>

<cs><mcol><col>In purpose</col>, <col>Of purpose</col>, <col>On
purpose</col></mcol>, <cd>with previous design; with the mind
directed to that object; intentionally. <xex>On purpose<xex> is
the form now generally used.</cd></cs>

<syn>Syn. -- design; end; intention; aim. See
<er>Design</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pur"pose</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Purposed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Purposing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OF.
<ets>purposer</ets>, <ets>proposer</ets>. See
<er>Propose</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To set forth; to bring
forward.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To propose, as an aim, to one's self; to
determine upon, as some end or object to be accomplished; to
intend; to design; to resolve; -- often followed by an infinitive
or dependent clause.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>Did nothing <qex>purpose</qex> against the state.</q>
<qau> Shak.</qau>

<q>I <qex>purpose</qex> to write the history of England from the
accession of King James the Second down to a time which is within
the memory of men still living.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pur"pose</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To have a purpose or
intention; to discourse.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Spenser.</au>

<hw>Pur"posed*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>In a
purposed manner; according to purpose or design; purposely.</def>

<q>A poem composed <qex>purposedly</qex> of the Trojan war.
<qex>Holland</qex>.</q>

<hw>Pur"pose*ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Important;
material.</def> \'bdPurposeful accounts.\'b8 <au>Tylor</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>Pur"pose*ful*ly</wf>, <pos>adv.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pur"pose*less</hw>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Having no purpose or
result; objectless.</def> <au>Bp. Hall</au>. --
<wordforms><wf>Pur"pose*less*ness</wf>, <pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pur"pose*ly</hw>, <pos>adv.</pos> <def>With purpose or
design; intentionally; with predetermination; designedly.</def>

<q>In composing this discourse, I <qex>purposely</qex> declined
all offensive and displeasing truths.</q>
<qau>Atterbury.</qau>

<q>So much they scorn the crowd, that if the throng
By chance go right, they <qex>purposely go</qex> wrong.</q>
<qau>Pope.</qau>

<def>One who brings forward or proposes anything; a

<sn>2.</sn> <def>One who forms a purpose; one who intends.</def>

<au>Bastian.</au>

<hw>Pur*pres"ture</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably
corrupted (see <er>Prest</er>) fr. OF. <ets>pourprisure</ets>,
fr. <ets>pourprendre</ets>: cf. LL. <ets>purprestura</ets>. Cf.
<er>Purprise</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Wrongful

highways, rivers, harbors, forts, etc.</def> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pourpresture</asp>.]</altsp>

<hw>Pur"prise</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pourpris</ets>,fr. <ets>pourprendre</ets> to take away
entirely; <ets>pour</ets> for + <ets>prendre</ets> to

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>\'d8Pur"pu*ra</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.,
purple, purple fish: cf. F. <ets>purpura</ets>. See
<er>Purple</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A
disease characterized by livid spots on the skin from
extravasated blood, with loss of muscular strength, pain in the
limbs, and mental dejection; the purples.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A genus of marine
gastropods, usually having a rough and thick shell. Some species
yield a purple dye.</def>

<hw>Pur"pu*rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of or
pertaining to purpura.</def>

<hw>Pur"pu*rate</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A
salt of purpuric acid.</def>

<hw>Pur"pure</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purpura</ets> purple. See <er>Purple</er>.]</ety>
<fld>(Her.)</fld> <def>Purple, -- represented in engraving by
diagonal lines declining from the right top to the left base of
the escutcheon (or from sinister chief to dexter base).</def>

<hw>Pur*pu"re*al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Of a
purple color; purple.</def>

<hw>Pur*pu"re*o-</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>. <def>A combining form
signifying <xex>of a purple</xex> or <xex>purple-red color</xex>.
Specif. <fld>(Chem.)</fld>, used in designating certain brilliant
<xex>purple-red</xex> compounds of cobaltic chloride and ammonia,
similar to the roseocobaltic compounds. See <er>Cobaltic</er>.
</def>

<-- p. 1166 -->

<hw>Pur*pu"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>purpurique</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to
purpura.</def>

<au>Dunglison.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to or designating,
a nitrogenous acid contained in uric acid. It is not known in the
pure state, but forms well-known purple-red compounds (as
murexide), whence its name.</def>

<note><hand/ <xex>Purpuric acid</xex> was formerly used to
designate murexan. See <er>Murexan</er>.</note>

<hw>Pyr"pu*rin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A dyestuff resembling alizarin, found in
madder root, and extracted as an orange or red crystalline
substance.</def>

<hw>Pyr`pu*rip"a*rous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purpura</ets> purple + <ets>parere</ets> to produce.]</ety>

purple-colored secretion; <as>as, the <ex>purpuriparous</ex>
gland of certain gastropods</as>.</def>

<hw>Pur`pu*rog"e*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>purpura</ets> purple + <ets>-genous</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Biol.)</fld> <def>Having the power to produce a purple

<hw>Purse</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>purs</ets>, <ets>pors</ets>, OF. <ets>burse</ets>,
<ets>borse</ets>, <ets>bourse</ets>, F. <ets>bourse</ets>, LL.
bursa, fr. Gr. <?/ hide, skin, leather. Cf. <er>Bourse</er>,
<er>Bursch</er>, <er>Bursar</er>, <er>Buskin</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>A small bag or pouch, the opening of which is
made to draw together closely, used to carry money in; by
extension, any receptacle for money carried on the person; a
wallet; a pocketbook; a portemonnaie.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q> Who steals my <qex>purse</qex> steals trash.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, a treasury; finances; <as>as, the public
<ex>purse</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>A sum of money offered as a prize, or collected
as a present; <as>as, to win the <ex>purse</ex>; to make up a
<ex>purse</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>A specific sum of money</def>; as: <sd>(a)</sd>
<def>In Turkey, the sum of 500 piasters</def>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<def>In Persia, the sum of 50 tomans.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Light purse</col>, <or/ <col>Empty
purse</col></mcol>, <cd>poverty or want of resources.</cd> --
<mcol><col>Long purse</col>, <or/ <col>Heavy purse</col></mcol>,
<cd>wealth; riches.</cd> -- <col>Purse crab</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any land crab of the genus
<spn>Birgus</spn>, allied to the hermit crabs. They sometimes
weigh twenty pounds or more, and are very strong, being able to
crack cocoanuts with the large claw. They chiefly inhabit the
tropical islands of the Pacific and Indian Oceans, living in
holes and feeding upon fruit. Called also <altname>palm
crab</altname>.</cd> -- <col>Purse net</col>, <cd>a fishing net,
the mouth of which may be closed or drawn together like a
purse.</cd> <au>Mortimer</au>. <col>Purse pride</col>, <cd>pride
of money; insolence proceeding from the possession of wealth.
<au>Bp. Hall</au>.</cd> -- <col>Purse rat</col>.
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <cd>See <cref>Pocket gopher</cref>, under
<er>Pocket</er>.</cd> -- <col>Sword and purse</col>, <cd>the
military power and financial resources of a nation.</cd></cs>

<hw>Purse</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pursed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pursing</er>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To put into a
purse.</def>

<q>I will go and <qex>purse</qex> the ducats straight.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To draw up or contract into folds or wrinkles,
like the mouth of a purse; to pucker; to knit.</def>

<q>Thou . . . didst contract and <qex>purse</qex> thy brow.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<hw>Purse</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To steal purses; to
rob.</def> <mark>[Obs. & R.]</mark>

<q>I'll <qex>purse</qex>: . . . I'll bet at bowling alleys.</q>
<qau>Beau. & Fl.</qau>

<hw>Purse"ful</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pursefuls</plw> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.</plu> <def>All that is, or
can be, contained in a purse; enough to fill a purse.</def>

<hw>Purse"-proud`</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Affected
with purse pride; puffed up with the possession of riches.</def>

<hw>Purs"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Purse</er>, and cf. <er>Bursar</er>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Naut.)</fld> <def>A commissioned officer in the
navy who had charge of the provisions, clothing, and public
moneys on shipboard; -- now called
<altname>paymaster</altname>.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A clerk on steam passenger vessels whose duty it
is to keep the accounts of the vessels, such as the receipt of
freight, tickets, etc.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Colloquially, any paymaster or cashier.</def>

<cs><col>Purser's name</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>a false
name.</cd> <mark>[Slang]</mark></cs>

purser.</def>

<au>Totten.</au>

<au>B. Jonson.</au>

<au>Holland.</au>

<hw>Purs"lain</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>Same as
<er>Purslane</er>.</def>

<hw>Purs"lane</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>porcelaine</ets>, <ets>pourcelaine</ets> (cf. It.
<ets>porcellana</ets>), corrupted fr. L. <ets>porcilaca</ets> for
<ets>portulaca</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Bot.)</fld> <def>An annual
plant (<spn>Portulaca oleracea</spn>), with fleshy, succulent,
obovate leaves, sometimes used as a pot herb and for salads,
garnishing, and pickling.</def>

<cs><mcol><col>Flowering purslane</col>, <or/ <col>Great flowered
purslane</col></mcol>, <cd>the <cref>Portulaca
grandiflora</cref>. See <er>Portulaca</er>.</cd> -- <col>Purslane
tree</col>, <cd>a South African shrub (<cref>Portulacaria
Afra</cref>) with many small opposite fleshy obovate leaves.</cd>
-- <col>Sea purslane</col>, <cd>a seashore plant (<cref>Arenaria
peploides</cref>) with crowded opposite fleshy leaves.</cd> --
<col>Water purslane</col>, <cd>an aquatic plant (<cref>Ludwiqia
palustris</cref>) but slightly resembling purslane.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur*su"a*ble</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>Capable of
being, or fit to be, pursued, followed, or prosecuted.</def>

<au>Sherwood.</au>

<hw>Pur*su"al</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <def>The act of
pursuit.</def> <mark>[R.]</mark>

<hw>Pur*su"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Pursuant</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act of pursuing or
prosecuting; a following out or after.</def>

<q>Sermons are not like curious inquiries after new nothings, but
<qex>pursuances</qex> of old truths.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being pursuant; consequence.</def>

<cs><col>In pursuance of</col>, <cd>in accordance with; in
prosecution or fulfillment of.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur*su"ant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[From
<er>Pursue</er>: cf. OE. <ets>poursuiant</ets>. Cf.
<er>Pursuivant</er>.]</ety> <def>Acting in consequence or in
prosecution (of anything); hence, agreeable; conformable;
following; according; -- with <xex>to</xex> or
<xex>of</xex>.</def>

<q>The conclusion which I draw from these premises,
<qex>pursuant</qex> to the query laid down, is, etc.</q>
<qau>Waterland.</qau>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pur*su"ant</hw>, <hw>Pur*su"ant*ly</hw>, }</mhw>
<pos>adv.</pos> <def>Agreeably; conformably.</def>

<hw>Pur*sue"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Pursued</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pursuing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>pursuen</ets>,
<ets>porsuen</ets>, OF. <ets>porsivre</ets>,
<ets>poursuivre</ets>, <ets>poursuir</ets>, F.
<ets>poursuivre</ets>, fr. L. <ets>prosequi</ets>; <ets>pro</ets>
forward + <ets>sequi</ets> to follow. See <er>Sue</er>, and cf.
<er>Prosecute</er>, <er>Pursuivant</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To follow with a view to overtake; to follow eagerly, or
with haste; to chase; <as>as, to <ex>pursue</ex> a
hare</as>.</def>

<q>We happiness <qex>pursue</qex>; we fly from pain.</q>
<qau>Prior.</qau>

<q>The happiness of men lies in <qex>purswing</qex>,
Not in possessing.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To seek; to use or adopt measures to obtain;
<as>as, to <ex>pursue</ex> a remedy at law</as>.</def>

<q>The fame of ancient matrons you <qex>pursue</qex>.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To proceed along, with a view to some and or
object; to follow; to go in; <as>as, Captain Cook
<ex>pursued</ex> a new route; the administration <ex>pursued</ex>
a wise course.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To prosecute; to be engaged in; to
continue.</def> \'bd Insatiate to <xex>pursue</xex> vain war.\'b8

<au>Milton.</au>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To follow as an example; to imitate.</def>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To follow with enmity; to persecute; to call to
account.</def>

<q>The servant is not greater than his lord. If they have
<qex>pursued</qex> me, they shall <qex>pursue</qex> you also.</q>
<qau>Wyclif (John xv. 20).</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- To follow; chase; seek; persist. See
<er>Follow</er>.</syn>

<hw>Pur*sue"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To go in
pursuit; to follow.</def>

<q>The wicked flee when no man <qex>pursueth</qex>.</q>
<qau>Prov. xxviii. 1.</qau>

<q>Men hotly <qex>pursued</qex> after the objects of their
ambition.</q>
<qau>Earle.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To go on; to proceed, especially in argument or
discourse; to continue.</def>

<note>[A Gallicism]</note>

<q>I have, <qex>pursues</qex> Carneades, wondered chemists should
not consider.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>To follow a matter judicially,
as a complaining party; to act as a prosecutor.</def>

<au>Burrill.</au>

<hw>Pur*su"er</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>One who pursues or chases; one who follows in haste, with a
view to overtake.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Eccl. & Scots Law)</fld> <def>A plaintiff; a
prosecutor.</def>

<hw>Pur*suit"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>poursuite</ets>, fr. <ets>poursuivre</ets>. See
<er>Pursue</er>, <pos>v. t.</pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act
of following or going after; esp., a following with haste, either
for sport or in hostility; chase; prosecution; <as>as, the
<ex>pursuit</ex> of game; the <ex>pursuit</ex> of an
enemy.</as></def>

<au>Clarendon.</au>

<q>Weak we are, and can not shun <qex>pursuit</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A following with a view to reach, accomplish, or
obtain; endeavor to attain to or gain; <as>as, the
<ex>pursuit</ex> of knowledge; the <ex>pursuit</ex> of happiness
or pleasure.</as></def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>Course of business or occupation; continued
employment with a view to same end; <as>as, mercantile
<ex>pursuits</ex>; a literary <ex>pursuit</ex>.</as></def>

<sn>4.</sn> <fld>(Law)</fld> <def>Prosecution.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>That <qex>pursuit</qex> for tithes ought, and of ancient time
did pertain to the spiritual court.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<cs><col>Curve of pursuit</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>a curve
described by a point which is at each instant moving towards a
second point, which is itself moving according to some specified
law.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pur"sui*vant</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[F.
<ets>poursuivant</ets>, fr. <ets>poursuivre</ets>. See
<er>Pursue</er>, and cf. <er>Pursuant</er>.]</ety>
<altsp>[Written also <asp>poursuivant</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn>
<fld>(Heralds' College)</fld> <def>A functionary of lower rank
than a herald, but discharging similar duties; -- called also
<altname>pursuivant at arms</altname>; an attendant of the
heralds. Also used figuratively.</def>

<q>The herald Hope, forerunning Fear,
And Fear, the <qex>pursuivant</qex> of Hope.</q>
<qau>Longfellow.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The king's messenger; a state messenger.</def>

<q>One <qex>pursuivant</qex> who attempted to execute a warrant
there was murdered.</q>
<qau>Macaulay.</qau>

<hw>Pur"sui*vant</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <def>To pursue.</def>
<mark>[Obs. & R.]</mark>

<q>Their navy was <qex>pursuivanted</qex> after with a horrible
tempest.</q>
<qau>Fuller.</qau>

<hw>Pur"sy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>pourcif</ets>, <ets>poulsif</ets>, <ets>poussif</ets>, fr.

<ets>poulser</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pousse</ets> the heaves, asthma.

<au>Shak.</au>

<q><qex>Pursy</qex> important he sat him down.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scot.</qau>

<hw>Pur"te*nance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Abbrev.

<au>Piers Plowman.</au>

<hw>Pur*vey"</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos>
<wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p. p.</pos> <er>Purveyed</er>
<pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Purveying</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>purveien</ets>,
<ets>porveien</ets>, OF. <ets>porveeir</ets>,
<ets>porveoir</ets>, F. <ets>pourvoir</ets>, fr. L.

<er>Purview</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To furnish or provide,
as with a convenience, provisions, or the like.</def>

<q>Give no odds to your foes, but do <qex>purvey</qex>
Yourself of sword before that bloody day.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To procure; to get.</def>

<q>I mean to <qex>purvey</qex> me a wife after the fashion of the
children of Benjamin.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scot.</qau>

<hw>Pur*vey"</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To purchase
provisions; to provide; to make provision.</def>

<au>Chaucer. Milton.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To pander; -- with <xex>to</xex>.</def> \'bd
Their turpitude <xex>purveys</xex> to their malice.\'b8
<mark>[R.]</mark>

<au>Burke.</au>

<hw>Pur*vey"ance</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pourvoyance</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or
process of providing or procuring; providence; foresight;
preparation; management.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<q>The ill <qex>purveyance</qex> of his page.</q>
<qau>Spenser.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>That which is provided; provisions; food.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <fld>(Eng. Law)</fld> <def>A providing necessaries
for the sovereign by buying them at an appraised value in
preference to all others, and oven without the owner's consent.
This was formerly a royal prerogative, but has long been
abolished.</def>

<au>Wharton.</au>

<hw>Pur*vey"or</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OE.
<ets>porveour</ets>, OF. <ets>pourveor</ets>, F.
<ets>pourvoyeur</ets>. See <er>Purvey</er>, and cf.
<er>Proveditor</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>One who provides
victuals, or whose business is to make provision for the table; a
victualer; a caterer.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>An officer who formerly provided, or exacted
provision, for the king's household.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>a procurer; a pimp; a bawd.</def>

<au>Addison.</au>

<hw>Pur"view</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[OF.
<ets>purveu</ets>, <ets>pourveu</ets>, F. <ets>pourvu</ets>,
provided, p. p. of OF. <ets>porveoir</ets>, F.
<ets>pourvoir</ets>. See <er>Purvey</er>, <er>View</er>, and cf.
<er>Proviso</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <sd>(a)</sd>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <def>The body of a statute, or that part which
begins with \'bd <xex>Be it enacted</xex>, \'b8 as distinguished
from the <xex>preamble</xex>.</def> <au>Cowell</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
Hence: <def>The limit or scope of a statute; the whole extent of
its intention or provisions.</def>

<au>Marshall.</au>

<q>Profanations within the <qex>purview</qex> of several
statutes.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Limit or sphere of authority; scope;
extent.</def>

<q>In determining the extent of information required in the
exercise of a particular authority, recourse must be had to the
objects within the <qex>purview</qex> of that authority.</q>
<qau>Madison.</qau>

<hw>Pus</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., akin to Gr.
<?/, <?/, and to E. <ets>foul</ets>: cf. F. <ets>pus</ets>. See
<er>Foul</er>, <pos>a.<pos>]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>The
yellowish white opaque creamy matter produced by the process of
suppuration. It consists of innumerable white nucleated cells
floating in a clear liquid.</def>

<hw>Pu"sane</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Anc.
Armor)</fld> <def>A piece of armor for the breast; often, an
addition to, or re\'89nforcement of. the breastplate; -- called
also <altname>pesane</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pu"sey*ism</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Ch. of
Eng.)</fld> <def>The principles of Dr. <ets>Pusey</ets> and
others at Oxford, England, as exhibited in various publications,
esp. in a series which appeared from 1833 to 1841, designated
\'bd Tracts for the Times;\'b8 tractarianism. See
<er>Tractarianism</er>.</def>

<hw>Push</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Probably F.
<ets>poche</ets>. See <er>Pouch</er>.]</ety> <def>A pustule; a
pimple.</def> <mark>[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Push</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Pushed</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Pushing</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[OE. <ets>possen</ets>,
<ets>pussen</ets>, F. <ets>pousser</ets>, fr. L.
<ets>pulsare</ets>, v. intens. fr. <ets>pellere</ets>,
<ets>pulsum</ets>, to beat, knock, push. See <er>Pulse</er> a
beating, and cf. <er>Pursy</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To press
against with force; to drive or impel by pressure; to endeavor to
drive by steady pressure, without striking; -- opposed to
<xex>draw</xex>.</def>

<q>Sidelong had <qex>pushed</qex> a mountain from his seat.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To thrust the points of the horns against; to
gore.</def>

<q>If the ox shall <qex>push</qex> a manservant or maidservant, .
. . the ox shall be stoned.</q>
<qau>Ex. xxi. 32.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To press or urge forward; to drive; to
<xex>push</xex> an objection too far.</def> \'bd To
<xex>push</xex> his fortune.\'b8

<au>Dryden.</au>

<q>Ambition <qex>pushes</qex> the soul to such actions as are apt
to procure honor to the actor.</q>
<qau>Spectator.</qau>

<q>We are <qex>pushed</qex> for an answer.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To bear hard upon; to perplex; to
embarrass.</def>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To importune; to press with solicitation; to
tease.</def>

<cs><col>To push down</col>, <cd>to overthrow by pushing or
impulse.</cd></cs>

<hw>Push</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To make a
thrust; to shove; <as>as, to <ex>push</ex> with the horns or with
a sword</as>.</def>

<au>Shak.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make an advance, attack, or effort; to be
energetic; <as>as, a man must <ex>push</ex> in order to
succeed</as>.</def>

<q>At the time of the end shall the kind of the south
<qex>push</qex> at him and the king of the north shall come
against him.</q>
<qau>Dan. xi. 40.</qau>

<q>War seemed asleep for nine long years; at length
Both sides resolved to <qex>push</qex>, we tried our
strength.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To burst pot, as a bud or shoot.</def>

<cs><col>To push on</col>, <cd>to drive or urge forward; to
hasten.</cd></cs>

<q>The rider <qex>pushed</qex> on at a rapid pace.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<hw>Push</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A thrust with a
pointed instrument, or with the end of a thing.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Any thrust. pressure, impulse, or force, or
force applied; a shove; <as>as, to give the ball the first
<ex>push</ex></as>.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>An assault or attack; an effort; an attempt;
hence, the time or occasion for action.</def>

<q>Exact reformation is not perfected at the first
<qex>push</qex>.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>hen it comes to the <qex>push</qex>, tic no more than
talk.</q>
<qau>L' Estrange.</qau>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>The faculty of overcoming obstacles; aggressive
energy; <as>as, he has <ex>push</ex>, or he has no
<ex>push</ex></as>.</def>

<mark>[Colloq.]</mark>

<syn>Syn. -- See <er>Thrust</er>.</syn>

that which, pushes.</def>

<-- 2. One who sells illegal drugs, esp. one who tries to
convince others to use such drugs. -->

<au>L. Estrange.</au>

<hw>Pu"sil</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pusillus</ets> very little.]</ety> <def>Very small; little;
petty.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<hw>Pu`sil*la*nim"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pusillanimitas</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pusillanimit\'82</ets>.]</ety> <def>The quality of being
pusillanimous; weakness of spirit; cowardliness.</def>

<q>The badge of <qex>pusillanimity</qex> and cowardice.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>It is obvious to distinguished between an act of . . .
<qex>pusillanimity</qex> and an act of great modesty or
humility.</q>
<qau>South.</qau>

<syn>Syn. -- Cowardliness; cowardice; fear; timidity.</syn>

<hw>Pu`sil*lan"i*mous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pusillannimis</ets>; <ets>pusillus</ets> very little (dim.
of <ets>pusus</ets> a little boy; cf. <ets>puer</ets> a boy, E.
<ets>puerile</ets>) + <ets>animus</ets> the mind: cf. F.
<ets>pusillanime</ets>. See <er>Animosity</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Destitute of a manly or courageous strength and
firmness of mind; of weak spirit; mean-spirited; spiritless;
cowardly; -- said of persons, <as>as, a <ex>pussillanimous</ex>
prince</as>.</def>

<-- p. 1167 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Evincing, or characterized by, weakness of mind,
and want of courage; feeble; <as>as, <ex>pusillanimous</ex>
counsels</as>.</def> \'bdA low and <xex>pusillanimous</xex>
spirit.\'b8

<au>Burke.</au>

<syn>Syn. -- Cowardly; dastardly; mean-spirited; fainthearted;
timid; weak; feeble.</syn>

<hw>Pu`sil*lan"i*mous*ly</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>adv.</pos>
<def>With pusillanimity.</def>

<hw>Pus"ley</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>
<def>Purslane.</def> <mark>[Colloq. U. S]</mark>

<hw>Puss</hw> <pr>(p<usdot/s)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. D.
<ets>poes</ets>, Ir. & Gael. <ets>pus</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>A cat; -- a fondling appellation.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A hare; -- so called by sportsmen.</def>

<cs><col>Puss in the corner</col>, <cd>a game in which all the
players but one occupy corners of a room, or certain goals in the
open air, and exchange places, the one without a corner
endeavoring to get a corner while it is vacant, leaving some
other without one.</cd> -- <col>Puss moth</col>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>any one of several species of stout
bombycid moths belonging to <spn>Cerura</spn>,
<spn>Harpyia</spn>, and allied genera, esp. <spn>Harpyia
vinuli</spn>, of Europe. The larv\'91 are humpbacked, and have
two caudal appendages.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pussy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Dim. of
<ets>puss</ets>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>A pet name for a cat;
also, an endearing name for a girl.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>A catkin of the pussy willow.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>The game of tipcat; -- also called
<altname>pussy cat</altname>.</def>

<cs><col>Pussy willow</col> <fld>(Bot.)</fld>, <cd>any kind of
willow having large cylindrical catkins clothed with long glossy
hairs, especially the American <spn>Salix discolor</spn>; --
called also <altname>glaucous willow</altname>, and
<altname>swamp willow</altname>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pus"tu*lant</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pus"tu*lar</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <def>1. Of or

<ex>pustular</ex> eruptions.</as></def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Covered with pustulelike prominences;

<hw>Pus"tu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <ety>[L.

fr. <ets>pustula</ets>. See <er>Pustule</er>.]</ety> <def>To form
into pustules, or blisters.</def>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pus"tu*late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pus"tu*la`ted</hw>
<pr>(?)</pr>, }</mhw> <pos>a.</pos> <def>Covered with pustulelike

<hw>Pus*tu*la"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pustulatio</ets>.]</ety> <def>The act of producing pustules;

<hw>Pus"tule</hw> <pr>(?; 135)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pustula</ets>, and <ets>pusula</ets>: cf. F.

<hw>Put</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[See
<er>Pit</er>.]</ety> <def>A pit.</def> <mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Put</hw>, <mark>obs.</mark> <def><pos>3d pers. sing.
pres.</pos> of <er>Put</er>, contracted from
<xex>putteth</xex>.</def>

<au>Chaucer.</au>

<hw>Put</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Cf. W.
<ets>pwt</ets> any short thing, <ets>pwt o ddyn</ets> a squab of
a person, <ets>pwtog</ets> a short, thick woman.]</ety> <def>A
rustic; a clown; an awkward or uncouth person.</def>

<q>Queer country <qex>puts</qex> extol Queen Bess's reign.</q>
<qau>Bramston.</qau>

<q>What droll <qex>puts</qex> the citizens seem in it all.</q>
<qau>F. Harrison.</qau>

<hw>Put</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp.
& p. p.</pos> <er>Put</er>; <pos>p. pr. & vb. n.</pos>
<er>Putting</er>.]</wordforms> <ety>[AS. <ets>potian</ets> to
thrust: cf. Dan. <ets>putte</ets> to put, to put into, Fries.
<ets>putje</ets>; perh. akin to W. <ets>pwtio</ets> to butt,
poke, thrust; cf. also Gael. <ets>put</ets> to push, thrust, and
E. <ets>potter</ets>, v. i.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To move in
any direction; to impel; to thrust; to push; -- nearly obsolete,
except with adverbs, as with <xex>by</xex> (<xex>to put by</xex>
= to thrust aside; to divert); or with <xex>forth</xex> (<xex>to
put forth</xex> = to thrust out).</def>

<q>His chief designs are . . . to <qex>put</qex> thee by from thy
spiritual employment.</q>
<qau>Jer. Taylor.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To bring to a position or place; to place; to
lay; to set; figuratively, to cause to be or exist in a specified
relation, condition, or the like; to bring to a stated mental or
moral condition; <as>as, to <ex>put</ex> one in fear; to
<ex>put</ex> a theory in practice; to <ex>put</ex> an enemy to
fight.</as></def>

<q>This present dignity,
In which that I have <qex>put</qex> you.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q>I will <qex>put</qex> enmity between thee and the woman.</q>
<qau>Gen. iii. 15.</qau>

<q>He <qex>put</qex> no trust in his servants.</q>
<qau>Job iv. 18.</qau>

<q>When God into the hands of their deliverer
<qex>Puts</qex> invincible might.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>In the mean time other measures were <qex>put</qex> in
operation.</q>
<qau>Sparks.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To attach or attribute; to assign; <as>as, to
<ex>put</ex> a wrong construction on an act or
expression</as>.</def>

<sn>4.</sn> <def>To lay down; to give up; to surrender.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<q>No man hath more love than this, that a man <qex>put</qex> his
life for his friends.</q>
<qau>Wyclif (John xv. 13).</qau>

<sn>5.</sn> <def>To set before one for judgment, acceptance, or
rejection; to bring to the attention; to offer; to state; to
express; figuratively, to assume; to suppose; -- formerly
sometimes followed by <xex>that</xex> introducing a proposition;
<as>as, to <ex>put</ex> a question; to <ex>put</ex> a
case.</as></def>

<q>Let us now <qex>put</qex> that ye have leave.</q>
<qau>Chaucer.</qau>

<q><qex>Put</qex> the perception and you <qex>put</qex> the
mind.</q>
<qau>Berkeley.</qau>

<q>These verses, originally Greek, were <qex>put</qex> in
Latin.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<q>All this is ingeniously and ably <qex>put</qex>.</q>
<qau>Hare.</qau>

<sn>6.</sn> <def>To incite; to entice; to urge; to constrain; to
oblige.</def>

<q>These wretches <qex>put</qex> us upon all mischief.</q>
<qau>Swift.</qau>

<q><qex>Put</qex> me not use the carnal weapon in my own
defense.</q>
<qau>Sir W. Scott.</qau>

<q>Thank him who <qex>puts</qex> me, loath, to this revenge.</q>
<qau>Milton.</qau>

<sn>7.</sn> <def>To throw or cast with a pushing motion
\'bdoverhand,\'b8 the hand being raised from the shoulder; a
practice in athletics; <as>as, to <ex>put</ex> the shot or
weight</as>.</def>

<sn>8.</sn> <fld>(Mining)</fld> <def>To convey coal in the mine,
as from the working to the tramway.</def>

<au>Raymond.</au>

<cs><col>Put case</col>, <cd>formerly, an elliptical expression
for, <xex>put<xex> or suppose the case to be.</cd></cs>

<q><qex>Put case</qex> that the soul after departure from the
body may live.</q>
<qau>Bp. Hall.</qau>

 -- <col>To put about</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to turn, or
change the course of, as a ship.</cd> -- <col>To put away</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To renounce; to discard; to expel.</cd>
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To divorce</cd>. -- <col>To put back</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To push or thrust backwards; hence, to hinder;
to delay.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To refuse; to deny</cd>.

<q>Coming from thee, I could not <qex>put</qex> him
<qex>back</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To set, as the hands of a clock, to an earlier
hour.</cd> <sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To restore to the original place; to
replace</cd>. -- <col>To put by</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To turn,
set, or thrust, aside.</cd> \'bdSmiling <xex>put</xex> the
<xex>question by</xex>.\'b8 <au>Tennyson</au>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>To lay aside; to keep; to sore up; as, <xex>to put by</xex>
money.</cd> -- <col>To put down</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To lay
down; to deposit; to set down.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To lower; to
diminish; as, <xex>to put down</xex> prices</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd>
<cd>To deprive of position or power; to put a stop to; to
suppress; to abolish; to confute; as, <xex>to put down</xex>
rebellion of traitors</cd>.

<q>Mark, how a plain tale shall <qex>put</qex> you
<qex>down</qex>.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<q>Sugar hath <qex>put down</qex> the use of honey.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To subscribe; as, <xex>to put down</xex> one's
name.</cd> -- <col>To put forth</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To thrust
out; to extend, as the hand; to cause to come or push out; as, a
tree <xex>puts forth</xex> leaves.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To make
manifest; to develop; also, to bring into action; to exert; as,
<xex>to put forth</xex> strength</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To
propose, as a question, a riddle, and the like</cd>. <sd>(d)</sd>
<cd>To publish, as a book</cd>. -- <col>To put forward</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To advance to a position of prominence
responsibility; to promote.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To cause to
make progress; to aid</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To set, as the hands
of a clock, to a later hour</cd>. -- <col>To put in</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To introduce among others; to insert; sometimes,
to introduce with difficulty; <as>as, <ex>to put in</ex> a word
while others are discoursing</as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld> <cd>To conduct into a harbor, as a ship</cd>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>To place in due form before a
court; to place among the records of a court</cd>.
<au>Burrill</au>. <sd>(d)</sd> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>To restore,
as a dislocated part, to its place.</cd> -- <col>To put
off</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To lay aside; to discard; <as>as,
<ex>to put off</ex> a robe; <ex>to put off</ex>
mortality</as>.</cd> \'bd<xex>Put off</xex> thy shoes from off
thy feet.\'b8 <au>Ex. iii. 5</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To turn
aside; to elude; to disappoint; to frustrate; to baffle.</cd>

<q>I hoped for a demonstration, but Themistius hoped <qex>to
put</qex> me <qex>off</qex> with an harangue.</q>
<qau>Boyle.</qau>

<q>We might <qex>put</qex> him <qex>off</qex> with this
answer.</q>
<qau>Bentley.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To delay; to defer; to postpone; as, <xex>to put
off</xex> repentance.</cd> <sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To get rid of; to
dispose of; especially, to pass fraudulently; <as>as, <ex>to put
off</ex> a counterfeit note, or an ingenious theory</as><-- = to
pass off --></cd>. <sd>(e)</sd> <cd>To push from land; <as>as,
<ex>to put off</ex> a boat</as></cd>. -- <mcol><col>To put
on</col> <or/ <col>upon</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To invest
one's self with, as clothes; to assume.</cd> \'bdMercury . . .
<xex>put on</xex> the shape of a man.\'b8 <au>L'Estrange</au>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To impute (something) to; to charge upon; as,
<xex>to put</xex> blame <xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex>
another.</cd> <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To advance; to promote</cd>.
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdThis came handsomely <xex>to put on</xex>
the peace.\'b8 <au>Bacon</au>. <sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To impose; to
inflict.</cd> \'bdThat which thou <xex>puttest on</xex> me, will
I bear.\'b8 <au>2 Kings xviii. 14</au>. <sd>(e)</sd> <cd>To
apply; <as>as, <ex>to put on</ex> workmen; <ex>to put on</ex>
steam</as>.</cd> <sd>(f)</sd> <cd>To deceive; to trick.</cd>
\'bdThe stork found he was <xex>put upon</xex>.\'b8
<au>L'Estrange</au>. <sd>(g)</sd> <cd>To place upon, as a means
or condition; as, he <xex>put</xex> him <xex>upon</xex> bread and
water.</cd> \'bdThis caution will <xex>put</xex> them
<xex>upon</xex> considering.\'b8 <au>Locke</au>. <sd>(h)</sd>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>To rest upon; to submit to; as, a defendant
<xex>puts</xex> himself <xex>on</xex> or <xex>upon</xex> the
country.</cd> <au>Burrill</au>. -- <col>To put out</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To eject; <as>as, <ex>to put out</ex> and
intruder</as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To put forth; to shoot, as a
bud, or sprout</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To extinguish; <as>as,
<ex>to put out</ex> a candle, light, or fire</as></cd>.
<sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To place at interest; to loan; <as>as, <ex>to
put out</ex> funds</as></cd>. <sd>(e)</sd> <cd>To provoke, as by
insult; to displease; to vex; as, he was <xex>put out</xex> by my
reply</cd>. <mark>[Colloq.]</mark> <sd>(f)</sd> <cd>To protrude;
to stretch forth; <as>as, <ex>to put out</ex> the hand</as>.</cd>
<sd>(g)</sd> <cd>To publish; to make public; <as>as, <ex>to put
out</ex> a pamphlet</as></cd>. <sd>(h)</sd> <cd>To confuse; to
disconcert; to interrupt; <as>as, <ex>to put</ex> one
<ex>out</ex> in reading or speaking</as></cd>. <sd>(i)</sd>
<fld>(Law)</fld> <cd>To open; <as>as, <ex>to put out</ex> lights,
that is, to open or cut windows</as></cd>. <au>Burrill</au>.
<sd>(j)</sd> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <cd>To place out of joint; to
dislocate; as, <xex>to put out</xex> the ankle.</cd> <sd>(k)</sd>
<cd>To cause to cease playing, or to prevent from playing longer
in a certain inning, as in base ball</cd>. -- <col>To put
over</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To place (some one) in authority
over; <as>as, <ex>to put</ex> a general <ex>over</ex> a division
of an army</as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To refer</cd>.

<q>For the certain knowledge of that knowledge of that truth<
 <qex>put</qex> you <qex>o'er</qex> to heaven and to my
mother.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To defer; to postpone; as, the court <xex>put
over</xex> the cause to the next term.</cd> <sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To
transfer (a person or thing) across; <as>as, <ex>to put</ex> one
<ex>over</ex> the river</as></cd>. -- <mcol><col>To put the hand
to</col> <xex>or</xex> <col>unto</col></mcol>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>To take hold of, as of an instrument of labor; as, <xex>to
put the hand to</xex> the plow; hence, to engage in (any task or
affair); <as>as, <ex>to put</ex> one's <ex>hand to</ex> the
work</as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To take or seize, as in
theft</cd>. \'bdHe hath not <xex>put his hand unto</xex> his
neighbor's goods.\'b8 <au>Ex. xxii. 11</au>. -- <col>To put
through</col>, <cd>to cause to go through all conditions or
stages of a progress; hence, to push to completion; to
accomplish; <as>as, he <ex>put through</ex> a measure of
legislation; he <ex>put through</ex> a railroad
enterprise</as>.</cd> <mark>[U.S.]</mark> -- <col>To put
to</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To add; to unite; <as>as, <ex>to
put</ex> one sum <ex>to</ex> another</as>.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>To refer to; to expose; <as>as, <ex>to put</ex> the safety of
the state <ex>to</ex> hazard</as></cd>. \'bdThat dares not
<xex>put</xex> it <xex>to</xex> the touch.\'b8 <au>Montrose</au>.
<sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To attach (something) to; to harness beasts
to.</cd> <au>Dickens</au>. -- <col>To put to a stand</col>,
<cd>to stop; to arrest by obstacles or difficulties.</cd> --
<col>To put to bed</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To undress and place
in bed, as a child.</cd> <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To deliver in, or to
make ready for, childbirth</cd>. -- <col>To put to death</col>,
<cd>to kill.</cd> -- <col>To put together</col>, <cd>to attach;
to aggregate; to unite in one.</cd> -- <mcol><col>To put this and
that</col> (<xex>or</xex> <col>two and two</col>)
<col>together</col></mcol>, <cd>to draw an inference; to form a
correct conclusion.</cd> -- <col>To put to it</col>, <cd>to
distress; to press hard; to perplex; to give difficulty to.</cd>
\'bdO gentle lady, do not <xex>put</xex> me <xex>to 't</xex>.\'b8
<au>Shak.</au> -- <col>To put to rights</col>, <cd>to arrange in
proper order; to settle or compose rightly.</cd> -- <col>To put
to the sword</col>, <cd>to kill with the sword; to slay.</cd> --
<mcol><col>To put to trial</col>, <xex>or</xex> <col>on
trial</col></mcol>, <cd>to bring to a test; to try.</cd> --
<col>To put trust in</col>, <cd>to confide in; to repose
confidence in.</cd> -- <col>To put up</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To
pass unavenged; to overlook; not to punish or resent; to put up
with; <as>as, <ex>to put up</ex> indignities</as>.</cd>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdSuch national injuries are not <xex>to be
put up</xex>.\'b8 <au>Addison</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To send
forth or upward; as, <xex>to put up</xex> goods for sale.</cd>
<sd>(d)</sd> <cd>To start from a cover, as game</cd>. \'bdShe has
been frightened; she has been <xex>put up</xex>.\'b8 <au>C.
Kingsley</au>. <sd>(e)</sd> <cd>To hoard.</cd> \'bdHimself never
<xex>put up</xex> any of the rent.\'b8 <au>Spelman</au>.
<sd>(f)</sd> <cd>To lay side or preserve; to pack away; to store;
to pickle; <as>as, to <ex>put up</ex> pork, beef, or
fish</as>.</cd> <sd>(g)</sd> <cd>To place out of sight, or away;
to put in its proper place; <as>as, <ex>put up</ex> that
letter</as></cd>. <au>Shak</au>. <sd>(h)</sd> <cd>To incite; to
instigate; -- followed by <xex>to</xex>; <as>as, he <ex>put</ex>
the lad <ex>up</ex> to mischief</as>.</cd> <sd>(i)</sd> <cd>To
raise; to erect; to build; as, <xex>to put up</xex> a tent, or a
house</cd>. <sd>(j)</sd> <cd>To lodge; to entertain; <as>as,
<ex>to put up</ex> travelers</as></cd>. -- <col>To put up a
job</col>, <cd>to arrange a plot.</cd> <mark>[Slang]</mark>

<syn>Syn. -- To place; set; lay; cause; produce; propose;
state.</syn> <usage> -- <er>Put</er>, <er>Lay</er>,
<er>Place</er>, <er>Set</er>. These words agree in the idea of
fixing the position of some object, and are often used
interchangeably. <xex>To put</xex> is the least definite,
denoting merely to move to a place. <xex>To place</xex> has more
particular reference to the precise location, as to put with care
in a certain or proper place.  <xex>To set</xex> or <xex>to
lay</xex> may be used when there is special reference to the
position of the object.</usage>

<hw>Put</hw> <pr>(put; <it>often</it> p<ucr/t <it>in def.</it>
3)</pr>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To go or move; <as>as,
when the air first <ex>puts</ex> up</as>.</def>
<mark>[Obs.]</mark>

<au>Bacon.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To steer; to direct one's course; to go.</def>

<q>His fury thus appeased, he <qex>puts</qex> to land.</q>
<qau>Dryden.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To play a card or a hand in the game called
<xex>put</xex>.</def>

<cs><col>To put about</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to change
direction; to tack.</cd> -- <col>To put back</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to turn back; to return. \'bdThe French .
. . had <xex>put back<xex> to Toulon.\'b8 <au>Southey</au>.</cd>
-- <col>To put forth</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To shoot, bud, or
germinate</cd>. \'bdTake earth from under walls where nettles
<xex>put forth<xex>.\'b8 <au>Bacon</au>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To
leave a port or haven, as a ship.</cd> <au>Shak.</au></cd> --
<col>To put in</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to enter a harbor;
to sail into port.</cd> -- <col>To put in for</col>. <sd>(a)</sd>
<cd>To make a request or claim; as, <xex>to put in for<xex> a
share of profits</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To go into covert; --
said of a bird escaping from a hawk</cd>. <sd>(c)</sd> <cd>To
offer one's self; to stand as a candidate for</cd>.
<au>Locke</au>.</cd> -- <col>To put off</col>, <cd>to go away; to
depart; esp., to leave land, as a ship; to move from the
shore.</cd> -- <col>To put on</col>, <cd>to hasten motion; to
drive vehemently.</cd> -- <col>To put over</col>
<fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to sail over or across.</cd> -- <col>To
put to sea</col> <fld>(Naut.)</fld>, <cd>to set sail; to begin a
voyage; to advance into the ocean.</cd> -- <col>To put up</col>.
<sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To take lodgings; to lodge</cd>. <sd>(b)</sd>
<cd>To offer one's self as a candidate</cd>.
<xex>L'Estrange<xex>.</cd><-- put up or shut up --> -- <col>To
put up to</col>, <cd>to advance to. <mark>[Obs.]</mark> \'bdWith
this he <xex>put up to<xex> my lord.\'b8 <au>Swift</au>.</cd> --
<col>To put up with</col>. <sd>(a)</sd> <cd>To overlook, or
suffer without recompense, punishment, or resentment; <as>as,
<ex>to put up with<ex> an injury or affront</as></cd>.
<sd>(b)</sd> <cd>To take without opposition or expressed
dissatisfaction; to endure; as, <xex>to put up with<xex> bad
fare.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pu*tred"i*nous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.

<hw>Pu`tre*fac"tion</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>putrefactio</ets>: cf. F. <ets>putr\'82faction</ets>. See
<er>Putrefy</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>The act or the process
of putrefying; the offensive decay of albuminous or other
matter.</def>

<note><hand/ Putrefaction is a complex phenomenon involving a
multiplicity of chemical reactions, always accompanied by, and
without doubt caused by, bacteria and vibriones; hence,
putrefaction is a form of fermentation, and is sometimes called
<xex>putrefaction fermentative</xex>. Putrefaction is not
possible under conditions that preclude the development of living
organisms. Many of the products of putrefaction are powerful
poisons, and are called <xex>cadaveric poisons</xex>, or
<xex>ptoma\'8bnes</xex>.</note>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The condition of being putrefied; also, that
which putrefied.</def> \'bd<xex>Putrefaction's</xex> breath.\'b8

<au>Shelley.</au>

<hw>Pu`tre*fac"tive</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf.
<ets>putr\'82factif</ets>. See <er>Putrefy</er>.]</ety>
<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to putrefaction; <as>as, the
<ex>putrefactive</ex> smell or process</as>.</def>

<au>Wiseman.</au>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Causing, or tending to promote,
putrefaction.</def>

-- <wordforms><wf>Pu``tre*fac"tive*ness</wf>,
<pos>n.</pos></wordforms>

<hw>Pu"tre*fy</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <altsp>[Written
also <ets>putrify</ets>.]</altsp> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Putrefied</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Putrefying</er> <pr>(<?/)</pr>.]</wordforms>
<ety>[F. <ets>putr\'82fier</ets>; L. <ets>putrere</ets> to be
rotten + <ets>-ficare</ets> (in. comp.) to make; cf. L.
<ets>putrefacere</ets>. See <er>Putrid</er>, and
<er>-fy</er>.]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>To render putrid; to cause
to decay offensively; to cause to be decomposed; to cause to
rot.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To corrupt; to make foul.</def>

<q>Private suits do <qex>putrefy</qex> the public good.</q>
<qau>Bacon.</qau>

<q>They would but stink, and <qex>putrefy</qex> the air.</q>
<qau>Shak.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To make morbid, carious, or gangrenous; <as>as,
to <ex>putrefy</ex> an ulcer or wound</as>.</def>

<hw>Pu"tre*fy</hw>, <pos>v. i.</pos> <def>To become putrid; to
decay offensively; to rot.</def>

<au>Isa. 1. 6.</au>

<hw>Puz"zle</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[For
<ets>opposal</ets>, in the sense of problem. See <er>Oppose</er>,
<er>Pose</er>, <pos>v.<pos>]</ety> <sn>1.</sn> <def>Something
which perplexes or embarrasses; especially, a toy or a problem
contrived for testing ingenuity; also, something exhibiting
marvelous skill in making.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>The state of being puzzled; perplexity; <as>as,
to be in a <ex>puzzle</ex></as>.</def>

<hw>Puz"zle</hw>, <pos>v. t.</pos> <wordforms>[<pos>imp. & p.
p.</pos> <er>Puzzled</er> <pr>(?)</pr>; <pos>p. pr. & vb.
n.</pos> <er>Puzzling</er> <pr>(?)</pr>.]</wordforms> <sn>1.</sn>
<def>To perplex; to confuse; to embarrass; to put to a stand; to
nonplus.</def>

<q>A very shrewd disputant in those points is dexterous in
<qex>puzzling</qex> others.</q>
<qau>Dr. H. More.</qau>

<q>He is perpetually <qex>puzzled</qex> and perplexed amidst his
own blunders.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To make intricate; to entangle.</def>

<q>They disentangle from the <qex>puzzled</qex> skein.</q>
<qau>Cowper.</qau>

<q>The ways of Heaven are dark and intricate,
<qex>Puzzled</qex> in mazes, and perplexed with error.</q>
<qau>Addison.</qau>

<sn>3.</sn> <def>To solve by ingenuity, as a puzzle; -- followed
by <xex>out</xex>; <as>as, to <ex>puzzle</ex> out a
mystery</as>.</def>

<syn>Syn. -- To embarrass; perplex; confuse; bewilder; confound.
See <er>Embarrass</er>.</syn>

bewildered, or perplexed.</def>

<q>A <qex>puzzling</qex> fool, that heeds nothing.</q>
<qau>L'Estrange.</qau>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>To work, as at a puzzle; <as>as, to
<ex>puzzle</ex> over a problem</as>.</def>

<hw>\'d8Py*\'91"mi*a</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[NL.,
fr. Gr. <?/ pus + <?/ blood.]</ety> <fld>(Med.)</fld> <def>A form
of blood poisoning produced by the absorption into the blood of
morbid matters usually originating in a wound or local
inflammation. It is characterized by the development of multiple
abscesses throughout the body, and is attended with irregularly
recurring chills, fever, profuse sweating, and exhaustion.</def>

pertaining to py\'91mia; of the nature of py\'91mia.</def>

<hw>Pyc"no*dont</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/

<def>Any fossil fish belonging to the Pycnodontini. They have

<hw>\'d8Pyc`no*don"ti*ni</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL.]</ety> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>An extinct order of

<hw>Pyc*nog"o*nid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>\'d8Pyc`no*gon"i*da</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n. pl.</pos>
<ety>[NL., fr. Gr. <?/ thick crowded + <?/ knee.]</ety>
<fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld> <def>A class of marine arthropods in which
the body is small and thin, and the eight legs usually very long;
-- called also <altname>Pantopoda</altname>.</def>

<note><hand/ The abdomen is rudimentary, and the triangular mouth
is at the end of a tubular proboscis. Many of them live at great
depths in the sea, and the largest of them measure two feet
across the extended legs.</note>

<hw>Pyc*nom"e*ter</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[Gr. <?/
dense, compact + <ets>-meter</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Physics)</fld>
<def>A specific gravity bottle; a standard flask for measuring
and comparing the densities of liquids.</def> <altsp>[Also
written <asp>pyknometer</asp>.]</altsp>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pyg"my</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <hw>Pyg*me"an</hw>

<cs><col>Pygmy antelope</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
kleeneboc.</cd> -- <col>Pygmy goose</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>any species of very small geese of the genus
<spn>Nettapus</spn>, native of Africa, India, and Australia.</cd>
-- <col>Pygmy owl</col> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>, <cd>the
gnome.</cd> <col>Pygmy parrot</col></mcol> <fld>(Zo\'94l.)</fld>,
<cd>any one of several species of very small green parrots
(<spn>Nasitern\'91</spn>), native of New Guinea and adjacent
islands. They are not larger than sparrows.</cd></cs>
<-- <col>Pygmy chimpanzee</col>, a species of anthropoid ape
(<spn>Pan paniscus</spn>) resembling the chimpanzee, but somewhat
smaller; also called <altname>bonobo</altname>.  It is considered
(1996) as having the closest genetic relationship to humans of
any other animal.  It is found in forests in Zaire, and is an
endangered species. -->

<hw>Pyg"my</hw>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl. <plw>Pygmies</plw>
<pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[L. <ets>pygmaeus</ets>, Gr. <?/, fr.
<?/ the fist, a measure of length, the distance from the elbow to
the knuckles, about 131 inches. Cf. <er>Pugnacious</er>,
<er>Fist</er>.]</ety> <altsp>[Written also
<asp>pigmy</asp>.]</altsp> <sn>1.</sn> <fld>(Class. Myth.)</fld>
<def>One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the
cranes, and were destroyed.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <def>Hence, a short, insignificant person; a
dwarf.</def>

<--3. one of a race of short forest-dwelling African peoples. -->

<q><qex>Pygmies</qex> are <qex>pygmies</qex> still, though
perched on Alps.
And pyramids are pyramids in vales.</q>
<qau>Young.</qau>

<hw>Pyr"a*mid</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pyramis</ets>, <ets>-idis</ets>, fr. Gr. <?/, <?/, of
Egyptian origin: cf. F. <ets>pyramide</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>A solid body standing on a triangular, square,
or polygonal base, and terminating in a point at the top;
especially, a structure or edifice of this shape.</def>

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <def>A solid figure contained by a
plane rectilineal figure as base and several triangles which have
a common vertex and whose bases are sides of the base.</def>

<sn>3.</sn> <pluf>pl.</pluf> <fld>(Billiards)</fld> <def>The game
of pool in which the balls are placed in the form of a triangle
at spot.</def> <mark>[Eng.]</mark>

<-- financial scheme -->

<cs><col>Altitude of a pyramid</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>, <cd>the
perpendicular distance from the vertex to the plane of the
base.</cd> -- <col>Axis of a pyramid</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld>,
<cd>a straight line drawn from the vertex to the center of the
base.</cd> -- <col>Earth pyramid</col>. <fld>(Geol.)</fld>
<cd>See <cref>Earth pillars</cref>, under <er>Earth</er>.</cd> --
<col>Right pyramid</col> <fld>(Geom.)</fld> <cd>a pyramid whose
axis is perpendicular to the base.</cd></cs>

<hw>Py*ram`i*dal</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pyramidal</ets>.]</ety>

<sn>1.</sn> <def>Of or pertaining to a pyramid; in the form of a
a pyramid; pyramidical; <as>as, <ex>pyramidal</ex>
cleavage</as>.</def>

<q>The mystic obelisks stand up
Triangular, <qex>pyramidal</qex>.</q>
<qau>Mrs. Browning.</qau>

<-- p. 1169 -->

<sn>2.</sn> <fld>(Crystallog.)</fld> <def>Same as
<er>Tetragonal</er>.</def>

<cs><col>Pyramidal numbers</col> <fld>(Math.)</fld>, <cd>certain
series of figurate numbers expressing the number of balls or
points that may be arranged in the form of pyramids. Thus 1, 4,
10, 20, 35, etc., are <xex>trangular pyramidal numbers<xex>; and
1, 5, 14, 30, 55, etc., are <xex>square pyramidal
numbers<xex>.</cd></cs>

<hw>Pyr"i*dine</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[From Gr.
<?/ fire.]</ety> <fld>(Physiol. Chem.)</fld> <def>A nitrogenous
base, <chform>C5H5N</chform>, obtained from the distillation of
bone oil or coal tar, and by the decomposition of certain
alkaloids, as a colorless liquid with a peculiar pungent odor. It
is the nucleus of a large number of organic substances, among
which several vegetable alkaloids, as nicotine and certain of the
ptoma\'8bnes, may be mentioned. See <er>Lutidine</er>.</def>

<hw>Pyr"i*dyl</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyrid</ets>ine + <ets>-yl</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A hypothetical radical,
<chform>C5H4N</chform>, regarded as the essential residue of
pyridine, and analogous to phenyl.</def>

<hw>Pyr"i*form</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos> <ety>[L.
<ets>pyrum</ets>, <ets>pirum</ets>, a pear + <ets>-form</ets>:
cf. F. <ets>pyriforme</ets>, <ets>piriforme</ets>.]</ety>
<def>Having the form of a pear; pear-shaped.</def>

<hw>Pyr`i*ta"ceous</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>Of or pertaining to pyrites. See
<er>Pyritic</er>.</def>

<hw>Pyr"ite</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>; <plu>pl.
<plw>Pyrites</plw> <pr>(#)</pr></plu>. <ety>[Cf. F.
<ets>pyrite</ets>. See <er>Pyrites</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>A common mineral of a pale brass-yellow color and brilliant
metallic luster, crystallizing in the isometric system; iron
pyrites; iron disulphide.</def>

<q>Hence sable coal his massy couch extends,
And stars of gold the sparkling <qex>pyrite</qex> blends.</q>
<qau>E. Darwin.</qau>

<hw>Py*ri"tes</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos> <ety>[L., fr. Gr.
<?/, fr. <?/ fire. See <er>Pyre</er>.]</ety> <fld>(Min.)</fld>
<def>A name given to a number of metallic minerals, sulphides of
iron, copper, cobalt, nickel, and tin, of a white or yellowish
color.</def>

<note><hand/ The term was originally applied to the mineral
pyrite, or iron pyrites, in allusion to its giving sparks when
struck with steel.</note>

<cs><col>Arsenical pyrites</col>, <cd>arsenopyrite.</cd> --
<col>Auriferous pyrites</col>. <cd>See under
<er>Auriferous</er>.</cd> -- <col>Capillary pyrites</col>,
<cd>millerite.</cd> -- <col>Common pyrites</col>, <cd>isometric
iron disulphide; pyrite.</cd> -- <col>Hair pyrites</col>,
<cd>millerite.</cd> -- <col>Iron pyrites</col>. <cd>See
<er>Pyrite</er>.</cd> -- <col>Magnetic pyrites</col>,
<cd>pyrrhotite.</cd> -- <col>Tin pyrites</col>,
<cd>stannite.</cd> -- <col>White iron pyrites</col>,
<cd>orthorhombic iron disulphide; marcasite. This includes
cockscomb pyrites (a variety of marcasite, named in allusion to
its form), spear pyrites, etc.</cd> -- <mcol><col>Yellow</col>,
<or/ <col>Copper</col>, <col>pyrites</col></mcol>, <cd>the
sulphide of copper and iron; chalcopyrite.</cd></cs>

<mhw>{ <hw>Pyro-</hw>, <hw>Pyr-</hw>  }</mhw>. <ety>[Gr. <?/,

<hw>Pyr`o*a*ce"tic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyro-</ets> + <ets>acetic</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pyroac\'82tique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, and designating, a substance (acetone)
obtained by the distillation of the acetates. It is now called
also <altname>pyroacetic ether</altname>, and formerly was called
<altname>pyroacetic spirit</altname>.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*ac"id</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>An acid obtained by sybjecting another
acid to the action of heat. Cf. <er>Pyro-</er>.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*an`ti*mo"nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pyr`o*ar"se*nate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pyr`o*ar*sen"ic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<hw>Pyr`o*bo"rate</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pyr`o*bo"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>

<altname>tetraboric</altname> acid), which is the acid ingredient
of ordinary borax, and is obtained by heating boric acid.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*cat"e*chin</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyro-</ets> + <ets>catechu</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>A white crystalline substance,
<chform>C6H4(OH)2</chform>, of the phenol series, found in
various plants; -- so called because first obtained by
distillation of gum <xex>catechu</xex>. Called also
<altname>catechol</altname>, <altname>oxyphenol</altname>.
etc.</def>

<hw>Pyr"o*chlore</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyro-</ets> + Gr. <?/ pale green.]</ety>
<fld>(Min.)</fld> <def>A niobate of calcium, cerium, and other
bases, occurring usually in octahedrons of a yellowish or
brownish color and resinous luster; -- so called from its
becoming grass-green on being subjected to heat under the
blowpipe.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*cit"ric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyro-</ets> + <ets>citric</ets>: cf. F.
<ets>pyrocitrique</ets>.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>Pertaining to, or designating, any one of three acids
obtained by the distillation of citric acid, and called
respectively <altname>citraconic</altname>,
<altname>itaconic</altname>, and <altname>mesaconic</altname>
<it>acid.</it></def>

<hw>Pur"o*coll</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Puro-</ets> + Gr. <?/ glue.]</ety> <fld>(Chem.)</fld>
<def>A yellow crystalline substance allied to pyrrol, obtained by
the distillation of gelatin.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*e*lec"tric</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyro-</ets> + <ets>electric</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, or dependent on,
pyroelectricity; receiving electric polarity when heated.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*e*lec"tric</hw>, <pos>n.</pos> <fld>(Physics)</fld>
<def>A substance which becomes electrically polar when heated,
exhibiting opposite charges of statical electricity at two
separate parts, especially the two extremities.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*e`lec*tric"i*ty</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>
<fld>(Physics)</fld> <def>Electricity developed by means of heat;
the science which treats of electricity thus developed.</def>

<hw>Pyr`o*gal"late</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>n.</pos>

<hw>Pyr`o*gal"lic</hw> <pr>(?)</pr>, <pos>a.</pos>
<ety>[<ets>Pyro-</ets> + <ets>gallic</ets>.]</ety>
<fld>(Chem.)</fld> <def>Pertaining to, derived from, or
